FELIX SANCHEZ, THE MURDERER, ARRESTED IN NEW-ORLEANS.--A telegraphic dispatch was received yesterday morning, from New-Orleans, by the acting Police Superintendent CARPENTER, announcing the arrest in that city of FELIX SANCHEZ, accused of murdering his father-in-law, HARMON CURNAN, on the 6th of January last.

OUR MUNICIPAL MACHEATH.--In the opening chapter of DICKENS' new story, which, we may be pardoned for mentioning in a paronthesis, is in as fresh, vigorous and elastic a spirit as any of his earlier works, he dashes in a few of the characteristic events of the period at which the action commences,

Like most other great international conflicts, the approaching collision between France and Austria has a double origin. It has been brought about in the first place by the operation of certain recognized causes of which diplomacy can take cognizance, and which will constitute the ostensible ground of war;

In my letter by overland mail of the 8th I stated that the clipper ship Moonlight, Captain BRECK, just arrived from New-York, reported the burning at sea of the New-York ship Manitou. Since then facts have come to light which lead to the belief that it was not the Manitor which burned.

Pursuant to a call, signed by some of the leading members of the Bar, a meeting of members of the profession was convened in the Circuit Court-room New City Hall, to express the general feeling, of regret at the death of the late distinguished NICHOLAS HILL, Esq.

We sing MORTON, the man of mud I While tarbarrels are cheap and the emptying of strawbeds abound, let us illuminate the City in his honor, and meanwhile rehearse what he has done for all trades and men.

Senator WILSON publishes a second letter on the proposed amendment to the Massachusetts Constitution, which will require naturalized voters to wait two years after naturalization. It is a reply to Mr. AMASA WALKER. The letter closes as follows: You say, my dear sir, we differ in opinion as to whether the Republicans outside of the State are opposed to this proposition.

By the arrival of the Coatzacoalcos we have Vera Cruz dates to May 1. Gen, RODLES, with 1,700 men, was at Jaiapa, and Gen, AMPUDIA, with 2,000 men, was eneamped before that city. JUARTZ had Issued a general exequatar to all American Consuls.

SERIOUS BREAK IN THE ERIE CANAL--DAMAGE $30,000--The Rochester Union, of 31 May, says: " The recent disasier to the Erie Canal at Holley was even greater than we had been led to suppose. We are happy to hear, however, that the loss of life had been over stated--but one man perished, although a number had a narrow escape.

TEN-MILE RACE AT HARTFORD.--The Springfield Republican says: One of the most attractive incidents on the 4th of May, at Hartford, was the great trot of ten miles at one pull between the horse Broker, of ANDEEW A. DALTON, of Springfield, and the "Rockdille mare," Lady Gilbert, owned by Mr. FARGO, of South Coventry, Conn.

ANNIVERSARY WEEK.--CONDITION OF THE STREETS.--The Anniversaries of our great benevolent institutions which are held this week, bring to New-York a good many thousand of strangers from every part of the Union, and a large number of visitors from Europe.

The City was favored on Saturday afternoon with one of the first fruits of the existing interregnum in the arrangements of the Associated Press with the Nova Scotian telegraphic lines.

THE CASE OF JUDGE VONDERSMITH IN PHILADELPHIA.--The Philadelphia Inquirer of the 6th, says: "Yesterday morning ex-Judge VONDERSMITH was brought up for sentence. Judge CADWALADER said but little about the case. He could not see one mitigating circumstance in it, and for the sake of his family he regretted it was so,.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I highly appreciate your practical and scientific article upon Boiler Explosions, in your issue this day. I think I have two theories of explosions which will satisfactorily explain the cause of most if not all explosions, and so materially narrow down "the field of probable causes," and also make known the remedies which are efficient in every case.

THE VOTES OF NATURALIZED CITIZENS.--Massachusetts holds a special election to-day, for the purpose of allowing the people to pass upon the "Two years' amendment, " so -called. That amendment is a proposed alteration of the State Constitution, to the effect that no alien who, subsequent to its adoption, shall declare his intentions,

THE FLORAL FESTIVAL.--This will be a gala week at Palace Garden--the object being a charitable one : the end, to obtain means whereby the full intentions of the same may be carried out. A few days since we referred to Mrs. PHELPS' scheme of establishing an institution on Long Island for young orphan girls.

The "Crawford House," in the White Mountain Notch, destroyed by fire April 30, was erected about nine years since, in the centre of a plateau 2,000 feet above the sea. The water flowed from it in both directions; in front there is a small lake which forms the head water of the Saco River. It is the third hotel destroyed by fire in the Notch within twenty years.

MY DEAR FRIEND: You ask my opinion in regard to the past action and the future course of the Oberlin prisoners, now in jail at Cleveland for violating the Fugitive Slave enactment. That measure was passed under the influence of threats and intimidation. Disunion and bloodshed were proclaimed as the alternative in case of refusal.

GROWING FEROCIOUS.--The Hon. J. R. GIDDINGS reverses the ordinary rule and grows more vehement and bloodthirsty with advancing years. He has written a letter on the Oberlin rescue, which surpasses in truculence any thing we have recently seen even from the most ultra of the Radical Abolitionists.

Very few persons will be found on this side of the water willing to maintain that the rule and the influence of Austria in Italy are otherwise than disgraceful to the character and dangerous to the peace of modern civilization.

The late hour on Friday night at which the mails by the Niagara reached this City precluded the publication, in our issue of Saturday, of all those details which can alone place the actual position of affairs in Europe in its appropriate light. We complete the record this morning by the addition of important extracts from English and Continental papers, illustrative of the crisis.

For a few weeks past the attention of the citizens of this place has been almost daily called to some fresh case of illegal cruelty practised on sailors, and in every case but one, I am ashamed to say, the offices have been committed by American officers on: American ships.

Among the passengers by the steamer, Ariel, on Saturday, for Southampton, was the Hon. WILLIAM H. SEWARD, who has gone on a visit to Europe to recruit his healthy, and, as he has publicly stated, in order to study the institutions and people of the Old World, that he may be the better prepared to labor for the benefit of his own native land.

The U.S. Frigael Sabine, and U. S. sloop-of-war Falmouth, were at Montevideo March 16, and would shall in a few days for the West Indies. Also, at Montevideo, same date, U. S. brigs Bainbridge, Perry and Dolphin; U. S. Elenmers Maclcomet and Atlanta repairing. The storeship Supply sailed March 10th for New-York 15, with loss of foretopmast and maintopgallant mast.

THE EASTERN TELEGRAPHS AND THE FOREIGN NEWS.--The Boston Journal Says: "It is proper to state that the contract of the Associated Press agent with the Nora Scotia line for the transmission of its dispatches, ceased on the first of May, and the agents of another association are at Halifax who propose to compete with the agent of the Associated Press in the transmission of the steamer's news.

The approaching exhibition of the Royal Academy infuses a special interest into Art, its works and wonder for the time being. The Rhadam??thi amateurs and connoisseurs are making their customary visits to the ateliers of academicians and associates, the former nibbling their pens in anticipation and the latter "taking notes," which they will introduce in their after-dinner talks "across the walnuts and the wine."

WM. SMITH O'BRIEN had a public reception in Toronto on the 3d May. In response to an address of welcome from Mr. J. G. MOYLAN, he made a speech of considerable length, After returning thanks for the cordiality of his reception, Mr. O'BRIEN said:

The French Emigrant System is, I think, abandoned in Liberian waters. Soon after the unfortunate fate of the ship Regina ??, it was circulated here that the French commodore of this station was on his way to bombard Monrovia. Many of the native tribes who are hostile to the Government hailed this news with great satisfaction. No definite intelligence has been received to give coloring to such a report.

NIBLO'S THEATRE.--A capital revival of the once famous drama of "Rob Roy" was effected here last night under the direction of Mr. EDDY. A CURIOUS CASE.--In March last, Mr. JOHN T. CLUB, of Hyde-Park, advertised a reward of $100 for the recovery of two trunks alleged to have been stolen from his residence. Yesterday a Detective Officer found two trunks, answering the description, in a house up town.

The Canadian screw steamship Anglo-Saxon, from Liverpool April 27, arrived at this port at an early hour this morning. The steamships Kangaroo and Alps, from New-York, arrived at Liverpool April 23, and the Persia, from New York, and the Nova Scotian, from Portland, on the 24th.

There is such information in Washington as to warrant the belief that the time of settlement of our affairs with Costa Rica is not far distant. So far the Water Witch and the Fulton are the only vessels to be sent to the Gulf of Mexico, and these cannot be Immediately dispatched, as they are previously to be overhauled and repaired at Norfolk.

DRINKING HYDRANTS-A resolution exceedingly refreshing for those hot May days was brought up in the Board of Conneilmen last evening. It has in view the placing five hundred drinking hydrands in the streets and squares of the City, and directs the Croton Board to furnish estimates forth with of the probable expense of the work.

YET ANOTHER NOMINATION FOR CITY INSPECTOR RETURNED TO THE MAYOR--DRINKING FOUNTAINS--LEGALITY OF THE ORGANIZATION OF THE BOARD OF SUPERVISORS--ADDITIONAL CLERKS FOR THE COMPTROLLER. At the meeting of the Board of Aldermen, last evening, a communication was received from the Mayor, nomination S. Benson McGown for City Inspector in place of Geo. W. Morton.

The Rahway (N. J.) Register says the Coachmakers' Association of that city have raised $T000 for the purpose of starting a manufactory of their own. This Association was formed by journey men coachmakers who, several weeks ago, turned out for wages, and not being able to come to terms with their employers, they have determined to go into business for themselves.

Political animosity remained in abeyance pending the affair with Spain, only to break out with renewed violence as soon as it was over. GUERRERO, with SANTA ANNA, and several other prominent Yorkinne, determined PRDRAZA should not occupy the Presidential chair. They immediately organized, a rebellion, which produced a wretched state of anarchy and bloodshed.

ANTI-RENT T0 BE REVIVED.--The Troy Whig states that many of the tenants in the AntiRent districts are disposed not to acquiesce In the recent decision of the Court of Appeals against them. Meetings have been called to consider the condition in which that decision has placed them, and in the language of the handbills, " to take an appeal to tile people."

Dr. ABBOTT, the collector of the valuable gallery of the Egyptian Antiquities, which for six years past has formed one of the prominent Art and Historical Associations of New-York, died on the 30th of March, at a village near Cairo, in Egypt. He was born in London, about forty-seven years ago, and, at the age of twenty-three, received the appointment as Surgeon on board a British man-or-war.

THE CENTRAL PARK.--We cannot forbear to call the attention of our readers to an instance of single-minded public spirit which, although it sounds "like stories from the land of spirits," did actually occur at yesterday's meeting of the Park Commissioners.

THE BERMER POISONING CASE.--Coroner HORDON commenced on Saturday to take testimony in the ease of MARY BERMER, who, it is alleged, died in February last from poison administered by her husband. Several witnesses were examined, when the case was adjourned to Tuesday next. It was ascertained after the adjournment that no poison had been found in the body of deceased, and the accused will probably be discharged on Tuesday.

The Pennsylvanian, Mr. BUCHANAN'S organ, asks in despair : " When are we to be consulted as an equal among the nations of the world? We answer, when the people demand statesmanship from their loaders, and national views as prerequisites for representative offices; when they cease to heed the miserable wrangling of local politicians;

WHEN DID HE DIE? -- The Herald, in an agony of apprehension, exclaims: "From what class can the Charleston Convention select? Where can they get a man that can unite the floating materials? There is no old solid statesman like Mr. Buchanan alive now."

The Royal Mail steamship Persia, which left Liverpool on the 30th ult., is now about due at this port. She brings details of the news telegraphed from St. Johns, as brought by the Adelaide, and published in yesterday's TIMES. The Kangaroo will probably arrive to-day. She brings details to the 27th ultimo.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--One of the most exquisite comic operas ever written, the "Ellsir d'Amore," will be played he'e to-night, with PICCOLOMINI as Adina, BRIGNOLI as Nemorina, and MAGGIOROTTI as Dulcamara. A novelty like this--for the opera is s?? seldom played that it really amounts to a novelty--with PICCOLOMINI in a new part, deserves a crowded house, and will undoubtedly obtain it.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: When ALEXIS DE TOCQUEVILLE died, France lost a great and good man. Born of the highest old nobility of his country, endowed with a genius grand, comprehensive, accurate, his nobleness of heart and justice of soul cast into comparative shade the brightest attributes of birth and intellect.

A YOUNG LAWYER SHOOTS HIMSELF.--Mr. FRANCIS J. Q. UMSTED, a young lawyer, who had an office in Wall-street, and who resided in Eighteenth-street, adjoining the Clarendon Hotel, shot himself yesterday morning with a revolver, but whether purposely or through accident, is unknown. The ball passed into the right ear, producing instant death.

Her relatives, and friends of the family, are respectfully invited to attend her funeral, this (Wednesday) afternoon, at 2 o'clock, from her late residence, No. 148 East 24th st.

The Boston papers of yesterday give the returns of about two-thirds of the vote on the question of the two-years' amendment, One hundred towns heard from comprise the heaviest portion of the vote of the State. The total vote in these towns was 19,382, of which 12,141 were cast In favor, and 7,241 against. Majority in favor, 4,000.

The Legislative Council or Upper House, which refused, last week, to consider the Supply bill, and thus all but caused a crisis, has repented of its determination and passed that indispensable measure. The members absent at the first vote came in for the second; hence the reversal. No sooner was this accomplished than his Excellency, the Governor, came down in state and proregued the Parliament.
Mr. VALENTINE'S Corporation Manual, for 1859--the eighteenth annual issue of a very valuable series--has just appeared. It excels the previous publications in many respects.
AMENDMENT OF THE MASSACHUSETTS STATE CONSTITUTION.--Contrary to general expectation the two years' amendment was approved by the popular vote of Massachusetts on Monday.

Elizabeth Raney, administrative, , vs. The Mayor, , of New-York -- The plaintiff sued the City under the act of the Legislature, as administration of her husband, who was severely injured in he First-avenue, between Twentieth and Twenty-first sts., by his cart wheel failing into a hole and pitching him out, so that he died four days afterward.

When men are excessively violent and vituperative, they are generally supposed to be in a bad way. Frantic vehemence usually springs from extreme desperation. Judged by this principle the ultra Abolitionists, now in session in this City, must be particularly hard pressed.

The contract for carrying the mail between New York and San Francisco, and New-Orleans and San Francisco via Nicaragua, connecting at Key West, has been awarded to DAMIEL H. JOHNSON, of New-York, at $162,000 for a semi-monthly service for nine months from the 1st of October.

OUR COMMON COUNCIL.--The Board of Aldermen is talking again about publishing their proceedings in newspapers which have some circulation. The project was discussed on Monday night, a Committee having reported in favor of contracting for advertisements in the for daily papers having the largest circulation.

The philosophers, falsely so called, who insist upon believing that the world is governed by an enlightened regard to its own interests, must find the Stock Exchanges of mankind a very puzzling set of institutions. Not once in ten years does it happen that a general fall in corporate securities upon these centres of purchase and sale can be traced to any clear or sufficient cause.

WHY THE COURIER WISHES MRS. HARTUNG HUNG.--The New-York Courier and Enquirer proposes an immediate decimation of the population. At least we infer as much from a statement made yesterday morning in the columns of that grave and grandiose journal.

GENTLEMEN: The first meeting of the Republican State Central Committee since I received your esteemed letter of the 6th inst., was held yesterday. I am not a member of that Committee, and obvious considerations of propriety restrain me from taking part in its consultations, unless specially invited to do so.

THE NATURALIZED VOTE.--Governor CHASE of Ohio, joins in the general Republican protest against the two years amendment proposed to the Massachusetts Constitution. He thinks it would create an unjust distinction between native and naturalized citizens, and would seriously injury the prospects of the Republican Party.

Mrs. SARAH WARREN, nec Judson, formerly of Michigan, who recently married her father's hired negro man, and is now living with her husband at Windsor, C. W., has written a letter to he Pontiac (Mich.) Gazette. She says: "I cannot listen longer to the atrocious falsehoods which the newspapers have originated, concerning my father, and keep silent.

THE FLORAL FETE AT PALACE GARDEN.--The remorseless rain put an extinguisher on the entertainments that were to have taken place, last night, in Palace Garden. Deterred by dread of cholle, cold bronchilis, or, as Mr. FRY says, "something of that sort," the people stayed at home.

MODEL REPORTING AND EDITING--We have enjoyed our laugh over the editorial antics of our Plum Glut neighbor, when dealing with matters foreign to navigation, and now our readers may share the sport. The poor old man of the Herald has been trying to get into respectable company o into, and so has sought to mix himself with the Tract Society matters.

METHODIST MISSIONS IN ARIZONA.--The Christian Advocate and Journal Publishes a letter from the Rev. D. TUTHILL, recently appointed Missionary to Arizona. Mr. TUTHILL writer from Tubas that his reception was by no means flattering, though respectful. An inquiry into the character of the population, however, readily explained any absence of enthusiasm.

The report that Senator GREEN is endeavoring to reconclue the differences in the Democratic Party is entirely a fabrication. His business here is entirely of a private character. The Royal Mail steamship Persia. Captain GODKINS which called from Liverpool at 8 1/2 o'clock on the morning of the 30th April, arrived here yesterday morning. The screw steamship Kangaroo, Captain JEFFREY, which called from Liverpool at 3 o'clock on the afternoon of the 25th ult., also arrived here a few hours previous to the Persia.

The arrival of the Liverpool steamships Persia and Kangaroo at this port, yesterday morning, supplies us with details of European news for the week ending on the morning of April 30. It will be remembered that the decisive and official statement of the fact that the Austrians had invaded Sardinia was forwarded from Paris to the Adelaide, which left Galway on the evening of that day, some hours after the departure of the Persia.

PALMETTO AGRICULTURE.--IMPORTATION OF STOCK.--The "Black Oak Agricultural Society" of South Carolina, at a recent meeting adopted resolutions setting forth "the great need of negro labor" in that State, and requesting the Legislature to take such steps as will induce Congress to repeal the law prohibiting the African Slave trade.

LOOKWOOD.--In this City. on Sunday morning, May 8, of consumption. ELIZA WELLS, wife of Charles Lookwood, aged 30 years. The funeral will take place on Thursday afternoon at 1 o'clock, from her late residence. No. 61 Lexington av. ?? Boston and Newburgh papers ??. TYLER--In this City, on Tuesday, May 10, Mrs. CHRISTOPHER ?? aged 36 years. 6 years.

THE PALACE GARDEN FESTIVAL--Yesterday evening the rain, which had been uncertain enough throughout the day, degenerated into a mizzle, and the Palace Garden fite, which had been unpromising enough all day, degenerated into a fizzle. This melancholy result, however, is not attributable to the public, but to the weather, which, in this free country where the people rule, is almost the only thing not supposed to be regulated by the will of the majority.

A JOB'S COMFORTER.--The Pennsylvanian wails bitterly over the obstinacy of papers like the TIMES, which will not be persuaded to praise the President. This drab-colored defender of an afflicted Chief Magistrate thinks that the President deserves sympathy and support as a more matter of compassion.

Although the Persia and the Kangaroo yesterday arrived at this port, bring us the most disastrous intelligence from the London Stock Exchange which has crossed the Atlantic for many a year, there is not one feature in all their news which, on a calm examination at this distance of time and space, appears to offer anything like a serious warrant for the fearful effects it had produced.

The U. S. District Court at Prove City adjourned on Monday last, the 4th inst, after a session of nearly four weeks. This past besion of the Court has been of unusual interest, and has formed one of the most important events in the history of our country.

The excitement in our market continues to increase, and prices show a further advance. FLOUR is in good demand for home interior, Eastern and Canadian trade, sales 100 bbls. WHEAT 30@50. higher, with an active demand; sales 15,000 husles, at $1 43 for Milwaukee club; $1 63$1 70 for red winter Illlnois, including 2,000 bushels white Canadian on Private terms.

HUTCHINSON.--In this City, on Wednesday, May 11, EMILY, daughter of James and Margaret B. Hutchinson, in the 27th year of her age. The funeral will take place this (Friday) afternoon, at 4 o'clock, from the 18th-st M. E. Church. The friends and acquaintances of the family are respectfully invited to attend.

THE LATE CHERRY-STREET STABBING CASE.--Bridget Freeman, the woman who was stabbed a few evenings since at No.24 Cherry-street, by John JOYCE, a tailor, died late on Wednesday evening at the City Hospital. Joyce, his wife, mother and the deceased were in a room together, when a dispute arose between the deceased and Joyce's mother.

The Administration organs have been planing their favorite air of "Hall toe the chief" with extraordinary fervor, ever since the Mormon leaders kindly resolved to overlook the impertinence of the Federal Governments, and consented to conclude a peace with the United States.

AN ALDERMANIC EXPERIMENT.--The Board of Aldermen passed a resolution last night, for the purpose of testing their right to make contracts authorizing the removal of the Russ

QUARTERLY REPORT OF THE DEPUTY SUPERINTENDENT OF POLICE.--Deputy Superintendent of Police Folk, reports 3, 602 arrests during the quarter ending the 1st instant, being 234 more arrests than during the previous quarter. The force under his command, all told, 15,245 when classified as follows: 6 Captains, 29 Sergeants, 167 Patrolmen, 15 Doormen, 25 detailed men.

In the bustle of the Anniversaries, the excitement incident to the recent news from Europe, and the pertinacity of the northeast "May storm," the arrival home of Mr. PAUL MORPHY has passed alm st unrecorded. Mr. MORPHY arrived in the Persia on Wednesday morning.

The following property, understood to belong to Mr. POTTER, was sold to-day by Mr. A. H. MULLEN. One on the southwest corner of First-avenue and Forty-eighth-street, $1 230; one adjoining on the avenue $750. Next two $630 each. All T. FARLEY. Two lots on the east side of second, 75 feet 4 inches south of Forth-ninth-street.

CONDITION OF THE INDIAN TRIB .S.--Major VACGHAN, United States Agent for the Blackfeet Indians, has arrived at St. Louis from Fort Benton. He reports that peace prevailed among the Indians; the region being inhabited by the Gros Ventres, Ass??nes, Black feet, Crows, Arickarees, Mandans and Sioux. There had been more than the usual number of Buffalo in the Blackfeet country, and the trading houses had done an excellent business. .

To the Editor of the New-York Times: You will confer a favor on me and serve the ends of justice by inserting in your widely-road columns a brief statement in reply to the card of Mr. THOMAS BRENNAN, published in your' issue of this morning.

The Mexican news received in New-Orleans by the arrival of the Tennessce, from Vera Cruz, is quit interesting. Matters at the Capital seem to be in the utmost confusion. It was believed that another change in the centralist Government would soon take place, MIRAMON probably giving way to ZULOA.G Attempts were being made to effect a loan on a pledge of the Church property.

Montgomery ; Captain, A.S Baldwin ; Lieutenant,s, Henry Rolando, william G. Temple, W. W, Captain of Marines, John C. Grayson.

In the case of Bradbury and Evans as, Dickens and Wills, Mr. Jesse applied on the 20th April to the Master of the Rolls for leave to serve notice of motion for the 21st, to advance the hearing of this cause on account of the depreciation which the copyright of a work like Household Worlds would undergo if the able were celayed for any considerable time.

The announcement of the decease of DENISON OLMSTED, LL. D., late Professor of Natural Philosophy and Astronomy in Yale College, will be received with feelings of profound regret by the thousands of his pupils scattered all over the land. Prof. OLMSTER was born at East Hartford, connecticut, June 18, 1791. His father, was a farmer, and died while his son was but a year old.

In another part of this paper we publish an article translated from the Paris Constitutionnel on the Asiatic development of the Russian Empire, which curiously illustrates at once the movement of events since 1815, and the effects produced upon the mind of France by the ill-ordered and abusive course which some of the London journal have pursued with regard to the French Emperor and France, over since the explosion of January, 1858.

Before Justices Roorevelt Inkraham and Pratt Wm. B. Buil vs. Milliss Ayers.--This is an interesting case growing out of the great pante of 1857. The defendants were one of the largest houses in the Notingham lace trade. the same persons composed the firm of Melliss Ayers in New York, and Ayers Mellis in Nottingham.

Some curious developments of family history have recently been made public in Massachusetts, in contested will cases. In the Supreme Court at Boston, a few days ago, the will of WILLIAM STABBS, of that city, was set aside on the ground of undue influence of the wife; the contestants being GEORGE LILLY and wife, the son-in-law and daughter of testator.

NEWSPAPER ENTERPRISE IN THE WEST.--We observe that the Cincinnati Commercial, in addition to its regular Telegraphic Reports, received in common with other dailies, from the Associated Press, maintains in this City and in St. Louis an independent organization for reporting and telegraphing the latest commercial and general news for its own exclusive use.

The Fifth Report of the British PostmasterGeneral has just been Issued. The view It presents of the working of the Cheap-postage system, and of the constantly enlarged facilities afforded the English public for the transmission, not only of mail-matter proper, but of money and of books, is in the highest degree Interesting, and fertile In lessons to those who control the corresponding branch of affairs In this country. Indeed, no argument

The newly organized Board met yesterday afternoon. All the Commissioners were present including the two Mayors. In secret session, patrolman James P. Boyle, who was dismissed several months since, was reinstated and sent to the Twenty-third Precinct.

The United States steam frigate Mississippi, on her way home from the East Indies, and the Lancaster, Wyoming and Levant, on their way out, will touch at the ports of Chill. In view of the unsettled condition of our relations with that Republic, the Administration has come to the conclusion that an exhibition of a portion of our naval force may have a good effect in hastening a settlement.

The great French Exhibition of Fine Arts opened to the public on Friday last. The exhibition is held in the Crystal Palace of the Champs Elysdes, as on former occasions, and finds in this spacious building, notwithstanding the immense number of objects exposed, more than ample room.

The failure of Congress, at its late session, to make the usual appropriations for the Post Office Department, has induced the Postmaster-General to scrutinize the service, with a view to discontinue all that may be dispensed with without material injury to the public convenience.

The great prize fight came off yesterday. The origin of the match we could not ascertain, but the time was set for 1 o'clock P. M., and the place the Abbey track, and after 12 M. the corner of Fifth and Green was alive with the fancy. About 12:15 a start was effected, and the "procession" moved toward the field of battle.

The World Before the Flood. POPULAR GEOLOGY: A Series of Lectures by MUGH MILLER, Boston; GOULD LINCOLN, 1859. Thank Heaven for HUGH MILLER for the noble specimen of mankind that he was; for another solution in his career of the problem--a profound scholar with a big poetic heart growing up in a field of physical labor beside which Paul's seems like needlework and even BURRITT's gentle.

There is a rumer afloat that Mr. BUCHANAN is about to avail himself of the war in Europe to effect a change in the Ministers representing as at all the European courts. Our readers may remember that it was announced immediately after his election that he was about to oust all our Ambassadors, and put more needly Democrats in their places, in recognition of the doctrine of rotation in office.

OSWEGO, Friday, May 13--6 P.M. FLOUR--Market firm with an active demand, partly speculative sales 2,500 bbls, at $6 from Chicago Spring Wheat, and $6 75@$7 from Milwaukee Club; included are 1,000 bbls, for Montreal. Our mills are grinding chiefly to supply the wants of the local, interior and Canadian trade, and none has been shipped for the New-York market.
ALLAIBE.--In this City, on Friday, May 13, after a protracted illness of disease of the heart, ANTHONY J. ALLATRE, aged 61 years.

JEAN BOSQUET AT SING SING.--The Italian "man-Monsier," as he has been designated, JEAN BOSQUAT, who killed the boy MAETINO SANTEZ, and subsequently stabbed a follow-prisoner soventeen times with a fork, was sentensed, as has been already stated, one week since, by Judge Davies, to hard labor for life in the State Prison, on his own plea of manslavghier in the first degree, the indletment against him being for murder.

I have argued that the question of emanelpation in the British West Indies, or in Barbadoes, which is under special consideration, is a commercial question and must be determined by a commercial standard.

THE OBERLIN RESCUE TRIALS.-BUSHNELL the first one tried of the Oherlin rescuers, was sentenced on Thursday. The Court seems disposed to be lenient in respect to penalties in these cases, as, under all the circumstances, it is proper that it should be. Accordingly, the sentence of BUSHNELL is sixty days' imprisonment, and a fine of six hundred dollars.

A letter from Ontonagon, dated April 26, to the Detroit Free Press, says : "On Sunday night there was a fight at the Minnesota mine between the Cornishmen and Irishmen. An Irishman killed a Cornishman with an axe, cutting him across the small of the back, severing his kidneys in two.

THEHON, G. A. GROW, MEMBER OF CONGRESS, ON LAND REFORM. The Floral Fote at Palace Garden, In aid of the Horticultural School for females, which had been interrupted by the rains of Tuesday and Wednesday, was revived on Thursday evening, in all the glory of its perfumed beauties.

The United States Treasurer Reports the amount of cash on hand subject to draft as $869,000. In suspending several overland mail routes, ?? Post-office Department does not interfere with the great Overland Mail to California.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The readers of my response to the note of Messrs. DANIEL LORD, HIRAM KETCHUM, WM, H. ASPINWALL. JAMES BROWN, GREENE C. BRONSON and others, published in the TIMES of the 30th ultimo, must have observed that I carefully avoided all personalities.

GARDINER THOMPSON, of New-York to MANETTE, eldest daughter of J. L. Smallwood.

All the various grades of French officers, from a Marshal of France to the lowest subaltern, and of every conceivable corps, may now be seen in the streets of Lyons, preparing to follow the army already marched over the Mont Cents Pass.

A PERSONAL CONTROVERSY-O. JENNINGS WISE AND JOHN M. BOTTS. The political contest in Virginia has stirred up a great deal of bad blood. The personal controversies are becoming very spicy. The last specimen is a card issued by Mr. O. JENNINGS WISE, through the columns of his paper, the Richmond Enquirer, leveled at the Hon. JOHN M. BOTTS, and treating that distinguished gentlemen in the most disrespectful manner.

The officers of the Lake steamer Michigan having received orders from the Navy Department to confine their operations for the season to Lake Erie, Capt. E. B. Ward, of Detroit, addressed a letter to the Hon. Henry Ledyard, at Washington, wishing him to present the case to the Department, stating that it would be of great benefit to the lake marine if the steamer could be allowed to extend her operations.

A CHARMING COUNTRY FOR POLITICIANS.--Revolutionary epochs are not without their soft delights, and Tammany Hull can hardly offer such blandishments as would appear to be just now lavished at Naples on some of the King's Ministry.

Ex-Governor VROOM, lately Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary at the Court of Berlin, will probably be nominated as the Democratic candidate for Governor of New-Jersey. He denounces Mr. BUCHANAN, and, therefore, is popular with the Democracy.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: My attention has been called to an article in your paper of the 10th inst., headed, "No Verdict in the case of JAMES GLASS." In that article it is said that "the one dissenting juror, who is said to be a friend of the prisoner, would prevent their agreement for whatever length of time they are locked up."

Mr. Watson, the discoverer of the new cotnet writes from the Ann Arbor Observatory that the comet is moving from the earth and towards the sun, Its geocentrie distance is now sixty-six millions of miles, and its heliocentric distance eighty-eight millions seven hundred and seventy thousand miles.
ADDRESSES BY THE HON. WM. JESSUP, THE REV. GEO. W. WOOD, THE REV. C. C. BALDWIN, THE REV. BENJAMIN C. MEIGS, THE REV. HENRY SOUDDER, THE REV. JUSTIN PERKINS, AND THE REV. JAMES EELS.

SUDDEN ADDITION TO THE NATIONAL WEALTH, --There arrived yesterday at this port 8,7?? Immigrants, men, women and children, all of them from Northern Europe, and all of them belonging to the laboring classes, who are accustomer to hard work and frugal living, They were brought over in eight ships, seven of them being American.

The United States ship Portsmouth is being fitted out with utmost dispatch. It is rumored her destination has been changed, that she will immediately proceed to reinforce the Mediterranean squadron. We are flattered by the Secretary's selection, and doubt not the Portsmouth will sustain her well earned reputation as a fast smaller.

The death of Colonel Joseph Park, principal Chief of the Shawnee tribe of Indians, was recently noticed. He died in Kansas. The Detroit Tribune gives some interesting particulars of his life, He was once a resident of Michigan, and during the war of 1812, while his tribe was living in Northern Ohio, Joe was employed by the American officers as interpreter guide, and confidential express messenger.

The Commissioners of Health met, yesterday at the City Hall--present the Mayor, Dr. GUNN, Dr, ROOKWELL, dr. MILLER Alderman McSPADON and Councilman CORNILL. The Health Officer reported the arrival of the ship Constellation, from Liverpool, with passengers, several of whom were suffering from small pox. The Board directed that they be vaccinated and the ship laid up for five days for fumigation,

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR - Will you permit me through the columns of your valuable journal, to suggest to the Navy Department the propriety of affording protection to our citizens and commercial interests in the Mediterranean. The United States trade with Southern Europe is daily increasing.

A few rowdies so successfully disturbed the Woman's Rights meeting on Thursday night at Mozart Hall, that out of some 1,700 in attendance, who in an orderly house might have heard every word that was uttered from the platform, probably not five hundred were able to follow the speakers at all.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: A question just now of greater moment to the ladies than the fluctuations of the cotton market and the beginning of hostilities in Europe to the gentlemen. I say ladies, and mean thereby at once to crush the individual who would presumptuously suppose the gentlemen have anything to do with the matter.

THE FIRE DEPARTMENT.--By a recent act of the Legislature, provision was made for the organization of a Court of Appeals, with power to review the action of the Fire Department Commissioners in cases where a party feels aggrieved by their decision in any case brought before them. The fallowing named gentlemen have been elected to compose this Board in the Eastern District: D. D. Winant, D, II,

Yesterday morning the Seventh Biennial Session of the Southern Baptist Convention commenced its Session in the Fast Baptist Church in this City. In point of numbers, it is the largest Baptist Convention ever held in the United States, all the Southern, or Slave-holding, States being largely represented.

" La Favorita," the best of all Operas that DONIZETTI ever wrote, (and his invention and felicity are alike recognized by the world.) was played here last night, with tumultuous success. A magnificent distribution was bestowed on the Opera by Mr. STRAKOSEN, the active and libaral caterer of our present season.

A WOMAN NATURALIZED.--A German woman having recently applied for naturalization at Lancaster, Penn., a paper published in that place refers to the fact as something extraordinary, intimating that she must be "strong-minded" and inclined to vote.

ANOTHER CONFERENCE OF RAILROAD MANAGERS--Representative men from the several contending through lines between the seaboard and the West have been for the past few days at the St. Nicholas Hotel in this City, conforming with each other on the position and interests of the companies they respectively represent.

Official dispatches from Vern Cruz report that Mr. McLANE has arranged the basis of a treaty, by which we secure the right of way, from such point on the Rio Grande as the United States may selects to Guaytas; also, from Tubac, in Sonora, to any point on the Gulf of California we may designate.

The remorseless logic of events has brought us at last to a point in the pending European crisis, at which the blindest of obstinate halcyons must recognize the facts which for the last six months they have been steadily trying to ignore.

THOMPSON, Esq., who died at his residence in Newark, N. J., on the 8th inst. Mr. THOMPSON was admitted a member of the Society, July 4, 1842, in the night of his grandfather, ALEX. THOMPSON, and was elected Secretary July 4,

By way of Havana we receive files of Mexican papers, brought by the English steamer which left Vera Cruz on the 30th ult. We are thus supplied with details of the intelligence ten days later than were furnished by our last budget of journals and correspondence, still later news, however has reached its by telegraph from the Tennessee at New-Orleans.

To the Rev. C. L. Brace--DEAR SIR : When I called in question your statement, on the floor of the Reformatory Convention, in regard to the expense of providing for the beneficiaries of the Home of the Friendless, ou replied that you would prove the truth of your estimate at any proper time.

By the arrival of three European steamers at this port on Saturday and Sunday, we are placed in possession of profoundly interesting intelligence to the 3d inst. The Austrian troops passed the Sardinian frontier in the sight of the 29th ??, in three different bodies, amounting in the aggregate to 120,000 men.

If we are to infer the tendencies of English opinion in regard to the present, European war from the tone of the London Times, it is plain that our pugnacious cousins beyond the water are gradually working themselves up to the belief that England can only vindicate her position, and recover her just influenced as a great Power, by drifting into the conflict as the "def??cer" of Germany and of the "Treaties of 1815."

The Isthmus is very dull at present--gradually drawing towards the wet season. "El Tempo Aqua." The flag ship Roanoke paid a visit to Greytown, to see how the Brooklyn was riding outside of the harbor. The old Channel is reopening, and the new filling up. The original entrance has now 12 feet of water, and is increasing in depth.

ALLAIRE--In this City, on Friday, May 13, after a protracted Iliness of disease of the heart, ANTHONY J. ALLAIRE, aged 87 years. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, from his late residence, No. 109 Henry-st., on Monday, the 10th inst., at 9 o'clock A. M. His remains will be taken to New-Rochelle for Interment.

ARRIVAL OF THE PHILADELPHIA--THE HAVANA MARKETS--MORE SLAVE-CARGOES LANDED. United States Mail Steamship Philadelphia, G. HARRISON, commander, New-Orleans, May 5, for New-York, via Havana, at which port she arrived on the morning of the 8th, and sailed on the P. M. of same day for this port, where she arrived Saturday morning. The Philadelphia landed and transferred 88 passengers at Havana, and brings 129 passengers and a fair cargo for New-York.

THE SOUTHERN TRADE--The Southern Commercial Convention, assembled at Vicksburgh, Miss., is again rigidly confioing its attention to one find of commerce, and one only--the trade in negroes. The Slave-trade seems to be the staple topic of all the orators; but even this they steadily avoid treating with the smallest approach to practicability.

The screw steamship Adelaide, of the Galway Line, from Oalway on the evening of April 30, arrived at this port on Saturday afternoon. The screw steamship Weser, Captain CARTJEN, of the Diemen Line, and screw-steamship Borasia, Captain TEALTMANN. of hte Hamburga Line, both from on the 3d inst, arrived here in the afternoon of yesterday.

The U. S. Mail steamship Star of the West, Capt. GARY, arrived here on Saturday morning from Aspinwal on the 4th and Havana 9th May. She brings the California malls and specie shipment of April 20. On the 7th inst., in lat. 2128; lon. 81 48 the Star of the West passed U. S. storeship Relief standing to the north.

The steamship Arago passed Cape Race, and an abstract of her news, which was put on board a fishing boat by Captain LINES, has reached this port, The Arago has 140 passengers, She left Cowes on the evening of the 4th.

FLOUR active before the receipt of the Arago's news, and afterwards prices advanced 25c.@50c. on desirable brands, with a moderate demand; sales 3,000 bbls. at $6 75@$7 for extra Illinois; $7 25@$7 50 for do. Wisconsin; $7 50@$8 for good to choice extra Michigan and Indiana; $8 10@$8 50 for double extras. WHEAT excited; red Ohio advanced 5c ;

THE OBERLIN TRIALS.--The cases before the United States District Court at Cleveland are losing none of their interest. We have already mentioned the conviction and sentence of BUSHNELL and LANGSTON, the former to a $600 and costs, with sixty days' imprisonment, and the latter to $100 fine and costs. ts.

LOYED--In this City, on Monday, May 16, of a lingering illness, MARY E, daughter of Joseph and Mary Jane Loyed, aged 2 years, 11 months and 16 days. Funeral services on Wednesday, at 2 o'clock, at their residence, No. 170 West 30th-st. The relatives and friends are respectfully invited to attend.

If it were not for the excellent reputation which Mr. FALCONER'S comedy of the "Men of the Day, or Extremes" brings with it from the other side--a reputation that saved a management and established an author in the favor of the public--we might be disposed, at the late hour at which we write, to indulge man excessively condensed style of criticism, and describe the piece as an exceedingly long effort of clever talk.

DEMOCRATIC PREPARATIONS FOR 1860--The Washington States, a Democratic Journal, supposed to represent the DOUGLAS interest, has suffered some discomposure within the last few days from various rumors, to the effect "that certain prominent politicians are encaged in arranging the reorganization of the Democracy, with a view to the campaign of 1800," and it attributes such movements to a solicitude for certain personal interests.

SIR SAMUEL SLICK.--Judge HALLIBURTON, of Nova Scotia, better known as "Sam Slick, of Slickville," has been made a G. C. B., or something of that sort, by Queen VICTORIA, which will entitle him hereafter to be called "Sir Samuel."

The British yacht St. Ursula, Commander CATRNIE, arrived at his port on Sunday evening, at 8 1/2 o'clock, in 30 days from the Clyde, on a pleasure trip. ITALIANS IN AMERICA.--While the "Italian question" is passing the ordeal of arms and its possible solution occupies the minds of all liberal and thinking men in Europe and America, there is an obvious propriety as well as duty in the Italian exiles among us, giving expression to their sympathy and affording practical aid to their countrymen.

To COL., T. M. PATRIDGE.--Dear Sir: In response to your inquiry of this morning, whether I would be a candidate for Congress in this District, I gladly embrace the opportunity of answering numerous inquiries on this subject, by stating that I shall certainly not be a candidate. I have no ambition to participate prominently is such struggles as are likely to occur in Congress during the next two years.

THE PIKE'S PEAK DELUSION.--The reports from the new mining region, which, until lately, have been contradictory, now set with steady current in one direction. We hear nothing of gold, but much of disappointment, suffering and repentance. Miners are leaving in crowds. The speculation has exploded. Pike's Peak is no California.

In the morning Mr. Scorr, the Mayor's Secretary, was placed in charge, with some policemen, who had directions to let people pass in and out, but not to let any of the books and papers be disturbed.

" Don Glovanni" attracted a fine house, last night, in spite of the weather, which somehow always manages to be unpleasant whenever there is anything "classical" going on. The cast of the opera was certainly a justification of all the manager promised. PICCOLOMINI, as Zerlina, sang the music excellently, and acted with supreme naturalness.

WHAT HAS BECOME OF ALL THE CROAKERS?--In the whole course of our journalistic experience, we do not remember a time before the present when there have not been heard dismal croakings from the great grain-producing regions of damage to the crops, and predictions of a scarcity of our great staples.

A SMALL MISTAKE.--A correspondent, who declares himself to be a daily "reader of the TIMES," and adds the tautological assurance that he is "a lover of the truth," bitterly complains that we have violated the rules of " fair play" by withholding from the public Lord DERBY'S Address to the Electors of Buckinghamshire.

The Detroit Advertiser learns that seventy fugitive slaves lately arrived in Canada by one train from the interior of Tennessee, probably the largest number that ever escaped in one company. The week before, companies of twelve, seven and five were safety landed, making a total within about a week of ninety-four.

The steamship Canada from Liverpool on the afternoon of the 7th May, arrived at Halifax yesterday. The news is of interest. No general action had taken place between the belligerent forces. A portion of the Austrian army, however, had been repulsed in an attempt to pass the Po at Trassinatto.

When Mr. DISRAELI went out of his way in a speech before the British House of Commons to declare that Trieste was a German port, and that the Rhine might be attacked upon the Adriatic, he uttered words which were all the more dangerous that they wore neither original with himself nor fully intelligible to his hearers.

ARRIVAL OF THE QUAKER CITY--STATE OF THE MARKETS. The United States Mail Steamship Quaker City, R. W. SHUFELDT, Commander, left new-Orleans on the morning of the 12th inst. for new-York via Havana, at which port she arrived at 9 A. M. of the 14th, after a rapid run of forty-eight hours from city to city; left Havana evening of same day for this port and arrived at her wharf at 6 o'clock last evening.

By the arrival of the Tennessee at New-Orleans the mails have put us in possession of our correspondence from Vera Cruz to the 8th, and from the City of Mexico to the 2d of May. All regular communication between Vera Cruz and the capital has been stopped. so that our despatches were necessarily sent by private courier.

The Canada brings sad verification of the singular prophecy uttered a year since by Baron VON HUMBOLDT, in regard to the probable period of his own death. A remarkable presentiment that the year 1859 would be the end of his life, found casual expression, and has been fulfilled. Our dispatches this morning announce that the venerable savant expired at Berln, on Friday, May 6, in his 9lst year.

PANIC IN A PUBLIC SCHOOL.--Yesterday afternoon a panic seized the children in Public School No. 1, corner Concord and Adams streets, caused by a false alarm of fire, and had it not been for the coolness displayed by the Principal and teachers, must have resulted in the loss of life.

BOARD OF SUPERVISORS.--The Board met Tuesday afternoon at the usual hour. The Special Committee, on fitting up the chamber were authorized to expend #25 for a clock. A large number of bills were sent in. Among them was one amounting to $2.300 for advances to Deputy Superintendent of Police, for contingent expenses since Jan. 1, Referred to Committee on Criminal Courts.

For a twelvemonth and more the Administration men and the Douglasites of this State have been at swords' points. Their ware of words on what they style the paramount question of the times still continues with unabated fury. Nothing in the vacobulary of abuse is left amused by the contending factions. Their former bone of contention was Lecompton--their present bone is Squatter Sovereignty.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: My attention has just been called to a verbose article in your paper of the 6th ult., headed "Rank in the Navy," which appears to be an attempt to re-open the question of assimilated rank long since thoroughly discussed and definitely settled by abler men than the writer of that article shows himself to be.

SMITH O'BRIEN AT BOSTON.--It seems very difficult indeed for a foreigner to visit this country without meddling, to nobody's advantage and to his own hurt, with its internal affairs. Our guests from abroad scorn to take it for granted that because this is a free country, everybody is at perfect liberty to take a hand in tile regulation of its affairs.

There are miles of streets that are well built up, in both New York and Brooklyn, of which the houses are not numbered. This neglect causes a vast deal of unnecessary trouble. The death of Dr. DIONYSIUS LARUNER is announced in the additional foreign news which we publish this morning. The time and place of his decease are not mentioned, but the event is stated as having occurred in England. Dr. LARDNER'S age was 66. He was well known in this country, where he obtained an excellent reputation as a popular lecturer on Science, some eighteen years ago.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In your paper to-day, you make some comments upon the Southern Convention at Vicksburgh, and its breaking of law tendencies, its action being for the most part confined to the reopening of the Stave-Trade question. Your disgust at this law-breaking, and adhesion to the higher law is quite natural, and I would not dispute its sincerity.

THE STRET-CLEANING BUSINESS--The Mayor nominated another City Inspector last night, and the Aldermen rejected him. This farce has ceased to be amusing. It is not worth while for the Mayor to make any further demonstrations of the kind, and the Aldermen have certainly done quite enough to prove their own obstinacy in the matter.

The state in which the telegrams of the news by the Canada reaches us offers a valueable illustration of the truth that the most surprising inventions are of little use unless they are to be employed by men who know what they mean. As the intelligence from the seat of war reached us yesterday, it was a mass of blunders and mysteries,

Private detectives in this city were recently written to by Chicago parties to ferret out a man named Samuel Raymond, who was supposed to be living somewhere in the vicinity of this city, and who fled from Chicago last fall, where he had been guilty of a heavy robbery of a wholesale store, in which he had for some time been employed as a porter.

Gen. JAMES W. NYE and Mr. LEBBETS B. WARD late Commissioners of the Metropolitan Polices, were the recipients of a warm hospitality and friendly tender of personal good-will and political sympathy last night in the Actor House. The banquet was primarily the work of a number of the Police Captains, but readily evoked the support of many others low intimately concerned.

Additional telegraphic advices from the Canada at Halifax extend our information of the movement of events in Italy. The Austrian army had passed the Po at one or two points, and at Frasinetto had had a smart action with the Mlies, resulting disastrously for the invaders. The line of the Railroad from Trouzana to the Ticino was in their hands:

From the New-York L' Eco d' Italia. ADDRESS OF THE ITALIAN COMMITTEE OF NEW-YORK TO THE ITALIAN RESIDENTS IN AMERICA. Italy is rising once more to assert her independence. The national cause represented by the State of Sardinia, supported by the sympathy of all civilized people, and aided by France, ever the avant guard of European civilization, awakes to new life.

The Place Garden file in aid of Mrs. PHELPS' project for as horticultural school for girls was largely attended Tuesday evening. The arrangements were much better than on previous occasions, and the celebration, from beginning to end, was as felicitous as its most sanguine friends could wish. The Rev. Dr. BELLOWS delivered a clever address on "Woman."

The Express, with the Canada's news, reached here at 6 o'clock this morning. The R. M. steamship Canada left Liverpool at noon of Saturday, the 7th inst., and arrived at Halifax at about 10:30 A. M. yesterday. The steamship City of Baltimore, to sail from Liverpool on the 11th, would call the following day a' Queenstown for dispatches and First-cabin passengers,

LETTER FROM COMMISSIONER REED.--The following is the letter of the Hon WM. B. REED, late United States Commissioner to China, in reply to an Invitation to a public dinner, tendered by citizens of Philadelphia: PHILADEPHIA, May 13 1859. GENTLEMEN: I thank you for your kind words of welcome.

THAT'S THE WAY THE MONEY GOES.--Book editing for the Common Council is becoming a very profitable business for those engaged in it. Mr. VALENTINE, the Clerk of that body, has been In the habit for some years past of compiling and publishing the Corporation Manual. The book is a very valuable one in its way,

COMMISSIONERS OF EMIGRATION.--The Commis sioners of Emigration made a tour of inspection to Ward's Island Wednesday, starting from Castle Garden at noon bysteam-tug Dr. Kane. On reaching the Island they went through the various Institutions under the guidance of Capt. PILLSBURY, Superintendent. The different hospitals and buildings were uniformly well ventilated and thoroughly clean.

MEDICAL ENTERPRISE AND LIBERALITY.--Among the instances of professional devotion and liberality, for which medical men, with all their faults, are certainly to be credited, the late donation made by Dr. JACOB HARSON, of this City, an alumnus of the College of Physicians and Surgeons, is one of the most noticeable.

NEW STYLE ENVELOPES.--The Postmaster-General has under consideration the propriety of adopting in the preparation of stamped envelopes a new style, just coming into use. These envelopes are so prepared that black lines on the inside of the back of the envelope, and invisible from without, become patent on the front when the envelope is pressed, and serve as ruled lines to guide the superscription.

The TIMES has repeatedly expressed the opinion that the appointment of General NYE to be Police Commissioner was an unwise and an injurious step. We hold that opinion still--in spite of the genial, eloquent and admirable speech with which the General took his leave of the Police Department on Thursday night.

In the outline map which we this morning publish of the seat of war in Italy we have aimed simply to set before our readers at a glance the general features of the theatre on which a great European contest has now been commenced.

THE BACHELORS' BARGE CLUB.--The Bachelors' Barge Club, of Philadelphia, reached this City at noon Wednesday. They left Philadelphia at 11 o'clock on Monday Morning, by the Delaware and Raritan Canal, and reached Trenton at 11 1/2 o'clock that night, where they lodged.

A thriftless farmer leaves weeds and worms to scatter their seeds and make their nests, until his domain is worthless. A day of timely labor would have exterminated his pests. We have the image of such a farmer before us whenever our attention is called to the mode of dealing with moral vermin in a great City like our own.

MAKING Too MUCH HASTE.-We find a significant indication of the approach of a Presidential contest in the Washington States. That vigorous partisan sheet-which is as zealous as a partisan without a party can be--proclaims that Governor SEWARD has gone to Europe to enlist the Excter Hall philanthropists in a crusade against tile Union and the Constitution.

Before Judge Nelson. KOTION FOR A STAY. John Graham vs. Louis H. Meyer.-An applicawas, this morning, made on behalf of the defendant herein, for a stay of execution, pending a motion for a new trial. Judge NELSON gave the defendant 00 days to make a case on which to move for anew trial, but denied the motion for a stay of execution.

The receipts from Customs, yesterday, at New-York, were $163,300. The net balance now in the Treasury, subject to draft, is $4,356,000. The receipts for the week are $1,267,000, against $920,000 last week. The Hon. L. M. KEITT and his bride left the City this afternoon, for New-York, en route to Europe. Mr.KEITT intends to visit the seat of war.

GRIDLEY.--In this City, on Thursday. May 19, MARY GRIDLEY, relict of John V. Gridley, in the 67th year of her age. Her relatives and friends, also those of her sons James John V. and Edward Gridley, are requested to attend her funeral, on Saturday afternoon, at 1 o'clock.

GREAT BRITAIN IN CENTRAL AMERICA.--The Washington Constitution, of Thursday, in a brief article which we elsewhere copy, on the strength of information received by our Government, completely exonerates Great Britain from the charge of attempting by negotiations or otherwise any sinister projects in Central America.

PICOOLOMINI'S engagement. A favorite so well and so long supported by the public is not likely to be neglected in her last moments, The most remarkable of little prima donnas will, it is said, take her departure for Europe early next week.

A great triangular battle has been going on during the last century, between Money, Birth and Brains. Birth went into the field with the prestige of many preceding victories. It claimed all the thrones, manned all the constructed forts, and had things its own way at the start.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: From the moment that the war of French conquest has commenced in Italy we have refrained from asking pecuniary aid for Italy, the Republican Party feeling itself unable to participate in that war until it shall be transformed into a struggle for Italian Emancipation.

DEATH OF CHARLES R. LESLIE, R. A. The last English papers announce the death of the celebrated painter, CHARLES R. LESLIE, R. A., who died in London suddenly of disease of the heart, at the age of 65. Mr. LESLIE has always been regarded as an American, though he was born in London, where he lived the greater part of his life, and where he gained his reputation.

The Dale has just returned home from the Coast of Africa, after an absence of more than two years. For several weeks awaiting a summons to the land which none love better those who have long been exiles,we were anchored at Porto Praya. Anything more arid, leafless and calcined than that wretched little Portuguese town, and its background of volcanic peaks, perhaps does not exist.

BROOKLYN SABBATH SCHOOL ANNIVERSARY.-The anniversary of the Brooklyn Sabbath Schools, or rather those belonging to the Sabbath School Union, embracing ninety-nine schools in the Western District, was celebrated yesterday. The most deplorable accounts reach us daily of the sutlerings among the disappointed gold-seekers in Kansas. A correspondent of the St. Louis Democrat, writhing from Deaver City on the 9th inst., asserts that many of the emigrants were dying of starvation, and that in some instances the dead bodies of these who had perished were devoured by surviving companions.

Mr. CALDWELL was appointed a colporteur for Staten Island, to supply such of the people as need it with the Scriptures. A new mania for committing murders appears to have broken out. Our exchanges from all parts of the country are filled with accounts of bloody doings. Among numerous reports are the following: At Denver City, Kansas, April 18, two old friends, named R. F. BASSEIT and JOHN SCUDDER, fell into a quarrel, and SCUDDER shot BASSETT, who died in a few hours.

To the Editor of the New-York Times. Slaves, say Messrs. WISE and BOYON (indeed so say the whole South,) are property. Not such merely under the local laws of the Slave States, but property within the meaning and under the protection of the Federal Constitution. Therefore, like other personal effects, it may be removed by its Virginia owner to Kansas, and there held as such.

A YOUNG MAN SUPPOSED TO HAVE BEEN KILLED BY ROWDIES--Charles C. Cochran, a young man who was employed as book-keeper in the store of Backley Co., No. 7 College place, and who boarded at No. 21 Amity place, was found dead yesterday morning in his bed. From the circumstances, it is believed that his death was the result of violence.

DENISON.--In this City, on Wednesday, May 25, WILLIAM DENISON, in the 40th year of his age. Funeral services at the 43d St. M. E. Church, near 8th av., on Friday, May 27, at 9 o'clock A. M. His remains will be taken to Wilmington, Del., by the 11 o'clock A. M. train. The friends of the many are invited to attend his funeral. without any further invitation.

ALLEGED PERJURY AND ATTEMPT TO BLACK--MAIL.--Philip Moses and Samuel Preiss, two Polish Jews, entered a complaint. Monday, before Justice WELSH, against Wm. Meyer tailor, at NO. 554 Broadway, charging him with having inveigled one of them, Preiss, into the rear of his store, knocking him down and robbing him of watch.

THE NEW WAR ON THE KANSAS FRONTIER.--A correspondent of the St. Louis Democrat, writing from the Missouri River, May 13, says: We have just been conversing with an intelligent, reliable gentleman from Bates County, the seat of the frontier war. He says General PARSONS is organizing companies by authority of the Governor.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: In your notice in yesterday's NEW-YORK TIMES of the late C. R. LESLIE, observe some inaccuracies. The first picture which distinguished Mr. LESLIE, was his "Sir Roger de Coverly going to Church," which was painted for the late JAMES DUNLOP, Esq., of London, (his early and Munificent friend.) and afterwards copied for the Earl of EGEEMONT.

We have steadily insisted, in opposition to the views of early alarmists, that this country could not seriously suffer in its material interests from the pending war in Europe. We remain of that opinion, provided the war be confined nearly within its present limits.

The ladies' shoemakers in Philadelphia met in convention a night or two ago, and adopted the following pungent resolution, among others: "That we recommend the unmarried men of the trade to accept the invitation of God of Nature gives them, to seek employment in the invigorating and health-giving atmosphere of he country, thereby giving those who have to stay in a crowded city by necessity, the ability to maintain intact the bill of wages."

Mr. MICHAEL PHELAN publishes in Porter's Spirit a rejoinder to the letter of JOHN SIEREITER concerning the new Billiard challenge, He take direct issue with SIEREITER on technical points; states that the cloth and balls used in the Detroit match were not chosen without SIEREITER'S knowledge, but that the latter selected the balls and had played one cloth precisely like that on which the match was contested.

The Royal Mail steamship Fersia, Captain JUDKINS, left yesterday for Liverpool, carrying out two hundred and thirty-five passengers, and more than three millions of dollars in specie. This is the largest amount by nearly a million of dollars that has ever been carried out by one vessel from this port.

Arrival of the Overland Mail--California News to April 29. The Overland Mail brings California dates to the 29th April--nine days later than steamer advices. We are indebted to BUTTERFIELD Co.'s, and WELLS, FARGO Co.'s Expresses for papers. The mining news from all the mining localities in California was very encouraging.

STREET CLEANING.--The street cleaning under Mayor TIEMANN starts well. We hope there will be no fainting by the way, for there is no time to spare. Stirring up such immense accumulations of dirt, hoeing out gutters that have been for months choked up, is a dangerous business for June.

WHAT THE SOUTH WANTS.--The Mobile Register entertains the opinion that "what the South wants is a great paper to give utterance to its side of the world-dispute about its institutions." We doubt very much whether the South wants anything of the kind, for if it did why should not the South lave it? The South is all of a mind in relation to its institutions, and needs no information nor instruction on the subject;

The annual Convention of the Episcopal Church in New-Jersey began its session this morning at Burlington. A much more than ordinary interest atteaches to this Convention, because a Bishop will probably be chosen by it to succeed the late Bishop DOANE.

THE CHANGES OF THE YEAR.--It was just a year day before yesterday since a torchlight procession and various other kinds of commemorative demonstrations were made in honor of the lamented memory of PIERRI and ORSINI, by the Red Republican refugees of various nations in this City.

THE COMMISSIONERS OF HEALTH.--The Commissioners of Health held a private meeting at the Mayor's office yesterday. Reports were received from the captains of 17 police precincts, detailing the general condition of the streets.

The Douglasites and Buchananites of our Seventh Congressional District, after all their spats, have again come together and dovetailed. They met in Convention the other day, absolved one another. wiped out the past, practically ignored their immaterial, non-essential issues" about squatter sovereignty and the like, and virtually declared themselves thenceforth one and inseparable.

WAR AT ALBANY.-When the thunderbolts are rattling overhead, the noise of rolling tenpins dies out. Were not Austria and France at loggerheads, we should hear more of the great battle that is waging at Albany. The parties to this neglected fight are the majority of the Canal Board on one side, and Auditor BENTON on the other.

CONVENTION OF LIFF INSURANCE COMPANIES.-A National Convention of Life Insurance Companies is in session in this City. It proposes mostly a work of preparation, and has already appointed committees to investigate and report, at the next annual meeting, upon several topics of great importance to all companies issuing life policies.

Mr. W. If. JARVIS, in company with several Americans, residents of this Territory, arrived in Tubaco from Sonera on the evening of the 30th ult. Their departure from Hermesillo was somewhat accelerated from the fact that a singular excitement existed in the city, and every American was notified to leave at once, under penalty of death for remaining.

DONIZETTI'S opera of "I Martiri," under the Italian title of "II Poliuto," was produced here last night for the first time in America, and with decided success. This is perhaps the least known of the Master's numerous works. At the outset of its career it incurred the displeasure of the Neapolitan authorities, and was in consequence snubbed and shelved. It has been given since in a modified form, and with fair success.

FIRST DAY. The first National Convention of Underwriters of Life Insurnce Companies met at the Astor Hevre yesterday. The object of this Convention is to adopt measures for placing the subject of Life Insurance in this country, which is one of fast increasing importance to all closes of people, upon a more uniform, reliable and permanent basis.

CONSTITUTIONAL AMENDMENTS.--As a people we are prone to manufacture new Constitutions. In some one or more of the States this process is going on continually. Sometimes it is accomplished by a Convention of delegates formally called by the Legislature, and solemnly organized at a capital city, to overhaul the fundamental law, revise the Bill of Rights, and give the State a new rule of legislation. All this involves no revolution.

From the Scientific American. There is an old saying that " time tries all ;" and surely, if this be true, candles have stood the test of time well, for they were among the earliest inventions of the fathers of our race, and despite burningfluid, gas and coal-oil, still keep their place as lightgivers--a luxury to the rich, a blessing to the poor.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--Mlle. PICCOLIMINI's benefit to-night at this popular establishment will undoubtedly be the occasion of a great gathering especially as the opera selected is the highly successful "Poliuto" of DONZIZETTI. In addition to the other attractions, Mlle. PICCOLIMINI will deliver a farewell address. We leave our readers to decide whether this is in correct taste; we are perfectly sure that the speech will be.

THE VIRGINIA ELECTION.-Mr. LETCHER, the Democratic candidate, is probably elected, but by a majority much smaller than he had a right to anticipate. Personally, he is a popular man in Virginia,-no one more so,-and it is difficult to believe that the Ruffner affair injured him.

The widow of the famous Republican General Hoche died a fortnight since, in Paris, at a very advanced age. In view of the rumored return of WALKER to Nicaragua, it has been thought desirable to strengthen the Home Squadron, for the purpose of preventing any new trouble in that quarter. The session of our Provincial Parliament closed just in time. THE GERMANS AND THE SUNDAY LIQUOR TRAFFIC. -- We observe with regret that the Stoats Zeitung and one or two other German dailies seem disposed to mislead their readers as to the object sought by the memorialists on the Sunday liquor - traffic. No new laws are depended. No old and obsolete laws are dug up for enforcement.

The Quarantine law at the port of Philadelphia is in operation for the Summer. The season extends from June 1 to Sept 1. It is required that every vessel coming from a foreign part shall anchor in the Delaware, as near the Lazaretto as the draught of water will permit, before any portion of the cargo is removed, or any person on board shall leave. The Ruffalo papers state that the Banks in that city have been extensively victimized by the $100 counterfeits on the Brighton Bank. Besides this, $700 in these notes was left to pay a note falling due at the Niagara River Bank, now removed to Lockport.

The Northern form of lotus-eating is not a very noble development of human character. The Rev. John C. Baker, P. D., died at Philadelphia May 27. His age was 67. For twenty-five years he was pastor of the Lutheran Church at Lancaster, Pa., and afterwards removed to Philadelphia. He occupied a prominent position in all the religious and benevolent societies connected with the Lutheran Church.

One-eighth of the whole population of our City were on the sick list last year, and received gratuitous medical aid ! The number of patients treated in 1858 by the five Dispensaries of the City was 149,140; of these, 65,955 were under 15 years of age, and of this latter number three-fourths were under four years.

FIRE IN THE CITY HALL--The Fire Telegraph Office in the basement of the City Hall, the grand centre for receiving and disseminating fire news, was the scene of quite an exciting fire yesterday afternoon. The telegraph tells us that an unusual number of officers fell on the side of the French in the recent battle of Montebello, and the inference has been drawn from this fact, that the French officers in that action must have exposed themselves with uncommon audacity under the inspiration of the near presence of the Emperor.

If the French Army of Liberation in Italy had needed mystical portents of victory and inspiring coincidences of glory to nerve its energies in the conflict with Austria, the battle won by General Forsy at Montebello on the 21st of May should certainly have sufficed to confirm its faith in its own fortune and in the star of the Napolcons.

Great excitement exists at Port Morris, Westchester County, in consequence of the discovery of the remains of seven human bodies, closely packed in a pine box, found floating near Hell-Gate on Thursday. Two men, named RAMSAY and O'NxIL, divers engaged in exploring the wreck of the frigate Hussar, at Hell-Gate, on Thursday observed a box floating in the river, and towed it to the shore.

We have Bermuda papers to the 25th of May. The Colorial Parliament met on the 18th, when the usual address was delivered by the Governor to the two Houses. The address speaks favorably of the agriculture and products of the island. In the House, on the 23d, Mr. Zuill gave notice of a bill to establish a decimal currency. A balance of [Pound]1,644 l0s. 51. is in the Treasury.

STEAMBOAT EXPLOSION AND MIRACULOUS ESCAPES.--About 2 o'clock on Saturday afternoon, the boiler of the iron steam-tug Margaret Kembis, lying at the pier foot of Gouverneur-street, exploded just as the Captain and men employed on the boat were getting up from dinner.

ANNUAL. MEETING OF THE STOCKHOLDERS-CONDITION OF THE ROAD-COLLATION, The annual meeting of the Stockholders of the New-Jersey Railroad and Transportation Company was held, Saturday morning, in the D6p6t of the Company at Jersey City.

C. O. Halsted, Esq., President of the Manhattan Company, New-York:

The screw steamship City of Washington, from Liverpool on Wednesday, 25th of May, via Queenstown 26th, passed Cape Race at 9 o'clock on Thursday evening, in route to New York. The news was obtained by the news yacht of the Associated Press, but could not be forwarded until Saturday, owing to the non-working of the wires. It In of the highest importance.

FATAL AFFRAY BETWEEN BOYS.--Two boys, each about eight years old, named LOUIS LAPOINT and JOSEPH PRAGER, had an altercation, on Saturday afternoon, in Walker-street, which resulted in the latter's death. The boys were playmates, and while LAPOINT was amusing himself with a younger brother, PRAGER caught him playfully around the waist and threw him down.

The United States steamer Walker, Lieutenant Commanding T. B. Hunen, arrived on the morning of the 30th, and would leave for Key West the next day; all well on board.

Wife Murder In the sixteenth Ward. Another wife-beating, ending in the death of the woman, occurred Yesterday at No. 222Y. West Seventeenth-street. The alleged murderer is a German, and the victim of his violence Is an Irish woman; and from the statements of the neighbors and a number of policemen, the couple have bee n in the habit of getting drunk together and then quarrelling, for a considerable time.

The death of Mr. WILLIAM II. ROBERTSON, for several years a resident of Havana, and repeatedly Acting-Consul of the United States for that port, is announced among the news of the Cahawba. Mr. ROBERTSON was a native of New-London, Conn., where he was born in 1788.

The United States Revenue cutter Washington, Capt. HUDGINS, sailed for New-Orleans Saturday. She goes to New-Orleans to take the place of the cutter Robert McClelland, to which vessel Capt. H. has been instructed by the Treasury Department on his arrival out to transfer his officers and crew, and then to return immediately to New-York.
