U. S. ARCHIVES IN MEXICO.--We learn by private letters that, during the closure of our entire Legation at the City of Mexico, by the withdrawal of Consul BLACK'S exequatur, the archives of the legation have been intrusted to Senior PASTORE, Charged' Affaires for the Republic of Ecuador.

We published on Friday a very extraordinary report from the pen o Mr. HLLIDAY, concerning our City's deficiency of dwelling houses. In 1856 nineteen Wards of New-York had a population of 535,027 souls, and only 36,088 houses to shelter them in, or an average of 15 persons under each roof.

The steamship City of Washington, a brief summary of the news by which we published yesterday morning, as received from Cape Race, arrived at this port about 1 o'clock this morning. She brings full particulars of the opening of hostlities in Italy, and a variety of interesting political and miscellaneous intelligence.

The New-York Herald has fallen of late into the habit of issuing what are supposed to be "dispatches from our Ministers abroad to the State Department." In point of fact, our first-olass Envoys have been so steadily neglected, not to say insulted, by the actual Administration, that they never volunteer any general dispatches at all, and confine themselves exclusively to their necessary business communications.

METROPOLITAN THEATRE.--Doctor WARD's opera of "Flora, or the Gypsey's Frolic," written for the "promotion of harmony and good feeling," and played some months since at the Doctor's house, was given here last night for the first time in public. It may be safely affirmed that what is good for amateurs is bad for artists;

To the Editor of the New York Times: The Rev. C. L. BRACE stated on the floor of the Reformatory Convention, on the 11th or 12th of May, that " the Children's Aid Society could send off 700 to 800 children a year, at an expense of from $12 to $15 per head, counting the whole expenses, while Institutions like the Home of the Friendless paid an average of from $60 to $100 per head."

The Boston Traveller says of foreign Insurance Companies in Boston: Under a law of this Commonwealth, any foreign Insurance Company doing Dusiness in Massachusetts, is obliged to transmit to our Insurance Commissioners an annual exhibit of the condition of their affairs. A large English Company declined some time since to furnish this statement, and the operations of the agent of the Company here were in consequence suspended.

The rapidity and facility with which the Judges have disposed of the Stephens case, in spite of Mr. ASHMEAD'S monster bill of exceptions, gives us some reason to hope that something like a reform is at last beginning in our criminal procedure, and that hanging will soon begin to wear the appearance of a probable contingency in the eyes of ambitious cudgellers, poisoners, and garroters.

The discovery at the beach in Fort Hamilton, on Sunday, of the body of a young and handsome woman, well clothed, and but apparently recently dead, naturally excited much interest Ithere; and, when the intelligence reached this City, evoked probably a greater interest here.

The screw steamship City of Washington, Capt. PETRIE, which sailed from Liverpool at 2 o'clock on the afternoon of the 25th ultimo, and from Queenstown on the afternoon of the 26th, arrived here at 1 o'clock this morning. The steamer Indian, for Quebec, left Liverpool an hour or two in advance of the City of Washington, and the Ariel was to leave Southampton for NewYork on the same day.

THE OVERLAND MAIL.--The St. Louis Democrat publishes interesting statements in relation to the Overland Mail service. The remarks of the Democrat in reference to the favor shown to this service by the Californians are confirmed by our latest news from the Pacific.

To the Editor of the New- York Times: I observe that the Judges of the Supreme Court have made an application to the Board of Supervisors for an increase of salaries, and I trust they may not be treated with the supreme indifference shown to the suplication of the Superior Court Judges for a little more light, a little more air-elements generally supposed to be essential to the well-being of all classes,

The folly of in??rusting the government of a great commercial country to a purely territorial class, has just been signally illustrated in the course of tile Derby Ministry in England upon the question of neutrality as applied to the maritime relations of Great Britain.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC--Owing to the severe indisposition of Mme. CORTESI, the new prima dones, there was no performance at the Academy last night, MLYERDERE'S famous Opera of "Robert is Diable" will be revived to night, with Mme. COLSON and the other members of Mr. STRAKOSOR'S fine company in the cast.

The Emperor yesterday departed from Genoa amid the same acclamations and enthusiasm that greeted her arrival. At 2 o'clock his Majesty reached the depot of the Alessandria railway, and took his place in the royal carriage. At 41/2 o'clock the Imperial train entered the city of Alessandria.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--Mme. CORTESI, the new prima donna, will appear to-night in DoNIZETTI's Opera of "II Poliuto"-the success of the season. It is stated officially that the lady has recovered from her recent indisposition, and that there is no longer the hazard of a postponement.

A telegram from St. Louis, published on Saturday, announced the murder of Mr. JOSEPH CHARLESS, a prominent citizen of St. Louis, by one JOSEPH W. THORNTON, formerly book-keeper of the Boatmen's Savings Association, against whom Mr. CHARLESS gave evidence some time since in a criminal proceed. ing for embezzlement.

DEATH AT THE WORK-HOUSE.--Coroner GAMBLE held an inquest upon CATHERINE KAIN, an intemperate woman, recently admitted to the Workhouse, at her own request. When she came to the establishment she exhibited marks of having been engaged in a recent fight, but was not supposed to be seriously injured.

Yesterday morning the President and Secretaries THOMPSON and FLOYD returned to Washington from their visit to North Carolina, and a Cabinet meeting was immediately held for the discussion of Mexican affairs, at which it is understood the President declared his intention to let the whole subject lie over until the next meeting of Congress, except as to the protection, so far as possible, of American interests, at all points accessible to our war vessels.

A letter from Cairo says: "The general subject of conversation in this city is a discovery which has just been made by the well known archaelogist, M. Marlette. He has found at Thebes, after long and difficult researches, the tomb still intact of Pharaoh Amosis. The king is lying in a coffin, completely covered with gold leaf, ornamented with large wings painted on it.

We make room in our columns to-day for the very striking and elaborate Speech delivered by KOSSUTH at the London Tavern, on the 20th of May, before a public meeting, "called to consider the attitude which it becomes the English nation to assume in relation to the war in Italy," and presided over by the Lord Mayor. This speech is, in many particulars, worthy of special attention.

The President and Secretaries THOMPSON and FLOYD returned this morning, in improved condition. A Cabinet meeting was called immediately, and the Mexican question was discussed. I learn that Mr. BUCHANAN says the whole subject must lie over until the meeting of Congress, except as to protection at points within reach of our vessels of war. At present he has no idea of calling an extra session.

By a curious coincidence, the steamer which brings intelligence of the reappearance of KOSSUTH as a director of the public opinion of England, also conveys to us the tidings of the death of KOSSUTH'S old enemy, the Ban JELLACHICH. The Ban had long been laboring under a disease of the chest, which caused his death at Agram, in Croatia, about the 20th of May.

THE SUMMER OPERA.--Austria is famous for her diplomacy. A casualty overtook her forces at the Academy on Monday night. There was a postponement and the promise of a retreat. But Mr. STRAKOSCH instantly covered himself with a programme of superb and dazzling mystery.

FLEMING.--In Savannah, Ga., on Thursday, June 2, EMILY, wife of Wm. M. Fleming, Manager of the Savannah Theatre. Her funeral will take place on Wednesday afternoon, at 3 o'clock, from the residence of Jas. L. Smith, No. 368 Pacific St., beteween Bond and Nevins sts., Brooklyn. The relatives and friends of the family, and the members of the theatoical profession, are invited to attend.

THE PRINCESS HARRIET ON THE HUDSON.Monday was a gala day at West Point. The venerable walls of Fort Putnam must have thrilled with a strange sort of notion that the old royal days had come back once more; that the King was enjoying his own again; and that a royal daughter of his royal house was on her "progress" through the land.

The excessive servility with which the British Minister at Mexico has played the spaniel to the Reactionary faction, has at last extracted a growl from the observant watchdogs at home. The London Times thinks Mr. OTWAY wholly in the wrong.

A KILLING FROST.--The chilly nor'-wester o Saturday night, which suddenly swooped down upon us, as full of icy particles as though the opposite side of the North River were a mer de glace, was a sufficient warning of damage done to the crops in the West. But the actual harm done by this sudden blast appears to have been much more disastrous than could have been anticipated.

I cannot but agree with you that the result of the late canvass in Virginia, and of the pending one in Kentucky, is of little or no significance, so far as relates to the question of Slavery. Mr. GOGGIN and Mr. LETURER, and their respective spokesmen, seemed to plume themselves on their out and out pro-slavery proclivities, and vied right hard for the Pro-slavery vote.

Ex-Governor THOMAS WHIFFLE, of Rhode Island, died at Coventry, June 7, aged 71. The Provldence Journal has the following sketch of his life: "Very early in life he became interested in public affairs. He was first elected as Representative from the town of Coventry in 1847, the year of the success of Governor KNIGHT and the Democratic Party-the year that the Federal Party made its last real struggle for power in this State.

We have highly important news from the seat of war in Italy by the arrival of the steamship Argo at St. Johns, N. F., at 10 o'clock last night, from Galway on the 30th of May. The advices are four days later.

This section ot the Union has been remarkably quiet this week. Business of all kinds, especially within the last three days, has been quite dull, and no remarkably exciting events have transpired since my last, except the usual incidents of crime and casualty.

Very naturally, you refer only to the five dispensaries which, I believe, are established by the City, and supported mainly by appropriations from the City and State.

The following is the speech of President BUCHANNAN at Chapel Hill, delivered in response to an address of welcome from President SWAIN, of the University: Mr. BUCHANNAN said: I thank you for your kindness, and I am thankful for the kidness with which I have been received by the citizens. I have always had a partiality for this good Old North State.

The steamship Edinburgh, from New-York fol Glasgow, put in here at 7 o'clock last evening, with two of her compartments full of water, having struck an iceberg on Monday, at 11:20 A. M., one hundred and eighty miles east of St. Johns, in a dense fog. The iceberg was first discovered directly ahead, the ship being in lat. 47[degrees]40' long. 48[degrees]20'.

Monarchical England is sometimes as sorely puzzled where to look for a Premier, as is Democratic America where to look for a President, The causes which operate to make the right man unavailable for the right place are not indeed identical in the two cases, but the practical effects of those causes are frequently the same.

The Southern rebellion against the Administration grows fiercer daily. The unhappy President is Soundly belabored all through the Soulh by the men who were once his firmest friends. Our Southern exchanges are filled with sharp personal "cards," defining the position of Congressional and Gubernatorial candidates, and generally winding up with a bitter attack on Mr. BUCHANAN.

The tax-payers of New-York may as well prepare for a heavy run upon their cash accounts. The Common Council is evidently bent on selling out the City, and their plan of operations is already laid down.

The screw steamship Argo, Capt. WHITE, from Galway on the 30th May, arrived at this port at 10 o'clock this evening. Her advices are from Liverpool by mail to the evening of the 28th, and by telegraph to the morning of the 30th.

THE SOUTHERN OVERLAND MAIL ROUTE.-A letter has been received by the Indian Bureau, from Indian Superintendent COLLINS, of New-Mexico, in which he assures that Bureau of the perfect safety of the Southern Overland mail route, and says that the dangers spoken of by letter-writers from that country we their origin to misapprehension.

The Austrian organs in England are decidedly in ill luck. On attempting a review of the military position in Italy up to the 24th of May, they made up their minds that the position of General GARIBALDI on the extreme right of the Austrian forces was both awkward and perilous.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.-DONIZETTI'S opera of "If Poliuto" was played here last night, with Mme, CORTISI as the heroine, vice PICCOLOMINI, resigned. The role is an important one in a dramatic point of view, and is therefore especially valuable to an artist like CORTESI, whose specialty is intensity.

From the Cincinnati Commercial. We are indebted to a friend for the following report of louses by a conflagration at Eaton, Ohio, Sunday morning. Thirteen of the principal business houses in the city were laid waste, and a large quantity of merchandise destroyed. The total loss is estimated at $40,000 or $50 000, with insurance upon the entire amount of only 312 000.

St. Paul papers contain reports of the disastrous freshet on the Upper Mississippi. On June 4, by the rapid rise of the waters during the previous there days, St. Paul and other towns and the country along the Mississippi, above and below St. Paul, suffered seriously. The flats along the river at St. Paul are completely covered with water, and much damage has been cone to property in warehouses a eag the levees.

CELEBRATION AT HADLEY, MASS.--The two hundredth anniversay of the settlement of the town of Hadley, Mass., was celebrated on the 8th June with great ceremony. Five towns united in the celebration, the throng was enormous, and the proceedings interesting. Professor F. D. HUNTINGTON delivered the Oration, a Poem was recited by Mr. EDWARD C. PORTER, there was a procession, a banquet, and hosts of speeches.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC--The "Traviata" was given here lastnight to an audience considerably weakened by the prospect of a storm. Mme. CORTESI was the Violetta, and fully sustained the high reputation she has already won in this City. There was not the enthusiasm that prevailed on Wednesday, when the audience was fully carried away by the combined dramatic and musical fervor of the lady-but her reception was satisfactory.

HEALTH COMMISSIONERS.--At the meeting of the Health Commissioners, yesterday, Dr. GUNN reported this arrival of the brig Hebe, from Rio in 88 days, with a cargo of coffee and 150 bales of hair. A part of the crew were sick while in port, but all are now well. Her cargo was ordered to lightered to Quarantine, and the vessel to be permitted to come up after having been detained a suitable time for inspection.

We may import novels for our reading and poetry for our inspiration, but a good part of our natural history must be written at home, or stay unwritten. One fact settles that point. Most of our native species of animals and plants differ from those of the same genus abroad. They who discovered America, literally discovered a new world-not a new continent merely, but a new world of organic nature.

Late on Wednesday night last, two men, named PATRICK KILBOY and JAMES QUINLAN, while on their way home from a store at Fort Hamilton, a little excited by intoxicating liquors, got into a quarrel, when QUINLAN inflicted such injuries upon KILBOY that he died last night. The wound inflicted was upon the top of the head, and is supposed to have been made by an ax.

Wagons containing the disappointed adventurers are seen almost daily passing through town on their way back to the States, or to Southern Kansas, where they go in search of claims for farming purposes.

GENERAL CONVENTION OF SWEDENBORGIANS IN PHILADELPHIA.--The Philadelphia Ledger (June 11) says: "The General Convention of the New Jerusalem Church of the United States continued its sessions yesterday at the Church on Cherry-street, near Twenty-first. The Convention comprises about 100 delegates, from Maine, New-Hampshire, Illinois, Maryland, Massachusetts, Ohio, Michigan, Indiana, New York and Pennsylvania.

On the 30th ult. the trial of FRANCIS L NORTON, first mate of the bark E. A. Rawlins, accused of murder on the high seas, was commenced in the United States District Court. The impanneling of a Jury was completed by the next day, and the testimony for the prosecut on began.

Our Quarantine Commissioners, favored by the late frosts and unseasonably cold weather, are very likely to get their floating hospital ready for use before any considerable arrival of yellow fever in the port. They have nearly finished their work of fitting up the old steamer Falcon as a floating hospital.

PUNISHMENT AT SING SING.--An ancient mode of punishment for the refractory has been revived at the Sing Sing prison, consisting of a box about three feet square, and as high as the tallest man. The convict enters by a door and puts his head through a hole in the top, after which a sliding collar of wood is fastened around his neck and keeps him in his place.

ARRIVAL AND RECEPTION OF THE MILWAUKEE LIGHT GUARD.--FESTIVITIES AT THE CITY GUARD ARMORY.--Saturday morning at half-past six the Milwaukee Light Guard reached this City by the steamboat Isaac Newton from Albany. Company C of the Seventy-first Regiment had been ordered out to receive the visitors, and were under arms for the purpose at five o'clock.

BOAT CAPSIZED--TWO MEN DROWNED.-On Saturday afternoon a small sail-boat containing Capt. JAMES W. KIEDY and his son, a lad about 10 years old was capsized in a squall on Long Island Sound, just off Throgg's Neck, and both of the occupants were drowned, before assistance could reach them. Captain KIBBY was about 47 years old, and kept a note at Throgg's Neck.

A MANIFESTO AGAINST LAGER BIER.-The Milwaukee papers publish a correspondence which has recently passed between Mr. A. WELLINGTON HART, late editor of the Milwaukee Daily American, and Mr. EDWARD McGRAW, State Prison Commissioner of Wisconsin; which correspondence relates exclusivelyto lager bier.

THE FREE NEGROES OF MARYLAND.--The fact brought to notice by the recent Slaveholder's Convention, that the free blacks constitute more than one-eighth of the entire population in Maryland, excites no little surprise. Few at the North were prepared to hear that they were so numerous, though an examination of that much-neglected volume, the census returns of 1890, would have revealed the state of the case.

PROBABLY ANOTHER HOAX.-In the midst of the disastrous intelligence from Pike's Peak comes a dispatch, designed to revive the hopes which have already led so many to famine and death. The news imports that express coaches arrived at Leavenworth, in Kansas, from Denver City, on the 10th instant, with "extraordinary reports, calculated to renew the gold fever with more virulence than ever."

ARRIVAL OF THE QUAKER CITY--STATE OF TRADE. The mail steamship Quaker City, Captain SHUFELDT which left Havana at 7 P.M. on the 7th, arrived at this port on Saturday evening. A cargo of Coolies, Numbering 788, was landed at Havana, June 2, from the ship Live Yankee, twelve only having died on the voyage.

The screw steamship North Briton, from Liverpool on Wednesday, June 1, passed Further Point at 5 o'clock on Saturday morning, and reached Quebec in the evening. The steamship Niagara, from Boston via Halifax, arrived at Liverpool on the 29th May. The steamship Bavaria, from New-York, arrived at Southampton on the 29th.

The last number of Household Words has been published, and both DICKENS and BRADBURY EVANS avail themselves of the opportunity to fire cross shots at one another. DICKENS exhibits the most spite and sharpness, but his antagonists have the better side of the argument of their statement. The following is DICKENS' last Household Word:

POST-OFFICE AFFAIRS-DRAD LETTERS AND STAMPS.--With a view of responding to a resolution of Congress, calling upon the Post office Department for information as to what legislation, if any, is necessary to reduce the number of dead letters, that Department has prepared a circular directing the attention of postmasters to the subject.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: It was a happy thought of Esop's to represent a fly seated upon a chariot-wheel, as saying: "How we do make the dust fly." Somewhat of this fly spirit seems to have? descended, legitimately of course, to the denizens of the goodly town of Boston, situated, as I am told, not far from Marblehead.

THE NAVAL ACADEMY GRADUATES.--The following are the names of the acting midshipmen who have recently graduated at the Naval Academy, arranged in the order of merit. viz, No. 1, Wilburn B. Hall, of Louisiana; No. 2, Alfred T. Mahan, of New-York; No. 3. Samuel W. Arerett, of Virginia; No. 4, George C. Remv, of Iowa; No. 5. A. Slidell Mackenzie, of New-Jersey; No. 6, Norman A. Farquhar, of Pennsylvania: No. 7. Samuel D. Greene,

As a legitimate result of the northeast winds which have prevailed for the last day or two, we are enjoying the luxury of an energetic rain. All the morning the clouds scudded about as if uncertain what their work was to be. Finally they settled sullenly down on the sides of the mountains and are now relieving themselves of their liquid burdens.

NEWS ONE DAY LATER--ARRIVAL OF THE PHILADELPHIA--THE HEALTH OF THE PORT. The U. S. mail steamship Philadelphia, ELISHA HOWLS, Esq., commanding, left New-orleans June 5 for New-York via Havana, at which port she arrived on the morning of the 8th, and sailed on the P. m. of the same day, arriving at this port last evening.

THE WOMAN'S HOSPITAL AT THE ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--Our readers, fashionable, musical, charitable, curious, idle and busy, must not, for their own sakes, be suffered to forget that BELLINI'S magnificent opera of "I Puritani" is to be performed at the Academy of Music to-night, for the benefit of one of the noblest benevolent institutions of New-York.

DANIEL E. DELAVAN APPOINTED CITY INSPECTOR--PROPOSALS FOR CLEANING THE STREETS. Previous to the meeting of the Board of Aldermen, yesterday, a caucus of the Democratic members was held, at which it was resolved to confirm the nomination of Daniel E. Delavan for City Inspector.

COMMON COUNCIL.-A regular meeting of the Brooklyn Common Council was held last evening, and a large amount of business was transacted, principally in the reception of reports of committees, mostly however of local importance. A report of the Law Committee was adopted, authoriting the Corporation Counselor to employ extra assistance to meet the increased business of that department, the expenre not to exceed $1,000 per annum.

FLOUR inactive, market steady; sales 1,300 bbls. at $7@$7 25 for extra Michigan, Indiana and Ohio; $7 50@$7 75 for double extras. WHEAT-demand moderate and market steady; sales 12,000 bushels at $1 19 for Milwaukee Club ; $1 38 for red Winter IIlinols; $1 60 for red Ohio. CORN steady: sales 11,000 bushels at 73c. for Illinois, to arrive; 65c. prime do.

The steamship Fulton, from Southampton on the 1st inst., with details of two days later advices from Europe, arrived at this port last night. Her news has been partially anticipated by the arrival of the North Briton at Quebec. THE WAR IN ITALY. Miscellaneous Telegrams Published in the London Papers. VIENNA, Sunday, May 29---Noon.

O'CONNOR.--At his residence at Clifton, Station Island on Saturday, June 11, MICHAEL O'CONNOR, Builder, aged 49 years, 6 months and 6 days. His relatives and friends, also those of Joseph M. respectfully requested to attend the funeral, without further invitation, from the Staten Island ferry, foot of Whitehall-st., on Tuesday morning, at 101/2 o'clock, to St. Patrick's Cathedral, were a solemn High Mass of Regueim will be celebrated for the repose of his soul.

The steamship Fullon, from Southampton on the 1st inst., arrived at this port late last night. She brings London papers of the day of sailing, from which we obtain lull details of the news. a brief summary of which we received front Quebec, as brought by the North Briton, and published yesterday morning. The intelligence relative to the war is of the most interesting character.
In perfect conformity with the precedents of several years' experience, a suit for libel brought against the TIMES by Mr. W. W. SMITH, was yesterday terminated in favor of this journal.

The present position of the German States, with relation to the War, has been adopted, it is true, by the Princes and their Councils; but it meets with a remarkably unanimous approbation at the hands of the people. I may say, there are three great interests which teem equally to be served and satisfied by the political stand taken, within the last month, by the Bund.

FIRE IN EAST TWENTY-FIFTH-STREET.--Yesterday afternoon, about 4 o'clock, a fire broke out in the Empire Kindling-wood Factory, No. 78 East Twenty-fifth-street, owned and occupied by WM L. WILLIAMS. The fire was first discovered in the vicinity of the boiler connected with the engine.

In referring to the business of the past fortnight, we again have occasion to notice a continuance of the dull condition of trade, to which we have called attention for the past two months. Since the sailing of the steamer of the 5th Inst., but little of interest has occurred requiring especial notice, and, with the exception of a sale of a fresh Importation of tune quality Teas,

An important movement, preparatory to the calling of a Territorial Convention, took place at Arizona City on the, 7th inst. The total absence of regulated authority in this Territory has thrown upon the citizens the responsibility of inaugurating measures for self protection.

From W. T. Coleman Co.'s Circular. At length there is a gratifying improvement observable in the receipts of Gold Dust from our own mines. The daily receipts by the Express Companies are becoming quite large, indicating that access to the mining localities situated high up in the mountains has again been restored.

By a unanimous vote, the Aldermen last evening confirmed the Mayor's nomination of DANIEL E. DELAVAN as City Inspector. The language of their resolution of confirmation," that the Board do advise and consent to the appointment," it was necessary to their own consistency, involves a wanton insult to Mr. DELAVAN.

NINTH ANNUAL FESTIVAL OF THE NEW-YORK TURNVEREINS--FESTIVITIES IN ELM PARK. "Pfingst-Montag,"- Pentecost, or Whit-Monday, is the great festival day of the year with the Germans of the Old World and the New. They celebrate it if they are " City pent," by excursions into the country;-if they dwell in the country, they still have their festive out door recreations.

THE LAST SLAVER.-The vessel picked up, seuttled and abandoned, off the Pan of Matanzas, by the schooner Cumberland, Captain STMMES, of New-York, and towed lately into Havana, was the bark J. J. Cobb, of New-York. She is an A 21/2 vessel of 307 tons register, and was built in Robbinston, Me., in October, 1858, by J. W. Cox.

MACK--WICKS.--In this City, on Wednesday, June 8, at All Saints' Church, by the Rev. M. Ward, WESTCOTT B. MACK. of Bredhead, Wis., to OPHELIA, daughter of the late Haviland wicks. INGRAM-BENNETT.---In this City, on Friday. June 10, at Grace Church, by the Rev. Dr. Taylor, WILLIAM INGRAM to MARY ISABELLA BENNETT, both of this City.

PREPARATIONS FOR THE FOURTH OF JULY. The Joint Committee of the Common Council which is charged with the preparations for the celebration of the Fourth of July, met at 3 P. M. yesterday at Room No. 8, City Hall. The Chairman appointed the following sub-Committees: On Fireworks, Councilmen McCarty and Bickford, Alderman Genet.

The Times' City article has the following: "The market continues to be but slightly influenced by the accounts from Italy and France. The report that M. BENEDETTI is about to proceed from Paris on an extraordinary mission to the Germanic Confederation, tends, according to some views, to strengthen the supposition of a possible compromise at no distant date, by means of Russian agency, to terminate the present war."

In steamship Star of the West, from Aspinwall.--H. W. Halleck, lady and servant, John Sickles, Lieut. Chas. Churchill, S. Kile, J. R. Keys, w. T. Bryant, S Boutenon, J. M. Wright, R. B. Lee, Jr., and brother, Theo. Ladd, P. Chrystal and wife, Mr. L. Gapky and child, Mr. Lambert, F. Peter, F. D. Fairbank. L. Pollack, J. Connolly and wife.

Recently-received information from Madrid, of an altogether reliable character, shows that, however desirable it may be for the United States to acquire Cuba, there is no prospect whatever of such a consummation, nor in there any probability of the negotiation of a commercial treaty between Spain and this country.
THE Two BORRIOS.--The New-York Herald will insist upon it that there are two Bobbios in Italy as there were two Dromios in the " Comedy of Errors." It also demands a river Gogna for Sardinia.

THE DELEGATE WAR.--We almost begin to fear that there is, after all, a degree of trouble deep in the bosom of the Democracy respecting the best mode of appointing delegates to Charleston. Most of the papers of that party express themselves in favor of the District system.

ROYAL DUKES IN DIsGRACE.-The chief command of the British army seems to be fatal to royal dukes. Fifty years ago, in February, 1809, his Royal Highness the Duke of YoRK was driven to perpetrate a downright falsehood in order to screen himself from the public indignation excited by a traffic in army commissions, which had been carried on with his connivance and consent by his mistress, Mrs. MARY ANN CLARKE.

Information lately received here by the Government has excited serious apprehensions as to the public peace in Texas. At least two thousand men had assembled near the reservation to attack the Indians. Secretary FLOYD has ordered the commander of that intillary department to furnish the largest possible escort he can spare, to conduct the Indians to the Choctaw Lease, in the Indian Territory.

MILLER--PECK.--In this City, on Monday, June 13, by the Rev. E. O Flagg, DAVID B. MILLER, M. D., to ELIZA L., only daughter of the late Henry S. Peck, all of this City. CLOSE--SWEENEY.--In Brooklyn, on Tuesday, June 11, by the Right Rev. Bishop Loughlin, JOHN E. CLOSE to SARAH E. SWEENEY.

Professor WILSON used to say that an " unpaid contributor" was er vi terminis an ass; and we published yesterday a South American letter which proves, beyond question, that the same thing may be predicated with perfect accuracy of unpaid Consuls.

From the Constitution. The observations attributed to the Hon. JACOB THOMPSON, in notices of his recent brief speech at Raleigh, have excited a good deal of comment, especially in regard to disunionists, North and South, and the reopening of the African Slave-trade.

Certain of our contemporaries have fallen into the bad habit of carrying their partisan politics into every question which engages their attention, and who are accordingly devoting themselves to the cause of Austrian tyranny in Italy in the belief that by so doing they may propitiate the German vote of America, will do well to remember that the German policy of Austria is not wholly unknown to the Germans on this side of the water;

ANOTHER ACT OF THE MEXICAN MELODRAMA. -A blundering dispatch from New-Orleans, received yesterday, affords a glimpse of a new and startling state of things at the City of Mexico. That chosen son of the Church and defender of the faith, President MIRAMON, has, it is represented, quarreled with the hierarchy, and, after repressing an effort of that body at revolution, has sent the priests to Vera Cruz, and ZULOAGA, their elected leader, to prison.

MISSION SUNDAY SCHOOL OF THE MARINERS' CHURCH.--A Strawberry Festival was held in the lecture room of the Mariners' Church, corner of Madison and Catharine streets last evening, for the benefit of the children of the school. No withstanding the threatening aspect of the evening there was a large attendance.

Important Arrest of Counterfeiters of United States Coln. Last week a large quantity of counterfeit ten, twenty-five and fifty cent pieces were put into circulation, both in this city and New-York. These counterfeits were so well executed that any person was liable to receive them in change without noticing their spurious character. unless particular attention was called to the fact;

THE NEW CITY INSPECTOR HEARD FROM.Coloned DELAVAN, the new City Inspector, entertained his political friends at the PewterMug last night, and in the course of a speech, responding to a toast in his honor, he stated that while he remained at the head of the City Inspector's Office, the streets of New York should be kept clean.

THE NEW CITY INSPECTOR.-Col. DELAVAN the new City Inspector, received and entertained his friends last evening at the Pewter Mug, where a bountiful collation was spread, of which a number of the prominent members of the Democratic Party partook. Speeches were made by Capt. RYNDERS, Col.

THE CAPTAIN DIES OF A BROKEN HEART. The bark Orion, which was seized en suspicion hat she was engaged in the slave traffic, arrived at his port last evening, and was anchored under the guns of the Navy-yard. She is from Congo River, Africa, from whence she sailed 50 days ago, in charge of Lieutenants DALLAS and CAMPDELL.

CORNELL--In this City, on Monday, June 13, WM. T. CORNELL, in the 55th year of his age. His funeral will take place on Wednesday, the 15th inst., at 2 o'clock P.M., from his late residence. No. 163 East 21 st st. The relative and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend. without further invitation. Cincinnati and Long Island papers please copy.

The Austrians have won two or three more "victories of Montebello." That is to say, after advancing in force to Robbio, immediately upon the victorious passage of the Sesia by the King of Sardinia, they proceeded to give the Sardinians battle between Robbio and Palestro, and alter a series of sanguinary conflicts were forced to fall back, leaving a thousand prisoners behind them, towards the Ticino;

By the arrival of the steamship Europa, at Halifax, we have advices from Liverpool to June 4. They are highly important. A series of hotly-contested conflicts had been fought between the Allies, commanded by King VICTOR EMANCEL, and the Austrians, the latter endeavoring to recover Palestro.

EXTRAORDINARY POSTING.-One of our evenng contemporaries in this City deserves singular credit for its success in stimulating the French mail service to new and brilliant feats. It published yesterday evening a letter from the "seat of war," dated Alessandria, May 28, which must have arrived by the Fulton at this port, and must consequently have been mailed at Paris six hours before the sailing of the steamer from Havre on the 31st.

In every other country but this the efforts of accomplished amateurs in the cause of charity receive at least a kindly and liberal recognition from the public. Here that august body seems to be utterly indifferent to any impulse of mere generosity. It demands its money's worth. To mention the word amateur, is in point of fact to depreciate an entertainment.

The R. M. steamship Europa, from Liverpool at 10:30 A. M. of Saturday the 4th inst., fired her first Sun at Halifax at 20 minutes past 11, last night, and reached her wharf at about 1 o'clock. Her advices are three days later and important.

DAILY ROUTINE. It is a pity that the patriotic young gentlemen who are so desirous of "playing soger" could not each one of them spend a few days here, under ail the irksome regulations of eadet life, before they secure their final appointment.

The City Guard, Captain HALLICK, renowned as the elite military company of the City, celebrated yesterday the twenty sixth anniversary of their organization, by an excursion to West Point, on the steamboat Erie, chartered for that purpose. A large number of invited guests accompanied them, including Lord FRANCIS CONYNGHAM, son of the Marquis of CONYNGHAM, one of the heroes of the Crimean War;

REPAIRING THE ROADS--STREET-CLEANING CONTRACT, The Board of Councilmen met Monday night, the President, Councilman CORNELL, in the chair. The minutes of the previous meeting having been read and approved, a number of petitions were presented, among which was one from various residents on Broadway, remonstrating against the removal of the Russ payement.

WALLACK'S THEATRE.--During the warm weather it has become a custom in the Metropolis to have Summer seasons at the theatres. It is a good plan and answers well. The favored cit, dreaming of open landscapes and balmy breezes, beholds at least one of the products of the country--its actors:

THE GREAT NORTH WEBSTERS MAIL--The DEtroit Free Press says. "We learn that the Post-office Department bus entered into an arrangemetn with the Detroit and Milwaukee Railway Company by which the great mail for the States of Wisconsin and Minnesota will hereafter pass direct from this city to Milwaukee. instead of all Chicago, as heretofore.

The Savannah Republican, June 11, says : "The steamer Jo??n G. Lawton, which left this city yesterday afternoon for Parachuela, exploded her boiler between 6 and 7 o'clock, 18 miles above the city. Considering the number on board, the destruction of life is shocking .

BOARD OF HEALTH.--The Brooklyn Board of Health held an adjourned meeting, yesterday, in the office of the Health Officer, City Hall. The Mayor was authorized to make a temporary arrangement with FRANCIS SWIFT, the lowest bidder, for the contract to remove the offal of the city.

BARK CHARM BURNT.-The tow--boat W. H Webb, Captain NICKERSON, arrived yesterday morning, having on board the sails, rigging, one anchor and two chain cables, furniture, , of the bark Charm, Captain SLEEPER, from New-York, destroyed by fire at the head of Pass a POutre.

A visitor to the State Prison at Sing Sing, if only a visitor, not urged to make a long tarry, is very areeably impressed. The premises are scrupulously clean, destitute of the minutest speck of dirt. The floors are scenred to a wonderful degree of whiteness.

Mgr. Pinsonnean, the Bishop of London, C. W., who recently went to Rome to induce the Pope to transfer the Western See from London to Sandwich, has succeeded in accomplishing the purpose of his mission. A Toronto paper says:

An exciting trot came off on the race course at Chatham Four Corners on Friday, between Hector and the Berkshire Boy for $400, which resulted in favor of the latter. Very good time was made by both the horses, arid though the Berkshire Boy came in second best, he is allowed to be a very fast horse and a very good one.

THE HALFORD--The United States steam sloop-of-war Hartford sailed from Boston on Saturday the 4th, and remained away until the following Friday. She then stood in towards Boston Light, showed her signals, and once more Love away for sea. The sloop-of-war Levant safied from Boaster, on the 9th, bound to the Pacific Ocean.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The main object of laborers in the cause of temperance has been to enlighten the public mind as to the effect of intoxicating liquors, as a beverage, on the health, happiness, virtue and prosperity of the people, so that they could act understandingly should they think action necessary.

Those who visited the Eclipse Course yesterday, with the expectation of seeing a good trot, found that they had reckoned without their host. Happily they were few; there were not more than a hundred and fifty persons there altogether. The great trot which is to take place there to-day sufficiently accourts for the paucity of the spectators yesterday.

The steamship City of Manchester, from Queenstown June 3, arrived at this port yesterday morning. Her dates are not so late as those by the Europa, but from Cork papers of the 3d we derive a few additional details.

TO THE DEMOCRACY OF CALIFORNIA. The Demecratic Party will soon be called upon to assemble in their primary meetings to elect delegates to the State Convention. MURDER AND SUICIDE.--The New-Orleans Bee learns from Belton, Texas, that a horrible murder and suicide were committed in Bell County on the 30th May. Mr. ASHLEY, who had married a daughter of MUREELL, the land pirate, killed a brother-in-law, McCORMICK, and wounded another man, who was standing near: then fled and ended his own life by taking strychnine. The particulars we do not sufficiently understand to give here.

NEW-YORK SUNDAY-SCHOOL UNION.--The Board of Managers held their regular monthly meeting at their rooms, No. 375 Broadway, on Wednesday afternoon the 15th inst., WM. FORREST, Esq., in the Chair. The meeting was well attended. The Committee of Ways and Means reported that the receipts during the last month for Missionary purposes, amounted to $3,186 89, against the corresponding month of last year, when the receipts were only $724 13, with two collecting agents.

A CHARACTERISTIC WESTERN REMONSTRANCE.A great company of witnesses have been sum. moned to the capital of Missouri to give evidence at the coming trial of a Supreme Court Judge, and the allowance per head is only two dollars and a half, with ten cents mileage. It seems this amount is inadequate to cover the necessary expenses at the Capital,

LAURA KEENE'S THEATRE.-- A new burlesque on the famous story of" Cinderella" was produced at this house on Wednesday evening with marked success. Pieces of this sort are the thing when the thermometer ranges above 80. The burlesque emanates from the prolific pen of the Brothers BROUGH, and has been localised by a "gentleman of this City."

At Greenpoint, Mr. WILLIAMS has on the stocks a screw steamship for H. B. CROMWALL Co., 175 feet long,29 feet wide, and 17 feet deco. She is to be called the Monticello.

THE ERA OF RECONCILEMENTS.-Once a week at least we have news from Washington of an important reconciliation between the President and some estranged Democratic leader. Considering the proverbial harmony of the Democratic party, it is astonishing that so many burials of the hatchet are possible. Yet so it seems to be; at least so it is reported.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Your report of the "Strawberry Festival," held by HENRY WARD BEICHER'S corgregation, at David's Island on Thursday, induces me to tell you something of my experience in that disgraceful imposition. I sent, from my family, three boys and a lady to this "Festival." The eldest boy is 18, the next 10 and the next 5.

DISCHARGE OF THE ORION'S CREW. - The two Lieutenants of the U. S. sloop-of-war Marion were yesterday examined as witnesses before United States Commissioner BRIDGHAM, in the case of the alleged slaver bark Orion. The mate, supercargo and crew were all present ; the latter were all down-east looking sailors.

Chancellor Darman, of South Carolina, died at Charleston on the 13th of June. The Courier says: "He served with ability and characteristic fidelity as Commissioner in Equity, and would have been longer in office, had such been his desire. He represented Darlington District in the Senate for a term, we believe, but the duties and demands of his profession, in which he recognized the highest standard, were ever foremost in his view.;

ATTACKRD BY A Cow.-On Thursday afternoon, as Mrs. MARY BOWLEY. of Steuben-street, was crossing a vacant lot on Ryerson-street, she in some manner excited the ire of a cow. The animal made a furious attack upon her, throwing her down, and trampling upon her. A policemen of the Fourth Precinel rescued Mrs. BOWLEY, and took her home, Fortunately, she was more frightened than hurt.

THE DEMOCRATIC STATE COMMITTEE AND THE W. YORK HARDS.--The Democratic State Committee will not be at peace with the Hards. Yesterday a telegram from Albany contradicted a statement which appeared in this City, to the effect that a privale meeting of said Committee had been held.

A meeting of the friends of Gov. WISE was held in Philadelphia, a day or two ago. The call was a private note, served personally upon such admirers of the Governor "as desired to see him nominated by the Democratic Party for the Presidency." RICHARD V. BRENNAN presided, the claims of the Governor were canvassed, and it was agreed that he ought to be the nominee in 1860.

The population of Trinidad, according to the census of 1851, was, in round numbers, 69,000 souls, and taking into consideration the great mortality by the cholera of 1854, the present increase over the estimate of the last census must be small. It was first seen near the middle of the pond, whirling the water in a terrific column several hundred feet into the air.

A POLITICIAN RELAPSED.-A reformed politican is as rare as a reformed inebriate. He may become weary of party, disgusted with trickery, and solicitous for the shades of private life. While in such a frame of mind he may in all sincerity take a pledge of total abstinence from public affairs.

ORRIS, was arrested at Cleveland and incarcerated in jail, upon the charge of passing several bills upon "The Manufacturers' Bank," which purported to be located at Hartford. Ohio County, Indiana, but which were alleged to be worthless. Three thousand doears of the paper was found upon his person.

At Baltimore, a few days since, ANNIE B. HERRING sued JAMES BAUGHEN for breach of promise of marriage, laying her damages at $5,000--a moderate amount compared with Miss EFFIE CARSTANG'S demand of $1000,000. The principal evidence offered was documentary.

THE RECENT KANSAS ELECTION.--The election just held in Kansas for delegates to a convention to be held for tile purpose of framing a Constitution, preliminary to the admission of that Territory as a State, has resulted, as between the Republican and Democratic parties, in something like a drawn battle.

THE TROUT - The trout is the only fish that comes in and goes out of season with deer ; he grows rapidly, and dies early after reaching his full growth. The female spawns in October-- at a different time from nearly all other fish;

The refusal of certain Virginia postmasters to send returns of elections to the Secretary of State, without prepayment of postage, has led to a correspondence with the Post-office Department, and the offending postmasters are directed to forward the packages, charging the proper amount of postage, but not to insist upon prepayment. This is a precedent for coming elections.

From the Bulletin of last evening. This morning about 5 o'clock, the murdered body of a woman was found in the yard of a house in Krider's-court, back of No. 719 Bedford-street. The deceased was a white woman, apparently about 30 years of age and Irish by birth. The woman had evidently been good looking, although a life of vile dissipation had made wreek of her.

BREAD RIOTS IN VIRGINIA.-The flour panic among the farmers in this section bids fair to carry many persons into all sorts of wild extravagances. Last Wednesday, 15th inst., was Presentation Day at Yale College. The day was fine, and a little before 10 o'clock the chapel was filled with the students and their friends, among whom were many of the gentler sex.

A remarkable case of commercial swindling has been developed in New Orleans. A commission merchant named J. L. BOARD OF SUPERVISORS.--At the meeting of the Board of Supervisors yesterday, the President, Mr. PURDY, offered a resolution directing the Special Committee on Building the new City Hall to inquire into the expenses incurred by the Commissioners appointed under the act of 1858 in relation to the new City Hall. It was adopted.

These parties, when arrested, attempted to make way with a quantity of the counterfeit money, but it was recovered.

BARON DE HESS. Field-Marshal Baron HENRY DE HESS, who although not actually on the battle-field of Magenta, is understood to have acted ever since his arrival in Italy as Commander-in-Chiefof the Austrian army, is a veteran of the old Napoleonic wars, upon whom a new and recent glory has fallen from his connection with the Italian campaigns of Marshal RADETZKY DE RADETZ in 1849.

NEW-YORK CLUB AGAINST MASSACHUSETTS. This match was won very easily by the gentlemen on the New-York side, they having only eight to score in their second innings. This number cost the New-Yorkers four wickets before it could be obtrained, thus winning the match with six wickets to spare.

I have sad news for my first letter. Dr. BAILEY, the well-known Editor of the National Era at Washington, died on board the Arago on Sunday last at a little past 3 o'clock in the afternoon. He came on board an invalid, and was hoping that relief from toil and change of scene would restore the strength and vigor which the incessant and strenuous labors of his profession had greatly impaired.

We publish to-day a highly interesting letter in regard to the projects and policy of the Earopean Republicans, from a correspondent who enjoys the best possible means of information on that subject. The letter, we are confident, will he read with interest, as an authoritative exposition of wishes and hopes and plans which must eventually help to modify the results of the pending conflict in Europe.
The result of the recent division in the House of Commons is as signal a rebuke as any English Ministry has ever received within the present century.

DESTRUCTIVE HAIL-STORM.--A terribly destructive hall storm passes through the centre of the town of Clifton Park yesterday afternoon about 2 o'clock. A gentleman from that town brought to our office this morning a congealed mass, which weighed more than five pounds; and some of the hall-stones in the mass were as large as marbles. Some picked up half an hour after the storm measured a full inch across.

I gave in my last letter some of the leading featires of the Trinidad Immigration laws; sufficient, I hope, to convoy a correct idea of the system under which the Colony is being supplied with foreign labor, and of the manner in which that system has been reduced to practice. I do not hesitate to say-and no one here will express a contrary opinionthat immigration has been the salvation of Triniadd.

SIR: In response to your inquiry as to what legal condition you, born in Turkey, and a naturalized citizen of the United States, wilt have in Turkey during a proposed sojourn there, I state: The laws of the United States do not admit the indefeasibility of natural allegiance. The assertion of the right of self. expatriation is one of the principles of the fundamental public law of the American Union.

Mr. ALVIN F. EDDY, a merchant of Marquette, Lake Superior, arrived in this city, yesterday, by the steamer North Star, from Lake Superior, in search of his sister, who disappeared from Marquette on Wednesday. The sister was a married woman, who had left behind her in her flight her husband, a respectable man named BARNS, possessed of ample means to make their home comfortable, and a child but six months old.

The benefit in aid of the Italian Fund, given yesterday afternoon and evening, was a complete success. The net proceeds, we are informed, will exceed three thousand dollars-a very desirable addition to the contributions already so liberally made to the cause, and peculiarly creditable, when it is remembered that the present moment is by no means the best for operatic or other indoor entertainments.

In the recent election for members of a Convention to frame a Constitution for Knasas, both the Democrats and Republicans were in the field. The returns that have been received from most of the counties in the Territory show that the Democrats have elected eighteen of the fifty-two members, giving the Republicans a large majority.

Judge MERRICK, today, remanded to Hageretown, M., a colored man who has been residing here twelve years, and who was claimed under the Fugitive Slave Law. Tile Court having no power to pass upon the question of his Freedom, it must be decided in Maryland. There as a large number of colored persons about the Judge's chambers, who manifested much interest in the progress of the ease.

The Cunard steamer Africa, Captain SHANNON, left this port yesterday at noon, for Liverpool, with one hundred and thirty-one passengers, and $551,600 in specie. The steamship Quaker City, Captain SHUFELDT, left yesterday, at 2 o'clock P. M., for Havana, with a good freight, and about forty passengers. Several valuable horses were sent out by her.

MAP OF THE SEAT OF WAR.--A very admirable map of Northern Italy has been prepared by that competent officer, Lieut. J. C. IVES, of the Corps of Topographical Engineers. THE CASE OF MAYOR GOLDSALL.--The case of MEYER GOLDSALL, the St. Louis merchant who was brought to this City from Missouri, a few days since, on a requisition from Governor MORGAN, charging him with detranding several jewelry and other dealers of this pace of large amounts of goods, was called up for formal examination before justice WELSH at the City Hall Police Court yesterday afternoon.

Trot between Flora Temple and Princess--Princess Wins in Two Seraight Heats--Flora Temple Disabled--Trot one the Union Course. Aldermen, Councilmen, and the sporting characters--the weather included--did all they could to make yesterday a genuine "Derby Day."

LEE-AVENUE CHURCH SABBATH SCHOOL FESTIVAL-The sixth annual Strawberry and Floral Festival of the above-named Society was Celebrated yesterday, in the grove at Bedford owned by J. CARSON BREVOORT, Esq.

The new Reading and Coffee Room, intended to meet the wants of those who are driven to the barroom in lack of better sources of amusement, is on the second floor of No. 26 New-Bowery, and was crowded last night by young men and old, from the Fourth and Seventh Wards, who met to hear the opening speeches.

THE FRENCH GENERAL CLER.--One of the heroes of the French Army who lost his life fighting on the field of Magenta, was Gen. CLEE, commanding a division under CANROBERT. Galignari furnishes the following particulars of his military career: "Gen. CLEE had scarcely reached the age of 42.

THE NEWLY IMPORTED AFRICAN NEGROES.--The Galveston News has a letter from mississippi about the African negroes, descriptive of their habits and values. The writer says; I have this morning required from a visit to Mr. SMITH'S plantation near Canton, Miss. He has sixteen of the real bona fide Africans; all young and likely.

He had stepped from his office on a business errand, and on his return found several small nuts lying upon the table, and, wondering how they got there,

ST. GEOEGES VERSUS BOSTON CLUB. The match between the first Eleven of the St. George's and the first Eleven of Boston, was finished last evening, resulting in favor of the formerThe game was very interesting throughout, and some very fine cricketing was exhibited on both sides.

THE CASE OF PLUMER, THE MUTINEER OF THE JUNIOR.--We understand that the Rev. Mr. LOTHROP, the spiritual adviser ot CYRUS W. PLUMER, had an interview with him at his cell at the jail this morning; and informed him of the result of his journey to Washington to obtain a commutation of sentence to imprisonment for life.

THE TEXAN BOUNDARY COMMISSION.--The Austin (Texas) Intelligencer has a letter from the camp of the Boundary Commissioners on the Pecos, stating that the further progress of the survey has been arrested by a difficulty between the Texas and the United States Commissioners.

NEW MOVEMENT AT OBERLIN.--On the evening of June 15, a large number of the citizens of Oberlinmet, and perfected an organization called the Sons of Liberty, and declared as follows: "The immediate object of the organization is to raise funds for the present contest, and to extend and direct the action of Anti-Slavery principles here and elsewhere."

Y., left her home on Sunday evening, June 12, and, notwithstanding a alligent search and the offer of a reward of #\$100, was not again heard from till the following Saturday, when her body was found by A. G.

To the Editor of the New- York Times : In the report of the motions in the suits of TOMLINSON vs. FREDRICKS, in the United States Circuit Court, your paper of Wednesday last states that the motions were denied, and the article referred to conveys the idea that the claim of the complainant was abandoned. This is a mistake.

Relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend the general, from the residence of her grandfather, George T Elliot No. 25 East 14th st., this day, (Friday,) June 24, at 10 A. M.

The Commencement exercises of Rutgers College are just over, and the streets of our quiet old city are thronged with a crowd of pleasure-seekers on their way to the ice-cream saloons and gardens, students in the agonies of packing up in time for the class-dinner and the early train, country-people searching for their vehicles, and grave and reverend gentlemen waiting to dine with the Alumni.

A PHILADELPHIA CLOTHIER DEMANDING A DIVORCE--HIS FRIGNED INSANITY AND SICKNESS--THE WIFE MAKES A FALSE CONFESSION. The Philadelphia Daily News, June 22, says: "For some weeks past there has been quite a sensation in certain circles of our city, growing out of a report that one of our prominent clothiers had succeeded in obtaining a divorce from his wife, of whose society he had tired.

The steamship William H. Webb arrived here to-day, from Minatitlan, bringing San Francisco dates to the 6th inst., and 19 passengers. The steamship Golden Age left San Francisco on the 6th inst., with 1,000 passengers and $2,643,000 in treasure. When the Webb left Minatitlan, a rumor was current there that the Church Party had taken Oajaca.

CUBA AGAIn.--The Pennsylvanian, a paper supposed to represent, in a peculiar manner, the views and interests of tile President, has undertaken a reargument of the proposition to purchase Cuba. Mr. BUCHANAN rode in on that question, and the Pennsylvanian intends he shall ride out on it.

HON. JOHN MINOR BOTTS-DearSir: The prompt and satisfactory answer which you have given to our letter of the 11th inst., upon the subject of the duty of this Government towards its adopted citizens, in affording them the same absolute protection which is guaranteed to native born citizens, elicits our highest approbation and warmest esteem.

Judge DOUGLAS has written a letter, which will be found under our telegraphic head this morning, explaining his position on the subject of the Presidency, and setting forth the conditions upon which be will allow his name to be used before the Charlest on Convention in connection with that office.

MUNICIPAL HYDROPHOBIA.--Men will differ about nuisances. "Rats and puppies for pies" is said to be an inviting street-cry among the Chinese; here we prefer to listen to the music of "Straw-ber.ri.e.s." So, some unfortunate people have a great disgust for whisky; while others have even a greater abomination of water. De guslibus non est disputandum.

GARIBALDI AND HIS FORMER ENGLISH LIEUTENANT.-Colonel FORBES, during the whole of GARIBALDI'S former campaigns, had been the guardian genius of the chieftain, the head and brain of every enterprise, while GARIBALDI himself seemed to be the heart and aim.

To the Editor of the New- York Times: The death of an eminent and upright public man deserves more than the customary tributes of re gret. It is proper that the lessons of his life should be held in remembrance, and their influences thus preserved to the living.

D., in the Chair. The Treasurer was unable to report, as their financial agent had not returned to the City.

Mr. DOUGLAS has issued his proclamation of policy for tile Charleston Convention. It contains nothing to startle his friends; nothing to elate his enemies. In tone and style it is certainly a very happy evasion of the Scylia and Charybdis of American public men steering for the White House--being neither vague nor vaunting, but clear, consistent with the latest published convictions of the Illinois Senator, and temperately firm.

To-day, His Excellency Governor MORGAN has been publicly received by the civic and military authorities of this city, and in a manner which must be gratifying to him. The day was most propitious, the sky which in the morning looked dark and tareatening, by noon had cleared, and a cool breeze sprung up, which added immensely to the comfort of the military and other participants in the out-of door ceremonies.

If agreeable to you, I should be pleased to have it published in your paper.

The Charleston Mercury re-states its position in reference to the Charleston Convention, and in bitter hostility to Senator DOUGLAS. It says: "As for an'alliance' with DOUGLAS, we will here state that the Mercury will sustain or countenance him under no circumstances whatever. He is a traitor to the Democratic Party, and a traitor to those principle which secure the South. He is dangerous and designing.

The superior authenticity of the French over the Austrian reports of occurrences at the seat of wart has been curiously illustrated in the case of the most recent news. Through Germany and England the tidings of the Battle of Magenta came to us embellished with accounts of the " disgrace of Marshal BARAGUAY D'HILLIERS," and of the fall of Marshal CANROBERT, mortally wounded in action."

LIFE IN TEXAS--HORRIBLE MURDERS IN BRAZOS COUNTY.--Murders are plentiful in Texas. On Tuesday, June 7, in Brezos County, THOS. BRUMFIELD was killed by a young man who called himself DAVIS, but his right name is BELTON. They were in the woods, at cards, a short distance form the house of LEWIS RECTORS. There were three other men present, who, being duly sworn, stated the amount of money up was $1 50.

The Roman Catholic Orphan Asylum in Fifth-avenue, between Fiftieth and Fifty-first streets, was the scene of a pleasant entertainment yesterday. The boys, to the number of some five hundred-clean, smart, sharp, lively lads, all-went through their annual exhibition in presence of a large and distinguished audience.

The dirt-eaters of the Orinoco are a very miserable and degraded folk, whose abject condition is well calculated to excite the warmest compassion in the hearts of all well-fed, wellclothed, well-bled and comfortable Christians. Their ethical rank in the race is even lower than that of the Feejeean savages, of whom an English midshipman wrote to his mother that their " manners were none-and their customs filthy."

LOVE. From the French of M. J. MICHELET. By. J. W. PALMER, M. D. New-York: RUDD CARLETON. In translating MICHELET'S very original and interesting treatise on Love, Dr. PALMER has done a bold thing, which in the eyes even of many not over-fastidious persons will seem, we doubt not, too bold.

SUPPOSED SUICIDE ON FOX HILL, N. J.--On Thursday morning, between the hours of 8 and 9 o'clock, the body of a man was found on Fox Hill, N. J., and from the position of the body it would appear that he had committed suicide. He was shot through the head by a pistol, which must have caused instant death.

FOREFATHERS MONUMENT AT PLYMOUTH, MASS.--The Plyrouth Rock, June 23, says: The workmen are making good progress in laying the foundation of the Pilgrim Monument, some six hundred tons of Quincy granite being already embedded. The foundation itself comprises three tiers of stone, all laid in hydraulic cement. and as one after another the courses rise upon each other in solid masonry,

The most important arrest that has been made by the Police for some time was made on Thursday evening by Captain Dowling, and Officers Wooldridge and Journay, of the Sixth Precinct. Thomas Kelly and Thomas Hughes, two of the boldest, most reckless and most successful burglars whose names have appeared on the Police records of the City for years, were stealthily seized in the public street, disarmed and securely lodged in the Station house.

The War Department has issued general orders, with a view of enforcing the greatest possible economy in the military service, especially as to the conveyance and distribution of supplies. No buildings are to be erected, nor any extraordinary expense incurred, except by authority from the War Department. No persons shall be hired for purposes immediately connected with the troops, excepting the necessary guides and interpreters.

SOLDIERS OF THE REVOLUTIONARY WAR.--The Pension-Office had upon its rolls, on the 30th of June, 1858, the names of 253 revolutionary soldiers. Of this small remnant of heroes, information has been received that during the succeeding half year 46 went to their long account, leaving, upon the first day of the present year, 207 survivors. The ages of some of these soldiers are stated to have been 100 to 103 years.

To the Editor of the New- York Times: I observe that some correspondents of the NewYork Press have rather hastily represented the native African soldiers in the French Army as given to the bad practice of " drinking the blood of their foes" on the battle-field. Will you allow me, as formerly an inhabitant of Algiers-familiar with the people in question, and with their habits under arms-to refute this cruel calumny?

THE BOGUS INDIANA BANK CASE--THE OHIO LAW OF BANKS.--The Cincinnati Gazette. June 22, says: "The preliminary examination of N. H. WILLIAMS, the Hartford bogus banker, took place yesterday. Judge Low: held that the word "Bank" had a peculiar meaning in our statute, and referred only to such institutions as are recongnized by the law as banks, in other words, an incorporated, and not a private bank.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--Mr. DUBREUIL, the stage manager here, and an artist who never hesitates to make himself generally useful in the cause of the public, takes his first benefit to-day at the Academy in the form of a Matinee. The programme is extremely rich; the whole of " Ernani," and a concert, with FORMES, BRIGNOLI, In the opera we are to have GAZZANIGA, STEFANI, GHONE and GASPARONI.

PURCHASE OF FOREIGN VESSELS--LETTER FRO SECRETARY CASS.--The Baltimore Sun published the following letter from Secretary CASS: DEPAARTMENT OF STATE, WASHINGTON, June 20, 1859. To John THomson Maso, Esq., Collector of the Customs, Baltimore. SIR: Your letter of the 18th instant, with the copy of correspondence which accompanied it, has been received.

ASSAULT AND ROBBERY BY SAILORS.--TWO sailors, giving their names as Joseph Murphy and Michael Conlin, were yesterday arrested charged with assaulting and robbing Samuel Noonan, at 4 o'clock yesterday morning. The accused met Noonan in Pine street and demanded his money. Noonan refused to comply with their request, and thereupon they knocked him down, rifled his pockets and then fled.

One section of the Appropriation bill passed by our State Legislature, at its late session, set aside $50,000 with which the Quarantine Commissioners were to provide temporary accommodations for persons arriving in our port sick with yellow fever or other pestilential disease, and also to arrange for removing and taking care of all the sick from the hospitals at Castleton.

THE WINANS STEAMER.--This vessel, an account of whose sinking appeared in the edition of yesterday, has been successfully raised, and yesterday a party of men were engaged in putting everything in order in the interior. The machinery was not injured in the least, nor did the hull suffer by the mishap.

THE PIKE'S PEAK GOLD.--The following is an extract from a private letter, received by a gentleman in this City: LEAVENWORTH, Friday, June 10, 1859. There will be another tide of emigration to Pike's Peak and vicinity within a few weeks, as every day we are getting reliable news in confirmation of the existence of gold there in sufficiency to compensate miners well for their labor.

Mr. Gilbert A. Grant, formerly State Senator in Cailfornia, has sued the San Francisco Evening Buietin for libel, laying his damages at $50,000. The offensive article contained some unfavorable comments upon Mr. Grant's course in reference to the famous "Bulkhead bill."

The following editorial article appears in Saturday's Constitution. It may be regarded as the Administration comment upon the Presidential letter of Senator DOUGLAS:- "We publish to-day, in another column, a letter written by Senator DOUGLAS to a gentleman in Iowa,

A FOOL AND HIS FEAR.--A being, probably an ape, but whose keepers call him by the rather human name of "Montieur BLONDIN," it is publicly announced will walk on Thursday next across the chasm below Niagara Falls, upon a rope stretched from bank to bank for that purpose.

ARRIVAL OF THE STEAMSHIP EMPIRE CITY. The Empire City Left New. Orleane at 8 A. M. on the 20th inst. and entered Havana harbor at sunrise on the 23d, embarked passengers, mails and fright, and left at 2 P. M. the same say for this part. Left in port American steamer Galveston, from Propeller Commerce, from Baltimore, and British steamer Feriot, from st. Thomas.

KAZINSKY--JOHNSON.--In this City, on Thursday evening, June 5, at No. 243 50th-st., by the Rev. Robert Lowry, Count LOUIS KAZINSKY, of this City, to Mrs. AMELTA F. JOHNSON, only daughter of the late Samuel Prior Esq., of Ovster Bay, L. I.

COLLEGE COMMENCEMENTS.--Commencement week at Princeton begins to day, At 11 o'clock this morning, the annual oration before the two Literary Societies will be delivered by the Rev. Dr. McHVAINE,, of Rochester. At 12 o'clock, the annual meetings of the American Whig and Cliosophic Societies will take place at their respective Halls; and at 8 P. M the Junior Orations will be delivered.

The steamship Nova Scotian, from Liverpool on Wednesday, the 15th inst., passed this point at 4 1/2 o'clock this afternoon, on her way to Quebec. The steamship North American, from Quebec 4th inst., arrived at Liverpool on the 14th, The steamship City of Baltimore, from New-York 4th inst., arrived at Queenstown on the 14th.

LAURA KEENE'S THEATRE.--The burlesque of "Massaniello," tortured from the opera by the Brothers BROUGH, and modestly localized by a gentleman of this City, was produced here last night, with decided success. The GOUGENHEIN Sisters are addicted to this species of composition, and seem willing to stake their chances of success on the public appreciation of their efforts.

The Rev. R. S. MACLAY, one of the Methodist Missionaries in China, concludes a letter dated Fah Chau, April 6, with the following: "Two events of great significance in the political world have recently been noticed in the 'Pekin Gazette,' the organ of the Imperial Government in China. One is the announcement that henceforth Shanhai is to supercede Canton as the centre of foreign negotiations with China.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In a notice of my translation of LOUIS NAPOLEON'S political work, entitled "Napoleonic Ideas," printed in your edition of this day, you make a remark calculated to mislead and to injure.

A GERMAN ISRAZLITE ON THE WAR IN EUROPE. The Cincinati Israclite, whose editor, Dr. WISE, is a German, is indignant at the German sympathy for Austria. He says: "But, as a Garman, we can sympathize only with Italy and France in this struggle as KOBBUTH, VOOT, KLAIRA, GARIBALDI, and even the as KOBBUTH, VOOT, KLAIRA, GARIBALDI, and even the Democrats of Vienna do.

SPEECH BY GOVERNOR BANKS. Yesterday, at the invitation of the Board of Governors, Governor BANKS, of Massachusetts, who is in this City, temporarily, made a tour of inspection of our Island Institutions, The party which accompanied him was quite select.

General HOUSTON having been requested by a number of citizens of Texas to express his views of the American Party, replied in the foliowing letter: INDEPENDENCE, Texas, July 24, 1855. GENTLEMAN: Your letter ot yesterday's date was presented to me early in the afternoon.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: You will please correct the statement in your Law Report of the proceedings in the Court of General Sessions of Saturday, published in this day's edition of the TIMES, that "WILLIAM H. KIMBALL pleaded guilty to stealing some money from a fellow student in the Theological Seminary."

Mr. DUNDAS, head of the Contract Office, Postoffice Department, is just now cutting down postal service in some of the Southwestern States, and, as fast as time will permit, the process will be carried out generally, upon the principle of reduction established by acceptance of contracts for service at the recent lettings for the Atlantic States south of Maryland.

The past week has been one of unusual excitement, a variety of incidents having occurred to disturb the usual quiet of this city. Whit-Monday was celebrated as usual by the Germans, who assembled for the purpose at one of the Gardens, and, inasmuch as it is one of the annual holiday seasons for the colored population, country negrodom was largely represented in town,

DEMAREST--In this City, on Monday morning, June 27. SUSAN VAN WAGENON, youngest daughter of Heary and Margaret Demareat, aged 5 years and 6 months. The friends and relatives of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, on Wednesday. 29th inst., at 3 o'clock, without further invitation, from No. 49 West 33d-st.

Mr. Nicholas Longworth, the veteran vine-grower in Cincinnati, recently declined an invitation to participate in a railroad opening celebration, in the following curt terms: DEAR SIR: Young Jerseymen are fond of traveling on railroads, whore no charge is made. I therefore regret that I cannot accept the invitation to visit Chicago. The absence of my son and son-in-law deprives me of the pleasure of visiting that flourishing city.

Tile English at Hong Kong are complaining, and not altogether without reason, that while the American merchantmen are rapidly monopolizing the carrying trade with China, the English men-of-war should be expected to do police duty for these successful interlopers.
An expose by the Harbor Master of the Eighth District in relation to the controversy now existing between himself and the Agent of the Savannah line of steamers.

From the Chicago Press and Tribune. We have received copies of the Leavenworth Times of the 21st, and the Rocky Mountain News extra of the 11th inst. From the Times we learn that the Pike's Peak Express reached Leavenworth on the 20th, in eight days from Denver City, bringing $2,500 IN dust on consignment.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The New-York Herald of June 18, inst., reported a correspondence of the London Star, which, alluding to the then believed defeat of GARIBALDI, insinuated that all his successes, in his former campaigns, were entirely due to a Colonel Hugues Forbes, a cool-headed Englishman, who formerly lived upon ample means at Vienna and took part in the Italian Revolution of 1848 and '49.

On the Ist inst. the legislature of this State was opened by Governor ALSINA in person. His Message, which is a straightforward and statesmanlike document, gives us a true account of the extraordinary advance of this country, the only point of South America which enjoys a truly Republican rule.

It has been the custom hitherto for the City Inspector's Department to pay its bills for work done by the day, at the Essex Market office, the money having been received from the Comptroller upon requisition. It has not been the custom, however, to pay promptly or punctually.

FLOUR dull and heavy ; sales 600 bbls., at $6 87 1/2@7 12 for extra, and $7 25@$ 75 for double extra, Michigan, Indiana and Ohio. WHEAT dull, and no sales of moment. CORN firm ; sales 4,000 bush., at 74c. for Illinois ; 73c. for Toledo. OATS nominal, at 42c. for Western. BARLEY and RYE quiet. WHISKY steady ; sales 100 bbls., at 25c.

A three-day's German Festival was begun yesterday in Jones' Woods, under the auspices of the Steuben Monument Association, the object, as set forth in the advertisement, being to aid the fund for the erection of a monument to Baron STEUBEN, of Revolutionary memory. The proceedings were under the management of the Steuben Central Committee' who have already some $3,000 in hand for this object:

VICIOUS ANIMALS AT LARGE.--Improbable as it may appear, a Coroner's Jury has done its duty at last. A child in the street at Albany was kicked by a horse--a bad horse, whose vicious propensities his owner knew,--and so severely injured that in a few minutes the little fellow died.

There were no public sales to-day. Messrs. RAYNOR and BLACKWELL have sold four lots on the northeast corner of One Hundred and Twenty-second-street and Tenth-avenue, at $350@ lot. Also, seven lots on the north Side of One Hundred and Twenty-second-street, 100 feet east of Tenth-avenue, at $225@ lot.

A FITTING SACRIFICE.--Let the whole City heartily rejoice! The City Hall is on the point of demolition. They are planting platforms around it, digging mines beneath it, preparing fire and gunpowder to blast it withal; and on the Fourth of July next it will be blown to atoms, that not one stone shall be left upon another.

If we can put any confidence in the war news, which is fabricated at Berne and Vienna for the western markets, the Emperor FRANCIS JOSEPH has really assumed the command of his armies in Italy, and is organizing them as rapidly as possible behind the lines of the Oglio and the Adige, to await the attack of his advancing enemies.

Shortly after 9 o'clock last night, a murder of an exceedingly cold-blooded and atroeious character was perpetrated on Second-street, neat the end of the new Birmingham bridge, in the Eighth Ward. The victim was the well-known MARY DELANY, and her murderer RICHARD JONES, Constable of the Sixth Ward, her husband.
