We have advices from Europe one day later, by the arrival of the steamship Nova Scotian at Further Point, on her way to Quebec. She sailed from Liverpool on the 15th inst. There had been no further collision between the belligerent forces in Italy, but the news is nevertheless quite important.

BROOKLYN COMMON COUNCIL.--A meeting of this body was held last evening. A communication from the Fire Commissioners, proposing a plan to reorganize the Fire Department, was referred to the Joint Board.

Among other reforms suggested by Collector SCHELL is the renting out of public Warehouses to private individuals. Messrs. MATHER and BIXBY, of the firm of MATHER, McINTIRE BIXBY, are pressing their proposition to take the Warehouses for a specified sum, and do all the public business, including carting,

Twice within six weeks of the Italian campaign of 2859, it has been the fortune of the French army under NAPOLEON III. to win brilliant victories on spots already consecrated in the annals of French glory.

SAD TERMINATION OF A LONG LIFE.--A few evenings since, two Third Precinct Policemen discovered a very old man lying among a heap of rabbise, upon one of the docks near the Washington Market, in a fit. They convoyed him to the Stationhouse, where he died in agony a few minutes afterwards, though Police Surgeon KENNEDY was almost immediately present, and rendered all possible aid,

The latest eccentricity of Mexican politics is the capture of a Government conduct of five millions of dollars, on its way from the capital to the seaboard. This feat was accomplished, the telegraph informs us, by Gen. OBLES-PEZUELA, some forty miles from the city.

Of course, Princeton is in a feverish state of excitement, mentally and physically. The weather, which is swelteringly hot, produces the latter result, and the fact that it is Commencement Week at Nassau Hall sufficiently accounts for the former. Even last night the hotels were filled, and this morning they are overflowing with the influx of strangers from Newark, New-York, Philadelphia, and elsewhere.

While we have been wondering what they severally would do with it all, the Commissioners for Quarantine Removal have labored, day and night, until we are enabled to announce that the Quarantine Hospitals have been removed. Not the hospitals themselves, nor the physicians, nurses, orderlies, and doorkeepers that watch over them, but the patients are all gone,--with one solitary exception, and that one sim. ply an oversight.

A day or two since we published the statement of Mrs. RACHEL A. BENNETT, of Philadelphia, against whom her husband, JOSEPH M. BENNETT, has brought a suit for divorce. Mr. BENNETT has put in a rejoinder to his wife's statement, which develops some curious points. He declares that the common scandal about his wife's infidelity, which came to his ears, seriously affected his health; and then proceeds:

A highly interesting case, as an illustration of the uncertainty of circumstantial and even positive evidence, is presented in the following statement in connection with the arrest, about a year ago, o?? a young man named EDWARD GRIFFITH, who was arrested, and convicted, and sentenced for ten years to the State Prison for shooting a private watchman in Brooklyn.

The moral victory which has been won by NAPOLEON III. in England may well be regarded as the first fruits of his clear, resolute and magnanimous policy on the question of Italy. Its gravity and extent may be measured by the cohesive force it has exerted upon those scattered elements of English Liberalism, which nothing but such a crisis as this which the French Emperor has evolved, could possibly have compelled into harmony and coalition.

From our West Indian correspondent, to whose very clear, fresh and interesting accounts of the state of things in the emancipaled English islands, we have before invited the attention of our readers, we publish to-day a strikingly suggestive picture of the state of feeling in Barbados between the white and colored population of---that- old and flourishing colony.

A train on the Michigan Southern Railroad was thrown from the track, last night, by the washing away of a culvert, and twenty or thirty persons are reported to have been killed. Particulars will be obtained as soon as possible. CHICAGO, Tuesday, June 28-P. M. The accident on the Michigan Southern Railroad, last night, occurred rear South Bend, Indiana.

There is a faith that removes mountains, though it is seldom put on exhibition in these latter days. Quite as rare and unlooked-for a phenomenon is a Commission that removes Quarantine. But we have one at last. In January, 1859, Gov. MORGAN, with the advice and consent of the Senate, appointed GEORGE PATTERSON, HORATIO SEYMOUR and JOHN C. GREEN a Board of Commissioners, under the act of 1857, for the removal of Quarantine.

ALBANY AND RICHMOND.--There is a degree of discordance between the Democratic organs at Albany and at Richmond. The E??irer, published at the latter capital, is in favor of WISE; the Atlas and Argus, published at Albany is not. On the contrary, quite otherwise. Naturally enough, therefore, the latter paper holds the former very cheap indeed.

AN APPEAL FOR THE FOURTH WARD COFFEE ROOM.--COFFEE AND READING ROOM IN THE FOURTH WARD--This genial resort for young men is now open and well attended. The experiment promises well. There is much desire for intellectual improvement among them, and the readers more numerous than might have been expected.

From the London Spectator. An interesting problem has been opened in our general relations with the French Government, and it is one which is not likely to be left at rest by that Government, it our own should not procure a satisfactory solution. A proprietor of the East India Company has publicly notified that he shall call attention to the case, with a sufficiently practical object.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: If calamities the most appalling call fix men's attention long enough to be really useful, and the perisbing of thousands excite alarm sufficiently durable, to be efficient in providing measures of safety to such as "go down to the sea in ships," then may it be said truly that dreadful evils result in good.

There are four men in the City Prison, in Center-street, at present, under sentence of death,--JAMES SHEPHERD, convicted of arson in the first degree, JAMES STEPHEN'S, convicted of poisoning his wife; QU??MEO APPO, the Chinaman, convicted of stabbing his landlady, and FELIX SANCHEZ, the Cuban negro, convicted of stabbing his wife's father. SHEPHERD has been nearly eighteen months in prison since his conviction.

MORTON.--In this City, on Tuesday afternoon, June 28. MARGARET A., wife of Robert Marton, in the 40th year of her age. Notice of the funeral to-morrow. DUSENBEREY.--In this City, on Tuesday, June 28, EMMA, daughter of Stephen W. Dusenberry, aged 17 years,. 6 months and 20 days.

As visitors do not come to Saratoga for the sake of enjoying rain water, the weather of the past three weeks did not have the effect of filling all our hotels with guests. But such are the attractions of the place, that a very large number of visitors have dropped in, notwithstanding the coolness and dampness of the reason.

We have published the account given by the New-Orleans Delta, of the sudden disappearance of one DURYEE, late a commission merchant in that city, with a record of sundry alleged swindles to which he was a party. The Rochester Union of Monday publishes the following indignant epistle from DURYEE, who appears to be living at his ease in this city.

A YOUNG WIFE MURDERED BY HER HUSBAND. The quiet locality of Willington, Conn., was thrown into a state of great excitement on Saturday, by the discovery of a brutal murder, which seems to have been cremated about the 2d of June. The victim was a young married woman, Mrs. JOHN WARREN. formerly of Beichertown, Mass. The murderer was her husband, who is only 21 years old. The young wife was but 18.

WARD-HARRIS--In this City, on Tuesday, June 23, at the Memorial Church, by the Rev. W,. St Frost, ELLIAM WARD to Miss. MARY HARRIS, both of this City. SACKETT--BERTINE--In this City, on Tuesday, June 23, by the Rev. B. M. Adams, Mr. GUERNSEY SACKEETT and Miss GERTRUDE R. BERTINE, daughter of Robert Bertine, Esq., all of this City.

HOMICIDE IN THE FOURTH WARD--A SAILOR BOARDING-HOUSE KEEPER KILLED.--A homicide occurred yesterday afternoon in the Fourth Ward. James Boston, keeper of a sailors' boarding and lodging house, at No. 44 Baxter street, was stabbed by Richard A. Eddy, a sailor, and instantly killed. Eddy returned a few days since from sea, having been shipped, as he alleges, six months ago, while intoxicated, by Boston, who retained his advance money.

To the Reverends M. Mahan, D. D. E. A. Hoffmann, Jos F. Garrison, M. D., Abm. Browning, Esq., R. J. Fuid. Esq. REVIREND OZZTHEEN AND GENTLEMEN: Your official communication, announcing to me my election, Unanimously of ??, as Bishop of New-Jersey, by the Seventy-sixth Annual Convention of that Diocese, has receives my most serious consideration.

A NEW AUTOMATION CHESS-PLAYER.--A respectable audience, not too large for the season, was last night assembled at Clinton Hall, for the purpose of exercising its wits upon a new Automaton claimant for the honors of PHILODOR and MORPHY. It would probably be of no use for us to point out the impossibility of automatic chess-playing, as distinguished from automatic singing, or hornpipe-dancing, or trumpet-blowing.

COURT OF APPEALS, JUNE 28. 1859.--Nos. 82, 83 --Lathrop vs. Scott ; same vs. Pier, argued ; J. H. Reynolds for appellant ; J. K. Porter for respondent. Judgement affirmed, with five per cent, damages. No. 64--Wolf vs. Howes , argued ' T. Jenkins for appellant ' F. Kernan for respondent. No. 85--Marvin vs. Jarvis, argued ; D. S. Dickinson for appellant ; Robert Parker for respondent.

EMIGRATION FROM LOUISIANA TO HAYTL--The New-Orleans Delta says: " Large parties of free persons of color have lately, at intervals, emigrated to Port-an-Prince, in Haytl, for the purpose of there setting. They carry cut with them farming implements, goods, a goodly quantity of the "rhino." and all the necessary articles to constitute a settlement.

The United States mail steamship Granada, JEFFERSON MAURY, Commander, arrived here yesterday morning, having left Aspinwall early on the morning of the 10th of June, with 350 passengers for NewYork and New Orleans. The Granada arrived at Key West on the evening of the 23d, at 7 o'clock. After having coaled and disembarked her NewOrleans passengers and mails, left again at 4 o'clock the following morning.

SUPREME COURT--Circuit.--Part I.--Adjourned for the Term. Part II.--Calendar same as yesterday. SUPERIOR COURT.--Numbers same as yesterday, except such cases as were yesterday tried. COMMON PLEAS.--Gneral Term. SUPREME COURT--CHAMBERS. Before Justice Roosevelt Mutter of David J. Osborn.--This irregular case came up again to-day.

The Royal Mail steamship Arabia, from Liver. pool on Saturday, the 18th inst., with three days' later news from Europe, arrived at Halifax at noon yesterday, but owing to the scandalous telegraphic arrangements in Nova Scotia, the public were kept in ignorance of her advices, while they were being made use of by speculators.

Of all the deliberately false (as we have the best of reasons for believing,) and wickedly mischievous articles ever connected in that notorious den of iniquity--the New-York Herald office--the editorial which appeared in the issue of that journal of Thursday, relating to the reconciliation of the President and the Hon. ROBERT J. WALKER, is the most atrocious.

RAISING SUNKEN VESSELS AT SEBASTOPOL.-One of the parties engaged in raising the Russian ships sunk at Sebastopol, writes to a friend in Boston in reference to the progress of the work: "I have raised whole, 13 or 14 steamers and vessels of various sizes, and broken to pieces and removed 14 or 15 more, and the work goes bravely on, and will continue to a successful completion.

Among the early discoveries of Mr. KIRKPATRICK, when he entered upon his duties as agent and Warden of the Auburn Prison, was the fact that his predecessor had failed to receive an adequate compensation for imprisoning, supporting, and outfitting when discharged, the convicts which had been sentenced to confinement there by the Federal Court of the Northern District of New-York.

From the Newark Mercury. The following extract from a letter received in this city from a Newarker now residing in Walnut Creek, Parker County, Texas, gives some information which will be new to the great majority of our readers. It seems that the Indians on the Reserve are continually making depredations, and then retreating upon their own territory.

The British steamer Medway, with Mons. BELLY on his return trip to France, came in from San Juan on the 18th. The little Frenchman, finding his draft were returned protested, determined to pay a visit to France in person, in order to raise the needful. Some malicious persons say that this schemer never will return, and that is without doubt the finale of the Canal project.

From the St. Louis Republican. Tile Santa Fe Mail has just arrived with later dates from New-Mexico. The news brought is of an interesting character. There is great likelihood of a renewal of warlike difficulties with the Navajo tribes of Indians, with whom the United States Government was at war only a few months ago, and concluded by formal treaty.

Bids have been received by the Common Council of New-Orleans for the construction of City Railroads; New-Orleans thus following the example of other cities. The Picayune indorses the project with great warmth. It says: "The experiment of street railroads in other cities has astonished even those who Invested in their stock. Travel has been increased beyond all expectation.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In your issue of this morning you publish an article, headed "Stopping a Leak," in which you erroneously state that it has been, heretofore, the custom of the City Inspector's Department to pay its bills for labor, the money therefor being drawn from the Comptroller, upon requisition. This is untrue.

Captain AMOS PILSBURY, the newly elected General Superintendent of Police, yesterday entertained the Commissioners of Emigration and a party of invited guests at a farewell dinner given at his residence on Ward;s Island, upon the occasion of his resigning his charge of the Institutions to assume the duties of the Police Department.

Within the past few weeks the firm of SETBBINS, HOYT Co., domestic dry goods merchants at No. 152 Chambers-street, became convinced that portions of their stock were being clandestinely removed in some manner and by some one to them unknown, Private investigation proved for a time insufficient to unravel the mystery, but it appeared pretty plain that the goods must have been taken from the store after it had been closed for the day.

I have come down to see these "ruined" Islands, and to learn why St. Vincent and her Grenadine Dependencies, which, before emancipation, exported on an average twenty five million pounds of sugar, should now export only sixteen and seventeen millions, and why the sugar exporiations of Grenada have fallen away from twenty-two millions to something less than one-half of that amount.

The R. M. steamship Arabia, Captain STONE, from Liverpool on Saturday, the 18th inst., arrived at Halifax at noon to day, en route for Boston, where she will be due to-morrow (Wednesday) night. The following brief summary of her news is all which has yet come to hand: THE WAR IN ITALY. The news from the seat of war is highly important.

SUPREME COURT--CIRCUIT--Part I.--Adjourned for the Term. Part II.--Calendar same as Monday, except such cases as since tried. SUPERIOR COURT--(Snort Causes)--Same as Monday, except such cases as since tried.

Although the United States declined being a party to the Paris Conference, I have good reason for believing that they will soon be admitted to the enjoyment of all the benefits arising therefrom-at leas during the present war in Europe. The only point of objection on our part to the Paris Conference was the Privaterring question, which at present is practically unimportant.

For the fourth time since the 1st of June, Summer has set in, and this time with so general a blossoming out of thin coats, straw hats, and lace mantillas, that probably there will be no more relapses till the leaves begin to fall. The hegira must soon commence. Those who tarry in the streets another week will find themselves in the midst of the annual bombardment of the City by armies of boys...

INQUESTS.--Coroners SNELL and HORTON held the following inquests yesterday: on the body of FREDERICK M. GIBBONS, barber, at No. 213 Adamestreet, who died from the effects of poison (supposed to have been laudanum), on Tuesday night, which was administered by himself. The deceased had been in a desponding mood for several days, and gave due notice of his intention to poison himself.

The American steamship Washington is here, and sails to-morrow for California via Panama. She has been here ten days. Dr. PERKINS leaves her. She has advertised for $14,000 on bottomry. ?? McLAUGELIN lost his life off Coronet, south of this fall into the sea and could not be recovered. B. T. HOPPER, passenger, was killed at that portia an affrey on shore.

The Chamber of Commerce had a special meeting yesterday, ROYAL PHELPS, Esq., presiding, to hear and consider the report of its Committee, appointed some months since to consider the subject of Quarantime. MR. TILESTON (of the firm of STOFFORD TILESTON) read the report, which was as follows: REPORT.

The American Express Company, Agents for the Galway line of steamers, last evening received telegraphic dispatches from Newfoundland announcing that the steamer Argo had gone ashore near Cape Race in a dense fog. The following are copies of the dispatches: TEEPASSEY BAY, N. F.. Tuesday, June 28.

Further details of the important intelligence brought by the Arabia at Halifax reached us yesterday. All accounts indicate that another great battle would be fought in a very short time. The Allies passed the River Serio on the 13th towards the River Oglio, and at last advices their advanced guard was at Coccoaglio, and the headquarters of the King of Sardinia was at Palazzuolo,

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The late researches of Prof. HETET, of the school of Medicine of Toulon, France, on the medicinal effects of the Ailanthus Glandulosa, of China, now so common among us as a shade-tree, at the same time that they establish its claim as one of the best antidotes for the toenia would also satisfy the most sceptical of its unfitness to ornament our residences.

MARIAGE OF THE HON. RECORDER BARNARD.-The Reformed Dutch Church. corner of Fifth-avenue and Twenty-first street, wag the scene of unuaual interest yesterday morning. The occasion was the marriage of the lion. G. G. BARNARD, Recolder of this City, to Miss FARDIE A. ANDERSON, the accomplished daughter of the eminent and wealthy tobacconist of that name.

The following extract is from the official circular sent me by the Hon. LEWIS CASS, Secretary of State:

UNITED STATES MARINES. - The Secretary of the Navy has directed that double rations shall not hereafter be allowed to marine officers commanding guards of the receiving ships at Boston, New-York and Norfolk; nor to the marine officer in command of the guard at the Navy-Yard gate in the city of Washington, D.C.

FURTHER ISSUE OF CENTRAL PARK STOCK--MISCELLANEOUS BUSINESS. The Mayor sent a Message to the Board of Aldermen last evening, in which he assigns his reasons for declining to approve the appointment of any more Commissioners of Deeds; he says there are 340 persons exercising the duties of the office in this City, while by law only 300 are allowed.

To-day Capt. PILSBURY takes his place as Superintendent of Police. It is no reflection upon but rather a compliment to the Commissioners who have secured his services and endowed him with ample powers, to add that we expect to see henceforth a new order of things in and about the Department.

THE STATE PAPER.-The long legal controversy between the Albany Evening Journal and the Albany Atlas and Argus, as to which of the twain is entitled by law to print the words "State paper" under its title, and to receive the emoluments thence accruing, and variously estimated at from $8,000 to $20,000 per annum, was terminated on Thursday in favor of the Atlas and Argus, by a unanimous decision of the Court of Appeals.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In your paper of to-day, you declare war against Ailanthus. Thousands and tens of thousands of New-York citizens will thank you for it. Do keep it up till the infernal, stinking, poisonous thing is extirpated, root and branch. New-York is wicked.

The intelligence brought from Southampton by the Vande, bilt on the 22d ult., is not of decisive importance. The Croton Aqueduct Department enjoys the distinguished reputation of being honest. At times, every other limb ot the Municipal Government has been charged with corruptionthis never. It lives close up to its rules,teats its regulations as if they were Median and Persian laws, and religiously conforms to them.

ALLEGED WIFE MURDER--A man named CHRISTIAN McQRADE ??, was arrested, yesterday, by Captain ?? and Officer GRIFFITH, of the Fifth Precinct on suspicion of having caused the death of his wife, at 12 1/2 o'clock yesterday by beating her. An investigation will be held to-day. The accused resides at No. 2 Broadway.

FOR ASSESSMENT ROLLS AND THE LEGALITY OF THE APPOINTMENT OF THE NEW TAX COMMISSIONERS. THE QUESTION OF THE SOUTH--The Hon. ALEXANDRA H. STEPHENS is unquestionably one of the shrewdest and sharpest men ever sent by the South to Congress. On Saturday, at an ovation given him in the city of Augusta, he made a two hours' speech. As a matter of course, it was ultra Southern in every thought, word, and aspiration.

THE ALLEGED SLAVERS.--The cargo of the bark Orion was, yesterday, entirely discharged, under the direction of the Government, the object being to discover, if possible, some proof that she was intended for the slave trade. Everything, however, came out according to the ?? and invoices. The "irons," which were carefully searched for, could not be found.

CELEBRATION BY THE GERMAN "GRWERBEVABRIN" IN NEW-YORK.--Not the least interesting and suggestive of the celebrations of the Fourth of July was that by the "Gewerbe Verein," a German Society of the Industrial Arts, incorporated by the Legislature last Winter. The fete was arranged and carried out by Germans exclusively, and is one of many proofs that the American national spirit is making its way among that class of our population.

The bursting of the boiler of the steamer Bay State, of the Fall River line, on her way up the East River on Monday last, has resulted in the death of two persons, Mr. GEORGE F. ARNOLD, a passenger, and Mr. EDWARD H. LAWRENCE, Second Assistant Engineer. They both died at Bellevue Hospital on Tuesday evening, whither they had been taken soon after the accident occurred.

HERALDIC GEOGRAPHY.--Heraldic Zoology, as all the world knows, is a very quaint and licentious science, paying small reverence to genera and species, and making a mock of all laws, alike of form and color. Its categories are not to be disturbed by double-headed eagles, scarlet lions, pea-green human savagesor three-tailed snakes.

The kidnapping cases of JACOB K. LOWE, DANIEL DAVIE, ANDERSON JENNINGS and RICHARD P. MITCHELL are set for to-day in the Lorain Common Pleas. JENNINGS, MITCHELL and BACON, the Kentucky slave-owner and catchers, have been in this quarter and Canada for some days, making thorough search by agents and otherwise in the Queen's free dominions for the rescued JOHN.

ANOTHER MEXICAN MYSTERY.--Decidedly Mexico is the land of marvels. Its politics are not so stupendous as those of Europe, but they are quite as startling. It was but the other day that an Ex-Envoy of Mexico at Washington, Gen. ROBLES, stopped a convoy of specie on the highway, and "conveyed away" five millions of dollars.

A DEATH IN BROOKLYN FROM YELLOW FEVER.--On the 29th of June the brig John Boynton, from Port-au-Prince, arrived at this port with a cargo of coffee and logwood. According to the Health Officer's report to the Board of Health, the Captain had been several days ill with bilious fever, and one of the crew was down " with a fever of doubtful character."

The Fifth Annual Convention of the American Normal School Association will assemble in the new ball of the Normal School at Trenton, N. J. on Wednesday and Thursday, the 17th and 18th of August next. The Convention will be addressed by the lion. GEORGE S. BOUTWELL, Secretary of the Massachusetts Board of Education, and it is also expected that an address will be delivered by the Hon. HOEACE MANN, President of Antioch College, Ohio.

THE WHEAT CROP IN MICHIGAN.-At last we have some definite knowledge of the wheat crop in Michigan , and are happy to be able to congratulate our readers that neither the late untimely frosts, the doleful croaking of unscrupulous bulls, nor the anxious fears of nervous agriculturists, have had any effect in defeating our hopes of an abundant harvest.

Some of our cotemporaries in the rural districts are expending a good deal of sympathy upon our religious destitution during hot weather, and this upon the assumption that during the dog-days we have little or no preaching.

Sumner is the season for departures and arrivals, and in Paris the streets and shops are full of bustle. Women on the eve of going to compete their purchases the new comers to replenish their wardrobes the heat obliges everybody to make some change and whichever way you turn, the scene is animated and lively.

J. M. COOPER, a special messenger from the office of the Attorney-General of the United States, arrived in this city yesterday, bringing to United States Marshal FREEMAN an official document, signed by the President, commuting the sentence against CYSUS W. PLUMER to imprisonment for life.

BURNING OF A FAT-MELTING ESTABLISHMENT, $13,000--The fat-melting establishment of Mr. JOHN J. EOKEL, located in Forty-fifth-street, near First-avenue, was totally destroyed by fire about 8 A. The Rev. A. KINGMAN NOTT, Pastor of the First Baptist Church of this City, in Broome-street, was drowned at noon, on Thursday, while bathing in the surf at Perth Amboy, N. J. He had gone to that place on Wednesday to preach, by invitation of the Rev. Mr. KING.

The express train, due here at 3:30 yesterday afternoon, ran off the track about a mile this side of the Oneida station. We saw the conductor, Mr. YATES, last evening, and learned from him the following particulars: At the place of the accident there was an embankment about 15 feet high. The engine, tender, baggage car, and smoking-car, kept the track.

BROOKLYN FINDS A CHAMPION.--There is an old quarrel between New-York and Brooklyn, which dates back to "the beginning." NewYork claims, under the Dongan and Montgomerie Charter, that her boundary terminates on the Brooklyn side of the river at high-water mark, and of course that the right to run a ferry to Long Island, opposite the City, resides only in her.

THE PROSECUTION RELINQUISHED--SCENES AT THE JAIL. The Oberlin Rescuers were all released from imprisonment at Cleveland on Wednesday, July 5, the Government entering the plea of noli contendere. The Morning Leader says:

A Penang paper states that the Nutmeg crop is a failure. The death of the trees is going on to such an alarming extent, that it is calculated there will riot be a single Nutmeg tree left in the island in the course of ten years hence. A Singapore journal add:

The late excessively warm weather which has decimated the population of our dusty cities, has driven an immense crowd of pleasure seekers to this favorite Summer resort, and the Old Hygeia is now crowded with a gay throng of visitors from all parts of the country.

In accordance with an order just issued by the Secretary of War, a Board of Officers will assemble at Fort Monroe, Va., on Tuesday, the 12th inst., or as soon thereafter as practicable, for the trial of such rifled cannon as may be presented by the Ordnance Department.

INDIAN TROUBLES IN UTAH.--The Indian Office have received intelligence from the Indian Agencies of Utah of date May 30. The Utahs, to the number of 400, had assembled at Spanish Fork Reservation, where Superintendent FORNEY has an Indian farm, conducted on the principle of " no work, no bread," which has been a decided success.

We are now in July. The sun has scaled his meridian height and looks down with a fervid power that oppresses while it lasts. Summer has indeed arrived, and we are no longer to be tantalized by its coming and then being withdrawn.

Before Commissioner Morton. Charles Brown and John Vane, seamen on board the ship Anneli Own, sent home by the Consul at Neuvitas, Caba, charged with revolt and mutiny, were brought before Commissioner MORTON. They were committed to await the action of the Grand Jury.

It is now understood here that the Russian Government wholly repudiates the Perkins claim as entirely without merit, there being no proof whatever of any contract. Official advices just received here reiterate the opinion that the European war will become general.

The morning Express train on the New-York Central railroad ran off the track on Thursday morning at eleven o'clock, one mile east of Oneida, while going at the rate of forty miles an hour, throwing all the passenger cars off the track, demolishing three of them, and seriously injuring an old lady and two young ladies, whose names could not be ascertained, besides wounding twenty or thirty others.
SENATOR DOOLITTLE'S VIEWS OF THE NEGRO QUESTION.--The orator of the day at Buffalo, on the 4th inst, was the Hon. JAMES R. DOOLITTLE, Senator in Congress from the State of Wisconsin.

The President visited Georgetown College on Commencement Day, (July 6,) and distributed the medals awarded to the successful students. The Constitution is very jubilant over this circumstance seeing in it another evidence " of the cheerful readi ness with which President Buchanan, amidst his numerous pressing engagements, appropriates his time and attention to these academic celebrations."

To the Editor of the Ne- York Timnes: Pennit me to make through the columns of your valuable journal a few remarks in regard to the funeral services to be held by the Germans of this City in honor of the late Baron vot IHUMBOLDT, on bMonday, the Ilth inst.

The stated meeting of the Managers was held at the Bible House, Astor-place, on Thursday, the 7th instant, at 41/2 o'clock P. M.; WM. B. CROSBY, Esq., in the chair. One new auxiliary was recognized, which is in Tennessee. Communications were presented from agents and friends of the cause, showing the progress of the work at home, In various parts of the country;

A counterfeiter named Joseph C. Lloyd was arrested at Wyanootie, MICR., July 6, on a charge of complicity with a gang of counterfeiters in Essex County. N. Y. Some months since, a gang of silver coin counterfeiter, were broken in upon in that county, and some of them arrested, including a man named Farnsworth.

GOVERNMENTAL ECONOMY--REDUCTION IN THE PENSION OFFICE.--The Constitution, July 8, says: "It has been generally known for some months past that the di diminution the business of the Pensioa Bureau would, about the present period, require a corresponding reduction of its clerical force;
A NEW COUNTERFEIT.-For a week past a number of well executed counterfeit bills, of the denomimation of $5, on the Stissing Bank, Pine Plains, N. Y., .have been passed in this City.

This day being the birth-day of her most gracious Majesty Queen VICTORIA, I am writing this amid a deafening salute from all the foreign men-of-war in port, who are thus demonstrating their emotions at "the day we celebrate."

THE SUNDAY LIQUOR "REMONSTRANCE"--It has been ascertained at the Police Office that of the 446 names signed with their residences to the American edition of the "Remonstrance" against closing the rum-shops on Sunday, that 38 are liquor dealers and confectioners, 118 live in New. Jersey, Long Island and other out-of-town places,

Unless very weary with life it is always pleasant to a man to fancy that he will be talked about after he is gone. Hence he gives the greater part of his life to the consideration of a monument of some sort to perpetuate his memory after death.

SHIPMENT OF THE MEXICAN SPECIE.--We understand that the agent at Vera Cruz had assurances, before the steamer left, that the Mexican specie belonging t American merchants, $800, 000, brought down by the late conducia, should be shipped to this port by the steamship Tennessee. There is indeed, no other way in which it canbe brought here in safety.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Will you oblige several members of the Twelfth Regiment by publishing the following remarks upon "Special Orders No. 106," published in the NEW-YORK TIMES of the 6th, from the Commander in-Chief, disbanding the Twelfth Regiment--with the extra-official orders added from Gens. SANDFORD and EWING:

ACCIDENT TO THE HON. SILAS SEYMOUR, LATE STATE ENGINEER OF THE STATE OF NEW-YORK. - He was going to the Plermont boat, foot of Harrison-street, on Wednesday evening. A horse attached to a light wagon was running away, and coming furiously down Washington-street as Col. SEYMOUR was crossing.

FOURTEEN PERSONS DROWNED-SAD RESULT OF A PLEASURE EXCURSION.-An extra of the Adrian (Mich.) Expostor, July 5, has the following: "A sad accident occurred, yesterday afternoon, at Clear Lake, Steuben County, Ia.,twenty,miles south of Hillsoale, by the upsetting of a sailboat containing a party of twenty-seven persons, mostly ladies and children, fourteen of whom were drowned.

MURDER IN BOSTON.--The Boston Herald of July S says: "About 7 o'clock last evening, a young man named JUSTIN McCARTY was almost instantly killed, in a liquor cellar No. 51 Lincoln-street, by JAMES F. COLGAN, the proprietor of the place.

` THE TREMBLES FOR THE FUTURE OF HIS COUNTRY. The citizens of the town of Chelmsford, Mass., propose to erect a monument in honor of the Revolutionary heroes of that place, and had made arrangements for the inauguration on the 4th of July. Unforeseen obstacles having arisen, the ceremony has been postponed to the 22d of September.

ECCLESIASTICAL.-On Monday last the Congregational Church of Northfield (in the southeast part of Litchlield Township) withdrew their connection from the Litchfield South Consocition. They are now strict Congregationalists, by the passage of the following resolutions, with but one or two dissenting votes:

The steamship Hungarian, from Liverpool on Wednesday, the 29th ult., passed this point at 11:30 A. M. to-day, in route to Quebec, where she will be due at a late hour this evening. The steamship City of Baltimore was to have sailed on the 18th, but owing to her large draft of water could not get out of the dock, and only sailed two or three hours in advance of the Hungarian.

ROBBERY OF A RAILROAD BOND. - Mr. Adolphus G. Mangel, of No. 242 Pearl-street, yesterday made a complaint against Louis Hananer, his book keeper, and Emil calmon, a porter in his emoloy, for the alleged purloining of a bond of the Sandusky, MARE field and Newark Railroad. Mr. Mangel valued the bond at $121. and swears that it was stolen about the first of last February.

The Commissioners of Health met yesterday at 12 o'clock, present all the members. Dr. GUNN called the attention of the Board to the case of the brig John Boynton, which arrived from Port-au Prince about a week since; the Captain of which (Capt. Wm. Blye) died yesterday at his residence in Brooklyn, as reported of yellow fever.

Tile National Era publishes a feeling tribute to the memory of the late Dr. BAILEY, from tile pen of JOHN G. WHITTIER. We copy the following passages: "The death of Dr. BAILEY will be widely felt as a public calamity. lie was one of those men who mould and shape the age in which they live.

ATLANTIC VS. ECKFORD--The first of three matches between these Clubs came off yesterday afternoon upon the Eckford Grounds, Manor House, Greenpoint. Over 4,000 spectators of this interesting and exciting game were present.

To a future generation of Englishmen it will seem inconceivable that, much as we sympathized, as a people, with the great Italian cause, we did not more deeply appreciate the mighty moments in which we now live. In the Cabinet and on the field all is equally in suspense.

A case involving the right of a free negro of another State to take property by will in this State has recently been adjudicated by the High Court of Er. rors and Appeals; and as the decision embraces principles of the utmost magnitude, we hare improved the earliest opportunity to spread it before the public. The able and lucid decision was pronounced by Judge HARRIS--Chief-Justice SMITH concurring.

Some authentic particulars of the great Battle of Solferino-the name by which the engagement near the Mincio is to be known-have reached us by the arrival of the steamship Hungarian at Quebec, from Liverpool on the 29th ult. Her advices are four days later than those by the Adelaidc and the Asia.

It is an error to suppose that people go into the country for the sake of being more comfortable during the continuance of hot weather than at home. Or if people go a Summering with any such motive in their heads, the experience of one campaign thrusts it out forever.

Superintendent Neighbors, of Texas, writes to the Indian Bureau that it is reported another attack will be made upon the Caddo reserve. Much ill-feeling prevaile, and the Governor of Texas has appointed five commissioner to assist in preventing further hostilities, and to make such arrangements as will insure the preservation of peace.

Mayor TIEMANN recently received a letter addressed to his care for "Mr. S. D. DAY, or the Cashier of the Globe Bank, N. Y,, New-York City." The Mayor could not ascertain that there was any such bank in this City; neither could he learn who Mr. DAY was, or where he was to be found.

Whoever will pause, this morning, on his walk to business, along any of the streets that are shaded with old trees, will see trunks gay with white killers. In Brooklyn, especially, the crop is plenty, and if there is a breeze stirring, the sidewalks look as if dotted with great snow-flakes.

The Spirit of the Times says of the prospects of the Fall season on the Course: "We regret to learn that our prospects for a Fall meeting are very poor indeed. The people in this section appear to have placed all their affection upon trot. ting, for good races are totally abandoned for a trot,

BURGLARY IN NEW-JERSEY.--For some time past, during this and the last Summer, a large number of house robberies have been committed along the Jersey shore, between Bulls Ferry and Fort Lee, by persons in boats from New York.

HOPPOCK.--In this City, on Friday afternoon, Mrs. ELLEN HOPPOCK in the 9th year of her age. The funeral services will take place at the residence of her son. Ely Hoppock. No. 38 West 11th st, at 3 1/2 o'clock this, Saturday) afternoon. Her remains will be taken to New Jersey for interment. The relatives and friends are invited, without further invitation.

LORD--WATSON--In this City, on Thursday, July 7, in St. Peter's Church, 20th-st., by the Rev. Dr. Turner. WILLIAM HENRY LORD, of Western New-York, to ANNIE M., eldest daughter of James Watson. CRAZY--BRLMS.--In this City, on Thursday, July 7, by the Rev. H. D. Ganse, WILLIAM E. CRARY to Mrs. JULIA S. HELMS, daughter of Nathan Sayre, all of this City.

A deeply-interesting scene took place in the cell of CYRUS W. PLUMER, in the Cambridge-street jail, this morning, the principal feature of which was the administration of the rite of baptism to PLUMER by the Rev. Dr. LOTHROP, who has been his kind and faithful spiritual adviser since his sentence.

SERIOUS ASSAULT.--TERENCE O'CONNER was brought before Justice BLACHLEY yesterday, on a charge of committing a serious assault and battery upon the person of PERRIN HINES, Wednesday night, on Baltic, near Hoyt-street. The complainant was found insensible upon the sidewalk in Baltic-street by the Police, suffering from a severe contusion on the head.

The gallant and hospitable Gen. URQUIZA, whom Mr. Commissioner BOWLIN exalted into a model of disinterested urbanity and superexcellent statesmanship, appears to be doing his best at this moment to justify the doubts which, on the settlement of the Paraguay difficully, the TIMES took occasion to express as to the entire unselfishness of the Argentine President.

THE BI-CENTENNIAL CELEBRATION AT WOODBURY, CoNN.-The Bi-Centennial Celebration of the first settlement of the town of Woodbury, took place on Monday and Tuesday, July 4 and 5. Early on the first day, there was an immense in-gathering from Roxbury, Southbury, Washington and other villages that have been formed from the old town of Woodbury, besides a host of the descendants of early settlers and former inhabitants of the town.

We find the following items of news in our Havana files: A sailor, who was intoxicated Wednesday evening haring been taken into custody by a Salve Guardia, refusing to proceed to the prison, the Salve Guardia drew his sword and inflicted a severe wound on the sailor's head, and then placed him in the Charity Hospital.

TRIUMPHAL RECEPTION OF THE RESCUERS AT OBERLIN.--The untried "rescuers" who had lain in jail eighty-four days at Cleveland, having been liberated pursuant to an arrangement between their counsel, the counsel for the Kentucky men arrested on a charge of kidnapping, and the Court, have returned to their homes at Oberlin.

To the Editor of the New York Times: As you Imputed the failure of Mr. PUSEY's balloon t ascend at Jones' Wood on the Fourth to a deficient supply of gas, please allow me to state that such was not the fact. The gas was furnished in part by me, and was sufficient both in quantity and quality.

The improvement in the construction of stamped envelopes ordered by the Postmaster-General consis a in the combination of black lines with the ordinary letter envelope in such a manner as to render them visible only when the face and back of the envelope are pressed by the band at the time of superscription; and the pressure being removed, or the letter inserted, the lines disappear.

A company of gipseys, who have been encamped for some days near Pittsburgh, left that city on the 8th for Cinecinnati. The Gazette says: "These gipseys are from England. They have been in this country several years, having come hither from the vicinity of Westmoreland County, (in England,) we believe.

A gentleman just arrived from Alexandria in this State, informs me that BUCHANAN has ostracised from office from the Custom-house Department of that city some eight orten Democrats, who voted for SHACKELFORD, the late Independent Democratic candidate, against Extra Billy SMITH.

NORWEGIAN IMMIGRANTS.--The Toronto Globe July 7, says: On Tuesday last the steamer Bowmanville landed in Toronto one hundred and fifty Norwe. gian emigrants, who were all bound to the Western States. They were forwarded to Chicago via Collingwood. A more desirable class of emigrants it is impossible to obtain.
Notwithstanding his self-sacrificing efforts in behalf of Lecompton and kindred Democratic idols, Mr. BUCHANAN has failed to conciliate the South.

The Commissioner of Indian Affairs has been informed that the children saved from the MountainMeadows massacre In Utah, have been kept from their journey by the bad roads, but would start for the East early in June. Indian Superintendent Forney has received information that two more of the children, one 17 and the other 4 years of age, are at Cedar City.

Convention of the Anti-Secret Confederation: The Anti-Secret Confederation, composed of Chapters from Williams, Union, Amnerst, Hamilton, Waterville, Middlebury, Bowdoin and Rutgers Colleges, and Rochester University, met in Convention at the Massasoit House, in Springfield, Mass, at 2 o'clock, Wednesday, July 6.

The following general order from Secretary FLOYD was anticipated in the TIMES more than a week ago. It is believed that six or eight guns wilt be presented for trial, including the " Sawyer gun," and the cannon invented by Ex-Senator JAMES, of Rhode Island:

WHEN HOMICIDE BY A POLICEMAN IS JUSTIFIA BIE.--The case of policeman SAMUEL H. CUNNINGHAM in Philadelphia has just been decided by Judge ALLISON. The rulings of the Court in this case are important. CUNNINGHAM, a member of the Police force of Philadelphia, was detailed on the 29th of April last store on Seventeenth street.

HIS DIFFICULTY WITH THE CATHOLICS OF ILLINOIS. The Rev. Father CHINIQUY, formerly of the Church of Rome, whose persecution by the Catholics in Illinois has rendered him famous, preached two sermons at the Cooper Institute, yesterday, at the Union Sabbath meetings held there.

MORTALITY.--Dr. BOYD, Health Officer, reports 121 deaths for the week ending Saturday last. Although this is about a fair average of deaths for this season of the year, physicians and druggists are unanimous in their opinions that the City is unusually healthy. The druggists say that their business is one-half less now than last year at this time.

Nobody can read the full and graphic account which we this morning publish of the recent ballooning of Messrs. WISE and LAMOUNTAIN, from St. Louis to New-York, without a thrill of interest and admiration-of interest in the great scientific experiment so boldly undertaken, and of admiration for the quiet and resolute courage with which the fearful risks of an aerial tempest were met and overcome.

CROPS IN NEW-JERSEY.--The wheat crop in every quarter of the country is represented to be in excellent condition. In this State the crop promises to be larger than for some years. In Salem County, where the harvest has been mainly gathered, it exceeds in abundance and quality any which has been raised for ten years past.

To the Editor of the New-York Times : There are probably many of your readers who would like to be informed why it is that no satisfaction can be obtained for the Wisconsin Securities that are now being repudiated. These are not technically State, but are termed Farm-Mortgage and Municipal Securities or Bonds.

THE OBSERVANCE OF THE SABBATH LAWS.-Since the Police Commissioners adopted resolutions, on Friday, which admitted their power and intimated their intention of enforcing the Sunday laws, naturally enough an impression became general that decisive and peremptory orders would be issued to the Police henceforth to assert the law's supremacy.

In this portion of the State there is a dead calm in polities. No movements, since PETER WASHINGTON (son of LUND) fizzled for GUTHRIE; no intrigues even, save the efforts of the followers of Mr. GREELEY to " whisper down" Mr. SEWARD-nothing but speculation. What Commodore STOCKTON intends doing no one can tell, but whatever he does wll be likely to be decisive, as it was in 1856.

HEAZLITT.--In this City, on Sunday, July 10. WALTER ROBERTS BEAZLITT, infant son of Mary A. and Thomas B. Beazlitt aped I year and 7 days. The friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral service on to morrow. (Tuesday.) at 4 o'clock P.M., No 147 8th-st., near Broadway.

From the Augusts (Ga.) Constitutionalist. Yesterday a large concourse of people assembled in the City Hall Park, to hear their Representative in Congress address them, on his resignation of the high office which they have so long conferred upon him, and which he has so honorably and so able filied.

The corner-stone of the Agricultural College of the State of New-York, was laid at Ovid, Seneca County, on the 7th July. Ex-Governor KING officiated, and made an address. A correspondent of the Albany Evening Journal says:

The steamships Weser and Arago, with details of the European news, a summary of which we published on Saturday morning, are now fully due at this port, both from Southampton. The former sailed on the 28th, and the latter on the 29th. The steamship Great Britain, which left Liverpool on the 30th, one day later, is also about due. She will probably bring full accounts of the great Battle of Solferino.

The deadest season of the year in this country for authors and artists is Midsummer. They then, with the rest of the world, indulge in a long siesta; the authors repose languidly under the shade of their myrtles, and the artists retire to the coolest and most picturesque spots the earth affords to smoke their meerschaums in and to take a look at Nature for Winter working up.

The Oberlin Rescuers, released from prison, took the first train for their homes. According to a six column report in the Cleveland Plaindealer, the wives and little ones, the great men of the village o Oberlin, the strangers within its gates, and all the neighborhood, vied with each other (June 6) i.e doing honor to the " martyrs.

Before Justices Boswoth, Woodruff, Pierrepont and Monerief. Thaddeus Wilson vs. Edward Roberts.--New trial granted, costs to abide event. George Boyd vs. Joel W. Foote et' al.--Judgment affirmed if plaintiff elects to deduct $375 with interest from Oct. 1, 1855, and if no such affirmance to be without costs of appeal. If he does not so elect judgment reversed and new trial ordered, costs to abide event.

FIREMAN'S FLIGHT IN THE FIRST WARD.--AT the fire at the National Theatre, on Sunday Morning some little feeling of animosity was stirred between Hose Company No. 18 and Engine Company No. 20, in consequence of its having been alleged that Engine Company No. 20 ran into Hose Company No. 18, and severely injured one of the members of the latter Company.

DODWOBTH'S CONCERT IN THE RAMBLE OF THE CENTRAL PARK.--If a poor joke night be admissible in connection with so solemn a subject as a mass meeting of one's fellow-creatures, we would say that there was quite a scramble in the Ramble on Saturday afternoon, to hear DODWORTH'S music, which it was worth a heap of dods to listen to.

On Saturday afternoon a new step was taken in the progress of the Central Park. This noble work, which is so clearly destined to be the honor and delight of New-York, has now received the "consecration of tones."

The negro minstrel, Mr. Thomas Coleman, died in Newark, N. J., on the evening of the 5th of July, in his 34th year. He was born in Boston, Mass., Aug. 9, 1826, and for more than 20 years has been among the most prominent delincators of the Ethiopean character. He was a pupil of John W. Smith,

The Commissioners of Health did a wise thing yesterday. The City Inspector stated that a great many dead animals were lying in the streets, through the neglect of the offal contractors. Whereupon the Commissioners directed Mr. DELAVAN himself to see the carcases removed, the expenses to be paid by the Comptroller, and charged to the contractors.

The Steamship Arago, on the 29th June, from Southampton, with one day's later malls from Europe, arrived here yesterday afternoon. The America arrived at Liverpool on June 26, The Hammonia arrived at Cowes, June 27. The screw steamer Weser will sail from Southampton on the 30th June.

We learn from the Leavenworth Times of Monday, that one of the coaches of the Pike's Peak Express Company arrived there on the evening previous, bringing dates to the 23d ult. HORACE GREELEY left Denver in a private conveyance with a week's outfit for Utah via Ford Laramie, on the 19th ult. An immense cofiagration commenced raging in the mountain pineries on the 20th ult.

A QUARREL AND DOUBLE MURDER. The PittsburghEvening Chronicle, July 9, reports an affray in Lawrence County, Pa,, on the 4th of July, in which two men named JAMES LOSTETTOR and FRANK MCCORD were shot by JACOB SERHART receiving injuries from which they died soon afterwards. It appears that from some cause or other unexplained, an old grudge existed between LOSTETTOR and GERHART,

We have all overrated the difficulties of the negro question. Our political world, it is true, is just now rather out of joint, but we need not echo Hamlet's cry, and think it " cursed spite" that we are born to set things right, for the work is the easiest work imaginable--a molehill which our own extravagance has swollen into a mountain.

GREEN.--In this City, on Monday afternoon, July 11, after a severe illness, WILLIAM GREEN, aged 30 years and 24 days. his relatives and friends, also those of his brother Charles Green, are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, on Wednesday, at 2 P. M., from the residence of his brother, Charles Green. No. 277 Madison st. ?? Boston and Charlestown papers please copy.

An adjourned meeting of the Joint Board of Supervisors and Aldermen was held yesterday after. noon, to consider the annual statement of the several sums of money necessary to be raised by tax for the various purposes authorized by the charter. The first and second resolutions, relating to paying public debt and the interest thereon, were laid on the table, the Committee having the subject matter in charge not being ready to make a report.

The Synagogue of Sheirath Israel, the oldest Jewish congregation in the City, driven by increase of numbers, has been obliged to remove from its ancient site in Crosby-street to a more spacious and more fashionable location. The ground selected for the new edifice is in West Nineteenth-street, near Fifth avenue. The building will be 92 feet in depth, with a front of 70 feet.

This morning the Brooklyn, Capt. FARRAGUT, with the American Legation on board, took her departure from Vera Cruz for a point on tile Gulf 75 miles below, from which point Mr. MOLANE proposed to proceed to San Andres Tuxtia, some thirty miles in the interior. ANOTHER DEPLETION IN THE ILLINOIS STATE TREASURY.--The Chicago Times has the following: We regret to hear that the State Treasury of Illinois has suffered a most terrible depletion. Old settiers will remember the claim of MCALLISTER and STEBBINS against the State, amounting to nearly, if not fully, a million of dollars. This claim has been a Constant attendant at the Legislature for many years.

By the arrival at this port of the City of Baltimore and the Arago, we have full details of European intelligence to the 29th ult., a telegraphic summary of which we have before published. Letters from our Special Correspondents at the seat of war in Italy give us details of the great battle of Solferino in advance of all the Press of London and Paris.

A YOUNG GIRL KIDNAPPED.-As the congregation in attendance upon divine service were leaving the Broadway Congregational Church at Chelsea last evening, a buggy containing two young men reined up near the Gerrish House, and one of the men Jumping out, seized a young girl about 16 years of age, and thrusting her into the carriage, drove off in the direction of Chelsea Bridge.

The Philadelphia Press says: An apprehension having been entertained that Commander M. F. Manry, of the National Observatory, Washington, would be required to go upon active duty, we have the gratification of stating that both the President and the Secretary of the Navy are too deeply impressed with the value of his eminent scientific services to think of permitting his removal upon such a pretext as this.

The Roval Mail steamship Canada arrived at Halifax yesterday forenoon, bringing European advices to the 2d instant, three days later, but owing to some trouble with the telegraph line east of Sackville, N. B., we have but a very brief summary this morning.

ST. JOSEPH PRISON, Mo., Thursday, June 23, 1859. DEAR FRIEND: You will be surprised to receive a letter from a convicted felon. But so it is. This day a Missouri jury brought in a verdict, and on their oaths declare that I was in Missouri, myself or by an agent, and stole or abducted a man called DICK, of the value of $1,500.

A POLICEMAN ATTACKED BY A RUFFIAN.-Wm. Murphy, who, it is alleged has twice served the State in the Prison at Sing-Sing, whence he a fortnight ago returned to the City, threatened to take the hfe of Officer Boyle. of the Fifth Ward. The policeman, late on Sunday night, had been asked to arrest a disorderly woman in Worth-street.

MOVEMENT OF UNITED STATES TROOPS.--A detachment of one hundred and thirty-six soldiers, from Carlisle Barracks, Penn., arrived by railroad yesterday morning, and left in the afternoon on the steamer Sky Lark, for Fort Leavenworth, Lieut. MAURY was in command.

The St. Louis Republican publishes the following letter: AURARIA, Sunday, June 8, 1859. I scarcely know what to write about this community and country. Person's ideas vary so much that one could scarcely form a correct notion of matters and things here, judging from correspondence. Men are perfectly wild and crazy.

The system of " drumming" up customers, which was once in vogue among our jobbing merchants, has been abandoned by all respectable houses for several years. Even customers from the far West cannot fail to discover that, on sound commercial principles, no house could afford to treat its customers to champagne and game suppers, unless the extra cost was put upon the price of the goods.

The United States have been collaterally represented in the British Parliament, by the BARINGS (descended from the BINGHAMS of Philadelphia, where Lord ASHBURTON, the present head of the family, was, born, in 1799,) and by WILLIAM BROWN, of Liverpool, of the firm of BROWN BROTHERS of New-York.

The Atlantic Royal Mail Steamship Navigation Company's steamer Argo, Capt. HALPIN, left NewYork on Thursday, June 23d, with two hundred passengers; her officers and crew amounting to about one hundred and twenty men.

From a Paris Correspondent. It is so much the custom to go out of Paris at this time of the year that we are gradually losing all our fashionable women. They disappear with their train of packages, and seek the quiet of wateringplaces, in order to make up for the fatigue of Winter. There are still some new coverings for the shoulders, only it is difficult to select out ot so many patterns.

The people of Illinois have a summary way of ridding themselves of horse-thieves and other nuisances. The other day the towspeople of Sparta warned one Graham and two other suspected individuals to leave.

The famous Rosetta Stone, the name of which is very widely known, and which has been seen by thousands in the Egyptian Gallery of the British Museum, was discovered by a French oflicer named BASSARD, in NAPOLEON'S Egyptian campaign.

A woman by the name of JANE HANEY was brought in yesterday by Messrs. BENJ. KIRK and A. M. THAYER, of Port Jervis, Orange County, N. Y., fron that place; she was handed over to those gentlemen by Mr. H. R. RIDDLE, Division Superintendent of the New-York and Erie Railroad, having been run over by their night Express train, going West at 8 P. M., July 9, between Goshen and Hampton.

Major OSBORNE CROSS, Quartermaster in the United States Army, against whom charges of malfeasance in office have been preferred, will not resign, as intimated in a previous dispatch, but wil stand his trial before a Court-martial, which has been ordered to-day for that purpose.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: At a late meeting of the Sanitary Association, a resolution was passed in reference to the inefficiency of simply cleaning the streets as a measure sufficient to remove the causes of disease.
The Royal Mail steamship Canada, from Liverpool on Saturday, the 2d inst., passed Cape Race at 5 1/2 P. M. on Sunday, the 10th inst., and arrived at Halifax to-day.
Mr. G. MALLAT, "civil engineer," has favored us with his views of the plans and plots set on foot by the House of Orleans for tile recovery of the throne of France.

OBTAINING GOODS UNDER FALSE REPRESENTATIONS--Mr. FRANK B. NEWELL a merchant, of No. 192 Broadway, made a complaint yesterday before Alderman SMITH, at the Lower Police Court, against a man who represented himself as JOHN J. HARRIS, of New-Bedford, Mass. Mr. NEWELL alleges that he received an order by telegraph three weeks ago to forward some goods to the above-named address at New-Bedford.

SLOOP OF WAR WYOMING.--The engines of the sloop-of-war Wyoming, two in number, are direct acting double piston of one thousand horse power; cylinders fifty inches in diameter, with thirty inches stroke. They were made by MERRICK SONS, and are beautiful specimens of mechanical skill.

The following is the address of the Rev. A. FISCHEL. delivered on the occasion of laying the cornerstone of the new Synagogue of Sheirath Israel, on Monday, and which was crowded out of our report: It affords me extreme gratification to find my see surrounded on the present occasion by so many worthy and respected members of the Hebrew community.

GRAY, Esq., Commander, from Aspiawall Juy 3, with passengers, malls and treasure received from Pacific Mail Steamship Company's steamer Sonora, which left San Francisco Jne 25, touched at Key West July 8, and arrived at this port last evening.

One of our contemporaries has been at the trouble of sending to Washington for intelligence of the reconciliation of Mr. SICKLES with his wife, and has ascertained, what we believe to be the truth, that the most resolute of avengers has approved himself also the most relenting of husbands, and is now living once more with the victim of the late PHILIP BARTON KEY.

The appearance of this town, the capital of the Island of Grenada, is even more picturesque and more dilapidated than that of St. Vincent. St. George is built upon two sides of a hill, one facing the ocean, and the other the Carrenage--a magnificent harbor, where fifteen hundred ships could ride at anchor.

THRASHED FOR HIS KINDNESS.--On Monday morning, Wm. McClintock, who lives in Thirty-ninth-street, between Ninth and Tenth avenues, quarreled with his wife, and site, to punish him for his bad behavior, whipped him and sent him from the house.

DEPREDATIONS OF THE PAWNEE INDIANS.--Th St. Joseph Journal, of the 8th, says: "Considerable excitement still exists at Omaha and vicinity in regard to the late depredations committed by the Pawnce Indians. The depredation committed at Fontenelle was much greater than was at first supposed.

The closing exercises of the forty-first academical year of the Institution for the Deaf and Dumb tock place yesterday in the chapel of the Institution at Fanwood, Washington Heights, commencing at 3 o'clock, The hall was filled by the pupils and their friends.

The arrangements for the sale of the Collins steamships have at last been completed, but the announcement of their sale on Monday was premature; negotiations were then pending, but it was not until the day after that the terms offered were accepted.

BASLETT.--In this City, on Wednesday morning, July 13, LILLY BASLETT, aged 44 years. The relatives and friends are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, this day, (Thursday,) at 10 o'clock A. M., without further invitation HYSLOP.--In this City, on Wednesday afternoon, July 13, ROBERT BYSLOP, Jr. His friends, and those of his father, are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, from Grace Church, at 4 o'clock, on Friday afternoon, without further invitation.

Mr. L. Waggoner, editor of the Toledo Blade, has been assaulted in the street by some gamblers whose tricks he had exposed. He publishes a long personal statement of the difficulty, and adds that he shall continue his exposures, and risk the consequences.

S. BARNES, Secretary,

THE AUSTRIAN ACCOUNT. The official journal at Vienna, of June 26, published the following official dispatch from the seat of war: VERONA, Saturday, June 25. On the 23d inst. the Imperial Royal army crossed at four places to the right bank of the Mincio. The right wing of the army occupied Pozzolengo, Solferino, and Cavriana.

DEAD-LETTERS RETURNED TO THE OWNERS.--The Washington Star says: The number of letters registered and sent from the Dead-Letter Office for delivery to the owners during June, 1859, was 1,???, containing in bills of exchange, drafts, checks, notes, , 933 15s, 10d., $219,040.79, and 9,737 franes.

At 5 o'clock last evening this City and vicinity were visited by altogether the most terrific thunderstorm that has passed over here for a year past. For nearly an hour before rain began to fail the approach of the storm was indicated by a lowering sky and fitful gusts of wind.

HEALTH COMMISSIONERS.--The Health Commissioners had a full meeting yesterday noon. Dr. ROCKWELL moved to amend the resolution recently adopted, making the removal of offal and canvasses obligatory within twelve hours,by substituting six hours instead. The motion to amend was carried.

Times in Utah are growing more prosperous. Business is reviving. The war of party feeling is somewhat lulled, awaiting the impression of the late action upon the States and national mind, although the same spirit, the old sentiments. and the accustomed traits remain inveterate.

COL. DURYEE PERSISTS IN HIS RESIGNATION. The Seventh Regiment (National Guard) had a volunteer parade last evening, in fill uniform, for the purpose of calling upon Col. DURYEE, en masse, with a request that he would reconsider his resignation, and retain his commission as Colonel of the Regiment

M ENDELSSOHN UNION.-This young and vigo rous Society, which has already given the musicapublic a series of excellent entertainments, has projected a new enterprise, of a very attractive character. For Wednesday evening of next week, the Union offer a moonlight musical excursion on the Hudson; starting at4 P.M., and proceeding up the river to Cozzens' and the Highlands.

The City Inspector, yesterday, took a look at some of the offal-boiling establishments up town, Most of them are shanties, not at all pretentious in appearance, from the chimnies of which smoke wreaths curl, which the passer-by, but for the odor, would imagine indicated only that the ordinary culinary operations were going on within.

Before Justice Clerke. Matter of Opening Seventy--Fifth--street.---Order granted, appointing Thomas Carroll, Richard B. Connolly and James S. Sanford, Commissioners. Matter of Opening Seventy-Sixth-Street.--Order granted. George W. Busteed, James S. Sanford and Richard B. Connolly, commissioners.

There is a very general feeling in the community that the future of California is brightening, notwithstanding that the over stock of goods in our markets sent from the East, continues to fill ourmerchants with somewhat gloomy forebodings.

The question of Sunday travel on the city passenger railways is becoming a very interesting one to the whole community. The ventilating of the old law of 1794 has been productive of good in enlightening the public, and few if any men claim to find in it any restriction that can be made to prohibit Sunday travel.

The Legislature of this State was convened in special session by executive proclamation, on the 16th ult., and as by the Constitution, its term was limited to twenty days, it was compelled to adjourn to-day sine die.

The Constitutional Convention of Kansas met at this place at noon yesterday. It was called to order by Mr. STIMSON, of Leavenworth, and S. A. KINGMAN, of Brown, was chosen temporary Chairman, and JNO' A. MARTIN, of Atchison, and F. G. Ross, of Richardson, Secretaries pro tern.

SHEPARD, of Alablama, who writes to him: "In regard to consistency I will compare notes with you, and submit them to the scrutiny of the Southern Rights Party. Mr. BUCHANAN, the known personal and political enemy of your honored father, when he came to the Presidency, found you in office in Mexico.

The first direct correspondence from the battlefield of Solferino was published yesterday morning by the NEW-YORK TIMES, which has thus outstripped, not only its American cotemporaries, but also the English journals, in which we find as yet no letters.

The members of the new English Ministry, which has rather coalesced around Lord PALMERSTON than been called by him into office, have gone to their constituents and have been returmed with permission to represent the people in serving the Queen.

After a careful examination of the English journals which reached us yesterday by the Etna, with mails to the 2d of July, we fee ourselves warranted in claiming a decided superiority for the American Press as represented in our own correspondence from the seat of war, over our contemporaries on the other side of the water.

The War Department has adopted a regulation fixing the tax upon sutlers at posts occupied by one or more companies, at ten cents a month for each commissioned officer and enlisted man belonging to the command in each regiment. The fund accruing to it as above, or as much of it as may be necessary, will be appropriated to the maintenance of the band.

I n these "piping times of peace" there is not much army news of importance to record. The principal thing to be done ins to be done is to mention the officers, as they all have friends at the East who will be pleased to hear of their wherebouts.

United States Mail steamship Philadelphia, ELISHA HOWES, Esq., commanding, left New-Orleans July 5, for New-York via Havana, at which port she arrived on the morning of the 8th, and sailed on the afternoon of the same day for this port, reaching New-York last evening.

Excepting a small pillaging party on the southern frontier, near the Indian territory, about two hundred strong, peace has been restored in all the Republic. Probably this small fraction is by this time reduced, as a force had gone from Conception in pursuit of them. To-day the state of siege expires.

A very large assemblage of the first residents of the place, comprising a liberal proportion of ladies, were gratified spectators of the pastime. An elegant entertainment was participated in by both clubs, after which the Union escorted the Liberty Club and their friends to the cars. We give the score:

There are two islands under the dominion of the Windward Government-of all the live the smallest and most distant from each other-upon whose condition I must make a few remarks. I mean Tobago and St. Lucia. The former is the most southerly of the Caribbee Islands.

From the National Intelligencer. It is fortunate that something yet remains of the amount appropriated for the Capitol extension, so that the work thereon can be pursued without the unnecessary inconveniences and expense of suspensions. We learn that the original plan of the dome is to be slightly modified whereby the diameter of the upper section will be greater than at first intended, but the height of the dome will be something less.

By the arrival of the steamship Eina from Liverpool, simultaneously with the Canada, on the 2d inst., we receive highly interesting details of European news. A very late dispatch by the Canada also gives particulars of the war movement in Italy not otherwise received. The entire allied army had passed the Mincio, and been joined by the command of Prince NAPOLEON, numbering 35,000 men. The Emperor had stated in a tele.

There is no spot accessible to the people of this crowded city where the tired citizens, worn with the fatigue of business and enervated by the closeness and confined air of our busy streets, can enjoyan hour of pleasanter repose or more interesting recreation than in a stroll through the Central Park, particularly that portion of it bearing the pretty, simple flame of the Ramble.

INDIAN TROUBLES.--The United States Indian Office has received official dispatches, reporting Superintendent CULLEN, with the Government supplies for the Yancton Indians to have passed the Yellow Medicine about fifteen miles, when he was met by two hundred Siesiton warriors, who seized the horses of the train and refused to permit Mr. CULLEN to proceed, unless he would first pay them their annuities.

The American Scientific Association will hold its Thirteenth Annual Meeting this year at Springfield, Mass., beginning Wednesday, August 3, at 10 A. M. Prof. STEPHEN ALEXANDER is President, and Prof. HITCHCOCK of Amherst, Vice-President. Of the Local Committee, Hon. GEO. BLISS is Chairman, and Dr. GEO. A. OTIS, Secretary. All the signs indicate a good time.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Your paper, this morning, correctly states that the Rev. Mr. IIATC was excommunicated, last Tuesday evening, by the Church of the Puritans, on account of his views and actions respecting the Christian Sabbath. But your report conveys the impression that Mr. H. found some sympathy in three members oftheChurch who voted against the motion.

HALL says, in a piquant sketch of the late Lady MORGAN: The last time we saw "The Wild Irish Girl," she was seated on a couch in her bedroom, as pretty an?? picturesque a rain of old-lady womankind as we ?? looked upon; her black silk dressing-gown fell ?? her petite form, which seemed so fragile ?? feared to see her move.

The NEW-YORK TIMES, of yesterday, contains a letter from its Editor, H.J. RAYMOND, dated Castiglione, Italy, June 24. He arrived just in time to witness a part of the great Battle of solferino, fought on that day. He says the battle lasted all day, and extended over a circuit of fifteen miles.

To the Editor of the New-York Times : During the thunder-storm of Wednesday afternoon, the tower on the dwelling of Mr. SAMUEL R TREMBLIY, at Bergen Point, N. J., was struck by lightning, tearing from it a portion of the weather-boarding.

DR. BAILEY'S PAPER.--The Cincinnati Gazette says: DONN PIATT, Esq., having returned from Washington, we learn authoritatively that he is not in any way connected with the editorship of the National Era, the rumors to that effect being unfounded. Dr. BAILEY, before sailing for Europe, made arrangements for the publication of his paper during his proposed absence.

The mails by the steamship Canada, forwarded from Boston, were received here last evening. We are thus placed in possession of our correspondence from Italy, from Paris, and from London; with our usual ample files of European journals. Many new, important, and highly interesting details are laid before the reader.

The Democratic Committee will soon follow by a like movement, and the contest will be fairly inaugurated on both sides.
