UNFOUNDED CHARGE OF MURDER.--A man named JOHN NEWMAN, living in the rear of No. 58 Attorney-street, was arrested by the Thirteenth Ward Police, on Wednesday evening, on a charge of murdering the infant child of WM. JENKINS, who resides at the same place.

Professor GAJANI, an Italian exile, delivered a lecture on Wednesday to a small but appreciative audience in Dr. CHEEVER'S Church, Union-square, upon the present war in Italy. The lecturer commenced by saying that he was glad to see the nearly universal sympathy excited in this country in behalf of the Italians in the present strugle.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Several correspondents for the Press, laboring under a total misconception of all the facts surrounding the late " Flour Contract" with Messrs. RUSSELL, MAJORS and WADDELL, made by the Secretary of War, have boldly charged that distinguished official with malfeasance in office, and published to the country that he is a party to a monstrous fraud upon the public treasury.

The files of Vera Cruz papers to June brought to New-Orleans by the William H. Webb, reached us last evening. We find the following details of news already received by telegraph: The conducts has been allowed, after much persuasion by Gen. ROBLES, to proceed to Vera Cruz.

The telegraph announced yesterday the melancholy intelligence that RUFUS CHOATE, of Massachusetts, was no more. Mr. CHOATE left Boston with a party of friends but a few weeks since in one of tire Cunard steamers, intending, if his strength would warrant it, to make a voyage to Europe, with the hope of improving his health.

Judge ROSE, the American Consul at Guaymas reached here this afternoon, and tendered his resignation to the Government. He made a thorough exploration of Sonora, and pronounces it the richest mineral country in the world. Governor PESCHIERA is now absent in Sonora, and the Indians are devastating all the upper and western portions of Sonora.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I desire to call the attention of your numerous reader to a fact which I have never seen alluded to, and which in the present position of the Emperor of the French is worthy of notice. It is generally admitted that NAPOLEON I. commenced his downward course by the divorcement of JOSEPHINE, and we have semons and homilies without end to this effect.

THE DAMAGE BY THE STORM.--In addition to what has been heretofore published of the damage done by the storm Wednesday evening, we have the following: A row of five frame Houses, nearly completed, on Marcy, near DeKalb-avenue, were entirely demolished. A house at the corner of Nostrand and DeKalb-avenues, was unroofed.

THE SPIRITUALISTS AT A PIC-NIC.--The Spiritualists to the number of about 5,000, went upon an excursion and pic-nic at Island Grove, Abington, yesterday. Delegations were present from Boston, (very large,) Charlestown, Chelsea, Plymouth and elsewhere. There are 300 from Plymouth. All along the line of the Old Colony Railroad the people flocked to the trains and swelled the throng.

CURIOUS PROPERTY CASE.--A singular and important law-suit was tried a few days ago by the Court of Common Pleas at Upper Sandusky. It was an action of ejectment brought by JOHN JACOB VOSGELIN against BENJAMIN COPLEY. The plaintiffs, who reside in the Grand Duchy of Baden, claimed, as the heirs of one JOHN MARYMAN, who died in 1855 at Upper Sandusky without any known heirs.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The friends of the Children's Aid Society felt that the public had had about enough of this subject, and they were willing to leave the questions discussed on their merits ; but some assertions of a "Director " of the Juvenile Asylum in your journal may, unless corrected, make a false impression.

POLICEMEN ASSAULTED.--Policemen O'Donnell, of the Fourth Precinct, while endeavoring to protect a woman and her two children, had his club wrested from him and was badly beaten about the head. Officer Tools, of the same Precinct, was also beaten and had his coat torn into shreds.

PASTIME CLUB, OF BROOKLYN vs. NEOSHO, OF NEW-UTRECIIT, L. I. This game, being a return match between the Clubs, was played yesterday afternoon upon the grounds of the Neosho Club, at New-Utrecht. A great many spectators were upon the grounds.

There is something in the " smell of turf" as bewitching to those who were " raised " on a farm, as refreshing to the rest of mankind. The dream of most young men in business in the cities, is like that of BONAPARTE at Elba, a competency, and an early retirement to a small farm within an hour's ride of the old homestead.

MOUNTAIN MRADOW CHIDREN.-The Commissioner if Indian Affair has received a communication from superintendent FORNEY, dated Great Salt lake city, June 16, 1850, in which he states he cannot as yet say what line precisely the caildren will be put enroute for Leavenworth, but presume within a week or ten days.

VEST WASHINGTON MARKET--HARBOR OBSTRUCTIONS--SEMI-ANNUAL CITY EXPENDITURES. The Board met last evening, Mr. CORNELL in the Chair. Councilman JONES offered a resolution, which was adopted, directing the Street Commissioner to transmit to the Board a schedule of all bills paid or now pending before him for work ordered by the Police Commissioners, without authority, since January 1, 1859.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The remarks in your valuable paper of the I lih inst., signed "Bondholder," are just. I cannot yet make up my mind that the City of Racine, whose bonds I hold, and purchased in good faith, will repudiate their own acts.

The scornful old Spanish saying that the "animal which most resembles man is a Swiss " seems likely to be revived throughout the world, by the conduct of the Helvetic mercenaries who sell themselves, their valor and their strength, to the despots of Southern Europe, to be used in suppressing abroad the liberty for which TELL fought and WINKELRIED died, among their native Alps.

The European mails by the Canada were delivered in this City last evening. We complete the summaries already repeatedly given, with highly interesting correspondence and extracts from European journals.

The late rains at the north and west of us, have produced the highest water in Root River, ever known, At the present writing it stands two feet higher than the grea flood of 1854. The entire railroad line along the valley is submerged, and fears are entertained that serious loss must follow.

Insurrection of the Negroes--Dreadful Batchery -- Conflicts with the Government Troops. By the bark White Wing, at Philadelphia, which sailed from Puerto Cabello July 1, we have important news form Venezuela.

At a pic-nic, near Boston, of the Rev. THRODORX PARKEE'S congregation, on Wednesday, letters from Mr. PARKEE were read, dated Montreux, Switzerland, June 25, in which he spoke quite encouragingly of his health. Mr. PARKEE also writes as follows of the War: "A great struggle goes on in Europe to day, in all Europe.

THE CASE OF MR. SEAMAN, LATE SUPERINTENDENT OF PUBLIC PRINTING.--The Washington Star, July 13, says: "Mr. A. G. SEAMAN appeared before the United States District Court for this District this forenoon, surrendered himself, and gave bail in the sum of $5,000 to appear at the opening of the December Term of the Court, to be tried under the indictment against him, with which the public are familiar.
PATRIOT SOLDIERS!--Do not forget that you are Hungarians. The Austrian has brought destruction on your sacred country, and usurps it as his own. The best of your heroes he executed on the sealfold.

THE RIVAL ERONAUTS.-There is trouble between Mr. WISE and Mr. LA MOUNTAIN, the aeronauts, who went up harmoniously together in their balloon, but came down at sword's-points. Mr. LA MOUNTAIN publishes the following challenge: I go to Watertown to- day for the wreck of my balloon, which will be at once rebuilt.

CENTRAL PARK.--The musical entertainment at Central Park will be repeated this afternoon, should the weather be favorable. Mr. HARVEY DOD-WORTH is the conductor of the performance, and no more need be said on that head. The programme comprises selections from A??E, ROBBINS. FLOTOW, ??, and certain compositions of Mr. DOD-WORTH'S own.

The extracts from the "Blue Book of Italy," given in yesterday's TIMES, show as strongly as possible the real temper of the late British Ministry in the altercation between France and Austria. Minister at howe and Envoy at St. Petersburg both do their best to make Russia look on the contending empires with perfect impartiality.

The municipal millennium, long foretold, and Icing despaired of, appears to be realized in the elevation of Messrs. PILLSBURY and DELAVAN to office. The Police, it is understood, are to be converted from their present recondite use into an instrument for the protection of life, property, and social order.

Will of David Nichols.-This case has been several times before the Surrogate. The Will was admitted to Probate in April, 1858. By the provisions of the Will, the testator left a considerable property to his widow, also legacies to his sisters and his brother.

VISIT OF COUNCILMEN TO CROTON DAM.--A Portion of the members of the Board of Councilmen Yesterday visited Croton Dam and inspected the Water Works there. The party consisted of Councilmen CORNELL, LENT, ALLEN, ROSS, BABCOCK, TOWNSEND, VAL?? HALE, BULTELL, BIOKFORD,

The thunder-storm which visited this City on Wednesday extended to Connecticut, and inflicted great damage. The New-Haven Palladium says: "Out in the country the damage was immense, especially to the crops. In Orange the corn, cats, grass, , are almost wholly prostrated.

PROCEEDINGS OF THE BOSTON BAR. The Boston Atlas and Bee of yesterday has an interesting sketch of the life of RUFUS CHOATE. After a brief summary of the principal events in Mr. CHOATR'S career, the Atlas and Bee gives some particulars which have not been punished elsewhere.

The St. Louis Republican, July 12, says: "Mr. A. D. RICHARDSON, correspondent of the Boston Journal, reached this city last evening direct from the gold mines, having left Danver City on the 30th of June.

Your Burlington correspondent is very much in error when he declares that Judge DOUGLAS has no supporters in New-Jersey. There is no man named who will at Charleston receive a stronger vote from New Jersey than DOUGLAS.

THE VICTORIA BRIDGE.-We are glad to be able to announce that tile Victoria Bridge is so far advanced that it may safely be counted upon as being certain to be open for traffic by the 1st November next. Fears were at one time expressed, we observe, that the progress of works might be impeded by the high water in the St. Lawrence; and that the opening of the bridge would be delayed till next year.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In the recent petition to the Commnissioners of Police against the enforcement of the Sunday laws, I observe that a certain Mr. SCHAUM signs himself as a minister of the Lutheran Church. Will Mr. S. or some of his friends inform us by what authority he assumes this titles?

When the Austrians were beaten at Magenta, a sadden conviction seems to have seized upon their leaders, that if they could once put their forces in safety beyond the lines of the Chiese and the Mincio, they would be able to make head against the courage and the skill of France.

The thunder storm of Wednesday evening is represented as having been indescribably grand and terrible in the vicinity of Fort Lee, on the Hudson River. The chain lightning played about the heights of the Pallisades with the most recklces abandon, scattering its bolts hither and thither in the most confused and careless manner.

Just nineteen miles from the Battery, in the Lower Bay, there has t anchor, a trim shugeraft, the Florence Nightingale. When she dropped anchor, some two weeks ago, in the place where she is expected to ride out the Summer, she was called the Falcon.--a bulk admirably adapted to smother the miserable wretches that should fail within the experience of her cruel mercies.

The exercises of Commencement week at Rochester University began on the 10th July with the eulogy upon the late Rev. A. KINGMAN Norr, of your City, delivered by his fiend. the Rev. GEORGE D. BOARDMAN. pastor of the Second Baptist Church in Rochester.

The North German Lloyds screw-steamship Wiser, which was to have sailed from Southampton on the 30th alt., but which was detailed by an accident to her propeller, left that port on the 4th inst., and arrived here at a late hour last night, making the passage in about eleven days and a half.

The following circular has been issued. The movement is a good one: SIR: The undersigned being engaged in the management of Prisons, and believing that much good might result from a Convention of all the Prison officers in the United States who could conveniently attend, as well as such others as might feel interested in tile subject, have ventured to call such a Conven.

HILL--In this City, on Friday morning, July 15, EMMA the youngest daughter of John and Jane Bill, aged 2 years and 8 days. The friends of the family are invited to attend the funeral, on Sunday morning, at 9 o'clock, from No. 137 Christopher-st. MAHANEY.--In this City, on Friday afternoon, July 15, THOMAS MCHANEY, Esq.

THE AMERICAN OFFICERS IN EUROPE.-The Richmond Enquirer has the following paragraph: "Private letters from the continent of Europe intimate that the American officers, who had been permited hy the United States to go to the seat of war in order to gain military insight into war tactics, by ob servation of the contending Powers, have been refused passports to travel thither.

The United States steam-frigate Brooklyn, arrived off the Bar here on the 30th ult, bringing United States Minister MOLANE and his Secretary. They were accompanied by the Chief Judge of St. Andreas, Col. PICTON, the American Consul at Vera Cruz, and several others.

A duel came off to-day, in North Carolina, between O. JENNINGS WISE, of the Enquirer, and PATRICK HENEY AYLETT, a contributor to the columns of the Examiner. Mr. AYLETT fired first. Mr. WISE then fired in the air, when Mr. AYLETT withdrew the challenge, and asked for a reconciliation, which Mr. WISE refused.

By the Mexican schooner Brillants, Capt. ESPINOLA, arrived this morning, we have advices from Campeachy, Yucatan, to the 27th ultimo, and sisal to the 1st instant. The news is important. Ex Governor BABREKA, leader of the Reactionary Party , had descended from the mountains at the head of some 500 men, there collected, and openly proclaimed a revolution at Jopelchen, in the Department of Campeachy.

ITEMS.-JAMES DUNN, of Twentieth-street, Gowanus, died on Wednesday last from the effects of the heat. The body of an unknown man was taken out of the water at Bay Ridge.Thursday; the deceased was about 25 years old, 5 feet 6 inches high, sandy hair, whiskers and mustache.

A letter from Tehuantepec, in the New-Orleans Picayune, says: "Mr. MURPHY's survey of Muatulco has demonstrated the entire practicability of that port for a coaling and water station; but the most interesting feature in this exploration of the Pacific coast of Mexico is the discovery of the ruins of an ancient city within a few miles of the sea.

Members of the Can't--get-away Club, these poor unfortunates who are obliged to deny themselves the privileges of country air during these hot summer days, have found a faithful friend where they little expected ever to come upon one.

CONSTITUTIONAL LORE OF THE SECRETARY OF STATE--For a man who has well nigh attained the ripe age of four score, and enjoyed in his time considerable opportunities for political reading, General CASS is only moderately familiar with the provisions of our National Constitution.

The Buffalo Republic, July 15, has the following account of M. BLONDIN'S last performance at Niagara. "Never did Niagara present such a seene as yesterday. From morning dawn until evening close the streets were a solid mass of human beings, brought hither by long trains of cars, crowded steamboats, and every other conveyance which could be obtained, to witness the intrepid BLONDIN perform his last great crowning feat.

Half a century ago, the title of Ministry of "all the talents" was applied in scorn to an English Cabinetmade up of the weakest and least conspicuous of English politicians of tile time. The same title has been fastened now in quite a different sense, upon the brilliant staff which rallies around Lord PALMERSTON in this critical hour of English policy.

ROOSEVELT--JACKSON.--At Poughkeepsie on Thursday, July 16, by the Rev. Washington Roosevelt, CHARLES H. ROOSEVELT, Esq., Attorney and Counselor at Law, New-Rochelle, N. Y., to ANNIE J., daughter of Joseph H. Jackson, Esq., of the former place.

Yesterday the contested seats were disposed of, adverse to the Wyandot claimants. A motion to admit them to honorary seats was lost by one vote. Four of the Nebraska delegates have arrived in town, and others are expected to-day. It is very doubtful whether they will make any effort to get seats in the Convention since knowing the fate of claimants nearer home.

If any rash prophet had suggested to the Pilgrims of New-England two hundred years ago that their descendants would be called upon to decide for themselves the grave question whether a Christian State should or should not permit the Sabbath to be observed by all men after their own fashion, the said prophet would doubtless have been hanged for his pains.

LOUTREL--In this City, on Saturday, July 16, at 11 p. M. JANE DE MARSAN, wife of Louis Loutrel, aged 65 years. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited, without further invitation to attend the funeral, from her late residence, No. 578 Broome-st.. this (Monday) afternoon, at 2 o'clock. Services at St. John's Chapel, at 21/2 o'clock P. M. The remains will be taken to Trinity Cemetery.

THE AFRICAN SLAVE-TRADE.--The Washington Star has the following correction of another story of the Herald: "The recent statement of the New-York Herald, that between sixty and seventy cargoes of Africans have been landed in the United States since the successful voyage of the yacht Warderer, is incorrect.

The steamship Indian, from Liverpool, at about noon of the 6th inst., passed this station at 3 P. M. today, and will be due at Quebec at 5 A. M. of Monday. The steamship North Briton, from Quebec, arrived at Liverpool at 11 P. M. of the 5th. The steamer City of Washington was to leave Liverpool, and the Ariel to leave Southampton for New-York on the afternoon of the 6th.

The Sixth Annual Convention of Young Men's Christian Associations, which assembled in this city on Wednesday, is attended by some 250 delegates, representing an sections of the country. On Thursday morning, the delegates from New-Orleans and St. LOUIS invited Convention to hold its next meeting there. The invitation of St. Louis is most likely to be accepted.

We owe it to our readers to say that, by a confusion of manuscripts, sent up at a late hour on Friday night, our leading article of Saturday on the " Austrian Defensive Square " was rendered perfectly unintelligible. The article appeared correctly in our second edition, but we reprint it today in another column.

HONORS TO BISHOP DUANE.--The graduates of the last class at St. Mary's Hall, Burlington, N. J., have provided the funds for the election of a memorial window in the Chapel where he taught them; and it is further proposed to found in the same institutions "Bishop Do??ne Scholarship," by means of which there shall always be maintained at the Theological School of Burlington college,

The United States steamer San Jacinto went into commission on July 6, at 1.30 P. M., at the Brooklyn Navy-Yard, and is now lying off the Battery, and will in a few days sail for the coast of Africa. The following is a list of her Officers: Captain--WM. M. ARMSTRONG. Lieutenants--1st, EDWARD Donaldson; 2d, Aaron K. Hughes: 3d James Madigan; 4th P. C. Johnson;

A young lady named Callista Robinson, daughter of A. Robinson, of Southwest Oswego, N.Y., was killed by lightning on the 14th July. An eve-witness describes the catasiroplie as follows : The house was filled with smoke and the floor covered with plastering from the wails, and the parents almost distracted, 1 immediately sent for Dr. Place, who arrived in about an hour after the catastrophe.

This morning near 11 o'clock a most horrible accident occurred at the Washington Navy-yard by the bursting of a Navy cannon--a sixty eight pounder--by which two men were instantly killed and eight severely wounded. The cannon was being used in baliery practics, under orders from the Ordnance Department, under the supervosior of Messrs, Jas. Wilson and Wilsiom Nokes, Roclie, Beachman, McMillen, Stewart, Ludwig, Daniel Wilson, J. Conner, and Holland.

Our citizens were somewhat excited this morning by the announcement made at an early hour that there was a strike and riot at the canal breach in Perinton. There was a disturbance at the breach in Perinton, growing out of the dissatisfaction of the laborers. There are from seven to nine hundred men employed on the job, under the direction of Mr. KING, the Superintendent or this section.

Last week, at the theatres, was chiefly devoted to the benefits of the leading actors, who were more or loss successful, according as the weather was more or loss propitious. Mr. BUETON'S appeal to the public crew together, on the sultry evening of Friday last, an assemblage which would have been considered numerous on a cold Winter's night, with the City full of the patrons of the drama.

EXAMINATION OF A JEWISH SUNDAY SCHOOL.--The Sunday School connected with the congregation of Reformed Jews "Emanu-El," worshipping in the church in 12th street, between the Third and Fourth avenues, was examined yesterday in the presence of Mr. LEVENTMTT, Vice-President, and the School Committee. The synagogue was very well attended by adult members of both sexes, and the proceedings were of a most interesting character.

SUNDAY OBSERVANCE IN THE POST-OFFICE.--A new phase is developed in the Sabbatarian movements. In reply to the inquiry of a party in Princeton, the Post-office Department states that a letter indorsed with the words, "To lie over on the sabbath,' may be delayed until Monday,--providing the Post master at the distributing office does not overlook the indorsement.

In steamship Borussia, from Hamburg and Southampton--M. Speyer, E. Atens, D. S. Colm. lady and 2 children. A. Hanson. A. Schlesinger and lady, E. Duysing, R. Oelbermann. H. Helmkampf and lady, M. A. Hion, M. Aderson, E. Voss, A Otto, G. Weber, E. Fridan. lady and 2 children, C. Tobes, E. Balley, lady and 2 children, Mr. Waldmar.

A RESULT OF THE RAILROAD WAR.--SUIT FOR DAMAGES.--The Pittsburgh True Press states that some well-known merchants of that city have instituted proceedings in the District Court of the county, against the Pennsylvania Railroad Company for damages sustained by them in being ejected from a train on said road, while they were on their way East. on business.

THE GREAT NEWSPAPER VICTORY OF THE DAY,--The NEW-YORK TIMES is entitled to the credit at being first and foremost of the American Pies in publishing intelligence from the seat of the great European war. The accounts of Mr. RAYMOND and of his correspondent "Malak off" of the battle of ?? were not only quite full in detail (considering how raptory their preparation followed events.)

A correspondent of the Toronto Globe, gives an interesting sketch of the Red River country, now thrown open by the facilities of travel: "Our great drawback has always been this--that we are far inland and have no means of easy and speedy communication with the civilized world. This is the real secret of the slow progress which the Red River Colony has made.

The Democracy of North Carolina do not favor the President's project for the acquisition of Cuba. The Congressional candidates of the party, in that State, with the single exception of Mr. L. O'B. BEACH refuse to commit themselves to the measure. The Democratic press, following the lead of the popular sentiment, generally discontenance the proposition as one of "questionable policy;"

ANOTHER-DOMESTIC TROUBLE.--The Philadelphia Ledger, July 16, says : "The Court of Quarter Sessions was occupied, yesterday, in disposing of desertion cases. In one of these Cases there was an illustration of the difficulty generally resulting from the interference of mothers-in-law in matters concerning husband and wife. The wife, who was the complainant before the Court, is but eighteen years of age, while her husband had but completed his twenty second year the day previous.

In addition to the inquest, now being held at Bellevue Hospital upon the bodies of the woman and boy we referred to yesterday, the Coroners have been notified to hold inquests upon the following persons, who died here yesterday under the following circumstances: CATHARINE MCDONALD, 27 years of age, was brought here on the 11th inst., by Officer SHERWOOD, of the Eighteenth Ward, from No. 167 Best Sixteenth-street.

Will you allow me to correct the spelling of the name of the Commander of the French cavalry in Italy? General de Division LOUIS MORRIS (not MAUMCR) belongs to a highly respectable French family of English descent. He is a graduate of the military school (St. Cyr,) and won all his grades by conspicuous gallantry and solid talent.

The Letter addressed by the Rev. THEODORE PARKER to the members of the Twenty-eighth Congregational Society of Boston, briefly announced among the items of personal gossip a few days since, has been published in a neat volume of 175 pages, by RUFUS LEIGHTON, Jr., Boston.

The screw-steamship Indian, from Liverpool, July 6, arrived at Quebec last evening. Her advices, which are two days later, are not of decisive import. The Emperor crossed the Mincio on the 3d inst., fixing his head-quarters at Vallegio, while Villafranca was occupied by the corps of Marshal NIEL. The outposts of the enemy were quite close to those of the Allies.

"I remember," said Mr. PHILLIPS, "that in Hood's Odduics,' there is a picture of a spoiled child. The baby had been laid in an arm-chair, and there came in a man weighing about three hundred pounds, with the London Times in its hand,

From the Edgefield (S. C.) Advertiser. The question here proposed is not designed merely to startle our readers; neither do we take it as a text of an indignation article. Looking upon it as a question that must be met squarely if it be brought upon us, and believing that South Carolina should decide her course In the matter by considerations of prudence and policy, tempered throughout with principle.

A dinner to celebrate the eighty third anniversary of the Declaration of American Independence, took place on the evening of July 4, at St. James' Hall, under the auspices of the American Association, one of the principal objects of which is to afford assistance to necessitous American in London, and thus to prevent them from becoming dependent on the charity of the benevolent in this country.

The institution of Slavery has been engaged for near hail a century in a fierce and vital struggle with fanaticism. It has borne the brunt of a fearful crusade, in which the mad zeal of misguided philanthropy, the radicalism of an infidel political philosophy and the untiring artifices of national rivalries, have been combined for its overthrow and destruction.
The proceedings of the Convention, yesterday, were interesting. The Committee appointed to report a place of meeting for next year, reported in favor of Louisville, Ky.

SHAW, a highly estimable photographist on Mainstreet,deserted her home, and in company with a fellow named WM. A. LLOYD, formerly somewhat known in this community, and now, we believe, a resident of Philadelphia, fled.

Affairs In Washington. WASHINGTON, Monday, July 18. The President, accompanied by Mrs. Secretary THOMPSON and Miss LANE, left this afternoon for Bedford Springs. Gen. CULLOM, under indictment for alleged malfeasance while Clerk of the House of Representatives, to-day demanded a trial in the criminal Court, but this was postponed until the next term, owing to the absence of material witnesses for the United States.

The steamship City of Washington, from Liverpool, July 6, touching at Queenstown the following day, reached this port last evening. We thus receive advices one day later. The position of the opposing army in Italy was unaltered. The Austrians were 200,000 strong on the line of the Adige, and another great battle was deemed likely to occur at any moment.

The Springfield Republican says: "Among the invited guests expected by the Committee of Arrangements of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, are Gov. BANKS, Lieut. Gov. TRASK, Gov. MORGAN, and the chief magistrates of several of the neighboring States, ex-President FILLMOKE, who is an active member of the Association, Sir WM. LOGAN, the distinguished Canadian geologist, and ex-President VAN BU??EN.

THE GREAT BILLIARD MATCH--ROBERTS OF ENGLAND, AND PHELAN OF AMERICA.--A gentleman at present here from Dublin has arranged, by authority, a billiard match between Mr. JOHN ROBERTS, of Liverpool, the champion player of Great Britain and Ireland, and MICHAEL PHELAN, who has thus far proved himself to be the best player in this country.

The question of Sunday travel on the City Railroads in Philadelphia, has assumed an important aspect. It appears to have become the absorbing topic. On Sunday, the clergy preached against the attempted desecration of the Sabbath; the papers are filled with communications on both sides of the controversy;

AN IMPOSTOR DETECTED.--A man, who pretended to be a brother of the famous RAREY, and who has been lecturing in various quarters on the secret of horse-taming, has been arrested in Pittsburgh as an impostor. The Chronicle says: "His real name is FRANK BARCLAY, and about 13 years since he worked as a carpenter in Alleghany City.

The residents in the vicinity of Twenty-fourthstreet and Seventh-avenue have been in a state of deep excitement for a day or two past, in consequence of a singular case of supposed suicide, which took place at No. 110 West Twenty-fourth-street last Wednesday evening. An affidavit made by Dr. E. R. AKIN, of No. 206 Seventh-avenue, who was called to attend the deceased,

IMMENSE EMIGRATION ACROSS THE PLAINS.--The Secretary of the Columbus Ferry Company at Loop Fork informs the Omaha Nebruskian that the emigration across the Plains up to June 25, was as follows: 1,807 wagons, 20 hand-carts, 5,401 men, 424 women, 480 children, 1,610 horses, 406 mules, 6,010 oxen, and 6,000 sheep, had crossed this ferry at that point.

ENLARGEMENT OF AUBURN STATE PRISON.--The Auburn Advertiser, July 16, says: "The prospect is flattering that relief is soon to be furnished in the enlargement of the Prison. An architect has been appointed by the Governor to make an examination of the Prison building, and report the best and most feasible plan for enlarging the same.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: An American traveler not long since visited some of the Institutions for the Deaf and Dumb in Europe, and on his return to this country, published an account of the wonderful art, lately discovered, of teaching Deaf Mutes to speak and to hold conversation orally with others.

WOMEN IN COLLEGES.--The effort recently made for the admission of female students into the University of Michigan, has been discussed anew by the Regents of that Institution, who have resolved to adhere to their former action, and has raised the ??re of the young gentlemen of the College, who have passed strong deprecatory resolutions;

An American family, in which many of your readers are interested, Mr. and Mrs EDWARD PEEKINS, of Boston, with his mother, Mrs. DOANE, of New-Jersey, and sister and neice, Mrs. and Miss CLEVELAND, narrowly escaped the dreadful carnage at Perugia on the 20th inst.--of which you have doubtless heard through the telegraph to London--but were subjected to serious alarm and suffering.

The most significant feature of the latest intelligence received from the seat of war in Europe, is the statement that a French force of ten thousand men has been landed on the island of Lussin-Piccolo, in the Adriatic.

CASE OF RUSSIAN JUSTICE.--Last December an efficer in the elegant uniform of the Chevalier Guards galloped along one of the most crowded and fashionable streets in Petersburgh. Passing a magasin de modes, he saw a charming young girl enter. He followed her, and was struck by her sheerful but modest grace, and the freshness and tenderness which distinguished her.

THE BLOOMERS IN NEW-YORK.-Mrs. Doctor LYDIA SAYER HASBROUCK, who edits a little paper at Middletown, N. Y., recommends that the next Bloomerite, or "Dress Reform" Convention, be held in this City, for reasons which she assigns, as follows: "In my mind no better thing could be done for advancing our cause-in no way can we bring its merits so effectually before the world-as to hold our next meeting in New-York City.

NEGRO CONSPIRACY IN VIRGINIA.-The Clarksburgh (Va,) Register, July 15, says: "A negro woman belonging to Mr. M. J. Nixon, of this county, gave information on Wednesday last, that there was a combination among tke negroes of the neighborhood of Shinnston, for the purpose of running off, and defending themselves in so doing.

THE FORTY-FIRST-STREET STABBING AFFRAY.DEATH OF ONE OF THE WOUNDED.-Coroner SCHEIMER held an inquest, yesterday, at the New-York Hospital upon the body of JOHN SAMMONS, one of the three men stabbed, on Thursday night, in Forty-first-street, in a quarrel with three Germans. SAMMONS died at a late hour on Sunday night from the effects of the injuries then received.

The screw-steamship City of Washington, Capt. P??, which sailed from Liverpool at 2 P. M. on the ??th inst., and from Queenstown on the 7th, arrived here last evening. The Ariel was appointed to sail from Southampton for New-York on the same day.

Commander MAURY issues the following circular: At the instance of the Royal Society and the British Association for the Advancement of Science, the British Government is just now commencing a series of observations in and around the North Atlantic Ocean, for the purpose of investigating the law of storms and other phenomena concerning the weather in and about the ocean.

Before Justice Clerks. William Baldwin and J. Jacox vs. The Mayor, of the City of New York, and E. N. Fairchild Co.--The plaintiffs in this case claim to be the lowest bidders for the contract for constructing gatehouses for the new reservoir.

SIX MONTHS' DISASTERS ON THE WESTERN WATERS.--The list of disasters on the Western waters during the first six months of the present year, sums up a heavier loss of boats, property and lives, than at any former period. The following is the recapitulation:

The number of vessels at present reported in this port is thirty four steamers, one hundred and thirtyeight ships, one hundred and eleven barks, one hundred and twenty brigs, and one hundred and eightyeight schooners-total 591. The number of steamers is somewhat beyond the usual average, the present season being favorable for repairs, and quite a large number are temporarily detained here for that purpose.

THE LATE SHIP-YARD RIOT IN BALTIMORE--ITS ORIGIN.-- The Baltimore Exchange gives an elaborate explanation of the origin of the recent ship-yard riot in that city, and takes occasion to lament the general lawlessness that prevails in that community. It appears that the Thistle, the vessel which was to be repaired, has been sent to New-York for renovation. The Exchange draws the following sorry picture:

The means employed at the Royal Mint for the prevention of peculation is a subject of intereat to the public, and visitors to that remarkable manufactory, bewildered with the sight of thousands of pounds' worth of the precious inetals scattered around them in apparently careless profusion, inevitably ask the question of their guide, 'How are losses avoided?'

ACADEMY OF THE VISITATINON.-The Annual distribution of prizes to the pupils of the Academy of the Visitation, in Johnson-street, took place on Thursday last. The Academy is under the care of the Sisters of the.Visitation, a religious society attached to the Roman Catholic Church, and is in a prosperous condition.

To the Rev. E. H. Chapin: DEAR SIR--In your powerful, eloquent and beautiful, because Saxon, earnest and truthful sermon this morning, you gladdened my heart; and, in the words of your text, caused another "pool in the vale of Baca to be filled with water;" for, in the "great desert," which we are going through, it is to me a glad sign, like more, more, believe! "water, sweet water!"

In another part of this morning's TIMES will be found an article taken from a prominent Democratic journal of South Carolina, the Edgefield Advertiser, which undertakes to answer for that State the grave question, "Shall we accept DOUGLAS?" The Advertiser pronounces decidedly enough in the affirmative; and does not shrink from giving its reasons for this conclusion.

The Millenium, so confidently foreseen by the Hon. Miss MURRAY, does not seem to be very near at hand in the prosperous City of Mobile. Instead of bending their intellects to the task of emancipating the slaves they already have, the people of that cotton-loving community are evidently inflamed with the desire of adding to themselves other slaves that as yet they know not of.

Father Chiniquy writes to a friend in this City, under date of July 14, in a desponding strain. He says: "I am going back to my little colony with a truly broken heart. I have not been able to sleep a single moment this night, having constantly before my eyes the imminent ruin of my dear colony."

ATLANTIC, OF JAMAICA, VS. OSCEOLA, OF BROOKLYN. These Clubs played yesterday, upon the grounds of the Atlantic Club, at Bedford, L. I. The afternoon was very pleasant, and the usual large Brooklyn audience was in attendance to view their favorite pastime. The game was a close one, and was well contested by both Clubs-the Osceolas winning by two runs only. Eight innings were played. The following is the score:

The great Hall of the Cooper Union was filled comfortably last evening by an audience who went to listen to the oratory of some young men, members of the Graduating Class, who were selected to compete for the annual prizes for superiority in oratory. Quite a number of the School officers of the City, with the Faculty of the Free Academy and a few invited guests, occupied the stage.

WALLACK'S THEATRE.--A new piece in this warm weather is a gift which we should receive from the gods with all humility and gratitude. And in good truth the new piece produced at Wallack's Theatre last evening would very well justify some thanks. "Lalla Rookh " is a decided success, despite the little inconvenances which marred the general effect at the first representation last evening, and which we hope to see amended.

Mr. EVERETT'S last Mount Vernon paper has the following personal reminiscence of HUMBOLDT: "It will not, I think, be denied that the great reputation of Mr. VON HUMBOLDT was built upon his American expedition, and the scientific, historical, statistical and miscellaneous works for which it furnished the materials.

The Board met last evening at the usual hour Councilman CORNELL in the Chair. The Board concurred with the Aldermen in directing the New Jersey Railroad and Transportation Company to run ferry-boats from their slip in Jersey City to the foot of Desbrosses-street.

At the last monthly meeting of the Board of Trade of Chicago, the custom prevailing among elevator men of speculating in grain belonging to other parties, by selling, shipping, or loaning the same, thereby jeopardizing the interest of owners, and exercising an improper influence on the trade, was brought up. Resolutions were passed deprecating the same.

Mr DEAR WHITBREAD: Some few months ago we were speaking of the cases of cruelty on shipboard, which the newspapers had reported, and you asked me whether anything could be done to prevent their repetition. The subject is most involved and difficult, and I cannot enter into it t length.

Two fighting men known as PRICE and KELLY have settled the preliminaries for a fight for $1,000 a side, to take place on tne 6th of October next, at Point Albino, Canada. KELLY is said to be training at Fort Hamilton, and PRICE in the vicinity of Boston. The following are the ARTICLES OF AGREEMENT, Entered into this 1st day of July, 1859,

FOOT-RACES-SEVENTY-EIGHT MILES IN NINE HOURS.--The Albany Argus says: "Two remarkable foot-races came off on the Empire Trotting Course yesterday. Two Indians, named SMITH and BENNETT, matched themselves to run 100 miles within thirteen hours. During the morning the atmosphere was very sultry, and the mercury, at 10 o'clock, stood at 90?? in the shade.

BUSSELL.--In this City, on Sunday, July 17. KITTY, eldest daughter of the late Geo. Bussell, Jr., in the 14th year of her age. The friends of the family are invited to attend the funeral, this day, (Tuesday,) July 19, at 3 o'clock, from No. 727 Houston-St. WEBSTER--In this City, on Sunday, July 17, after a lingering illness.

Attorney-General BLACK has, in compliance with the request of the President of the United States, rendered an opinion in the case of CHRISTIAN ERNST, a native of Hanover, and who emigrated to this counby in 1851, when he was about ten years of age.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I am directed by the management of the Mammoth Musical Festival to correct a misstatement of fact which occurs in your journal of this morning. The only trouble which occurred last evening arose from some difficulty between one of those present and a special officer employed on the grounds.

The Hon. TOM CORWIN opened the campaign in Ohio on the 15th July, by delivering a stirring speech at Xenia. He said: "He had met his fellow-citizens with a view to settle his relations with the Republican Party, and to define his position before his constituents.

A certain Rev. Mr. PRETYMAN, having recently died in England, attention has been called by the Press to the preferments lavished upon him by his father, formerly Bishop of Winchester. A correspondent of the London Times furnishes that journal with the following interesting list of the situations held (not filled) in the Church by this meek divine:

GOVERNORS OF THE ALMSHOUSE--The weekly statement of the Governors of the Almshouse gives 7,092 as the number of inmates in the different institutions, being an increase during the week of 40. Since July 9, 39 have died; 1,500 have been discharged; III have been sent to the Penitentiary; 8 to the State Prison, and 1,758 have been admitted.

The immediate and prospective importance in the history of our times, of the great victory won by NAPOLEON III. over FRANCIS JOSEPH of Austria, at Solferino on the 24th of June, has induced us to present our readers with a full, accurate and intelligible plan of the battle-field of that memorable day.

So many rumors are afloat, so much exaggeration, respecting the Indian troubles and their origin in his Territory, that we deem it necessary to give a concise history of the whole affair, which we have been able to gather from sources every way reliable.

The Vanderbilt steamship Ariel, from Havre and Southampton on the 6th inst., arrived at this port last night. Her advices have been anticipated by the Indian, at Quebec, and the City of Washington, at this port. The R. M. steamship Africa, from Liverpool on the 9th inst., with two days' later news, is now in her eleventh day.

From the Cincinnati Gazette. A group of living serpents brought from North Carolina were secured for scientific purposes, and have been handed over to Professor FOOTE, of the Medical College, for safe-keeping. They consist of two rattlesnakes, two bull snakes, one spreading adder, one black racer, and one joint snake. They are all very fine specimens.

The great historical painting by COPLEY, which has just been presented to the City of Boston, is an acquisition to the whole country. This work justly takes its place in the first class of historical paintings. It is remarkable for its exquisite finish, spirited grouping, and thorough truthfulness, combining correctness of portraiture with life like vigor.

Stringent laws have been enacted at the instigation of our Harbor Commissioners to prevent the accumulation of silt in the bay, and for the avoidance of the danger which must result from steamboats throwing ashes and cinders into the river.

Before Justice Clerke. Elizabeth Bloxham vs. John Bloxham; Robert Diedricks vs. Samuel Ward.--Orders settled. Hopper vs. Hopper.--This was an application for alimony in the action. The parties to this suit have been married forty years, and now the wife, at the advanced age of fifty-six years, sues for a divorce from her husband who is sixty-four years of age.

From the St. Joseph (Mo.) West. About dusk, evening before last, two young men, who work for THOMAS HUBBARD. residing about 4 1/2 miles from this city, on the Rochester road, were sitting on the fence near the house, when one remarked that he heard a gun go off, and very soon afterwards a pair of horses harnessed to a buggy came walking along slowly, coming west.
The philosopher of the school of COMTE may justly regard the latest development of Mexican politics as the happiest illustration of his master's creed.

The Boston Post of the 19th, says: "It is rumored among the spiritual circles in NewYork, that Prof. FELTON has become a believer, if not a meduim, finding, in the course of his researches, that the evidence was irresistible. We do not, however, notice his name among the expected speakers at Plymouth; nor was he at the spiritual pic-nic the other day.

The Committee appointed by the Constitutional Convention to prepare and report a Preamble and Bill of Rights, have submitted the following: PREAMBLE. Existence was the first gift of Omnipotence to man. It is the end of the institution and administration of Government to secure to every individual perfect freedom to enjoy in safety and tranquillity the rights and blessings of that existence;

AMERICAN MECHANICS IN RUSSIA.--Ever since the commencement of the great St. Petersburgh Railroad, the Messrs. WINANS have been providing excellent employment for such skillful American mechanics who were disposed to render themselves useful in that distant country. Many of these have been successful. and are now occupying positions of responsibility and profit. Whilst others are following.

The Hon. D. R. ECKELS, Chief Justice of the Territory, accompanied by the lion. ANDREW HUM PHREYS, Indian Agent, returned to this city on tile evening of the 15th. Judge ECKELS was met abou twelve miles east of the city by a number of Federa officers and citizens, and escorted in in state.

In the British Court for Divorce and Matrimonial Causes, on the 1st inst., the case of Mure vs. Mure and Chichester was called up. This was a petition by Mr. WM. MURE for a dissolution of marriage, on the ground of the adultery of his wife, LUCY VIRGINIA MURE, with the co-respodent, the Hon. GEORGE AUGUSTUS HAMILTON CHICHESTER.

COOK.-In this City, on Tuesday, July 19, JAMES C. COOK, in the 46th year of his age. The friends and relatives of the family, and the members of the St. David's Benefit Society, are respec??y invited to attend his funeral. from his late residence. No. 258 ??d st., on Thursday, 21st inst., at 2 o'clock P. M. The remains will he taken to Cypress Hills.

The Hon. THOMAS CORWIN, who was elected last Fall to represent the Seventh District of Ohio in the Thirty-Sixth Congress, made a speech to his constituents on Friday of last week, at Xenia, a sketch of which may be found in the TIMES this morning.

The Boston Journal, July 18, has the following particulars of the case of the slave MARIA at Ply. mouth, reported yesterday by telegraph: "This morning, at Plymouth, Mr. N. B. SPOONER petitioned Judge THOMAS RUSSELL, of the Superior Court, (who was in Plymouth at the time.) for a writ of habeas corpus, to take the body of one MABIA GASKINS, a female slave then in Plymouth.

The case of Monsieur Julien has occupied the Paris tribunals. He is in the debtor's prison in consequence of old liabilities of a dozen years date, and had sought to become a regular bankrupt in French law, but he is unable to do so from the fact of his having become naturalized in England.

SOMEBODY TO BLAME.-The Coroner's Jury who have been investigating the causes of the terrible disaster on the Michigan Southern and Northern Indiana Railroad, have, after a long delay, rendered their verdict, which is to the effect that the accident was caused by the smallness of the culvert, it not being half the size that it should have been.

From the Rochester Democrat. MESSRS. EDITORS: Permit me to call your attention and that of the public to the following facts: In the late battle of Solferino, between the Allies and the Austrians. it is computed that three hundred and fifty thousand soldiers were engaged for at least twelve hours. Of these three hundred thousand were armed with muskets.

To the Editor of the London Times. SIR: Perhaps amid the press and distraction of politics which are now agitating the great world you can find room for the account of a most extraordinary deception which has been practised in the republic of letters, some details of which I now beg to lay before you.

The Americans in London, residents and travelers, representing the great Republic not unfairly in the various phases of our social, commercial and political activity, have fallen of late years, with singular facility, into the good old British custom of eating dinners and drinking toasts, to the glory and for the good of their dear native land.

From the St. Joseph (Mo.) Examiner. The following letter was addressed to Dr. EDWARDS, of this city, Penitentiary Physician. The writer was, not long since, an inmate of the Missouri Penitentiary, occupying most of the period of his incarceration, the post of hospital steward. He proved a superior nurse-the best indeed that Dr. EDWARDS ever saw in that position.

IMPORTANT DECISION--NEGROES IN OHIO.--The Cleveland Herald, July 14, has the following: "The Court of Common Pleas for Cuyahoga County, through Judge Foote, this morning, delivered an important decision. At the last election, FREEMAN H. MORRIS, tailor, of this city, and having about one-fourth Negro blood in his veins, presented himself at the First Ward voting place, and was barred from voting on account of his Negro blood.

AUBURN STATE PRISON.--JOHN P. HUBBARD, Esq., one of the keepers recently discharged from the Auburn Prison, by Inspector RHODES, has instituted proceedings to test the constitutionality of the law under which a single member of the Board of Inspectors has heretofore exercised the power of suspending officers, and appointing others to discharge the duties of these suspended.

The recent advices from Europe have chronicled new movements of the ex-Governor of Hungary, and have at length informed us of his arrival at the seat of war in Italy, on overt terms of friendship with the Allied Powers. We are even told in the latest dispatches that KOSSUTH has issued a manifesto, calling on the Hungarians to rise, and promising that he will soon be among them.

The President has recognized EMIL CHRISTIAN HAMMER as Vice-Consul of Denmark for the State of Massachusetts, to reside at Boston. The British and Spanish Ministers are preparing to leave the city, for the purpose of visiting the Summer resorts in the North.

NEW-YORKERS' BALL AT NEW-BEDFORD.--The citizens of New-Bedford are to be entertained next Saturday evening, at the Parker House, by a party of New-York gentlemen, now engaged in a pleasure cruise in the Andrew Stewart. DEATH OF THE KING OF SWEDEN AND NORWAY.--A telegram from Stockholm announces the death of OSCAR, King of Sweden and Norway. The event occurred on the 8th of July, after an illness which had incapacitated the King from taking any active part in Government since Sept., 1857. King OSCAR was the son of BERNADOTTE, whom he succeeded on the Swedish throne in 1844. Born in Paris in 1799,

MAIL ROBBERY.-An extensive mail robbery was perpetrated at Kalamazoo on the 19th July, the regular mail bag between Detroit and Kalamazoo having been stolen at the station, carried into the woods and robbed of its contents. It was found about two miles from the place, with all the letters opened, and whatever money they may have contained abstracted.

THE LAW OF CORYRIGHT.-The Constitution has the following official information regarding copyrights: "Under the act of 1831, respecting copyrights, the duty of superintending the operation of the law was confided to the State Department.

When our paper went to press on Tuesday evening we referred, in a brief article in our city column, to an excitement prevailing among our colored citizens relative to the rumored recent rendition of three jugitive slaves from the State of Missouri into the custody of their masters.

MORTALITY.-From the 16th to the 23d inst, there were 149 deaths in Brooklyn, according to the official statement of Dr. BoYD, Health Officer. These are classified as follows: men, 9; women, 18; boys, 63; girls, 59; adults, 27; children, 122; males, 72; females, 77; colored persons, I.

TREMENDOUS BOILER EXPLOSION AT WORCESTER.-A terrific explosion occurred in the factory of Messrs. I. WASHBURN Co., at Worcester, Mass, on Friday, July 22, of which the Spy gives account: "One of the most terrific explosions that ever occurred in this vicinity, took place in this city yesterday afternoon, about 1 1/2 o'clock, at the wire factory of Messrs. I. WASRBURN Co., on Grove-street.

A Treaty of Peace has been signed between the Emperors of France and Austria, and the Italian war has been brought to a sudden conclusion. We Received this highly important intelligence by North Briton, which arrived at Quebec yesterday, with advices four days later-she having left Liverpool on the 13th.

DISTRACTED STATE OF THE REPUBLIC--A FRESH REVOLUTION INEVITABLE--THE BLACKS IN POSSESSION OF PUERTO CABELLO--RETURN OF GEN. PAEZ TO THE UNITED STATES. The bark Venus, Capt. ATKINSON, arrived at this port yesterday morning from Curacoa, with dates from that place to July 8.

The anticipations which we expressed on Saturday last of the progress of events in Italy have been suddenly and fully met. The war in Italy has been ended, without a Congress of the Great Powers, by the victories of France and the wisdom or the fears of Austria.

The Post-office Department having determined to resume the investigation into the alleged official misconduct of the Postmaster at Chicago, two special agents have been dispatched thither for that purpose.

The New Croton Board. To the Editor of the New-York Times: A writer, without signature, in your paper this mornings, asks who THOMAS B. TAPPAN is? The writer certainly could not have been acquainted wiht the affairs of this City for the last twenty-five years, for he would not be under the necessity of asking this question.

HARRIET MARTINEAU ON THEO?? FOURTH.--In HARRIET MARTINNAU'S last letter to the Anti-Slavery Standard, dated at Ambleside, July 4, she says: "The Fourth of July comes to those who know its significance under widely different aspects to-day. I imagine you, Sir, sitting in the midst of the din of rejoicing in your great City. .

A most dastardly attempt to throw a railroad train off the track was detected and frustrated on Thursday evening, about a mile this side of Pittsford Station, on the Auburn and Rochester Railroad; and to enhance the Satisfaction afforded by the circumstance, we are enabled to state that the villian who attempted to execute the murderous design has been arrested, and is now in jail awaiting trial for the crime.

The Atlantic Monthly has taken to itself a new editor in the person of Dr. J. W. PALMER, of this city, already so well known by his own pictures of life in the far East and West, and by his admirable translation of MICHELET'S book, L'Amour Dr. PALMER will reside in New-York and cooperate with his Boston colleagues in giving to the Atlantic that cosmopolitan character which is essential to its permanent success.

MR: GISBORNE'S OCEAN TELEGRAPH PROJECT.We learn by a letter received this morning from Paris that Mr. F. N. GISEORNE, who projected the telegraphic cable between Nova Scotia and Massachusetts, delated in our Legislature last Winter, has just completed two important contracts of a similar kind in France.

The steamer Ravenswood, Capt. hILLER, running between New-Orleans and Mandeville, Madisonville and Covington, took fire soon after she left Mandeville on Saturday, July 16. and burned to the water's edge. There were about thirty persons on board, including the officers and crew. Mr. BLOOM, an aged German, of Mandeville, was drowned in consequence of his being panic struck.

By the arrival of the Tennessee at New-Orleans we obtain possession of our files and correspondence from Vera Cruz and the City of Mexico. The details of news, of which we have had but a telegraphic synopsis, are of the highest interest.

The Leavenworth Times publishes the following Address of the Republican Central Committee of Kansas, announcing the Republican plan of action: FELLOW CITIZENS: After a violent and painful struggle of four years, Kansas has arrived at the great political crisis of her existence.

Undeterred by the experience of ?? DAVID, the founders of the American Constitution provided in that very charter of our ?? being for a periodical numbering of the people. Our rational theory of representation of course made such a provision necessary, and it has been complied with, more or less successfully, at regular intervals of ten years ever since the year 1790.

The People of the State of New-York, by their Attorney General, vs. James Bowen and owners.--SUTHERLAND, J.--This is an action in the nature of a quoivarranto, against the defendants, for assuming to be and acting as a corporation without authority of law. The complaint alleges that the defendants have associated themselves together and claim to be a corporation, and are unlawfully acting as a corporation.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I read the account of the sad and immensely "fatal termination to a pleasure excursion." in Friday's TIMES; also, in Saturday's TIMES DIRECTIONS FOR "resuscitating the drowned." taken from the North and South. I regret that you had not in your possession the modern system, or as it is known in the profession, MARSHALL HALL'S Ready Method.

JIMMERSON.-In this City, on Saturday, July 23, in the 20th year of her age, ANGELINE, daughter of N.S. and Eleanor Jimmerson. The friends and relatives of the family, also the offieers and members of E. L. Snow Social Union. No, 1, and the Order in general, are respectfully invited to attend her funeral, at the residence of her parents, No. 260 5th st., this (Monday) afternoon, at 2 o'clock.

MURDER AND SUICIDE IN ILLINOIS. The Southern Illinoisan, July 15, has the following: "A most lamentable occurrence happened in the town of Equality in this County on Wednesday evening. A Baptist Minister, (we have failed to learn his name,) from christian county. Kentucky, stopped at the boarding-house of Mrs. McCoel during the day, and in the evening started on his way.

THE WASHINGTON MIBYNEBT.-The difficult of leaching tile top of the Washington Monument column was overcome on Monday evening last. It was found that although arrows might be shot and stones thrown over the column while free, yet as soon as they were attached to packthread, force sufficient to get them over could not be obtained.

When the monk VARNES among other emissaries of the Clerical Power was sent from Rome to Paris, in 1849, to secure the aid of the French Republic in restoring the clerical authority in the Eternal City, he went about retailing a story of Pope GREGORY XVI. and the Prince LOUIS NAPOLEON BONAPARTE, which the peace just concluded in Europe is likely enough to revive.

The steamship New-York, Capt. Von Santen, from Bremen, July 9, and from Southampton, July 12, arrived here last evening. On the 13th, off the Lizard, she passed the Savonia, hence for Southampton; and subsequently passed the Ocean Queen, hence for the same destination.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Allow a working man to answer for you the inquiries which "M. S. T." makes, in his note published he to-day's (Monday's)TIMES. He asks: 1. "Do the successful business men of our community....use the Sabbath as a day of recreation, ?" Certainly they do, to a considerable extent, as any one will see for himself by visiting on Sunday the anburban places of resort.

American has the following bit of personal gossip: "Seven years ago an English boy of 17, a stranger, engaged to work for us at type-setting, with which he had an indifferent knowledge. He wes John Bull allover, persistent, stubborn and industrious-setting type by day and reading law in Riddle's building at evening. Same eight months passed,

VIRGINIA STEWART, the woman who was shot on Saturday evening last by her paramour, ROBERT C. McDONALD, is still at the City Hospital. The improvement which was apparent on Sunday evening did not continue. During the night she relapsed into an unconscious state, at times raving incoherently. All day yesterday she remained in the same condition, and Dr. QUIMBY is of opinion that death is inevitable. and may occur at any moment.

DIED. FAIRCHILD.-In this City, on Sunday, July 21, of consumption. Mrs. JANE FAIRCHILD, wife of Peter Fairchild, in the 58th year of her age. The friends and relatives of the family are respectfully invited to attend her funeral, from the house of her brother-in-law. No. 247 West 36th-st., without further invltation, on Wednesday afternoon, at 2 o'clock.

President BUCHANAN, his Cabinet, and the Constitution newspaper, are not the only high Democratic authorities in the City of Washington. There exists at the capital a sort of independent Democratic organ, the States by name, by which notes of warning, encouragement or entreaty are from time to time poured into the listening ears of the land.

We learn no further developments relating to the seizure of the ship Atlantic at this port. Since the date of my last letter to you, affairs in Mexico have continued in their regular unvarying course of rain and anarchy. The contending parties to the civil war have been as trifling and inactive as ever, and their leaders have manifested the usual portion of treachery common to their natures, although no positive results have yet taken place.

General JOSE.A. PAEZ and his companions, who came from Veneuzela in the brig Rowena, arriving at Philadelphia on Sunday, proceeded directly to this City, and put up at the Union-place Hotel. The reason of the disgust of General PA?? at the state of things in Veneuzela grew out of the jealousy of General CASTRO.

1859. PRELIMINARY EVENTS. April 19.-Departure of the first body of French troops from Toulon-Austrian ultimatum dispatched from Vienna to Turin. April 23.-It is received at Turin. April 26.-The limit fixed by the ultimatum expires-Count CAVOUR declines the Austrian conditions-Statement of the warquestion addressed to the Corps Legislalif by Count WALEWSKI-French troops first cross Mont Cenis.

WHEAT CROP IN THE GENESEE COUNTRY.-Although not so injurious as first reported, the frost af. fected the wheat crop very materially in many por. tions of the Genesee country, reducing the aggregate yield at least fifty per cent. But it would seem that the misfortune has not been without a compensating benefit.

THE TAXES.-The joint Board of Aldermen and Supervisors held an adjourned meeting last evening to consider the amount necessary to be levied for carr ing on the City Government t another year. As has been the practice at almost every meeting held, the first business was to undo what had been done at a previous meeting, and in accordance with this programme the sixth resolution, adopted at the last meetng, was reconsidered to begin with.

From the Cincinnati Gazette. HENRY P. BOYLAN, of Utica, New York, is a young man of about twenty-four years of age, with dashing address, and for one of so few years, well versed in the ways of the world.

The erection of public drinking-hydrants in Philadelphia has been ordered by the City Councils. The Ledger describes the plan: "The Committee finally decided to award one contract for the erection in front of the State-house, of a hydrant, in accordance with the plan of Mr. Gordon. This will combine the hydrant with a lamp-post, of a highly ornamental description.

From a Washington correspondent, who possesses the happy faculty of being able to penetrate the fogs in which the devotees of wax and red tape envelope themselves, we receive a synopsis of Mr. McLANE'S new Convention with the Liberal Government of Mexico. The moderation of the concessions obtained is creditable to the Envoy. There is no acquisition of territory.

The Navy Department is in receipt of dispatches of Flag-Officer LAVALETTE, of the Mediterranean Squadron, dated on board the flag ship Wabash, at Trieste, June 29. It appears that, owing to the unsettled state of Tuscany and the Papal States, and apprehensions of an outbreak at Naples, as well as by request of the United States Ministers at Rome and Naples, the Macedonian and Wabash remained cruising upon the coast of Italy for several months.

To the Editor of the New- York Times: SIR: An article appeared in your yesterday's issue which places me in a very unpleasant position before the public; and, In consideration of the same. I would beg a suspension of opinion until the hour of trial, when I trust I shall prove the charge of perjury preferred against me by a man named EDWARD PARKER to be a gross fabrication.

The Long Island Ferry Company vs. The Brooklyn Ferry Company.--This was an application by the plaintiffs for an injunction against the defendants to restrain them from running ferry boats between this City and Williamsburgh, from points known as the Peck-slip and Grand-Street ferries.

Accident with the command promulgated by Gov. MORGAN, at the instigation of Gen. SANDFORT the Twelfth Regiment, declared "disorderly" and "contumelious" by these gentlemen, for refusing to drop their own individuality, and amalgamate with the Tenth Regiment, yesterday proceeded from their armory in Broome-street to the State Arsenal in Brooklyn, where they delivered up their arms.

I spent a large part of yesterday in our jail here, conversing with those four persons who are there imprisoned, charged with those high crimes which have caused great excitement not only here, but in the surrounding counties in Indiana and this State. In the course of that conversation, TAYLOR ROBERTS reiterated to me his confession, with full consent to publish the same.

A spirited and closely-contested yacht race came off in Massachusetts Bay yesterday. There was a large fleet of sailing-craft in and about the harbor of Nahant, which at one time numbered one hundred and fifty sail. Besides those yachis which took part in the regatta, were seen the schooner Prioress, of Newburyport, decked with gay flags, and bearing a lively party of excursionists;

BREADSTUFFS depressed under North Brilon's advices. Flour very dull. Wheat lower; sales of 5,000 bushels; white $1 27??$1 31, and choice Kentucky $1 35; red $1 20. Corn dull, and 4c. lower; yellow 80c.@81c, Oats dull at 3Sc.@39c. PROVISIONS unchanged. WHISKY dull at 27c.@28c. NEW ORLEANS, Monday, July 25.

Y.-The Troy Whig, July 25, says: " A deep gloom pervaded the portion of the community this morning, upon the announcement that a dispatch had been received in this city from Plaitsburgh, that CORNELIUS H. BAILEY, a former well-known resident of Troy, had been shot down in cold blood.

Rights of way across the Northern States, between the Rio Grande and ports on the Gulf of California, with guarantees for their protection and safety.

At noon, yesterday, the debate commenced on the subject of the Northern Boundary, and the argument has just closed. The vote was immediately taken, and resulted in establishing the State boundary upon our present outskirts, except on the West. The Convention agreed upon the twenty-third meridian of longitude west from Washington, which makes our State about 300 miles in extent from East to West, and 210 from North to South.

Tile Hon. James P. Screven, a prominent politician in Georgia of the State-Rights Party, died at the Virginia Hot Springs, July 16, aged 60. He was a physician, pursued his medical studies in England, under Sir Astley Cooper, and practiced his profession in Savannah until 1835. when he retired. He had been a member of the Georgia Senate, Superintendent of the Savannah Water-Works, and Mayor of the city.

The steamship New-York, of the Bremen line, from Southampton, July 12, arrived here last evening. Her advices are not so late as those of the North Briton, and embrace nothing relative to the Treaty of Peace. We extract liberally from our files in illustration of events preceding that result.

From the Washington States. We would save the Democracy from harm--we would save it from severe animadversions--by cautioning it in time to beware of the dangers which will be set it in the construction of a platform.

MASS MEETING OF THE FRIENDS OF SUNDAY TRAVEL, The supporters of Sunday travel in Philadelphia held a mass meeting in Independence square on Saturday evening. Over four thousand persons were present. Mr. AQUILA PASCOE presided. Speeches were made by SAMUEL DAVIS, JOSIAH BOND, (a Quaker,) Messrs. COHEN, MARCHER and COATES, and others, and a series of resolutions, offered by Mr. ANDREW MILLER, was adopted.

A QUADRILATERAL TAKEN.--Mr. DELAVAN, the City Inspector, has proved himself a great conqueror and public benefactor. Yesterday he marshaled his forces before the famous quadrangle of piggeries and bone-boiling nuisances, bounded cast and west by the Sixth-avenue and Broadway, and south and north by Fiftieth and Fifty-third streets.

We mentioned in our last issue that the contain, mate and second mate of the American ship Messenger had been severally sentenced to three months' imprisement in Victoria Goal for the barbarities practiced by item on certain seamen under their control--Capt. MABTON being also fined $250.

Tile R. M. steamship Europa fron Liverpool on the 16th inst., with three days later European advices, arrived at Halifax at 1 o'clock, P. M., yesterday, but we are unable, in consequence of the continued misunderstanding of the Agent of the Associated Press with the Nova Scotia line of telegraph, to give the news this morning.

ANTI-WILD CAT MEETING IN MINNESOTA.--The mercantile community of Minnesota are taking strong measures against the wild cat banking system that the "operators" have succeeded in inaugurating in that State. A large meeting of merchants and others at Minneapolis recently adopted the following amongst other resolutions:

NEW MILITARY ACADEMY.--At the last session of the Legislature of Pennsylvania an act was passed incorporating the "Valley Forge Military Academy," to be located in Upper Merion Township. Montgomery County. It is intended to be for the civil and military education of youth, and will be under the control of a Board of seven Trustees.

During the month of August State Elections will be held in Kentucky, Tennessee, Alabama, North Carolina, Arkansas, and Texas. Full State tickets are to be elected in all these States. The contest is peculiarly animated in Kentucky and Tennessee, in each of which the opposing candidates have been actively engaged for some weeks past in a personal canvass.

THE INDIA-RUBBER CONTROVERSY.--Mr. HORACE H. DAY, having sued certain individuals in Baltimore for infringing the exclusive right which he asserts to the making and vending of elastic woven rubber goods, a decision, which has appeared already in our columns, was rendered recently in his favor by he Federal Court for the District of Maryland.

There are twenty-three Savings Banks in New-Hampshire, and the amount of the deposits is $4, 138,-822. Massachusetts has eighty-six Savings Banks, with deposits amounting to $34 000,000. The pioneer Savings Bank in Boston has deposits amounting to $5,966,843, or $1,768,021 more than all the savings institutions of New-Hampshire. Amount one-fifth part of the total population of Massachusetts have funds in some savings institution.

Our mercantile marine appears to be afflicted with two chronic disorders, which must seriously affect the prosperity of our shipping interests if some remedy cannot be discovered for therm. They are the worthlessness of the sailors, and tile cruelty of their officers.

Departure of the Mountain Meadow Children--Reception of the instructions to Federal Officials. We have received files of the Desert News and the Valley Tan to the 29th June. The news from Salt Lake City is interesting. The official instructions to the Federal officers in the Territory, (published some weeks ago in the TIMES,) had been received with great glee by the Mormons.

MR. BLONDIN AT ROCHESTER.--The Rochester Union, July 22, says: We received a call yesterday from Mons. BLONDIN, who has just returned from a brief visit to Cincinnati. He was accompanied by his agent, Mr. COLCORD. These gentlemen visited Buchester at the invitation of Mr. MEECH, for the purpose of examining the ground about Genesee Falls, and making arrangements for a crossing there by BLONDIN, on a right-rope.

From the Worcester Transcript. The first rowing clubs at Yale were formed in 1843, and since that time boating has been steadily guining in favor, so that now probably one-third of the students are enrolled among the different clubs. The navy organization, which is peculiar to that college, was established in 1853, and consists at present of fourteen boats, comprising four shell boats, four club boats, built lightly for racing, and six pleasure barges.

The arrival of the Camilla from the river Platte, has brought us the information of the departure of the Messenger Bird from Valparaiso, supposed bound for San Francisco. This is the vessel of which I wrote in my last; the captain having bolted with the cargo originally destined for the United States. All sorts of rumors are afloat with reference to this piratical transaction and its author.

Among the staples of Kentucky, blackberries will henceforth be enumerated. A correspondent of the Cincinnati Gazette gives an account of the harvesting of the backberry crop in, Kentucky the present season:

From the Detroit Tribune. The indomitable Hollanders are prosecuting the construction of the harbor at the mouth of Black River, on Lake Michigan, with characteristic energy and success. They have already extended substantial piers three hundred feet into the lake, on both sides of the outlet, and will extend them some three hundred feet further the present season, to ten feet depth of water.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Will you permit a citizen of Wisconsin a reasonable space in your paper, in reply to communication in a lake number of the TIMES, heated as above, and signed "A Bandholder." The article referred to contains many gross errors and misstatements in relation to the subject, doing manifest injustice to this State, which should not pass unnoticed.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: About a year ago a young German couple arrived here from Leipsic, Saxony; they were married in "the Old Country" by one of the American Consuls. The young wife left everything dear to her--a loving family and numerous friends--to follow her husband to a strange land, hoping that he would reward her love with kindness and affection. She found herself deceived.

We are still lying in the harbor of Chelbourg owing to the slow manner of doing business which characterizes the inhabitants of this town, having taken all this time to coal up. After having ordered a launch for bringing the coal, and having waited a sufficient length of time for its arrival, our Captain, with his accustomed energy, went on shore to find out if possible the cause of the great delay.

The relatives and friends of the family, and the members of the Bapiot ?? Church, are respectfully invited to attend her funeral, from the Church in 2d av , between 10th and 11th sts., this (Wednesday) afternoon, at 2 1/2 o'clock.

A CHURCH SEIZED WITH A BILIOUS ATTACK.--Last Sabbath was Quarterly Meeting of the M. E. Church, and, as usual on such occasions, the Sacrement was administered. After the meeting adjourned, the members went their several ways, some to dine with friends in town, some to their homes in the country.

He purchased, I am told. a saddle from Mr. HICKSON, and the peculiar articles of the lower man for which the late Mr. SLATER had been long renowned.

THE LAW OF LIBEL.--For a considerable period the decisions of the Courts in cases of libel suits against the conducters of public journals have leaned strongly to the side of liberality and common sense. The editorial profession, accordingly, began to feel that the law was its friend;

Judging from what we learn from members of the book trade, we are happy to say that the coming trade sale, to be holden on the 2d of August, promises to be equally successful with the sales that have just closed in our city. From all quarters of the country, South and West, come positive assurances of a large attendance of the trade. The catalogue is very large.

We have received Nos. 33 and 35 of the Musical Friend. The merits of this excellent publication, which has now fairly passed out of the bounds of experiment into the area of the most confirmed success, are being deservedly recognized. The orders for it both in the city and from the country, are, we understand, on a most encouraging scale, and we are very glad to here it.

Yesterday we had a conversation with Mr. J. A. CARPENTER of Detroit Mich., who has just returned from the Gregory Diggings, in the newly discovered Pike's Peak ??. Mr. CARPENTER states that he and seven others left Michigan for the mines on the 16th of March last, and went by the way of the Kansas City route. Route.

M. at WALDEMYER'S drove yard, corner of Fifty-fourth-street and Fifth-avenue.

At a recent meeting of the Board of Trustees of the Indiana University it was ordered that the lands donated to the Institution by the State should be appraised and put in market this Fall. The University lands comprise about 23,000 acres, and lie in fourteen different counties in the State.

Hearing that the railroad between Milan and Brescia--which was only reopened to the public on the 1st of the month-is about to be reclosed, I made the best of my way back, as I experienced no little trouble in getting to Brescia last time; and though that noble city is to me far more interesting than Milan--beyond the pettegolezzi of the day you get little general information worth having.

There are few who have heard of St. Catherine's, although in the little town which bears that name is one of the most remarkable medicinal springs on the continent, or indeed in the world; for, with the exception of a single spa in Germany, there is no known water of such powerful efficacy as that which gushes from the artesian well at this place.
