We have the most cheering intelligence from our political friends in Iowa. The campaign has opened under the most favorable auspices, and there every reason to believe that the Republican ticket will be elected by a larger majority than has ever before been given in that State.

CELESTIAL PHENOMENON.--A correspondent of the National Intelligencer describes a phenomenon witnessed in Washington: On Thursday last, the 21st July at half-past nine o'clock. P. M., a remarkable phenomenon was noticed by several persons in this city. Attention was first drawn to a light not like that of a flash of lighting, but increasing by degrees, though rapidly in intensity, suggesting the idea of a piece of firework.

REDUCTION OF POSTAGE TO GERMANY BY BREMEN OR HAMBURG MAIL.--We are requested to state that the postal administration of the Thurn and Taxis, in Frankfort-on-the-Main, has recently reduced the German postage upon letters for or from the United States, sent via Bremen or Hamburg, to the uniform rate of five cents, and, consequently, the single rate of half an ounce or under, for letters between the Untied States and Frankfort on-the-Main, Saxe-Coburg-Gotha. IMPROVING THE NAVIGATION OF THE OHIO RIVER.--The Cincinnati papers publish the report of the Committee appointed to consider the improvement of the navigation of the Ohio River. The report affirms the insufficiency of the present canal, and takes up in succession the various plans which have been presented for the construction of a new canal on the Indiana side.

The news by the Europe, after the usual delay to which all important European advices have been subjected this Summer, came to hand yesterday in the afternoon. The dates from Liverpool are fully confirmed. The news of peace is fully confirmed, but no further particulars had transpired beyond the fact that the Princes of Tuscany and Modena are to return to their States.

The name of the Rev. Mr. FROTHINGHAM, of this City, having been used by an evening journal without his authority, and in connection with a wild story about the Unitarian Ministers of New-York, and their plans for regenerating the Universe, that gentleman has remonstrated against the wrong done him in a very brief and very sensible letter.

The Leeds (Eng.) Mercury has the following: "Dr. Winterbottom, the father of the medical profession, his name being first in the new Medical Register, died at Westoe, near South Shields, on Friday, in the 95th year of his age. Dr. Winterbottom was also probably the oldest Anti-Slavery advocate alive, having been connected with the great movement for the emancipation of the African race from Doldage from early life.

Among the institutions of New-Haven is the Hopkins Grammar School. EDWARD HOPKINS, the Governor of Connecticut, who died in the year 1557, left the bulk of his properly in Connecticut, amounting to [Pounds] 1,000, as a fund which should be devoted to the support of two Grammar Schools, one in Hartford the other in New Haven.

As the terms of the treaty concluded between the Emperors of France and Austria at Villafranca gradually come before the world, the mingled astonishment and indignation and disappointment which followed the first intelligence that by such a transaction the great war of Italy had been suddenly ended, are more likely to increase than to diminish.

THE SOUTHERN OPPOSITION.--TWO Southern Slates, Kentucky and Tennessee, hold their annual elections next week. In each of these States a very earnest preliminary contest has been going on for the last three weeks, and the crisis now at hand is of interest to the nation at large, mainly because it promises to settle the question whether it is or is not practicable to organize a successful opposition to the Democracy in any Slave State.

THE SOUTHERN RIGHTS PARTY.--The Mobile Register, a Democratic organ, repudiates the claim of the Opposition, at the South, to style itself the Southern-Rights Party. According to that journal, the care and custody of those rights are committed wholly to the Democracy, while to every profane meddler of the Opposition, who attempts to touch the ark of the Slavery Covenant, it indignantly cries: "Hands Off."

GATE-HOUSES OF THE NEW CROTON RESERVOIR.--The new Croton Reservoir, now in process of construction in the Central Park, covers an area of more than one hundred acres, and is contained within banks of earth, formed to resemble the contour of a natural lake.

THE TAXES.--The Joint Board of Aldermen and Supervisors held another meeting last evening to consider the budget for 1860. Almost instinctively, the first action was to reconsider the work done at the previous meeting, which was the sixth resolution appropriating money for "general purposes."

Mr. Superintendent PILLSBURY, in taking command of our City Police force, has just issued an order which promises well for his theory and practice of discipline. He has abolished the system of "roundsmen," and will henceforth require the proper officers to discharge their own duties of supervision in person.

From the Ithaca Citizen, The American State Council is to be held at Geneva on tbe 24th of August the present year. This is in pursuance of an adjournment of the last A merican State Council. Upon this meeting will depend in a great measure the result of the election this Fall. The Americans have at least sixty thousand votes in the State, and therefore hold the balance of power.

A liquor-seller at Woburn, Mass., has got into a tight place. The Boston Journal says that a petition signed by 415 legal voters of the town was presented to the Selectmen, praying them to suppress the illegal sale of intoxicating liquors. The Selectmen immediately issued a notice and order, warning all persons engaged in the sale to desist, and ordering the police to prosecute all violators of the law.

In New-York, during the past week, the demand has been very good for desirable lots of Domestic Wool. The receipts from the interior have been more extensive, and have added to the available supplies.

A dueling correspondence is always interesting. This is peculiarly so, from the fact that these lights of Virginia chivalry have finally settled the terms of the code. .

Mr. de Cardova delivered his lecture on "Money" at Flushing on Monday evening at the request of the most distinguished citizens of the place, for the benefit of the Dutch Reformed Church. The proceeds of the lecture, amounting to $150, are to be appropriated towards the purchase of an organ for the church; the lecturer having given his services gratutiously.

SMITH.--In this City, at the New-York Hotel, on Monday, Aug. 1. at 7 o'clock A. M., ISAAC B. SMITH, in the 31st year of his age. His remains will be taken to Norwalk, Conn., when the funeral will take place from the residence of his father, Stephen Smith Esq., this day, (Tuesday.) Aug. 2, at 3 o'clock P. M. His friends, and the friends of the family, are respectfully invited to attend his funeral.

Public affairs have returned to their wonted channel. Congress is in session and transacts some small business. It has just conferred on the President power, during three months, to effect changes and reorganizations in the Custom-house.

DEATH OF COL. THORN.--A conspicuous citizen of New-York, whose face was better known on the Boulevards than on Broadway, and whose life, were it at all becoming to write it fully here would be a most curious picture of the history and progress of American society for the last forty years; Mr. HERMAN THORN, commonly called Colonel THORN, died yesterday at his house in Sixteenth-street.

From Our Own Correspondent. POUGHKEEPSIE, Monday, Aug. 1, 1859. The Twenty-fifth Anniversary of the Emancipation of the Slaves in the British West Indies was celebrated at this place to-day, by the colored people of the river counties and their friends.

The comments of the English Press upon the Peace of Villafranca, of which we present our readers with a large if not a luminous collection to-day, and the elaborate speeches of the late Derby Ministry at a Conservative funeral banquet in London, are certainly a " darkening of counsel by words without knowledge," so far as the character and causes of the Peace itself are concerned.

ANNUAL REPORT OF THE SUPERINTENDENTS OF THE POOR,-The Superintendents of the Poor, made their annual report yesterday of relief extended to the poor of the Western District, during the year ending July 31 last. The whole number temporarily relieved was 13 251, at an expense of $8 286 61-being $10,169 03 less than they expended the previous year.

A SPANISH-AMERICAN ORGAN.-Arrangements have been completed for issuing, in this City, a journal entitled El Noticioso de Nueva- York, to be managed with a special reference to the wants, wishes, and advantage of the Spanish-American States.

Affairs in Washington. WASHINGTON, Monday, Aug, 1. Col. SIM. JOHNSON, one of the editors of the late Washington Union, who several months ago was appointed Consul to Havre, has tendered his resignation. The office, however, is not open for competition.

The meeting of the Commissioners of Austria and the Allies at Zurich, for the purpose of defining the terms of the settlement of Italy, will be the most positive slight put upon that venerable institution, the " balance of power," since the famous quadruple alliance of 1840.

The recent act of the Commissioners of Emigration, summarily cutting off the pay and rations of the assistants of Dr. JEROME, the physician of the Marine Hospital, produces no marked effect among the few persons remaining upon the Quarantine grounds. Still confident that their services will sooner or later come into play, they are waiting quietly an order to resume.

A FORGER CAUGHT--A DECEIVED WIFE.--CHARLES WATSON, said to hail from Altoona, but had been living at the United States Hotel for the past three months, was apprehended early this morning at his boarding house, Mrs. UPDEGROVES, by Officer BEEKER, on a warrant charging him with forging the names of Messrs. JOHN BEADY and WILLIAM KANEAGY, to orders on Dr. PATTERSON and Miss WILSON, by which he obtained various goods from their respective stores.

There were nineteen American vessels reported lost and missing during the month of July-five ships four barks, and ten schooners, Twelve of these were wrecked, three abandoned at sea, one was sunk, and one reported missing.

To the Editor of the New- York Times : I reside on the eastern bank of the Hudson about twenty five miles from the City. Our venerable and virtuous Chief-Magistrate not only peremptorily declines to be again the candidate of his party, but, if the popular voice crying out of innumerable corners of the country speak the truth, has, through his Postmaster-General, gone very largely into the surprising business of making Republican votes.

The RAVELS opened their season at Niblo's Theatre last evening with a thoroughly crowded house. EXPEDITION OF THE SONS OF MALTA.--A large number of the Sons of Malta returned last evening to this city, from the St. Paul Expedition. On the same train were large delegations from Milwaukee and Cincinnati. Some of the excursionists stopped at Winona, Red Wing, Hastings, and other points on the river, to improve the magnificent trout fishing at those places.

MEETING OF THE SUPERVIORS--MYSTERIOUS ABENNON--The Board of Supervisors were to have held a regular meering yesterday, at 3 o'clock P M., at their room in the City Hall, but on the Cerk's calling the roll at the appoined hour, it was found that there was not a quorum present, and, what was still more remarkable, all the absentees except one were Republicans.

"The gifted die young" The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully requested to attend the funeral, from the residence of his parents, No. 213 West 13th st at 8 o'clock, on Thursday morning.

MUNICIPAL MISMANAGEMENT.--New-York is not the only city whose offices are mismanaged. The Mayor of Montreal, in a letter addressed to the citizens, tells them that the debt of Montreal exceeds [Pound]800,000, and there is this year a deficiency of [Pound]87.000. It has been attempted to add to the tax of 7 1/2 per cent,, with which the citizens are already charged, another of 5 per cent.--in all 12 1/2 per cent.

Commencement-Week has begun. On Wednesday evening last, the citizens and students of Williamstown were treated to an entertainment entitled "Freshman's Wake." The class of '62, having completed the first year of their College course, thought is to celebrate the event by sacrificing one of their slumber upon the funeral pile. The sympathies of the people ot Upper Canada have been pretty evenly divided curing the war between the Austrians and the Allies. The Conservatives, like their English namesakes, have generally been Philo-Austrian; the Liberals, Philo French. In Lower Canada public opinion has leaned almost exclusively to the French side of the question, as was natural with a people speaking the French language.

THE STATE OF KANSAS.-The Kansas Convention recently in session at Leavenworth, having drafted and agreed upon the form of a Constitution to be submitted to the people, it would be natural to suppose that, in case of its approval, of which there can be little doubt, Congress would gladly end the control. versy respecting that Territory by its speedy and unconstitutional admission.

The above Clubs played at Hoboken yesterday the Mutuals winning the game. At the end of the usual game, the ninth innings, their runs were equal24 and 24. They then played a tenth inning, to decide the game, in which the Mutuals made five runs to the Hoboken's one. Both Clubs played well.

A Battle of Chancellors--The Old Government and the New on the War and the Peace. On the 21st of July, the question of the Budget in the Periament of Great Britain provoked an attack by the Ex-Chancellor of the Exchequer, Mr. DISBARLI, on his successor, Mr. GLADSTONE, which grew up into a general conflict on the policy of the Outs and the Ins, with the respect to the great questions of Europe.

ALLEGED ROBBERY BY AN ESCAPED CONVICT.--About two weeks ago a man calling himself Thomas Morgan, alias Harper, engaged a room in the hotel, No. 44 Front-street, Brooklyn, kept by Hugh Cullom. Two days afterwards Mr. Cullom's bureau-drawer was broken open, and $500 worth of diamond jewelry was stolen, Morgan surreptitiously leaving the house the same day.

A desperate and bloody affray occurred here yesterday morning, in which a colored man named ALBERT LEE, a servant of Col. FREMONT's, attempted to kill his wife and himself. A RESTAURANT-KEEPER KILLED AT COXSACKIE. Air. ROBERT DECKER, the keeper of a restaurant in the city of Hudson, N. Y., was attacked and so severely injured at Coxsackie, on the evening of the 25th July, that he died of his wounds on the evening of the 29th. He had gone up to that village on a peddling expedition, as a circus was exhibiting there on that day.

MOORE, of this District, returned to this city yesterday, having in custody two prisoners, arrested on a charge of counterfeiting American coin, and also about seven hundred and fifty bogus dollar pieces, a quantity of base metal, with a large assortment of dies, stamps, a press and a full collection of counterfeiting utensils.

The annual Cricket Match between eleven of the best players in the United States and eleven seelected from the Clubs of Canada, commenced on the Toronto ground yesterday. For the smith time have these players, or the majority of them, met in friendly strife alternately at New-York and Toronto. Three times have the Americans been successful, while the Canadians have defeated their opponents twice.

A WIFE MURDURED BY HER HUSBAND-ARREST OF THE MURDERER. About 9 o'clock last evening a woman named CATHARINE NOONAN. residing in Commerce-street, near Van Brunt, was beaten to death by her husband, PAT. RICK NOONAN, who dragged her into the house, beat her and kicked her about the head and body, causing death in a few moments after.

Mr. McLANE'S private secretary left here yesterday for Pensacola, from which port he sails in the steamer Brooklyn for Vera Cruz. He takes back Mr. McLANE's project for a treaty, with the partial approbation only of Mr. BUCHUNAN, but with the confident belief on the part of the Washington Cabinet that the negotiation will be favorably concluded.

At the evening session of the Association, yesterday, an address was delivered by Prof. EDWARD L. YOUMANS, of New-York,on "The Chemistry of the Sunbeam, or the Celostial Origin of Terrestrial Forces." The fundamental thought which the lecturer developed was this: The earth furnishes the materials for all forms, but the heavens supply the forces which organize, combine, and throw them into action. Matter cannot more itself;

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The current of events has given prominence to a question that has slumbered for a quarter of a century. In New-York, Philadelphia, Baltimore, Chicago, St. Louis and elsewhere, the inevitable Slavery question yields place to Sunday matters, The daily Press finds itself drawn into the discussion, and deals with the topic as oracularly as if it had been a matter of profound study for years.

THE CHINESE INVASION.--The persistent influx of the Chinese peasantry to the United States, is a fact which presses itself upon the attention alike of the political economist and the statesman. BI-CENTENNARY CELEBRATION OF THE SETTLEMENT OF NORWICH, CONN.--The anniversary of the settlement of Norwich, Conn., in 1659 is to be celebrated on the 7th and 8th of September next. The corner stone of a monument to the memory of JOHN MASON, one of the earliest settlers of the town, will be laid. Hon. JOHN A. ROCKWELL will deliver an oration.

This Convention came together this morning at Davis' Hall in this town, holding its first session at 101/2 o'clock. But a few Spiritualists were in attendance, and those only from the neighboring localities and Boston, so that the title of "National" is yet open to question. As the trains come in tomorrow, however, some of the larger lights are looked for, and their arrival may possibly give more color to the name.

Juliet's question, asked so many years ago, has been answered by Judge DALY of this City. The learned Judge has decided that there is really nothing in a name; and that what we call a rose, we are at perfect liberty to call by any other name that we may please to give it.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Some over-kind friend has sent me a copy of a Beekman-street journal, containing a characteristic letter from one of the officials of the London Tract Society, intended to invalidate one or two of the statements in my review of Dr. PATTON'S letters on the London and American Tract Societies, as published in the TIMES.

It is curious and not altogether uninstructive to observe the effect produced upon the strictly Republican mind by the Constitution of Kansas published yesterday morning in these columns. The most zealous members of the Church of Freedom, having perused this Kansas Confession of Faith by favor of the TIMES, "pro. nounce it in every way worthy of the freemen by whose spirit and ability it has been made."

" I should have said you would he mere himar,e," observed a London friend to me, " than to shut up your cows. I could not have believed you would be so cruel." A few minutes' conversation made a wonderful difference in this benevolent lady's impressions. She was a thorough Londoner, arid knew nothing of cow tastes and habits.

By the schooner Susan Orlean we have Nassau (Bahama)papers to July 27. The only item of interest is one announcing that President BOCHANAN has presented a splendid chronometer to Capt. STEWART, of the Light house yacht J. J. Finlayson, for his zealous aid to the bark George Thomas, of New-York, stranded recently on the Bahama Banks. The presentation was made through the Governor of the Islands.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: When the Telegraph informed us last Fall that Senator DOUGLAS had carried the State of Ininois against the allied forces of the Republicans and the Administration, I addressed a letter to the TIMES, claiming the victory as a national one, establishing the principle of popular sovereighty, as in union with the popular will,

Having been here during the past three days in attendance upon the meetings of the New-York State Teacher's Association, I concluded to remain to bear what the advocates of Woman's Rights might have to say at the meeting to be held here to-day. As several of the persons who are actively engaged in this movement had been ill attendance upon the teachers' meetings,

To the Ex. Commissioners National Land Reform Association: GENTLEMEN: I am in receipt of your circular, with the of a memorial to Congress, on the subject of what is generally designated as the "Homestead Law," I approve of your object; and will endeavor to have the memorial circulated in this district.

The Philadelphia North American publishes several conclusive testimonials as to the superiority, both in point of durability and cheapness, of rails made of Pennsylvania iron, over the imported British iron. Anexperimnent was tried on the Central Railroad of Georgia to test the qualities of the two kinds of rails, the result of which has proved in the highest degree favorable to the rails of our own manufacture from American iron.

THE HAYTIANS LAPSING INTO IMPERIALISM AGAIN -Our dingy neighbors of Hayti are a most unpromising set of republicans. They have a very remarkable facility for gaining their freedom and disposing of their tyrants, but they cannot endure liberty for a longer time than a month or two.

THE PROPOSED RAILROAD TO NEWTOWN.--We understand that only tow bids have been put in for the lease of the proposed railroad from Pack sill Ferry, through Grand street and Metropolitan avenue to Newtown. One is by WATERBURY Co., who propose to carry passengers at five cents each, and the other by INA BUCKMAN, whose proposition is to carry passengers at three cents.

THE TWO VERDICIS-DIRECT AND INDIRECT. The two verdicts rendered by the Schaghticoke and Albary juries, present a curious contrast. Coroner MADDEN'S jury at Schaghticoke failed to cast the responsibility of the Northern Railroad slaughter upon the culpable parties; while the Albany jury, impaneled by Coroner DEAN, had no scruples against rendering a direct verdict. We republish these verdicts together, for the sake of the contrast:

THE GANSEVOORT PROPERTY--VETOES FROM THE MAYOR-RESERVOIR SQUARE. The Councilmen met last evening, Councilmann LINT in the chair. A petition was received from the operatives in the manufacturing department of the Institution for the Blind, representing that it was impossible for the managers to dispose of the stock which they turned out and that they were obliged to work on half time.

Is issued on the morning of every Tuesday and Friday, and contains, in addition to the bulk of intelligence given in the Daily Paper. A LITERARY DEPARTMENT, Embracing Standard Novels and Tales, and Miscellaneous Selections of the Highest interest.

When the once celebrated and still notorious GEORGE HUDSON, that English Railway King, in comparison with whose magnificent operations those of the most enterprising Railway pluralist of New-York are but the playful dabblings of an apprentice in the mystery of stocks, fell from his high estate and came to general shame, he retired from the world into the small town of Sunderland.

PLEASANT POLICEMEN.--Mr. ROBERT C. MACDONALD, of Mobile, now suffering great mental pangs in this City, in consequence of an interview between himself and a woman formerly his mistress, which resulted in her murder by his hand, has published a card, which puts the police of NewYork in a most captivating light before the public eye.

The Washington Greys, Capt. BOOK, of the New-York Eight Regiment, arrived in this city about 8 1/2 o'clock Saturday evening, and were met at the Lowell depot by the Union Guard of East Boston, (Company B.) Capt. EDWARD PEARL, and the City Guard of Roxbury, (Company D) Capt. T. L. D. PERKINS, both of the Second Regiment.

VISIT OF THE NEW-YORK MILITIA TO MONTREAL --ENTERTAINMENT.--Yesterday evening, Company F. of the Eighth Regiment, First Division, New-York State Militia, Washington Greys, commanded by Capt. BECK. arrived at the wharf, by the steamer Welland, from Niagara. Capt. STEVENSON'S field battery and Capt. WAND'S company of foot artillery, were drawn up to meet them.

From the Delhi (Del. Co.) Express. A tragedy of a most fearful nature occurred in the town of Hamden, (Fuller's Hollow,) on Tuesday night of last week, in the killing of her only son, WILLIAM, by Mrs. MARGARET GOW. The deceased and his mother. who is a widow, kept house together. He was about twenty five years of age, is said to have been a stout, athletic young man.

THE WISE LETTER--VOICES FROM RICHMOND AND ALBANY.--The Richmond Inquirer, Gov. WISE'S organ, which is edited in part by his son, has spoken on the subject of the now famous epistle received by Mr. DONNELLY, of William-street, and read for the edification of the congregated Softs at the Delavan House, last week.

The Cunard screw steamer Karnak, Capt. BROWN, arrived at an early hour yesterday morning from Havana, vid Nassau. Left Havana on the 2d inst., and Nassau on the 4th, and anchored on her arrival at the lower Quarantine.

INCENDIARISM IN ROCHESTER.--Since our issue of Saturday evening there has been some half-a-dozen or more fires discovered, and some of them involved a considerable loss of property. What is to be done in reference to this alarming state of things, is more than we can say. o be done in reference to this alarming state of things, is more than we can say.

Personal. There has recently arrived in this City an eminent Jewish traveler, a Mr. BENJAMIN, the object of whose life hitherto has been to explore the interior of the Asiatic and African continents for the purpose of ascertaining the condition, occupations, hopes, , of his Hebrew brethren.

COMMODORE WHIPPLE.--Mr. NAHUM WARD, a wealthy citizen of Marletta, has placed a handsome monument over the grave of the gallant Com. WHIPPLE, who rendered such distinguished services in the Revolutionary War. Com. WHIPPLE having given the best part of his life to his country,

A GOVERNMENT SPECULATION--THE BOSTON, NAVY-YARD AND THE STEAMSHIP CANADA.--It will be recollected that on the last voyage the Canada came in contact with an iceberg, which rendered it necessary on her arrival in Boston to be docked. No private dock being sufficiently large to receive her, application was made for admission to enter the dry dock at the Navy-year, which was granted.

If there be one opinion about the recent peace in Europe more reasonable than another, it is that whatever changes it may have made in the status quo, it is by no means a settlement of the whole question.

By private dispatches from Branchville, we received some accounts, yesterday morning, of a tatal explosion which occurred on Thursday afternoon on the South Carolina Railroad line, involving the death of five workmen. Other particulars reached us in the course of the day, and melancholy story is now given to our readers.

CANNON FOR THE EMPEROR OF MUSCAT.--Two byess Dahigreen cannon, just completed for the Imaum or Emperor of Muscat, as presents from parties in Providence, were exhibited on State-street Saturday afternoon. They are 42 pounders, and will carry a 7 inch ball. They have smooth hores. six feet deep. weight respectively 3 652 and 3,631 lbs., and are on ??, brass mounted carriages.

ATTACHING PROPERTY FOR ALLEGED BREACH OF PROMISE.--The Boston Herald of the 6th inst. says: "We learn that a well-known and well-circumstanced adopted citizen, residing in a town in this vicinity, has been ?? within the past week by a young lady residing in South Boson, on a charge of breach of promise of marriage, and that the property of the gay deceiver has been attached to the amount of $10,000 to abide the result.

Great excitement prevails in this town on account of the dispatch printed in the TIMES of Monday, in relation to two slavers reported to be fitting out at this port. The Collector, Mr. PIKE denies any knowledge of such vessels.

WINDFALL FOR THE LOUISIANA STATE BANK.-About the beat illustration we have known for a long time of the Scriptural maxim, that "unto them that have shall be given, and to them that have not shall be taken away even that they have," has recently occurred in our city.

HORACE MANN, President of Antioch College, will be burled to-morrow at 10 o'clock, in the park immediately in front of the College buildings, where the students will build a monument to his memory. His disease, though called by one or two of the physicians the typhoid fever, and by another the dyspepsia, was in reality exhaustion.

SEIZURE OF AN AMERICAN STEAMER BY THE CHINESE.--A letter from Hong Kong, dated May 13, states that ??a small American steamer, named the Cum Faa, plying between Macao and a Chinese village called Chong Sha, was taken by her passengers on the 4th inst.

RARE COINS.--We were shown, on Saturday, a handful of old coins which were recovered from the ruins of he "Chenevard House," on Main-street. Among them a Spanish pistareen, a Massachusetts penny, (worth about thirty seven and a half cents,) several Ben Franklin pennies, and numerous antiquated coins, much sought after at the present day.

The Court-Martial assembled to examine the charges of embezzlement against Major CROSS, met yesterday, at noon. After the minutes of Saturday's session had been read, the Judge Advocate said that he had received some dispatches bearing upon the investigation which would make it necessary for him to have a consultation with Major CROSS before proceeding further.

The R. M. steamship Arabia, from Liverpool on the 30th ult., with three days later European advices, arrived at Halifax at 2 1/2 o'clock P. M. yesterday, but we are as usual unable to publish her news with the promptness desirable, roving to the continued perverseness of the Nova Scotia Telegraph Company.

A MAN BURIED ALIVE.--We learn of a sad casualty which happened yesterday (Aug. 2) in the town of Walker, some three or four miles from the city, resulting in the death of a young man named CHASFITCH. It appears that he was engaged in digging a well on his father's premises.

THE MCDONALD CASF.--General Superintendent PILSBURY yesterday morning summoned Officers MARSHALL and GORDON, of the Sixth Precinct, before him and interrogated them respecting the charge made against them in the newspapers, of having taken MCDONALD, the murderer, to a house of ill-fame.

The preliminary business disposed of, the Chal? appointed the following Standing Committees for 1859.

Nearly all the foreign Ministers have left for the North. Barom STOKCEL and Viscount FREILLARD left for Newport yesterday. Senor MOLINA is in New-York, Senor MATA remains here. Letters from the Count SAETIGES, report his health still feeble.

Boston, in New England, an undoubted Republican city, s?? celebrated for its tea party, has just bee?? evincing its gratitude for the smallest favor by giving a municipal treat in the shape of ?? chowder-party, to the booksellers who attended a book trade-sale held there last week.

As we announced some time since, an effort will be made this week to repair the cable laid last year between the Vineyard aud Nantucket. Mr. BISHOP arrived in the propeller yesterday with the necessary amount of cable, which was put on board the tugboat, Spray, which left in the afternoon for Edgartown.

FAIRCHILD - In this City, on Tuesday, Aug. 9, PETER FAIRCHILD, aged 56 years. Relatives and friends are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, without further invitation, on Thursday, at 2 o' clock P.M., from the residence of his brother in law, Nathaniel Finch. No. 247 West 36th st.

We learn that the idea of celebrating the hundredth anniversary of the taking of Quebec by the English under WOLFE, Sept. 13, 1759, was suggested at the meeting of the Maine Historical Society, held in Brunswick last week, and that the Society thought so favorably of the proposition as to appoint a Committee to consider and act on the subject.

CHARGED WITH ROBBING THE MAIL.--United States Commissioner FROST yesterday committed to jail, in default of $2,000 bail for his appearance on the 9th inst., UPTON STARTZMAN, who is charged with stealing letters from the Post office in North Louisburgh, Champaign County, in this State.

A little son of PATRICK MURPHY, about 13 years old, keeper of the lodge at the mountain entrance of Llewellyn Park, near Eagle Rock, at Orange, N. J., died last evening from the effects of hydrophobia. Some time in June he was at work in a nursery, when a strange dog passed near him, and he slapped him with his hand. The dog snapped and inserted his teeth in the back of the right hand.

From the Troy Whig. We have already stated how Prof. POULTON, the hero of "that elopement up North" got into jail; and how he got out again. Well, it seems, on regaining his liberty, he took his way by "easy stages" of foot traveling in night time, toward Lansingburgh, his former residence.

Michael Phelan, the celebrated New-York billiard player, and Chris. Bird, a well-known Philadelphian, arrived in Pittsburgh a few days since, on a professional visit, and were handsomely received and entertained by the Pittsburgh billiard players.

There is no falling off in the amount of Cattle coming forward, and the supply at both yards is now in excess of the demand. At PHILLIPS' Drove Yard 1,152 head were brought in, most of which were sold at full rates. The sales, however, show a decline in prices, and no improvement is anticipated for several weeks to come. The market continues decidedly dull.

COMMISSIONERS OF HEALTH.--At the meeting of the Commissioners of Health yesterday, a communication was received from the Brooklyn Board of Health, thanking the New-York Board for their courtesy in inviting them to sit with them at their regular meetings.

The Royal Mail steamship Arabia, Capt. STONE, from Liverpool at 10 o' clock on the morning of the 30th ult., arrived at Halifax at 21/2 P.M. yesterday, and the horse express reached here with her news at an early hour this morning.

From the Montreal Herald. We yesterday had an opportunity of paying our respects to the bottom of the St, Lawrence, at the site of the last Pier of the Grand Trunk Bridge. The Coffer Dam of this Pier is now completed and the water pumped out, so that we were able to descend into a chamber some two and twenty feet below the surface of the river.

We were startled this morning at beholding the A. G. Benson, a steamboat plying between this place and Islip, fleating in the Sough Bay, and seemingly unmanageable. Looking through a glass, we perceived the passengers and crew were in a state of great excitement.

Again tile Apache Indians have commenced their depredations. A treaty was made, in March last, with the Pinal Apaches, at which they received in advance, for good behavior, about $4,000 worth of goods and 2.500 pounds of corn, Since that time not only the Pinals, but the Coyoteros and Mescaleros have time after time violated their treaties without any notice being taken by Government.

From the Richmond Enquirer. A heavy press of copy prevents comment, for the present, on the following letter, received yesterday, from Gov. WISE. To the Editor of the New-York Times: In your columns this A. M. there is a communication dated at Ballston, and signed by seven gentlemen, in which they say, "We have no interest in the road in question, and we positively assert that these culverts are perfectly safe." DOMESTIC MARKETS. In New-York, during the past week, there has been less activity in all kinds of Wool. Manufacturers, having been previously well supplied, have not purchased freely. The demand from cealers his been also restricted. The receipts have been liberal, comprising 2,199 bales Domestic, and 1.317 bales Foreign. The available supplies are increasing.

INTERESTING TO POLICEMEN.--One of the regulations of the Police Department requires the members of the force to get their clothing made at certain tailoring establishments. About a dozen tailors are favored with this monopoly of Police custom. Among policemen a good deal of dissatisfaction exists at this regulation, as they are obliged to put up with the kind of cloth furnished,

Before Justice Ingraham. Coan vs. Coan.--In this cause a decree of divorce was rendered against the defendant on the ground of adultery. The complaint of the plaintiff, the husband, alleged that he was married to the defendant in 1552, that they had one child, a boy, now about four years old, and charged defendant with having committed adultery with several persons unknown to the plaintiff There was no defence.

MARCUS J. PARROTT was, to-day, nominated by Republican Convention as a candidate for Delegate to Congress. He received 57 out of 103 votes cast, on an informal ballot, and was declared the nominee of the party by acclamation. The Convention met in this city, and was organized--JAMES M. WINCHELL, of Osage County, in the Chair.

A case which has created the greatest excitement and amusement in the Township of Yarmouth has come to our knowledge, and from the romantic and extraordinary circumstances connected with it, together with the "respectability" of the parties concerned, is worth recording in our columns. The facts are as follows.

The alleged meeting of "American leaders,' which forms the burden of a recent telegram from this place to the herald, consisted of seven persons, and no more. Not one of the individuals named was present, nor in any waY connected with the affair. The meeting, if it deserve the name, was simply an unsuccessful ruse, designed for the benefit of the Democrats,

To the Editor of the New-York Tribune: I find five columns of your paper to-day, occupied by letters from Mr. Day and his counsel, in reply to Mr. Judson's statement published by you some days since; and in the absence of Mr. Judson from New-York.

Wednesday last was a great day in Oswego. It was shortly after noon of that day that Prof. Cox, formerly an associate of CARLINCOURT, and now proprietor of the balloon Excelsior, started from that city, accompanied by Mr. C. H. HULL, of the Oswego Palladium, with the avowed intention of ballooning to the Acan'le Coast, and thus complete the journey begun by WISH LAMOUNTAIN and GAGER.

The mails by the Royal Mail steamship Arabia reached this City at 5 o'clock P. M. yesterday. In addition to the very full telegraphic sum mary by her advices, which we published yesterday morning, we give below a variety of correspondence and details from our Foreign exchanges.

The Hon. EDWARD BLONDEL was yesterday presented officially to the President and recognized as Minister from Belgium. The Central American Mission is still open for applicants, there having been no tender of it to the Hon, JAMES B, BOWLING, who left this afternoon for Missouri.

In yesterday's Palladium we mentioned the burning of the barns of HENRY HARVEY and RUSSELL FITCH, of Preston, on Monday night, but it appears that those events were but separated items in a most fearful scene of fiendish revenge. The Vanderbilt steamship North Star, Capt. JONES, arrived yesterday morning from Aspinwall, having left that place on the 3d inst. The steamship North Star left New York July 20, and reached Aspinwall on the 28th--three days and six hours in advance of the Star of the West. By this arrival we have Panama papers to the 21 inst. The local news is of no importance.

THE ESCAPE OF DE MIRANDA, THE DEFAULTER.--On Wednesday an item appeared stating that a Cuban named AUGUSTIN DE MIRANDA, who had been confined in Eldridge-street jail on a charge on embezzlement, escaped from a special Deputy-sheriff who had him in custody. It appears that MIRANDA induced the Sheriff to accompany him to a Spanish school in West Forty. fourth-street, where he resided previous to his arrest.

M. yesterday-having at that hour heard all the papers that were to be read either substantially or by title. But there still remained a pretty bit of pyrotechnics to be fired at Hampden Hall, whereunto, at 7 1/2 o'clock, a cense crowd of ladies and gentlemen gathered.

In the Journal des Debats of Saturday, July 23, M. PREVOST-PARADOL, a leading journalist of Paris, published an article on England and Europe, which deserves special attention, not less from the character and ability of the writer than from the well-known proclivities of the Debats in favor of the Anglo-French alliance and of English instituions.

Mr. CHURCH'S noble picture, the "Heart of the Andes," continues to win golden opinion in England. The London Times, of the 27th, contains the following graceful and appreciative notice of this tine work of art: "In the exhibition of the Royal Academy, this year, are some North American landscapes by American painters,

The United States Mail Steamship Quaker City, R. W. SCHUFELDT commanding, from Havana in three days and seventeen hours, arrived at this port last evening. She brings 103 passengers. The Quaker City left Havana on Monday, the 8th instant, at 5 P. M., meeting the steamer Granada, from New-Orleans entering the port. The Granada was expected to leave for New-York on the 9th.

THE TWELFTH REGIMENT TROUBLES--The Joint Committee of the Common Council appointed to memorialize the Governor in favor of reinstating the Twelfth Regiment had a meeting yesterday afternoon, Councilmen LAIMBEER, LENT and VAN TINE were present. A large number of members of the regiment were also in attendance. Mr. DALRYMPLE introduced Capt. BOYLE, who has belonged to the regiment since its organization, and Capt. HUSON.

The National Teachers' Association has just closed the first day of its sessions here, and has done a grand day's work for the cause of education here, and in this region. The Association was welcomed to the city by Mayor BERRITT in behalf of the City Government, and by S. Y. ATLRY, Esq., for the Board of Trustees of the schools of the City.

The arrival of the New-York Yacht Squadron has given to this usually dull harbor a gay and most attractive appearance. Its advent was Particularly welcomed by the Summer visitors, who had exhausted all the old sights, and were sighing for a new sensation.

The "British and Foreign Anti-Slavery Society" is one of the most restless institutions which the uneasy Anglo-Saxon temperament has ushered into existence. The virtuous and respectable members of this venerable body have always, with curious pertinacity, refused to "let well alone; "

LIVERMORS.-In this City, on Thursday, Aug. 11, at the residence of her son in-law, R. L. Larremore, after a lingering illness. LUCY, relict of the late Capt. Joseph lLivermore, in the 60th year of her age. The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend the funeral, at the Eleventh Presbyterian Caureb, corner of 4tb-st, and Avenue C, on Saturday afternoon, at 2 o'clock.

THE ATLANTIC TELEGRAPH.--On the first day of last September, at precisely 1 1/2 P. M., Greenwich time, the Atlantic Telegraph gave its last tick, and immediately became as silent as the caves in which the cable is buried. It happened, oddly enough, that its last halfuttered message was an announcement from

PERSONAL.--Private letters from Paris, received by the Arabia, informs us that Madame RISTORI has nearly, or quite, made up her mind to visit the United States, for the purpose of giving a series of dramatic Matinees. This intelligence will be welcome news to all lovers of the dramatic art; and we trust it may be confirmed by the speedy arrival of this now unquestioned Queen of Tragedy.

From Washington. THE TEXAS BOUNDARY SURVEY--REMOVAL OF INDIANS--A SWINDLER--THE RAILROAD CONVENTION. WASHINGTON, Friday, Aug. 12. The Interior Department has received dispatches from the Commissioner of the United States and Texas Boundary Survey. A trip was made up the Peoos River until Capt. WIPPLE'S trail was struck.

MR. BUCHANAN GROWING HAUGHTY.--"Occasional," the Washington correspondent of the Philadelphia Press, says, in his letter of the 10th: "JAMES BUCHANAN HENRY, Esq., the nephew and late private secretary of the President, is to be married to-morrow at Annapolis, Maryland, to Miss NICHOLSON, a daughter of Col. NICHOLSON of that city, and one of the officers of the United States Senate.

NAVIGATION OF THE HARLEM RIVER.--The majority of New-Yorkers know hardly more about the Harlem River than they do about the Straits of Magellan. Many of them do not know as much for they learn something about Magellan in their school days. But the Harlem is beginning to assert its claims to attention,

We see in it natural elements of strength that may defy any enemy from without or traitor within.

This document has not yet been printed here, and reaches you in advance of our press. Rumors are current here of the death of LOPEZ.

CHESTALOFF and lady, who had gone to Paris, he expecting to receive orders there, we hove up our anchor at 6 1/2 P. M. on the 8th inst., and entered the British Channel with charming weather and finding the sea uncommonly smooth.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: None of the "premonitory symptoms" which Mr. BOONE, in his letter of the 8th inst., to the Health Officer, adduces as "presaging" disease here, is so strong as the present foul state of the Croton water. For some time past the water has had a very disagreeable earthy flavor. Sometimes it tastes as if impregnated with putrid matter and is nauseating.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: DEAR SIR: A false and injurious paragraph entitled "Suspected of being a Lottery-dealer," was published in the Morning Express this day, and in the Tribune in a modified form, concerning Messrs. ISAAC HIRSCH Co., of this City. The paragraph, so far as it implicates that firm, is wholly false, and the Express will be held responsible for the publication.

The statements which have been made with regard to the indulgences granted to MACDONALD, the murderer of VIRGINIA STEWART, on his way to and from the Court-room and at the Tombs, and which, so far, have not been contradicted, are so extraordinary that we should, for the credit of the City, like very much to be able to disbelieve them.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: SIR: Two or three notices have appeared in your paper in reference to alleged swindling operations of Dr. THOMAS S. ELLIS. Public opinion should not be determined by ex parte statements, and I ask here only that the Doctor have as fair a hearing as his persecutors have had, and that the public withhold its final decision till his case be adjudicated.

The British screw steamship City of Baltimore, Capt. LEITCH, from Liverpool on the afternoon of Wednesday, the 3d inst., vid Queenstown afternoon of the 4th, passed Cape Race at 7 o'clock last evening, (Thursday) en route to New-York, where she will be due on Monday evening next. The advices by the City of Baltimore are five days later than those by the Arabia at Halifax and Boston, but are without any features of particular importance.

Mr. JOHN L. PEYTON, of Staunton, Virginia, has communicated to the Richmond Enquirer a letter from the Hon. S. A. DOUGLAS, expressing dissent from Gen. CASS' Naturalization notions, and also stating certain Constitutional grounds upon which its writer deems the renewal of the African Slave-Trade inadmissible.

EXCELSIOR, OF BROOKLYN, VS. BALTIC, OF NEWYORK. These Clubs played their return game, yesterday, upon the grounds of the Excelsior Club, South Brooklyn. As will be seen by the score, the Baltics were badly defeated.

How DID Gov. WISE's LETTER GET INTO PRINT?--Mr. CASSIDY, of the Albany Atlas and Argus, admits that the confiding BERNARD DONNELLY placed Gov. WISE'S letter in his hands, to be sent to DEAN RICHNOND, at Buffalo, with the understanding that Mr. RICHMOND was to bring it with him to Albany, when he should come to the meeting of the State Committee.

The mortification felt by the English Parliament at the abrupt termination of the Italian war betrays itself in more ways than one. The Lords make speeches showing that the leaving of England out of the question is a sore subject for a nation proud of having heretofore been considered as indispensable in the settlement of grievances between other European nations.

At a meeting of citizens of Great Salt Lake County, held at the Historian's Office, Great Salt Lake City, July 2. pursuant to previous notice, on motion, the Hon. JOHN M. BIRMHISEL was called to the Chair, and JAMES FURGUSON, Esq., was chosen Secretary, The Chairman staled that the object of the meeting was to nominate candidates for the several offices to he voted for in this county at the approaching August election.

Our files by the Vanderbilt and City of Manchester are full of varied and interesting matter. The Sardinian representative named by VICTOR EMANUEL, the Chevalier DES-AMBROIS, having been received by the Emperor, the excellent correspondents who were sure that Sardinia would be excluded from the Conference at Zurich are slightly discomfited.

Before Justice Ingraham. Stephen Leimeister vs. George Engelbreit.--Motion granted on payment of $5 costs. George J. N. Zabriskie vs. David Graham, -- Judgement set aside and plaintiff allowed to proceed on payment of $10 costs and disbursements of entering judgment.

A terrific fire broke out about one o'clock yesterday morning, in the rectifying establishment of BOYLE CO., East Second street. How the fire originated is not known. Some of the hands went through the building at nine o'clock, and at that time everything was all right. The only fire in the building on Wednesday was in the portable furnaces O some coppersmiths.

BRUSH.--In this City, on Saturday, Aug, 13, LEWIS BRUSH aged 26 years and 5 months. The relatives and friends of the family, and the members of Bedford-s Methodist Kpiscopal Church are respectfully invited to attend the funeral from the residence of his brother. Richard Brush. No. 27 West 44th-st., this (Monday) afternoon, at 1 o'clock.

THE WHALE AT BAY SIDE. --The fin-back whale which ran itself aground on Wednesday morning last near Willett's Point, continues to attract large numbers of visitors. The monster probably strayed into the Sound in quest of food, and getting into shoal. mater and between two rocks, was unable to extricate itself.

RESULT OF GENERAL-SUPERINTENDENT PILLSHRERY'S RECENT PROCLAMATION. Yesterday, for the first time, the order promulgated by the General Superintendent of Police for the better observance of the Sabbath, went into effect. On Saturday night, in compliance with his directions, the Police visited the Porter-houses within their respective Precincts, and warned their proprietors against keeping open house on the Sunday.

Gen. CUSHING, who is now here, has been tendered the Mission to Central America, but his engagements are of such a nature as to render his acceptance of the appointment impossible. The Administration regards the position as of great importance under existing circumstances.

The United States Mail steamship, Vanderbilt, on the 3rd August, from Southampton, with three days' later from Europe, arrived here at four o'clock, p.m.,Saturday, Aug. 13. Steamship Asta arrived at Liverpool, Aug. 31. The Hungarian arrived at Liverpool Monday, evening, Aug. 1.

Gen. HOUSTON has gained largely upon the regular Democratic ticket, and although the returns which have reached us do not warrant the conclusion that he is elected Governor of Texas over RUNNELLS, still such an event is rendered quite probable.

The lull and graphic correspondence from Mexico, which we published on Saturday last, is completed to-day, by a picture of such social disorders and excesses as seem to belong rather to the age of Gil Blas than to our own.

ANOTHER ROTTEN BRIDGE ON THE NORTHERN RAILROAD.--We are informed, and upon authority which we have good reason to believe reliable, that on the line of the Albany Northern Railroad, not a great distance above he point at which the fearful disaster of last week occurred, there is another bridge, the rottenness of which is apparent, and quite as thorough as that of the Tomhannock death-trap.

THE STRONGER PARTY.--Sometime since we took ccasion to advert to the fact that on all questions of a strictly Slavery character the North would necessarily unite, and that, being stronger than the South, it must prevail.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I have watched with some interest the various inquiries about the Croton water, its bad taste, etc. For the information of your readers who do not takes the trouble to think. I propose to give the cause. We receive our supply of croton from two sources.--one the springs and brooks running form the uplands or mountains, and one the marshes and swamps.

The Military Board for testing rifled cannon at Fort Monroe have taken a recess for ten days, to enable Col. DIMMICK to have his gun on the ground. A new supply of projectiles has been ordered. No report has yet been made to the War Department. Several additional guns will probably be entered for trial.

This long-expected ascension, which has been advertised so extensively throughout this section of country, took place in this village today. At an early hour wagon-loads of people from the rural districts began to pour in, and the town presented the appearance of a general holiday.

This Association is just closing up its labors to-day. Yesterday afternoon they paid the President a visit in a body, and were most cordially received. To-day the President sat on the platform in the hall for one hour, and listened with close and evidently pleased attention, while reports on the subject of Education in many States were given by the delegates. This afternoon the body is going to Mount Vernon.

Among the populous neighborhoods of the city, where reside the poor or the vicious, the inertin of Sunday is productive of many evils. In the absence of anything better to do, and with no inclination for attendance upon religious services, hundreds of people second that time which should be devoted to self improvement in drinking earning and card playing.

The boy DANIEL CREADON, the cause of all the mischief at the State Reform School at Westboro', is a hardened little sinner. He was sent from salem, for larceny, about a year ago, and has given the officers much trouble during his stay at the institution. He was ringleader in an organized attempt to escape, which was made on the 2d or 3d of July last.

The Era which occurred at Lawrence, Mass, on the 12th August, reported by telegraph, destroyed property to the value of about $100,000. It broke out at 2 P. M., in the upper part of the United States Hotel building. It was four stories high, the lower story being occupied by stores, and the rest was an unoccupied hotel, unfurnished, and the two upper stories unfinished. It was built last year.

Her Majesty, desirous of recording her admiration of the heroic consistence and unbroken discipline shown on board that vessel,

The screw-steamship City of Baltimore, from Liverpool on the 3d inst., and Queenstown on the 4th, arrived at this port yesterday. A brief abstract of her news, which is one day later than that by the Vanderbilt, was forwarded by telegraph from Cape Race, and published in the TIMES of Saturday morning.

The country must have been overjoyed with the announcement, flashed yesterday by telegraph from Washington to all parts of the Union, that " the Administration regards the position of affairs in Central America as of great importance under existing circumstances" It was comforting to hear that the President had at last discovered that the interests of the United States in Central America are worthy of attention and consideration.

The body of Capt. ISRAEL LANGDON, the well-known oyster salesman of Catherine Market, was this day found by Capt. JOS. BRADELL while on the trip to New-York. He immediately returned to this place. Too much praise cannot be given to Capt. B. by friends of deceased for the prompt manner in which he informed the father and friends of the deceased of the recovery of the body.

COUNTING WITHOUT NEW-YORK.--In Governor WISE'S letter to BERNARD DONELLY he managed to blunder upon one sensible remark,--that in which he represents himself as counting without this State when engaged in the enumeration of his Presidential Chickens. New-York will in no contingency vote for him, and by acknowledging that patent truth from the start he saves himself much subsequent disappointment.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I noticed in your paper this morning two complaints against the Croton water. I had already meditated a note to the TIMES, and a few remarks yet will help to keep the ball in motion. Tile water has been growing worse and worse for a month or two past, and now it is nearly unpalatable.

The Kansas Vigilance Committee has closed its labors and disbanced. It has succeeded in breaking up the organized bands of robbers, and has punished some of the worst of the ringleaders. The Leavenworth Times, commenting upon the acts of the committee remarks: " We trust, then that the action of the `Vigilance Committee' may soon be brought to a close.

TROUBLES IN THE AUSTRAIN ARMY.--Much excitement exists at Vienna on account o the quarrels and troubles aroused by the late misfortunes in Italy. The commission of Gen. URBAN, the slayer of peasants and beaten of GARIBALDI, has been revoked for his refusal to publish the armistice.

The Democracy of Kentacky elect a Governor, (MAGOFFIN,) and a legislative majority; Tennessee reelects a Democratic Governor, (ISHAM G. HARRIS,) but the Democracy lose tour members of Congress.

Dr. James W. Alexander was the almost idolized pastor. A few years ago the financial managers of the society voted to advance the minister's salary from $4,000 to $5,000 per annum.

The Hill-Country of Connecticut-Brookfield and its Surroundings. Correspondence of the New-York Times. BROOKFIELD, Tuesday, Aug. 9, 1859. I wonder why it is that there is so much ignorance among our city people of the "hillcountry" of Connecticut.

A large party of ladies and gentlemen participated in the pic-nic and witnessed the tournament which came off at Bentsville on Thursday. It is needless to say that the affair was pleasant throughoutthe dancing was good, the music excellent, and the riding "at the ring," in many instances, very fine.

A CAMP-MEETING, AT MARTHA'S VINEYARD--IMMENSE TURN-OUT.--The camp-meeting at Martha's Vineyard is a prodigious affair, according to a correspondent of the Boston Journal, who writes from the " Wesleyan Grove :" " The social religious exercises in the tents have been of a most interesting character, a large number participating in them.

The smaller German States which manifested two months ago a rather diabolical delight at the prospect of a great European war, in which United Germany should march as one man to avenge the murder of CONRAD of Hoihenstauffen, by CHARLES of Anjou, and to plant the standards of Wittelsbach and Coburg upon the battlements of the Tuileries, have suddenly conceived an altogether angelic love of peace and concord.

CATTLE--It will be seen that the receipts are very heavy. Even according to the old estimate of 16 to the car, the aggregate is 3,312 head, but this is swelled by the actual show in the yards to 3,426. None were held over. The average quality to about the same as last week, and the average weight a little better, perhaps. As to prices, there is little change to note.

Th Richmond Grays were yesterday the recipients of another ovation. The Second and Fifth Companies of the National Guard, commanded respectively by Captains SHALER and SPRIGHT, formed into line about 2 o'clock in Lafayette-place, and marched thence through Broadway to the Brandreth House, in front of which the Richmond Grays were drawn up to receive them.

KILLED HIS WIFE WITH A STONE.--DANIEL STEEL, who is respected as a hard-working and frugal farmer, near paterson, New Jersey, on the 29th ult, killed his wife in a strange but accidental manner, The hogs were in the corn, and Mr. STEEL and his daughter were racing them cut--the daughter handing stores to her father to throw at the intruders.

The above Clubs played a match yesterday upon the grounds of the Yorkville Club, Eighty-first street and Second-avenue. The Jefferson were short of two of their" first nine," yet they played very fairly. At the fifth Innings the game stood Jeffersen 7, to 21 for the Yorkville.

That the Democracy, if united, will be strong enough to elect the Charleston nominee, the organ of Mr. HUNTER does not permit itself for a moment to doubt;

In my previous letters I have probably surprised you by expressing a belief that Oregon would elect a Republican to Congress, and I presume that not one in ten thousand of the readers of the TIMES believed that such an event was even possible. The result, however, shows that my opinion was not entirely without foundation.

RUFFIANISM IN BALTIMORE.--On Sunday evening a party of city rowdies, on their return from the Baltimore County Camp Meeting stopped at the Hammett House, three miles on the Hookstown road, Mr. HARTZELL, proprietor. A number of ladies and gentlemen, who were at supper in the hotel, were compelled to fly from the table.

THE SAG IN THE NIAGARA SUSPENSION BRIDGE. The Falls Gazitte is down on the New-York Herald for starting the story of the sag in the Suspension Bridge, which has been going the rounds of the papers so widely, and has so often been contradicted by actual observation.

ALLTGRD VIOLATORS OF THE SUNDAY LAWS.-- Officer WM. Z. ROWLAND, of the Twentieth Precinct, was put upon special duty last Sunday, to report the names of those saloon- keepers who puplicly sold liqour on that day.

BOARD OF SUPERVISORS.--The Board of Supervisors held on adjourned meeting yesterday. Considerable feeling was manifested at the neglect of the Joint Board to pass another tax list for next year. A resolution was offered to levy the tax, notwithstanding the tardy action of the Joint Board.

Since the meeting of the Democratic State Committee, and the revelation of WISE'S letter, the lambs of the Hunker fold are lying down in most delightful harmony with the Barnburner lions. In short, the Millenium appears to be at hand. if not actually present.

" Water, water everywhere, but not one drop to drink," is the present cry of this always crying City. New-York is never happy without some special misery; and as the energetic action of Mr. DELAVAN and of Mr. SMITH promises to abate the fierceness of the street torments we have so long been nursing, we ought perhaps to be grateful for the extremely disgusting nature of our actual Aqueduct supplies.

FARRINGTON-In this City, on Tuesday, Aug. 16, of cholera infanium, JOSEPHINE. youngest daughter of Joseph T. and Sarah A. Farrington, aged 11 months and 6 days. The remains will be taken to Rhinebeck for interment this (Wednesday) morning.

From the London Illustrated Times, MR. DISRAELI. Every one knows, on his rising, when Mr. DISRAELI means to make a long speech. When he only intends to offer a few Interlocutory remarks he leans over the table, speaks in a low tone to the gentlemen opposite, and shows by his manner of standing and speaking that he intends soon to sit down.

The trotting match of yesterday on the Eclipse Course, between Flora Temple and Princess was the exciting topic in the sporting world for a week past, since Flora beat Princess, in that celebrated time of 2:22, on Tuesday of last week.

The Royal Mail steamship Asia, from Liverpool on the 6th inst., with two days later advices from Europe, is now in her eleventh day, and nearly due at this port. The California Overland Mail, which arrived at St. Louis yesterday, from San Francisco on the 25th ult., brings no news of importance.

George A. Roberts Vs. John W. Coster.--This was a motion to discharge defendant from arrest. It was founded on an affidavit of the defendant himself, denying the allegations in the affidavit of the plaintiff, on which the order of arrest was granted. The order was made in July, 1857.

Connors and his friends held that the decision was unfair. ir.

Terrible Gale at Prince Edward's Island. UPWARDS OF FIFTY LIVES LOST--NUMEROUS VESSELS WRECKED. BOSTON, Tuesday, Aug. 16. Advices of the 2d inst. from Pictou, N. S., received here to-day state that that region had been visited by a severe gale, doing much damage, and occasioning a fearful loss of life. On the south side of Prince Edward's Island, especially, the wrecks of vessels had been numerous, and the loss of life amounted to fifty.

The members of the Croton Board returned tom their examination of the lake and other sources of our water yesterday, without having arrived at any other conclusion of the present bad taste and smell of it than that which resulted from the examination by the Assistant Engineer. It is believed now that should the weather continue fair, the water will soon taste and smell as sweetly as before.

Mr. VICERS to a widow THOMPSON, both of that county, which took place a year and-2-half of two years ago.

SEVERAL PERSONS INJURED. We frequently have to chronicle accidents which arise from the practice of driving cattle through the street of the City in the day time; and they will continue to occur so long as drovers are allowed the privilege.

Our latest telegram from Sandy Hook, dated at 11 o'clock last night, reports that nothing had been seen of the Royal Mail steamship Asia, in her twelfth day out from Liverpool, and due at this port with two days' late European advices. The steamship Saxonia, of the Hamburg line reached this port yesterday in the afternoon, having left Southampton on the 4th.

REGULAR MEETING OF THE YOUNG MEN'S REPUBLICAN CENTRAL COMMITTEE--RESIGNATION OF POLICEMEN--The Monthly Meeting of the Republication Young Men's Central Committee was held last night at No. 618 Broadway. The names of one or more members from each Ward, who had forfeited their membership by violating the constitution in absenting themselves from two successive meetings of the Committee, were read by the Chairman of the Committee on Vacancies.

BOARD OF HEALTH.--An adjourned meeting of the Brooklyn Board of Health was held yesterday. Several small nuisances were ordered abated; severe large nuisances were referred for special report. Mr. JOHN T. HILDRETH, the great leader of the opposition to swill milk, was present, to look after a communication which he sent in a few weeks ago, complaining of HUSTED'S swill-milk stables on Franklin-avenue.

Quite a destructive conflagration took place just before daybreak this morning, in which three of the large frame machine-shops, immediately north of the north wing of the Capitol, were entirely consumed. The cause of the fire has not yet been satisfactorily ascertained, although it is generally believed to have been the work of an incendiary.

RIOT AND BLOODSED,-In Bethehem, just below the Albany City limits, on saturday night, Aug, 13, a deparate assault was made upon two brothers, bnamed MALTREON and MATTIAS CLIPP, by a gag of roediesied by three brother named FADEREC, ANDREW and HARRID HOFFMAN, It appears that the HOFFMANS first to the house where the CLIPPS reside, and ordered them out to fight.

INTERESTING MARINE SURVEY.--The Navy Department is in receipt of dispatches of date Hong Kong, May 25, from Lieut. BROOKE, commanding the United States schooner Finimore Cooper. The Fenimore Cooper sailed some months since from San Francisco on a voyage of observation and survey of the route from California to China.

The private history of Mr. Bernard Donnelly, of, Wise letter notoriety, is sketched by the Washington star as follows: "Writing letters to noted public men is a disease with him, He thus seeks to achieve a private correspondence with nearly every one o them, in turn, as they rise into prominence before the country.

The American State Council meets at Geneva, on Tuesday next, the 23d inst., pursuant to a call signed by II. B. NORTHUP and JAS. W. IUSTED, respectively its President and Secretary. It consists of a delegate from each local Council in the State. There were at one time some 1,500 of these, but the number is new materially less.

The fifth annual meeting of the American Normal School Association, which is composed of those who are personally employed in connection with the Normal Schools of the United States, is commencing its sessions this morning. There is a prospect of an exceedingly interesting and profitable meeting, as there are already many prominent educators here, from different sections of the country.

GEN. HOUSTON'S TRIUMPH.-We are sorry for Gen. HOUSTON. lie must leave his "sweet retreat," his sheep, and oxen, and goats, to govern rude Texans, and rule wild border rangers. He has been chosen Governor of Texas by 6,000 majority.

The stearnship Saxonia, of the Hamburg line, H. EHLERS Con:mander, from Southampton Aug. 4, arrived at this port yesterday, in the afternoon. We are thus placed in possession of London papers to the morning of the 4th inst., the date to which our telegraphic advices by the City of Baltimore extended. The feeling with regard to the immediate prospects of foreign politics was more favorable.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: You will recollect that Gen. JEREZ, the Nicaraguan Minister, left here by the steamer on the 29th of June, taking with him the contract which had just been concluded between himself and the representalives of the old Ship Canal Company. This contract was in lieu of the old one, and was to be surrendered on the ratification of the new one.

A few years ago, in consequence of his reputed affiliation with the Know Nothings, and of his decided opposition to the passage of the Kansas-Nebraska act, he lost, apparentry, every particle of the popularity he once enjoyed in Texas.

A MAN KILLS HIS MOTHER-IN-LAW. At a little past 10 o'clock last night Officer JOHNSTON, of Third Precinct Police, arrested a printer named ROBERT TOFLTS, at his residence corner of Atlantic and Willow streets, on a charge of having killed his mother-in-law, Mrs. ELIZABETH CRAWFORD.

The, time is so brief since the mail steamer left on the 20th that I have little for my budget to-day. ??AN MINSTRELSY.--It is a proud reflection that the world owes Black Opera to America. But for the Declaration of Independence and its effulgent string of glittering generalities, Ethiopian Minstrelsy had never been; thousands of white artists with black faces and hands, had not nightly submitted those portions of the cuticle to the blighting effects of impeded transpiration, and millions of quarters would annually have been appropriated to other and possibly more ignoble purposes;

MILES.--In this City, on Wednesday, Aug. 17, of cholera intantnin, KDMUND, only son of Edmund I, and Margaret Miles, aged 5 months and 25 days. The friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, Thursday, Aug, 18, at 3 o'clock P. M., from No, 466 6th av.

THE STOCKBRIDGE INDIANS.--Some days since Messrs. HENDRICKS and SLINGERLAND, agents for a portion of the Stockbridge Indians of Wisconsin, had an interview with the Commissioner of Indian Affairs, relative to the payment of annuities of that tribe. The Government provided a reservation for those Indians some time since, and the tribe in council agreed to settle on the reservation.

By the arrival of the steamship Asia at this port, from Liverpool on the 6th inst., we have European intelligence two days later. There is nothing of striking interest. The session of the British Parliament was approaching its close. The deliberations were, however, of exclusively local importance.

THE FILLIBUSTERS.--We have satisfied ourlselF that the rumors of a current effort to organize a gang of fillibusters for another raid on Nicaragua is wholly untrue, and that it has its origin simply in the desire of steamship parties to prevent, by hook or by crook, the proposed speedy reopening of the Nicaragua route under the Van Dyke-Wallace contract with Nicaragua, and the contract recently made by the Post Office Department with Mr. JOHSON.

Before Justice Ingraham. THE HAGGERTY HADIAS CORPUS CASE. Matter of the Application of Anna J. Haggerly.--This case came on this morning, pursuant to adjournment. Mrs. Haggerty was not present. The respondent and the respective counsel, with a large array of witnesses and other interested persons were, however, in attendance from an early hour, evidently eager to watch the progress of this singular case.

Politics in New-Jersey is just now in a very troubled State. There is neither union nor harmony to be found in any of the parties. The Opposition have resolved back again into the abnormal condition they were before their organization three years ago.

THE SOUTH VS. KANSAS.-The Southern Guardian, a paper published at the capital of South Carolina, intends to be true to its name. It informs its readers that " Kansas has adopted a Constitution, and will probably pray for admission into the Union." This statement is not strictly correct.

The Association was called to order at 7 1/2 o'clock. The Committee on Nomination of Officers repoted, recommending that the list of officers of the last year be reelected. The report was accepted, and the same officers were reflected. ADDRESS BY EX-GOVERNOR BOUTWELL.

The Royal Mail steamship Asia, Capt. LOTT, which sailed from Liverpool at 1 o'clock P. M. on the 6th inst., arrived here yesterday at 12 o'clock M. The steamships Arago and Wiser, from New-York, arrived at Southampton on the morning of the 4th inst., within an hour or so of each other. The Vigo reached Queenstown about midnight on the 3d, and Liverpool about 24 hours later.

The Board of Supervisors, on Tuesday last, adopted a report of their Committee awarding the sum of $25,000, in the shape of extra compensation, to three Judges of the Supreme Court. Of these gentlemen, one, however, is dead; one is no longer in office, and one only, Judge ROOSEVELT, is still on the Bench.

CURRY-KERR,--In this City, on Tuesday, Aug 16, at the Church of the Transfiguration. by the Rev. Dr. E. Houghton DUNCAN F. CURRY to ANGIE, youngest daughter of the late William K Kerr of Cincinnati. Cincinnati and Louisville paper's please copy.

REILLY.--In this City, on Thursday afternoon, Aug. 18. after a lingering illness. BRIDGET, the beloved wife of Bernard Reily aged 21 years Her funeral will take place on Saturday at 9 1/2 o'clock, A. M. from her late residence, No. 262 East 13th st, to the Church of the Immaculate Conception, in 14th-st., where a solemn High Mass will be offered for the repose of her soul, and thence to Galvery Cemetery for interment.

DOMESTIC MARKETS. In New-York, during the past week there has been less activity in all kinds of Wool. The demand from manufacturers and dealers has been restricted. The firmness of the principal holders has tended to check it. The reported receipts have amounted to 1,400 bales Domestic and 326 bales Foreign.

Since the acquisition of Arizona, much has been written and much read about the riches of silver mines. WARD'S Mexico is considered authority; and when he says that a piece of pure silver was found weighing 2,700 pounds, and it is known that the identical piece of silver is now in existence in the archives of the Spanish Government, it is not surprising that much confidence is placed in his statements.

The examination of the charge against Dr. BENJAMIN F. ROYAL, of attempting to cut his wife's throat, took place before Esquire MILLIKEN yesterday afternoon. The accused is a man about 45 years of age, a native, we understand, of Lynchburgh, Va., and who once occupied the position of a surgeon in the United States army. Mrs. ROYAL is said to have once been an actress.

Fortunately, the inhabitants of New-York are not compelled to make long journeys in search of Summer recreation. Within two hours ride of the City Hall may be found in perfection the various beauties of mountain, ocean, river and plain-every imaginable aspect of nature and art-to please the eye and beguile the mind worn down by the incessant fatigues of business or study.

THE OFFAL CONTRACT.-The parties authorized by the Common Council to make a contract for removing offal from the City have given the contract to Mr. FRANK SWIFT, for ten years, the City paving him $2,000 per year for tne trouble. Mr. SWIFT denies that the contents of one of his boats were washed ashore at Staten Island, as has been repeatedly stated.

The examination of the counterfeiters of Government drafts took place before Judge ECERLS, at Camp Floyd, last week. BREWER having turned State's evidence, was liberated. McKENZIE was bound over. There are parties here who have been presented, we learn, to the Attorney-General for prosecution for making counterfeit coin. So we see "the brethren" are or have been at their old tricks.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: Allow me, as a humble citizen of a meek provincial city, to congratulate you on the skill and energy of your Metropolitan Police. Your Detectives are especially wonderful; and that such New-York sharps should be foiled by our Philadelphia flats is really not at all to their discredit.

The Association resumed its sessions this evening. The first business in order was the reception of reports from the different States. Among others, the Hon. HENRY BARNARD gave a lucid and full exposition of the system of education in the State of Wisconsin.

A few days since the Street Commissioner sent a requisition for stationery of various kinds over to the Comptroller. Word was returned that the appropriation for stationery for the Street Commissioner's Department was exhausted.

NEW-YORK STATE FAIR.--The work on the Fair Grounds is progressing rapidly. The exhibition building are already far advanced. Application having been made by parties for the erection of buildings on the Show Grounds, at their own expense, the Committee on the arrangement of the grounds have been directed to assign places for such buildings--to be erected upon such plan as shall be approved by them.

Our streets were enlivened, yesterday, by a firemen's display, the occasion being the reception, by Harry Martin Engine Company No. 10, of this city, of Neptune Engine Company No. 10, of Albany, who visited this city for the purpose of taking home the machine built for them by J. N. DENNISON, at his works on Railroad-avenue.

Probably the largest crowd that ever assembled at Niagara Falls was present there yesterday to see Mons. BLONDIN cross the Niagara River upon his rope carrying a man upon his shoulders. Excursion trains were run upon all the roads leading to the Falls, and every train was crowded. The 9 o'clock train from this city took twelve coaches, the 1 o'clock train had twenty-two coaches,
