From the National Era. The State of South Carolina is now having a census taken, which will, by its revelations, throw light upon the question in regard ta the utility of reopening the African Slave-trade. We see it stated that in seventeen parishes there is a decrease of the white population of over 5.000 since 1855, while the blacks during the same period have largely increased in numbers.

It is very refreshing to be able to write of the condition of the public streets without dilating upon the stupidity and indolence, the recklessness and dishonesty of our Municipal officers. We enjoy this refreshment to-day. We car speak for once of the keepers of our highways in as lofty strains of praise as Philadelphians habitually use when speaking of their men in authority.

THE CONVENTIONS.--Both parties--Democratic and Republican--have commenced the selection of delegates to their respective State conventions in September. The Republicans hold theirs at Syracuse on the 7th of that month; the Democrats meeting at Syracuse also, but a week later.

It is most unreasonable, therefore, to except a lively magazine in September, seeing that the work done upon it has to be performed in July and August,

The General Land Office is in receipt of information from the Surveyor-General of Oregon of the extension of the base-line of public surveys in that State across the Cascade Mountains, and terminating 149 miles east of the summit of those mountains, and within three miles from the Blue Mountains.

FLOOD ON LONG ISLAND.--They have been having a great flood down toward the middle of Long Island, On Saturday, the 13th inst., they had a tremendous storm of rain, accompanied by incessant thunder. At Mattituck the rain fell to the depth of 20 inches, according to a correspondent, who writes that he could go in a boat over two-thirds of his farm, which is situated on high land.

On Friday of last week a couple of men were detected at Fort Huron in the act of passing counterfeit altered five-dollar bills on the Narragansett Bank. One of them was arrested, and between three ard four hundred dollars of the bills found on his person. A bag belonging to the party was also secured, in which was found a full set of counterfeiting tools. The accomplice of the person arrested escaped.

Flushing annually about the month of August enjoys in its immediate vicinity a camp-meeting which is regularly gotten up under the auspices of the colored people from various religious societies in this City. This year the meeting began on Friday last, and is advertised to continue until next Sabbath, if the good work should prosper.

The opinion prevails in all New-England villages that young Yankees, like young trees, flourish b st when transplanted; that it is better for the nursery itself to be thinned out often, and that the sapling stands a better obance of growing up and shooting out great branches, either for fruit or for shade, when removed from its parent earth,

Of course no one ever thought of such an event as anybody's being born in Newport. Multitudes of pleasure seekers come and go during the Summer season, some tarrying days and other weeks, but the idea that the "Island of Rhode Island" has sons and daughters must strike these thousands as refreshingly original.

The steamship Hungarian passed this point at 7 30 this morning, with Liverpool advices to the 10th inst. She was boarded by the news yacht of the New York Associated Press, and her news brought ashore. She left Liverpool at 9 o'clock on the morning of the 10th instant. The advices brought by the Hungarian are not of any marked importance, either politically or comme! cially.

WESTERN RAILWAY TRAFFIC.--Business OR the railroads leading from the West to the sea-board, does not promise any material improvement during the approaching autumn, notwithstanding the Western crops are good and the Western people much in need of money. The causes are obvious.

SUICIDE.--A man named PETER M. GOLDEN committed suicide on Saturday afternoon by blowing his brains out with a pistol, at his residence, corner of Tillary anti Stanton streets. Domestic trouble was the cause. He came home, fastened the door of the room which he entered, and, after writing a letter explanatory of his reasons for desiring to kilt himself, proceeded to do so.

There is but little if any doubt, from circumstances which have recently transpired, that a convention or treaty between the United States and Mexico will soon be concluded and received here from Minister McLANE, early in September, in which event Senor LRDOE will return to New-York with a view to conclude the pecuniary arrangements already initiated by him,

The steamship Harana is below, with San Francisco dates of the 5th inst. The steamers John L. Stephens and Orizaba had over $2,000,000 in specie, and 1,000 passengers for New-York. Business at San Francisco was dull, and prices tending downward. Candles were firmer.

Mr. Charles L. Porter, Esq., formerly Postmaster of Hartford, Conn., died at Auburn. N. Y, on Friday, Aug. 12. and was buried from the Centre Church, in Hartford, on Sunday. He resided for some years before his death in East Hartford, but moved from there to Auburn, the residence of his only daughter, about twelve months since. He died of paralytic convulsions.

The steamship Hungarian, from Liverpool on the 10th inst., with four days' later European advices, passed Further Point, on her way to Quebec, on Saturday morning. The general news by this arrival is interesting, though possessing no feature of marked importance. The Conference of Zurich met on the 8th, in accordance with preliminary announcement, but nothing relative to the proceedings had transpired.

Suicides, affrays, murders, seductions, cases of mysterious death, brawls and stabbings at midnight, forgery, bigamy, adultery and duels, follow one another with horrifying rapidity Our exchanges yesterday contained a fresh instalment of such reports, the substance of which is given below. The record is not pleasant, but it is part of the history of the day:

In another part of our columns will be found a Circular issued by the Republican National Committee. The document, which may be regarded as the first official demonstration of that Party in reference to the canvass of 1860, emanates from Albany under date of the 16th instant, though first published at Cincinnati.

SCANDALOPS CONDUCT--ELOPFMENTS AND ARRESTS.--Mr. DAVID DATSON, a cabinet-market, of Boonton, N. J, and JOHN FISHER, of the same place, who had been in the employ of the former, were arrested on Saturday by Officers GILLMORE and FASHA, of the Third Ward, on a charge of larceny. The prisoners were taken before Alderman BRADY,

The Boston Transcript of Saturday says: "The celebrated trotting mares Flora Temple and Princess, whose recent trials of speed have created such an excitement among the sporting men, arrived in this city last evening, by the Fall River line. They are both in the best condition, and an exciting race between the two is expected on Tuesday next."

A few days since we published a paragraph, on the authority of a statement in the Portland Advertiser, relating to the affair at the Glen Mountain House, where Mr. GANGOOLY, the Brahmin, was asserted to have been treated with disrespect on account of his complexion. The Rev. Mr. Bush, of Medfield, who was in Mr. GANGOOLY'S company on the occasion, sends us the following note in explanation.

THE CITY TAXES.--The Joint Board of Aldermen and Supervisors held another meeting, last evening, to consider the Budget for 1860, The reconsideration of resolutions adopted, being always in order in this body, advantage was taken of the fact to reconsider several passed at the previous meeting, and after incorporating some amendments the same were readopted. Among there was the fourth resolution.

Yesterday was Commencement Day at Madison University. Orations were delivered by twelve members of the graduating class, and a poem was recited by D. E. POPE, of Forestville, N. Y.--subject, "The Pilgrimage of the Scholar." The degree of Doctor of Divinity was conferred upon sixclergymen, and the degree of L. L. D. upon the Hon. TIMOTHY JENNINS, of Oncida, and Judge DENIO, of Utica.

AT SOUTH ABINGTON, MASS.--A fire at South Abington, Mass., which broke out at 3 A. M. on the 20th August, in HOBART'S works, destroyed a saw-mill, planing mill, tack factory, and boarding house adjoining. It is supposed that the fire took in the enginehouse, which is located in a small building adjoining the tack factory. The amount of property destroyed is estimated at $60,000.

Just as the London Times is beginning to make up its mind that NAPOLEON III. is, after all, in a fair way to prove himself a substantial benefactor to Italy, the Parisian organs of the French Government are talking up the English charge against the Emperor, of nefarious designs in the fortification of Oherbourg, and answering it with an equally plausible imputation of English intrigues against France, in the proposed fortification of Antwerp.

THE ROPE-WALKING MANIA.--BLONDIN has found in the person of one DE LAVE both an imitator and rival. Indeed, it could not be supposed that the former hero should be allowed to enjoy in exclusive monopoly the harvest of glory awarded him by admiring crowds at Niagara. His measure of fame was too full, his cup overflowed, and it was but natural that the surplus should bless at least one other intrepid contemner of peril.

At the first meeting of this American Whig Society, after the death of the Rev. JAMES W. ALEXANDER, the following resolutions were passed. Whereas, it has pleased Almighty God, in his all wise providence, to remove by death the Rev. JAMES W. ALEXANDER, O.D., an eminent scholar, a profound thinker, an able theologian; one who evertonk the deepest interest in our welfare and who ever reflected honor upon this institution, be it.

The Administration has bestowed upon the subject of the African Slave-trade its earnest attention, and with a view of suppressing, as far as possible, this traffic, has initiated measures more efficient and extensive than ever before for that purpose. The squadron for the Coast of Africa, as arranged by the Secretary of the Navy, will consist of the following-named vessels:

INGRAHAM J.--This motion is made by a judgment in favor of the defendant to set aside the judgment in this case for a defect in the statement of indebtedness.

The Montpelier (Vt.) Freeman tells the following story: "On Friday afternoon, Aug. 5, Mr. THOMAS CARR, while working with others at haying, near Be ??Pond, suddenly disappeared from the nay-field. Not re??ing at night, fears were entertained for his safety, and a search was soon instituted by his friends and neighbors, which was kept up for several of the succeeding days. s.

ELMENDORF.--In this City, on Monday morning. Aug. 22, JAMES W., infact son of Edmund Elmendorf. Jr., and Bachel is wife, aged 8 months and 22 days. The friends and relatives of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, from No. 12 Carmine-st., this (Tuesday) afternoon, at 2 o'clock. His remains will be interred in the Cemetery of the Evergreens. WARNEP.--On Sunday evening. Aug. 21,

The history of Mexico, since its discovery by the Spaniards, is marvelous enough in its reality, but the inflamed imagination of those early adventures, the children of avarice and fanaticism, brought forth such romantic, exaggerated, extravagant accounts of the country and its inhabitants, and their own performances, as to lay the foundation of a history the most erroneous of all that grace the literature of the present age.

The Mail steamship Bremen, Capt. WESSELS, from Southempton, Aug. 9, arrived at this port yesterday. The news we thus receive is not so late as that by the Hungarian, at Quebec; but we are placed in possession of British and Continental files, from which two derive various matters of the highest interest.

MCCAFFERTY--BUCKLEY--On Thursday, Aug. 18 at the residence of the bride's father, by the Rev. Dr. Rudolph. Mr. ROBERT McCAFFERTY to MARY, eldest daughter of Denny W. Buckley, Esq., both of this City. FORREST--HARPER--On Friday evening, Aug. 19 at the residence of the bride's father, by the Rev. James Thomson, Mr. WILLIAM FORREST, of Bathgate. Scotland, to Miss JANET HARPER, of Dua frieshire, Scotland.

The duty of the citizen to vote is universally admitted; but the confession of that duty implies another, which all are not so ready to allow. If voting is worth the citizen's while, it is also worth his while to do all in his power to make his vote tell upon the policy of the Government under whose protection he lives.

On Saturday, August 20, the dead body of a man was found floating in the Delaware and Hadson Canal, near Cuddeback, New York. The body ball apparently been in the water about a week or ten days. The deceased was about 20 years of age, five feet ten inches in height, stout built, brown hair, and no whickers. The clothing consisted of two centered shifts, overalls, and thick coat, with all the pockets entirely empty.

After a season unparalleled for business inactivity, even in the annals of Albany, we have porteats of an awakening--a regeneration--that promises to a awake up in a measure for a lethargy that has had an unco resemblance to death. All through the Summer the pulsations of trade have hardly been perceptible through car great arteries, the canals ; boats unladen at the docks and in the basin, have been the rale, not the exception.

The screw steamship Bremen, from Southampton Aug. 9, arrived here yesterday. An outline of news one day later had been previously received from the Hungarian at Quebec ; but our tiles by the Southampton steamer supply details and extracts of unusual interest. A fire in Halifax has destroyed the stables of Mr. McKAY, involving the loss of ten horses, including those used in expressing the foreign news from Halifax to Sackville.

The new tragedy at Wallack's, last evening, was successful, in so far as the somewhat mild appro bation of an attentive audience may be taken as a test of success. If that approbation was not as enthusiastically expressed as the many merits of the piece deserve, we believe that the absence of very marked applause was less owing to its not few demerits than to its extreme length. Three hours and a half--namely.

THE PENALTY OF GREATNESS.-This vast and growing metropolis is constantly assailed in its moral reputation by provincial towns like Boston and Philadelphia, as well as by the rural districts generally. These small friends of ours affect to be horror-struck at the enornious prevalence of crime in New-York, and charitably conclude that some inscrutable influence unfavorable to virtue pervades our very atmosphere.

Mr. BERNARD DONNELLY is by no means easy in his mind. He considers that the Press treats him unjustly; and to repel its imputations, has written still another letter, which we publish in this morning's TIMES. The missive is ingenuous to a degree, and quite touching.

A telegram from Boston yesterday announced he death of Mr. Moses D. Phillips, senior partner in the well-known publishing house of Phillips, Sampson Co. The Evening Transcript has the following: "It is but a few weeks since we reported the death of Mr. Charles Sampson, a member of the well-known publishing house of Phillips, Sampson Co.

MORE COUNTERFEIT MONEY IN CIRCULATION.--At an early hour last evening Detective Police Officer ELDER, was standing on the steps of the Brandreth House, when he observed a genteel-looking man standing on the corner, and who, after standing a few minutes, was accosted by another man; an, from their actions, the Policeman felt sure something wrong was going on.

By the arrival at this port of the brig George Albert, from Port au Prince, we are placed in possession of our Hayti files to August 6. It appears that the statement in La Republique asserting that President GEFFRARD had been offered and declined the dictatorship of Hayti was merely a bold newspaper conard.

A large number of delegates to the American State Council arrived here to-day. The attendance is quite large, but among the members are many who have been supposed for the past two years to act with the Democrats or Republicans. The lion. ERASTUS BROOKS, LYMAN ODELL, Gen. SCROGGS, and most of the leading Americans are here;

Affairs In Washington. WASHINGTON, Tuesday, Aug, 23. The President has recognized HENRY SCHONDORFF as Consul of the Prince of Roues of the elder branch, and of Prince of Reuss of the junior branch, to reside at New York, He has also recognized C. E. STEWART as Consul for Belgium, at Charlestor, S. C.

The Royal Mail steamship Canada, from Liverpool on the 13th inst., with European advices three days later, is now fully due at Halifax. There were no signs of her last evening, at the close of telegraphic communication. The steamship United Kingdom, from Glasgow on the same day, is also about due at Quebec.

THE WASHINGTON DEFALCATION.--It is now said that if any moneys have been misapplied by person recently arrested upon the order of the Secretary of the Treasury, the loss will fall upon Maj. BOWMAN, U. S. A., who is Superintending Engineer of Construction for the Treasury Department. In that capacity he disburses moneys, for the security of which he furnishes adequate bonds.

The publicity given to the letter from Gov. WISE to me, of the 13th of July last, has been the cause of much animadversion with regard to my name and character. Some of the political journals have been so unjust as to charge that I opened a correspondence with Gov. WISE for the purpose of afterwards betray his confidence.

In steamship Nashville, from Charleston--Mrs. Martin and child, Miss Van Noy, Mr. Reed, J M. P. Oreighton, lady, child and nurse Mrs J. Clark. Miss Clark, A. H. Abrahams., D. A. Duval. Miss M Lachie, Miss E. Manle, A. S. Hull, W. Carrington, J. Currie, L. Brown, E. J. Manle. Thos Gelyer. Mrs Gelver Miss Gelyer.

There is but one vessel at the Lower Anchorage, the brig Hannah Crooker, from Havana. Owing to the difficulty with the lightermen, we are likely to have a return of some of the dangerous features of Quarantine; we allude to the discharging of vessels off our shores.

Files of London and Liverpool papers, forwarded by the Hungarian were received yesterday. The dates are one day later than by the Bremen. We find various matters of interest, which we extract. Letters from Florence contain the expected anti very good news that GABIBALDI is about to assume the command of the Tuscan army.

On Monday evening the Ashlanders' Association, of Brooklyn, unanimously passed a resolution in favor of the Hon. JOHN MINOR BOTTS, of Virginia, as the united Opposition candidate for the next Presidency. A committee was appointed to prepare an address and present it in person to the distinguished gentleman, (who is now stopping at the Astor House,) on Tuesday evening.

Before Justice Ingranam. THE NEW-YORK AND NEW-HAVEN RAILROAD COMPANY--INJUNCTION ON THE AUGUST DIVIDENDS. John A. Underwood and Henry A. Underwood vs. The New-York Railroad Company and others.--This was an order to show cause why an injunction should not issue enjoining the defendants,

W. H. C. King, foreman in the composition room of the New-Orleans Crescent office, was examined in that city on Saturday, August 13, on a charge of murder, and indicted for manslaughter. During a meeting of the New-Orleans Typographical Union, on the 3d of July, Arthur McGill, assistant foreman and the accused had an altercation, during which McGill was stabbed by King in the back, which resulted in the death of McG.

Had we an American HOGARTH now among us, to note our national ways, and mark their real nature for the instruction of the people, we fear he would be called upon to surpass the skill with which his great prototype depicted the Progress of Cruelty.

At the Regular Meeting of the "Gewerbererien" in this City-a Society incorporated on the 23d of March, 1859, for the purpose of promoting science among mechanics and tradesmen-an address was presented to the Secretary, by Messrs. L. J. BOECK and Dr. J. C. ADELBERG, of the Polytechnic Institute, in relation to the impurities of our Croton water. The Address was as follows:

MODEST MERIT.--What is an Ashlander? We do not know, nor do we suppose that our readers much care. But really the Ashlanders ought to be ashamed of themselves. They have been tormenting Mr. JOHN M. BOTTS with superfluous inquiries into his views of the Presidency.

Yesterday afternoon, towards dusk, a serious riot occurred at a place called St. Vincent House, situate about one mile from the steamboat landing, at Tacony, in the Twenty-third Ward. There were some slight indications communicated by the local telegraph by the electricians at Frankford, but so vague, indeed, that neither head nor tall could be made of the matter.

KINGS COUNTY BOARD OF SUPERVISORS.--An adjourned meeting of this Board was held last evening, in the old Court Room, County Jail building, Raymond street. In the absence of the President, Supervisor CROOK, of Flatbush, was called to the Chair.

A very considerable number of people, say ten thousand or thereabouts, went on a mild jollification on Monday. A trivial expenditure of something less than half a dollar sufficed for all the outlay incidental to a trip to and from the Myrtle avenue Park, where the festival was held. Of those who took part in the celebration, the great majority were Germans. But they were not all Germans.

BALTIC, OF NEW-YORK, VS. ATLANTIC, OF BROOKLYN. The above match was played, on Monday, upon the grounds of the Baltic, corner of Eighty-first-street and Second-avenue. It resulted in the defeat of Baltic Club. The Atlantics are now looked upon as the most successful Club of New-York or Brooklyn, they having gone on from one victory to another for a long period.

If the Honorable (we believe he is the Honorable) O. JENNINGS WISE would condescend to take our advice, of which, however, we have not the least expectation, he would sell his pistol at once, and join the Society of Friends. Of all the great duelists, either of the present day or of past ages, we cannot recollect one who has fought so many duels to so little purpose.

We gather from the telegraphic report, published yesterday, of the Know-Nothing Council, that attempts were made by persons formerly members in good standing of the "sixty thousand," but now and for a considerable time past acting with other parties, to influence the proceedings of that "Great Body," as it is called, in favor of their present associates.

THE SANTA FE MAIL.-We learn from undoubted authority that the Postmaster General has ordered an increase of speed in the letter and paper service from Independence to San ta Fe. Instead of twenty days, the mail is hereafter to be carried in fifteen days-allowing the contractors thirty days in which to take through the book and document bags-a mode of overloading the malls all over the country which had better be dispensed with.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: A man killed! N'importe? We are getting used to that sort of thing. We are fast becoming indifferent to railroad slaughters; we hear and read o them with perfect callousness, always supposed none of our frier ds or relatives were in the cars to which the "accident" happened. Killed! We ask how many?

A terrible tragedy was enacted in our city on Sunday last. The circumstances of the case are as follows: THOS, CHAMBERLAIN, a stevedore, residing in New-Orleans, arrived here, Sunday morning on the steamer Omega, in pursuit of his wife, who had left him some two weeks previous for this city, taking with her $150 belonging to the husband.

The following account of the arrival and reception of the Washington Grays, Eighth Regiment, of this City, is from a correspondence of the Boston Atlas, under date of Aug. 23. He says the Washingion Grays arrived here this morning. The New-Bed. ford City Guard were in waiting at an early hour this morning to receive them.

A lawsuit of some importance, involving a principle as to the duties of steamboat captains, was tried at Belvall??, Orange County, N. Y., on the 26th of July. The issue was between Daniel L. Holley, complainant, and Capt. Anderson, of the steamboat ThomasPowell, defendant. On the 26th day of August 1858.
We have received from Messrs. WILLIAM HALL Son, of Broadway, the following new publications: " Grand March and Chorus from Donizetti's Opera of Poliuto," arranged by FRADEL, op. 222.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The Northwestern Dispensary having been founded under the auspices of the "New-York Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor," that institution has ever felt a deep interest in its increasing usefulness and prosperity.

The Kansas City Journal of Commerce makes the following mention of a trip lately performed by the steamer Spread Eagle, Capt. CHOUTEAU: "The steamer Spread Eagle, Capt. CHOUTEAU, returned on Saturday from the most remarkable voyage ever performed in river navigation, having, when reaching St. Louis, performed on one trip over six thousand miles.

The Gallatin (Tenn.) Examiner says: Col. James Glover, of the California Overland Mail Company, informs us of the existence of a remarkable spring, on his route, 280 miles east of El Paso, on the road leading to san Antonio. It is fully 150 feet in diameter, and has been sounded to the depth of 8,000 feet without finding bottom. The surface is as smooth as that of a mountain lake.

About three months since Mr. ABBOTT, the principal of the Spingler Institute, entered into arrangements with Mr. TOWNHEND for the purchase of his famous residence on Fifth avenue, and the transfer of that building, with all its furniture, ha been effected, we understand, for the sum of $200,000.

The Third Judicial District Court, Judge SINCLAIR presiding, opened its session in this city the first of this week ; but owing to the juries being incomplete, was adjourned until yesterday, when Judge SINCLAIR delivered an able and pointed charge to the Grand Jury; one suited to the times and locality, referring to crimes and their punishment, to events past and present in this Territory.

DOMESTIC MARKETS. In New-York during the past week the transactions In Woolhave been somewhat restricted. The demand has been fair, especially for desirable lots of domestic, but generally at prices unsatisfactory to the principal holders, who are not disposed to make any material concessions.

The Administration has assurances from the Government of Costa Rica of its preparation to appoint, in conjunction with that of the United States, a Commission to settle all claims of our citizens against that Republic. It is presumed this Commission will be appointed shortly after the arrival of Minister DIMITRY at San Jose.

The Constitution contradicts the report that a cargo of Africans was recently landed on the Fiorida coast. It says: " The following letter, which we are permitted to publi????, from a gentleman in Florida, whose position and character render any statements he may make entirely reliable, proves beyond a doubt that the late rumors in respect to the landing of native Africans on the coast of Florida have no foundation in truth.

The steamer Sonora, of the mail line, arrived yesterday afternoon from Panama with the malls and passengers from New York the 5th inst. The Orizaba, of the opposition line, came in towards midnight. She left Panama earlier than the Sonora, but was passed by the latter on the way.

The old farce has its fun over the pair of punctilious chevaliers d'industrie, neither of whom would take precedence of the other in entering a drawing-room for fear of having his pockets picked. The droll spectacle is reproduced in the relations of England and the United States with Mexico.

The Boston Atlas of yesterday gives a report of the race between Flora Temple and Princess, at the South end Riding Park: At 4 P. M. yesterday, the great, much-mooted trot between Flora Temple and Princess took place at the South-end Riding Park, perhaps better known as the Agricultural Fair Grounds.

A State Temperance Convention will be held in Boston, on Tuesday, Sept. 13. The call emanates from the State Temperance Alliance, and one object of the meeting will be to organize the Alliance. The Boston Traveller says:

To the Editor of the New- York Times: Allow me to have recourse to your valuable paper for rectifying an error which appeared in the Sunday Herald, (Aug. 21.) In speaking of Zurich it says: " It is one of the three citiesBerne and Lucerne being the two others-where the Diet assemble in turn."

THE OATH OF A HORST-THIEF.--Two men, D. A. Rouse and J. E. HOLLY, from Cincinnati, were sent to prison in Louisville, a few days since, on suspicion of horse stealing, having shipped a fine stallion the day previous. ROUSH's conduct, such as appearing in false whiskers and the like, caused his arrest.

The Philadelphia Sunday Transcript calls attention to a growing evil which has followed the introduction of the city railroad system in Philadelphia. It says "The condition of the public streets used by many of our City Railway Companies is the subject of frequent and well-founded complaints. Some of them are deplorably bad, the roadway on each side of the rails being sunk, and in a great variety of instances full of ruts.

WISE really had some hold upon the confidence of the Democrats of this State, and what is more remarkable, the Virginia Governor's notable plan for carrying a delegation in this State,

BLEECKER,--In this City, on Tuesday, Aug. 23, CORNELIA, wife of Anthony J. Bleecker, and daughter of the late John Van Benthuysen, of Dutchess County. The relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral, without further invitation, at 3 1/2 o'clock, this (Thursday afternoon at Trinity Church.

FLATHUSH-A VENUE IMPROVEMENT.--The contractor for cutting down the grade of this avenue, at the highest point, is pushing the work forward as fast as possible. The work already has progressed so far as to make a marked difference in the appearance of the avenue.

The refusal of the Constitutional Convention at Wyandotte to comply with the memorial of certain citizens of South Nebraska to extend our northern boundary to the Platte River gives general satisfaction to our people, and has been productive of good results in our neighboring Territory;

A MARRIAGE AND ITS RESULTS.--CECILIA PFEISHER, a German woman about 45 years of age, of the Hebrew faith, appeared before Justice BEENMAN yesterday, and preferred charges of as fault and battery and larceny against KING SCHOENFELD, also a German and a Jew, Louis and ABRAHAM SOHOENFELD, hisons, and a man named SCHWARTZ.

The various contaminations to which water is liable may all be arranged under two heads: they are either organic or inorganic. The organic impurities again naturally resolve themselves into the dead and the living. Inasmuch as the dead organic substances present in impure waters form the material or food upon which the living impurities are sustained, it is proper to allude first to them.

A fire broke out in Waterville, Me., about 12 o'clock Sunday night, Aug. 21, which destroyed all the mills, machinery. c., situated near the steamboat wharf, below Ticonic bridge. The fire took in the large wood machine shop owned by Daniel Moore, and occupied by FURBUSH DRUMMOND and others, as a sash, blind and door manufactory, and for other small manufactures.

Before Justice Ingraham. THE SCHUILER FRAUD LEASE. John. A. Underwood and Henry A. Underwood vs. The New-York and New-Haven Railroad Company.--the argument in this case was continued. Mr. Noyes said it conceded on all hands that a separation of the genuine and spurious shares is entirely practicable, and as it had been made it was practicable. The Court had no doubt it was practicable.

From the London Saturday Review. It is difficult, and more than difficult, to fathom, for even to apprehead, the great American mind in the popular aspect. What it seems to reproduce on the most exaggerated scale is the manner of life and the domestic boats of English village society.

The newspapers will have informed you that Mr. BUCHANAN'S penchant for the Hellenic race is not confined to the individual who will soon have to measure intellectual swords with the shrewd and oily Sir WILLIAM GORE OUSELEY.

SCIENTIFIC OBSERVATIONS IN MID-AIR. Mr. JOHN WISE is as prolific of long letters as his Virginia namesake. No sooner does he come down from one of his airy fights than he falls to writing a tow-columedescription. His last effert is an slaborate statement concerning his voyages from Lafayette, Ind., which were undertaken consecutively on the 16th and 17th August.

The last news from Washington assures us that the Administration is making tremendous preparations to put down tile Slave trade. Instead of eighty guns, the number stipulated for by the treaty with England, they are going to keep one hundred and sixteen on the Slave coast.

The Newburgh (N. Y.) News has the following:--"Some days ago we noticed the finding of a dead body in Murderer's Creek. It has been identified as that of JOHN OGLE, who had for some time past resided in Newburgh. Mr. OGLE was of Scotch birth, but for some 20 years resided in the Island of Jamaica. Hoping to better his condition he brought his family to this country and came to Newburgh.

Be it known to all men by these presents--by presents I of course mean the service of silver plate with which the proprietors of the TIMES will present me when they read this letter-be it known, therefore, by these presents that I-Jack Robinson-am at Nahant.

THE TERRITORIAL CONVENTION-MEMORIAL TO CONGRESS, The St. Louis Republican has news from the Rocky Mountains to August 6, with further particulars of the movements in the new Territory of Jefferson. The Territorial Convention had adjourned after a session of a week. It adopted a Constitution which is to be submitted to a popular vote.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Did it ever occur to you that in the laying of the Atlantic Telegraph Cable, the injury was done which finally destroyed its power of working? I have examined every article published by you, on the subject of this great experiment, but I have never yet seen anything which seemed to satisfactorily explain the cause of failure.

Within a few weeks, two of the Institutions for the Reformation of Juvenile Delinquents in Massachusetts have been burned to the ground. The Reform School at Westborough was set on fire by one of the boys who was sheltered under its roof.

OAKLAND VS. POWHATAN. A match was played between these Brooklyn clubs on the 19th inst., resulting in a tie. The play on the part of the Oakland was splendid ; OGG, a first base, catching every ball that came near him The third base was splendidly played by MURTHA, who caught some balls that seemed almost an impossibility; his throwing to first base was as well as we have ever seen any senior player do.

Soon after the organization of our Government it became apparent to its founders that though remote from the Old Continent, our distance might not avert a participation in the wars that the French Revolution had spread over the rest of Christendom; and accordingly a very large amount of money was expended on forts and batteries at the principal sea-port towns.

It is of the highest importance to the present peaceful tendencies of the world's commercial activity that the international relations of Europe should remain undisturbed. Mr. Isaac Otis died in Boston, Aug. 21, at an advanced age. He was of Puritan descent, and resided in early life in Massachusetts, where he married the daughter of Capt. Oliver Smith, of Walpole. He was educated at the Seminary in Wrentham, under the charge of the Rev. William Williams, a retired Professor of Brown University.

THE NEW-BEDFOBD FIRE.-The disastrous tire at New-Bedford, Aug. 24, briefly reported by telegraph, broke out in the saw and planing mill of Wilcox Hathaway, on North Water-street. It spread from the mill to the large lumber-yard adjoining, in which there was a great quantity of soft lumber used in the mill. Loss on mill, $9,000-no insurance; on lumber-yard, $99.00; next, Ryder Smith's spar-yard; loss, $30,000.

BOLD ROBBERY AT. NEWBURGH.--A bold and adroit robbery was committed on Tuesday evening, at the store of ISAAC WOOD, Jr. Watching his opportunity, while the attention of the clerks were occupied by customers at a little distance from the desk, the thief opened the cash drawer and abstracted some $300, and safety decamped with his plunder.

Drs. CHILTON and TORREY have finally completed their analysis of the Croton water with a vie w to ascertaining the cause of the unpleasant taste which has been observable in it for some time past. The report was submitted to the Croton Board on Saturday. As soon as it had been read by them, it was sent to the NEW-YORK TIMES for publication.

DEATH FROM SHOOTING.--Mr. BENJAMIN T. TILT, who shot himself some days since, died of his wounds on Saturday, at his residence in Gold street. No cause is assigned for ending his life. He was believed to have been in good circumstonces. A post mortam examination was held yesterday morning. but nothing impor?? was elicited. His remains were conveyed to his father's residence in Newton for interment.

The Doctors have saved us all a great deal of trouble by agreeing upon a verdict in the case of New-York against the Croton Aqueduct. The chemist and the botanist have done their worst, and the water which has been for weeks past in such ill odor has now a scientific right to smell sweet once more.

To the Editor of the New York Times: The peace of Villafranca has produced a temporary suspension of the struggle for national independence in Europe. Of this peace-dissipating so many patriotic hopes--the daily papers have already given the most important featurers, though certain incidents still enveloped in mystery will, when the time arrives for their disclosure, yet astonish the public.

I announced in my last letter that a grand fancy dress and mass masquerade ball was to be given by the guests of the Hygeia Hotel. This interesting event is over, and Hoteldom, here, can now settle down to its usual state of undisturbed country quiet. Everything has its climax, and the excitement among the guests of Hygeia reached its climateric last evening at the hour of 9 o'clock precisely,

Gen. HOUSTON'S victory in Texas is even more sweeping than was at first reported. Of one hundred counties, from which returns had been received on the 16th instant, he had majorities in all but twenty-one, and it was believed that his total majority might reach twelve thousand.

The steamship Indian, from Liverpool on the 17th inst., arrived off Further Point at 11 o'clock on Sunday morning. Her dates are four days later than those by the steamships America and Etna. The steamship City of Washington, from Liverpool on the same day with the Indian, and from Cork on the 18th, to which date she brings telegraphic advices

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Mr. DOUGLAS pivots his "dividing line," which you published Saturday, upon what he calls the Jefferso??ten plan. He says Messrs. JEFFERSON, CHASE and HOWELL "submitted to Congress a plan for the temporary government of the territory" called the Northwest. This much is true.

The article which we yesterday translated from the Paris Constitutionned Upon KOSSUTH, deserves the special attention of all who really wish to understand the relations which the peace of Villafranca has established between France and Austria, between NAPOLEON III. and the Italians, to whom he promised freedom and self-government " from the Alps to the Adriatic."

Nobody entertains such a savage contempt for colored people as your mulatto, and, by the same token, none are so thoroughly outraged at the vision of females coming up to the performance of novel labors as your old women in pantaloons.

THE MEADOW MOUNTAIN CHILDREN AT FORT LEAVENWORTH.--The Commissioner of Indian Affairs, says the Washington Star, has received a dispatch from Mr. WM. C. MITCHELL, special agent in charge of there children, informing him that they had arrived safely at Fort Leavenworth, in excellent health, and that arrangements were immediately to be made for restoring them to their relatives and friends.

THE REOPENING OF LAURA KEENE'S THEATRE--Right is it and proper that places of public amusement should be renovated and redecorated every season. The charm of the theatre being variety, the eye is pleased to find blue in 1859 where yellow was in 1858--amber in the place of gold--and roses where were only leaves before. .

I visited the celebrated Natural Bridge of Virginia a few days ago in company with a few friends, now on a tour of pleasure through the mountains of Virginia. It is situated in Rockbridge County, about eight or ten miles from Lexington, and is certainly one of the rarest specimens of Nature's architecture to be found in the country.

The Empire City, Capt. GRIFFIN, left New-Orleans on the 20th inst., and arrived at Havana on the 24th, at 6 A. M., having touched meanwhile at Key West to land passengers in route for California, She reached this port yesterday morning. On the 22d inst., the Empire City encountered a very severe gale, mainly from the S. E., which lasted about eighteen hours, accompanied with a heavy sea.

The European news by the steamship Indian, at Quebec, from Liverpool on the 17th instant, the transmission of which on Sunday night was interrupted by the extraordinary effect of the aurora borealis on the telegraphic wires, will be found in this morning's TIMES. the French Army of Italy made its triumphal entry into Paris on Sunday, the 14th.

Base Ball. EMPIRE VS. MUTUAL. These Clubs played at the Elysian Fields, Hoboken, on Monday. The Mutual Club had the advantage for four or five innings; but after that the Empires gained upon them and recovered their leeway. The game was an excellent one, and was closely contested from its commencement.

The first business of the Institute, this morning, was the discussion of the question--"Is it expedient to require the use of the Bible by pupils in Public Schools?" The Rev. B. G. NORTHRUP took the affirmative of me question, and, at the same time, so defined his views as to limit the question by saying that he would have no coercion in the matter.

A convict named JOON CABRA attempted to escape from the prison at this place yesterday afternoon. He secreted himself on the grounds, and was not missed until the hour of closing. Finding one man abort, the guard was kept on and search made. About 8 o'clock in the evening, he was discovered on a low parapet wall, endeavoring to escape by the water, When discovered he was commanded to stop,

CHABERT.--In this City, on Monday, Aug. 29, of pulmonary consumption, Dr. JULIUS XAVIER CHABERT, aged 68 years. The friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend his funeral this (Tuesday) afternoon, at 3 o'clock, from his late residence, No. 431 Grand St. WILLIAMS--In this City, on Monday, Aug. 22, at 13 M. CLARENCE, youngest son of Wm. H. and He??rietta Williams, aged 1 year, 6 months and 21 days.

The present generation have listened with wonder and admiration to the stories their fathers and mothers have told them of auroras and meteors. They have opened ears and mouths and eyes as they heard of stars falling from the heavens like rain, of the sky at night becoming red as with blood, and in the day-time of its being so darkened 'that stars were visible.

While the Democracy are indulging in acrimonious and premature discussions over tile respective claims of various prominent leaders to the command of their party in the coming Presidential election, the Republicans have thus far escaped any open dissensions on this point of their plan of campaign.

There is a rumor prevalent here this evening that the frigate Congress, which sailed from here on the 14th inst., has gone down with all on board. The story seems to have originated at the Navyard, but it is impossible to trace it to any definite or reliable source whatever. It has caused much anxlefy among the friends of the crew.

THIS COAL DIGGERS' STRIKE IN PENNSYLVANIA--Another meeting of the coat digger was held at saw Mill Road, yesterday, when a proposition was made by Road Co, to the effect that if their men would go to work on Monday next, they would put no scales within sixty days. If the care weighed more than the brand indicated, the difference would be put to the credit of the miners;

A FIRE SCHOOL OF VOCAL ART.-Those desiring instruction in the vocal art, as may be seen by an advertisement under the head of Education, have an excellent opportunity afforded them, by Joining "The Gullmette Free School of Vocal Art," the members of which will meet at Cooper Institute this evening.

UNITED STATES CIRCUIT COURT.-Ordered that a Special Term of the Circuit Court of the United States for the Southern District of New-York be held at the court-room in Chambers street, on Thursday, the 15th of Septemper next, at 11 o'clock A. M., to Lear appeals in admiralty, issues at law, and cases in equity, according to the statute in such case made and provided. S. NELSON.

THE FEES OF REFEREES.--Ex-Judge COWLES is reputed to do the prettiest Referee business in the City, and it is gratifying to be able in the light of the proceedings before the Court of Common Pleas yesterday to presume that it is profitable.

EMPIRE VS. MUTUAL. These Clubs played at the Elysian Fields, Hoboken, on Monday. The Mutual Club had the advantage for four or five innings; but after that the Empires gained upon them and recovered their leeway.

We have been besieged with inquiries as to the truth of the telegraphic report in this morning's paper concerning the rumored loss of the frigate Congress. We can only say that the dis patch came in the usual way to all the papers from the agent of the Associated Press, and that it professed to give nothing more than tile vaguest of rumors.

Four hundred and fifty-two children, under the age of two years, died in this City of Ncw-York last week; of that number 145 died of cholera infantum and 43 of diarrhoea ; the whole number of deaths of all ages being 710. Common decency demands an inquisition of this innocent blood.

TYLER HODGES "OPERATING"--A SERIES OF SPICY DEVELOPMENTS. The Pittsburgh papers of Saturday contain full particulars of recent developments, concerning the affairs of the Monongahela Valley Bank. Parties well known in New-York are involved in charges of forgery and attempts to awindle.

There is some talk in Paris about the discovery of a new motive power, said to have been made by a young workman, named Jacob, a turner in copper. Although the precise nature of the discovery is not stated, it has been said that this, like many similar discoveries, was tha result of an accident.

At 1 o'clock this afternoon, the bark Wyman, Capt. BARKER, sailed on an expedition to the Northern Atlantic Ocean to survey a route for a telegraphic cable by way of Greenland, Iceland and the Shetland Islands, to Glasgow. The vessel has been chartered by Col. T. P. SHAFFNER, who goes in her, accompanied by his wife and son, and two gentlemen of Worcester.

On Monday last, the 1st inst., was held the Territorial election of Utah-a feature in the politics of this Territory, heretofore merely nominal, considered only a formality, but which this year has assumed an Importance little anticipated by the followers of the Prophet.

INJUNCTION AGAINST THE SEWER COMMISSIONERS.--There has been growing between the Broadway Railroad Company and the Sewer Commissioners for some time past, but it has at last assumed a definite shape and is before the constituted authorities, where it should be, and where the matter in dispute will be finally settled.

Mr. BUCHANAN is certainly a master in the "Art of Sinking." In every lowest depth of political discredit he still contrives to find a deeper deep. Ills bathetic exploits will assuredly secure for him the posthumous renown of which he might else have failed;

Our readers doubtless remember that in January last, a man who called himself ALEX. NORTON, SWINDLED Mr. W. E. SMODDY cut of several thousand dollars. Mr. SMODDY had been traveling with him some time previous on a steamboat, and became favorably impressed with him.

The Treasury Department is now preparing some interesting statistical tables relative to the trade between France and the United States, exhibiting by Comparison, the amount of duties paid by each on the imported products of the other. These tables, it is understood, are designed to facilitate the negotiation of a treaty between the two countries, by which our commercial interests will be extended.

THE ENLARGEMENT--ARRANGEMENT OF THE LIBRARY--NEW BOOKS. Bibliopoles had their hearts gladdened, Monday, by the announcement that the Astor Library was again open for their delectation and accommodation. They were little prepared, however, for the total transformation which the interior of the building had undergone as regarding the arrangement of books.

The case of a man named JANOWVITZ, recently decided in Montreal, has created some interest in that city. JANOWITZ was arrested in Montreal, on a charge of forgery preferred against him by HEOKER BROS, of this City, and his return to the United States for trial was demanded under the terms of the Extradution Treaty. The prisoner, however, was discharged from arrest on the 25th August, by Justice SMITH, of the Superior Court.

The steamship Jason, Capt. CARTER, of the Atlantic Royal Mail Steam Navigation Company's NewYork and Galway Line, from Galway, on the 20.h inst., parsed this point this afternoon en route to NewYork, where she will be about due on Saturday evening next.

THE FINANCIAL CONDITION OF THE GOVERNMENT By the arrival at Boston of the brig Million, from Port-au-price we are place in possession of out usual Haytt files to July 30. The Government had published a complete exposition of its financial affaire. By this it appears that the Government has a reserve fund of 124,00o plasters.

The steamship Jason, of the New York Galway line, with two days' later advices from Europe--she having left always y on the 20thpassed Cape Race yesterday afternoon, and was boarded by the news-yacht of the Associated Press. The Jason will probably arrive at this port on Saturday.

First--It is false that there ever was firm in Cincinnati under the style of DIM, LANODON HAW as engaged in publishing a detector, or in any other business.

Political matters remain tranquil, Nothing, in fact, has transpired in the past month worthy of note. To the Editor of the New-York Times: "Herod in our Homes" is not a myth. Our sanitary officers all receive their commissions from his majesty King Herod, and hold them on the conditions that the slaughter of children and fools shall never fall below a certain standard, which has been for the past seven years annually one cut of every twenty seven of the good, easy going people of this City.

THE GENERAL ADMIRAL AND HER BUILDER.--From a recent letter from St. Petersburgh, we learn that a public dinner was given to WILLIAM H. WEBB, Esq., on the 28th of July, at the residence of the American Consul, by the American residents in Russia, Speeches highly commendatory of the American ship-builder were made, and toasts drunk in bumpers of champagne, by some thirty or forty gentlemen who sat down to the dinner.

According to dispatches received at the Navy Department, from the United States ship Saratoga, dated the 13th inst., Minister McLANE was passing the Summer at the City of San Andreas, and would return to Vera Cruz on the 1st of September.

In reference to the Overland Mail routes, the Washington Star deems it proper to state, as there is such a strong prejudice existing against the continuance of the routes costing $1,000,000 annually, with scarcely any return, that it is the desire of the Postmaster-General to have them abolished, and that he would long since have applied the principle of retrenchment in this pardeuist had he not been prevented by a decision of the Attorney-General.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: It was the prayer meeting, but one of more than ordinary interest to those accustomed weekly to assemble for prayer in the lecture-room of the Old North Reformed Dutch Church.

WIFE MURDER IN LEBANON, CONN--The Norwich (Conn) Bulletin states that a man named CHAS STARK, of Lebanon, residing in a houses in the woods, about one mile from any other dwelling murdered his wife some time during Monday night or Tuesday morning. ARK was discovered on Tuesday Fore.

We learn from Commander CARR, of the Navy yard, that the rumor that the frigate Congress had been lost, contained in a morning contemporary, is without foundation. The vessel left our naval station a few weeks since for the Brazil station, as the flag ship, and at last accounts was doing admirably, and all on board were enjoying excellent health.

Before Justice Davies A FORGETFUL SHERIFF. O. S. Leland vs. C. W. Daniels impleaded, summons and complaint in this case were served by a Deputy Sheriff of Steuoen County, who returned a certificate that they were served on the 23d of June. An answer was served on the 14th of July, but the plaintiff refused to receive it, and entered judgment as for default.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The accompanying letter from Professor HOESFORD, of Cambridge University was received yesterday morning. His eminent professional standing and his great practical experience in this particular subject will. I think, render his communication a most interesting paper at this time, corroborating as it does, the views of our own Professors COUTOD and TORREY.

KEMP -- In this City, on Wednesday, Aug, 31, after a long illness, from teething and water on the brain, SARAH LUCRESYIA, youngest daughter of Jeremiah G. and Mercy Ann Kemp aged 1 year, 4 months and 2 days. The friends and relatives are invited to attend her funeral, without any further notice, this (Thursday) afternoon at 3 o'clock from the residence of her parents, No. 88 Budson St., corner of Harrison St.

One after another the several States of our American Confederacy elect their Governors, members of Legislature, and officials of lower grades. Among the Austrian prisoners at Paris at this moment (says the Court Journal) is one belonging to a regiment which claims a singular privilege--that of ?? for three cavs, whenever they pass through Vienna, in the Court of the Emperor, and of receiving the most regal entertainment.

Mr. Koch, English Consul at Frankfort-on-the-Maine, cied recently, aged 82, Mr. Koch was profoundly versed in European politics, and enjoyed the personal friendship of the late Sir Robert Peel and many other leading statesmen, who entertained high respect for his diplomatic knowledge and experience. He was also honored by marks of esteem from George IV and his successors.

We have received per the schooner A. C. Brcuer, from Port.au-Prince, the Fettille du Commerce of Aug. 13. At that date business in Port-au-Prince conunued dull. During the week five vessels had arrived and four had sailed.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In your paper of yesterday I noticed an article entitled " The fees of Referees," in which Ex-Judge COWIES is substantially charged with extortion in regard to Referee fees. Since my retirement from the bench of the Marine Court I have directed much of my time to the bearing and decision of Reference cases.

The latest news from Mexico, published in our impression of yesterday, is less unfavorable to the Liberal cause than we were led to expect by previous advices. It is an encouraging piece of intelligence, that Mr. OTWAY, the British Minister, has received instructions to put the business of the Legation into the hands of his secretary, Mr. MATHEWS, and return to England without delay.

The British Association for the Advancement of Science holds its anniversary meetings this year at Aberdeen. The first meeting will be opened by the Prince Consort, as President of the Society on the 14th of September ; and His Roval Highness has, we understand, expressed his intention of being present curing the business of the first two days.

Two years ago the City resounded with protestations against tile impropriety of allowing the choice of candidates for the Municipal Government, and above all for the Mayoralty, to be influenced by party politics. Everybody was then bewailing in sackcloth and ashes the evils which blind partisanship had brought on the City.

The following Communication has been addressed by Mr. HOADLEY. President of the Pacama Railroad Company, on his recent visit to England, whence he has just returned, to Mr. COBDEN. Chairman of the Packets' Contract Committee of the House of Commons:

We record, this morning, another long chapter of suicides. About a month since, we printed a list of twenty-six which had been committed within the then preceding fortnight. Those which we publish this morning have occurred during the month of August. They number twenty-seven instances in which life was actually taken, and twenty more unsuccessful attempts.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Will you permit me to make a slight correction of your report of the shooting affair in the First Ward, on Wednesday night--viz.: It was Officers KOULER and BRYAN who were "quickly on hound," having heard the report of the pistol from their respective beats, and while assisting the wounded man into a drug store, learned from himself the name of the party (HAYS) who shot him.

The schooner Neptune's Bride arrived in this port yesterday from a port in North Carolina, loaded with naval stores. She was hauled into the Atlantic Basin to Messrs. HAFF CO.;S wharf to unload. Upon removing the main hatch a horrible stench greeted the men who were at work on the vessel, and many were the conjectures as to the cause, but no one could solve the mystery as to what produced the disagreeable smell.

HE RECOMMENDS A UNION OF "THE OPPOSITIONS." On Thursday evening, a Committee from the Whig General Committee of this City, of which HIRAM KETCHUM is Chairman, waited upon the Hon. JOHN MINOR BOTTS, at the Astor House, to pay him the respects of the organization they represented. Mr. DAVID WEBB was Chairman.

The Royal Mail steamer Africa, Capt. SHANNON, from Liverpool at 1 1/2 o'clock on the afternoon of August 20, arrived at this port yesterday morning. Her news has been anticipated in outline by the telegram forwarded from the Jason at Cape Race. THE ZURICH CONFERENCE. The Conference at Zurich appears to be making no headway.

Porter's Spirit of this week contains the following correction: "The Vanderbuit, last Saturday, took out quite a large exportation of trotting stock, consisting of seven horses, in all-two Morgans, two pairs of Black Hawk geldings, and one Mambrino. They go to Europe on speculation, and not on consignment to H. I. M., the Emperor NAPOLEON."

DOMESTIC MARKETS. In New-York, during the past week, there has been more activity in Wool. The demand has been mole animated, from the trade and from manufacturers, The receipts have been decidedly less extensive, and the principal holders have not manifested any disposition to force their supplies on tile market.

ALDER--In this City, on Thursday. Sept 1, at No. 298 7th av., MARGARET MARY PATERSON. daughter of Thomas and Margaret Alder, aged 1 year, 7 months and 15 days. McDOWELL -In this City, on 3d day evening. 8th month, 38th, of congestion of the brain. HENRY, son of ?? T. and Isabella M. McDowell, aged 3 years, 5 months and 21 days.

The Vermont State Convention of Universatists has just concluded its annual session at Stowe. It was remarkable on many accounts and interesting to the highest degree. After hearing the various reports and transacting the usual business in the village, the whole assemblage adjourned for worship to the nose or summit of Mansfield Peak.

The Administration has recently taken upon itself to deny, in the most formal manner, the existence of such a scandalous thing as a Southern Slave-trade with Africa. At the same time the Northern officials of the Government have solemnly protested that no slave ships are, or have been, or could be, fitted out in the smaller Northern sea-ports.

I should not address you a line to-day except to tell you that there really is no news of importance from this aide of the Continent. Indeed it has been insufferably dull here during the last few days, so far as events are concerned. Our wharves, however, present a lively appearance, lined as they are with clippers discharging their cargoes of goods that we don't need and cannot consume for a long time to come.

Mr. SEWARD was in Rome on the 18th of August, and enjoying excellent health, in spite of the bad reputation of the Roman climate in the later Summer. As the distinguished Senator has gone to Europe "to study despotism," he will have an admirable opportunity in Rome of learning how despotism dies and free institutions struggle into being.

MONS EDITOR: Some friends have told me that a Mons. FOOLER, who was an American Colonel and was in the war of Italy, has made an attack at my hotel because I do not subscribe for a paper published by a M. GATTY, or GAYETTY, in New-York, I do not know if M. FOOLER is the editor of M. GAYETTY'S paper or not;

WILLIAMS, alias Heary Johnson, advertied in several Philsdephia for young ladies to go down to Montgomery, Ata. for the purpose of becoming teachers of Music in respectable Private families there. Lieutenant IVES, to whom the care of the National Monument to WASHINGTON, at the Federal Capital, has been confided, with the permission of the Secretary of War, has just ??sued a careful explanation of his object in suggesting that boxes for the collection of voluntary contributions from the people at ??rge, toward the completion of the work, should be set up in the various Post-offices of the United States.

ST. PETER'S CHURCH.--The corner-store of a new Roman Catholic church, to be called St. Peter's, will be laid to-morrow afternoon, at the corner of Hicks and Warren streets, with appropriate exercises. The Society has secured here a plot of land at the place named, with a front of 172 feet on Hicks-street, and extending back along Warren-street 95 feet.

FIRE IN SPRUCE-STREET--Between 5 and 6 o'clock yesterday afternoon a fire occurred on the fifth floor of the building No. 10 Spruce-street, in this hat factory of NASCIMETO Co. The fire was caused by defect in the furnace used for heating the items of for smoothing hats. It has extinguished by the firemen. The loss of NASCEMINTO CO. amounts to amount $500; insured in the St. Nicholas, Brevoort and Excelstor

The United States Mail steamer Quaker City, R. W. SHUFRLDT, Commander, from Havana Monday, August 29th, 5 P. M., arrived at Quarantine yesterday morning at 9 o'clock, with 53 passengers and $31,000 in Specie. There was no sickness on board. The health of Havana improving, with very little alarm felt among the residents.

The exhibition of the Aurora on Thursday night and Friday morning, exceeded in brilliancy that of last Sunday evening; but upon the last occasion it was chiefly confined to the southern heavens, and hence was more properly an Aurora Australis than an Aurora Borealis.

The Canadian screw-steamship North Briton, from Liverpool on the 24th ult., with tour days later European advices, is now about due at Quebec. THE BOOK TRADE-SALE.--The semi-annual Book Trade-sales are progressing at the rooms of GEORGE A. LEAVITT Co. On the first day's sale DEBBY JACKSON'S list was the most in demand. There were bid off 2,508 volumes of select fiction; 1,600 novels; miscellaneous, 2 305; British classics, 500; female novelists, 650. Wednesday PETERSON'S list was offered.

It is evident that this distinguished gentleman designs participating very actively in the coming Presidential canvas, and is already loud in his denunciations of the Federal Administration.

The return of Ex-President PIERCE to his home in New-Hampshire, to-day, called forth a lively display of friendly feeling. The Amoskeag Veterans, one hundred strong, proceeded in the morning to Nashua and received the Ex-President, who was accomparied by Mayor HARRINGTON and other distihguished citizens at the Depot. Here the crowd was very large and the welcome hearty and enthusiastic.

The ninety-first annual Commencement of Brown University will be held on Wednesday, 7. On Tuesday, the 6th, the biennial Address before E.q., of Providence, a graduate of the class of 1838. In the afternoon an Address will be delivered before the Philomenian and United Brothers' Society, by Col. E. G. PAEHER of Boston.

Tax payers who are inclined to grumble at the large amounts which they are called on to deposit in the City Treasury, should make the tour of Central Park semi-occasionally. There a million and a half of their funds are to be expended, yet, strange as it may teem, almost every visitor knows more of the beauties and my?? Of the Park than, New-Yorkers do themselves.

The clergymen having under their pastoral change the various denominational churches in this City and Brooklyn have, for the most part, returned from their respective trips into the country, whence it is their custom to repair during each Summer vacation, which embraces usually six or eight weeks previous to the 1st of September, and which is generally Improved by both pastors and congregations for recreation and improvement of health.

The people of New-York are gradually awakening to a sense of the really priceless possession which the Central Park bids fair to he to them and to " their heirs forever." Not a mere common, or play-ground, or loungingplace is preparing for us in this vast and beautiful public work, but a majestic breathingplace for the life of a great city, and an imperial domain of beauty, worthy the metronolis of the great Republic.

At the morning session of the Canal Convention, to-day, the following Committee on Business and Resolution was appointed: Ansel Bascomb, of Seneca; S. P. Hunt of Erie: Thomas J. Flagler, of Niagara; W. T. Holmes of Monreo; L. B Crocker, of Oswego; H. O'Rielley, of New-York; Thomas Kempshad, of Rochester.

Notwithstanding a definite announcement made by the Company which owns the Great Eastern, to the effect that the great ship will certainly make her first Transatlantic voyage from Holyhead to Portland, some doubts still exist as to her destination upon this side of the Atlantic. Mr. JOHN O. LEVER early in the last month proposed to charter the monster for his Galway line.

The new Minot's Ledge Lighthouse has obtained a height of sixty feet, being two thirds of its intended altitude. The waves are said to have twice dashed over the structure in the course of last week, a fact which is claimed as a good reason for suspending the work for the season. Yesterday, says the Courier.

SUPPOSED CHILD-MURDER. - We mentioned yesterday that the body of a male infant had been found on Thursday in the East River, at the foot of Twentieth-street. An investigation of the matter was yesterday made by coroner JACKMAN, which resulted in the showing of suspicious circumstances. A poet mortem examination of the body disclosed the fact that the child has been born alive, and that death had been caused by suffocation.

The Railroad interest has blundered a premature charge upon the Canals. Mr. BROCKWAY'S paper, pronouncing the Canals too slow for this fast age, and the whole system a broken-backed concern, which has seen its best days, was published a month too early.

EAGLE, OF NEW YORK, VS. PASTIME, OF BROOKLYN. This match was played on Friday at the Elysian Fields, Hoboken. The Pastimes commenced the game with much spirit, and for several innings they kept handsomely in advance of the Eagles, but the latter, nothing daunted, went resolutely to work, and turning the tables, secured a handsome victory.

The steamship Arago, from Southampton on the 24th u!t., with European advices four days later, passed Cape Race on Saturday at 1 o'clock P. M. (as stated by the dispatch, though the date is probably wrong,) and will reach this port on Tuesday or Wednesday. No political news is telegraphed. The Liverpool Cotton market is reported dull, though with unchanged quotations.

The Convention of the friends of the canals adjourned, last evening, to meet, at Utica again, on the 28th instant, when arrangements will be made for arousing the public attention, and especially the attention of business men and tax-payers, to the great importance of the measures they seek to speedily accomplish--to call forth such an expression from the peoples as neither the candidates before, nor the Legislature after election, will dare to disregard.

The Aurora which occurred on Thursday night produced effects much more remarkable than those of the previous Sunday night. The auroral currents were Aufficiently powerful on Thursday to enable the telegraphic operators at Portland to transmit messages to Boston without resorting, to the use of the battenes; and similar phenomena were observed at Pittsburgh.

The Apaches are again committing depredations in this vicinity. A Mexican, employed by the Sonora Exploring and Mining Company, at the Arivass Ranch, was hot by an Apache at 2 o'clock this morning. A horse picketed about twenty feet from the door was taken. Mr. JARVIS' horse has been missing several days, and, doubtless, is in the hands of the Indians.

Detroit papers notice the death of Major Jonathan Kearsley, formerly of the Army, and for many years Receiver of Public Moneys in the Michigan Land Office. He held the latter office under all the Aministrations from Monroe to Polk. He died at the age of 74. The unexpected death (says a Paris letter) of Lord Henry Seymour is the topic in many circles.

Small thanks await any body of "free and independent electors" which presumes to distrust the predestined arrangements and foreordained balance of great political parties. The voter's right to his vote, in the popular apprehension, is like the soldier's right to his legs.

When it was known that the work in the public stores had been given out by contract, there was great fear among the laborers who had heretofore been employed in the stores by the United States Government, that they would be discharged by the contractors.

There has been one gain achieved by the campaign in Italy, which, if nothing else follows, one can hardly help setting down as worth a good deal of bloodshed and a great many lives. Lombardy contains, at a moderate calculation, 3,000,000 of people-or a population equal to that ot the United States when they asserted their independence of English rule ;

THE STREET-PREACHER'S LICENSE REVOKED BY THE RECORDER--HIS COMMITTAL TO THE TOMES.--A man calling himself EDWARD FALCONEE has for some weeks past annoyed the citizens who dwell or perambulate in the vicinity of the City Hall, by street preaching on Sunday. His harangues have uniformly caused a disturbance, and he has been several times arrested. His pulpit or platform was generally the steps of the City Hall or the Court Records.

During the past six months various attempts having been made to throw trains off the western division of the Ohio and Mississippi Railroad, the officers of the road made application to Mayor BISHOP for assistance in discovering the scoundrels guilty of the ??farious attempts. The Mayor accordingly sent Detective READY to Vincennes and St. Louis, to trace up, If ??ossio??e, the Vitlains, believing that, with his varied experience, he might prove successful in the search.

The pluck of Tammany is greatly to be admired. It has incense for its gods, but when its gods tamper with the spoils that it has been accustomed to enjoy, it grows itself incensed and talks up to their face with refreshing plainness and energy. During the past week Mr. COBB has made this discovery to his mortification and annoyance.

The United States Mail steamship Arago, Capt. LINES, from Havre and Southampton 24th of August, passed Cape Race at one o'clock this afternoon. The screw steamship Anglo-Saxon, from Quebec, arrived at Liverpool on the 23d of August. We have received no political news by this arrival We are inclined to think the dispatch has been un intentionally misdated, and that the Arago passed Cape Race on the 2d.]

Before Justice Slosson. PORTER'S SPIRIT OF THE TIMES IN COURT. Abraham C. Dayton vs. George Wilkes,--This was the return of the order to show cause why a permanent injuction should not issue restraining the defendant from interfering with the paper called Porter's Spirit of the Times.

An investigation into the cause of death of JOSEPH SOHADE, an English youth, 19 yearn of age, who was billed on Friday afternoon by the explosion of a boiler in the foundry of Mr. JOHN ROACU, in Goerckstreet, was made yesterday by Coroner JACKMAN. The proceedings were held at the Eleventh Precinct Police Station, and were largely attended by boller-makers and engineers, who evinced much interest in the matter.

Politics In Kentucky. The Hen. BERTHA MAGOFFIN, just elected Governor of Kentucky, was inaugurated on the 30th August. MAGOFFIN defended the Administration in the course of his inaugural address, holding the following language:

To the Editor of the New-York Times : A few suggestions as to the course necessary for the New-York Insurance Companies to save themselves and the insured from utter ruin may not be amiss, in waking up the insured and stockholders to a true sense of their duty in this trying emergency. The Companies should organize again upon a fair basis, and have a complete set of rules for their government.

The Republican State Convention meets on Tuesday next at Syracuse, and the Democrats at the same place precisely a week later. Neither party can afford to lose the State this Fall, as the prestige of victory for the Presidential campaign will reside with the party that conquers now.

IMPORTANT TO TRAVELERS.--The New-York Central Railroad have given notice to all Western roads that on and after Sept. I they will not receive any tickets that are over fifteen days old, and, further, that they will refuse all tickets that are not properly dated and signed by the agent selling them.

A very interesting meeting of the above named Association was held at the Cooper Institute on Thursday evening last. In the absence of the President, the Vice-President was called to the Chair The attendance of members was not very large, in consequence of the absence of many of them from the City.

Coroner SCHIEMER held an inquest yesterday at the New-York Hospital upon the body of an Irishman, 23 years of age, named EDWARD KELLY, who was admitted into that Institution on Wednesday night last, suffering from a pistol-shot wound in the abdomen, the ball having penetrated the bladder and passed behind the prostrate gland.

Mexico in undoubtedly one of the finest cities every built by Europeans in either hemisphere.

After a thorough examination here, by Lord LYONS, of the coast trade question, the issue made by the British Government with ours, as mentioned in Parliament, has been withdrawn. The Light-House Board has received information from Commander De Camp, Inspector of Lights on the Pacific Coast, that the steamer Shubrick is anchored off Port ??, Washington Territory, for the Protection of the adjacent coast against incursions of the Northern Indians, who are again becoming troublesome.

At the meeting of the Health Commissioners on Friday, all the members were present. Dr. GUNN reported the arrival of the bark American Eagle from Havana. The captain and one sailor had died at Havana of yellow fever; three more of the crew were taken sick at that port, and one died on the passage to New-York. It was directed that the vessel be detained fifteen days in the Lower Bay.

Mr. LEWIS CLEPHANE, a gentleman who, by his use of the mystic syllables, "Secretary Nat, Repub. Ass." would appear to write himself down an ass, has a serious grievance. His memorial may be read elsewhere in this paper.

Sundry influential citizens of Plymouth, who are not disposed to acquiesce In the site selected for the Pilgrim Monument in the northern section of that town, have recently held private meetings with the view of erecting another monument on Barylog Hill.

THE ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--The preparations for the coming season at the Academy go bravely for ward. The handsome subscription of $20,000 raised by the Stockholders to enable Mr. ULLMAN to purchase new and effective properties has been most judiciously laid out.

The case of Mrs. HARTUNG was to be called up to day, on a bill of exceptions, before the General Term of the Supreme Court, but it has gone over the Court not having been able to dispose of the motions which have precedence.
