To the Editor of the New-York Times: The United States steamer Sumpter, under the command of Lieutenant-Commanding JAS. F. ARMSTRONG, left this port this morning. The storeship Supply, under the command of Commander W. WALKE, left the Navy-yard on Saturday, but came to anchor to the Lower Bay, and is new going out with us.

ANOTHER INDIAN BATTLE ON THE PLAINS. The St. Joseph (Mo.) Journal, Aug. 30, says: On the 13th inst., a band of the Brule Sioux came upon and attacked a band of the Poncas while the larger were encamped on the banks of the Running Water, After a brief but desperate engagement,

In my last I referred to an order brought by a person-understood to be a horse-dealer--for the sale of 3,000 mules belonging to the Utah command. This order was said to be accompanied by another directing commanders of posts along the route to furnish relays of horses to the bearer.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: What Washington is to the political world in the Winter, the White Sulphur is in the Summer visiting season. Here gather all shades of Southern politicians, and one can get no better idea of the temper and tone of the political feeling of the South than by an interchange of opinion with the habitues of this spot.

CITY GOLD DIGGINS.--While the Board of Supervisors are quarreling over the Tax Levy, it may be interesting to the people who have to bear the burden of that annual imposition to know how some of the items which help to swell its grand total came to be included in it.

A paragraph published in yesterday morning's Gazette, in reference to the kidnapping of a negro boy, who was legally free and a resident of this city, created considerable stir yesterday among some of our citizens.

The mania for strikes has been revived, with the addition of violent acts. The Detroit papers of the 3d state that all the men employed on the Michigan Southern Railroad are on a strike; that they hare stopped the trains on the road, and refuse to return to work until they receive the back pay due them.

The morning papers contain a statement to the effect that an Imperial act has just been passed which will allow deals and butter, the produce of Canada and shipped from Portland, to enter Great Britain at the same rates as if shipped from a colonial port.

Ex-President PIERCE met an enthusiastic welcome on his return to his New-Hampshire home on Friday, Sept 2. On his way to Nashua, Gen. PIERCE received very complimentary tokens of public favor at Lawrence. Lowell, Manchester and Concord.

Robberies of the mails have become frequent occurrences, showing a faulty management somewhere on the great mail routes. The latest important arrest was effected in San Antonio, Texas, on the 10th August.

The world has long been aware that doctors will sometimes differ, and that it is not easy to say who shall decide the questions on which they disagree. But we venture to say that, from the days of ESCULAPIUS to those of HABNEMANN, no such doctoral dissensions have been known among the diplomats of any Faculty as appear to flourish among the learned physicians of New-Orleans.

THE SUPPOSED MURDER IN THE NINTH WARD.--An investigation was entered into yesterday by Coronor HORTON, to ascertain by what means JOHN REANY came to his death. At an early hour last Sunday morning, the deceased was found fatally injured on Pacific-street. He was taken home by the Polics, where he died during the day.

Senator BRODERICK made his "great effort " of the campaign at Sacramento on Tuesday evening last. A party of over 600 admirers chartered a steamboat for that especial occassion, and went up to the meeting (some 120 miles distant) with music and banners. The speech was an utter failure,

PROGRESS OF THE SURVEYS--INDIAN HOSTILITIES. The General Land Office has received returns of the progress of the boundary survey in Daoolah Territory. The main lines of the survey constitute bases for the sub divisional work in that part of the surveying district of Wisconsin and Iowa which, upon the organization of the State of Minnesota, was not embraced within its limits.

Base Ball. MANIIATTAN VS. BALTIC. This game was played on Tuesday, upon the grounds of the Manhattan Club, Sixty-first-street and Third. avenue. The game was won by the Manhattan Club. The Manhattan Club has been very fortunate, having lost but few matches since their formation.

ANTI-RENT DISTURBANCE IN COLUMBIA COUNTY.--Another anti-rent difficulty occurred in Columbia county, in this State, on Tuesday. August 30. The Deputy Sheriff, with a posse, proceeded to a house in Tagakanie, occupied by one PETER FINKLE, who had dispossessed a man named MALLORY. FINKLE had previously been ejected from this house, and MALLORY was placed in possession.

THE COLLIER FOLIO SHAKESPEARE--The Duke of DROVENSHIRE, its owner, has withdrawn the famous COLLIER folio from the British Museum, and has placed it in the hands of his solicitor for safe keeping, Such was the excitement which the question raised as to the good faith of Mr. COLLIER and the corrector of the folio had created, that the Duke thought it best to have the volume under his own eye.

THE NEW MEXICAN TREATY.--Public expectation, in supposing that Mr. McLANE had brought home a ratification of our new treaty with Mexico, has been premature. Our Washington correspondent telegraphs to-day that the State Department has received no communication from Mr. McLANE on the subject-an omission which would not certainly have occurred if any important intelligence had to be revealed.

THE MAYOR INTERFERES WITH A PROJECT OF THE NINTH AVENUE RAILROAD COMPANY.--The Common Council, not long ago, as our readers know, passed a resolution authorizing the Ninth-avenue Railroad Company to run their cars on the tracks of the Sixth and Eighth avenue, and Hudson River Railroad Companies, provided it was permitted so to do by those Corporations.

THE MAGDALEN ISLANDS.--The Toronto Colonist says that the Provincial Government has issued a proclamation regulating the holding of a Circuit Court st Amhet Habor, in the Magoalen Islands, Gulf of St. Lawrence. These Islands have been much neglected, to the great dissatisfaction of the inhabitants, who were disposed to look to New-Bruns wick for the encouragement and sympathy which they failed to receive at the hands of Canada.

Why WILLIAM A. WHEELER Was nominated President is a profound puzzle. He presided capitally, and the Convention was delighted with his election. His speech was eloquent, "rode the fence" admirably, and was loudly applauded on both sides. JAMES KELLY, Chairman of the Nominating Committee, urged Gen. NYE for the post. Others named SPINNER, of Herkimer; but quietly the majority said WHEELER.

IN AUGURATION OF THE WEBSTER STATUE--The inauguration of the WEBSTER statue, on the 17th of the present month, will be one of the most interesting occasions of the year. It occurring on the anniversary o the settlement of Boston, the day will be made a holiday throughout the city. the schools, banks, , will be closed, and the day devoted, as it should be, in a general celebration.

There were anxious hearts on the steamer Connecticut and in Norwich Monday evening. Clouds covered the sky, a chill northeast wind for stold a settled storm, and the good, people of this substantial city and made up their minds to celebrate the two hundredth anniversary of the settlement of their town under circumstances the most unauspicious.

The Republican State Convention adjourned soon after 2 o'clock this morning, having completed, its work to the satisfaction of all. That is saying a good deal, bet excepting always the disappointed candidates themselves, I have seen none who do not profess perfect resignation to it, and all agree that if the State cannot be carried with this ticket, the men are not to be named by whom it could.

We have an exciting rumor, this morning, to the effect that the British war steamer Satellite has bombarded the United States military station recently established upon San Juan Island. The story comes in a round about way, and is probably false.

An experiment in scientific Ballooning, greater than has yet been undertaken, is about to be tried in this City. The project of crossing the Atlantic Ocean with an Air-ship, long talked of but never accom plished, has taken a shape so definite that the apparatus is already prepared and the aeronaut ready to undertake his task.

BODY FOUND.---Yesterday the body of a man was taken out of the water at the foot of Forty-fifth street, Gowanus, which had apparently been in the water several weeks. The deceased was apparently about 35 years old, five feet nine inches high, dark hair and whiskers on chin.

RETURN TO BUENOS AYRES OF THE NAVAL EXPEDITION, WITH THE LOSS OF A STEAMER--THE FIRST BLOOD OF THE CONFLICT--THE AMERICAN MINISTER FIRED AT. By the arrival at this port of the bark O. J. Hayes, Capt. SHIVERICK, we have advices from Buenos Ayres to July 15. The Buenos Ayrean steamers,

THE CASE OF THE SUPPOSED SLAVER AT NEW BEDFORD.--The New-Bedford Mercury announces that the bark Atlantic, which was seized by the United States Government as she was upon the point of sailing from that port, on the charge of being fitted for a slave voyage, was on Thursday released from custody.

Lieut. JUNIUS WHEELER, now in the Topographical Corps of the United States army in Oregon, has been appointed Assistant Professor in the Military Academy of West Point. Major R. B. LEE, Subsistence Department, has been directed to proceed, after the settlement of his accounts at the Treasury, to the City of Baltimore, and take post there.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Will you be kind enough to correct an error due to the English Press, and repeated in this country, as regards the Belgian Chamber? The project for the fortifications of Antwerp was not voted by 757 to 42, because there are only 108 Deputies in Belgium, consequently you must read 57 to 42.

At an early hour yesterday morning the Harmonia Hotel in Hudson-street, Hoboken, was discovered to be on fire. The alarm was given, and the firemen and others soon succeeded in subduing the flames. The building was then entered and examined

Before Justice Davies. PRACTICE.--FILING SECURITY NUNG PRO TUNG. The Tyrone and Lock Haven Railroad vs. Allen Schenck.--This was the argument on the return of the order to show cause why the proceedings of plaintiff should not be dismissed as irregular, on the ground that he had not filed the requisite bonds before commencing the suit, as provided by statute in regard to actions brought by foreign corporations.

The exhibition of French and English pictures by contemporary artists, which took place here two years since, must have been sufficiently successful to induce the artists interested in it to repeat the experiment.

SLIGHTLY ASTONISHED.--Our dilapidated neighbor, the Herald, seems to have been somewhat astonished by the publication in Thursday's TIMES of a verbatim report of Senator DOUGLAS' speech, delivered the day before a thousand miles away.

PLAYING WITH EDGED TOOLS.--Two enterprising gentlemen of London, famous in the small world of facetious literature, Mr. GEORGE AUGUSTUS SALA, the "double" or "fetch" of DICKENS in the Household Words, and Mr. EDMUND YATES,

The candidates of the Republican and Democratic Parties, Messrs. PARROTT and JOHNSON, are about to stump Eastern Kansas together, going into every settlement, and discussing before the people the questions at issue in the approaching election for delegates to Congress. They will hold joint meetings, after the style of DOUGLAS and LINCOLN in Illinois, last year.

SHOPLIFTERS.--Two middle-aged women named Mary Morgan and Mary Graham, both residents of Brooklyn, yesterday morning went into the tailor's establishment of Francis B. Baldwin, No. 70 Bowery, and examined some vest patterns on the pretence of purchasing.

HUMPHRIES.--In this City, on Wednesday, Sept. 7, Mrs. JANE HUMPHRIES, widow of the late John Humphries, in the 94th year if her age. Her friends and acquaintances are respectfully invited to attend her funeral, from the house of William Kemp, No. ?? West 23d-st., near 8th-av., on Saturday, Sept, 10, at 2 o'clock P. M.

The three parties which contend for empire in New-Jersey have just completed the list of their candidates for gubernatorial honors. It stands thus: Democratic. Republican. American. E. V. R. WRIGHT, CHAS. S. OLDEN, PETER I. CLARK. The nominations appear to be regarded as the most available the several conventions could have selected.

The R. M. steamship Europa arrived at Boston at 11 o'clock A. M., yesterday, and her mails, forwarded in the afternoon train over the New Haven Railroad,reached this City at midnight. We are thus placed in possession of details of the news, a telegraphic abstract of which we published in yesterday morning's TIMES.

ARREST OF A WEST POINT CADET.--A few days ago Mr. ALEXANDER ROBERTSON, of No. 93 Fulton-street, in this City, applied to Recorder BAENAED for a warrant for the arrest of one of the West Point Cadets, whose name was then unknown to Mr. RODIRTSON, but who, he subsequently learned, was JOHN II. KELLY, upon a charge of assault and battery.

COMMERCIAL CHANGE IN HAYTI.--The Government of Hayti has heretofore charged on coffee the export duty of one-fifth in kind-" du einquiems"--levied on the article for the benefit of the Emperor's Treasury. This odious impost has been abolished and the substitution of a uniform export duty of one and three-fourths (81 75) per, 100 pounds.

To the Editor of the New-York Times : A Committee for the erection of a National monument n Philadelphia have, by advertisement, called upon the artists and architects of the country to contribute designs for the work; or, what is more arduous, to lick into shape the absurdities of the Committee for a great national architectural raffle.

MELANCHOLY SUICIDE OF AN AMERICAN MERCHANT IN ENGLAND.--We regret to state that Mr. HERSHEY STOWELL, Jr., American merchant, of Cross-street, committed suicide yesterday, under distressing circumstances, by hanging himself. An inquest was held upon the body yesterday afternoon, before Mr. HEREFORD, City Coroner, when Mr. ALFRED FLOCKTON, clerk to the deceased,

" Viator," weary of Newport frivolities, resolved to try before the advent of the sober Autumn a month's change of air and scene. Extremes meet, and the transit therefore from fogs and fashion to country homespun and dy upland breezes was both easy and natural.

LESLIE, the swindler of the fifteen music teachers, arrived in this city, from Washington, last night, under escort of Special officer SCHLEMM. The people of the State of New-York, being formally interrogated at the general election in November last, whether or no they desired a Convention to revise and amend the Constitution, answered deliberately and emphatically in the negative.

The Royal Mail steamship Europa arrived at Boston from Halifax at 11 o'clock yesterday forenoon, and her malls, which were forwarded in the 3 o'clock train over the New-Haven Railroad, reached this City at midnight. The lateness of the hour at which our packages are received will not permit of copious extracts, but we give below such details as seem to be more immediately demanded by their importance.

Much annoyance is felt here, both by the English Legation and the Secretary of State, at the recent news from San Juan; the relations of the two Governments having lately become most cordial and friendly. It is hoped the good sense of both Powers may prevent any serious mischief in the premises.

On Wednesday of next week, the 14th inst., the Democratic Party will hold its State Convention in the City of Syracuse. The list of delegates embraces many experienced leaders, men who have figured at similar gatherings on many former occasions.
Of all the swindles palmed upon the country by the present Administration, the famous Utah expedition and the " pacification" of that ungodly Territory may be fairly regarded as a crowning iniquity.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Some weeks since a paragraph headed, "A Female in Male Clothing" appeared in the TIMES, in which I was charged with having enticed a young girl away from her home in Somerset, Pa., and employed her (in male clothing) as an equestrian and tumbler for some years, ,

The banking office of Messrs. SMITH HALE of this place was robbed last night of between $4,000 and $5,000--$700 in gold, and the remainder in currency and checks. The rogues gained admission by cutting a panel out of the door, after which they destroyed the lock of the safe, apparently by means of a hammer and chisel.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In your editorial this morning in reference to the Republican State ticket, you class CHARLES IIUGHES as "formerly a Whig." This is a mistake, Mr. H. was a Democrat up to 1818, when he espoused the cause of Mr. VAN BUREN.

THE GREAT INTERNATIONAL CRICKET MATCH--THE ALL ENGLAND ON THEIR WAY TO AMERICA. Wilkes' Spirit of the Times, for the present week, states that "there is no longer any doubt about the visit of the crack cricket players of England to Canada and the United States. They are already on their way, and may be expected to arrive at Montreal within a week.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: On the 12th of last month you copied from the Leeds Mercury, England, an "Appeal from two hundred and thirty-eight Methodist Ministers" in this country, to their brethren in England, upon the subject of Slavery.

The people of Baltimore are making an effort to redeem their city from the despotism of ruffians. We hope they will succeed-not merely for their own sake, but for the encouragement such a result would give other cities to imitate their example.

A COLORED MAN STABS HIS FATHER-IN-LAW. Last evening a negro attempted to kill his fatherin-law. The story of the affair is that some six years since, an old colored man married a widow woman tamed JACHSON, and the marriage was not very agreeableto the relatives of the woman, especially to a sonnamed JOHN JACKSON, who is represented to be a desperate fellow, and particularly so when under the influence of liquor.

The most remarkable dramatic success of the season has been Mrs. BATEMAN'S tragedy of "Geraldine," at Wallack's Theatre. It has been played every night since its first production, and it will be continued until the closing of the Theatre on Wednesday night. MATILDA HERON, who personates the heroine, takes her benefit to-night.

The Coroner's inquest in the case of the four persons who were suffocated in the fire at the Harmonia Hotel, Hoboken, on Friday last, was concluded on Saturday afternoon. The deposition of MARY BAESE, the eldest daughter of deceased, was taken by Coroner POHNSTEDT, and embraces all the particuJars of the sad affair, so far as she witnessed them. She says:

THE COMPTROLLER'S OFFICE ENLARGED ARD REPAIRED.--The old Comptroller's office refitted and repaired, and with the addition of the apartment which was formerly the offices of the Street Commissioner, now occupying the whole of the second story of the Hall of Records, will be reopened for the transaction of business to-day.

BRITISH RIGHTS IN BRITISH HONDURAS.--An incident has just occurred which tends to strengthen public confidence in the present conduct of the Foreign Office with respect to the preservation of British interests in Central America. The rights of Spain in the continent of America were those of conquest. The true test of conquest is permanent occupancy. Territory never occupied, never belonged to Spain.

A REGISTRY LAW IN MICHIGAN.--New-York is not the only State in which a Registry takes effect, for the first time this Fall. The Legislature of Michigan passed a Registry Law last Winter, which unlike ours is one not only nominally but also in fact, inasmuch as it provides that no person shall be permitted to vote unless his name shall have been previously placed upon the registration list, as that of an approved elector.

ARRAIGNMENT OF STEPHEN D. DILLAYE, AT PITTSBURGH, FOR UTTERING FORGED PAPER--HE IS HELD IN $2,000 BAIL FOR TRAIL. The Pittsburgh Commercial Journal, Sept. 9. states that the hearing of STEPHEN A. DELAYE, of New-York, on a charge of uttering forged paper in order to secure stock in the Monongeheh Valley Bank of Pennsylvania, took place in that city, before Mayor WEAVER, on Thursday.

FELLOW CITIZENS OF CINCINNATI: There seems to be a fatality accompanying my attempts to address you on the great political topics of the day. Four years ago, when I came here for the purpose of addressing you, I was attacked with disease of the throat, which deprived me of the opportunity of being heard, and confined me to my room for many months.

GASSNER.--In this City, on Friday, Sept, 9, PETER GASSNER, in the 76th year of his age. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, from his late residence, No. 207 West 14th-st., this day, (Monday,) Sept. 12, at 2 o'clock. BRITTON.--In this City. on Saturday morning, Sept. 10, JANE BRITTON, wife of Capt. John Britton.

Opening of Eighty-ninth, Ninetieth, and Ninety-first streets.--The motion to confirm the award of the Commissioners of Assessments, in the matter of opening these streets from Third-avenue to Harlem River, came up, but the papers on the part of the Corporation not being redy, the matter was postponed to the 26th inst. GENESEE, N. Y., Saturday, Sept. 10. RANDALL REED was this day elected delegate to the Democratic State Convention

BREAKING UP RAPIDLY.--Poor old BENNETT is certainly going to the dogs as fast as possible. We never knew a wreck on a lee shore break up more rapidly than his crazy old Herald. The last Summer has been specially hard on him.

The Vanderbilt steamer Ocean Queen, from Havre on the 31st ult., and Cowes on the morning of the 1st inst., passed Cape Race on Saturday morning, and will be due at this port on Wednesday. She was boarded off the Cape by the newsyacht of the Associated Press, and a short telegraphic abstract of her news, which is four days later than the Europa's, will be found in this morning's TIMES.

THE RENSSELAER COUNTY GRAND JURY.--The grand inquest of the County of Rensselaer, recently in session at the City of Troy, refused to find an indictment for manslaughter against WHITE, the President and Superintendent of the Albany, Vermont and Canada Railroad.
The Vanderbilt steamship Ocean Queen, Capt. SEABURY, from Havre vid Cowes, passed Cape Race at 5 o'clock this (Saturday) morning, on her way to New-York, where she will be due on Wednesday next.

Senator GWIN, of California, publishes a long "statement," addressed to the people of California, in reply to the charge that he attained his election to the United States Senate by selling out the Federal patronage to DAVID C. BRODERICK. Mr. GWIN charges home upon BRODERICK with accusations of falsehood, deceit and hypocrisy.

Sam Slick, it is painful to see, is quite unable to separate his facts from the herd of thickcoming fancies which have rendered his name famous. His recent English experiences have furnished various apt illustrations of this peculiarity; and, indeed, he seems to regard himself as an accepted authority on cis-Atlantic manners,

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In your paper, of the 6th, I notice the following: "At Albany the striking iron molders, who have stood out for higher wages for nearly a month, are committing disgraceful outrages upon obnoxious workmen who prefer to continue working at low prices." The gives a false impression of the question, and also does injustice to a large body of worthy men.

Mr. DOUGLAS is a bold politician,--and he is playing a bold and a hazardous role. He has entered seriously and deliberately upon the task of compelling the Southern Democrats to nominate him for the Presidency. His speeches in Ohio are the opening blows in this crusade.

ROWDYSIM.--ONE MAN STABBED.--Between 10 and 11 o'clock Saturday night, three rowdies entered a saloon at No. 309 Atlantic, near Smith-street, and after eating and drinking they started to leave without paying for what they had had. Upon tile proprietor remonstrating with them for scuh treatment, they made an assault upon him and broke a portion of the furniture anti crockery belonging to the premises.

ARRIVAL AT MONROVIA OF THE BARK MENDI--RECEPTION OF THE EMIGRANTS--TRADE--STAFF OF THE COUNTRY--DR. DELANEY. The arrival of the bark James W. Page, from Monrovia, furnishes Liberia advices to July 29. The bark Mendi, which left New-York early in June, with a large number of emigrants, arrived out about the middle of July, and was received with great rejoicing.

CITY MORTALITY.--The City Inspector reports 472 as the number of deaths in this City, during the week ending on Saturday last, which is a decrease of 101 as compared with the mortality of the previous week; and as compared with the corresponding week of last year a decrease of 112. Of those who died, 107 were men: 84 women; 189 boys and 178 girls.

THE GREAT EASTERN.--We learn by private advices from London that Mr. J. SCOTT RUSSELL, the builder of The Greal Eastern, is to come out in her on her first trip to America. Great numbers of tickets have been sold, and for her trial trip to Cherbourg, which was to take place on the Sth, an immense number of places had been taken.

The screw steamship Anglo-Saxon, from Liverpool on the 31st of August, reached Quebec yesterday. The prominent traits of her news have been anticipated, by a telegram from the Ocean Queen, off Cape Race. The crew of the ship Ben Bolt, already reported as lost, had all been saved. The vessel was proceeding from Trieste to London when tile catastrophe occurred.

THE POPULAR SOVEREIGNTY QUESTION.--The Constitution of Saturday publishes a reply to Senator DOUGLAS' views on Popular Sovereignty.--filling six columns of that paper, and understood to be from the pen of the Attorney General. Judge BLACK. It is clear in its style, temperate in tone and exceedingly forcible and cogent in argument.

SEVENTH WARD SCHOOL, No. 2.--The distribution of monthly and semi-annual certificates to the pupils of this School took place yesterday in presence of the Trustees and a number of visitors. The exercises were quite interesting, and were opened in the Primary Department by the reading of the 14th chapter of Exodus by Mr. Nathaniel Terry, Chairman of the Board.

As the recent difficulty between the American and English authorities on the Pacific seems to have originated mainly in certain acts and pretensions of the Hudson's Bay Company, it may be worth while to consider the relation in which that Company actually stands to the Crown of Great Britain.
The steamship Anglo-Saxon from Liverpool 31st ult., passed this point at 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon, on her way to Quebec, where she will be due at noon to-morrow.

AQUATIC. THE DAN BRYANT AND THE GEORGE J. BROWN. --The much-talked-of match race between these noted four-oared race-boats came off yesterday, over the usual regatta course, upon the Harlem River. An immense assemblage, numbering several thousand, had gathered to view the race. The boats rowed for a purse of one thousand dollars-five hundred being put up by the friends of each boat.

Every resident of the Fifth, Sixth and Seventh Fire Districts of the Metropolis was roused from sleep between the hours of 12 and 3 on Monday morning by the sound of the alarm bell. In each of these districts the most sonorous and ponderous of bells iterated and reiterated their strokes of five, six, seven.

It is fair to presume that the Democrats in the State Convention to be held on the 14th inst., at Syracuse, will adopt the substance of live out of the eleven resolutions which the Republicans adopted last Wednesday. If they do not, there are live new questions to be agitated, considered, and settled, at the November elections.

The Anglo Saxon, whose news is telegraphed from Father Point, brings intelligence of the death of LEIGH HUNT. The veteran poet died in London, Aug. 28, in his 75th year. He was born at Southgate, in Middlesex, near London, Oct. 19, 1784. His father, who was a clergyman of the Angliean Church, was a native of the West Indies, and his mother was by birth a Philadelphian, and a relative of WEST, the painter.

FROM WASHINGTON. The California Mail Service-The Treasury--Lieut. Lynde Dismissed from the Army--Further Mexican Advices, Special Dispatch to the New-York Times. WASHINGTON, Monday, Sept. 12. The Postmaster-General addressed another urgent letter, on Saturday last, to the contractors for the California Mail service, demanding to know if they expect to be prepared for a prompt execution of their contract.
In steamship Star of the West, from Aspinwall--

The United States Mail Steamship Star of the West, A. G. GRAY, Esq., commander, from Aspinwall on the 2d inst., and Key West on the 7th, with mails, treasure and passengers by the Sonora, which left San Francisco Aug. 20, arrived at this port yes. terday morning. She left in the port of Aspinwall U. S. war steamer Roanoke, the sloop-of-war Preble, and the store-ship Relief. Crews all well.

THE POPE AND HIS PREMIER.--A private letter from Rome thus describes the Pope and his Premier: "Day before yesterday I saw his Holiness. It was in his library at the Vatican. He takes Snuff; has a fever-sore on his leg, and does not stand or walk much; is 67 years old, very corpulent, and seems truly 'to be touched with a feeling of our infirmities.'

MACDONALD.--In this City, on Monday, Sept. 12, CHARLES J. MACDONALD. aged 34 years. His friends are requested to attend his funeral, from Thorp's Hotel, corner of 8th-st. and Broadway, this day, (Tuesday,) Sept. 13, at 3 P. M. punctually. His remains will be interred in Calvary Cemetery. DAVISON.--In this City, on Monday morning. Sept, 12, ADA B., only daughter of Elias E. and Lucinda Davison, aged 3 years, 3 months and 21 days.

Astraea is expected to return to the Metropolis after the municipal election in November. The Arts have not waited for that auspicious season. They run before the great annual reflux of fashionable New-York, like gracious heralds, and announce the approach of Winter by adding to the general charms of City life all their own special fascinations.

A SOUTHERN FREE-SOILER.-One excellent effect of General HOUSTON'S election to the office of Governor of Texas, by the. crushing majority of ten or twelve thousand over the regular Democratic nominee, has been to open Southern eyes very wide to the inevitable character of the Slave-trade as a political issue.

RATHER FORMIDABLE.-Senator CLAY, of Alabama, has been making a speech lately, denouncing Mr. DOUGLAS and his platform, and declaring that before he will vote for such a policy as he advocates, even at the command of his own State, he " will resign his trust, retire to the deepest seclusion of private life, and, hiding his face in shame and humiliation,

The "Reform movement" in Baltimore, which we noticed the other day, meets the usual fate of such attempts. It is denounced on every side, and from various and opposite motives. The Patriot brands it as a violent rebellion against the regular authorities. The Clipper deprecates the inference which will be drawn from it, that Baltimore is a lawless and riotous city.

Form the Newark Daily Advertiser of last evening. The Annual Fair of the New-Jersey Agricultural Society opened very auspiciously to-day. The inclosure includes several acres, surrounded by a substantial board fence, and located upon an expansive plain stretching away east ward to Newark Bay, which is plainly visible, with the picturesque slope of Bergen Hill for its back ground.

HEALTH OF THE FRENCH MINISTER,-The friends of M. DE SARTIGES, the French Minister, are much distressed at learning that he has been pronounced by the physicians at Plombieres to be in a very dangerous state of health. An enlargement of the liver in combination with an inflammation of the spleen threatens the most serious consequences.

The United States Mail steamship Occan Queen, Capt. SEABURY, from Southampton at 2 o'clock on the afternoon of Aug. 31, arrived at this port last evening. Her advices have been anticipated by dispatches received fran her off Cape Race, and by the arrival at Quebec of the Anglo Saxon, which sailed from Liverpool on the same day.

The Boston Traveller says of the suspension of "The Courier, in noticing this suspension, states that the "Atlantic Monthly load" was one of the causes of their embarrassement, So far from this being true, we are assured, on reliable authority, that the Atlantic has not only paid its expenses, but a very handsome profit over its cost.

The movement which has for its aim the abrogation of all affecting the observance of the sabbath, formally culminated in a largely attended public meeting, which was held at the Volks Garten, in the Bowery. At 8 1/4 o'clock the meeting was brought to order by Mr. FRIEDMANN, who read the call, and submitted the name of Ex-Judge DANIEL W. CLARK for President.

A NOVEL MODE OF ADEVRTISING.--The Elliptic Bed-Spring Company, of this City, introduced a new principle in advertising a short time ago, which is said to have had the effect of largely increasing their business. A long descriptive advertisement of their cheap and luxurious bed-bottom, closes in this wise:

PAYMENT OF THE STATE FLOATING DEBT.-If, in the uncertain fortunes of political war, the Republican Party should chance to be defeated, we trust it will not be on account of the manly manner in which it has faced the question of paying that portion of the public liabilities known as the Floating Canal Debt.

GENERAL UNANIMITY.--We are glad to see that the papers in all sections of the country, and without distinction of party, unite in commending the recent action of Postmaster HOLT concerning the abuse of franking. The claim that the frank of an official entitled to it may be affixed to a mailed document by any other person than himself is preposterous.

All the world, we are sure, will be delighted to hear, on the excellent authority of the London Times, that "England is now rapidly approaching, if she has not actually reached, such a state of defensive preparations that no assailant can attack her with impunity."

EFFECT OF SUNDAY RAILROAD TRAVEL IN THE CITIES-LETTERS FROM THE MAYORS OF NEWYORK, BROOKLYN AND BOSTON-TRIAL OF THE CAR-DRIVER, JEANDELLE, IN PHILADELPHIA. The Philadelphia papers publish an interesting correspondence on the subject of Sunday travel on city railroads.

The Democratic Convention will organize tomorrow. The Tammany Delegation will be received without controversy. The Convention will elect delegates to Charleston. An earnest spirit of reconciliation appears to prevail. ISAAC V. FOWLER will probably be presented as delegate at large.

By the brig John Butler, Capt. MINER, we have dates to 1st inst. Business was very dull, as the tobacco crop was nearly all bought up. Exchange--Paper for gold, $2 50 national for $1, and not much paper. Very little hard money in circulation.
GEN. PlERCE AGAIN.-It is said that Gen. PIEECE intends to be a candidate for reelection to the Presidency. We do not believe it,-but on one account we wish it were true.

HOW THE PAUPERS AND CONVICTS LIVE. Five of the Ten Governors were in attendance at the Rotunda yesterday afternoon at 4 o'clock. The weekly report which was submitted, states that there were 7,414 inmates remaining in the in the institution Sept. 3. Since that time 1,726 have been admitted; 38 have died; 1,513 have been discharged; 134 have been making an increase of 37 during the week.

Messrs. DUNCAN, SHERMAN Co., of New-York have taken the residue--$1,380,000--of the Loan of 1858. Commander Wm. MM. McBLAIR has been ordered to the Washington Navy Yard. Lord Lions, in his interview with Secretary CASS this morning, expressed confidence in the amicable settlement of the Northwestern question.

The State Convention of the Democrats, for the nomination of candidates for State officers, will meet at Syracuse to-day. Our dispatches from there, received late last night, report a very full attendance of delegates and outsiders. The principal interest in the proceedings of the Convention will centre in the determination of the method of choosing delegates to the National Convention at Charleston.

There is so little known of the silver and copper mines of Arizona that any report of them is read with interest. The exaggerated and the almost fabulous accounts on the one hand, and the discouraging ones on the other, have so unsettled the public mind that any account having the least semblance of truth is quite likely to be believed.

SALT WATER COMPLAINTS CONCERNING THE -tailors very seldom complain of the quality of the water they drink. The taste or smell of that liquid is a matter wholly confined to landsmen, who never dream of being put on short allowance, and who have never experienced the horrors of shipwreck where there is " water, water everywhere, but not a drop to drink." The quantity of fresh water on board vessel, however, becomes rno ; .

STEPHENSON.--In this City, on Sunday, Sept. 11, CHRISTOPHER STEPHENSON, Commissioner of Stamps for the Island of Jamaica, West Indies, aged 53 years. Kingston, Jam., papers please copy. WOODWARD.--In this City, on Tuesday, Sept. 13, LETITIA, wife of Samuel Woodward, aged 49 years. The friends and relatives of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, on Thursday, Sept. 15, at 10 o'clock A. M., from her late residence, No. 16 7th-av.

Our files of Rio papers extend to the 25th of July. There is no political news of interest. The United States sloop-of-war Levant, Commander HUNT, was lying in the harbor. On July 17 a fracas occurred between some of men-of-war's-men and boatmen in the harbor, in which two of the latter had been knocked overboard and drowned. The police were unable to make any arrest.

DEMOCRATIC ASSEMBLY CONVENTIONS. -- The Democratic Assembly Conventions were held last causing, when the following nominations were made: First District--Joseph Wilson. Second District--In this District, on the first ballot, where were ten votes cast, one more than the number of delegates in the Convention. Of these, Charles P. Leslie received 5, Charles Kelsey 4, and J. R. Del Vecchiod.

Rascality occasionally rages in the form of an epidemic. The successful operations of one set of plunderers are the certain prelude to other attempts, which may prove equally remunerative, or may fail, according to the degree of shrewd. ness that is exercised. One very unpleasant mania appears to be just now prevalent.

Before Justice Davies. Motion to discharge from arrest.--B. F. Bruton, and another, vs. William Smith.--This was a motion by the defendant to be discharged from arrest. He was arrested on a charge of obtaining under false pretences a bill of goods from the plaintifts, who do business at No. 20 Chiff-street.

The Democracy are already assembled here in great force, and it may be safe to predict that the proceedings will be more than commonly harmonious. It is all but sure that the present State Officers, with the exception of Secretary of State TUCKER, will be renominated by acclammation, though there are rumors that Comptroller CHURCH will decline, preferring to stand back and wait for the next Governorship.

SWINDLING TAILORS.--On Tuesday evening, Officer Charles C. Fisher, of the Twentieth Precinet, made a seizure of a considerable quantity of clothing at the store of Peter Cohen, a German tailor, at No. 738 Eighth-avenue, which was supposed to have been stolen.

The Democratic State Convention, which opened its proceedings yesterday at Syracuse, was the scene of the most disgraceful violence and rowdyism. The Hards, under the leadership of FERNANDO WOOD, took possession of the hall with a large body of fighting men from this City, and proceeded to effect a temporary organization before the Softs had an opportunity of knowing what was going on.

A dispatch from Washington to the Tribunc says: "Since the stoppage at the Post-office of the docu ments purporting to have been franked by Mr. Co. VODE, Mr. BLAIR of Missouri, and one or two other Republican Members of Congress, have been here in person to affix their franks."

The Fall campaign in Wisconsin is fairly open. At the election in November a full set of State officers is to be elected, and the tickets of both Parties, Democratic and Republican, are already nominated. The appointments agreed upon by the two candidates for Governor for stumping the entire State have been published, and each side is organizing its forces for the approaching contest.

According to official data the importations for the present fiscal year will greatly exceed those of the year 1857, and will reach in amount at least $390,000,000, which, at the average duty of 16 per cent., will yield revenue of $62,400,000, or $6,400,000 more than was estimated for by Secretary Conn in his last annual report to Congress.

PHAIR.--In this City, on Wednesday, Sept. 14, JAMES PHAIR, formerly of Killyshandra, County Cavan, Ireland, aged 70 years. The friends and acquaintances of the family, and those of his sops, John and William, are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, from his late residence, No. 3 Madison-St., near Pearl, on Friday, Sept. 16, at 9 o'clock in the forenoon.

TAMPERING WITH SLAVES--VIGILANCE COMMITTEES.--The planters residing in the parish of Lafayette, Louisiana, having been seriously annoyed by outside persons tampering with their slaves, formed a Vigilance Committee a few days since, and expelled a large number of obnoxious persons from the parish, after administering to them severe punishment.

A GLIMPSE AT OUR RULING CLASSES.--Judge MORRIS, of Brooklyn, has lately been into a County Convention, and he came out whipped. His Honor and Mr. SCHUMAKER, the present incumbent of the District-Attorney's Office, were both ambitious to serve the County as its District-Attorney. Both enjoyed unusual facilitics for making friends among our ruling classes,

ANOTHER DISTINGUISHED EXILE AMONG US.--The exiled President of Costa Rica is now sojourning for a season in our City, and seems to regard his recent political misfortunes with commendable philosophy. While conversing freely upon all the circumstances attending his being seized,

From the Rochester Democrat. Wednesday. For some time past, a man calling himself SHIELDS has been advertising that on Friday of this week, the 16th inst., he would perform a wonderful exploit at Niagara Falls, by jumping from a height of 90 feet into the river, below the cataract.

The National fair will open to-morrow. I send you to-day a description of such objects as were displayed this afternoon. The weather is very fine, and the people are coming in rapidly. The hotels in the city are all full, and camping ground is provided within the Fair grounds for those who desire to camp out.

The International Cricket Match--The Turf--American Horses in England, It is announced that the headquarters of the "Eleven" of England, who come to play the great Cricket match, will be at the Astor House. We find in Wilkes' Spirit of the Times the following list of the American players:

The Vanderbiilt Steamship North Star, from Aspinwall on the afternoon of Sept. 6, arrived at this port early yesterday morning, making the passage in seven days and nine hours. Her advices from Central and South America are four days later than those by the Star of the West.

Still more robberies of the mails are reported A dispatch from Delaware City, Del., dated Sept. 13, states that the Post-Office at that place was ?? on Monday night, and all the letters in the office ?? of their contents. The letters intended for the morning's mail were deposited in the office the same evening, so that the number was very considerable. The extent of the loss cannot yet be ascertained. d.

The great popular movement against the Sunday laws, which that eminent theological journal, the Herald, has been drumming up with so much vigor for the past fortnight, came off on Tuesday night, and its proceedings wore duly reported in the TIMES of yesterday. We confess our surprise at the meagre attendance and the spiritless character of the meeting.

ONE WAY TO MAKE CAPITAL.--The Democratic State Convention opened its proceedings at Syracuse, yesterday, with an explosion. According to the information thus far received, our estimable Ex-Mayor, F. WOOD, Esq., made rather a bold push to secure the organization, and thus obtain the substantial control of the Convention.

Two NEW-YORK THIEVES IN PHILADELPHIA.--The Philadelphia papers are strong in praise of the authorities of that city, for having caught two female thieves, well known as "shoplifters" in this city, in the act of making off with a quantity of stolen goods.

GENERAL INTELLIGENCE--COMMERCIAL NEWS. Additional files of Rio journals extend to the 30th of July. There is no news of striking interest. The Spanish war-steamer Concordia, bound from Cadiz to the River Plate, was in the harbor.

DEATH OF THE ORIGINAL OF WALTER SCOTT'S "MADGE WILDFIRE."--A Scottish paper contains tile following interesting history: "On Sunday forenoon intelligence was brought to Galashiels that an old woman of weak mind, well known to the people of Galashiels and Melrose by various cognoniens--as Black Bess, Bet Gramsley, and Daft Bess--was lying in a dying state on the road near Ellwand Bridge.

SLAVERY ABOLISHED AT FERNANDO PO.--The Madrid Gazette, Aug. 22, contains the following official announcement of the abolition of Slavery at Fernando Po, the new Spanish settlement in the Gulf of Guinea:

Our files from Buenos Ayres reach to the 22d of July. The warlike preparations were carried on as actively as possible. A reserve division was being organized in the town of Mercedes, the centre of the province, and counted already 1,200 men.

ARRIVAL OF THE BROOKLYN--THE VERA CRUZ PRESS ON THE DEPARTURE OF MR. M'LANE--MEETING OF REACTIONIST LEADERS AT THE CAPITAL--A STEAM LINE GRANT. Files of Vera Cruz papers to the 1st inst. have been received by the arrival of the Brooklyn off Point Clear, near the mouth of the Mississippi.

CARROLL HILL SEMINARY.--The exercises at the opening of this new institution for female education, in South Brooklyn, took place last Monday evening. The exercises consisted of intrumental and vocal music, prayer, and addresses by several gentlemen. A large number of citizens of that locality, and others interested in the institution, were present.

By an arrival at New-Orleans we have received files of Kingston, Jamaica, papers to the 15th day of August. The Journal of that day says that the Falmouth rioters, of whom nearly a hundred had been arrested, were to have come up for examination the Friday previous.

The upward march of the City population is fast making itself felt on our places of amusement, and he power of the tide was never more strikingly illustrated than at the opening of the so-called " Winter Garden" of Mr. STUART last night.

The United States Mail steamship Philadelphia, G. HARRISON, Esq., commanding, from New-Orleans vid Key West and Havana, arrived at this port last evening. The Philadelphia arrived at Key West at 1 o'clock P. M., on the 8th, transferred twelve passengers for California, and the mails; sailed same day for Havana, arrived there at sunrise on the morning of the 9th. At 4:00 P. M. she left for New-York.

George Brodie et al. vs. The Eighth and Ninthavenue Railroad Companies.--This was an application for a temporary injunction against the defendants, to restrain them from laying an additional track on the south side of Canal-street.

LOCOMOTIVE EXPLOSION AT ROCHESTER.--The locomotive "Ontario," run by STEPHEN HANFORD, an engineer who has been employed on the road for 21 years, and the senior engineer on the road, exploded her boiler at Rochester on Monday morning, while drawing a train of freight cars from the freighthouse to North-street. The locomotive was quite demolished.

GOSENHEIMER--CAMPBELL.--In this City, on Sunday, Sept. 11, at the Parsonage of the 18th-st. M. E. Church, by the Rev. John Porsal, ADOLPHUS GOSENHEIMER to Miss ISABELLA CAMPBELL, all of New-York. BOGERT--HEMPHILL.--In this City, on Tuesday, Sept. 13, at the Bedford-st. M. E. Church, by the Rev. J. P. Newman, Mr. CHARLES H. BOGERT to Miss SARAH J. HEMPHILL, and only daughter of Alex. Hemphill, all of this City.

Scottish Games at Jones' Wood-Meeting of the Caledonian Club. The occasion drew together a large crowd of spectators, who seemed greatly pleased with the entertainment afforded them. The members of the

The friends and acquaintances of the family, and those of his sons, John and William, are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, from his late residence, No. 3 Madison--st.. near Pearl, on Friday, Sept. 16, at 9 o'clock in the forenoon.

We have at last an intelligible and reliable account of the state of our negotiations with Mexico. A letter from Washington, which will be found in another column, confirms the statement that Mr. McLANE has returned without a treaty, and at the same time traces his failure to its proper cause,--the instructions which hampered his action and prevented its success.

Of this there is little doubt. The council of the Horticultural Society, at

The latest dispatch from Sandy Hook, dated at midnight, states that up to that hour nothing had been seen of the steamship Persia, now in her thirteenth day. The Kangraroo is also overdue, she having left Liverpool on the 31st ult. The news, however, has been anticipated by other arrivals.

ARTICLES ON EXHIBITION--LOCALITY OF THE FAIR. The New-Jersey State fair opened at Elizabeth City on Tuesday inst. The grounds are located between Elizabeth and ?? immediately on the line of the New-Jersey Central Railroad. The inclosure devoted to the exhibition of the various articles comprises about thirty acres, almost enough, one would think, to contain all the agricultural and mechanical products of the State.

Lieut. GEORGE M. RANSOM has been detached from the Boston Nave-yard, and ordered to the United States steam sloop Narragansett. Lieut. JAMES M. WATSON has been ordered to relieve Lieut. W. H. BALL, in command of the United States store ship Fredonia, at Valparaiso, Chili. Lieut. P. U. MURPHY has been ordered to the Naval Rendezvous, Norfolk, Va.

Mr. THOMAS FLYNN, of this town, was accidentally killed in this village on Saturday, 10th inst., under the following circumstances; He was returning from Sidney Plains with a load of 110 bushels of oats, when at the head of Mr. HENRY DOWIE'S milldam, near the lower end of the village, he lost his hat by a sudden gust of wind, and while seeking to recover it his horses became frightened and ran.

We publish this morning the first letter of a special correspondent commissioned to examine and report upon certain great features of European progress in practical matters, and the application of science to the useful arts. Truly treated, this theme involves the special history of the present age.

TELEGRAPHIC NEWS.--SUIT AGAINST THE AMERICAN TELEGRAPH COMPANY.--In the Supreme Judicial Court, at Boston, on the 10th, before Judge MERRICK, the case of Johnson Zabriskie vs. The American Telegraph Company was heard, on the part of the petitioners, who describe themselves as reporters of news by telegraph. It is an application for an injunction to restrain the respondents from refusing to receive and transmit their messages at Sackvillc.

Mr. William E. Robinson and wife, of this City, having stopped at Coleraine, Ireland, on their homeward trip after a tour on the Continent, were entertained on the 23d August at an out-door festival at the Giant's Causeway. The Coleraine Chronicle Sates that a large number of guests were present at the entertainment, and that an address of welcome was delivered by the Rev. Mr. McConachie, who visited the United States in 1852.

Let not the reader be alarmed by the heading of this article. We do not propose a review of the Rev. Dr. BELLOWS' dramatic sermons, nor a screed upon the civic and moral properties of the theatre generally. We simply mean to say what we think, in our capacity as critics, of a certain new play which Miss LAURA KEENE, in her capacity as manager, this week presents to the enlightened public.

In my last I promised to give you some of the particulars of the manner in which the great male sale conducted. After the arrival of Mr. HOLLIDAY and the development of the fraud perpetrated upon the Government by the contract for the furnishing of flour to the army in Utah, it was whispered around that developments would be made in a few days that would start us still more than the flour contract.

If the correspondent of the St. Louis Democrat tells the truth, the Administration having exhausted the coal and flour business, has gone into the mule trade. There will soon be hardly a branch of commerce left in which they will not have turned a penny, There has recently been large sale of supernumerary baggage unless at Camp Floyd in Utah.

Among the many scientific works that are attracting attention abroad, the mammoth derrick, which lifts a thousand tons at a pull, is the lion at the present writing. Nor does it attract the popular wonder alone, for the highly scientific manner in which it works is much admired by the profession.

On Monday last an election was held in this city for municipal officers, and resulted in the reflection of Mr. DENMAN as Mayor by a small majority, not exceeding thirty. The Republicans elected the Recorder, Marshal, Treasurer, Street Commissioner, Assessor, and six of the twelve Councilmen, and are very much elected at their success in reducing the Democratic majority of last year from over 200 to less than 30.

To the Editor of New-York Times ; Somebody has written for RUSSELL, Chief Judge of the General Sessions, a verbose opinion to the effect that a dog is property, and accordingly this is made the subject of an elaborate pull of the " brother jurist" by the Herald. The opinion and the puff are exceedingly valuable, when it is remembered that the Revised Statutes distinctly affirm dogs to be property;

CHEAP POSTAGE AND PROTECTION TO THE IRON INTERESTS.--The Hon. JAMES COOPER has written a letter to some gentlemen of Philadelphia upon the subject of cheap postage. He not only warmly opposes the suggestion that the rates of postage should be increased, (as was was proposed by the bill of last session,) but advocates its still further reduction,--either by a direct tax or by the Government selling stamped envelopes for the price of stamps.

MOORE--UNDERHILL,--In this City, on Wednesday, Sept. 14, at the residence of the bride's father, by the Rev. Dr. Jamesson, Mr. HENRY S. MOORE to MISS CLARA BELMONT, the eldest daughter of Capt. M.H. Underhill, all of this City. AUSTIN--BRADBURN.--In this City, on Thursday evening, Sept. 15, at Trinity Chapel, by the Rev. Geo. C. Pennell, LEANDER W. AUSTIN to MISS JULIA BRADBURN, all of this City.

MEETING OF THE PARK COMMISSIONERS--AN EXTENSIVE PARK PROPOSED.--The Commissioners on Parks, appointed by a recent act of the Legislature to locate parks and a parade ground for the City of Brooklyn, held a meeting last evening. The Commissioners early the present Summer effected on organization by electing Judge JOHN GREENWOOD as President, LUTHER B. WYMAN, Esq., as Secretary, and appointing Committees for the different sections of the City.

A REMARKABLY SHORT PASSAGE--STATE OF THE COFFEE TRADE. The Bark Roebuck, Capt. CHASE, from Rio Janeiro, arrived at this port yesterday morning, having sailed the afternoon of the 14th August, thus making the passage from port to port in thirty-two days.

Before Judge Nelson. The September Term of this Court was opened this morning by Judge NELSON> The appeal Calendar was taken up and called nearly through before any case was found read for argument to-day, although almost all "would be ready to -morrow".

SINGULAR CASES OF ARSON.--About 9 1/2 o'clock yesterday morning a fire was discovered in a carpenter's shop in the rear of No. 216 Ninth-avenue, which was extinguished before it had made progress. Among the shavings a small fluid lamp was found, which had evidently been placed there to fire the building.... Shortly after 10 o'clock another fire was discovered by Officer WM. OVERTON, IN THE HOUSE OF Mrs. ELIZABETH PRYOR, at the same umber.

COMMENDABLE ENTERPRISE.--The NEW-YORK TIMES takes the lead among the New-York dailies in all its enterprises and arrangements for supplying the public with the earliest and most desirable news of the day. Its issue of Thursday last contained a verbatim report of Senator DOUGLAS' speech, delivered in Columbus only the day previously. The speech was reported solely for the TIMES, and at their own expense. contained 7,100 words,

BRITISH LEGATION TO MEXICO.--We have anthoritative intelligenen to the effect that Mr. OTWAY, British Minister to Mexico, did not sail, as reported, from Vera Cruz, in the packet of the 4th inst., but will remain at least a month longer at the capital. Several reasons are assigned for this, the principal of which is that he entertained suspicious of the course Mr. MATHEWS, who is left in charge of the Legation, would pursue.

Reliable information received in official circles leaves but little doubt that Sir WM. OUSELEY was a party to the revolution in Costa Rica. Having failed to induce President MORA to assent to the treaty which Nicaragua had rejected, it is believed he then determined to lend his influence to the revolutionary movement.

Under a call made by the Senate of the United States, the Department of State furnished a list of all claims filed with the Government by citizens of the United States against foreign Powers; but at the time of furnishing it, Secretary Cass protested that it would only lead the public mind to false conclusions-that where it would show millions claimed,

The last Legislature, by a large vote, passed an act submitting to the people a law authorizing a loan of $2,500,000, with which to pay off the floating debt of the State, and at tile same time imposing an annual tax sufficient in eighteen years to pay the interest and redeem the principal of the loan.

A NOVELTY IN FASHION.--Among the novelties recently introduced In ladles' apparel, is a new article of suspenders. They bear resemblance to those worn by gentlemen, except that they are made ol delicate, white elastic fabric, with frilled edge, about one inch wide, and are attached to the skirt by buttons In like manner. We doubt not this invention will be generally adopted,

A DEAF MUTE KILLED ON THE HUDSON RIVER RAILROAD.-One of the pupils in the Institution for the Deaf and Dumb, named ANDREW J. STONE, was so seriously injured on Thursday morning from being struck by the cow-catcher of a locomotive on the Hudson River Railroad, that he died in a few hours after at the New-York Hospital, whither he had been conveyed immediately after the accident.

To the Editor Of the New- York Times: SIR: In this morning's impression of the TIMES your Syracuse correspondent has (unwittingly, I believe,) done me an injustice ; one which is calculated to injure me in the estimation of a large circle of social friends. He says the "first act of ruffianism occurred in the bar-room of the Voorhics House,"

About half past two o'clock y yesterday afternoon an alarm of lire was sounded for the Fifth District. The alarm was occasioned by a fire in the third story of the brick building, corner of McWhorter and East Hamilton streets, occupied by D. G. GRIFFITHS, for fancy scroll and circular sawing, by T. E. CHAPMAN, wood turner, and A. C. WARD, manufacturer of wood mouldings.

The divinity that once did hedge a king is strangely dying away in these modern days. The world's rulers, daily becoming more and more a part and parcel of the great machine of society, are relying less on their ancestors and their armies, more upon the public opinion of their own day, in all emergencies of political difficulty.

The workmen employed on the Bergen Tunnel struck for their one month's back wages yesterday morning, and informed the contractor, Mr. LYMAN, that they would work no longer until the same was paid, Mr. L., seeing there was trouble ahead, told the men that they were short of money at the present time, but that they should have their money the first of next month.

Mr. JOHN BELLO has just been appointed Chilian Charge near the Government at Washington, has been appointed Minister to France, when he will pass to Belgium, to argue the Macedonian case, of United States citizens' property seized by Lord COCHRANE as Spanish property.

This post derives importance from having been the first permanent post established in Arizona. It was first commanded by Maj. STEEN, of the Dragoons and has subsequently been commanded by Maj. FITZGERALD and Capt. EWELL; it is now under command of Lieut.-Col. REEVE, of the Infantry, and garrisoned by one Company of Dragoons and one of Infantry.

The steamer Kangaroo from Liverpool 31st ult. vid Queenstown 1st inst., put into Halifax at 6 o'clock short of coals. One hundred and fifty tons were obtained of the Cunard Company, and the ship leaves for New-York to-day, where she will be due on Monday. The Kangaroo has 100 cabin and 220 steerage passengers.

The example of our Central Park has produced a mania among our neighbors of a very commendable nature, Philadelphia has been holding prelimible meetings towards laying out a great Central Park, and Boston would take immediate steps, no doubt, for the same object, but, unhappily, Boston is already built up; there is not a square foot of unoccupied ground left for any purpose whatever,

To the Editor of the New-York Times: It has been stated in several of the papers of the day, that an effort would be made to influence the House of Bishops at the next General Convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church, to terminate the sentence of suspension which has been imposed upon the Right Rev. BENJAMIN T. OSDERDONE, D.D.

The Boston Journal publishes full particulars of the riot which occurred on Thursday, at Manchester, N. H. The origin of the difficulty is thus definitely stated : "The immediate cause of the riot was the open practice of gambling by at least a hundred sporting men in different sections of the city.

PRESIDENT GEFFRARD'S DAUGHTER SHOT The brig Baltimore, Capt. BLY, from Port-auPrince, arrived last night, bringing dates to 5th inst. Among her passengers is Gen. GUIRRERE-PROPHITE, Ex-Minister of the Interior, of Hayti, and his son. The daughter of the President, GEFFRARD, was shot dead while sitting in her father's chair, from the palace gardens, on the evening of the 3d inst. There was great excitement in consequence.

ACCIDENTS AT FERRIES.--We were compelled yesterday to record another death by a futile attempt to jump after the Fulton ferry-boat after it had left the wharf. If there were any such thing as a just and vigorous public sentiment on such subject, the Ferry Company would speedily be compelled to put an end to these utterly needless casualties.

The Fifth Annual Exhibition of the New-Jersey StateAgricultural Society concluded yesterday. Cold, damp northeast winds and a storm which by noon passed from threatening to reality, made the attendanee rather small. Certainly not a tenth part of tile mythical thirty thousand, which the telegraph reported as in attendance on Thursday, visited the grounds yesterday.

One of the European steamers expected at this port has been heard from. The Kangaroo, which left Liverpool on the 31st ult., and Queenstown on the 1st inst., put into Halifax yesterday morning short of coal. She will probably arrive here on Monday. She brings one day later news, which has not been forwarded by telegraph.

WAITE.--In this City, on Thursday morning, Sept. 15, in the 36th year of her age, CATHERINE I., wife of John Waite, and daughter of Cornelius Westerfield, Esq. Her relatives and friends are respectfully invited to attend her funeral this afternoon, at 2 o'clock, from the residence of her father. No. 231 Bleecker-st. Her remains will be taken to the Cemetery of the Evergreens, Long Island.

SPECIAL NOTICE.--NEW-YORK, Sept. 19. 1859. An entire new Calendar for trials by jury will be made up for the ensuing October, November, and December Terms of this Court. All notes of issue for said Calendar must be filed with the Clerk on or before Saturday, the 24th day of September instant.

My last letter gave an account of the great feast day of Corpus Christi in the City of Mexico, June 23. In all the year no better public opportunity is afforded the observing stranger to obtain a general idea of the peculiarities appertaining to the priesthood and their religion than this feast day.

POLITICAL.--The Democrats in the Third Assembly District have nominated T. C. CALLICOT, Esq., as a candidate for Assembly. The Republican primaries will be held on Thursday evening next. A lively fight is going on in the Second Assembly District between two persons who claim to have received the Democratic, nomination for Assembly, and their friends.

THE CENTRAL PARK POLICE.-What a police force, even in this country, can be made when properly managed, may be seen by a visit to the Central Park, and an observation of the Central Park Police. They are under the command of a military man, who has introduced into the force military order and discipline.

It is pleasant to see politician really taking a practical interest in a question of humanity. Gov. BANKS, we all know, is a daring horseman, a skillful party leader, an able presiding officer of popular assemblies, and a man destined perhaps to reach high rank as a statesman; but as a philanthropist and penal reformer, he had not yet appeared before the public.

The Democratic State Convention, though its proceedings began in storm and tempest, made a very successful and fortunate termination of its labors. It appointed a full list of delegates to Charleston, and instructed them to vote as a unit, in obedience to the decision of the majority of their members.

There was but a slim attendance of delegates from the various wards. After some preliminary business,

It has at length been decided that Superior City is a city, and that the Trustees of the Corporation formed under the general law of Wisconsin are permitted to enter it as such. This much-litigated case has given rise to numerous questions of interest that have been passed upon by the Department of the Interior, under the late and the present Administration.

The National Fair was formally opened yesterday; but the ceremony was rather a failure, so far as pageantry was concerned. However, the enthusiasm of the people made up what was lacking in pomp and display. There were, no doubt, fully fifteen thousand persons present. At 10 o'clock in the morning the President and officers of the Society were escorted from the Tremont House to the Fair grounds,

PRINCIPLES vs. CHRONOMETERS.--It was generally supposed that Ex-Mayer WOOD Went to Syracuse for the purpose of testing the principles of the party in this State.

The screw steamship Borussia, Capt. TRAUTHAN, from Hamburg on the 1st inst., and from Northampton on the 4th, arrived at this port yesterday morning. She was off the Hook on Saturday night. The Borussia passed the Hamburg steamship Hammonia, on the 4th, off Start Point, English Channel.

The Board of Supervisors will meet at 11 o'clock A.M., to-day, to select three Registrars for each election district in this City--in accordance with the Registry Act, passed by the Legislature last Winter. The election will be by ballot.

The Royal Mail steamship Persia, Capt. JUDKINS, which sailed from Liverpool at about 1 o'clock on the afternoon of the 3d inst., arrived here at an early hour this morning. She brings 232 passengers. On the 5th inst., at 10 P. M., broke the crank-pin o the port engine, and laid to until 7th, at 9:45 P. M. under canvas.

HEALTH OF THE CITY--STATE OF THE MARKETS--EXCHANGE. The United States Mail steamship De Soto, J. D. BULLOCH, Commander, from New Orleans via Havana, arrived yesterday morning, having left the latter place on the evening of the 13th. She brings little of interest from Havana.
PUBLIC TRANQUILITY--ADJOURNMENT OF THE COLONIAL PARLIAMENT--THE RECALL OF GOV. GREY. By the arrival of the British mail steamer at Southampton, we receive advices from the Cape to July 23.

There is a popular notion afloat that circumlocution offices are the special property of foreign nations,--and that the art and mystery of knowing how not to do things, has not yet been introudced into this new and happy Republic.

FATAL RESULT OF A QUARREL BETWEEN CHILDREN.--An inquest was held yesterday by Coroner JACKMAN, at the Fourteenth Ward Station house, upon the body of MARY LOUISA NOONAN, a little girl 12 years of age, who was badly beaten by two little boys, named SAMUEL CLARKE and ROBERT FISHER, on the 9th inst., from the effects of which, it is supposed, she died.

The mails received by the steamship Borussia, which reached this port yesterday, make it quite certain that the steamer Persia, of the Cunard line, left England on her appointed day of sailing, and will therefore very naturally increase the anxiety to which her non-arrival has already given birth.

The screw-steamship Borussia, of the Hamburg line, having touched at Southampton on Sunday the 4th inst., arrived at this port yesterday morning. Her London advices are to the afternoon of Sept. 3, substantially four days later than those previously received. They are not of especial moment.

ARMSTRONG.--In this City on Sunday morning, Sept, is, SARAH HAVEMEYER, only child of Hector and Sarah C. Armstrong, aged 1 year, 9 months and 20 days. The relatives and friends of the family, and those of her grandfather, William F. Havemeyer, are respectfully invited to attend her funeral, on Tuesday morning, Sept. 20, at 10 o'clock, from the residence of her parents, No. 226 West 14th-st.

The leviathan of steamers, it will be seen, has postponed her day of sailing, and also the day of her trial trip. She is now announced to sail on tile 17th, which was Saturday last, for an excursion of two or three days, and to start on the 29th,-a week from Thursday,-fur Portland.

The scenes of riot and disorder which took place two years ago this Fall upon the Erie Railroad tunnel, at Bergen Hill, have been repeated during the past three days, occasioned, as in the former instance, by the failure of the contractor to fulfill his engagements with the workmen by promptly paving them at the time agreed.

TIFFT--GRAY.--In this city, on Thursday, Sept. 15, by the Rev. E. II. Chapin, at the residence of the officiating clergyman. Mr. HENRY R. TIFFT to Miss MARY E. GRAY, all of this City. GRIFFEN--BURLING.--At Harrison Town, Westchester County, on Tuesday, Sept. 13, JAMES GRIFFEN, of White Plains, to SARAH ANN, daughter of John Burling, of the former place.

The avages of the equinoctial storm which commenced so furiously Friday afternoon, and made Saturday hideous with its howlings, were not, so far as we have yet learned, of a very serious character. It was a barking dog that did not bite, or, at least, took hold so gently that no one is much the worse for the encounter.

At the dedication of the statue of WEBSTER in the State House Grounds in Boston on Saturday, Mr. EVERETT made the following address: May it please Your Excellency: On behalf of those by whose contributions this statue of Mr. WERSTER has been procured,

Abolition, Free Love, Intidel and Women's Rights Convention. BUFFALO, Saturday, Sept. 17. A Convention of self-styled reformers has been sitting in this city for two days past, comprising the leading abolitionists, spiritualists, free-lovers, infidels, fanatics, and women's rights men and women of the country.

RASH AND HASTY INFERENCES.--The New York correspondent of the Richmond Enquirer is quite sure that the influence of the TIMES has been secured for DOUGLAS in the Presidential canvass, because we procured a full report of his Columbus speech by telegraph.

DESTRUCTIVE FIRE IN EAST ATTLEBOROUGH, MASS.--THREE HUNDRED PERSONS THROWN OUT OF EMPLOYMENT. A disastrous fire occurred at 3 1/2 o'clock on Saturday morning at East Attleborough, Mass., on the line of the Boston and Providence Railroad.

All the City theatres and places of amusement are now in full operation, reaping the fruits of that extraordinary harvest of strangers which the hotels barely succeed in housing. First on the list is the Academy of Music, where a short season is being conducted with immense vigor.

At a meeting of the Board of Aldermen, yesterday, Alderman BOOLE offered a resolution correcting a clerical error in the ordinance redistricting the City, by which file boundaries of some of the Districts in the Fourth and Sixth Wards are altered. It was laid over.

In this City on Sunday morning, Sept. 18, SARAH HAVEMEYER, only child of Hector and Sarah C. Armstrong, aged 1 year 9 months and 20 days. The relatives and friends of the family, and those of her grandfather, William F. Havemeyer, are respectfully invited to attend her funderal, on Tuesday morning, Sept. 20, at 10 o'clock, from the residence of her parents, No. 226 West 14th-st.

Gen. LAMAR, Ex-Minister to Costa Rica and Nicaragua, who has been on business here ever since his return from Central America, left Washington to-day for his home in Texas. No increase of our Naval forces in the Pacific is contemplated, in consequence of the San Juan island dispute.

We learn from good authority that an effort is now is progress, having for its object the immediate revision, and eventual annualment at no distant day, of the contract made with Messrs. MATHER, McISTYRE and CRAIG, for performing the labor in the Public Stores attached to the Custom-house of this city.

In another column will be found a report by the Street Commissioner setting forth the facts in relation to another of' the fraudulent judgments obtained against the City in connection with his Department. It is tile old story.

The Persia, as announced elsewhere, arrived at her dock early on Monday morning, after a stormy passage of fifteen days and a half. The advices by the Persia, which left Liverpool on the 3d, were anticipated by the arrival of the Borussia, which left Southampton on the 4th inst.; but from our complete files received by the former vessel we are able to gather some additional news.

THE CASE OF THE OVERPAID CONTRACTOR--THE STREETS TO BE LIGHTED ALL NIGHT--BELGIAN PAVEMENT FOR FULTON-STREET. A regular meeting of the Board of Alderman was held last evening. For the first time since the Summer covation reports of Committees were reached, and consequently a large amount of business was transacted.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I notice that DANIEL B. HASBROUCK, Deputy Clerk of the Police Department, has been dismissed by the Police Commissioners for "attending the Republican State Convention at Syracuse, and taking an active art in the deliberations of that body."
