Since the date of my letter to you on the 13th inst., the whole character of our local discussions has changed from splitting straws upon the two points of whether the property of the clergy is to be devoted to continuing the civil war or at once to be turned into the national strong-box, and to be used for paying foreign debts and aiding public improvements in the country.

Mr. FRANCIS BACON, employed by the banking firm of G. S. ROBBINS SON, made a complaint on Saturday, before Alderman BRADY, at the City Hall Police Court, against PAUL SEITHEL and GEORGE H. LOCK, whom he charges with conspiring to defraud his employers to the extent of $6,490 11.

To the Editor of the New-York Times; The severe article in one of the City papers a few days since concerning Intelligence Offices in this City, was all on one side, abusing the proprietors enmasse, as much as to say, there was "no good come ont of Israel."

THE OLD TRICK..--Our readers may have noticed that the notorious ENRIGHT, whose name has for years been conspicuously and constantly connected with the swindling of emigrants, and of other strangers in the city had been arrested on charge of robbing a Frenchman, ignorant alike of our customs, languagce and laws.

THE TIMES' REPORT OF MR. DOUGLAS' SPEECH.--Before Mr. DOUGLAS had ceased to speak, on Wednesday afternoon, at Columbus, the first sentences he had uttered were flashing across the magnetic wires to all parts of the country ; and in New-York, many hundred miles away, the next morning, the readrs of the TIMES night learn, before they had break fasted, the very words in which the orator had addressed them.

The effects of the steady and persistent gales which for two weeks preceded the equinoctial storm of Saturday last, are reported from various quarters. The steamship Persia arrived at this port at 2 1/2 o'clock yesterday morning, after a wearisome passage of sixteen days from Liverpool, whence she sailed on the afternoon of the 3d September.

A trial took place to-day between the steam fire-engine of Hope Company, Philadelphia, and the steam fire-engine of the Atlantic Company, of this city. The former beat the latter 30 feet. The Atlanic has a rotary-pump, and was built at Seneca Falls.

The following extract of a private letter from a gentleman whose position enables him to give reliable information concerning the movements of the Great Eastern, contains particulars of general interest on this subject;

The special police force detailed on Sunday to watch at the scene of the late riot prevented the return of the mob, and the track remains clear. Foiled and exasperated by the arrest of many of their leaders, they changed their plan of attack on Sunday night, and threatened individually such persons as happened to have become obnoxious to them.

The readers of the TIMES during the past month have been kept well posted with the progress of what was popularly known as the "Piggery War." About the middle of July the Commissioners of Health ordered the abatement of one of greatest nuisances of the City--the pig-pens which abounded in the vicinity of the Central Park.

The Fair grounds were enlivened yesterday by a display of the steam plows, and by the competition o three military companies for the "stand of colors," worth $400, which was offered as a prize to the best drilled company.

Since my last of 9th July the United States ship Levant, Com. HUNT, arrived after a passage of thirtynine days from Boston, and sailed again seven days after her arrival. All well on board. The sloop-ofwar John Adams, Com. MASON, (a brother of Senator MASON, of Virginia,) put in here on the 31st of July, leaking and very much strained, owing to bad weather experienced on the voyage, and the immense weight of her batteries.

We are in possession of news from Japan to the 5th of June. The intercourse of Europeans with the country was daily becoming more extensive, and is likely in a few years to effect a complete change in its aspect.

TWO KNIVES FOR ONE KNOT.--We are delighted to learn that tile Commander-in-Chief of the British army, his Royal Highness the Duke of CAMBRIDGE, has sailed from Bantry Bay in a noble air-ship) of three hundred guns, for Vancouver's Island, where he will meet the Commander-inChief of the American army deputed by the President to keep Gen. HARNEY from plunging the United States into a sudden and sanguinary war with Great Britain.

The proceedings at Syracuse seem to have occasioned a good deal deal of bad blood among the prominent actors in the affair. We observe that a placard was posted about the City yesterday signed by ANDREW SHEEHAN, denouncing Mr. BUCHANAN'S Marshal for this District, ISAIH RYNDERS, Esq., in the most ferocious and unmistakable terms.
The arrival of the Great Eastern, whatever maybe her success, will at least have the good effect of recalling public attention in this country to the general subject of Ocean Navigation by Steam.

The disastrous fire at Chicago, Sept. 15, pre viously reported by telegraph, broke out on Canal street, north of Lake ; the loss is estimated at $500,000. The Chicago Times gives the following part culars:

The Royal Mail steamship Persia, Capt. JUDKINS, which sailed from Liverpool at about 1 o'clock on the afternoon of the 3d inst., arrived here at an early hour yesterday morning. She brings 232 passengers. The announcement of her arrival appeared in a small portion of our edition of yesterday morning.

The steamship Arabia, of the Cunard line, with European advices to September 10, reached Halifax last evening. Owing to the misunderstanding existing between the Nova Scotia Telegraph Company and the Associated Press, the dispatches, in due course, we should have received immediately upon her arrival, will only come to hand in time for our evening edition.

The examination of the rioters of the Bergen Tunnel was concluded yesterday at the Court-house in Hudson City, District-Attorney LITTELL having called and examined the remaining witnesses. The only additional arrests made were those of MICHAEL MULVEY and WILLIAM ALVIN. MULVEY was chased from Hudson to Jersey City by Mr. SEYMOUR, and a special policeman, where he was finally arrested.

We received the other day the following deleetable little communication from a publishing house established in a neighboring city, which we shall not further specify than by saying that it is more prolific of prose than of peaches; and that its female inhabitants are more famed for the solidity of their understandings than for the taste of their toilettes.

The news at this time is not of great interest. Tile President recently returned from a visit to Petite Goave, and will presently set forth on a grand tour to the North. This movement is to consolidate the Government and extinguish the petty efforts that have been made, from time to time, by demagogues of tile more ignorant class, to inaugurate a revolulion against President GEFFRARD.

THE KANSAS TROUBLES.-The Lawrence Republican states that Capt. MONTGOMERY has concluded not to venture to an appeal to arms unless new arrests are made by parties from over the line. The Fort Scott Democrat gives the proceedings of a meeting of the citizens of Franklin, Bourbon County,
About one hundred and twenty persons are here this evening on attendance to the American Convention, including delegates from thirty Counties, but not all full.

A MURDER AVENGED AT LAST.--The pardon granted three years ago, by Gov. CLARK, TO Dr. GRAHAM, that dangerous man has already converted into a death penalty. In a political quarel, touching the origin and nature of which the telegraph is silent, the murderer of LORING has been shot dead in the streets of New-Orleans.

LECTURES ON BOTANY.-A course of lectures on Botany is in progress of delivery on Tuesdays, Thursday and Saturdays, at 2 1/2 P. M., at the College of Physicians and Surgeons, by Dr. J. G. COOPER, known in connection with the Patent-Office Reports and a volume of the Pacific Mail Report.

AN EDITOR ASSAULTED IN HIS OWN OFFICE.--About 1 1/2 o'clock yesterday afternoon, FRANCIS McCABE, a well-known Ward politican, and keeper of a public house in Broadway, corner of Twelfth-street, went into the business office of the Daily News, and entered into conversation with Mr. W. DRAKE PARSONS, the proprietor of that paper.

The Baltimore Exchange publishes an elaborate correspondence which has just taken place between the Committee appointed at the Reform Meeting and Mayor SWANN. Some curious points occur in the letters.

The alarm at about 12 o'clock last evening, was caused by the discovery of flames breaking out on the second floor of the four-story brick building No. 49 Ann-street, occupied by E. LIEBENROTH VONAUW, blank-book manufacturers. The fire was discovered by some of the members of Engine Company No. 5, whose engine is located next door to where the fire broke out, and the alarm was given.

The Nova Scotia Line having closed without forwarding the regular Press report, we are compelled to await the arrival of the horse express with the news, which will be due at this place at an early hour to-morrow morning.

Lieutenant-General WINFIELD SCOTT departed yesterday on his mission of pacification to tile Pacific. The pier at the foot of Warren-street, North River, from which it had been announced that the General would sail in the Star of the West at 2 P. M., was crowded with people long before that hour, and every available spot on the adjacent wharves and shipping was occupied.

Gen. SCOTT took his departure yesterday for the Pacific Coast. It is understood that he has been sent thither by the President to settle the dispute which has arisen between Great Britain and the United States as to the ownership of the Island of San Juan.

DEVOE.--In this City, on Monday, Sept. 19, MARY FI?? DEVOE, in the 43d year of her age. Her relatives and friends are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, from her late residence, No. 140 East Broadway, on Thursday, Sept. 22, at 1 o'clock precisely.

The Comptroller, yesterday, sent the following communication, assigning his reasons for refusing to attend the opening of bids for the contract for extending Beckman-street across the Park, to the President of the Croton Aqueduct Department: CITY OF NEW-YORK DEPARTMENT OF FINANCE, COMPTROLLER'S OFFICE, Sept. 20, 1859. M. Van Schaick, Esq., President Croton Aqueduct Department :

When the great commercial panic occurred two years ago, the Press teemed with nostrums and panaceas for the prevention of a recurrence of the calamity. Some said that it was too much credit that did it; others, that it was too many bank notes; others, that it was the wrongheadedness of the bank presidents; and others, again, that it was the too lavish importation of foreign goods, or, rather, of foregin luxries.

AN UNEQUAL RACE.-A few weeks since, Mr. N. P. WILLIS, in the Home Journal, gave a very graphic narrative of an alleged incident in the early life in the personal history of Lieut. MAURY. The amount of it was thai a young Owhyee princess insisted on his marrying her, which he finally did, with the usual ceremonies of the country.

Second Lieut. ALEX. MURRY, Tenth Infantry, has been directed to join and take command of the escort to the exploring party under Capt. SIMPSON, Topographical Engineers. Second Lieut. JAMES L. THOMPSON, Tenth Infantry, having tendered his resignation, "unconditional and immediate," has leave of absence for sixty days.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Is there anything in the new Registry Law of this State that requires a citizen who has not changed his residence since the last election, and who voted at that election, to go before the Board of Registry and have his name entered upon the list to enable him to vote at the next election ?

THE HALIFAX FIRE.--The loss by the recent fire at Halifax, N. S., is ascertained to have been $1,200,000. The insurances were as follows: Alliance, of London. ?? Royal, of London, $128.000; Liverpool. of London. $112,000; Phenix, of London. $32.000; American offices, $30,000; Halifax of ??. $32,000; total. $180,000.

The new Registry Law requires the Supervisors of this City to assemble on the third Monday of September, and proceed to ballot for three inspectors of each election district in the county. Promptly the Supervisors met at 11 o'clock on Monday, and balloted once for the inspectors of the first district.

The Christian Advocate and Journal reports the movements of the American Methodist missionaries in India. The Rev. James Baume arrived at Calcutta, July 15, in good health. The Rey. Dr. Butler has fixed his residence at Bareilly.

THE AYER AND FAY AFFRAY IN BOSTON.-Dr. J. C. AYER, of Lowell, has been held to bail in Boston in the sum of $20,000, to appear and answer for his ecent assault upon Mr. FAY, Secretary of the Middlesex Mills Company. Mr. FAY has made the folowing statement: "Dr. AYER, on entering the office of the Middlesex Company, offered Mr. FAY his hand, which was not accepted.

The Constitution of the United States, which has endured a good many commentaries in its day, received yesterday, in this city, a most luminous exposition from one of the leading members of the Democratic Party.

To the Editor of the New-York Times : Another "Signer of the Petition" for the removal from Bishop ONDERDONE of the sentence of suspension was much astonished at reading in your issue of yesterday the communication of " One of the Signers," who seems to speak with authority.

A fine house attended the performance of the "Trovatore," despite the pitiless rain-storm, which in the "season" would certainly have kept the benches empty. Our country friends are not so easily balked in their pleasures, and a pleasure it was to hear this energetic opera interpreted as it was las night.

A FRACAS.-The political loungers in tile rotunda of the City Hall were entertained yesterday, at about noon, by a fracas between a lawyer and a stage proprietor, who resides in the Eastern District. The latter gave tile former tile "lie direct," when both assumed belligerent attitude and several blows were struck by each in rapid succession.

In New-York, during the past week, the demand for Wool has been good, though not general,-some holders having had a very satisfactory run of custom, while other factors have had only a limited number of applications from buyers. The receipts hare bees quite liberal, especially of domestic,-yet receivers have not manifested any unusual eagerness to sell, and certainly no disposition to make any material

The German student-life is universally characterized by the existence of so-called corps, Verbindungen and Landsmanunschafren. The distinction between these three classes of associations may be presented as follows: A landsmanunschaft is composed only of fellow countrymen: it drinks and fights duels. A Crops is not so strict as to the nationality of its members; it also drinks and fights.

In my last letter to the TIMES I narrated, briefly, how a young Roman Catholic girl in the neighboring City of Hamilton, a member of a society of novitiates, and who was shortly to have become a nun, gave her affections too freely to a gallant, whose attentions, by the rules of the order, she should rather have discouraged.

In steamship New-York, from Bremen and Southampton--K. Brock and lady, Mrs. E. Weber, Miss Rerkhiem, S. Flecshmann. G. Gerkel and lady, E. Black, F. Merisse and lady, Thereleth;

ISAAC V. FOWLER, ESQ.--Dear Sir: Can you inform a citizen what is the use of paying a cent or putting a one-cent stamp on City Government-dispatch letters? If you do, the postman charges two cents; if you don't the postman charges two cents. Can you inform me why I do not possess the right of prepaying a City letter, if I so choose to do, to some person in indigent circumstances, for instance?

The R. M. steamship Arabia, Capt. STONY, left Liverpool at 9 o'clock on the morning of the 10th inst., and arrived at-Halifax at about 6 o'clock P. M. of the 20th. The Arabia was twelve hours in the fog off Halifax harbor. Professor AGASSIZ, his wife and daughter, are among the passengers. The screw steamer Balbec left Liverpool at about the same time for Halifax.

By the arrival of the Salacia, at this port, papers from Buenos Ayres, to Aug. 2, have been received. The mediation of the American Minister, Mr. YANCEY, was progressing satisfactorily. lie had laid the propositions of the Buenos Ayrean Government before URQUIZA, and had several long interviews with that leader, after which he had returned to Buenos Ayres, and, it was said, with every prospect of procuring a final settlement of the pending difficulties.

By the arrival of the Arabia at Halifax, the Nova Scotian at Quebec, and the New-York at this port, we receive news from Europe one week later than that brought by the Borussia. The great event of the week had been the departure of the mammoth steamship Great Eastern on her trial trip.

There is a curious controversy going on between the two sections of the Democratic Party, as to which has the most bruisers and prize-fighters in its employ. It appears that a change has recently been made in the position occupied by the shoulder-hitting gentry in the government of the country,

The announcement of the death of Prof. GEORGE BUSH will not be a surprise to the friends of that distinguished gentleman; for his health had been rapidly failing, and it is but a few weeks since an unfounded rumor of his decease went abroad. Prof. BUSH died at Rochester on Monday, Sept. 19, in the 63d year of his age.

POLITICAL MUTATIONS.--Nothing shows more strikingly the changes which time brings about in the political relations of public men, than the fact, that while the completion of the State Canals is the leading measure of the Republicans, their nominee for Comptroller is Mr. DENNISTON, who, up to 1848, was a leading Democrat, and as such active in opposing the Canal policy.

Five Hundred American Troops Entrenched on San Juan Island--Refusal of the British Admiral to Hasten a Collision, NEW-ORLEANS, Wednesday, Sept. 24. The steamship Habana, of the Tehuantepec line, has arrived, with San Francisco dates of the 5th inst. The steamship Washington had been libeled before the Brazillan Consul.

FIRE IN PELL-STREET.-About 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon a fire occurred in the six-story brick building, No. 20 Pell-street. A large conflagration was only prevented by extraordinary exertion on the part of the firemen, for the building was filled with combustible materials. Mr. WALSH occupied the three upper stories.

The Autumn Regatta of the New-York Yacht Club takes place to-day, unless the weather be such as to render a postponement necessary. Unusual preparations have been made for the occasion, and, should all go well, the lovers of yachting will doubtless be afforded a pleasure which they covet ardently.

The Richmond Whig is insisting on the necessity of overthrowing the Democracy in that State and throughout the Union, on the ground that the slaveholding interest is not safe in their hands. It quotes from a recent letter of one of the TIMES correspondents to show that in Western Virginia, there is a strong distrust of slave labor on grounds of economy, and adds;-

The transfer and foreign-note clerk of the Fulton Bank, Mr. WILLIAM J. LANE, Jr., was taken before Justice OSBORN at the Lower Police Court, yesterday, on a charge of embezzlement, preferred by Mr. JOSEPH KERNOCHAN, the President of the Institution.

Four shows or fairs, in which citizens never fail to take a lively interest, have been for some tile back advertised as to open yesterday. The American Institute's Fair at Palace Garden, (which, however, was the day before postponed until the 27th,) the American Institute's Horticultural Exhibition of flowers, fruit and vegetables, under the superintendance of the New-York Horticultural Society;

DIRECT MAIL TO NAPLES, VIA FRANCE.--Notice has been given, by the French Post-office, of the recent establishment of a weekly line of French mailpackets, to ply between Marseilles and Naples, stopping at Leghorn and Civita Veechia, both going and returning.

The Doctrine of Poplar Sovereignty--Letter from a Retired Statesman. To the Editor of the New-York Times: I have not read Senator DOUGLAS' article on "Popular Sovereignty" in Harpers' Magazine, nor Attorney-General BLACK'S reply in the Constitution.

Notwithstanding the storm that has prevailed for several days was as violent last evening as at any time since Saturday last, the large Hall of the Cooper Institute was nearly filled with persons who desired to welcome the deputation from the Irish Presbyterian Assembly, that arrived here recently, for the purpose of soliciting aid in behalf of the Evangelization of the South and West of Ireland.

THE REGATTA YESTERDAY.--The stormy weather proviso included in the announcement of the Fall Regatta appears to have ?? wisely inserted,--the heavy north, east gale and accompanying rain-storm, yesterday, rendering it inexpedient to attempt the race.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I just received an official notice that I have been removed from my position as First Deputy Clerk n the Police Department, for alleged participation in a political convention. The rule on the subject applies in its letter to members of the Police force only--and as such it has been promulgated.

Scarcely a day passes that some allusion is not made to the Island of Jamaica. From the bench, the Pulpit and the Press come long homilies on its desolation; premises are laid down and conclusions drawn hostile to liberty, and a universal supplication is added to the already groaning litany of Slavery, "From Emancipation and its evils, good Lord deliver us."

The British Government has just presented to Parliament a second series of papers relative to the affairs of British Columbia, extending over the six months from October to the end of March last. Gov. DOUGLASS reports most favorably of the condition and resources of the colony, which was in course of being provided with all the institutions and establishments of a well-ordered settlement.

MANUFACTURED FOREIGN CORRESPONDENCE.---In is well known that a majority of the New-York papers publish a manufactured European correspondence made up in their own offices. The Herald publishes a column of matter purporting to be a Paris letter, which it is an insult to the public to attempt to impose upon it readers.

The TIMES' dispatch containing the Treasury statistics and estimates seems to have stirred up the bile of several correspondents here, who, while they have not the comprehension to understand, have the hardihood to deny the correctness of my figures.

Thursday proving no less horribly wet and muddy a day than Wednesday, visitors were very scarce at the Cattle Show and Horticultural Exhibition. BEESLEY--DUNHAM.--In this City, on Wednesday, Sept. 21, at the residence of the bride's father, by the Rev. J. Q. Adams, JOSEPH W. BEESLEY to BELL T. DUNHAM, all of this City. DIAMOND.--CAVANAGH.--In this City, on Wednesday, Sept, 21, by the Rev. Mancius S. Hutton, P. H. DIAMOND to KATE HARRLSON, daughter of W. A. Cavanagh, all of this City.

MY THIRD BOOK. A Collection of Tales. By LOUISE CHANDLER MOULTON. New-York: HARPER BROS., 1859. Miss MOULTON is entitled to the credit of having invented a new style of naming books which will be very convenient to voluminous authors.

The critical effort of that wonder of ship-craft, the Great Eastern, at walking Earth's waters, is fairly the leading topic of the morning. Thanks to the letter of the Special Reporter of this paper, we are presented with a detailed, intelligent, and graphic narrative of this decisive voyage, with such scientific jottings as throw light on the mechanical aspects of the experiment.

The Americans have held their State Convention, and decided upon the part they will take in the coming State election. Their action betrays a profound and rather melancholy consciousness that, as a party, they have survived all their usefulness and most of their strength.

A temporary agent of the American Express Company at Terre Haute, within the past two of three weeks, has embezzled sums reaching nearly $40,000. This was all staked and lost at gaming tables. The last sum taken was an entire package of $14,000 for the Pike County Bank. This was lost in one night at a gambling saloon.

We have been requested to publish the following card from the Managers of an enterprise which we have more than once taken occasion to commend to public favor: To the Editor of the New-York Times: Your readers are all familiar with our "Coffee and Reading Room" in the Fourth Ward, under charge of Mr. ORVILLE GARDNER.

Loss of the Schooner Alhambra--Vessels Ashore--Damage by Freshets, Tile fishing-smack Charles Johnson, of Greenport, which arrived here last night, reports the loss of the schooner Alhambra, of Baltimore. She went ashore, during the thick weather of Wednesday night, in Vineyard Sound, on the shoal known as the Handkerchief, and was breaking to pieces at last accounts. She had no cargo.

THE U. S. GRAND LODGE OF ODD FELLOWS--The Grand Lodge of Odd Fellows is now in session in Baltimore. The Grand Treasurer on Wednesday submitted his annual report of the receipts and disbursements, as follows: The receipts and disbursements, as follows: The receipts were $17,373 70, and the disbursements $17,536 19--showing an excess of $101 10 of expenses over receipts.

We publish in another column a card from Mr. D. B. HASBROUCK, complaining of his removal from the deputy Clerkship of the removal from the Deputy Clerkship of the Police Commission for having attended a political Convention. having attended a political Convention.

Another opening came off yesterday-in fact two openings; one of the windows of heaven, the other of the milliners' windows on Broadway. The Fall weather and the Fall Fashions set in upon us together; the first dark, wild, wet and windy; the second more gorgeous than Solomon in all his glory, gleaming, sheeny, blazing like the American forests beneath the fiery finger of October.

AN EMPHATIC OPINION.--The following paragraph is from quite a long editorial article in the Mobile (Ala,) Register: "The New-York Herald is the journal which, during the Italian war, first received the astounding intelligence that LOUIS NAPOLEON had requested permission to march 30,000 men through Hanover to the Rhine.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: On perusing your valuable journal of this date, I was somewhat surprised to find that Mr. Comptroller HAWS, in rendering a reason for not assenting to the proceedings authorized to be taken in the matter of the much-needed improvement of extending Beekman-street across the Park, cited a provision of law

From our Special Correspondent, whose inleresting story, written on board the big ship, may be found in another column of this paper, and is amply confirmed by tile accounts of the London papers, we learn that the Great Eastern had left her moorings, and that her performances, so far as opportunity had been afforded, fully met the most sanguine expectations.

The steamship Arabia, having arrived at Boston at 7 o'clock yesterday morning, her mails and dispatches were forwarded by railroad, and reached this City last evening. We enlarge the telegraphic abstract of her intelligence, with correspondence and copious extracts.

We have more than once taken occasion to commend the general management of his Department by the present Postmaster-General. So far as we are able to judge from his acts, Mr. HOLT may fairly be regarded as a specimen of that almost extinct species of men,

To the Editor of the New-York Times: We are Still without news of the Nova Scotian, and of course of the English cricketers who are on board of her, and who were announced to play on Wednesday. It is surprising what interest is felt both in Canada and the United States, in these international cricket matches.

CITY COURT.-- Calendar for this day--Nos. 53---Miller vs. Parker and others; 54---McKenney and others vs. The City of Brooklyn; 55---Edwards vs, Myers, Jr.; 56--Lynch and Wife vs. Flannery and Wife; 3---Searle vs. Toucey; 13---Wood vs. Robinson; 14--Pfirman. et al. vs. Kunze 23---Bishop vs. The City of Brooklyn;

A meeting of the Academy of Medicine was held, Wednesday, to which much interest was prospectively attached, because of the understanding among the members that Dr. GRISCOM would deliver an address on the subject of Quarantine, in opposition to the well-known views of Dr. FRANCIS and Dr. MOTT,

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The Occupants of pews on the orange-street side of Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER'S churchare sadly annoyed during "fly-time," by the stamping of horses, the singing, whistling, and loud conversationof men and boys, supposed to be engaged in keeping the horses quiet and the flies off.

We are glad to learn that a new society has been organized for the special purpose of look, after the interests--material and moral--of the lower classes in the lower Wards of the City. WILSON G. HUNT is President of the new organization, and its other executive officers are gentlemen of recognized energy, influence and public spirit.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The Comptroller objects to extending Park-Place across the Park on the legal ground that the property is " pledged" for the City Debt; and to take it for a public street would divest the City of its title, dedicate the land to the public, and thus destroy the security of the creditors.

FLOUR steady and in fair demand; holders firm; sales 14,000 bbls., at $4 25 for extra State from Spring Wheat; $4 50 for extra Wisconsin from ditto; $4 55@ $5 for good to choice extra Canadian, Ohio, Michigan and Indiana; $5 25@$5 50 for double extras, the latter figure for very choice.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I am glad to see that the case of Bishop ONDERDONK has been brought before the public in your paper. In this as in every other matter our Church papers (Episcopal and non-Episcopal) can only present the side of the subject which squares with their notions of theological dogmas.

THE RING--THE TURF--CRICKET, ETC. The noted pugilists, "Australian" KELLY and ED. PRICE, are training actively for their approaching fight. The event is to take place in Canada early in October. Both the combatants are powerful men, and are said to be in "excellent conditions." KELLY is well known in New-York;

To the Editor of the New-York Times: It is very interesting to watch the progress of newspapers and ascertain how commuities are influenced by the kind of papers they read. The first NEW-YORK TIMES ever introduced into the section of country where the writer of this article resides, was introduced by himself.

By a curious coincidence, our City reporter yesterday morning passed from a series of observations on the ordinances prohibiting the keeping of swine, to the account of a riot in a drinking saloon of the Third Ward, with the remark, " speaking of Councilmen."

To the Editor of the New- York Times : I was gratified that in this morning's paper you called attention to our Post-office system, with especial reference to the delivery of letters in the City. You have spoken of one of the evils of that delivery. But there is another more annoying, and that is the unnecessary time consumed in the delivery of them.

Yesterday, in accordance with the announcement, the "Second Anniversary of the Fulton-street Prayer-Meeting" was celebrated in an appropriate and very interesting manner. The meetings for prayer have been held, for two years, in the North Dutch Church, corner of Fulton and William streets, and it was there that the anniversary services were held.

At a special meeting of the Trustees of the American Bank Note Company, held Sept. 23, 1859, the following preamble and resolutions were adopted: Whereas, It hath pleased Almighty God to remove from this scene of labor our friend FREEMAN RAWDON, one of the original corporators of this Company, and a member of its Board of Trustees;

At a meeting of the New-England Historic Genealogical Society, in Boston, on Wednesday, a painting was exhibited which was executed by a Natick Indian, named Solomon Wamsycon, about the year 1730. It is painted on a smooth pine board, about five feet long and sixteen inches in width, and represents three stags sporting under the trees, they being considerably taller than the trees aforesaid, which surround them.

The Eighth Annual Exhibition of the Aquidneck Agricultural Society commenced yesterday at their Fair Grounds, a short distance from this city. The weather was lowry and uncomfortable, yet not deterring from attendance the more enthusiastic admirers of " native true nobility." A little rain is no obstacle to those hardfisted farmers and their sympathizing wives,

The Court-room was more densely crowded than before the opening of the Court yesterday morning, a large concourse having been drawn to the scene by the announcement that counsel were to address the jury upon the case. The interest of tile jury and the bar, and of the audience without the rail, was sustained throughout the session.

The Massachusetts House of Representatives, by a vote of 112 to 31, have expunged the word "white" in the militia laws, which has hitherto stood a hindrance ?? the organization of colored military companies. This matter was debated at great length in the Constitutional Convention in 1853.

KINGSLEY-SMITH.--In Rockville Center, L. I., on Thursday, Sept. 22, at the M. E. Church, by the Rev. Mr. Gothard, Mr. Wm. C. KINGSLEY, of Westmorcland County, Penn., to Miss SARAH D. SMITH, of the former place.

PORTRAITS OF LONGFELLOW, THE HON. S. A. DOUGLAS AND DR. BAILEY.--The series of portraits of eminent Americans, statesmen, poets, philosophers, politicians, novelists and journalists, in course of publication by Mr. C. H. BRAINARD, of Boston, we have already had occasion to notice in terms of commendation.

At the secret session of the Police Commissioners, which commenced at 2 P. M. yesterday and lasted two hours, all the members were present and Mr. STILLMAN presided. The following members of the old Municipal Police force were reinstated: M. O'Brien, of the Fourteenth Precinct: W. Farrel, of the Seventeenth Precinct; J. II. Voss, of the Seventeenth Precint;

The Overland Mail brings us further particulars of the difficulties at San Juan Island, received at San Francisco by the steamer which left Victoria on the 22d August. The report of the landing of another detachment of U. S. troops on the Island is confirmed. The camp had been removed to a piece of woods immediately behind the barns belonging to the Hudson's Bay Company's station,

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Though but one of the many drops that compose the vast ooean of subscribers to tile NEW-YORK TIMES, et I hope the editor will pardon the intrusion of a personal statement of domestic grievances, growing out of political despotism. It is your honest, frank and straightforward views of justice that induces me to call on you for a public exposure of official pressure.

We have watched the reform movement in Baltimore with special interest, because we hope the time is not very distant when something of the kind may be attempted in New-York. The fact that the respectable citizens of Baltimore have had the energy and independence to attempt such a movement at all, shows that as yet they are decidedly in advance of our people.

There is little of local interest transpiring with us at present. The political campaign goes on apace, and continues to be marked by much bitterness. There seems to be no probability of an open fusion between the Republicans and the Anti-Lecompton men, but the chances are that they will fuse on the Congressional ticket, in favor of MCKIBBEN and BAKER, the last of whom is a Republican candidate.

Brief dispatches appeared in yesterday's TIMES, giving accounts of freshets in the Lehigh and Delaware rivers, in Pennsylvania. This morning we have additional telegraphic intelligence, to the effect that the rise in the Lehigh has been so considerable as to almost entirely submerge the village of Mauch Chunk. The damage done in various localities must be very considerable.

The Tribune has been badly sold. It regards seriously tile persiflage of the Herald about the enormous and preternatural things it is going to do this Winter. It believes, or at least pretends to believe, its announcements about reporting the proceedings of Congress verbatim by telegraph, and the kindred stuff with which it has been trying to bolster up tile dying hopes of its subscribers for tile past three months.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The account of the attempted suicide of L. THOMPSON, of Cheever-place, Brooklyn, in your issue of Tuesday last, is not in all respects correct. The facts are these: on Friday of last week, while writing a letter to those who had occasioned social differences,

I have just returned from a trip into the Counties of Franklin, Lykins and Johnson. The weather has been very pleasant during the past week; the crops look well and promise an abundant harvest. Corn never made a better appearance since the first settlement of our Territory.

SENATOR DOUGLAS AND THE SUPREME COURT.--In his Wooster speech Senator DOUGLAS discusses, though briefly, the bearing of the Dred-Scott decision of the Supreme Court upon his theory of Popular Sovereignty. It has been claimed by Southern men that the Court had decided slaves to be property under the Constitution,

Brooklyn Academy of Music--Only $10,000 More Wanted. An adjourned meeting of the subscribers to the stock for the proposed Academy of Music, was held last evening in the Polytechnic Institute. The Chairman of twenty-five, appointed at the last meeting to obtain subscriptions.

Additional intelligence from the disputed territory of San Juan Island reaches us, via San Francisco, by the Overland Mail. The report of the landing of another detachment of United States troops on the island is confirmed. A company of sappers and miners was expected to arrive by the next vessel from Vancouver, and it was understood that they would be set at work to erect fortifications.

The private secretary of Senor LERDO left NewYork on Tuesday last, as bearer of dispatches from Senor MATA to his Government, via New-Orleans. This messenger expects to reach New-Orleans in time for the steamer of the 27th inst., arrive in Vera Cruz by the 3d of October, leave again on the British steamer of the 5th for Havana, and reach this city by the middle of October.

The following notice of the British steamer Bogota is taken from the Liverpool Albion of Sept. 5. We publish it because of the interest which attaches to every improvement in the running of ocean steamers. The Bogota belongs to the line running between Panama and Valparaiso, touching at all the prominent ports on the coast, and which has been conducted with so much success during the last ten years.

It is barely possible that the name of TERENCE FARLEY may not impress general readers as one of those "few, immortal names that are not born to die." Not in standard literature, nor yet in the current issues of the publishing world, does the representative of the Farleian family honors secure a place; but journalism is not unfamiliar with his deeds, and on contract, surety.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: "Fiat Justitia " asks for the publication of tile Memorial of Dr. ONDERDONK, praying for the removal of his sentence of suspensions and of the paper said to be in the hands of the Rev. Dr. HAWKS, in which the suspended Bishop pledges himself, in the event of the removal of the sentence, to assign all his Episcopal rights and prerogatives to Bishop POTTER.

RAWDON.--In this City, on Thursday morning, Sept. 22, FREEMAN RAWDON, Esq., of the firm of Radway, Wright, Hatch Edson, aged 57 years. The funeral will take place from his late residence, No. 10 St. Mark's-place, on Saturday, Sept. 24, at 12 o'clock M. His friends and those of his family are respectfully invited to attend without further notice.

THE REGATTA--A SECOND FAILURE.--There was yesterday, a second failure of the race, of the New-York yacht Club, not, as on the previous day, because there was too much wind, but for the reason that there was none at all. The fleet, however, assembled at the appointed hour, with the exception of the Alpha, Manersing and Restless.

ERICSSON'S CALORIC ENGINE.-The appearance in our columns of an advertisement of ERICSSON'S Caloric Engines will probably recall to the minds of our readers the first experiment made with this new Motor, applied to ocean steam navigation in our harbor, some six or seven years ago.

An investigation into the charge of embezzlement preferred against WM. J. LANE, late transfer clerk of the Fulton Bank, was commenced on Saturday, before Justice OSBORN, at the Tombs. Mr. KERNOCHAN, the President of the Bank, in his affidavit gives a complete history of the defalcation, and describes the manner in which LANE operated.

RAISING OF A CROSS.-For the past week, daily services have been held at the Church of St. Benedict, located at New Brooklyn. This is a German Catholic Society of which the Rev. M. ALBRIGHT is minister.

Judge ROOSEVELT and some of his colleagues seem determined not to let the proposed abuse touching the Judges' salaries rest quietly in the grave to which Mr. FLAGG's obstinacy when Comptroller seemed to have consigned it.

The weather, during the day, has been chilly, rainy and melancholy ; in the morning it was doubly so, on account of the long faces worn by disappointed crowds who thronged the hotels, anxiously waiting for some news to turn up of the expected arrival of the Nova Scotian, with the long wished for English heroes of cricket.
In steamship Roanoke from Norfolk, Petersburgh, Mrs. Shider, Miss F. Eley, Miss A. Eley, Mr. Eley, W. J. Hamord and lady, W. H. Fyler, Capt. S. Browne, lady child and servant;

The New-Hampshire papers state that the effect of the recent frosts has been very severe, all the crops having been killed. On Thursday and Friday the White Mountains were covered with snow, apparently as fully as in January, and the occupants of the Tip Top and Summit Houses descending Mount Washington on Friday, found snow to the depth of six inches, with drifts of considerable magnitude.

THE GREAT EASTERN.-We find in our English files the following paragraph relating to the Great Eastern: "The transactions on Thursday at LLOYD's, in insurances on the Great Eastern, were few and small in amount. The risk has been taken very sparingly for the voyage out and home, including the trial trip, at six guineas per cent. against total loss.

The United States sloop-of-war Brooklyn, Capt. D. G. FARRAGUT, commanding, arrived at this port yesterday from a trial trip, having been absent nearly eight months. After landing Minister MCLANE at Mobile on the 5th inst., she proceeded to Pensacola to fill up with wood, water, coal, provisious and other stores.

IN PERIL, FROM FRIENDS.-The Mobile Register is charged with inconsistency by the NewOrleans Delta, for supporting DOUGLAS for President after his avowed hostility to the reopening of the Slave-trade,-a measure which that paper has hitherto warmly advocated.

The following Order has recently been issued by the General Superintendent of Police. The Captain of each District was simultaneously served with a request to have the same placed in the hands of every officer and patrolman of his precinct, and to post it conspicuously in his Station-house. The policemen are also requested to commit the rules to memory, and to conform thereto in every parcularti:

THE REVOLUTIONARY MONUMENT AT CHELMSFORD, MASS.-A telegram has already announced that the citizens of Chelmsford, Mass., erected a monument on the 22d September to the memory of the natives of that town who fought in the Revolutionary war. The Boston papers report the proceedings very fully.

ARREST OF J. W. BIGGS FOR SHOOTING ELEZAR PARISH.--Detective Officers Sampson and Devoe returned from Boston last evening with J. W. Biggs, who ran away from Augusta, Ga., some time ago, while under bonds to appear for train on a charge of having assaulted Elezar Parish with a dangerous weapon.

KNOWLES.-In this City, on Saturday morning, Sept. 24, NORMAN WHITE, only child of Wm. F. and Margaret Knowles, aged 7 months and 6 days. The relatives and friends are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, from the residence of his parents, No. 75 Horatio-st., this (Monday) afternoon, at 1 o'clock.

We publish this morning the details of one of the most agreeable imbroglios which we have in some time been called upon to lay before an ingenuous public. On Saturday morning last, at about 1 o'clock, a man was shot on Broadway, at the corner of Canal-street. Of course there was nothing remarkable in this.

The steamship North American, from Liverpool at 11.30 A. M. of the 14th inst., passed Father Point at 1.45 A. M. yesterday, en route to Quebcc. The steamer City of Baltimore, from Liverpool 14th, via Queenstown morning of 15th inst., passed Cape Race at 8.30 P. M. on Friday, and will be due in New-Yorkon Tuesday next.

MOTION TO SET ASIDE THE JUDGMENT DENIED. The Receiver of the Accessory Transit Company vs. Cornelius K. Garrison.--Superior Court--Special Term.--About two years ago the plaintiff commenced a suit against the defendant to recover large sums of money, amounting in all to nearly $2,000,000, of which it was alleged the defendant had defrauded the Company (while engaged as its agent in San Francisco) by means of false vouchers.

Boston has been celebrating. It is always celebrating. Its motto should be that of WALTWHITMAN, " I celebrate myself" This time DANIEL WEBSTER was the stalking-horse from behind which the solid men of Boston shot the arrows from their oratoric al long bows.
An interesting ceremony occurred, yesterday, at the Catholic Church in Yorville, of which the Rev. Father QUARTERS is pastor, with the Rev. ROBERT BYRNE as assistant.

The European advices to the 15th inst., which reached us yesterday, contain intelligence of the highest interest. As of more immediate concern at the present moment, the precedence is due to a sad calamity that has befallen the Great Eastern in the course of her experimental voyage, not, happily, affecting the programme of her coming trans. Atlantic trip, but attaching a melancholy interest to the early story of the ship. On the 9th inst.,

Shortly before 1 A. M., on Saturday, another shooting affair came off in Broadway, opposite the Brandreth House, within a couple of rods of the spot where VIRGINIA STEWART was mortally wounded about two months since by ROBERT C. MCDONALD.

WINTER GARDEN. --- The bill at this beautiful theatre is still unchanged. for a thoroughly delightful entertainment of the dramatic sort, nothing can be better than BOURCICAULT'S adaptation of the "Cricket on the Hearth."

MINING EXPLORATIONS AT LAKE SUPERIOR.The Ontonagon Miner, Sept. 17, states that the past summer, though unfavorable for such work by reason of the wet weather during the former part of the season, has been devoted mainly to explorations in those sections of the copper district most needing examination.

THE INSOLENCE OF RUFFIANISM.-On Thursday of last week the office of the New-York Daily News was entered by a ruffian named MCCABE, who perpetrated an atrocious personal assault upon the Editor of that journal, taking him at a disadvantage and adding the infamy of cowardice to the disgrace of open violence.

DEMAREST--CURTIS.--In this City, on Wednesday, Sept. 21, at the residence of the bride's grandfather, by the Rev. Cornelius T. Demarest, HENRY H. DEMAREST to HELEN M. CURTIS, both of this City. Bridgeport papers please copy.

DEMAREST--CURTIS.--In this City, on Wednesday, Sept. 21, at the residence of the bride's grandfather, by the Rev. Cornelius T. Demarest, HENRY H. DEMAREST to HELEN M. CURTIS, both of this City. Bridgeport papers please copy.

FRANCA.--A correspondent of the National Intelligencer has found, in the English Blue Book, the following very interesting extract from a letter written by Lord COWLEY, the British Ambassador in Paris, to his Government just before the outbreak of the Italian war: PARIS, Thursday, May 12, 1859.

A NUISANCE WHICH OUGHT TO BE ABATED.We were treated to the information last evening that BRANCH'S Hand had been seized, and that that gentleman himself was keeping out of the way to avoid the officers, who were in search of him under a warrant issued against him for havng libeled somebody's mother. It appears that the publisher of his little sheet had orders to keep" it going until it was stopped by a war.

The steamship Vanderbilt, from Southampton on the 15th inst., arrived at this port yesterday morning. The Saxonia arrived at Cowes on the 14th, and the Bremen on the 15th inst. The Vanderbilt's advices are one day later than those of the City of Baltimore off Cape Race, and the North American at Quebec.

The concluding Regatta for the season, of the New-York Yacht Club, came off yesterday, after three previous unsuccessful attempts to have the race--unfavorable weather and lack of wind obliging the Committee to postpone it from time to time. Had they known in advance how little wind there would be yesterday, it is certain that another day would have been selected for the occasion.

STABBED FOR HIS INTERFERENCE--On Sunday Mr. EUGENE CALLAHAN, of No. 141 Liberty-street, remonstrated with a Philadelphian named R. ROBINSON SCOTT, for using indecent and boisterous language in the cabin of a Jersey City ferry-boat, in hearing of the female passengers.

EXPERIENCES AND PRAYER-MEETINGS FOR MEN OF THE SEA.--The assemblies held under the direction of the "Business Men's Daily Union Prayer-meeting Convention," held at the Cooper Institute since Friday evening last, have been very well attended. The meeting Monday night was devoted to the interests of seamen.

Among the passengers by the Vanderbilt yesterday was MAURICE STRACKOSCH, Esq., and a operation troupe for the Academy of Music. The announcement, although brief, carries with it the destinies of opera in this City for the ensuing year. The troupe consists of 22 artists; some of them of first importance, others merely auxiliary.

SYMPATHY FOR THE ERIE RAILROAD WORKMEN--The meeting which was to have taken place, Satur day evening, at Hoym's Theatre, in the Bowery, for the purpose of expressing sympathy with the laborers who united in the strike at Bergen, was postponed to Saturday next, when it will be held at Union Square, at what hour is not yet decided.

A MANLY ACT.--Just as the Boston express train of Saturday was leaving the Bridgeport depot, a girl, 8 years of age, and daughter of Mrs. MAITINEE, fell between two cars upon one of the rails, while at. tempting to pass from one car to another. Mr. WM. H. CLAPP, of Hiram, Ohio, saw her fall,

The Common Council have held four regular sessions since tile contract for repairing tile City Hall was returned to them, approved by the Street Commissioner and Comptroller, but have never yet had tine to devote their attention to the trifling work of confirming it. Both Boards are busyVery deeply busy.

CITY MORTALITY.--The City Inspector reports the number of deaths during the past week to be 486, which is an increase of five, compared with the number that died the previous week, and an increase of 45, as compared with the corresponding week of last year. Of the number, 82 were men, 84 women, 172 boys, and 148 girls.

A Boston hay-dealer has been detected in a curious fraud. The hay was so loaded that a person could crawl into a hole left near the bottom of the cart, and in this place a colored man, in the employ of the hay speculator, was in the habit of concealing himself while the hay was being weighed.

A NEW FIELD FOR NEWSPAPER ENTERPRISE.--Competition is the life of business:--but common sense requires that the competition should be fair and legitimate, in order to yield either profit or honor. The merchant who should attempt to undermine a rival by falsehood and defamation would be set down as a sneaking scoundrel,

To the Editor of the New-York Times: It would seem from present indications that the peace and harmony of our Church are once more about to be disturbed by the agitation of a question which has been long dormant, and which we had hoped was forever at rest-the restoration of Bishop ONDERDONK to the jurisdiction of the Episcopate of this Diocese.

Mr. FRANCIS McCABE, who earned for himself a very unfavorable notoriety on Tuesday evening of last week by knocking down and seriously injuring the editor of the Daily News of this City, in his own office, has addressed to us a letter, not in extenuation, but in explanation of his behavior on that occasion.

BRANCH'S TYPES CONFISCATED AND HIS PAPER STOPPED--THE PRINTER AND VENDER ARRESTED.--Yesterday, Officer BROWER, of the City Hall Police Court, went to the printing office of FREDERICK CARRICK No. 172 Centre-street, and seized the type-forms of the libellous publication which STEPHEN H. BRANCH has issued for some weeks past under the name of the Daily Hand, taking the proprietor of the establishment into custody on a charge of printing an indecent publication.

Tile special correspondent of this paper on board the Great Eastern supplies a graphic ac count of the casualty which marked the first seavoyage of the mighty ship. The source of the calamity, as previously stated, was one of the casings surrounding the funnels or smoke-pipes passing from the fires below through the main saloon to discharge their smoke and flame in the outer air.

Since an account of the disaster on board the Great Eastern will be more interesting than the details of a purposely slow voyage, which was not intended as a trial trip, I will describe the particulars and results of the explosion before I proceed with the narrative commenced in my letter of the 8th.

The contest concerning DOUGLAS is waxing somewhat warm in the Southern States. In Georgia, especially, where senator TOOMBS has taken ground substantially in this favor, a feeling of intense bitterness has been aroused. The Macon Citizen denounces Mr. TOOMBS as "an unprincipled traitor to the rights and interests of the South in the Territories of the United States;"

The report that President MORA designed return ing to Costa Rica and appealing to the people is without foundation. He remains in New-York to await news from home, Instructions will be sent out to Mr. DIMITRY on the 5th of October, directing him to recognize at once the new Government, and open negotiations for the settlement of American claims.

JOHN WM. MCALPINE, of the numerous aliases, failed to restore Miss WOODBINE'S trunks yesterday morning, as his counsel stipulated for him should be done. In consequence he was brought up to receive the fullest measure of punishment which the law would allow. The Court was crowded, and great interest was manifested by a majority of the spectators in the result.

The United States Mail steamer Moses Taylor, J. MCGOWAN, Esq., Commander, from Aspinwall on the 19th, and Key West on the 22d, arrived at this port at an early hour this morning. Her advices from the Isthmus and the North Pacific are of interest. She brings nothing from Central or South America. The Treasure List, which may be found under the monetary head, (page 8,) foots up $2,042,363.

CASUALTIES.-The corpse of an unknown man was found, on Sunday afternoon, in the water at Pier No. 1 North River. Deceased appeared to be of middle age. The Board of Supervisors presented, yesterday, an edifying spectacle. Its action illustrated forcibly the chance of fair play which justice and decency have, when they come in collision with party greed. The Board of Supervisors, as our readers know, is so constituted that neither political party can have a majority of it.

The Oracles at Zurlch are dumb. The diplomatists, French, Austrian, Sardinian, are at their posts, but they are devoting themselves to eating the elaborate dinners of the Hotel Baur, and have left the fate of nations to the telegraphic clerks and the correspondents of the Press.

Last evening a most singular case came to light in the Sixth Ward, the dead body of a man, evidently murdered, being found in a house corner of Little Water and Worth streets. The scene of the tragedy used to be the resort of murderers and thieves, and years ago, when the Five Points were much worse than at present, " Crown's Corner," as it was known, was decidedly the worst locality in the neighborhood.

SINCLAIR presiding, met in this city on Monday the 25th day of July last, in the office of the Secretary of State for the Territory. Up to this time the United States Marshal had attempted in vain to rent a suitable room for the use of the Court.

BUXTON.--In this City, on Tuesday morning, Sept. 27, suddenly, after a short and severe illness, FRANCIS, son of John P. and Sarah A. Buxton, aged 4 years and 25 days. The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend his funeral, at the residence of his parents. No. 205 Wooster-st., this day, (Wednesday,) at 2 1/2 P. M.

The Government is in the receipt of dispatches to-day from China. They report the popular opinion there, even among British merchants, as against the action of the British and French forces in attempting to force the passage of the Peiho River. The Duke DI LICIGNANO, who has been recognized by our Government as Consul-General for his Majesty the King of the Two Sicilies, has arrived and entered upon his duties.

The steamship Circassian, Capt. CAMPBELL from Galway, on Saturday, the 17th inst., arrived a this port at 2 P. M. to-day. The Circassian has 300 passengers for New-York. She experienced heavy weather on the passage. Some of our readers may remember that we called attention some three months since to a gradual revival then going on in Spain of the question of Gibraltar, as curiously coincident with orders given by the Spanish Government for the construction in London of heavy iron gun-boats, suitable for sea-coast operations.

The great cricket match between the Eleven of England and Twenty-two of Eastern Canada is, of course, the great subject of interest here, just now. Nobody talks or writes or dreams of anything but cricket, Bats are discussed at breakfast as freely as beefsteaks, and balls, at dinner, as often as if they were eatable. All the world is here. The steamship Northern Light, from Aspinwall on the 20th September, arrived at this port yesterday morning. Her advices, which are two days later than those of the Moses Taylor, are unimportant. Our Aspinwall correspondent furnishes a summary of the news.

It does not often happen at any time of the year that all our meritorious places of entertainmcnt find an abundance of public patronage, and least of all at that anomalous season when the agonies of house-cleaning have barely come to an end.

CLAFLEN.--In this City. on Tuesday evening. Sept. 27, EDWARD A., youngest son of Osmond T. and Hannah Claflen, aged 6 years, 2 months and 14 days. The relatives and friends of the family, also the members of Palestine Lodge No. 204 F. A. Our county was disgraced yesterday by one of the most terrible and outrageous riots that has ever occurred within her limits. It is pretty generally known that, for weeks past, a most unpleasant feeling has existed between the large mass of our coal-miners and their employers.

THE PARDONING POWER IN ENGLAND--THE CASE OF DR. SMETHURST.--The absurdities to which "the pardoning power," as at present exercised in England, as well as here, occasionally leads has recently been well exemplified in the case of SMETHURST, the surgeon accused of poisoning a lady in order to get possession of her money.

THE JEWISH NEW-YEAR.--This is the Jewish New Year's day, and it is observed as such by all the Israelites throughout the land. The occasion is called the Rosh Hashanah, or New-Year, notwithstanding that the months are counted from the season of the Passover, in accordance with the ordinance of the law--Exodus xii., 2: " This month shall be unto you the beginning of the months;

DOMESTIC MARKETS. In New-York, during the past week, a good inquiry has prevailed for Wool, especially for Domestic, which has attracted more attention from manufacturers. Holders have not exhibited any disposition to press their supplies on the market. Prices have been well supported, and the tendency has been, in the main, favorable to sellers.

For the former, he has entered Starke, Prioress, Des Chiles, Cincinnati and Ochiltree, Mr. HARLAN has also entered his horses for the same races.

ARRIVAL OF THE GRANADA. The United States mail steamer Granada, from Havana on the 23d inst. at 3 P. M., arrived at this port yesterday morning. The Granada left New-Orleans on the 20th at 8 A. M., and arrived at Key West on the evening of the 22d at 6 1/2 o'clock.

We published, yesterday morning, a communication from our correspondent at Salt Lake City, describing a state of affairs which, we think we may assert without either exaggeration or fear of contradiction, is not to be paralleled by anything to be found within the jurisdiction of any civilized government on the globe.

BRUTAL MURDLR IN ERIE, PA.--The Erie papers bring us intelligence of a terrible murder which was perpetrated in that city last week, it appears that a man mamed PATRICK O'NEILL. and a desperate character named WILLIAM RICHTER, got into a difficulty, during which the latter, punged a knife into the former. He kept his feet for some time, and after crying "mother," "mother," he fell and expired.

Mr. EVERETT, in delivering his eulogy of WEBSTER the second time in Boston, prefaced it with the following remarks: Mr. President, Gentlemen of the Senate and of the House of Representatives: In rising to repeat, in your presence and at yourrequest, the discourse prepared for the dedication of the Statue of DANIEL WEBSTER, my first duty is one of grateful acknowledgment.

VERDI'S opera of " Ernani " was performed here last night to a good house. In vigorous conception, bold dramatic effects, and telling harmonic combinations, it is one of the most successful works of the composer, and one of the best. The distribution, although unique in some respects, was popular in its elements, and presented us with a new Elvira, in the person of Mme. GASSIR.

The proceedings of the Protestant Episcopal Convention of the Diocese of New-York began yesterday morning in St. John's Chapel in Varick-street. The attendance of delegates was large, being enough to fill the ground floor, which was reserved for them exclusively. The gallery was set apart for the public, which had its representation in a numerous assemblage of ladies.

Mr. Wise in New-York-Interesting Exhibitions and Experiments--The Fate of Mr. La Mountain. ASCENSIONS AT HAMILTON PARK. The promised balloon ascensions of Mr. WISE took place at Hamilton Park on the Third-avenue,near Sixty-sixth-street, yesterday, but not at the hour for which they were announced.

REPUBLICAN SENATORIAL CONVENTIONS.--The Republican Convention for tile Second Senatorial District met last evening in Republican Hall, No. 9 Court-street. On the first formal ballot, HENRY R. PIERSON received 17 of the 27 votes cast, anti was declared the nominee of the party. The nomination, on motion of GEORGE W. PARSONS, was made unanimous Mr. PIERSON is a lawyer by profession,

The much-abused Registry Law promises to work well at the coming election. In the rural districts, and in all the cities except New-York, we hear that the work of preliminiary canvassing progresses admirably. In Brooklyn it is already completed, and there is every promise that but little illegal voting can happen there in November.

In our New-Orleans exchanges we find very full particulars of the affray between Dr. ROBERT M. GRAHAM and Mr. ERNEST TOLEDANO, in which the former lost his life. Since the Saturday previous, says the Courier, it appears that Dr. GRAHAM, who had been drinking more than usual, had been denouncing Mr. TOLEDANO as a coward, etc., and uttering threats to shoot him whenever he met him.

Military Operations in the Interior--Condition of the Liberal Army. By the brig Nancy, Capt. GODFREY, at New-Orleans from Vera Cruz, we have advises from that port to the 3d inst. Very late intelligence had been received from the military operations in the interior, which were everywhere progressing satisfactorily.

BATTEE OF YORKTOWN.--The anniversary of the Battle of Yorktown will be celebrated with becoming sprit on the approaching 19th day of October. All the military at Old Point, consisting of seven companies, will be present, and the military of Baltimore will be invited to join in the celebration. It was at Yorktown that CORNWALLIS surrendered his sword to WASHINGTON.

Nothing that is the least exciting is now transpiring in the Territory. The Apache depredations are quite numerous, but trifling. We hear of them almost daily, and think nothing of it. Those who have any number of animals corral them nights and watch them days.

The Board of Aldermen, last evening, transacted considerable routine business, but very little that was of public interest.

The Royal mail steamship Asia, Capt. LOTT, which sailed from Liverpool at about 11 A. M. on the 17th September, arrived here at a late hour last evening. Her advices have been briefly anticipated by the arrival of the Circassian at St. Johns, that vessel having left Galway at a later hour on the same day. We add, however, details of the highest interest.

We have drawn public attention once or twice to the movement on foot in Baltimore for a thorough reform in the City Government. It is by no means certain that the Chinese authorities were guilty of the deliberate treachery by which the English journals attempt to explain and excuse the renewal of the war. They had stipulated in their treaty of last year that the English might go to Peking.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Without in the least wishing to question the motives which actuate the Corporation Counsel in his opposition to allowing extra compensation to the Judges of the Supreme Court in this district, the mater, I conceive, presents some very salient features which deserve a more dispassionate regard than they are likely to receive in the present heated state of the Corporation Counsel's epistolary efforts.

The telegraph has already informed us of the occurrence of a serious accident on this road, by which about twenty persons were injured. The Cincinnati Gazette has full particulars of the accident. It was caused by a broken rail, over which the locomotive passed safely. The baggage car was thrown partially off the track; while the hind trucks of the third were thrown partially into the White Water Canal.

Yesterday being the Jewish New-Year's Day--a festival of immemorial observance among all the Hebrew race--the occasion was appropriately observed in the several synagogues of this City, and doubtless in all other parts of the country. The sporting season is getting to be lively. The crisp air of Autumn appears to agree with the "Fancy," and they are active enough on the turf, in the ring, over the billiard-table, at the cricket-wicket, and promise a variety of entertainments for the gratification of those who find pleasure therein. THE PREDICTION OF A BUFFALONIAN.--The Buffalo Republic indulges itself in the following: "We predict that in less than ten years a steamboat will be constructed to run on our lakes which will be longer than the Great Eastern, and capable of carrying three thousand passengers and three thousand tons freight, and that she will make over thirty miles and hour, and be capable of running in Winter as well as Summer.

It is fact that will hardly be credited that during the last three days the receipts at the Palace Garden gate have been grater than they over were for three consecutive day at the Crystal Palace while the American Institute occupied it. The phenomenon is due to the fact that Fourteenth-street is the centre of an immense population of Pedestrians;

The Episcopal Convention opened at 9 o'clock A. M., yesterday. The morning services were solemnized in the presence of but comparatively few delegates. At a few minutes before 10, Bishop POTTER took his seat, and the informal recess, which had occurred at the close of the Prayers, was interrupted by a call to order.

THE KANSAS GOLD.--After all the contradictory reports which have reached us from the mines in Kansas, the fact seems at last settled that there is gold in the mining region, and that various shipments, to the aggregate amount of $104,000, have actually been made. A tabular statement, published in the Leavenworth Daily Times, gives a detailed account of the receipts from May 18, to August 15;

W. Winans, Esq., all of this City.

An engraver named Peter Gorman got on a spree recently in New-Orleans, and feeling the want of money he stopped Joseph Sass on Poydras-street, and, remarking to him that he looked like a man that had money, and had no business running around with money in his pocket, deliberately proceeded to search him . Mr. Sass, having taken his pocket-book out, held it in his hand behind his back, and quietly submitted to the search.

Tile Rochester Union, Sept. 29, has the following corrected list of the persons killed and injured by the fall of the Canal Bridge at Albion: KILLED (so far as ascertained).-Mr. Cornell and Mr. Stillson, of South Barre; Albert Wilcox, of West Kendall; Jane Avery, Lydia Harris and Thomas Cady, of Albion; Mrs. Veile, of Barre Thomas Handy, of Yates; Sarah Thomas, Augusta Martin, R.

Bursting of a Boiler at the Girard House One Man Killed and another Badly Injured. Soon after 6 o'clock yesterday morning a large boller in the cellar of the Girard House, on the corner of West Broadway and Chambers-street, exploded with a loud report, instantly killing a man named JOHN O' CONNOR and severely scalding JOHN COLLINS, the fireman.

POLICE COMMISSIONERS.--At a regular meeting of the Board, at 2 P. M. yesterday, all the members were present except Mayor TIEMANN, who had gone home unwell early in the day. The compliant against Dr. A. S. JONES, charging him with receiving a bribe, was dismissed. Messrs. STILLMAN and BAILEY declined voting with regard to this matter.

Carl Schurz has consented to spend a few weeks at the East, during this Fall, for the purpose of addressing Lyceums and lecture bodies upon general popular themes. He has two or three lectures prepared for this visit. In Wisconsin he is regarded as one of the most eloquent and influential speakers in the country.

We publish the following in justice to Mr. LILLIE, as we copied the extract alluded to: Correspondence of the Chicago Press and Tribune. The communication in your paper of the 3d inst. from your correspondent M., respecting the Bank robbery at Knoxville, is calculated to deceive the public in several respects. He says, "the safe is one of LILLIE'S manufacture, of chilled iron, with the approved combination lock."

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--MOZART'S opera of "Don Glovanni" was given here last night as a finale to the season--the customary finale always brilliant when intrusted to artists of the right stamp. The cast was excellent in names and the performance well voiced enough, but for the music of MOEART a degree of art is required which we do not find in an average Italian company, even when headed by a CORTESI.

REPUBLICAN ASSEMBLY NOMINATIONS.--The Republican Assembly Conventions, in Kings County were held last evening. The nominations were as follows: First District--George W. Stilwell. Delegates to Judicial Convention: S. N. Meeker, F. L. Dallon. Second District--D. O. Bradley, Delegates: E. D. Culver, Lucien Birdseye.

A little more than a week ago, in commenting upon the proceedings of the American Convention at Utica, we expressed our belief that they betrayed a profound and melancholy consciousness that the party, as a party, "had survived all its usefulness and most of its strength;''

A BISHOP WITHOUT A CHURCH.--The Diocesan convention of the protestant Episcopal Church of New-York yesterday passed a resolution recommending the House of Bishops to "take remedial action" with regard to the ease of Bishop ONDERDONK, of this Diocese, suspended in his office fourteen years ago for alleged misconduct of a highly immoral and disgraceful character.

CONKLIN.--In this City, on Thursday, Sept. 29, at her late residence, No. 269 West 24th-st., suddenly, ANN B., wife of Daniel CONKLIN, in the 49th year of her age. The relatives and friends of the family re respectfully invited to attend her funeral, from the residence of George Merritt, Esq., No. 167 West 20th-st., on Sunday morning, at 8 1/2 o'clock without further invitation. Her remains will be taken to Greenwood for interment.

BENNETT AND HIS BOILERS.--The humanizing effect of agricultural pursuits upon the character has been often sung by poets, but all their fancies have never painted a prettier illustration of the truth than is afforded by tile case of the Columbus of Plum Gut since he took to the culture of Pump. kins.

The list of Inspectors of Registry, appointed by the Board of Supervisors, and published in yesterday's TIMES, is a curiosity. An evening cotemporary has been studying the list in the light of the nationality of its members, and has made the discovery that out of the 609 names, 358 are unmistakeably Irish. It presents its readers with the following interesting statistics of what we may be forgiven for calling patronymics : Michaels, 24; Patricks, 22;

The information which the Department of State has received from Costa Rica, completes the unfinished story of revolution heretofore received. The momentary government which assumed the seat of the ejected MORA, has given away to a more settled organization, of which Senor MONTRAGETLA remains the chief, with VICENTE DE AUGUILAR, JULLAN VOLIA, and JESUS JIMENEZ, as his cabinet officers.

More than a week has elapsed since Mr. JOHN LA MOUNTAIN, accompanied by Mr. HADDOCK, a Watertown editor, started from Watertown on a balloon voyage. No tidings have yet been received of the party. When last seen, the balloon was proceeding due east, being then at an altitude variously estimated at from three to five miles.

Some time in the year 1841, a bed of young, or seedling oysters, was found near the east beach, at the mouth of Northport harbor, and there was a lively time among the oystermen, while the deposit lasted, in securing them for the purpose of transplanting.

The English Cricketers arrived in this City, yesterday morning, by the night boat from Albany. They were escorted to the Astor House where they will be located during their stay. The great Cricket match between these eleven Englishmen and twentytwo of tile United States is to commence this morning on the St. George's ground, Hoboken.

BY HIS EXCELLENCY, EDWIN D. MORGAN, GOVERNOR OF THE STATE OF NEW-YORK. The gathered harvest and the varied hues of Autumn admonish us that another year is drawing to a close. To us, as a State and a Nation, it has been a year of countless blessings.

THE NEW ROUTE FROM LAKE SUPERIOR TO RED RIVER,--Mr. DAWSON, the Canadian Engineer, appointed to survey the route for a new road from Lake Superior to the Red River District, has returned to Toronto, and makes a favorable report. The line from Thunder Bay to Dog Lake is nearly all laid out and will soon be practicable for goods and passengers.

ST . PAUL'S HOMES FOR THE POOR.--It has been determined to re-open the Homes for the Poor in connection with St. Paul's Mission Office, but on a larger scale than that of last year, if a sufficient amount should be contributed for the purpose. The season is at hand when persons ready and desirous to work for their living, but unable to procure employment, will be thrown in great numbers on our hands.

THE BALTIMORE COMMITTEE AGAIN.--The Reform Committee of Baltimore having failed in their endeavor to enlist the Mayor of tile city in support of their measures, have turned their attention to the Sheriff. In a long letter, addressed to that functionary, the Committee represent the probability of the recurrence of scenes of violence at the coming election, and call upon the Sheriff to aid them in the prevenlion of outrages upon respectable citizens.

About 2 o'clock this morning a fire broke out in the auger shop of the Prison at this place, and before the flames were subdued the file shop, the auger shop and the dye house were destroyed. The loss is very heavy. The file shop, occupied by JAMES HOMER Co., employed 90 men per day.

ACCIDENTAL AND VIOLENT DEATHS, CASUALTIES, ROCK, a laborer, fell from the stringpiece of Pier No. 17, East River, on Saturday afternoon, and was drowned. His body was found soon afterwards .... CHARLES SMITH, of New-Haven, a hand on board the steamboat Traveler, lying at Peck-slip, fell off the rail of that boat on Saturday night, and drowned before any one came to rescue him.

Every disaster and calamity must needs have a victim to atone for it. When things go wrong, it does not answer for national indignation to waste itself either upon the enemy or upon fate or any other abstraction. It must have an individual, who can be made to exhibit a palpable result in the fact of his humiliation.

The statement that a reply to Judge BLACK is in course of preparation under the supervision of Judge DOUGLAS, has no foundation whatever. I am assured that Judge DOUGLAS has not authorized, supervised or sanctioned ally reply to review of his article in Harper.

The European advices we received by the Hungarian, extend to Sept. 21. They are deficient in interest. The Coroner's inquest in the case of those killed upon the Great Eastern, in the recent explosion, had been rendered "accidental death"--the customary inanity.
