WINTER GARDEN.--The highly-successful drama of " Dot" will be played here every night until further notice. During the past week a succession of the most brilliant audiences rewarded the management. It is difficult to say which is the most successful, the house or the play. Both are beautiful. WALLACK'S THEATRE.--The old comedies are the order of the day here.

TOOMBS ON THE PRESS.--Senator TOOMBS, we all know, is not a gentleman who is apt to express himself either tersely or concisely. He frequently says a great deal more than he means, and sometimes says things he does not mean at all. We all remember how he declared war against England a year ago, in propria persona,

Among the improvements which the Metropolitan Police I aw was designed to make in the ineffectual system under which the crime of the City was brought to publicity and justice, there was not one that met with as early and general approval as that which directed the Commissioners to establish a house for the detention of witnesses, distinct from the places in which criminals themselves were confined.

BUFFALO, Monday, Oct. 3-6 P. M. FLOUR unchanged ; sales light. WHEAT in good milling order and shipping demand; sales 15,000 bushels No. 2 Springo Spring at 92c., afloat; 2,800 bushels Extra Milwaukee Club, at 97c.; 4,700 bushels Standard do., slightly damaged, at 92c., and 10,500 bushels prime white Canadian, at $1 15@$1 16, the market closing firm with little or no Upper Lake on the spot. CORN wanted; market continues bare.

That long-anticipated contest between the Elite of English Cricketers and the choice of American players, commenced on the Hoboken ground, yesterday. The weather was all that a cricketer could desire. The interest manifested throughout the City was extreme. As soon as the Eleven made their appearance on the steps of the Aster House, they were received by a large concourse of spectators.

The Teutonia from Southampton, on the 17th, furnishes no later European advices. From the London journals of the 17th there are various extracts of interest. The intelligence now received from Venezuela is not of an encouraging character. While the Government forces are successful in defeating the insurgents in every encounter, the insurrection erects its head at some other and distant point;

To the Editor of the New-York Times: A visit to the new Veterinary College, in Twenty-third-street, near Sixth-avenue, has given me great pleasure, and satisfied me that New-York at length possesses an institution where sick or lame horses are sure of receiving the best treatment, the want of which has long been seriously felt by the writer, in common with all other gentlemen who own horses.

Maj. R. S. Neighbors, Superintendent of Indian Affairs in Texas, was murdered in the town of Belknap, in that State, Sept. 14, by an unknown man, who stepped towards him in the street and shot him, and then fled. Maj. Neighbors had gone to Belknap to examine into the cause of some troubles with the Indians, and it is supposed that private revenge for some fancied injury prompted the act of his murderer.

Advices from Rio de Janeiro to the 25th of August are received. The following ships had just arrived there: Banshee, from Baltimore: Rhine, from Newcastle; Glenwood, from New-York; Marion, from Pernambuco; Chevalier, from Bahia, and North Point, from New-York. The ship Paladin had sailed for Baltimore, and the Imperader for New-Orleans.

If, as politicians say, the price of liberty is eternal vigilance, our liberty may be considered permanent. Our politicians never go to sleep. They watch by day, and watch by night. We have forty thousand officers to elect in Ohio, and, you may depend, it keeps us quite busy.

The screw-steamship Teutonia, from Southampton on the 17th inst., arrived at this port yesterday. The intelligence she brings has been anticipated by the Asia at this port, and, telegraphically, by the Hungarian at Quebec; but we obtain London papers one day later than those previously received. There is nothing additional of interest. The correspondent of the Times writes from Vienna on the 13th:

COMMON COUNCIL.--An Adjourned meeting of the Board of Aldermen was held last evening, and considerable routine business was transacted. A communication was received from the Mayor, remitting the penalty incurred by the contractor for delay in the grading and paying of Douglass-street from Nostrand and Vanderbilt avenues. The usual order to publish was made.

The steam plow has arrived at last. It marched into the yard adjoining Palace Garden on Friday, and took a few turns about the premises to demonstrate its ability to turn short corners and travel at ease, but the plows were not permitted to disturb the sod--there was hardly enough of it to make it worth while to spoil the walking.

By the arrival at Boston of the brig Monticello, we have received Hayti files to Sept. 4. The Moniteur Haitien gives the following official account of the discovery of the conspiracy against the present Government: "The events of this week, which have just resulted so seriously, had a commencement that might have been expected to lead to such consequences.

The Ninth Annual Fair of the Wisconsin State Agricultural Society is held this week in this city. The exhibition is exceedingly creditable, and the attendance of visitors large. Monday and Tuesday were occupied in receiving entries and arranging stock and articles. On Wednesday the Fair was formally opened by the president of the Society.

The canvass for Mayor, although the election is still two months off, excites a keener interest than the State contest, which occurs in November. No one cares a pin for the State election, except as it may affect the Presidential canvass.

We have received the following affidavit from CORNELIUS WOOD, who, in the Democratic Convention at Syracuse, knocked or pushed Mr. JOHN STRYKER, President of the Convention, off the platform:-- City and County of New-York ss.--CORNELIUS WOOD. being duly sworn, doth depose and say:

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The ladies of the Five Points Mission (site of the Old Brewery) prefer an earnest request for books for their school library. The present stock has been read and reread by the children until its interestisexhausted. Books they will read, and if we do not supply them with good, they will read bad ones.

OPENING OF THE LAW DEPARTMENT OF THE NEW-YORK UNIVERSITY.-The Winter term of the Law Department of the New-York University was formally inaugurated yesterday morning, between the hours of nine and eleven. The interval was occupied by Mr. WEDGE WORTH, the secretary and one of tile Law Faculty, in entering students desirous of attending the lectures on Jurisprudence which will form the Winter Course.

BEATTYS.--In this City, on Monday, Oct. 3, after a short illness, MARY, wife of Benjamin Beattys, and daughter of G. P. B. and Nancy Hoyt, aged 25 years, 1 month and 12 days. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend her funeral, on, Wednesday morning, Oct. 5, at 10 o'clock, from No. 34 Jefferson-st.

A dispatch was received in this city this evening from Prof. LA MOUNTAIN, dated Ottawa, C. W., Oct. 3. It is as follows: Lost all. Landed three hundred miles north of Watertown, in the Canada wilderness. We were four days without food. Brought out by Indian guides in canoes, Please inform my wife. (Signed.) JNO. LA MOUNTAIN. OTTAWA, C. W., Monday, Oct. 3.

Horse-railroads in the cities seem to be productive of a great deal of trouble. In Philadelphia, the Sabbatarians will not permit the ears to run on Sunday, and in Cincinnati the permission granted to two different companies to lay three tracks in Fourth-street has roused the ire of all the property owners in that section.

The burning of the Lion Lager Bier Brewery on Sunday night proves to have involved a much more serious destruction of property than was at first supposed. The brewery buildings were near the Bloomingdale Road, between One Hundred and Seventh and One Hundred and Ninth streets, where they were erected about two years ago by Messrs. ALBERT SPEYERS Co.

The Oyer and Terminer was opened yesterday morning. There being not a sufficient number of the panel of tile Grand Jury present when called, those who were present were discharged for a fortnight, when all additional panel will be called. The People vs. Robert Macdonald.--The prisoner is indicted, it will be remembered, for the murder of Virginia Stewart, whose unhappy end caused so much sensation a few months since.

First Assistant Postmaster-General KING arrived here yesterday for the purpose of examining into the merits of the "Johnson contract" for carrying the California mail, by ascertaining from personal inquiry what facilities the contractor has for making the isthmus transit in case they are sent by that line tomorrow.

Lord DERBY, the ex-Premier, is about, if report speaks truly, to exercise his "rights of property" in a manner for which, we venture to say, no parallel is to be found in tire history of tenures since the day of GLANVIL and LITTLETON; and if he carry out his purpose he will practically assume a power such as has been vested in no subject in Europe for more than a century and a half.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The Territories of the United States are governed under " The Congress shall have the power to dispose of, and make all needful rules and regulations respecting the Territory of the United States," or under" a right to govern, the inevitable consequence of the right to acquire territory."
The recent correspondence of Lord JOHN RUSSELL, at London, with M. DE RECHBERG, at Vienna, has hardly received all the attention which it deserves on this side of the water.

A JACK TAR TROUNCED.-Thos. Hanley landed on Monday from a long sea voyage. In search of relaxation, he wandered into No. 13 Oliver-street, a house of entertainment of which Lewis Keene is proprietor. Hanley danced and drank with the girls, and afterwards quarrelled with the men, who beat him badly on his head, and stole $10 from him.

The mails by the steamship Hungarian, whose arrival at Quebec has been already announced, reached this City yesterday afternoon. We obtain some interesting extracts from our London files, which extend to the 21st ult., inclusive. THE SAN JUAN BOUNDARY DISPUTE. OPINIONS OF THE ENGLISH PRESS.

BOARD OF EDUCATION.--A regular meeting of the Brooklyn Board of Education was held last evening. The first part of the session was occupied in disposing of a bill of about $250, presented by a carpenter for extra work on a school-house. It was finally referred to the Law Committee, with instructions to defend the suit, which had been commenced, to recover the amount of the bill.

AN APPEAL FOR AID--The Christion Adrecate contains the following notice. "The Rev. ?? BOWMAN, a colored brother, and himself an emancipated slave, is now in the City soliciting money to redeem a brother from Slavery. He has unexceptionable testimonials of character and standing in the Church , and is entitled to full confidence.

It proposes as an offset, that "Catholic and Adopted Citizen voters select for the recipients of their suffrages those candidates on the Republican

At the meeting of the Board of Supervisors at 3 o'clock P. M., yesterday, all the members except Supervisor WEISMANN were in their seats, and many spectators were present.

MARSHALL to Mrs. DEBORAH MARSHALL, both of Poughkeepsie. LAWRENCE-COTHEAL.-In this City, on Tuesday morning, Oct. 4 at Trinity Chapel, by the Rev. Dr. Berrian, SAMUEL LAWRENCE to CAROLINE P., youngest daughter of the late Henry Cotheal.

THE FLOATING HOSPITAL.-The approach of tile stormy season rendering it expedient, if not perilous, to keep tile Falcon at her moorings in the lower bay, has caused her removal to a more secure anchorage near the old Quarantinp.

It is a notable evidence of our great commercial prosperity that our Collectors of Customs are, as a rule, so much absorbed in gathering the dues of the Government that they quite lose the power of collecting their own wits in a way to be useful to themselves or others.

The marvelous discovery of a genuine oyster fundum in Long Island Sound, and within the jurisdiction of New-York, whereof all Fulton Market and the cellars of Broadway " do ring from side to side," when contemplated from the point of view of our national politics, threatens the most serious consequences.

Under the call of the General Committee of the City and County of Albany, the Democrats held a grand ratification meeting at the Capitol to-night, to indorse the State nominations and rejoice over the reunion of the party. Large numbers of persons assembled in the Park of the Capitol, where a speaking platform was erected.

A sort of revival is. in progress in the ranks of the Democratic Party. The conviction has dawned upon the Democratic mind that the work of corruption and degradation has gone about as far as is consistent with its safety, to say nothing of its respectability.

REVELATIONS OF THE RULING CLASSES.--Bully after bully of those who professionally attended the Syracuse Convention, is furnishing us with his version of the affair in the shape of an affidavit. The "Benicia Boy" has already set before the public, under oath, the nature of his mission on that august occasion.

A BOSTON LAWYER ATTACKING TIIE BENCH.The Hon. JoHN C. PARK is one of the oldest and ablest of the criminal lawyers of Boston; a wag as well as an astute counselor, and a defiant individual as well as the leader of the Boston Bar. The new rule of the Superior Court of the State, which requires counsel to stand during the examination of witnesses, has provoked a vigorous opposition

MEETING OF THE HISTORICAL SOCIETY-ADDRESS BY MR. J. A. POOR, OF PORTLAND.-The Historical Society met last evening, for the first time since the Summer vacation. The Hon. LUTHER BRADISU, President of the Society, occupied the Chair.

The indomitable fillibuster, Gen. WALKER, has again eluded the United States officials, and is by this time on his way to Nicaragua. A clearance from New-Orleans for the steamship Philadelphia was applied for yesterday morning, with the understanding that she was to convey Gen. WALKER and a number of his followers to the Chiriqui Gold Mines or Graves.

THE GREAT EASTERN AGAIN.--The Coroner's July, as we have already stated, failed to fix the responsibility for the accident on board the Great Eastern upon any one. It was caused, unquestionably, by negligence on the part of the person in charge of the paddle engines,--but who that was no one seems to know.

An important Convention of ministers and laity of the Baptist denomination, having for its object the formation of a Sunday-School Union for the country at large, was held in this City yesterday. The success of similar organizations in the Methodist Episcopal and other Churches, has had its influence in originating the movement.

The hotels are closed, the avenues deserted, and a solemn stillness seems to pervade the entire city. The Allgemeinc Zeilung figures up the cost to the immediate parties to the war, and also to the neutral Powers who were required to make preparations for contingencies,

BLANCK.--In this City, on Tuesday morning, Oct. 4, HENRY C., youngest son if John W. and Eliza E. Blanck, in the 3d year of his age. The friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral from the residence of his father, No. 67 Vandam-street, on Wednesday, Oct. 5, at 2 o'clock, without further notice.

Collector HATCH has refused a clearance of the steamer Philadelphia, for Aspinwall, because it is alleged the steamer is engaged to take Gen. WALKER and two or three hundred men from Texas, Alabama and elsewhere, now encamped below this city, and ready to start for Nicaragua. They are ostensibly bound to the Chiriqui diggings, and intending to leave on the 5th.

At 10 o'clock yesterday morning the Hoboken ground was again thronged with spectators, greatly exceeding the numbers present the day before, and it was with difficulty room could be found for the Eleven to make their hits. Everything, however, went off exceedingly well, the officers, in the efforts to restrain the curious, receiving in all cases the utmost courtesy from the spectators.

The reported receipts of the principal kinds of Produce since our last have been 9 bbls. Ashes, 18,797 bbls. Flour, 1,375 bbls. Corn Meal, 15,321 bushels Wheat. 9,300 bushels Corn. 11,250 bushels Barley, 34,385 bushels Oats, 326 pkgs. Provisions, 344 bbls. Whisky. ASHES--Sales have been reported to-day of 60 bbls. Yesterday, at the opening of tile Court of General Sessions, a telegraphic dispatch was received at the District-Attorney's office, from Albany, announcing that tile Judges of the Court of Appeals had affirmed the judgment of tile Court of Oyer and Terminer, in this City, in the case of James Stephens, convicted of the murder of his wife by poison. Stephens was tried before Judge Roosevelt in March last, the trial lasting nineteen days.

OUR RELATIONS WITH BRAZIL-We have already mentioned the reception by the President of M. LISBOA, the new Brazilian Minister. Besides the ordinary phrases of congratulation usual on such occasions, the President further observed: " That the two countries were bound together by the reciprocal interests of trade and commerce;

MORE ABOUT THE GREAT EASTERN.-The NEWYorkr TIMES, which is doing all that the Herald brags of, but fails to perform, has published several letters from England relative to the Great Eastern,-letters over the sobriquet of "TUbal Cain," which have given us more information upon the subject than all the longwinded and elaborate reports of the London papers.
The U. S. steamship Cahawba, J. W. SMITH, Commander, from New-Orleans via Havana, arrived here yesterday at noon.

A MATTER OF TASTE.--Mr. DICKINSON, in addressing the great ratification meeting at Albany, though as happy as he usually is in many of his "hits." nevertheless made some statements which he must have been aware would be received with some little incredulity. One of them was that the Democratic Party "had a divine mission to curry out, but that this must be done by human agency."

FROM WASHINGTON. The British Government, Sustained by the Buchanan Administration, engage to expel Walker and his Men from Nicaragua. RETURN OF GEN. HOUSTON TO THE SENATE , , Special Dispatch to the New-York Times. WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Oct. 5. Lord LYON, the British Plenipotentiary, had a protracted interview with Secretary CASS to-day, in regard to the departure of the Nicaragua expedition.

AMERICAN BIBLE UNION. Annual Meeting at Broome street Church--Organization--Reports of the Treasurer and of the Managers--Proceedings and Address. The Tenth Annual Meeting of the American Bible Union, a well-known association, which has for its aim the preparation and diffusion of a revised translation of the scriptures, was commenced yesterday morning in the church, corner of Elizabeth and Broome streets.

The uncertainty about the route by which the mails were to be dispatched to California, the news from New-Orleans regarding Gen. WALKER, and the anxiety manifested by the prominent fillibusters in this City to find some pretext by which they might manage to join their illustrious chef without subjecting themselves to prosecution for violation of the neutrality laws, combined to throw the City into a state of unusual excitement yesterday.

KING's COUNTY BOARD OF SUPERVISONS.--An adjourned meeting of this Board was held at the County Jail, last evening. Report from the Keeper of the Penitentiary was received, by which it appears that during the month of September there were committed to that institution 128 persons--males, 53; females, 75.

The election is over, and the speculations in my last have been fully realized. LATHAM (Administration Democrat) has been elected Governor by from eight to twelve thousand majority, and the whole regular Democratic State ticket is also successful. Although JOHN 0. MEARA, Anti-Lecompton candidate for State Printer, ran far ahead of his ticket, he is still supposed to be defeated.

SUPPRESSING LIBELS.--The Recorder treated the Grand Jury on Tuesday to a tolerably long dissertation on the law of libel--somewhat unnecessarily, as it seems to us, seeing that it merely heralds the trial of BRANCH and a parcel of fellow-offenders, who live by the publication of obscene trash.

Could one of those maniacs who go up in balloons have hovered a while this morning over what three days ago was a green field, a mile and a half north of Albany, he might have looked down upon an extemporized city of more inhabitants than any one not in the habit of reporting political meetings and given to estimating crowds, could easily conceive to be crowded within such marrow limits.

The Evening Post is willingly incredulous in regard to the movement for reforming the organization of the Democratic Party. Like a thorough partisan, as it professes to be, it denounces the Democratic Party as too rotten for reform, and affects to think it very strange that the respectable men in its ranks do not cut loose from their associates and "join the Republicans."

A NEW SENSATION PREACHER.--These last few years have been singularly prolific in odd, out-of-the-way, striking, eccentric preachers. Some of them draw audiences by their talents, and others by their singularities, and some by a combination of both ; but of all the oddities with which the pulpit has lately been illustrated, we venture to say the Rev. HENRY CLAY DEAN, as described by the Dubuque Times, is, in every respect, the most remarkable.

There is little room for doubt as to the successful inception of a fresh piratical expedition to Nicaragua. The United States officials at the South admit their defeat. The exact numbers that have made their escape from Charleston, Mobile, New-Orleans, and, perhaps, from other points, is still a matter of conjecture; but there is reason to regard the estimate of 2,000 as not excessive.

MITCHELL--POST.--In this City, on Wednesday, Oct. 5, by the Rev. Joel Parker, D. D., the Rev. ARTHUR MITCHELL, of Richmond, Va., to HARRIET EDITH, daughter of Dr. Alfred C. Post, of New-York. BRAKER--JESSUP.--In this City, on Tuesday morning, Oct. 4, By the rev. Dr. Armitage, Mr. GEORGE BRAKER to Miss ANN ELIZABETH JESSUP, both of this City.

DAMAGES FOR BEING PUT OFF A RAILROAD 'TRACK.-A suit of a somewhat singular character was tried at the Mansfield (Ohio) County Court last week. Some time ago a lady, the wife of the Postmaster at Salem, got on the cars of the Cleveland, Columbus and Cincinnati Railroad at Crestline, intending to go to Salem. She had along with her a couple of small children.

THE LIQUOR AND LAGER DEALERS.--Our reporter yesterday stated that the number of members of the Liquor-dealers' Association was between 0,000 and 7,000, and added that " the society are disposed to acquiesee in all reasonable demands of the authorities respecting the non-sale of liquor on Sunday."

The Board of Education met last evening, tile President, Mr. WARREN, filling tle Chair. The Sixteenth Ward asked for arrearages of salaries of Messrs. McNary and Foulke, Principals of tile Male Department of the school in that Ward. The salaries of these gentlemen were fixed at $l,800 a year, but subsequently the Board of Education adopted a rule that no Principal be paid more than $1,500.

The capture of the Caucasian Chief, S0HAMYL, now authoritatively reported from St. Petersburg, will, no doubt, evoke a good deal of sentimental sorrow from hundreds of tenderhearted people, who think savages and hillrobbers the most interesting of mankind, and delight to take sides with raw flesh and RousSEAU against tooth-brushes and civilization.

REPUBLICAN CENTRAL COMMITTEE. A meeting of the Republican Central Committee was held last night at their rooms. No. 618 Broadway, the attendance being quite full. The session was principal occupied in the discussion of a matter in dispute between the Committee and the Seventeenth Ware Republican Association.

MURDER AT BLACKWELL'S ISLAND--A VAGRANT BENTEX TO DEATH BY A LUNATIC.--Soon after midnight, on Tuesday, a shocking homicide was committed at the Workhouse, Blackwell's Island. JOHN McGET, a man eighty-two years of age, who assisted in building the institution, and has been one of its inmates for many years, was the victim.

The Philadelphia Ledger, Oct. 3, says: "This morning, agreeably to an order of the Secretary of the Navy, Com. STEWART will hoist his flag on board the Receiving Ship, at this Navy-yard, as Senior Flag-Officer of the United States Navy-a rank conferred upon him by a recent act of Congress. Today the veteran Commodore will inspect the Wyoming and Crusader, and it is expected that both will leave this evening or to-morrow.

Late last night an official dispatch was received from New-Orleans stating that the steamer Philadelphida had been seized by the U. S. Marshal. An answer was immediately transmitted, directing the retention of the Captain and crew in view of judicial proceedings, and to hold the vessel, which, if it shall be found she was employed in a filibustering expedition, will be subject to forfeiture.

MILITARY INTELLIGENCE--THE LATEST CONSERVATIVE LOAN--SEVERE PENALTIES DIRECTED AGAINST AMERCIAN VOLUNTEERS. By an arrival at New-Orleans, advices from Tampico to Sept. 26 have been received. The news principally concens the war in the interior. From the Liberal camp the letters make light of the recent engagement between WOLL and DOBLADO.

The community was yesterday profoundly shocked at the announcement of the self-inflicted death of Mr. CHARLES MORTIMER LEUPP, for many years well known as a prominent leather merchant. The deplorable event occurred on Wednesday evening, at the residence of the deceased, No. 23 Madisonavenue.

ARREST OF A MURDERESS.--On Sunday evening last, a man named MICHAEL CORNELIUS, living in the Sixth Ward, was fount in Donovan's-lane by Officer GILGAN, suffering from the effects of a stab in the left breast. He was conveyed to the City Hospital, and died there Wednesday evening. The inhabitants of the lane denied all knowledge of any disturbance in that neighborhood during the Sabbath.

The prize-fight between Australian KELLY and ED. PRICE came off this afternoon at Point Abino, and was won by the latter in twelve rounds, and forty minutes. KELLY was seconded by HARRY GRIBBEN and JEMMY MASSEY, and PRICE by HEENAN and MACKEY. At 1:40 P.M. the men shook hands and stripped for the fight.

I had intended to write you a long letter from tills place, descriptive of the Annual Fair of the Agricultural and Mechanical Association of this Province, but I fear there is little to say. The ceremonies which were to have taken place, were not performed with the anticipated eclat, because of the death of the son of Sir EDMUND HEAD, the Governor-General.

Chamber of Commerce. COLLISIONS AT SEA-NECESSITY FOR MORE LIGHTHOUSES-NEW-JERSEY COMPLAINS OF A NEWYORK NUISANCE. The regular monthly meeting of the Chamber was held yesterday-the President in the Chair.

A TOUCH OF MONOMANIA.-That distinguished orator, Mr. WENDELL PHILLIPS, in a recent lecture in Boston, is reported to have said that "the man who would strike the head from the statue recently erected to WEBSTER would do a great service and his name would be immortalized."

THE EVERGREENS CEMETERY.-The annual election of Trustees and Inspectors for the Evergreens Cemetery Company, took place at East New-York on Monday last, but owing to a threatened disturbance along the parties interested, the votes were not counted until yesterday. Even then it was found necessary to canvass them in the private office of the Deputy Superintendent of Police in Brooklyn.

PLATT.--In this City, on Thursday, Oct, 6, Thomas Platt, Esq-, in the 39th year of his age. The relatives and friends of the family, and also of his father-in-law, Peter D. Collins, Esq., are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, from Christ Church, corner of 5th-av. and 35th-st., on Sunday afternoon, Oct. 9, at 1 1/2 o'clock, without further invitation. HEDDEN,--In this City, on Thursday, Oct. 6, James HEDDEN. aged 63 years.

BOARD OF ALDERMEN. Obstructions in the Harbor-A Snug Sum for the Widow of Judge Oakley-The Chief Engineer of the Fire Department Declines a Gold Medal-The Reason of It. The Auditor's Quarterly Report was sent to the Board of Aldermen, last evening, and it was directed that 2,000 copies of it be printed.

Dr. Smethurst, the English convict lately reprieved, is allowed, it seems, many indulgences in prison. He occupies a cell by himself, and under the special order of the visiting magistrates he is permitted to have the free use of writing materials, and he is relieved from the performance of the usual labor, such as picking oakum, which is generally required from a convict under similar circumstances.

Kansas is ready for another application for admission into the Union. The Wyandotte Constitution has been submitted to the popular vote, and, according to the telegraph, has been approved by a very large majority of the people.

THE LATE STEAMBOAT ROW AT ANNAPOLISSENTENCE OF THE RIOTERS.- The trial of GEO. DEFORD, JAMES COSGROVE, JOHN HOWARD and WM. REESE, accused of having been engaged in the rioting on board the steamboat Express, on the 21st of August last, while conveying some passengers to a camp-meeting, was concluded in Baltimore on Wednesday.

The steamship Canada, bringing news from Europe to Sept. 24, arrived last evening at Halifax. Owing to the prevalence of a severe storm, the express dispatched with the telegram to the Sackville office, was so retarded as to prevent the possibility of presenting the advices in this morning's issue. They will appear in our Evening Edition.

The litigation as to the title of this great quicksilver mine, which is now going on before the United States Courts in California, has taken a shape somewhat novel in our jurisprudence, and has led, among other singular incidents, to the unusual spectacle of a considerable number of the high official and ex-official men of the Mexican Government voyaging from their own country to San Francisco,

Gen. WALKER, the telegraph informs us, has once more started for Nicraragua, with one hundred of his followers, for the purpose of resuming his old trade. It would be somewhat ludicrous if we were to set about discussing the pros and cons of fillibustering at this time of day, or Gen. WALKER'S prospects in his "beloved country," Nicaragua.

The Courrier des Etats Unis informs us that an ingenious French chemist at Lyons has just hit upon an expedient which promises to make the "dusty highway" as much a dream of the past as the "blazing hearth" has become since the roaring back-log gave place to the black furnace hole in the floor.

To the Editor of the New-York Times. Having read the article of your correspondent " Looker-on from New-York," dated " Mansion House, Buffalo," on "Railroad and Canal Matters," I ask the privilege of a reply, especially as that article does great injustice to the railroads of New-York, and is well calculated to seriously injure the carrying trade of the State.

Verdi were heard along the line of procession.

The proceedings were introduced by the ordinary devotions, in which several of the delegates took part.

EXPLOSION AT THE SCHAGHTICOKE POWDER MILLS.--At 2 1/2 o'clock. Thursday morning, one of the wheel mills attached to the Schaghticoke Powder works, of which Messrs. SWIFT, MASTERS and others are proprietors, was blown up, killing a workman named BENEDICT.

The advises by the Canada are of unusual interest. The mystery which for more than ten years has enveloped the fate of Sir JOHN FRANKLIN and his exploring party has been cleared up by the steamer Fox, dispatched last winter by Lady FRANKLIN, on a final searching expedition. The logbooks and journals of the lost vessels had been found,

There is but little additional intelligence, to-day, relative to the fillbusters. An official dispatch, from New-Orleans, states that the tow-boat Panther has been seized, together with the Captain and crew, and arrangements have been made to arrest the party who went down tile river, as far as the South Pass, in that vessel. The opinion is expressed in the same telegram that the whole illegal scheme has been frustrated.

MOZART HALL ASSEMBLY CONVENTIONS.' The Mozart Hall Democratic Assembly Conventions met last evening in their respective Districts. There was but little excitement, and no fighting. The result was as follows:

A BOY ARRESTED FOR STEALING ATTEMPTS TO COMMIT SUIOIDE.--Yesterday afternoon Officer BROWN, of the Second Precinct, arrested a boy named WILLIAM WELSH, for stealing staves from the shop of S. C. BROWER, corner of Front and Adams streets.

The Farmers' Protracted Evening meetings have come to a conclusion. They have been exceedingly entertaining, and it was hard for them to part at last. The three great topics of discussion have been the Grasses, Manures and Soiling. Some of Mr. JOHN STANTON GOULD's statements on the first of these subjects stuck in the crop, especially of the Onondaga people.

WHY TIIE CHINESE WAR WAS RENEWED.The excuse given for the renewal of tile Chinese war by the Admiral of the squadron, as well as by the organs of opinion in England has been that the Chinese refused to permit the English and French Ambassadors to proceed to Peking to effect tile ratification of the treaty of Tien-tsin.

FUNERAL OF THE LATE MR. LEUPP.--The funeral of Mr. CHARLES M. LEUPP took place yesterday afternoon, from his late residence, at the corner of Twenty-fifth-street and Madison-avenue. A large number of sympathizing friends assembled to pay the last tribute of respect to the deceased. Among them were many of those prominent in the business circles of the City.

Repeated attempts have been made, says the Lafayette Courier, within a few months past, to log up the night Express on the N. A. and S. Railroad, a few miles below Crawfordsville. A heavy piece of timber through which the read passes had been selected for this diabolical purpose.

OPINION OF THE COURT SUSTAINING PLAINTIFF'S DEMURRER. Palmer, Assignee, , vs. Elisha Smedley. INGRAHAM, J.--The plaintiff sues upon a note given to the Antioch College for a scholarship. The answer sets up as a defense that the note was given upon a representation that the college would be located in Western New-York, and that the Directors had decided on such location, which the defendant believed to be true, when it was in fact not true,

MUSIC IN THE CENTRAL PARK.-The melancholy days have come, the saddest, if not the shortest, of the year; and their depressing influence has made itself felt in the delightful ramble of the Central Park. Mr. OLMSTED, too, the very "pulse of the machine," has gone to Europe, partly for his health, partly to do the City service in his arduous pursuit of the true standard of excellence in Parks.

The Royal Mail steamship Canada, Capt. LANG, left Liverpool at 3 P. M. of the 24th, and arrived at Halifax at 11 A. M. of Thursday, the 6th inst. The Canada reports, Sept. 29, lat. 53 degrees 28' N., lon. 28?? 54' W., at 10:30 A. M., passed Royal Mail steamship Europa. . The steamer City of Washington, from New-York, arrived at Liverpool at 11 P. M. of the 21st.

PLATT.--In this City, on Thursday, Oct. 6, THOMAS PLATT, Esq., in the 39th year of his age.

VAN PELT.--In this City, on Sunday morning, Oct. 9, after a short and painful illness, which he here with Christian fortitude to the divine will, of consumption, WILLIAM VAN PELT, in the 31st year of his age. Funeral on Tuesday, at 1 P. M., from the Norfolk-St., Baptist Church, where the friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend, without further notice.

Advices have been received at the Post-Office Department from Independence, (Mo.,) stating that the Santa Fe mail, which left Independence on the 19th ult., had been attacked by a party of Kiowa Indians on the 24th, and that the conductor, M. SMITH. and his brother had been murdered.

THEATRE FRANCAIS.--This charming little establishment re-opened for the season on Saturday night, and was graced with a full attendance of the best classes, and a large representation of our French fellow-citizens. An undoubted fact is the Theatre Francais.

The mails by the Canada, whose arrival at Boston has been announced, reached this City at a late hour on Saturday night. Our London files furnish most interesting particulars of Capt. MCCLINTOCK'S successful explorations in the steam-yacht Fox.

GARROTED.--As John Wogamus was leaving a house in Cow Bay, Five Points, at a late hour on Friday night, two men, named John Shay and Patrick Duffy, seized him by the throat and robbed him of fifty cents. While attempting to get at his money, which they did by cutting off his pantaloons' pocket, they gashed their victim's hand.

QUITE A MISTAKE.--When it was reported that Mr. HOWARD, Chief Engineer of the Fire Department, had declined the gold medal voted to him by the Common Council, his reputation for modesty rose rapidly. His letter has now been published, assigning quite a different motive.

The mails by the Canada, whose arrival at Boston has been announced, reached this City on Saturday at midnight. THE KNIFE.--At about 1 o'clock yesterday morning a party of half-intoxicated men got into a fight in Van Brunt, near Williams-street, south Brooklyn. During its progress a participant, named JAMES GALLAGHER, was stabbed three times in the breast. The wounds though severe are not considered mortal.

THE MODEL CITY.-It is pleasant, us well as profitable, to ascertain the standards by which the citizens of Baltimore decide their own city to be the perfection of a metropolis. As the judicial tribunals of a community generally afford a reasonable basis for such a judgment,

The cricket match at Hoboken and the interest it has excited, seems to have led some people to the conclusion that a new era is about to be inaugurated, that every doctor, lawyer, editor and merchant in the country will henceforward devote himself to the bat and ball, and present himself to the admiring gaze of his friends with a pair of rosy cheeks and a stomach of leather ;

The Stockholders of the Erie Railroad, to the number of about fifty, met at the Cooper Institute, last evening, to consult upon the interests of the road, and to nominate a ticket for Directors, to be voted for at the election which takes place to-day. Among the principal Stockholders present were GEORGE BRUCK, DANIEL DREW, WASHINGTON MILLS, THOMAS EWBANK, K. ALBURTIS, and others.

SIGLER--POST.--In this City, on Sunday, Oct. 9, by the Rev. W. S. Mickels, JOHN I. SIGLER to Mrs. LOUISA POST, all of this City. PIERSON--VALESTINE.--In this City, on Monday, Oct. 10, at St. Peter's Church, 20th-st.. by the Rev. Dr. Beach. JOHN G. PIERSON to MARIE E. VALENTINE, both of Newark. N. J.

Advices from Brownsville, Texas, are received, stating that place was attacked on the 28th ultimo by a bard of guerillas, who had killed five citizens, broken open the jail and freed all the prisoners. The most intense excitement prevailed, and the Mexicans sent aid from Matamoras.

The extraordinary report which reaches us to-day from St. Petersburg, to the effect that the American Minister, after reaching Peking, had been seized and confined by the Celestial authorities, gives a special interest to a letter which we elsewhere publish from Mr. WARD himself, in regard to his participation in the battle of Tien-tsin.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I have just received a letter from Mr. WARD, our Minister in China, which, though not intended for publication, contains so much that is interesting to the world, and especially to the American world, that I cannot refrain from sending you some part of it for publication in your widely read paper. M.

The trial of JAMES ADAMS for killing STEPHEN CUNNINGHAM in a beer saloon in Canal-street, in July last, took place in the Court of Oyer and Terminer today, the jury rendering a verdict of guilty of manslaughter. The trial of CHARLES CRANE for manslaughter in causing the death of an old man named PETER GADDIS, by striking him on the head with a stone some weeks since, was next commenced, and is still on.

OUR CITY GOVERNMENT.-The Courier and Enquirer says, "There was a time when our City was well governed, when the right men were put in the right place-a time when the qualification for office was not subserviency to party, but the possession on the part of the candidate of those qualities which constitute true fitness-integrity and ability."

The Quarterly Report of the Street Commissioner was transmitted to the Board of Aldermen last evening. The San Francisco Times, of the 14th ult., says that, in accordance with our anticipations, the expected duel between Senator BRODERICK and Judge TERRY took place yesterday morning, in a small valley ten miles from Merced Lake. The parties went out of town the night previous, passing the night in separate localities.

In the Episcopal Convention the Committee on Canons reported adversely as to amending article first of the Constitution so as to locate the Convention permanently at Philadelphia. The report was tabled. The Committee also reported that canons one and two of 1853 are not repealed by the action of the last Convention.

It is not, we trust, too boastful to say that New-York is the American parent of Italian Opera, which at the best is but a rickety imp, always tumbling down and getting into mischief. The triumph of creating such an offspring is not absolute. Still, as something of our own, we nurse it and pet it affectionately, believing that one of these days it will more than reward our anxiety and care.

Thomas Asten vs. Horatio N. Wild.--The defendant in this case in Councilman Wild, the well known contectioner on Broadway. The action is brought to recover damages for an assault alleged to have been committed by defendant upon the plaintiff, on June 14, 1858. The cause came on for trial in the Supreme Court, before Justice ROOSEVELT.

The Cricket match between the All England Eleven and Twenty-two of the United States, which was to have commenced at noon to-day, was postponed till 3 o'clock P. M., in consequence of the bad state of the ground occasioned by the heavy rains of last night. The players are all in fine trim.

EMPLOYMENT OF CAMELS IN THE UNITED STATES SERVICE.--A letter has recently been received by the Secretary of War from Superintendent BEALE, dated Port Tejon, California, in which the writer speaks in the strongest terms of the great advantage to be derived from the employment of camels in the public service in the West.

CONSOLIDATION OF THE TELEGRAPH LINES.-Negotiations, having in view the union of the several telegraph lines between New-Orleans and Sackville, (New-Brunswick,) and for the permanent connection for all business purposes of the seaboard lines with those of the North and West, have, it is well known, been pending for some months past.

THE BRITISH MAIL CONTRACTS.--The blue book has just appeared of the Select Committee appointed by the House of Commons in July last to investigate all existing packet and telegraphic contracts between the British Government and companies or individuals, of which Committee Mr. COBDEN was Chairman.

A SHABBY TRICK.--We cannot help calling attention to the shabby behavior of the Fillibusters who were captured by the United States Marshal in the Mississippi. It appears they were duly arrested, and brought in custody up the river, and placed in confinement in a barracks a little way below New-Orleans.

THE GREAT EASTERN DELAYS.-The Great Eastern, true to her name, is slow to make a western trip. Although advertised to sail for America on the 27th of the current month, it really begins to be a little doubtful whether she can be made ready to undertake the voyage during the present year.

FLOUR firm, particularly for choice brands, and scarce; sales 1,100 bbls. WHEAT--No. 2 Chicago Spring and Milwaukee Club advanced 1c., closing firm; sales 45,000 bush. The War Department, to-day, awarded contracts for Army transportation as follows: Route 1.-From Missouri River to Utah, and to the posts on the way, to IRWIN WHITE. Route 2.-From Leavenworth, or Kansas City to New-Mexico, to MOORE BOICE. Route 3.-From Frincipal Depot in New-Mexico to the several posts in that Department, to MOORE BOICE.

THE PLYMOUTH LECTURES IN BROOKLYN--INTRODUCTORY BY THE REV. E. H. CHAPIN.--The Rev. E. H. CHAPIN delivered the first of the Plymouth Lectures last evening in Mr. BEECHER'S Church, Brooklyn, to a crowded and brilliant audience. His subject was, "Woman and her Works." The lecturer was introduced in a neat speech by Mr. THEO. TILTON, and was warmly received.

AN ANTI-SLAVERY CLASS MEETING AT THE CHURCH OF THE PILGRIMS.-An audience, four-fifths of which were ladies, assembled last evening in the Lecture-room of the Church of the Pilgrims (the Rev. Dr. CHEEVER'S) to participate in a monthly meeting, instituted for the purpose of agitating the "sin of Slavery," and to pray for its overthrow.

As the period for Mayor TIEMANN'S release from official duty is drawing near, and as that officer does not covet a renomination to his present post, there is every prospect that an unbiased judgment will soon be formed by the public as to the character and extent of his services.

We steamship Indian, from Liverpool at 11 o'clock on the morning of the 28th ult., passed this point at 3 1/2 o'clock this afternoon, and will reach Quebec about 5 o'clock to-morrow morning. Her dates are four days later than those already received.

The October Elections. Five States-Pennsylvania, Ohio, Indiana, Iowa and Minnesota-hold General Elections to-day. No Members of Congress are to be chosen, except in Minnesota, and in one district of Ohio; the latter to fill a vacancy. Pennsylvania elects an Auditor-General and Surveyor-General, but no Governor.

By the arrival of the M. C. Stevens from Monrovia, we have interesting news from Liberia. The colony was in a prosperous condition. An abundant harvest was anticipated, and a large quantity of palmoil had been shipped to the United States, England, France and Germany. The news from the farming region is encouraging; sugar and syrup had been made in considerable quantities during the season:

Corn Meal, 13,932 bushels Wheat, 670 bushels Corn, 276 bushels Rye, 1,450 bushels Barley, 14,631 bushels Oats, 785 pkgs. Provisions, and 290 bbls. Whisky. Cotton-Has been quiet, to-day. Prices remain as last noticed. sales 300 bales.

HARD TO PLEASE.-We really must say that our cotemporary the Tribune is hard to please. He has been bemoaning for years the deplorable fact that, while we go on importing hundreds of millions of dollars' worth every year, we have nothing to give exchange for if but our agricultural produce, and this Europe will not take, or does not take. Ergo, we shall be for ever in debt.

Yesterday afternoon, at 5 o'clock, the steamed C. Vanderbilt, Capt. STURGES, of the Stonington line, left her dock with about 250 passenger, and a large and valuable freight. After starting, the steamer Connecticut, of the Norwich and Worcester line, came up, and was about passing the Vanderbilt, when the engineer of the latter increased the speed of his boat, and just before coming abreast of Williamsburgh, the Vanderbilt shot ahead.

ONDERDONK, the members of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the Diocese of New-York deeply feel that the position of the suspended Bishop is such in this community,

The Santa Fe mail of the 15th ult. reached Independence this morning. Messrs. OTERO, PORTER and CRENSHAW arrived, and confirm the attack on the mail party. The Indians took all the mules, provisions and clothing, but did not molest the mall, which was taken forward by the next outgoing party. The incoming party found dead bodies of four men, supposed to have been Pike-Peakers.

JENKINS ON MURDER.-In the way of frivolous ferocity, of combined ineptitude and brutality, it would be difficult to parallel from the records of any people reputed civilized, the details of the recent duel between Senator BRODERICK and Chief-Justice TERRY, as related in the telegraphic despatches which we this morning publish, in anticipation of the Overland Mail from California.

The news brought by the Indian to Quebec is of striking interest. There is every reason to apprehend, from the character of the advices received from China, that although Mr. WARD, the American Minister, had succeeded in effecting his entrance into Peking, he has there been subjected to confinement.

The dispatch from New-Orleans, announcing that a body of Mexican guerrillas had taken Brownsville, has created profound excitement in official quarters; and to-morrow the Cabinet will consider the propriety of sending a sufficient force to the Rio Grande, not only to protect the captured town hereafter, but to carry the war into Mexico, and there to punish the marauders.

UNITED STATES CIRCUIT COURT, OCT. 11-BEFORE JUDGE NELSON. John H. Brower et al. vs. the brig Water Witch William H. Sheldon vs. The same-John Clifton Vs. A quantity of Cotton.-NELSON, C.J.-The libels in the two first case were filed to recover damages for injuries to a cargo of cotton shipped in the brig water witch, from Lavacea, on the Bay in the brig Wa Texas, to this port, in May, 1854.

THE REPUBLICANS AND THE RESIDENCY.--The Tribune and Evening Post rather startled political circles a day or two since, by simultaneously announcing that Col. FREMONT had not written a letter declining to be candidate for the presidency in 1860; and the Tribune added, with apparent emphasis, that it believed the would accept the nomination if it should be tendered to him.

I have seed the card of Mr. JOHN C. HEENAN, under date of yesterday, in which he responds to my recent statement that I would meet him, or any other man, for $10,000 a side, by agreeing to close a match with me for that amount, and by kindly giving me the option o fix the time for the fight to come off, either before or after his approaching fight with SAYBRS.

The Arizonian to Sept. 22 has come to hand. A correspondent at Fort Buchanan furnishes it with the following military items: Lieut. Col. JOHNSON. First Cavalry, acting Inspector General for the Department of New-Mexico, is daily expected here on a tour of inspection. He will be accompanied by Major RHEER, of the Pay Department.

The Donnelly letter, in spite of the doubts which have been recently expressed respecting the existence of any such person as DONNELLY at all, still continues to agitate men's minds. The Richmond Enquirer, Governor WISE'S organ, has just been giving utterance to another groan over the document in question, at the same time publishing another correspondence which, in many ways, is much more remarkable than the Donnelly correspondence itself.

During my hurried transit from the Ferry to the steamer in your City on Saturday last on route for this place, I noticed in your morning issue of that day an article commenting with sarcastic bitterness upon a recent occurrence in the City of Baltimore, to which I would not take exception did I not know your statement of the facts to be very erroneous, particularly in reference to the crime of the parties tried.

PRIZE-FIGHTING.--There is a very stringent law upon our statute-books against prize-fighting,--yet these brutal conflicts have come to be every-day occurrences among us. We published yesterday an offer from the "Benicia Boy" to meet MORRISSEY again in the ring for a prize of $10,000; and to-day Mr. MORRISSEY, through our columns, accepts the challenge. Both these parties publish their purpose to violate the law of the State;...

DEATH OF CAPT. BOWNE, AGENT OF TIIE UNDERWRITERS. Capt. JOSIAH Q. BOWNE, for several years past the general agent of the New-York Board of Underwriters, died at his residence in this City on Monday evening, after a brief attack of paralysis. He left home when but a boy of sixteen, and shipping before the mast soon reached the rank of master.

THE FLOATING HOSPITAL--The very success full experiment of the hospital of the hospital ship Florence Nightingale during the past Summer-imperfect though that experiment was in many details-has established the fact that the floating system is the proper solution of our quarantine difficulties. One essential point is the satisfaction that the new scheme has given to all parties in the late "Staten Island War."

The special correspondent of this paper at Washington informs us that the action of Commodore TATNALL and our Envoy, Mr. WARD, in regard to the events in China, has met with the entire approbation of Government. There is no intelligence in the latest despatches received at the State Department additional to that embodied in the letter of Mr. WARD, published in the TIMES yesterday morning. The North Star has brought the passengers who left San Francisco on the 20th ult,, making the entire distance in twenty-one days and a half.

The steamship Yorktown, Capt. PARRISH, arrived about 11 1/3 A. M. yesterday, from Norfolk, bringing forty-six of the Quaker City's passengers, in charge of Mr. JOHN Y. HARGOUS, who, with Dr. FINNELL, have accompanied them since they left the ship. They immediately called at the office of Messrs. HARGOUS Co, where their passage money was refunded. Their hotel bills and passage from Norfolk were also defrayed by the house.

The British steamer Bolivia arrived at Panama on the 21st September, with dates from Valparaiso to the 1st, and Callao and Lima to tile 13th September. She did not touch at Guayaquil. The Bolivia brought $565,000 for England. PERU. EXPEDITION AGAINST ECUADOR.-BLOCKADE OF GUAYAQUIL RAISED.-DISTURBANCES ON BOARD AMERICAN VESSELS AT THE CHINCHAS.

Mr. BUCHANAN, since his inauguration into office, has been a very " Hans in Luck." One pear after another has ripened and dropped into his nerveless hand, only to fall to tile ground again, untasted and unenjoyed. The Kansas Question, the Mormon Question, the Fillibuster Question, the Central American Question, the Mexican Question, have all been in his hands to settle forever, with a glory beyond the dream of ordinary Presidents.

I wrote you in my last that the fight between Judge TERRY and Senator BRODERICK had been interrupted by the Police upon the field, but that it would probably come off at another time. MR. MEAGHER AND THE FILLIBUSTERS.--We are assured on good authority that the rumor referred to by our Washington correspondent, yesterday, connecting Mr. T. F. MEAGHER'S visit to Costa Rica with the renewed Fillibuster movement, is entirely unfounded. Mr. MEAGHER goes solely upon private business,

DRAYTON'S PARLOR OPERAS.--For a full and particular account of what constitutes a parlor opera, see advertisement in another column. Mr. DATTON'S editor leaves nothing to be said on that point. The first entertainment took place last night, at the French theatre, and was a success. A new idea, skilfully claboarated, and pleasantly presented, is sure to be success in a City fearfully night-mared as this is by all that is old and wearisome.

UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT, OCT. 12--BEFORE JUDGE BETTS. The United States vs. One case containing photographs.--The jury in this case, having been directed to bring in a sealed verdict, were called at the opening of Court. Only eleven jurors were present, but the parties expressed their willingness to take the verdict of the eleven, when it appeared that the absent juror had taken the verdict with him.

THE DEMOCRATIC REVIVAL--The reform movement in the ranks of the Democratic Party seems to be making god progress. The Committe, which has been enlarged to thirty-one members, has addressed a circular call prominent and influential Democrats, inviling them to attend a meeting this evening at its Fifth-avenue Hotel, for the purpose of promoting and the desired reorganization f the Democratie Party.

Just before the late war the number of men in the regiments of the Infantry of the Line was augmented from 1,800 to 3,200. Since the war the regiments of Infantry of the Imperial Guard have also been augmented from 2,800 to 3,600 men. During the late campaign the regiments of the Guard did not muster more than 1,800 men to the regiment-something like a normal number of working men to a regiment of 2,800.

Even in the dull city one feels the dreamy influence of this most delightful season. A warm mist broods over the Common and the Public Gardens, and even the raw lands of the recently filledup Back Bay are transfigured and glorified by the touch of the Autumnal enchanter.

To the Editor of the New-York Times : In Tuesday's TIMES appeared an article under the heading, "The Health of the City." Permit me to make extracts from that article, with brief comments. You say that "The health of the City never was better than it is now."

The telegraph may have given you a meagre account. of the recent Indian outrages on the Plains, but I hasten to communicate the details, as derived from authentic sources. Mr. PATTERSON, from Walnut Creek, brought us the first intelligence, and Mr. COLE, of this County, (who was with the train when attacked,) arrived a few hours later with further details.

BRODERICK--Sir: Some two months since, at the public table of the International Hotel in San Francisco, you saw fit to indulge in certain remarks concerning me which were offensive in their nature.

Though many Southern "Oppositionists" here and elsewhere, in accordance with the Supreme Court's declaration in the Dred Scott case," still "assert the power and the duty of the National Legislature to protect, mediately or immediately, the rights of slave property in the National Territories," they now express themselves inclined to fraternize with the Southern Opposition, despite their assertion of the contrary doctrine, in order to elect an Opposition Speaker for tile next House of Representatives.

Meeting of the New-England Society at the Historical Society Buildings. There was a meeting in the lecture-room of the Historical Society last evening, called under the auspices of the New-England Society, for the purpose of listening to the Rev. Dr. WADDINGTON, in relation to tile proposed erection of a church in London, in memory of the Puritans.

RECEIPTS AND GRANTS FOR SIX MONTHS. The receipts of the American Tract Society for six mouths of the Society's current year, ending Oct. 1, have been, for publications sold, $103,506 34, and in donations and legacies, $39,380 47--in all, $142,886 81; being $5,069 50 more than for the corresponding months of the previous year.

Mrs. BROWNING'S fantastic vision in Aurora Leigh of the meeting of St. Giles and St. James at a wedding, was in a manner realized yesterday morning, at the Roman Catholic Cathedral in Mott-street, in this City. For most practical purposes, Mott-street is just about as far from Fifth-avenue and Fourteenthstreet as the Coast of Africa, and the African element so completely preponderates in the street as to make the image singularly accurate.

MR. WARD'S LETTER FROM CHINA.--It is known hat the Americans,who were neutral spectators at the sad affair of the Pei-ho, found themselves obliged to lend their assistance to the English Admiral to bring up his reinforcements under the Chinese fire.

The Tenth Annual Fair of the New-Hampshire State Agricultural Society opened last Wednesday, Oct. 5, will great eclat, with fair skies and everything assuring the people of a gala time. State Fairs have become quite an institution, originating from NewEngland, and other States copying the Yankee idea and applying them to their fertile soils and magnificent lands. Fortune is smiling upon the American Institute this month with ample apology and atonement for the frowns of September. The receipts are flattering at PalaceGarden gate, and novelties are added to the exhibition every day. Every foot of room in the machinery department is occupied, and every machine that works by steam power is daily in operation.

No action has yet been taken in response to any communication which may have recently been received from the British Government on the subject of the Sun Juan Island difficulty. An extraordinary meeting of the Cabinet was held to-day. All the members were present with the exception of Mr. CASS, who was absent on account of physical indisposition.

NORRIS.--On Thursday evening, (Oct, 13 RICHARD NORRIS. aged 37 years and 2 months. The remains will be take to Newark on Saturday morning at 8 o'clock. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend his funeral from No. 50 Ludlow-st., New-York.

A NEW PILGRIM'S PROGRESS.--Capt. CoRRiE, late of the yacht Wanderer, is about to publish a full, true and particular account of his voyage in search of a slave-trade, with "developments involving the reputation of many public men of this country."

Jocl Nourse et al. vs. R. L. Allen.--This was a demurrer to the complainant's bill, which was filed to restrain the defendants from the infringement of several patents for improvements in a reaping-machine.

CONCERT.--The concert given by Mrs. STAGG last night was a complete success. NIBLO'S spacious Saloon was densely crowded. The laudable object contemplated by the beneficiare will, we trust, be measurably accomplished.

KANE MONUMENT ASSOCIATION.--A regular meeting of the Kane Monument Association was held on Wednesday afternoon at the law office of JOHN H. WHITE, Esq., No. 169 Broadway. The attendance of members was full. The report of the Lecture Committee was read.

NOMINATIONS OF JUDGES.--The Tammany Democracy, in their Judiciary Convention, on Wednesday night, passed a resolution indorsing the official ability and efficiency of Justice ROOSEVELT in the strongest terms; yet out of 110 delegates composing the Convention, only eleven voted for his renomination.

The present Commissioner of Patents having, as a member of Congress, been witness to a repugnance in influential quarters in that body to appropriating for the agricultural branch of the office, has not submitted an estimate of appropriation for that object for the next fiscal year. It is understood that the Secretary of the Interior approves this step, to devolve the responsibility in the matter upon Congress.

Recently, ten or fifteen slaves have been abducted from the neighborhood of Fredericksburgh, Madison County, Mo., and the event has stirred up considerable feeling in that part of the State. On Saturday, Sept, 17, three negroes belonging to D. M. Fox, and two belonging to JOHN M. GHOLSON, escaped and made tracks for Illinois.

For some time past it has been generally understood that a fillibuster movement was on foot, or at least supposed to be, from the fact of the presence in and about our city of persons who have formerly been connected with expeditions of that character.

The Southern political Press is engaged in a very active canvass of the Presidential question. The position of Mr. DOUGLAS enlists general discussion, especially in the Democratic ranks,--and the main current of Southern sentiment is unfavorable to his nomination, though advocates of its are not wanting.

The Paris Pays asserts positively that the American Minister has arrived in Peking, that he ascended one of the branches of the Pei-ho with his legation, having been conveyed in a box open at the top and drawn buy oxen and that "while awaiting an interview with the Emperor, he was required not to leave the residence assigned to him."

The Royal Mail steamship Africa, Capt. SHANNON, which sailed from Liverpool on the 1st inst, at noon, arrived at this port yesterday afternoon. The news is two days later than that brought out by the City of Washington.

The Baltimore Exchange gives the following details of the murders which were announced by telegraph in Thursday's TIMES: At 10 1/2 o'clock on Wednesday night a most cold-blooded murder was committed in front of Jackson Hall, on Front-street, near Buren, a young man 20 years of age, named JOHN P. HUBEL, having been shot and instantly killed.

Jacob H. Mott, having been arrested for complicity in the Erie Bank forgery case, in February last, was admitted to bail, a Mr. E. Belcher Sackett becoming hills surety. Sackett swore before Recorder BARNARD that he was worth $5,000 in real estate, and gave a description of his property.

A Toronto paper says a marble tablet is to be placed in St. James Cathedral, in that city. In memory of the late Capt. Wm. Mr. Maule lost his arm at Sebasteopol, and died a few days after at Scutari.

The Rev. Samuel Willard, D. D., well-known in Massachusetts as "the blind preacher," died at Deerfield. Oct. 8, in the 83d year of his age. for half a century he was a preacher, exerting great influence in the region where the labored. For about forty years he was totally blind. He graduated at Harvard College in 1803. and was the class-mate of the famous Dr. Pavson.

The Fall elections indicate the generate triumph of the Republican Party. In Ohio, Pennsylvania, Iowa, and other States from which returns have been received, the .Democratic candidates are either defeated, or succeed by greatly diminished majorities; and everything indicates a similar result in the States where elections are yet to be held.

THE SUNDAY QUESTION CARRIED TO AN ExTREME.--The arrest of a carriage-driver in Pittsburgh for a violation of the Sunday laws, has already been noticed. Mayor WEAVER, having had the case under advisement, has rendered a decision, holding the driver, JACOB OLSTELLE, amenable to the penalty of $25 Imposed by the ordinance.

The annual exhibition of the Connecticut State Agricultural Society, held at New-Haven this week, proved a decided success. The grounds containing about seventy-five acres, well fitted up and arranged have been scarcely excelled in the country. The entries of stock, implements, agricultural produce fruits, manufactures, etc., were not quite numerous as at some previous exhibitions, but excelled in real value those of any former year.

THE OPERA--OPENING OF THE SEASON.--The new season at the Academy of Music commences to-night, and Messrs. ULLMAN and STRAKOSCH play their first card, Mlle. SPERANZA, with undisguised confidence that it will prove a trump and be liberally backed by the public.

If the rumors which are permitted to escape from that recondite body, the House of Bishops, be credible, the case of Bishop ONDERDONK has been virtually settled. The vote upon his unqualified restoration is decisive, four-fifths of the Bishops uttering their protest against the position of the New-York memorialists, and declining to accept the society of the deposed brother upon the Episcopal bench.

CHARLES, a machinist from Pennsylvania, in a quarrel at Mound City, on the previous Saturday. ALEXANDER of Russia has followed the example of NAPOLEON of France, and after throwing the reins for a moment on the neck of that fiery steed, the Press, with an air worthy of Mr. RAREY himself, has suddenly caught them up again and tightened them in his imperial grasp.

The announcement of the death of the Hon. J. Y. MASON, our Minister to Paris, has produced a profound sensation here. Rumor is already supplying his place. It is said that Sceretary FLOYD will go to Paris, and that Mr. FAULKNER will come into the Cabinet.

The People vs. Felix Sanchez.--A session of the General Term of the Supreme Court was held on Saturday--Justices ROOSEVELT, CLERKE and SUTHERLAND being present. At the opening of the Court, Justice ROOSEVELT delivered the opinion of the Court denying the motion for a new trial lately made in the case of Felix Sanchez.

THE LATE WEDDING--THE PRESS AND PRIVACY.--The Philadelphia Press is shocked at tile conduct of the New-York newspapers in giving a detailed account of a private marriage. Such a violation of propriety, it is quite confident, could never have been perpetrated in Philadelphia.

Martin M. Haley, an omnibus driver In Charleston, was recently arrested and held to bail in the sum of $1,000. for shooting a negro on Southern wharf. At the time of the shooting, the negro was loading or unloading his dray, and the omnibus driven by Haley came against the dray with violence, throwing off a bale of cotton, which rolled under the horses attached to the omnibus.

The returns of the vote on the adoption of the Constitution come in slowly, but we think the majority in favor of it will reach five thousand. The contest for State officers is growing rather interesting to outsiders. In this county, and a majority of the counties south of the Kaw River, CHAS. ROBINSON is their first choice for Governor. In Leavenworth the County Convention broke up in a row.

The public sentiment of South Carolina seems far from being unanimous in support of the ultraism which has generally been supposed to characterize that State. The cry of Disunion is much less frequent, and much less potent, there than it was ten years ago, and the conservative sentiment seems to be constantly gaining strength and influence.

The steamship North Briton, from Liverpool on Wednesday, the 5th inst., at 2 P.M., passed Father Point at 3 o'clock yesterday morning, on her way to Quebec. The news we receive by telegraph. The R.M. steamship Europa, from Boston via Halifax, arrived at Liverpool at 1 A. M. of the 4th. The screw steamship Anglo-Saxon, from Quebec, arrived at Liverpool at 7 P.M. of the 4th.

THE MEMORIAL CHURCH IN LONDON.--We learn by a note from Rev. Dr. WADDINGTON, to which we very cheerfully give place in another column, that he has come to this country for aid towards the erection of the Memorial Church in London, solely upon the urgent and spontaneous exhortation of American friends.

On Wednesday morning, one NEPOMUCENO CORTINAS, a Mexican outlaw, with a band variously estimated at from 60 to 100 men, armed and on horseback, all Mexicans by nativity but most of them outlaws from Mexico, rode into the city about daylight, posted their sentinels, and proceeded to pick out the men most disagreeable to them. GEORGE MORRIS, WM. P. NEALE, R. L. JOHNSON, CLEMENTE REYES and VIVIANO GARCIA were killed by them.

The prevalent impression that the voyage of the Great Eastern was postponed indefinitely, in consequence of the casualty off Hastings, proves to be incorrect. From the letter of our Special Correspondent, who is in a situation to be thoroughly informed, the vessel will leave Great Britain on Thursday next, and, if the calculalations of the projectors prove correct, will reach Portland in the course of next week.

We have received dates from the Sandwich Islands to Aug. 27. The Honolulu papers have the following notices of the results of explorations among the islands west of the Sandwich group: The Hawaiian bark Gambia recently visited Necker Island, French Frigate group, Maro Reef, Laysan, Lisiansky, the Pearl and Hermes group and Ocean Island; passed over Long Shoals, and a shoal thirty miles west by north from the French Frigate group.

The United States Mail steamer Star of the West, G. HARRISON, Esq., Commander, from Aspinwall, with the California mails, passengers and treasure, arrived at this port yesterday forenoon, about 11 o'clock. She brought about two hundred passengers, having left two hundred and ten, with the New-Orleans mails, at Key West. The steamer left Aspinwall at 8 o'clock P. M., Oct, 3, with a light breeze from the eastward and a smooth sea.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Allow me through your columns to correct a statement recently made in tho TIMES--that the annual expenditure of a member of the Seventh Regiment amounted to $300. Such a report is calculated to Injure the Regiment and prevent its recruiting. The cost of membership is: For uniform and equipments, $05; for dues and incidental expenses, about $25 per annum;

A threatening insurrection has broken out at Harper's Ferry, for which no sufficient reason has, as yet, been assigned. A band, said to be composed of negroes and white Men, numbering two hundred and fifty, on Saturday night seized the bridge and took possession of the Government arsenal, which is located at Harper's Ferry.

The firemen yesterday enjoyed their triennial show, and are by this time either talking it over, or endeavoring to shake off its effects. The muster was large, the procession imposing, the weather better than it promised to be in the morning; the men were apparently in good trim and good spirits, and their female admirers,on the sidewalks and in the windows, were as numerous and enthusiastic as the most inflammable fireman could possibly desire.
THE DE MARBAIS AFFAIR IN CINUINNATI--The particulars of "the De Marbais Tragedy" must be fresh in the memories of our readers. The parties are again before the public in a not very enviable position.

DEATH OF JOHN CALHOUN.--A telegram from St, Louis states that Gen. JOHN CALHOUN, whose name is closely identified with the darkest period of the history of Kansas, died at St. Joseph, Mo., Oct. 13. CALHOUN'S age was about 52.

The people of Richmond County seem disposed, at this late hour, to wash their hands of the incendiarism with which, for two or three years back, they have been ruddy and stained. The Democrats are largely in the majority on the Island, so that a revolution within the Democratic organization of the County is equivalent to a change of policy on the part of the people.

THE STATE ELECTION.--The political canvass in this State seems to be waged mainly upon points of history. The great topics of debate between the hostile party organs at Albany are entirely of the past.

CONVICTION OF THE MURDERER MAUDE AT NEWARK.--PATRICK MAUDE, indicted at Newark, N. J., for the murder of his wife, was convicted, on Saturday, of murder in the first degree. The prisoner received the verdict with the utmost composure.

MACREA.--In this City, on Monday, Oct. 17, WILLIAM MACREA, aged 48 years. His funeral will take place from his late residence, No. 39 East 37th-st., on Wednesday, Oct. 19, at 2 o'clock P. M. The friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend. His remains will be interred in Greenwood Cemetery.

From the chaos of telegrams, in which the extraordinary outbreak at Harper's Ferry was in the first instance communicated, it was quite impossible to ascertain the origin and plan of the conspiracy. There was an insurrection of whites and blacks, mingled in nobody could discover what proportions, how far supported by outside influences, prompted by what motives, and aiming at what results, it was wholly impossible to form a conjecture.

The President, secretary of State, and Secretary of War were together several hours to-day, on matters connected with the proceedings at Harper's Ferry, and the result of the conference was the sending of District-Attorney OULD thither to superintend legal proceedings in the premises.

A decision was rendered yesterday by Justice OSBORN in the case of WM. J. LANE, Jr., the defaulting transfer clerk of the Fulton Bank. Forgery was tile offence charged, but the magistrate did not consider the evidence sufficient to sustain the allegation. and he accordingly dismissed it. LANE was immediately rearrested, and committed for examination on a charge of obtaining the funds of the Bank by means of false and fraudulent pretences.

THE DELANCEY-STREET SHOOTING CASE.--The affray between JOHN CARPENTER and THOS. CHEEVERS, at a late hour on Monday night, in which the latter was dangerously wounded in the left side, grow out an affidavit made by CARPENTER, respecting the disturbances at the late Democratic State Convention at Syracuse, in which several of CHEEVERS' friends were implicated.

MINISTER WARD'S PROGRESS TOWARD ?? LATEST AUTHENTIC INFORMATION. We were greatly hurried with our letters yester day, and now have another opportunity of writing in time to catch the mail. I therefore send this as a P. S. to my letter. The news is quite important, and will not leach any other journal I think.

A new order of things was instituted in City Politics yesterday. Citizens have been so long accustomed to going to the polls and depositing their votes unquestioned and without any complicated preliminaries, that it is difficult for them to comprehend the fact, while the election is yet three weeks in the future, that it is necessary for them to submit to a quasi naturalization process.

The Cricket Match between the All England Eleven and the Canadians, was resumed this morning and continued through the day. Occasional showers fell, and the air was cold and chilly. At half-past 4 o'clock a heavy rain put an end to the playing. Between five and six thousand persons witnessed the game.

The PLYMOUTH LECTURES.--Mr. GEORGE W. CURTIS delivered the second lecture of thsi course last evening, to a fair audience, in Mr. BEECHER's Church. His subject was " The Present Aspect of the Slavery Question," which he treated purely from a political point of view, basing his sentiments, however, wholly upon the moral character of Slavery, and the utter impossibility of ignoring its inherent wickedness and injustice in any scheme of action upon it.

The ex-members of Howard Engine Company No. 34, and several warm personal friends of the late DAVID C. BRODERICK, United States Senator from California, assembled last night at the engine-house of the Company to initiate proceedings in honor of his memory, and to express their deep feelings of indignation relative to his tragical fate.

The insurrection at Harper's Ferry, which startled the public yesterday morning, though sufficiently alarming at the outset, proves to have been but a short-lived affair. It was very speedily crushed by the formidable military forces brought against it from Washington, Baltimore and Virginia,-but, unhappily, not without serious loss of life.

We have been treated lately to a now Sensation. The British Press is praising the newspapers of America for their moderation ! To be praised at all by our professional brethren over the water is sufficiently rare to awaken surprise-but to be praised for moderation carries us beyond the limits of mere astonishment.

There seems to have been a general misapprehension as to the duties to be performed yesterday and to-day under the new Registry Law. We have received communications from various persons, complaining that they found no inspectors ready to enrol their names;and some are inclined to regard this neglect as indicating a purpose on the part of those officers to prevent a Registry of voters from being made.

ALBANY NORTHERN RAILROAD DISCONTINUED.--We learn that the present owners of the Albany Northern Railroad have determined to discontinue running it this day--except from this city to the Junction, abut 12 miles. The residue of the road is deemed by them unsafe. What course will be taken, whether the road will be repaired or abandoned, we are told will soon be determined.

MISCHIEF IN MATCHES.--Science is almost as successful as Satan in finding work for idle hands to do. According to a distinguished statistician in France, the use of lucifer matches has laid an enormous tax on the world, and at the same time robbed it of a great company of tax-payers, by immensely increasing the number of annual conflagrations, and consequently the premiums of insurance against fire.
