THE TIMES AND THE EVENING POST.--We beg to assure the Evening Post that we have never employed the services of any person, on either side of the Atlantic, whom we had any reason to suppose was already engaged in the service of the Post. We concur entirely in its estimate of such an attempt to interfere with the organization of a rival journal.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: There could hardly be a stronger argument against the reopening of the SlavE-trade than has been furnished by the events of the last week at Harper's Ferry, and we earnestly commend it to the attention of the fanatics who have been uproariously demanding fresh supplies of Guinea negroes, as essential to the prosperity of the South.

A correspondent in another column points the evident moral of the recent " insurrection," as it is absurdly styled, so far as two classes of our Southern population are concerned-those who desire to reopen the Slavc-trade and those who advocate a dissolution of the Union.

CARE OF ARMORIES.--A correspondent calls our attention to the fact that the United States Armory at Harper's Ferry became an easy prey to the marauders, because Congress recently cut down the appropriations for the care of arsenals and armories throughout the country, and thus compelled the Department to dismiss a large number of the trained and disciplined men who had previously acted as guards and gate-keepers.

From Washington. THE PAPERS FOUND IN CAPT. BROWN'S VALISE-LETTER FROM GEN. DEGOLLADO. WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Oct. 10. Papers found on the person and in the valise of BROWN, received by the Government, confirm the reports that his scheme had advocates in various States, who were well informed of his plans and movements for a servile insurrection.

The Royal Mail steamship Europa, Captain BRITCH, from Liverpoo'l at 9 A. M. of the 8th inst., arrived at Halifax at 2 o'clock this morning, and sailed thence at 9 1/2 A. M. for Boston, where she will be due to-morrow afternoon. The horse express, with her news, arrived here this morning.

The Supreme Court of Rhode Island, Chief-Justice AMES, has been in session for the past three weeks, disposing of a crowded docket of civil and criminal cases, The term opened with an array of eighty three divorce petitions, in nearly all of which eases have been disposed of in the short period of a fortnight.

October is a delightful month in this region, but the frosty nights which follow the warm, hazy days, admonish us that Winter stands ready to shut us in. The close of navigation is not more than five or six weeks off, and everybody is occupied in making the requisite preparation therefor.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: A few months since the papers were much occupied with the discussion of various projects for improving our Post-office. Necessarily the first point to be decided in the case would be the site. Several have been proposed, discussed, and abandoned. One, which apparently met with considerable favor, was the lower angle of the City Hall park.

It will be recollected that the Legislature introduced into the act, "To enable the Supervisors of the City and County of New-York to raise money by tax," a clause, authorizing the Comptroller;

BROOKLYN FIREMEN IN PHILADELPHIA.--Constitution Fire Company No. 7 reached Philadelphia Tuesday night, and were welcomed by a number of fire companies and a torchlight parade, display of apparatus, Hibernia Engine Company are their hosts.

The last news about this celebrated volume which has been brought into such prominence by the denunciation of it as an Imposture by the officers of the British Museum, was that the Duke of DEVONSHIRE, its owner, had removed it from the Museum, and that it was proposed that a Committee of men of letters and paleographists should examine its manuscript readings and pronounce upon their date.

LICENSE OF SOLDIERY.--Our City Inspector, it seems, keeps a target company; and his subordinate officers, judging from the Police returns, assert a much more summary jurisdiction over private persons and property than we have been in the habit of submitting to.

The Philadelphia North American dissents from our advice concerning Mexico, partly because we have no interests there requiring our interference, and partly because the Mexicans do not seem to suffer much from the condition of anarchy which has become chronic among them.

Democratic Ratification Meeting at New-Rochelle. SPEECH BY EX-MAYOR WOOD. A Democratic Ratification Meeting was held last evening, at New-Rochelle. Ex-Mayor Wood was the principal speaker. Subjoined is a summary of his remarks:

THE RAILROAD--ELECTION OF DIRECTORS AND OFFICERS. An annual meeting of the Staten Island Railroad Company was held on Tuesday, 28th inst., at their office. No. 2 Bowling-green, for the purpose of electing Officers, Directors and Inspectors for the ensuing year. The following were appointed:

Oct. 19, 1859, prepared for THE NEw-YORK TIME by PINNEY JOHNSON, Produce Commission Merchants, No. 231 Fulton-street. Our quotations are such as merchants and producers realize who skip their Produce to this market to be sold on commission.

In New-York, during the past week, the demand has been fair, chiefly for low and medium descriptions, of which manufacturers appear to begin want. Holders, however, continue to ask prices above the views of the principal purchasers, and as the available supply is not heavy for the season, there is no apparent eagerness to sell.

THE YELLOW-FEVER CONTAGIONISTS VICTORIOUS. The Academy of Medicine held its semi-monthly meeting last evening. Dr. GRISCOM moved a resolution which, happily for so many of the leading public as enjoy the wranglings and personalities of doctors, did not immediately carry, but was sent to the Council.

BOARD OF ALDERMEN. THE EXTENSION OF WORTH-STREET-A NEW MARKET-SITE FOR A COUNTY JAIL-ISSUE OF CENTRAI, PARK STOCK. The Board of Aldermen, last evening, received and referred a remonstrance, signed by propertyowners on Worth-street, against the extension of Worth-street, from Baxter-street to Chatbam-square, until they should have another opportunity to appear and oppose it before the Committee on Streets.

The Church Anti-Slavery Convention. ACTION IN REGARD TO THE HARPER'S FERRY REBELLION-ADJOURNMENT. CHICAGO, Thursday, Oct. 20. The Western Tract Convention met for the second time this forenoon. They were occupied in the discussion of the resolutions offered on the previous day, and which were adopted with but slight amendments.

The " sick mall " is evidently not getting any better. A few months ago the world was informed that the Turkish treasury was bankrupt, and the Sultan's personal expenditure greater than that of the wealthiest monarch in Europe. Now comes the news that an extensive conspiracy against his Majesty's life has been discovered, set on foot by some of the highest dignitaries amongst the clergy and in the army.

ADAMS, Esq., was called to the Chair, and D. T. MACFARLAN, Esq., appointed Secretary. A committee of six were appointed to draft resolutions expressive of the sense of the meeting, consisting of the following gentlemen, viz.:

The Hon. FERNANDO WOOD is almost as incontinent of speech as the Hon. HENRY A. WISE and the Hon. JOHN M. BOTTS. He has just been making a vast and voluminous harrangue to the quiet people of New-Rochelle, of which it is not too much to say, as Bishop SOUTH said of a certain commentator's discourses on the Apocalypse,

WANTED, A DECISION WHICH SHALL DECIDE SOMETHING.-It would be very well if some means were devised of arranging who is to decide whether judgments against the City have been lawfully obtained or not, and avoid the Unseemly row between the Comptroller and the Corporation Attorney, which always follows an attempt to enforce a large claim against the ,Corporation.

ACTION OF THE HOUSE OF DISHOPS. The Churchman of this week deplores, at great length, the refusal of the House of Bishops to reinstate Bishop ONDERDONX. It says: "It is our opinion that if the sessions of the House of Bishops had been conducted openly in the face of all men, Bishop ONDERDONK would not occupy his present humiliating position before the Church. No good and sufficient reason can be given for these secret sessions.

Yesterday, at noon, the Convention for the nomination of State Officers and Representative to Congress met in this city, and was called to order by Gen. S. C. POMEROY, of Atchison, Chairman of the Republican Central Committee, who stated the object of the Convention, expressing the belief that harmonv and union would characterize their proceedings.

WHAT IS KANSAS WORK?-One of the leicers from GERHIT SMITH to BROWN, found among the papers of the latter at Harper's Ferry, speaks of having given him considerable sums of money to aid in the prosecution of his "Kansas work." This phrase, a little peculiar and enigmatical in itself, occurs no less than four times in a letter of about twenty-five lines.

By private letter from Hakodadi I have received and am enabled to forward you important intelligence from Japan relative to an oppressive and ruinous change of currency made recently by the Government, which is destined especially to affect American commerce. My correspondent writes as follows: HAKODADI, Friday, Aug. 5, 1859.

THE CAPTURED FILLIBUSTERS SUING FEDERAL OFFICERS FOR $40,000 DAMAGES.--The New -Orleans Crescent, Oct. 15, has the following: "The examination of the alleged fillibusters, who were arrested by the United States Marshal at the Balize a short time since, will take place before United States Commissioner LUSHER on Monday next, commencing at 12 o' clock.

The development of the Harper's Ferry business proceeds slowly. BROWN, who is in fair way to recover from his, wounds, ahs, it appears, made disclosures in reference to Northern confederates ; but the names of the parties implicated have not been made public. Indeed, the telegram is indistinct as to whether names figured in the disclosure. Cook still succeeds in escaping his pursues. The United State troops remain at the Ferry.

. THE CITY TRESURY FLUSH.--The City Comptroller advertises his readiness to pay at once, principal and interest, certain portions of the City bonds, which do not fall due until the 1st of January next. We are glad to meet such indications of abundance in the City Treasury.

For the past week, one or two of our largest and most respectable French houses has been engaged in a most disreputable traffic, viz: Kidnapping Chinese coolies. The French ship Gertrude, four hundred and sixty-three tons, Capt. LE BALLE, has been lying in our Shanghai River for three months to the "Mauritius."

JUDGMENT IN FAVOR OF THE REV. MR. KENNEDY. The Presbyterian Synod of New-York reassembled yesterday, in Dr. McELROY'S Church, in Fourteenth-street, near Sixth-avenue, and continued their session until a late hour last evening. The proceedings during tile day were only in relation to tile case of the Rev. Mr. KENNEDY, of the Presbyterian Church in South Hampton, Long Island.

Bishop Odenheimer, of New-Jersey, addresses his first pastoral letter to his diocese, under date of Oct. 13, announcing that he shall. assume the duties of the Episcopate immediately after the conclusion of the official proceedings of the Richmond Convention. A pension of [Pound]70 a year has been given to Mr. Chas. Duke Yonge, author of several Greek and Latin

The Conferences at Zurich are a failure. This nobody now pretends to doubt. The Princes and Powers of Europe stand for the moment amazed, abashed and incapable in the presence of that terrible question of Central Italy, which is visibly swelling and growing fierce before them, like the black dog in the comer of Faust's chamber. Judge DAVID S. TERRY, at whose hands Senator BRODERICK received his death wound, was brought to this city on Friday night, and on Saturday gave bail to appear for trial. His bonds were fixed at $10,000--with B. WALKER BOUES, G. W. GEAUAM and MyERS F. TRUETT as sureties. The excitement in relation to the death of Mr. BRODERICK has quite subsided, and Mr. TERRY's friends, apparently, have no hesitation in trusting him here for trial.

THE CONDITION OF THE BASS RIVER BANK OF BEVERLY.--The Committee appointed to examine the affairs of this bank reported to the stockholders yesterday, that there had been some injudicious management and business errors on the part of the directors, and that the loans were enlarged to too great an extent.

American Enterprise in Russian Asia. The overland mail informs us of the arrival of the schooner Lewis Perry at San Francisco from Nicolaefsk, on the Amoor river, via Petropaulouski. The Perry left the Amoor river Aug. 12, and Petropaalouski Aug. 12. The Russian Government was preparing for the construction of a large fortress below the settlement of Nicolaefsk, for which frequent supplies of ammunition and material of all kinds were arriving.

WHOM DO THIS LAWS PUNISH.--It would be very easy for an enemy of our institutions to prove--plausibly, if not conclusively--that our criminal laws are made for the protection of scoundrels and the punishment of their innocent victims. We have already mentioned the case of the poor German who was swindled by emigrant-runners, and, on making complaint, was imprisoned as a witness. The villain who had robbed him was released on bail.

THE PEOPLE SAVINGS BANK OF BOSTON APPOINTMENT OR RECEIVERS.--The case of the peoples saving bank, against which an injunction was issued on Saturday, came up yesterday by appointment of the supreme court. The Hon. STEPHEN H. PHILLIPS, Attorney General of the Commonwealth, appeared for the Government, but there was no appearance of counsel on the part of the Bank.

The Bergrans had a late yesterday, in commemoration of their National Independence. They inaugurated a fine new column, just completed, in honor of the country's delivery. The bronze lions on the pedestal, which are of plaster, are to be replaced, it is hoped, by some more durable material. Altogether it is an ornament to this beautiful city. I arrived just in time to witness the military and popular display, and the evening's illumination.

DEPARTURE OF CALIFORNIA STEAMERS.--The steamer Atlantic left yesterday with over one thousand passengers for California. Among them were 250 United States recruits from Governor's Island, who are detailed to reinforce the Fourth and Ninth Regiments of Infantry under Gen HARNEY. The following are the names of the different companies, with their officers: The force, when inspected, formed a battalion of six large companies.

The United States Mail steamship De Soto, J. D. BULLOCH, commander, from New-Orleans via Havana, arrived at this port yesterday morning, having left Havana at sundown of the 15th inst. She brings nothing of importance in the way of news. Much anxiety was felt for the Quaker City,--many who expected friends fearing they might be among those who remained on board.

To the Editor of th New- York Times: In your editorial article of to-day you quote an extract from the Irkootsk Gazette, stating that arrangements had been made at Peking to receive Mr. WARD amicably, but that he would only be presented to the Chief of the Imperial Cabinet, and not to the Emperor at all. This last statement very much encourages the hope for Mr. WARD'S success-that is, thai he will be received.

Of the official Gaceta of Santo Domingo we have files to Sept. 17. They contain particulars of the suppression of the revolt which broke out in Azua on the 7th ult. The chiefs of the movement were Colonels MATIAS DE VARGAS and RUDESINDO RAMIREZ, partisans of Ex-President BAEZ, in whose interest the insurrection was attempted.

At the time of the explosion on board the Great Eastern, the stewardess of the ship was with the captain's little girl in one of the side cabins, which open, through a passage, into the grand saloon. Hearing tile explosion she cautiously opened tile cabin door, but Instantly closed it again on account of the rush of steam. She then opened tile port windows of the cabin, and remained quiet until assistance came.

ADVANTAGES OF THE CONSERVATIVE FACTIONDESERTIONS FROM THE LIBERAL RANKS-A NEW ATTEMPT ON VERA CRUZ. By the arrival of the British mail steamer at Havana we receive advices from tile City of Mexico to the 30th of September, and from Vera Cruz to Oct. 5. The news is without interest. The Liberal troops had recaptured Tepic, after defealing Gen. MARQUEZ.

Harbor Encroachments--Oyster Island. A special meeting of the Chamber of Commerce was held yesterday noon, for the purpose of considering the exposed state of the Harbor. The President, PELATIAH PERIT. Esq., occupied the Chair. Mr. BLUNT read the following letter from Prof. Bache, inclosing a report of a survey made by Lieut. Craven: LANE'S BROOK, Washington Co., Maine, Sept. 27.

The annual inspection of the Seventh Regiment, (National Guard,) Col. LEFERTS Commanding, and the Seventy-first Regiment, (American Guard,) Col. VOSBURGH, took place yesterday at Hamilton-square, and in spite of the raw, windy weather, attracted a great many spectators.

Subjoined we publish a long article from the Marksville (Avoyelles Parish) Organ, of the 8th inst., giving an account of the formation of a Vigilance Committee in that parish, and generally and particularly justifying the proceedings which have taken place.

The mails by the steamer Europa reached the City from Boston last evening, Our foreign correspondence and the extracts from foreign files, which are given below, contain interesting details of the latest intelligence. Contrary to my expectations, as set forth in my correspondence by the last packet, the Ministry, having lost ground in carrying out their financial project respecting a renovation of their banking system, appealed to the Emperor for a dissolution of the Chambers, which, being refused by His Majesty, obliged them to tender their resignations.

We learn from an authoritative source that the accounts carried to England by the last River Plate mails as to the nature of the misunderstanding between the Paraguayan Government and the British Consul at Asuncion, Mr. HENDERSON, are greatly exaggerated, and not at all warranted by the real facts of the case.

A DEAD BODY FOUND IN THE EAST RIVER.-The body of an unknown man was taken out of the water, at the foot of South Seventh-street, yesterday. It had been so long in the water that identification was impossible. Coroner SNELL took the remains in charge.

INGENUITY OF LEGAL COUNSEL BAFFLED.--Every humane man will sympathize with Mr. ASHMEAD on learning that his little contrivance for extricating STEPHENS, convicted of having poisoned his wife, from his difficulties, has not met with the success its ingenuity merited.

Of the intelligence supplied by the Europa's mails, the most interesting is the correspondence between the British Foreign office, and the Hon. Mr. BRUCE, the Envoy to China. The publication has not had the effect upon the public mind, which in authorizing it, the Government seems to have anticipated.

Our community were considerably excited today by the appearance at noon of one of the fugitives from Harper's Ferry, supposed to be COOK. A gentleman from Quincy overtook the man on the road heading from Waynesborough to this place, and carried him some distance in his buggy. When about three miles from town the man got out of the vehicle under pretence of taking another road.

The International Cricket Match commenced at 1 o'clock to-day. The weather was cold and blustering. There were only about 400 persons present, and they were shivering with the cold. The twentytwo were made up from Rochester, New-York, Philadelphia, Newark, Buffalo, and different parts of Canada.

BAREMORE.--In this City, on Friday, Oct. 21, DAVID DAREMORE, aged 36 years. The funeral will take place from the residence of his brother, James Baremore, No. 300 West 20th-st., on Sunday afternoon, at 1 o'clock. His relatives and friends, and those of his brother, are respectfully invited to attend.

Secretary CASS is in the receipt of a letter from tile Mexican Consul at Brownsville, Texas, stating that the insurgents at that place were all American citizens, though Mexicans by birth. They reside in Texas, and only four of them passed over into Mexico. The Consul visited their chief in person, and induced them to disperse.

NEEDED REFORMS IN OUR CRIMINAL COURTS.Our esteemed fellow-citizen, Mr. C. A. DAVIS, is again Foreman of the Grand Jury ; and we may accordingly look to that department of our government for suggestions and recommendations touching the whole range of public affairs.

There occurred yesterday an accident to one of the main pipes of the Croton Aqueduct, which has temporarily diminished the usual supply of water to the City, while it has largely increased the estimate the public places upon it. The upper, or Eighty-sixthstreet reservoir, is connected directly with the lower, or Forty-second-street reservoir, by two large pipes, or mains, 36 inches in diameter.

Men in a panic are never apt. to be very sensible or judicious in their conduct. And some of our Southern friends seem to be in danger of doing themselves very serious damage under the excitement of the Harper's Ferry insurrection.
Mr. R. TEN BROECK'S new horses Sherritt and Pretty-by-Night have reached Liverpool in safety. The former has been renamed Satellite and the latter Maggiore.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--VERDI'S opera of "Rigoletto"--the best in many respects that the author has yet produced--was given here last night. Mme. COLSON made her rentree as Gilda, assisted by the new artists, STIGELLI and FERRI. The lady was warmly received by the audience, and sang with all the easy skill for which she is famous.

Two Presentments by the Grand Jury--Alleu Convicted for Shooting Dixon--The Perjury Case of E. Belcher Sackett. Yesterday, in the Court of General Sessions, before Recorder BAENAED, the trial of Edward Allen, for shooting Richard Dixon, on July 31, was resumed. The alleged facts in the case were published yesterday.

BOARD OF POLICE COMMISSIONERS.--Most of yesterday's session of the Board was occupied with proposed alterations of the rules. These were finally referred to a Special Committee consisting of Judge ULSHOEFFER and Mr. BOWEN, and were ordered to be printed.

General Session. CLOSE OF THE TERM--SENTENCES--E. BELCHER SACKETT ACQUITTED AND RE-ARRESTED--THE RECORDER'S CHARGE. Saturday was the last day of the October Term in this Court, and those prisoners convicted during the term, who had not been sentenced, were placed at the bar.

CULPERT--REMSEN.--In Brooklyn, E. D., on Wednesday, Oct. 19, by the Rev. Mr. Haskins. JOSIAH CULBERT, to CORNELIA, daughter of Peter V. Remsen, Esq., all of Brooklyn, E. D. BILLINGS--MCARTHUR.--In Hudson, N. Y., on Wednesday, Oct. 12, by the Rev. T. Borden, CHESTER BILLINGS, of New-York, to SARAH, daughter of Charles McArthur, of the former place.

The day following our last letter another outrageous murder was committed heret, in the presence or sight of a score or two of witnesses, at about 8 o'clock A. M. There had been a drunken revel during the preceding night by certain parties, and the general expectation was that some one would be shot, as these sprees by those parties are the prelude to their worst deeds.

A man, who gave his name as WILLIAM HARRISON, was arrested here to-day on a charge of being implicated in the recent disturbance at Harper's Ferry. He was at first supposed to be Capt. Cook, as he answered to tile description given of the man seen at Chambersburgh, yesterday, talking with Mrs. Cook. When arrested he made a violent resistance, but was overpowered.

EMANCIPATED SLAVES.--Mrs. Littleton died recently in Clark county, Virginia, freeing her slaves by will. Her children are now trying to have the will set aside on the ground that she was of weak min 1. Occasionally, however, the wishes of testators are carried out, and fifty negroes from Lynchburg, Virginia passed through Wheeling on their way to Ohio, on the 16th.

The English Cabinet, not without serious risk, as the news by the Anglo-Saxon shows, to its own unity and permanence, is gradually bringing to the light the particulars of the British diplomatic transactions in China, which finally led to the fatal collision of the English forces under Admiral HOPE with the Chinese troops posted under the command of Prince SUNG-KA-LIN-SIN for the defence of Tien-tsin.

The steamship Anglo-Saxon, at Quebec, brings trans-Atlantic advices to Oct. 12. Among other interesting news thus received, we learn that the Zurich Conference had not resulted in that immediate treaty of peace which previous indications had led us to expect. Serious misunderstandings had arisen between the Envoys.

DANGEROUS ASSAULT.--PETER FOGERTY, proprietor of the Union Shades, in South Brooklyn, was arrested yesterday, by Detectives FROST and DEN roN, on a warrant in which he is charged with committing a deadly assault upon tile person of SILAS Lorr. The injured man entered the above place two weeks ago Saturday night last, and was struck over the head with a club in the hands of FOGERTY.

The Rev. Dr. FORBES, who some ten years since relinquished his charge of St. Luke's (Episcopal) Church and became a Roman Catholic priest, has now announced his withdrawal from that denomination in a letter to Archbishop HUGHES.

The steamship Anglo Saxon, from Liverpool at 10 A.M., of the 12th inst., passed this point at 8 A.M. to-day, en route to Quebec. The steamship Kangaroo, for New-York, would sail an hour later. The steamship Nova Scotian, from Quebec, arrived at Liverpool at 11:30 P.M., of the 11th.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.-A moderately successful matinee on Saturday brought the first week's operations to a satisfactory close. The attendance, although not good, was much better than the management had a right to expect, for of late these matinees have been shamefully neglected, seldom coming up to a decent standard of excellence, and never to the grandiloquent promises of the management.

THE YALE COLLEGE REGATTA.--The annual ??sgatta of Yale took place at New Haven on Friday, October 21. For the championship and first class prizes four boats were entered, which drew for position, and were placed as follows ; 1st, Lorelia, (Nereid Club,) 2d, Cymothoe, 3d, Atalanta Shell, 4th Olympia.

The Albany Evening Journal is right in its supposition that we did not have Gov. SEWARD's Rochester speech before us when, on Friday last, we spoke of its failing to " explain clearly and unmistakably the means and agencies" by which tile Republican Party, when victorious, is expected to bring about the abolition of Slavery.

WAYLAND.--In this City, on Sunday, Oct, 23, EDWARD CULLEN, son of Charles C. and Margaret C. Wayland aged 9 months. The funeral will take place this afternoon, Oct, 34, at 2 o'clock, from the residence of his grandfather,

There was a scratch-match played here yesterday between the five cricketers from the North of England, and the five from the South, with six Upper Canadians on each side, to complete the elevens. C?ESAR and GEORGE SHARPE stood umpires. Messrs, O'REILY and HARVEY scored.

THE BRITISH BARK MAJESTIC AGROUND--ARRIVALS AT THE PORT. By the arrival of the bark Eliza Barss we have Bermuda papers to the 11th inst. The American steamer Albert Horn, of and from New-York, out five days, arrived at St. George's on the 1st on her way to Porto Rico for coal, and proceeded on the 2d.

At 12 o'clock yesterday, Commissioner LUSHER commenced the examination of the charge against Messrs. FAYSOUX, MAURY, ANDERSON and SCOTT' charged with preparing an expedition against the State or Republic of Nicaragua, or some other State, with which the United States are at peace, in violation of the Neutrality laws.

SCALY.-Messrs. FAIRBANKS Co., who have the reputation of being able to weigh anything, from. a meeting house to a row of pins, have devised a very useful article in their line, which they call the Union Scale, a combination of the platform and counter scale.

THE GERMAN ELEMENT IN OUR CITY.--The numbers and influence of the immigrant Germans in our City give importance to all questions affecting their character and condition. No citizen can be indifferent to so powerful an element of our population, or to the social and moral problems connected with it.

The explosion of DUPONT'S powder mills, on the Brandywine, yesterday, occurred about 10 3/4 o'clock, A. M., while the men in the lower or hagicy-yard were employed in loading powder-dust (as it is called when in a certain condition) at the press-room, to be conveyed to one of the other mills there, to go through another process. A one-horse cart stood opposite tho press-room door, partly loaded.

PRESIDENTIAL PLOTS.-A letter from Concord to the Boston Traveller asserts positively that Gen. PIERCE intends to be a candidate for the Presidency and that his friends are actively at work, both in the North and South, to secure his nomination at Charleston.

INCREASING THE SALARY OF THE WATER PURVEYOR--AGAINST THE EXTENSION OF WORTH-STREET--VETOES--REPAIRS--REPAIRS FOR THE TOMBS. Alderman BOOLE presented to the Board of Alderman, last evening, a resolution directing that the salary of the Water Purveyor be raised to $2,500 per annum from Oct. 1, 1859.

The following official letter has been addressed to the Postmaster of New-Orleans: POST-OFFICE DEPARTMENT, Oct. 8, 1859. SIR: The contract with DANIEL H. JOHNSON for carrying the California mails, having been cancelled on the 5th inst., the provisional contract, made with CORNELIUE VANDERBILT for this service, went into effect on that day.

When the Registrars, appointed by the Board of Supervisors,-three for each election district,--meet to revise and correct their registries, the law explicitly directs then to remain in session from 8 A. M. to 9 P. M. of both the Tuesday and Wednesday next preceding election.

THE TRAIL OF THE FILLIBUSTERS.--The examination of WALKER'S fillibusters is once more going on at New-Orleans, and the papers of that city contain the usual descriptions of the prisoners, compliments to their personal appearance and short resumes of their various exploits.

Who does not remember the legend of the Lady GODIVA and her ride through Coventry, with the noble heroism which nerved her to deed that took the people's tax away, and built herself an everlasting name? Who has not execrated the eager prurience of Peeping Tom " boring a little augur-hole in fear"

The United States Mail steamship Ocean Queen, Capt. SEABURY, from Southampton on the 13th inst., arrived here last evening. Her advices are one day later than those received from the Anglo Saxon at Quebec. She also brings full files of London papers.

The telegraph has already brought the brief announcement of the loss of the propeller Troy on Lake Huron, and the almost miraculous escape of three of the crew, the only survivors of the fearful catastrophe. There were twenty-six persons in all aboard the vessel at the time she foundered, all of whom, as far as is now known, with the exception of the first mate, wheelseman and second engineer, were lost.

Death of the Hon, William Jarvis, of Vermont. It will be seen by our readers that another eminent citizen, and one of great age, is dead. The Hon. William Jarvis, of Weathersfield, Vermont, died at his residence yesterday morning, nearly ninety years of age.

Business in the vicinity of Reservoir-square is preparing to lookup, even as all in these parts who who have eyes will gaze heavenward on the not far distant day of Prof. LOWE's balloon ascension. An attraction is preparing within the high fence which incloses what was once the site of the Crystal Palace,

We copied, yesterday, from a Savannah journal a very curious story, with which Mr. C. A. L. LAMAR has been amusing the good people of that city, concerning certain extraordinary performances of his notorious slavetrading yacht, the Wanderer.

The Madrid Iberia publishes the following strange story, which the London journals are inclined to regard as a canard: "It appears that the English engineers at Gibraltar feel offended and mortified at being placed under the orders of ?? and African architects.

The North Atlantic Steamship Company's steamer Baltic, ALFRED G. GRAY, Esq., commanding, left Aspinwall Oct. 18 for New-York, where she arrived last evening. The Baltic brings 707 passengers and $1,871,554 76 in treasure. A list of both may be found on Page 8.

THEATRE FRANCAIS.--Our first impressions of he new company at this delightful little theatre have been confirmed by each successive representation. Last week "Brutus lache Caesar," "Les Femmes qui Pleurent" and "La Corde Sensible," were given to numerous and delighted audiences.

CAUSE OF THE DISCONTINUANCE OF POST-OFFICE.--A Washington dispatch to the Philadelphia Ledger says; "A great many Post-Offices are being discontinued, for the reason that their postmasters are from two to four quarters behind in their returns.

The steamship Ocean Queen, from Southampton, Oct. 13, arrived here last night. Her news is one day later than that brought by the Quebec steamer. There is little of additional interest. The murderers of Chevalier D'AUVITI, at Parma, had been arrested, and would be instantly brought to justice.

The trial of BROWN and his accomplices in the attempt to stir up a Slave insurrection in Virginia is expected to commence to-day in that State. Knowing the general interest felt in the subject, the Associated Press has made arrangements to receive full telegraphic reports of the proceedings from day to day, which will appear, of course, in the columns of the TIMES.

A woman, who called herself COOK's sister, arrived here this morning, and had an interview with the man in custody here. She says is not COOK The prisoner will have a hearing to-morrow. He asserts that he has not been at Harper's Ferry. LEGAL COUNSEL FOR BROWN. BOSTON, Monday, Oct. 24.

GILBERT.--In this City, on Friday, Oct. 21, MARIA CLARISSA GILBERT, in the 71st year of her age. The funeral will take place from the house of her brother-in-law, Talman J. Waters, No. 314 West 22d-st., on Monday, Oct. 24, at 10 A. M. precisely. CLAIRE.--In this City, on Sunday, Oct. 23, after a short illness, JOSEPH CLARE, aged 69 years.

LECTURE BY THE REV. H. W. BEECHER ON BARGAIN-MAKERS.--A very large audience filled the Cooper Institute to overflowing last evening to listen to a new lecture from the Rev. H. W. BEECHER. The lecturer stated at the outset that it was a great deal easier to denounce evil than to do good, and therefore he could easily deal in sarcasm and invective on the subject of Bargain-making, but this might not do his audience good.

The crushing reply of Senator DOUGLAS to Attorney-General BLACK will be ready for publication, I understand, to-morrow. Your correspondent having been favored by a friend with a proof sheet, is enabled to give the readers of the TIMES a synopsis of the interesting document in advance.

FAIR IN AID OF THE ST. VINCENT DE PAUL SOCIETY.--The St. Vincent de Paul Society is an association of laymen, under ecclesinstical direction, whose object it is to accomplish for merit what the Sisters of Charity aim to do by way of duty. viz., to help the needy, to comfort the afllicted, to relieve the sick.

We have advices from Victoria, V. I., to the 27th, and from Portland, Oregon, to the 23d of September. BRODERICH, left here yesterday, with a considerable number of our citizens, on an excursion to San Juan.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--Mine. GAZZANIGA will make her reappearance here to-night as Pauline in "Poliuto." There will, we trust, be an enormous house to greet the great lyric tragedienne. Signors BRIGNOLI and AMODIO sustain their original parts. DRAYTON'S PARLOR OPERAS.--Mr. and Mrs. DRAYTON will bring out another of their charming little operas to-night.

There is a suit pending before the Court of Common Pleas involving the right of Aldermen and Common Councilmen to hire carriages at the public expense. So far as the present claim is concerned, various members of both Boards testified to its having been actually incurred in the discharge of their official duties,

A MURDERER'S SPEECH ON RECEIVING SENTENCE.--The murderer PATRICK MAUDE was sentenced at Newark, Oct. 24, to be hung on the 5th of January. When asked if he had anything to say why sentence should not be passed upon him, delivered the following remarkable speech: "Though it will make little difference what I say, I will speak, for this is an execution, or rather a crucifixion.

It is not certain that the Great Eastern will leave here for America this Fall, and it is not certain that she will not leave, as some of the London newspapers inform us. But it is totally undecided--nobody knows, and no definite statement about it can be made before another Director's meeting.

WHY THE DELAY ?--It is now quite a month since the Commissioners of Emigration forwarded to Governor MORGAN letters charging Dr. JEROME, the physician to the late Marine Hospital, substantially with contumacy, and asking His Excellency's early attention to the subject. We cannot learn that Governor MORGAN has given the topic any attention what ever :

The royal nail steamship Persia, Capt. JUDKINS, which soiled from Liverpool at about 11 o'clock on the morning of the 15th instant, arrived here at about 3 o'clock this morning, bringing 227 passengers. 15th inst. passed a steamship bound in to Liverpool, supposed to be the Arabia out. 21st, lat. 49[Degrees] 05', long. 41?? 36', passed a four-masted steamship bound east.

SPANISH ASSAULTS UPON SHIPPING--BRITISH VESSELS FIRED UPON AT TARIFA.--The Liverpool Post says: "The Gem of the Sea, which has arrived at this port from America, was fired upon when passing the Spanish batteries at Tarifa; and yesterday a twenty-eight-pound shot, which was received on that occasion, and which was lodged in her hull, was exhibited at the Underwriters' Rooms.

Judge ROOSEVELT has granted QUIMBO Appo a new trial, basing his decision on the ground that this, and not "pardon" by the Executive, is the proper remedy when a prisoner has not been fully heard, or has new matter to urge in defense or extenuation. He says, "there is no fitness in compelling a free citizen, if innocent, to sue for pardon."

The report of the special correspondent of this paper will be found to contain a very thorough, scientific description of the trial trip of the Great Eastern, with other details of great interest to the general readers. The general conclusion the writer seems to have attained is, that, while the expectations of the public, unduly wrought up by incompetent authorities, are disappointed, those of the projectors are abundantly verified.

The Lighthouse Board to-day opened proposals for rebuilding the Cape Ann Lighthouse, on Thatcher's Island. Thirty-five bids were received, but no definite action was taken. The War Department has received intelligence, of the death of Licuts. DONELSON and SOLOMON, at fort Laramie.

Speech of the Hon. Henry Wilson of Massachusetts--Sudden and Alarming Illness of the Senator. A special meeting of the Young Men's Republican Committee was held last night at Clinton Hall, Astor-place, Senator WILSON, of massachusetts, having promised to deliver an address. The building was well filled, but not crowded.

MYERA. - In this City, on Tuesday evening, Oct. 25, HARMET ALICE MYELS, only daughter of Jacob and Anee E. Myers, in the 3d year of her age. The relatives and friends are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, at 2 o'clock P. M., on Thursday. Oct. 27, from her grandmother's residence, No. 50 Columbias.. New-York City.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I observe in the Washington Constitution, of Saturday, an official announcement of the long threatened removal of the Hon. J. J. FARAN, Postmaster of Cincinnati. The axe has been suspended over his head for some weeks, and at last has fallen. It is due to Mr. FARAN, and not less due to the American public, that a brief Statement of the circumstances of his case should be given.

A few weeks since, Mr. WHITEHEAD, one of the Englishmen expelled from the City of Mexico by the Miramon Government, passed through this City en route for England. This gentleman was the agent in Mexico of the English bondholders. On his arrival in London the parties interested proposed a meeting to hear the statement of their agent, and confer with him as to the proper course to be pursued in the premises.

The United States vs. One Case containing photographic views, ,--The evidence in this case was closed and submitted to the Jury, who after a few moments absence, found a verdict for the United States, condemning the goods. SMUGGLING. Worms Reiga, who were indicted for smuggling watches and jewelry, which were forfeited some days ago, withdrew their plea of not guilty, and pleaded guilty.

HOPKINS and Mr. B. C. YANCEY, late the United States Minister Plenipotentiary near the Argentine Confederation.

The trial of BROWN and other Harper's Ferry conspirators commenced here to-day in the Magistrate's Court. Col. DAVENPORT was the presiding Justice, and the following magistrates were associated with him on the bench. Dr. ALEXANDER, JNO. J. LOOK, JNO. F. SMITH, THOS. H. WILLIS, G.W. EIOHELBERGER, C. H. LEWIS and MOSES W. BURR.

D., all of this City. BICKFORD--CURTISS.--In this City, on Monday, Oct. 24, by the Rev. J. Parsons Hovey, ISAAC W. BICKFORD to EMMA IRENE, daughter of Gharles Curtiss, Esq., all of this City.

MAZZINI'S letter to the King of Sardinia has been placed on the Royal table with an autograph letter from the writer. It is making a great sensation. Written in Florence, printed in Geneva, it passes silently from hand to hand, but I believe has not yet been translated and published in any of the London journals. I send you, therefore, its most important passages.

ANNUAL MESSAGE OF THE PRINCIPAL CHIEF. The annual Message of JOHN ROSS, Principal Chief of the Cherokee Nation, delivered on the 3d October, represents that tribe as in a prosperous condition; the Chief regretting, however, that the too free use of intoxicating liquors has p many disturbances and several homicides. He reads his people a moral lecture on this point. int.

The late lamented death of our Minister at the Court of the Tuileries, Mr. MASON, afforded the Emperor of the French an opportunity of signifying his personal and official respect, not only for the deceased Envoy, but for the nation which he represented, of which NAPOLEON was not slow to avail himself;

The special correspondent of the TIMES gives the public through our columns this morning by far the most complete and valuable report of the recent trial trip of the Great Eastern which has yet been published on either side of the Atlantic.

Theodore Parker writes from Switzerland, Sept. 26: "I intend to pass the Winter in Rome, from the end of October to the end of March. In many respects I am better than when I left New-York. I have gained nearly twenty pounds of flesh since I reached Europe, if the scales are correct, going up from 140 to 158 1/2 pounds. The increase in strength is quite equal to the gain in weight.

A serious accident happened to the well-known steamer New World, as she was making her regular trip to Albany last evening. About 7 o'clock, when off Fort Washington, the connecting-rod of her engine broke. By the accident a portion of the machinery was drawn through the bottom of the vessel, making a large hole, through which the water rushed so rapidly as to defeat all attempts to keep tile vessel afloat.

ANNIVERSARY OF THE SCHOOL OF THE REFORMED DUTCH CHURCH.-The celebration of the Two Hundredand Twenty-fifth Anniversary of the School of the Reformed Dutch Church took place last evening, at the Greenwich Church edifice, in Bleecker-street, corner of West Tenth.

From the Plymouth Journal. A rather remarkable shipwreck took place off this port on Tuesday afternoon last. The running foul of the Eddystone Light (which, probably, is better known than any other light in this world) actually took place on Tuesday, and resulted in the loss of the American ship Quebec, 700 tons, Capt. ALEXANDER RUARK, (as reported in the Shipping and Mercantile Gazette.)

WITHDRAWN FROM. THE STAGE.-The fillibusters at New-Orleans have, as we expected, been all discharged. The "young men" will now return to the arms of their admiring friends, and we hope stay there. In any case, Mr. BUCHANAN will do us all a favor by setting on foot no more prosecutions against them.

ANOTHER MONUMENT.--The Sons of Temperance are raising the necessary money to elect a suitable monument to the memory of the late DANIEL H. SANDS, who was one of the original founders of that Order. The monument is to cost about $3,000. Washington Division, No. 4, subscribed $50 to the fund last Monday night.

KING.--In this City, on Wednesday, Oct. 26, of consumption, CHARLOTTE G. KING, niece of James and Euphemia Cushing, aged 3 years. Funeral from her late residence, No. 190 Hester-st., at 1 o'clock on Friday, Oct. 28. Friends of the family are invited to attend, without further invitation. Her remains will be taken to Green wood.

FIRE AND LOSS of LIFE AT WEYMOUTH, MASS.-- At Weymouth, Oct. 24, a small building near the Almshouse was burned. It was occupied as a place of confinement for two poor, crazy, demented persons, named FLAVIUS HAYDEN and TIRRELL, who for several years have been kept in it in cages. At times they have been quite violent, and have torn their clothing into shreds and thrown it from them.

The New-Orleans Picayune, Oct. 20, published the charge of Judge McCALEB to the Grand Jury, in the case of the arrested fillibusters. The Court interpreted the Neutrality Laws as follows; "The general terms providing or preparing means were clearly intended by Congress to refer to the usual means for a military expedition.

MAZZINI'S letter to the King of Sardinia, which was published in the TIMES of yesterday, consists altogether of advice which, judging from the earnestness of the tone in which it is couched, His Majesty is evidently expected to take as soon as he reads it.

The people who are wont to assemble in Mozart Hall, and who swear by FERNANDO WOOD, met last night at the Cooper Institute, " to express their sentiments on the public questions of the day, and to ratify the State and County nominees."

The steamship Jason, from Galway on the atternoon of Oct. 17, arrived at St. Johns on Monday evening. She brings the gratifying intelligence that the American Minister, Mr. WARD, has been courteously received and entertained at Peking, and that he had strong hopes of sending home the ratified treaty by the next steamer.

The New-Haven Palladium of last evening says: "We learn that it is stated on good authority in New-London that the bark Laurens, whose seizure on suspicion of being intended as a slaver our readers will remember, has landed a cargo of about 600 slaves on the Island of Cuba! The Captain and mate have been seen in New-York for three or four days past.

THE OYSTER ISLAND QUESTION.-GOV. NEWELL, of New-Jersey, has written to Gov. MORGAN, of New-York, correcting a misapprehension on the part of the New-York authorities, of the intention of the late proclamation issued from Trenton concerning the use of certain mudflats for a dumping-ground.

Col. Martin Rosienkiewicz, a Polich exile, died at Cincinnati, Oct. 22, aged 67. Col. Rosienkiewicz arrived in this country with the expatriated Poles who were sent over by the French Government in its motional vessels in 1832, having been for a year previous incareerated in the Austrian prisons.

DOMESTIC MARKETS. In New-York, during the past week, a fair business has been transacted in desirable kinds of Wool. With reduced supplies available, prices have been well supported. Holders generally are disposed to reserve their stocks rather than make any concessions to purchasers.

In Philadelphia, Oct. 25, a large mass meeting of delegates from the different Trades Unions of that city was held in Franklin Hall to sympathize with tile iron machinery molders of Philadelphia, who are now contemplating a " strike." An association of the molders has already been formed, and embraces nearly 200 members.

The steamship Jason, from Galway on the evening of the 17th October, arrived at St. Johns, N. B., at 12 o'clock on Monday night, and sailed at 11 o'clock next morning, for New-York. The royal mail steamship America, from Boston via Halifax, arrived at Liverpool on the 15th.

Addresses of the Hon. Henry Wilson and Horace Greeley. A large meeting of the Republicans was held a Musical Hall, Brooklyn, last evening, for the ratification of the State ticket. Gen. H. B. DURYEA presided, and a list of Vice-Presidents and Sccretaries was selected.

Vice-President BRECKINRIDGE never spoke more truly than when he declared, on the battle-ground of Tippecanoe, in 1856, that the Kansas-Nebraska bill was passe by the Congress of the United States as a measure for future perfect non-intervention and non-agitation by Congress, and for Territorial Popular Sovereignty on the question of Slavery.

Since my last, nothing of decided importance has transpired in this dullest of cities. Petty skirmishes between the Puros and the Conservatives, as they call themselves, daily occur, but without exciting the slightest curiosity or anxiety in a population accustomed daily to hear of bloodshed and murder on every road and highway in the country.

A meeting of Republicans was held at Cincinnation the 20th, to celebrate their recent victory in Ohio. Governor CHASE being called on made the following speech: FELLOW-CITIZENS:-I should be more insensible than stone, it I failed to be deeply grateful for the kindness I have ever received at the hands of the friends of freedom. It swells my heart with gratitude to feel that warm and earnest support which the people have always extended me.

The trial of the Harper's Ferry conspirators was continued at Charlestown yesterday. The Court having decided the night before to place BROWN first at the bar, notwithstanding his urgent plea for delay, a Jury, apparently unexceptionable in character, was obtained. In opening tile case on either side, the counsel defined their views of the statutes and common law upon which conviction was sought, wide differences of opinion appearing between the defence and the prosecution. ADDRESS OF CONDOLENCE OF PRESIDENT GEFFRARD TRIAL OF THE CONSPIRATORS. By the arrival of the brig General Veazie Hayti files to Oct. 8 are received. Several of the journals are in mourning out of respect to the memory of the President's murdered daughter. Funeral services had been held in the different towns of Hayti, and the whole nation appeared to unite in sympathy for the President, sorrow at the crime, and detestation of its perpetrators.

In your issue of yesterday there appeared an editorial article on the present condition of affairs in Turkey, to which some exception may be fairly taken. The assertion is make that "The Tanzimat and Hatti Humayoun--the charter for the Christians which the Allies exacted at the close of the last war--have never been carried out and never will be carried out so long as their execution remains in the hands of Turkish officials."

UNSEA WORTHY VESSELS IN THE NAVY.--The frigate Minnesota, five years old, has been discovered to be more or less rotten throughout, owing, it is said, to unreasoned wood having been used in her construction. Before going much further, it would be well to ascertain how many more of the national vessels are in the same condition.

The Bridgeport City Bank vs. The Empire Stone-Dressing Company.--The following is the opinion of the General Term of the Supreme Court in this case: CLERKE J.--Whether a corporation can become sureties, either as accommodation indorsers, or in any other form, we supposed was, beyond all question, firmly established in the negative. We had occasion to discuss and decide this question, little more than a year ago, at the General Term of this District.

A fire broke out yesterday at a few minutes after 12 o'clock, in the one-story frame building at the rear of No. 40 Thompson-street, owned by Mr. H. BLAUVELT, and occupied as a chair factory. At the time the flames were discovered all the workmen were absent at dinner, with the exception of a man named THOMAS, through whose carelessness the fire is believed to have been communicated from the stove.

A few weeks since the report came from Aspinwall that one and a half million of dollars in Mexican silver, brought to Panama by the Calypso, had been forwarded to England. The Calypso is an English sloop-of-war sent out to the Mexican Pacific coast to protect English interests.

The central point for all army interest on this coast is now San Juan Island, and we are waiting in some anxiety for the next news from Washington, to learn whether or not the Government will sanction Gen. HARNEY'S forced occupany. The decision of public opinion here, both in the army and out of it, is almost unanimous in condemnation of his course. The general feeling is that he should be recalled.

COTTON firm ; sales to-day 7,000 bales, at 10 3/4 c.@ 11c. for middling ; sales of the week, 51,000 bales; receipts of the week, 68,000 bales, against 55,500 last year; exports of the week, 19,000 bales, making the total this season 181,000 bales; increased receipts at this port over last year, 97,500 bales; do. at all the ports, 101,700 bales; stock in port, 263,000 bales.

CONVICTION OF A MAIL-ROBBING POSTMASTER.--LUTHER PRESTON, late Postmaster at Fillmore, Minnesota, recently arrested for robbing the mails, has been convicted and sentenced to the State Prison for fifteen years. The discovery of his speculations resulted from robbing the mail of a letter containing two $1,000 drafts, forwarded by a Troy party in May last, to WM. S. JUDD., of Faribault, Minnesota. These drafts were drawn by the Merchants and Mechanics' Bank.

He directs the issue of a peremptory mandamus to compel the bonds to be delivered.

THE LOCOMOTIVE EXPLOSION AT SCRANTON.-A terrible accident occurred in Scranton, Pa., on Monday. The boiler of the locomotive Virginiaexploded. instantly killing five men, whose bodies, horribly mangled, were soon found, some of them quite a distance from the spot where the accident occurred.

The Mexican Minister, Senor MATA, has received advices direct from Vera Cruz by the Saratoga, at Pensacola. The Juarez Government does not authorize the consummation of any treaty at Washington, but signifies its determination to continue the negotiations at Vera Cruz, conclude a treaty there if possible, and if no treaty can be made, they will struggle on as best they can.

The news that a final treaty of peace has been signed at Zurich between France and Austria, although it may seem at the first glance a purely formal consequence of the arrangements at Villafranca, has, in truth, an importance of its own, and an immediate bearing on the events which are now taking place in Italy.

BOSTON MONTS DE PIETE.--A meeting of the stockholders of the Pawner's Bank was held on Saturday, at which it was stated that $33,000 had already been subscribed to the stock. The Toronto Globe, of Oct. 28, describes the scene at the International and Colonial Banks, of that city, which suspended payment on the previous day. The International was soon forsaken by the eager crowd of bill-holders, being given over as a hopeless case; and the through then proceeded to the Colonial Banking-house, doors of which were closely besiced.

Public interest in tile Bennett divorce case is again awakened by the fact that the petitioner has asked permission of the Court to take her two children by Dr. BENNETT out of Connecticut. A pamphlet of 48 pages, " By A Southernn Citizen," understood to be the lion. REVERDY JOHNSON, late Attorney-General of the United States, and one of the most eminent lawyers in America, is now in press with the following title: " Remarks on Popular Sovereignty, as Maintained and Denied respectively by Judge Douglas and Attorney-General Black. By A SOUTHERN CITIZEN."

An interesting case is on trial in the Superior Court at Boston, concerning tile contract between the Russian Government and William H. Lane, for the raising of ships and guns sunk at Sebastopol. It is a suit brought by Isaac P. Wainwright against Mr. Lane, to recover back money alleged to have been paid for a share of that contract.

The injuries sustained by Hon. Samuel Sloan, President of the Hudson River Railroad Company, on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, on Thursday last, amount to but slight bruises, from which he has quite recovered. The Council Bluffs Nonpareil announces the arrival, in that city, of the lion, Wm. H. Hooper, delegate elect to Congress from the Territory of Utah.

A CAPTURED SLAVER--THE ISLAND LEGISLATURE--COOLIES. Dates from Kingston, Jamaica, to Oct. 11, have been received. A baik, called the Laura, captured as a slaver by H. M. S. Archer, on the coast of Africa, had arrived at Port Royal. The Laura is said to be an American; but as she was captured under Mexican colors,

REGISTRATION OF VOTERS. Let it be remembered that to-day and to-morrow are the days set apart for the registration of voters. All who desire to be relieved of much trouble and anxiety on election day should attend to the business immediately. Last evening, the various Ward associations, both Republican and Democratic, met and appointed committees to see that all who were

COMMON COUNCIL.-The Common Council met last evening and reconsidered the action of the last meeting in regard to the Grand-street Railroad. The contract was, alter much debate, given to Messrs. WATERBURY, McGRATH Co., and the rate of fare was fixed at four cents. The Special Committee on the Water Works difficulty presented a report.

HAUSER--JACOBSOHN.--In this City, on Sunday, Oct. 30, at the residence of the bridge's father, by the Rev. Dr. Raphael, ISIDOR HAUSER to LAVINIA, daughter of I. Jacobsohn, Esq., both of this City. UNCKLES--SWITZER.--In Brooklyn, on Thursday, Oct. 27, at the Church of the Restoration, by the Rev. H. Blanchard, THOMAS H. UNCKLES to AMA F., eldest daughter of Henry Switzer, Esq.

LECTURE.-WENDELL PHILLIPS is to lecture this evening in the Plymouth Course at Brooklyn. His subject-announced as " Lessons for the Hour"-is quite certain to embrace the recent affair at Harper's Ferry.

Now that the season is fairly under way, and the new artists begin to feel the ease that familiarity with our audienees is certain to insure, sometimes to too large an extent, by the way,) we are having, at the Fourteenth-street establishment, a series of thoroughly enjoyable performances. They are complete in every essential, and in many respects better than anything we have ever had before.

PROGRAMME AND ROUTE OF THE PROCESSION. The only organized body of citizens of this City who have proposed to publicly do honor to the memory of the late lion. DAVID C. BRODERICE is a military company known in the Eighth Ward as the " Broderick Guards," Uniting with this company, the various fire companies of the City and vicinity have arranged the programme of a funeral procession,

Mr. Arch. L. Cook, one of tile oldest Morse operators in the United States, died of consumption at Baltimore, on Thursday last, having been absent from his post of duty but a single day, and that immediately preceding his death. Mr. COOK was for many years in the employ of the Magnetic and Southern Telegraph Companies, and commanded their respect and esteem.

THE VICTORIA BRIDGE.--The Montreal Pilot says: "We have it, on authority, that His Royal Highness the Prince of Wales, accompanied by the Colonial Secretary and other distinguished person ages, will visit Canada in the end of May or the beginning of June next. The formal opening of the Victoria Bridge will then take place.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In a notice of the death of JOHN TUCKER, under tile head of " Coroners' Inquests," in your paper of this date, I observe that Dr. FRANK HAWTHORN, House Surgeon at Bellevue Hospital, is censured by Coroner SCHIRMER and a jury for "insufficient and improper treatment of the deceased on his reception at the Hospital, and at the post mortem examination."

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The occurrence at Harper's Ferry appears to have inflamed tile passions of the southernn people to an extraordinary degree, and to have furnished our reckless partisan presses with innumerable texts for gunpowder editorials. Popular excitements are inevitably followed by reactions.

TOO SHARP BY HALF.-As a general thing we are disposed to maintain friendly relations with that large, intelligent, respectable and influential portion of the business community who advertise through the columns of the TIMES. We consider them on the whole as decidedly the most estimable and useful part of the human family.

The United States mail steamship Arago, D. LINES Esq., Commander, from Southampton on the 19th inst., arrived here last evening. Among her passengers we notice Mrs. JOHN Y. MASON and family from Paris, Hon. L. M. KEITT and Indy, Mr. JEROME NAPOLEON BONAPARTE, Prof. CHILDS. of Cambridge, and Judge FORSYTH, of Troy.

Action to Set Aside an Assessment of 1826. Rupert J. Cochran vs. The Mayor, c., and twenty-two others.--This was an action to set aside an assessment on certain property in Twenty-sixth-street, between Ninth-avenue and Hudson River, made in 1826, and now come on before justice MULLEN, at the Circuit of the Supreme Court.

We are glad to see that the Journal of Commerce urges the wisdom and good policy of committing BROWN and his associate convicts to the Virginia Penitentiary instead of hanging them. The Journal will scarcely be suspected, even in Virginia, of giving such advice from any feeling of sympathy with these men, or any lack of detestation for their crime.

Mr. CHILTON, on the rendition of the verdict against BROWN, moved an arrest of judgment, both on account of errors in the indictment and errors in the verdict. The objection in regard to the indictment has already been stated. The prisoner had been tried for an offence not appearing on the record of the grand jury,-the verdict was not on each count separately, but was a general verdict on the whole indictment.

We mentioned yesterday that Judge ROOSEVELT, of the Supreme Court, and QUIMBO Arro, the Chinaman, convicted of murder, were both served with a writ of prohibition, in the Court of Oyer and Terminer, on Monday morning. Judge R., it will be remembered, had interposed in His case peremptorily to order a new trial,-being satisfied that the previous -trial was faulty or insufficient.

MANSON arrested a fugitive slave at Columbus, yesterday, named TOBE alias John Tyler, alias Price-the property of Mrs. ELIZABETH GRIFFIN, of Cabell County Virginia. The Tammany Hall Democracy, summoned by big posters, Capt. RYNDERS' gun in the Park, and a band of music on the balcony of the " Old Wigwam," gathered in great numbers, last evening, at their ancient shrine, where they offered sacrifices in honor of "the regular nominations." There were high priests on the platform: Capt. RYNDERS and JOHN COCHRANE

MORSE--CHURCH.--In this City, on Tuesday, Nov. 1, at St. George's Church, Stayvesant-square, by Rev. Dr. Tyng, Mr. SIDNEY E. MORSE, Jr., to Miss ANNIE M., second daughter of John B. Church, both of this City. ANGELL--SUYDAM.--In this City, at St. Ann's Church, by Rev. Thos. Gallaudet, L. K. ANGELL to SUSIE M., daughter of Hon. J. H. Suydam. BUSHNELL--SOUDDER.--In this City, on Tuesday, Nov. 1, at the Dutch Reformed Church.

BURNED TO DEATH.-Mr. BENJAMIN LENT, of Yonkers, was burned to death on Saturday evening. He had complained to two other men, with whom he had been spending the evening, of feeling unwell. They had retired, leaving him by the fire, but soon after were awakened by the smell of smoke, and found Mr. LENT sitting in a chair with his clothes in flames.

We have already mentioned the cruise of the British sloop-of-war Calypso on the Western coast of Mexico, and her direct participation in smuggling silver out of that country without paying the export duty which the laws of Mexico impose upon it.

Although men of all classes and professions must die sooner or later, there are various kinds of departures appropriate to specific cases. The soldier meets his end most fitly on the battle-field; the sailor on the sea; the policeman in the hot pursuit of some desperate Bill Sykes; the patriot on the martyr's scaffold; the statesman in the halls of legislation,

The trial of SOLOMON COLE, indicted with Dr. DAVID D. WICKHAM, for the murder of the wife of COLE in March last, has occupied the Court of Oyer and Terminer, for Sussex County, during the whole week. The evidence was mainly circumstantial; there were some fifty-five witnesses examined on the part of the State, and about hall a dozen called by the defendant.

THE HISTORICAL SOCIETY.-The regular monthly meeting of the New-York Historical Society was held last evening at their rooms, corner of Secondavenue and Eleventh-street. The President, lion. LUTHER BRADISH, occupied the Chair, and the attendance was quite full.

LECTURE OF GOV. BANKS AT THE ATHENAEUM.The Brooklyn Mercantile Library course of lectures for the season was inaugurated last night, at the Athenaeum, in Atlantic-street, by an address from the Hon. N. P. BANKS, of Massachusetts, on "Personal Character," with especial reference to the character of WASHINGTON. The audience entirely filled the building, and the lecturer was repeatedly and loudly applauded.

The steamship Arago, from Southampton on the 19th ult., reached this port last evening. The general outline of her news was previously obtained through the Nova Scotian, at Quebec; but we enlarge it by extracts of interest from our London files. We receive confirmation of the announcement that a treaty of peace, on the Villafranca basis, had been signed by the Plenipotentiaries of France and Austria at Zurich.

Letters from San Jose state that Sir WILLIAM GORE OUSELEY has arranged a treaty, which only remains to be signed, with. Costa Rica, President MARTINEZ, of Nicaragua, has also acceded to the British Mosquito treaty , which is now pending before the Chamber of Deputies. The special mission of Sir WILLIAM being thus ended, and his health requiring change, he returns immediately to England.

On the announcement of Mr. Stephenson's death, a regular scramble for the vacant seat for Whitby was commenced. Four gentlemen at once rushed into the field-two Liberals and two Conserva. tives. A MS. novel, written more than 30 years ago by Lord Normanby, has fallen into the hands of a West. end publisher, who is said to have procured the necessary permission to publish.

An audience numbering nearly two thousands persons persons assembled in Musical Hall, Brooklyn, last evening, to hear an address from lion. THOMAS CORWIN, of Ohio, who, it was announced, would present his views upon the political issues of the day,;and more especially upon the doctrines of the Republican party, and the recent occurrences at Harper's Ferry.

The election in Baltimore has resulted very much as we ventured to predict yesterday, in bloodshed, disorder, and in the triumph of the " Plug Uglies." The Reform Party, after a feeble resistance, quitted the field and with. drew their ticket, leaving some dead and many wounded behind them.

The British screw-steamship Karnak, Capt. BROWNLESS, from Havana, 25th Oct., and Nassau, 27th, arrived yesterday morning, at 5 o'clock. On the night of Friday, 27th, she encountered a severe gale, accompanied by thunder and lightning and very heavy rain, the wind from East. Since then had strong Northerly winds and clear weather.

Messrs. RUSSELL and SENNETT, from Boston, reached here to-day. Cook was brought before the Magistrate's Court, and waived an examination. COPPIE'S trial was resumed. No witnesses were called for the defence.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--DONZETTI'S opera of the " Favorila" was given here, last night. with an unysually powerful cast, and with a degree of success which will, we think, insure its repetition. Mme. GAZZANIGA, whose voice has gained in strength and freshness, and whose method is rapidly improving, was thoroughly admirable as Lenora.

RATIFlCATION MASS MEETINGS.--A large and enthusiastic Republican ratification meeting was held last evening, in Union Hall, corner of Ewen and Messerole streets, E. D. Several of the candidates spoke .... The Independent Democrats in the Eastern District were addressed by Judge MORRIS, B. F. SAWYER, Esq., and others.... Speeches were made by Hon. F. B. SPINOLA, JOHN G. SCHOONMAKEB, Esq.,

We appreciate fully the pressure which constrains our Democratic brethren to make the most of the Harper's Ferry affair just on the eve of the State election. We are not in the least surprised at their love of the Union, nor their detestation of any project, however foolish and contemptible it may be, for compassing its overthrow.

We had an opportunity of examining, yesterday, an Invention which can scarcely fail to prove of very great importance in transmitting messages by telegraph. At present, as every one is aware, a message can only be sent as rapidly as one operator can spell the words and record them, letter by letter, in the characters used.

Within tile last two weeks five emigrant trains have been robbed of their cattle almost within sight of the Camp. It is unnecessary for me to write the particulars of these robberies; suffice it to say that it is a well-known fact that we are surrounded by organized bands of robbers, and that both the army and the civil authorities are powerless to break them up, arrest their members, or protect emigrants.

THE WANTS AND WELFARE OF SEAMEN.--The Port Society of this City have issued a call for a Convention of Seamen's Chaplains, to be held in the marinets' Church, on the corner of Madison and Catherine streets, on Wednesday, Nov. 9, at 10 A.M., for the purpose of "considering the best mode of advancing the temporal and spiritual interests of Seamen.'

HOPKINS.-In this City, on Tuesday, Nov. 1, WILLIAM II. HOPKINS, in the 63d year of his age. The friends and relatives of the family, also those of his sons-in-law, Leonard W. Kline and Edward McManus, are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, or Thursday, Nov. 3, at 2 o'clock P. M., from his late residence, No. 194 Christiest.

CLAIM ON THE PRINTING CONTRACT. The People ex rel. McSpedon Baker vs. The Board of Supervisors.--This was the return to the writ of alternative mandamus issued to the defendants requiring them to show cause why they should not pay the relators for work and labor done, and to be done, under it contract made with the relators by the Commissioners of Record to do printing.

The Ex-Emperor of all the Haytis has abdicated his powers and retired into private life, hod" boring the city of Kingston, in the island of Jamaica, with his ex-imperial presence. Driven to the last extremities, the portly FAUSTUN was indebted to the magnaminity of the General by whom he was overthrown, for permission to leave the country;

THE COMMISSIONERS OF EMIGRATION. ACCOMMODATIONS FOR RAILROAD AGENTS. MR. VERPLANCK presided at the meeting of the Commissioners of Emigration yesterday afternoon. The weekly report stated that 1,308 emigrants arrived at this port during the week ending Nov. 2, making a total of 66,592 since the 1st of January, against 70,525 during the same period last year.

The Democratic State Convention met in this city to day, G. H. FAIRCHILD, of Atchison County, presiding. The Committee on Credentials reported that at least twenty-one Counties, nearly one-half of the organized portion of Kansas, was reported to be represented by parties not living in the Country.

The news that the treaty of peace had been signed at Zurich is contradlcied; but it matters little, as the Italians are convinced that a lasting peace can never be signed between Italy and Austria until the Alps, Nature's own barrier, divide them.

If any doubts still linger in the minds of thoughtful men as to the real character and aims of JOHN BROWN, or as to the best way of dealing with his crime, they must surely be resolved, on the reading of his brief speech, made before sentence was passed upon him by the Court, and published in our columns to-day.

LOCAL NOMINATIONS. The following are the names of the candidates for the various offices which are to be filled at the election next Tuesday. Where the parties lave been in dorsed by minor organizations it is appropriately indicated.

The process of inflating the monster balloon, The City of New- York, is proceeding slowly, but steadily, at Reservoir-square. Thither thousands of visitors go daily to witness it, and to examine the lifeboat, the basket, the caloric engine, the lime stove, the anchors, the drag, the copper-float, and other apparatus to be used in the aerial voyage to Europe.

DEATH OF HON. DANIEL CADY. Hon. DANIEL CADY died on the 31st October, at his residence in Johnstown, N. Y., aged 88. He was one of the oldest lawyers in the State, having been admitted to the bar in 1795. He served in Congress during one term, and was elected a Judge of the Supreme Court of his State in 1847, but resigned in 1855 in consequence of increasing infirmity.

DOMESTIC MARKETS. In New-York, during the past week, the demand has been fair. Purchasers, however, have not been disposed to pay asking prices for desirable lots. Hence, transactions have been restricted. The receipts have been quite moderate, having amounted to only 662 bales, including 51 bales foreign and 611 bales domestic. Of the latter, 109 bales arrived by the Eric Railroad, 19 bales by the Hudson River Railroad.

The steamboat Champion, Capt. JOHN BROWN, of New-York and New-Haven line, left this City about 3 A. M., yesterday, bound to New-Haven. She had only a moderate quantity of freight, and about forty passengers, a portion o whom were ladies and children. When off Mattinicock point, about 5 o'clock, she came in collision with the large screw-steamer Albatross, from Providence.

The subjoined letters were received by the Tammany Committee, but in the crowd of oratory on Tuesday evening, no opportunity was found to have them read. The names and position of the writers may entitle them to the space here assigned them: FROM THE SECRETARY OF STATE. WASHINGTON, D. C., Oct. 31, 1859.

Mr. J. D. ALLEN, a member of the State Senate in South Carolina, was recently Invited to deliver an address before tile citizens of Christ Church Parish, on the Revival of the African Slave Trade." Being unable to accept the invitation, he wrote a letter declaring his full sympathy with the movement, and his confidence in its final success.

The steamship Bavaria, from Southampton on the l8th ult., arrived at this port yesterday after. noon. Her advices have been anticipated. Our special correspondent on board the Great Eastern sums up his reasons for concluding that the monster ship fails to establish any new facts in the philosophy of Ocean Navigation.

I am glad to be able to announce a moderate improvement in business since the steamers left on Wednesday last. Still, such largo quantities of goods : resold constantly under the hammer, at a sacrifice, that the jobbers are doing far less than they should at this secs n of the year. The auctioneers are reaping a harv st from our glutted markets; and so it would continue to be for some time to come.

My letters about the Great Eastern's trial trip, I fear, have been too technical in their criticisms and conclusions to be popularly interesting,--a pardonable error, I hope, in a matter almost wholly scientific. I would now simply. submit, as a review of the whole matter, a few plain reasons why the Great Eastern thus far fails to establish any new and momentous facts in the philosophy of Ocean Navigation.

FROM WASHINGTON. Mr. McLane's Instructions-A Protective Alliance to be Negotiated With Mexico--His Success Anticipated. OUR FOREIGN MAIL ARRANGEMENTS. Special Dispatch to the New-York Times. WASHINGTON, Thursday, Nov. 3. Mr. McLANE left this morning with his instructions, which are very full, not only including a new proposition on the subject of Transit Protection, but also looking to the possibility of a General Reciprocity Treaty,offensive and defensive.

If Tammany expected, in writing to the various members of the Cabinet, requesting them to be present at the recent ratification meeting, to derive any comfort from the answers to be returned by those venerable sages, she has been wofully disappointed. We published five of their letters yesterday, three of them tolerably long, and none of them contained anything but wailing and lamentation.

A correspondent of the Philadelphia Press writing from the Indian Territory, says: "Six bridges are being constructed upon the eastern end of Lieut. BEALE'S route to the Pacific Ocean, under an appropriation of money made by Congress for that purpose at its last session. The general supervision of the work is in the hands of HENRY B. EDWARDS, Esq., of Chester, Penn.

The new tenor, Signor BEAUCARDE, makes his second appearance to-night in DONIZETTI'S "Lucrezia Borgia." Opinion is greatly divided concerning the success which this gentleman achieved on Monday night, and it seems probable that two parties will be organized, one to uphold, the other to annihilate the "inspired tenor."

The inquest on the body of Sonny WHITE, the rowdy, who was shot yesterday in the Fourteenth Ward, is concluded. The verdict of the jury is that he was killed accidentally by a stray shot. There was no evidence to ;show that DUFFY, who was arrested on the charge of committing the act, had anything to do with it.

REVERDY JOHNSON'S PAMPHLET.--The arrival of the NEW-YORK TIMES on Tuesday--the most enterprising journal in this country--announcing that Hon. REVERDY JOHNSON was the author of the remarkable paper just published in Baltimore, over the signature of "A Southern Citizen," created quite a stir in political circles.

AN ESCAPED WIFE-MURDERER REARRESTED.--JOHN P. WARREN, of Willington, Conn., who murdered his wife by drowning her in a stream of water, and who was confined in the Tolland County Jail as long as he chose to stay there, has been rearrested. He was found under his father's barn, in Mansfield, and it is supposed that he had not been far from that locality since his escape.

A WHITE MAN LYNCHED IN LOUISIANA FOR STEALING NEGROES.-The Shreveport (La.) Gazette has the following account of the lynching of a white man who was arrested in New-Orleans for stealing negroes, and was taken to Shreveport: "Our city has been infested for some time back with bands of thieves and murderers. Several of our citizens had lost their negroes, and no traces could be found of them.

Our artistic readers will be delighted to learn that Hon. HAMILTON FISH has confided Mr. PALMER'S exquisite statue of the "White Captive," to the care of Mr. SCHAUS for a short time, and that it will very soon be exhibited to the public in the most favorable possible circumstances, under Mr. SCHAUS' skillful superintendence.
