If there be any bat or owl among our readers so purblind as to come under any of these categories,

The political cauldron bids fair to be thoroughly stirred for the next two months. We have now before us the election of a delegate to Congress on the 8th proximo; also county officers and a Territorial Legislature at the same time. Then a separate campaign is in progress for the State organization under the Wyandotte Constitution, and that election comes off in January.

BOARD OF SUPERVISIONS.-At an adjourned meeting of the Kings County Board of Supervisors, last evening, a communication was received from the State Comptroller, informing the Board that there is a tax of $260,000 to be levied on property in Kings County, valued at $104,295,591. The Penitentiary Committee reported that the expenses of that institution for the year ending Aug. 1, 1859, amounted to $27,857 45. Number of prisoners, Aug. 1, 1858, 280.

NEW-YORK SANITARY ASSOCIATION.-At the regular monthly meeting of the New-York Sanitary Association last evening, Mr. HALIDAY read some statistics relative to the number of those who do business in this City, but live in the adjoining towns. The aggregate of arrivals in, and departures from, the City for one year, he computed to be 87,255,610; an average of 265,000 a day.

There is no place where less is known about the position of Italy and Austria than in Italy and Austria. I have been traveling in Salzburg, Tyrol and Venetia for the last two months, and could nowhere find political news of the countries in which I was. Such a mass of rumors and fears as agitate the population of those regions is no source from which to obtain truth.

There is always more or less competition between the front-door and the back-door of every mansion. The parlor and the kitchen are seldom quite harmonious, and close observers never have any difficulty in detecting rivalries and jealousies between them, alike aggravating to the parties concerned and amusing to the lookers-on.

From the Washington Constitution. As briefly as possible, eschewing all matters personal or quasi personal, and without introduction or preface, I shall notice the only points in Mr. DOUGLAS' last pamphlet that are worthy of attention. He denies that his views on "Sovereignty in the Territories," as expressed in Harper's Magazine, are Inconsistent with those of the Supreme Court in the Dred Scott case.

MITCHILL--SMITH.--In this City, on Wednesday, Nov. 2, by Rev. Dr. Osgood, Mr. SAMUEL, L. MITCHILL, Jr., to Miss HELEN SMITH, daughter of Uriah J. Smith, Esq., all of this City. GARDNER--HAWLEY.--In this City, on Wednesday, Nov. 2, at the residence of the bride's father, by Rev. Dr. Hawkes, ROBERT W GARDNER of Jersey City. N.J., to ADELIA, second daughter of David Hawley, Esq., of this City.

THE EXECUTION OF JOHN BROWN.-The Richmond Enquirer, the immediate organ of Gov. WISE, treats the suggestion of commuting the sentence of BROWN with characteristic complacency and lack of common sense. It can see nothing in it beyond granting a favor to the Republicans and Abolitionists of the North;

THE COPELAND CONFESSION. THE PLUMBS OF OBERLIN DENY THE CHARGE. The Cleveland Leader publishes the following letlers from the brothers PLUM?? of Oberlin: OBERLIN, Oct. 31, 1859. EDITOR MORNING LEADER: I have just been shown the National Democrat, of this morning, containing a statement purporting to come from JOHN COPELAND, which, if true, would implicate me in the insurrection at Harper's Ferry.

The Philadelphia Evening Journal has the following paragraph concerning Mr. Paul Morphy: "At the Atheneum, yesterday, Mr. Montgomery had just taken his seat to play, but a question of chess etiquette arose which prevented the game. Mr. Montgomery thought that his reputation is such that he was entitled to play without receiving odds, and Mr. Morphy has made it a rule since his return from Europe not to play an even game.

SOUTHERN CROPS.--The New-Orleans Picayune has received accounts of the progress of the sugar and cotton crops. In the Lafayette Parish of this State the sugar-cane is yielding well. Cotton in the same Parish opens fast and yields largely. In the Parish of Feliciana the picking of cotton is progressing rapidly, and the yield is represented as quite large.

POSTMASTER-GENERAL HOLT-SINGULAR ACCIDENT. Correspondence of the Baltimore Sun. Postmaster-General HOLT leaves in the mail steamer this evening to accompany his wife, who is in feeble health, to a Southern clime, where she intends to spend the Winter. The head of the Department will be absent but a few days.

ONE MORE UNFORTUNATE.-It has been quite generally understood that the leaders of tile Democratic Party have been looking about for an available candidate in ease the Charleston Convention should set aside all the more prominent aspirants for the nomination.

The Cunard steamer America arrived at Halifax yesterday with European news to Oct. 23. Owing to the refusal of the Nova Scotian Telegraph Company to transmit the news, it was not received up to the hour of our going to press. The bark T. M. Mayhew, from Bermuda, brings us files of insular papers to Oct. 5. They contain nothing of interest.

The sessions of the State Teachers' Convention, which have just been concluded, have been the means of much instruction and of diffusing a great deal of valuable information on the many subjects which were discussed. The Convention occupid four days, and the exercises consisted in drilling in mathematics, geography, music,

CAPTURE AND DEATH OF CUBAN BANDITS.--The local paper of sancti-spiritus, Cuba, comes to us with an exciting account of the death and capture of two noted bandits, who had long been the terror of the Southern part of the Island, waylaying travelers, and even venturing by night into populous villages. Their names were JOSE SANCHEZ, and JOSE GARCIA, otherwise RODRIGUEZ, but commonly known as "Pope the outlaw."

A correspondent of the Journal of Commerce, writing on board the United States ship Powhatan under date of July 15, gives the following account of Mr. WARD'S interview with the Governor-General of one of the Chinese Provinces: The conference was now opened, being sustained entirely on the one side, and mainly by the GovernorGeneral on the other, the second red-button Mandarin only occasionally joining it.

Dr. Jacob Frick, formerly editor of the American Sentinel, in Philadelphia, died at Germantown, Penn., Nov. 1, aged 77. He held at different periods a number of important offices in Philadelphia. The Bulletin says: "The death of Mr. Frick narrows the circle of the gentlemen connected with the Press of half-a-century ago. When Mr. John Binns established the Democratic Press, in this city, in 1805, Dr. Frick was the book-keeper of the establishment.

MURDER BY A BOY IN PENNSYLVANIA.--The Westchester (Pa.) Record gives the particulars of a brutal murder committed in West Nottingham township, Chester County, on Thursday last. The victim was a young girl between eight and nine years--and BENJAMIN REYBURN, the supposed perpetrator of the crime, is only sixteen years of age.

To the Editor of the New York Times: It is notorious to every one connected with the naval service that our national vessels are manned, for the most part, with foreigners, and that the inducements for enlisting are insufficient to secure the services of Americans--more particularly of American seamen.

The Reformers charge it upon the Americans, and the latter retort the accusation.

Uriah A. Hyde, formerly of Somers, Conn., who left that town six years ago, and was last heard of at Springfield, Mass., where his horse and wagon were found, and he was supposed at the time to have been murdered, has turned up in the northern part of the State of New-York. He gives no reason for his sudden departure. It is supposed he was partially insane at the time.

The Journal of Commerce is quite right in assuming that the TIMES is not " an apologist for Senator SEWARD or for his connection with the Harper's Ferry affair." We shall be quite as prompt and quite as emphatic as the Journal itself, in denouncing him for any participation he may be proved to have had, in that nefarious assault upon the rights and the peace of a sister State.

PRACTICAL CHARITY-ST. PAULS ?? FOR THE POOR.-In accordance with the announcement previously made in this paper, the Home for the Poor is new opened at No. 367 Pearl-street. The object of this Home is to furnish meals and lodgings to the hungry and homeless poor, who at this season of the year fill our streets, and worry us with their importu??ate solicitations for help.

From the Louisville (Ky.) Journal. Mr. ROBERTS, the gentleman selected by J. EDGAR THOMPSON, Esq., as Chief Engineer of the Southern Pacific Railroad, left Memphis last week for Marshall, Texas, accompanied by Mr. LYONS, his, assistant, after an interview with Dr. FOWLKES; the Doctor himself has started for New-York to consummate such business as requires his personal attention before resigning the affairs of the Company to the Presidency of Mr. THOMPSON.

The project of rendering the Harlem River navigable, and of thus completing water communication around the island, is attracting the special attention of residents in the extreme upper part of the City. M'Comb's Dam, as our readers are aware, has been removed, and a free bridge, which shall not interrupt navigation, is to be erected by authority of the State in its place.

A point of law, which tile evening papers agree in pronouncing " extremely curious," has been recalled to light in the proceedings of a court-martial now pending in Brooldyn. It consists in a decision that an officer in the military or naval service of the United States is personally liable for his acts, notwithstanding they are performed in obedience tosuperior orders, in regard to which he has no earthly discretion.

The duty of Christianity towards the poor is one becoming more and more recognized in this City. THE BROWN INVASION TRANSPLANTED FROM KANSAS.-An article which we copy this morning, from the Lawrence (Kansas) Republican, throws fresh light on the movement of BROWN and his comrades at Harper's Ferry. It confirms what has been plausibly evident from the outset, that this invasion of Virginia was in the main a transplantation from the fields of Kansas.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The report of the monthly meeting of the Chamber of Commerce yesterday, given in your estimable paper to-day, affords us the opportunity to call the attention of the Chamber of Commerce and of the public to the Meteorological Observatory erected by Mr. C. BECKER, nautical and astronomical instrument maker, No. 54 Columbia-street, on the Brooklyn Heights.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.-"Lucresia Borgia" was given here last night, to a good house, and with much effect. The part of the heroine is one of the best that Madame GAZZANIGA has interpreted to our public, and is always listened to with pleasure. She was in excellent voice, and gave fresh evidence of improvement in the business of singing. Madame ST??AKOSO?? and Signor AMODIO were also very acceptable.

The Kemble vase, presented to Charles Kemble, by his friends in London, on his retirement from the stage in 1839, has recently been brought to this country by his daughter, Fanny Kemble, and placed in the store of Messrs. Shreve, Brown Co., for safe keeping and inspection. It is a massive and imposing work, standing 38 inches in a height, of pure solid silver, costing upwards of $2,000.

ARCHBISHOP HUGHES BLESSING THE BELLS. Last evening Archbishop HUGHES performed the interesting ceremony of blessing two bells at the Church of St. Francis Seraph, in Thirty-first-street, between Sixth and Seventh avenues. The edifice, which is dedicated to the service of the Catholic German population in that part of the City, was completely filled on the occasion.

CITY MORTALITY.-The health officer reports 116 deaths for the week ending Saturday last. They are classified as follows: Men, 19; women, 23; boys, 41; girls, 33. Adults, 42; children, 74. The cause of the removal of Captain MEIGS from the Superintendency of Public Buildings by the Secretary of War, was a difference of opinion between them as to the payment of certain claims, Captain MEIGS refusing payment because the vouchers were informal, and the Secretary of War ordering that the claims should be satisfied, as he knew them to be just.

Rev. Dr. Bayne died at Gait, Canada, Nov. 4. He was one of the leading ministers of the Free Presbyterian Church, and exerted a very important influence over its affairs. A preacher of great power, he built up a congregation in Galt almost unequaled in numbers in the Province. Madame Roger de Beauvoir has just died at the age of 36.

The Vanderbilt, which arrived yesterday, supplies us with correspondence and papers from Paris to the 25th, and from London to the 26th ult. The most important feature in the news is the growing distrust between France and England, and the popular conviction in both countries that a rupture is one of the possible events of a no very distant future.

Tile Catholic Library Association held their quarterly meeting last night at their rooms, No. 809 Broadway. Mr. JAMES A. McMASTERS, editor of the Freeman's Journal, embodied the results of much rare reading and industrious research in an improvised address, the purpose of which was to rectify certain historical villifications of the personal character of CHRISTOPHER COLUMBUS.

AN IMPROBABLE QUAKERESS.--Some New-England journals, ardently addicted to literary Abolitionism, have already begun to put JOHN BROWN to profit, in the way of small sensations. One of them, for instance, has just published a letter alleged to have been addressed to JOHN BROWN by a sympathizing Quakeress of Rhode Island together with a reply from JOHN BROWN himself.

Production of the "Sicilian Vespers." Faithful to the promise of the programme and the "pledge" of Mr. ULLMAN, VERDI'S new Opera "I Vespri Siciliani" was produced last night. The event was celebrated by an overflowing house, and by a degree of success which will in the end amply repay the managers for the very extraordinary expense they have gone to.

The boy whose duty it was to open the store in the morning had been in the building but a few moments,

THE TEXAS BORDER OUTBREAK.--Public attention is at this moment diverted from the outbreak at Harper's Ferry to one of another sort in the region of Brownsville, Texas, headed by CORTINAS, said to be a Mexican. The extent of this guerilla chieftain's operations, and the pertinacity with which lie pursues his murderous plans, Would lead to the belief that he is giving free course to deep-seated and longsmothered feelings of revenge.

A HIGHWAYMAN. Ex-Alderman Hiram Corwin, of the Second Ward, was asked to "stand and deliver" his gold watch and chain as he was coming out of a drinking saloon in Broadway, near Walker-street, about 2 o'clock yesterday morning. Instead of complying, Mr. Corwin seized the highwayman and held him, despite his struggles, until Officer Barbell, of the Sixth Precinct, came up.

The Hartford Times says it appears that the ?? jealousy which actuated Othniel Russel, the returned Californian, to attempt the butcher of Rev. Mr. Miner, in Dainelsonville, on the 11th ult., as not without some foundation in fact. Miner has made a full confession, acknowledging that he has had intercourse with Mrs. Russell for two years past, while a part of the time he has been pastor of the Baptist Church in Killingly.

As our first edition goes to press, we have very slight data at hand by which to measure the results of the elections which took place in various portions of tile Union. The general scope, however, of the returns before us, exhibits a decided probability of the defeat of tile Administration upon every portion of the wellcontested field, and the growing strength of the Opposition.

Some time last Summer a paragraph was copied from some of the English newspapers, stating that a Miss JOHNSTONE had made her appearance in England for the purpose of collecting money to sustain Dr. CHEEVER'S Church in the City of New-York. As a general thing the statement was entirely discredited.

MEETING OF THE ALUMNI OF COLUMBIA COLLEGE.-There was a large meeting of the Alumni of Columbia College, last evening, in the Lecture Room of the Historical Society Building. Rev. Dr. LEONARD opened the exercises with prayer. Rev. MANCIUS HUTTON, D. D., delivered the annual address. His theme was, " Man's Sovereignty or, His Right Lordship over this World."

To the Editor of the New-York Times: A communication in the TIMES, of Saturday (signed by a formidable array of initials,) suggests various improvements in the existing Naval Apprentice System. These suggestions may be judicious, as far as they go, and in the main practicable, but they lack one important clement of success, if the object be to create for the Navy an improved class of seamen.

It was towards the close of a lovely day, in one of the early Summer months ; the declining sun was pouring a flood of golden radiance - however, as you may have heard something very much like this before, and as the state of tee weather has nothing, whatever, to do with the matter hand, I will proceed in a more direct and less hackneyed style.

AWARDS FOR DESIGNS OF NEW PLYMOUTH CHURCH.--The trustees of Plymouth Church have awarded the prizes for designs for the new church building as follows: first prize to CHARLES DUCGIN, No. 332 Broadway. This includes tile superintendence of the erection of the building, which may be valued at S5,000. Second prize, $500.

JAIL DELIVERY IN MONROE COUNTY.-- The Rochester Democrat, Nov. 7. reports the escape of thirteen prisoners from Monroe County jail. The prisoners seized the jailor, Mr. BASCOM, by the throat wrenched his keys from him, and flung him violently into a closet, when the door was closed upon him and fastened outside by means of a hasp and staple attached to it.

Postmaster-Gen. HOLT has completed his calculations for the last fiscal year, and ascertains that his retrenchments exceed by a fraction the sum of $1,000,000. This is tile result of tile curtailment of the Mail Service throughout the country. Mr. HOLT sets down the sum at the round figure, reserving the fraction for future contingencies.

The ship Peerless, Capt. RING, from Calcutta, touched at St. Helena Sept. 19, and arrived at Boston Nov. 7. She left at St. Helena (says the Traveller) two slavers which had been captured by British cruisers on the coast of Africa. One of them was the brig Stephen H. Townsend, of New-Orleans, the master of which called himself a " Cosmopolite," and his mate a " Yarman."

THE IRON LETTER-BOXES FOR LAMP-POSTS.It is high time that this improvement was adopted for the better administration of the local mail service of this City. Philadelphia, whose letter-delivery does not bear comparison with ours, has several thousands of these boxes attached to lamp-posts, on the corners of streets, and the revenue of the Post-office Deparment is largely on the increase.

WENDELL PHILLIPS IN VIRGINIA.-The Richmond Enquirer reprints from our columns the lecture of WENDELL PHILLIPS on the Harper's Ferry insurrection, and makes use of it, with deliberate intent to inflame the feeling of disunion in the Southern States. The following paragraph is the key to the entire article:

We read in the Herald a few mornings ago that the Editor of the TIMES had been arrested for a libel on Commodore VANDERBILT. The statement was untrue at the time it was made,-but in the course of two or three days it was verified by the service of the writ. So yesterday's Tribune announces that the Commodore has commenced a civil suit for libel against us, laying his damages at $100,000.

Monday the United States sloop-of-war Brooklyn set sail for the Gulf of Mexico, having on board Mr. McLANE, United States Minister to Mexico. In the evening she returned to Quarantine, and Coroner HESLEWOOD was notified that a death had occurred on the vessel, the circumstances of which it would be necessary for him to investigate.

THE GREAT AUSTRIAN SWINDLE.--We commented a day or two ago upon the extraordinary revelations in regard to Austrian financiering during the last few years, which have just taken place at Vienna, and have carried consternation into the hearts of all holders of Austrian securities.

BARROW.--In this City, on Saturday, Nov. 5, after a short illness, CATHERINE, eldest daughter of James Barrow. The friends of the family are invited to attend her funeral, at Trinity Chapel, 25th-st., on Wednesday, the 9th inst., at 9 1/2 o'clock A. M., precisely. HARDY.--In this City, on Monday, Nov. 7, EMILY, daughter of John A. and Martha Hardy, aged 3 years, 1 month and 11 days.

AN HISTORICAL EPISODE.-Mr. JAMES A. McMASTERS, editor of the Freeman's Journal, endeavored, on Monday night, to set CHRISTOPHER COLUMBUS right in the eyes of the Catholic Library Association, of No. 809 Broadway. That body appears to have, for some time, harbored notions about the great man's conduct as unworthy of them as of him.

The excitement in regard to the trial of the Harper's Ferry conspirators still continues, and fair progress being made by the Court in the disposal of cases. The case of COPELAND, the free segro, was brought to a chose on Saturday afternoon, the Jury finding a verdict of not guilty of treason, as charged on the first court of the indictment, he not being recognized as a citizen:

It is hard to tell where our Opposition " leaders" now stand. They would have it that they are not "Republicans" nor " Democrats," but somewhere between. On the "Territorial question" they are " Dred Scott Decision" men, if such a decision has been made.

In obedience to a call, published in the TIMES, for a meeting of tile resident Italians to take measures in reference to assisting GARIBALDI in his efforts to obtain a million of muskets, a few persons assembled last evening in the Stuyvesant Institute. The meeting was called to order by Gen. J. AVEZZANA.

The Governor of Virginia appears to be quite determined that the "irrepressible conflict," which he so much delights to denounce, shall not be suffered to die away because its sponsor, Mr. SEWARD, chooses to turn his back upon American politics and to disport himself for a while among the Pyramids of Egypt and over the sands of the Desert.

Dr. CHEEVER, as many of our readers are aware, is one of the most able and self-sacrificing friends of the slave in the New World. It was scarcely possible for a minister of the Gospel in the Empire City to pursue a course so straightforward, and to make war with so strong a hand against the slaveholder, without exposing himself on every side to hostile influences.

THE BENNETT CASE.--The hearing commenced yesterday, (Monday,) before Judge HINMAN, on the petition on Mrs. BENNETT for leave to remove her children out of the State. She desires to go West, and the late decree of divorce prohibits her from taking her children out of the State.

MURDER AT STATE-LINE, MASS.--The Albany Argus, Nov. 8 says: "On Saturday evening a man by the name of REYNOLDS, a blacksmith by trade, who resides at Richmond, Berkshire County, Mass., and a laborer by the name of JAMES O'BRIEN, residing at West Stockbridge, were in company in the town of Canaan, Columbia County, New-York, but near the railroad depot at State-Line, Mass., and got into an altereation.

THE SEMINOLES DISSATISFED.-The Fort Smith Times, of the 26th of October, gives a detailed account of an interview of Maj. RECTOR with the Seminoles, who emigrated with BOWLEGS from the Everglades of Florida. They expressed much dissatisfaction with their new country, declaring they had been deceived, and demanded the purchase of a tract for them from the Creeks. The successor of BOWLEGS.

Like business, fashion, and music, the pictorial art in New-York has now attained the development of double season. Once upon a time, and that not so very long ago that the least naturalized citizen among us may not recall it, we used to look for our apocalypse of art in the merry month of May.

From the Baltimore Exchange. Mr. KYLE went to the polls of the Fifteenth Ward, on the morning of the election, at about 8 1/2 o'clock, that being the hour at which the Reform Committee had agreed to meet on the ground. He was accompanied by his brother, Mr. A. B. KYLE, Jr., whose assassination, shortly after, has produced so deep a sensation in the community.

STEPHENS--MONEYPENNY.--In this City, on Monday, Nov. 7, at the Central M. E. Church, by Rev. Mr. Hare, THEODORE B. STEPHENS to EMMA W. MONEYPENNY. both of this City. BYRNE--LOOP.--In this City, on Tuesday, Nov., 8, at the Methodist Episcopal Church, 31th-st., by Rev. Mr. McKown, EZRA V. BYRNE to EMMA J., daughter of George H. Loop.

The steamship City of Baltimore, from Liverpool on the 26th off., and Queenstown on the 27th, arrived this part at an early hour this morning. The general advices are the same as those received by the North American and the Vanderbilt, though she brings one day later news, telegraphed from London to Queenstown.

The United States Mail steamship Atlantic Capt. R. PIERSON, from Aspinwall on the 3d ihst., arrived at 2 o'clock this morning. The Atlantic left New-York Oct. 20, at 7 o'clock P. M., in company with the United States Mail steamship North Star. On the evening of the 21st inst. saw the last of the North Star astern.

We have no news of startling importance to send you by this mail, although there are a few items of minor moment that may be acceptable. Business does not improve with us. Indeed, I never saw a much more gloomy time, with trade, than is the present in San Francisco. Do not suppose this results from any decadence of prosperity, nor look upon it as a symptom that San Francisco is not advancing in wealth.

RECTOR with the Seminoles, who emigrated with BOWLEGS from the Everglades of Florida. They expressed much dissatisfaction with their new country, declaring they had been deceived, and demanded the purchase of BOWLEGS, them from the Creeks.

Last night a most destructive tire broke out in the large grain elevator and warehouse attached to the New-York Central Railroad depot, on Ohio-street and the dock, in this city, which entirely destroyed the buildings and a very large quantity of grain which was stored therein. The buildings burnt belonged to the Central Railroad. Their large depot adjoining the property destroyed was not materially injured.

The New-York State Election on Tuesday remains undecided on that portion of the Democratic State ticket adopted by the Americans at Utica. The vote between the Democratic and Republican candidates for Secretary of State runs close. The new State Senate will stand twenty-three Republicans and nine Democrats, according to present returns.

WISE, Mr. BUCHANAN'S Cabinet officers, the Fifth-avenue Democrats, and that special section of Southern chivalry so admirably represented by the frothy feculence of the Richmond Enquirer. They may one and all read in it the results of their joint attempt to conquer a peace by bullying the North.

The official organ at Richmond, Va., communicates in the shape of consolation to " A Small Slaveholder," that the reason why Gov. WISE does not make out requisitions for the delivery of the great Northern participants in the Harper's Ferry insurrection, for trial in Virginia, is that an affidavit has to be made, and an indictment found by the Grand Jury, before he can act in the matter.

EXPLOSION OF THE PROPELLER OHIO.--The officers and crew of the ill-fated propeller Ohio, arrived yesterday afternoon, from Sandusky, by railroad. Capt. NICKERSON says the explosion was at 2 o'clock, Sunday morning. The fireman was trying the water, and the second engineer was oiling the journal. The explosion was downward, as no steam was seen, and no one was injured.

It being now desirable to get as near the new port as possible, this ship and the Toey-wan were got under weigh

The returns from the New-York State election on Tuesday, received to 1 o'clock this morning, leave the result on about one-half the State Ticket in very considerable doubt. The County majorities, as nearly as they can be collected from all the information now before us-received by telegraph, and through the Albany papers and otherwise-foot up nearly the same for Mr. FLOYD JONES,

I have good reason to believe that the Administration feel confident of the success of Mr. McLANE in negotiating the proposed treaty with Mexico. Senior LERDO had an interview with the President yesterday. Since then he has received late and highly Important intelligence from Vera Cruz, which he has submitted for the consideration of our Government.

NEW CHURCH--The corner-stone of a new Mission Church, connected with the Strong-place Baptist Church, was laid yesterday afternoon at the corner of Hicks and Rapelyea streets. The building is to be 50 feet in width by 100 feet deep, and constructed in the Romanesque style of architecture. Besides the principal room for the regular services, it will contain accommodations for the Sabbath School and classrooms.

The addition to our naval marine of twelve new steamers, which has just been effected in the completion of the screw vessels and gunboats ordered by Congress, in 1856-7, marks an era in the history of the United States Navy. Ten years ago, we had only five steam naval vessels, all told-three of these being very small craft, and only two of them measuring 1,000 tons burden. Since 1850, however,

The trial of COOK commenced yesterday, and the Court-room was crowded. Covernor WILLARD and Mr. CROWLEY, brothers-in-law of the prisoner were seated beside him. He pleaded guilty to all the counts in the indictment except that of treason The prisoner was well dressed, firm and dignified. The demurrer to the treason count was argued and overruled by the Court.

If the Fifth-avenue Democrats are wise they will, amongst other improvements, introduce some better methods of celebrating Democratic triumphs , on election nights, than the playful scenes over which Messrs. TAYLOR and RYNDERS president, at Tammany Hall, on Tuesday night.

The People vs. Quimbo Appo and Court of Oyer and Terminer.--The General Term of the Supreme Court--present, Justices ROOSEVELT, SUTHERLAND and INGRAHAM--have rendered a verbal opinion allowing the writ prayed for by the people in this case. tice ROOSEVELT stated that the majority of the Court were of the opinion that the Court of Oyer and Terminer had no power to grant a new trial

At last the Commander of the Military Department of New Mexico has taken measures to punish the Apaches. An expedition is now in the field against them. Orders have been sent to Fort Fillmore to the commanding officer for Licuts. McNEIL, LORD and HowLAND, with 140 men of the dragoons and rifles, to report themselves to Lieut.Col. REEVE, at Fort Buchanan.

THE BALTIMORE CITY GOVERNMENT.--It will be seen by the address of the Baltimore Reform Committee, which we publish in another column, that they recommend an application to the State Legislature for measures necessary to redeem the city from its present hopeless condition of corruption and misrule.

We continue to receive startling accounts of Indian murders and depredations on our western frontier. The last mail brought the news that the mail route between Santa Fe and California had been abandoned on account of the Indians. It is now stated that the conductor and driver of the regular Santa Fe mail coming this way, was killed at Pawnee Fork on tile 24th September.

BOSTON, Wednesday, Nov. 9. The oil-cloth carpet-factory of E. J. TALBOT, in South Dedham, was destroyed by fire last night. Loss $10,000; insured $8,060. KINGSTON, C. W., Wednesday, Nov. 9. HENDERSON, COWAN CO.'s store, several dwellings, and also the steamer Britannia, were destroyed by fire last night. The loss is partially covered by insurance.

To the Editor of the New- York Times : Destiny of Italy is soon to be the theme of a European Congress. The great Powers, unwilling to surrender to France the lead in Continental affairs, prefer to encounter the grave responsibility of deciding issues between peoples and princes. In this august Council the United States will have no voice,

The National Convention of Chaplains and other Friends of Seamen, was opened yesterday morning at 10 o'clock, in the Mariners' Church, Madison-street, corner of Catharine. The assembly was called to order by WILLIAM B. HARRIS, Esq., Chairman of the Committee of Arrangements, on the part of the New-York Post Society.

CROWELL.--In this City, on Tuesday, Nov. 8, JOSEPH CROWELL, in the 75th year of his age. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfull. invited to attend his funeral, from his late residence, No 149 Charles-st., on Friday. Nov. 11, at 1 o'clock. KELLY--In this City. on Tuesday, Nov. 8, of consumption, SUSAN M. KELLY, daughter of Jane and the late Henry Kelly. late Henrt kelly.

THE FOG AND THE FERRY-BOATS.--A dense fog made its appearance about midnight on Tuesday, and continued until late yesterday forenoon. As a consequence there were several collisions between ferryboats on the East River, but none of the passengers were injured. Two of the Williamsburgh boats were badly damaged by coming in contact, and another boat belonging to the same line struck one of those running on the Fulton Ferry, neither sustaining much injury.

THE MISSISSIPPI VALLEY MOVEMENT.--The citizens of Carroll County, Ky., held a meeting in Ghent on the 5th inst., and passed resolutions declaring that the capitalists of " the big and little States," and of the "big and little cities" on the Atlantic Coast had governed the Mississippi region long enough; that they were tired of these abuses, and that they must have the building of steamers transferred to their waters.

THE NEST MAYORALTY. - Now that the State canvass is over, public attention will be fixed upon the City Election, which, we do not hesitate to say, is practically much the most important of the two. The principal contest will be for Mayor, Ex-Mayor Wood has already caused it to be understood that he intends to be a candidate, whether nominated by the Democratic Party or not.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: It is easy to see from the remarks of the "Many Patrons of Classic Opera," in your paper of this morning, that he would more probably be found amongst the audiences to hear "Roberto il Diavolo" than "Puritani," or at "Martha" than "Lucia de Lammermoor," in other words, that he admires the German in preference to the Italian School.

Hon. H. S. Foote, of Tennessee, publishes a card in the Washington States, it having been refused admission into the columns of the Constitution, denying, in the most emphatic terms, the charge made by the latter journal that he taken an oath, as a member of the American Party, to proscribe the Catholic religion.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC. The second performance of VERDI'S opera, the "Sicilian Vespers," attracted a fine house last night, and elicited an amount of applause which seems to promise a long and brilliant career to the work. An opera written on so large a plan, needs many performances before it can be given with all the precision that it demands.

THE "EGG" THAT WAS CRACKED BEFORE COLUMBUS WAS BORN, AND THE INEVITABLE IRISHMAN THAT DID TURN UP ON BOARD HIS SHIPS. To the Editor of the New-York Times: Having some materials in regard to COLUMBUS of deep interest, but little known, I am putting some of them in form of a lecture, which, in answer to kind invitations, I am soon to deliver before several (non-Catholic) Associations.

CITIZENS OF BALTIMORE: Your efforts for reform were defeated, at the recent election, by deeplycontrived fraud and overpowering violence,carried to an extent which could hardly be credited, were it not that you have experienced the one and witnessed the other. The extensive scale of the operations, their careful design and skillful combination, indicate direct complicity, or at least criminal connivance, on the part of the authorities of the city.

ELDRIDGE--GOODRICH.--In this City, on Wednesday, Nov. 9, at St, Bartholomew's Church, by Rev. Samuel Cook, D. D. , FREDERICK g. ELDRIDGE TO Miss ALICE LEE, daughter of Hon. S. G. Goorich, all of this City. FANNING--EARL.--In Brooklyn, L. I., on Tuesday evening, Nov. 8, by Rev. Justus French, ANDREW M. FANNING TO MARY A. EARL, both of Brooklyn.

The Richmond Enquirer has been thrown into convulsions by our statement that the Richmond Examiner " shouted to us from the fair vales of Shenandoah and the rocky gorges of the Virginian Alleghanies." It asserts, with all the solemnity of a witless under crossexamination, that Richmond lies on the James River, and is fearfully anxious to have the public made acquainted with the fact.

The Hungarian, of the Portland line, having touched at St. Johns, N. B., yesterday, furnishes European advices to the 2d inst. They are of importance. NAPOLEON III., it is reported, has addressed a letter to the King of Sardinia in reference to the Italian question, inviting the unconditional assent of the Court of Turin to the arrangements outlined at the Villafranca interview.

The Canadian Company's screw steamship Hun?arian, from Liverpool on Wednesday, the 2d inst., called off this port and sent in this morning forty-two persons, whom she had saved from the wreck of a vessel from Labrador for -. The lives of her officers and crew were nobly risked to preserve their follow-creatures from impending death, and the greatest praise which can be bestowed is due to them.

We make the footings to-night on majorities for Secretary of State, based on a greater number of correct returns than have been hitherto published, but still with many counties only estimated, as follows: LEAVENWORTH'S majorities, 45,007; JONES' majorities, 44,722-LEAVENWORTH ahead, 285.

THE DISPLACEMENT OF CAPT. MET??S - Upon receiving notice, from the Secretary of War, that he had been displaced from the Superintendence of the Public Works at Washington, Capt. MEI??S communicated the fact to the workmen in his emplo, expressing his regret at being compelled to sever their connection, and thanking them for the steady, faithful and effectual assistance they have rendered him during the past seven years.

Another magnificent flash of darkness falls to-day, from the telegraph, upon the Italian question. We are informed that the Emperor NAPOLEON has addressed a letter to the King of Sardinia, in which he urges VICTOR EMANUEL most earnestly to join him in realizing the bases of the peace of Villufranca.

An interesting incident has recently occurred near Independence, Mo., that has not yet found its way into " the papers," in Kansas or anywhere else. There was living with a very respectable slaveholder, a family of negroes, five in number. The head of the slave family had ascertained that they would probably soon be sold and taken South.

Erec Press states, that through the efforts of Prof. Leonard Marsh, and the ganerosity of friends, there has been recently acquired for the Institution a super copy, in 20 volumes, royal 870., of the great illustrated edition of Currier's Animal Kingdom--the notes and illustrations being made by a corps of his mots eminent pupils and successors in France. A large and beautiful collection of stuffed.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I find in your paper of this morning the following paragraph: "The principal contest will be for Mayor. Ex-Mayor Wood has already caused it to be understood that he intends to be a candidate, whether nominated by the Democratic Party or not.

SEOOND DAY'S PROCEEDINGS. The countrymen of SCHILLER were even more enthusiastic in the City yesterday, than on the previous day, and business among them seemed to be generally laid aside. The first public proceedings in the poet's honor commenced at 1 P. M, in the great hall of the Cooper Institute, which was comfortably filled-not to overflowing-with a most respectable and intelligent audience, among whom there was a fair sprinkling of Americans.
A correspondent remonstrates against our intimation that Mayor WOOD will have the support of the great body of contractors and other jobbers in city wok, for the Mayoralty.

GERRITT SMITH's INSANITY.--The intelligence of GERRITT SMITH's removal to the Lunatic Asylum at Utica, seems to be established beyond reasonable doubt. The Evening Post makes the following statements concerning Post makes the following statements concerning an alleged family tendency to this disease: "Mr. SMITH is said to have an hereditary predisposition to insanity.

ANGLO-AFRICAN READING-ROOM.-The colored population of the City had a pleasant time last evening on the occasion of the opening of the AngloAfrican Reading-room in Prince-street, near Thompson. Long before the hour appointed the rooms were crowded to excess. Rev. H. H. GARNET stated that the enterprise was but lately started, and that the words Anglo-African meant white and black.

One of the most disastrous conflagrations which it has fallen to our lot to record for many years, look place, yesterday, in the Fourth District. More valuable properly has before been consumed by a single fire; but perhaps for 20 years, by no single disaster of the kind, have so many families been rendered destitute, or so large an area been swept over by the devastating element.

The Court remained in session until 9 o'clock last night, when a verdict of " guilty" was rendered against Cook, for murder and insurrection. Mr. VOORHEES delivered a powerful address to tile Jury in favor of the prisoner, drawing tears from the eyes of tile most embittered of his auditors. This morning a motion for a new trial was argued and overruled.

Congress will find itself, next session; deprived of the old desks whereon members were in the habit of writing their correspondence and composing various addresses and articles of consummate ability.

There are various ways of assisting people in affliction, but the mode adopted by the Virginian authorities of soothing the sorrows of the citizens who were wounded at Harper's Ferry, certainly has the advantage over any other we have heard of in point of originality.

Special Meeting of the Common Council--The Water -works-A Railroad Grant Vetoed. A special meeting of the Board of Alderman was held last evening , President KALBPLEISOU in the chair.

By the arrival of the Atlantic, we receive, in addition to the news issued in the greater portion of our morning edition of yesterday, a budget of highly Interesting correspondence from all parts of the Pacific Coast. The political intelligence is of more than ordinary moment.

The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully, invited to attend his funeral, from his late residence, No 149 Charles-St., on Friday, Nov. 11, at 1 o'clock. KELLY.--In this City, on Wednesday, Nov. 9, of consumption, THOMAS KILLY, a native of the parish of Killare, County Westmeath, Ireland, in the 33d year of his age.

THE SPORTSMEN'S CONVENTION--THE TURF, C. The State Convention of Sportsmen, to be held at Geneva, N. Y., on the 15th inst., is exciting some interest. The New-York Sportsmen's Club has appointed Messrs. RIGGS and BOND as delegates. Wilkes' spirit is informed that the Committee of Arrangements has secured several thousand pigeons for the Convention to use a recreative amusement at trapshooting.

HERRICK-MCKESSON.--In this City, on Thursday, Nov. 10, by Rev. Dr. Hutton, J. HOBART HERRICK to M. AMELIA, daughter of John McKesson, Esq., all of this City. MERRALL--BEARD.--In this City, on Wednesday evening, Nov. 9, by Rev. Edward Lathrop, D. D., WILLIAM J. MERRALL and MARY E. BEARD, daughter of William Beard, Esq., all of this City.

The pardon of BROWN has been urged upon Gov. WISE by two classes of persons-Abolitionists, who desire it from sympathy with the man and his crime, and the Anti-Abolitionists, who desire to deprive that mischievous fraternity of the damaging stimulus of his martyrdom.

WILLFUL MISCHIEF MARKING.--The Richmond Enquirer has entered deliberately on the work of making as much mischief, and creating as much ill-feeling as possible between the North and South, out of the affair at Harper's Ferry. It reprints every Abolition fulmination it can find in the Northern Press, with the avowed purpose of "ministering fuel," in its own words, to the flame of Southern excitement.

Reliable information just received from Utah, states that Judges SINCLAIR and CRADELBAUGH are on their way to Washington. Mr. HARTNELL, Secretary of the Territory, arrived here yesterday. It appears that there continue to be frequent murders and assassinations, but no arrests, as the Mormons systematically obstruct the course of justice.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--VERDI'S exceedingly successful opera of the "Sicilian Vespers" will be played here to-night for the third time. The performance will, undoubtedly, be the best we have yet heard. WALLACK'S THEATRE.--BUCKSTONE'S famous drama of the "Wreck Ashore" (why so called it would puzzle a Philadelphia layer to divine) was produced here last night.

STEAM-ENGINES AND MACHINERY FOR ARIZONA.--The schooner Sea Ranger, now lying at Pier No. 19 East River, and about to sail for Port Lavaca, Texas, has on board two steam-engines of twenty-five horse-power each, with machinery for crushing and amalgamating silver ores.

WYCKOFF.--In this City, on Thursday evening, Nov. 10, after a short illness, GARRETT WYCKOFF, aged 57 years and 8 days. His relatives and friends are respectfully invited to attend the funeral without further invitation, on Sunday, the 13th inst., at 2 o'clock P. M., from his late residence, No. 141 West 34th-st. His remains will be taken to Greenwood Cemetery for interment.

The news we receive from Mexico is ot more than ordinary importance. Gen. MARQUEZ, whose departure from Guanajuato had been announced, had pronounced in favor of SANTA ANNA, and in favor of appropriating a conducta of $2,800,000, which had been entrusted to him for convoy to Tepic.

We have no fears that the pending dispute concerning the ownership of the Island of San Juan, will lead to any interruption of the friendly relations which now exist between the United States and Great Britain.

From the San Francisco Evening Bulletin. On Aug. 30 last, we published a letter from Mr. BEN HOLLADAY, defending the conduct of the Secretary of War in ordering the sale of over 2,500 Government mules, at Camp Floyd, when it was clear that they must be disposed of, if at all, at an immense sacrifice.

When the prisoners were brought out for sentence the negroes COPELAND and GREEN declined to say anything. COOK and COPPIC both addressed the Court, denying that they had any knowledge of BROWN'S intention to seize the Ferry until the Sunday previous, when they were called upon to take the oath of obedience to their commander. They expected to be punished but did not think they should be hung.

Mr. J. W. PAILLARD, Treasurer of the Committee which was organized to collect funds for the relief of Father CHINIQUY, has recently returned from aN official visit to Ste. Anne and Kankakee city. He reports that he has paid to Rev. M. W. STAPLES, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church in Kankakee, $1,034 75 for the redemption of the College.

The SEMI WEEKLY TIMES, of Friday, Nov. 11, contains: THE VIRGINIA REBELLION--The Latest News from Virginia--Trial of the Conspirators, THE NOVEMBER ELECTIONS--Full returns of the Elections in New-York, New-Jersey, Massachusetts and Illinois.

AN AMERICAN SHIPBUILDER ON BRITISH SHIPPING. From the Boston Traveller. Mr. DONALD McKAY, who, at last accounts, was making a tour of inspection through the British shipbuilding yards, has sent several letters to his friends in Boston, concerning the views of what he had seen. From these letters we have been permitted to make extracts that may be interesting to our shipbuilders and others interested in commerce and navigation:

I learn that important dispatches have been re ceived by the Government, with reference to the San Juan dispute. In them Great Britain expresses an earnest desire to settle the difficulties which now exis amicably, and in a manner which shall give satisfaction to the United States. She has no doubt, moreover, that this will be accomplished.

SCHOONER NAUTILUS AT CHIRIQUI--The schooner Nautilus, Capt. WOODDFINE, which left this port early in September for the gold-diggings of Chiriqui, arrived in that Lagoon after a short run, passing through Bacas del Toro. and anchoring near the terminus of the new road which crosses the county to David, on the Pacific.

DR. CHEEVER AND THE NEW-YORK TIMES. To the Editor of the New-York Tribune: SIR: A lengthy leader in the NEW-YORK TIMES of the 9th inst., reflecting on Dr. CHEEVER and his Church, deserves reply. The article is headed "A Disgraceful Appeal," and recounts that statements some time ago appeared in the papers that a Miss JOHNSTONE was in England soliciting aid for the Church of the Puritans;

VERDI'S "Sicilian Vespers" was played here last evening for the third time, to a house in every respect equal to that which greeted it on its first night. It was a good performance, the chorus and orchestra being in fine working order, and the principal singers somewhat more at home in their parts. Most of the morceaux were loudly applauded.

SEMI-ANNUAL REPORT OF THE FIRE MARSHAL.-By the report of Fire-Marshal BELKNAP, it appears that during the six months ending the 1st inst., there were 49 fires, resulting in a loss of only $42,944, being $3,294 less than during the previous six months. $27,000 of the whole loss occurred at one fire in June by the destruction of a cotton batting factory on William-street. Red Hook Point.

ANOTHER COLLISION ON THE SOUND.--Early last Wednesday morning the steamer Connecticut, in running out of the Thames River at New-London, came in collision with a small sloop at anchor their, doing considerable damage to the steamboat, and injuring two of the hands, one of them, it appears, fatally.

The military laurels won by President BUCHANAN in Utah, Kansas, Nicaragua and Virginia are green and glorious. But our illustrious Executive must look well to his renown, for the price of fame is perpetual preeminence; and a South American dignitary, the President of Peru, Don RAMON CASTILLA, is evidently in a fair way to rival, if not to surpass, tile hero of Harper's Ferry.

An intelligent correspondent writing, from the Valley of Virginia, a letter which we publish this morning, informs us that the most extraordinary revulsion of sentiment has taker place throughout Virginia, in consequence of the Harper's Ferry business.

The Convention was opened by the singing of a hymn. Capt. II. A. CURTIS then rose and announced to the Convention that news had been received of the loss of the ship Charles Thomas, from Liverpool to Mobile, and that the whole crew had perished. Mr. CURTIS asked the prayers of the Convention for the men of the sea.

THE ASTOR HOUSE BANQUET. At the Astor House last evening the Schiller festivities were pleasantly prolonged. The dininghall was appropriately and beautifully decorated. It may be considered as a remarkable feature of the occasion that ladies were permitted to partake of the banquet which was so bountifully provided.

The connoisseurs of New-York are beginning to learn that a great sculptor as well as a great painter may possibly be had (having first been born, which is, after all, as HORACE wisely sang, the great essential in tile genes's of genius,) in the studios of nature on this side the sea, almost as well as in the studios of art beyond the Atlantic.

The rumors of a Papal-Neapolitan attack in the Legations seems gaining ground. Austrian soldiers disguised in the papal uniform are daily arriving at Amona. The Roman Government has given orders for the supply of 40,000 daily rations, and it is certain that His Holiness has under arms 30,000 brigand galley slaves let loose, and mercenaries of every description.

Yesterday's Tribune contains the official vindication of Dr. CHEEVER'S mendicant appeal to British Abolitionists for aid in supporting his pulpit in the City of New-York. We must not be accused of any special spite against Dr. CHEEVER, still less of any overweening personal vanity, for transferring this document to our own columns this morning.

At Chambers, yesterday, Judge DAVIES entertained this interesting cause, upon an application for leave of absence made by a witness, whose property at Brownsville is endangered by the difficulties there: The plaintiff, S. Mussina, is the party who has so perseveringly sought the impeachment of Judge watrous, of Texas, for his alleged combination with some of the defendants herein, in the celebrated ?? case, to betray the plaintiffs and destroy their rights.

A scandalous story has been whispered about from ear to ear, during the past week, respecting an alleged abduction of a mulatto girl of this city, and her being sold into Slavery at the South. The Newport News was the means of the story being made public, and as it has thereby obtained general circulation, I will state the facts of the case, There are two statements, each of which has firm supporters.

The upper border of the map is the boundary line, on the parallel of 49 degrees, adopted across the Continent to the middle of the channel between the Continent and Vancouver's Island.

Not only the man who retires upon a hundred thousand, (the cotton aristocracy,) but young men, the premature lords of fortunes, " set themselves up" as soon as a lucky knot is tied, and sport their fancy tandems and the " family carriage."

The ship Emily arrived at this port yesterday in charge of Lieut. H. K. STEVENS and a prize crew from the United States sloop-of-war Portsmouth, of the African squadron. She was seized on the 22d of September by Capt. CALHOUN, of the Portsmouth, under circumstances which strongly indicated that she was about to engage in the Slave-trade.

The event of the contest in New-York is still undecided. We give a table of results as received and conjectured at Albany, corrected by later returns received up to the hour we go to press; and we thus find Gen. LEAVENWORTH apparently 1,484 ahead of Mr. JONES, in the contest for the Secretaryship of State.

Late dispatches from England report that the British Government approves heartily of the belligerent course which Spain has pursued towards Morocco. No hope is entertained by the British Legation i?? Mexico that either of the parties there will be able to restore order or to establish a Government.

From the New-Orleans Crescent. Matters are in a sad way in Brownsville, as will fully appear from the appended appeal to the citizens of New-Orleans, and letter from a highly respectable gentleman in Brownsville. The letter was written to a merchant in this city, by whom it was placed at our disposal.

HARPER'S FERRY AND THE CHARLESTON CONVENTION.--The Richmond Enquirer is making prudent haste to turn the Harper's Ferry affair to Presidential service. It nominates Gov. WISE, on the strength of his suppression of the rebellion. The South needs a "man of nerve," will extend the protection of her slave property to the Territories.

Judge NELSON having returned to the City, took his seat upon the bench this morning with Judge IN0ERSOLL, and the two Judges heard argument in the case of Charles Goodyear and William Judson vs. Horace H. Day, which is one branch of the India-rubber controversy, involving the manufacture of shirred India-rubbergoods. Mr. Dickerson opened the argument for the plaintiff.

The San Francisco Times publishes the following letter from the physician who attended Senator BRODERICK in his last moments. 132 KEARNLY STREET, SAN FRANCISCO, October 13, 1859. To C. A. WASHBURN. Esq., -- Dear Sir, I have received your note of this morning, requesting me to state the language made use of by the ?? Senator BRODERICK on the occasion mentioned in your note.

CITY MORALITY.-Dr. BOYD, Health Officer, reports 83 deaths for the week ending Saturday last, classified as follows : Men, 15 ; women, 18 ; boys, 26 ; girls, 24. Adults, 33 ; children, 50. Males, 41 ; Females, 42. Colored persons, 1. Fifty-two were under 20, and 7 were over 50 years of age. Sixty-one were natives of the United States.

By the arrival of the brig Water Witch, from Pernambuco, at this port, on Saturday, we receive intelligence of the total loss of the clipper-ship Queen f the Pacific, of and from New-York, bound to San Francisco. The Water Witch brought home three of the crew, viz., ALONZO P. FRISBEE, WM. SMITH and JAMES MABBETT.

ELECTION, IN NEW-YORK. THE RESULT STILL IN DOUBT-APPARENT MAJORITY OF 803 FOR LEAVENWORTH. We have contradictory advices from eight or ten of the Republican counties, which, on the vote for Secretary of State, (or the Utica ticket,) would so reduce the LEAVENWORTH column, in the table given below, borrowed from the Albany Journal, as to leave the result in as much doubt as ever.

A hearing was had, yesterday afternoon, before United States Commissioner HEAZLITT, in the case of MYRICK SNOW, first mate, and JOHN COSGROVE, second mate, of the ship Thomas Jefferson, charged with cruelty to seamen. The defendants were arrested by Officers JENKINS and SHARKIE. The crew of the ship, consisting of a rather motley crowd, representing almost every nationality, as well as all ages and sizes, was present in full force.

SARMON BY REV. DR. ADAMS. Rev. Dr. ADAMS, pastor of the Madison-square Presbyterian Church, preached a sermon yesterday morning commemorative of the twenty-fifth anniversary of his settlement in this City. The text selected for the occasion was a clause from Hebrews, xiii, 17: "For they watch for your souls as they that must give account."

We copy from the St. Louis News what, we doubt not, is an authorized statement of the views and sentiments of lion. EDWARD BATES on the subject of Slavery. Its intrinsic interest is enhanced by the prominence of Mr. BATES as an Opposition candidate for the Presidency.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I read with pleasure a communication in a recent number of your journal of the existence of an ingenious apparatus now at work in Brooklyn, by which every hour of the day is signaled by a time-ball. But, is this enough, and is it a benefit or an inconvenience to the public? For example, suppose at the hour of 1 o'clock P. M.

FIRE IN STEUBEN COUNTY. - LOSS $75,000. - The fire which occurred at Bath, Steuben County Nov. 5, destroyed property to the value of $75,000. The Advocate Extra says : Flames were first discovered issuing from the roof of a wooden structure on Liberty-street, occupied by Messrs. S. D. HUNTER as a dry goods store, and DAVISON SECOR as a shoe manufactory.

KENT.--In this City, on Sunday afternoon, Nov. 12, of intermittent fever, FLORENCE, daughter of Julia and Edward N. Kent, aged 4 years. The friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, on Tuesday, the 15th inst., at 10 o'clock A. M., from No. 157 West 14th-St, without further notice.

The United States mail steamer Granada, S. P. GEIFFIN, Esq.,Commander, from New-Orleans, touching at Havana on the 8th, arrived hero last evening. She brings $160,000 on freight from New-Orleans. On the Florida coast the Granada observed two ships ashore, with wreckers about them; one of them a vessel of large size.

On Saturday, the telegraph gave us its semiweekly installment of news from Mexico, brough to New-Orleans by the Tennessee. As usual, it reported the Liberals defeated, and the Press has taken up the items in evidence of the hopelessness of their cause. But, as usual, again the telegraph is mistaken in one or two important points, at least.

One of the curious consequences of the abolition of the East India Company, and the annexation of India to the dominions of the British Crown, is the growth of a movement for its total abandonment, which, within the last year, has been making steady progress in England, and is now receiving support from a largo and influential portion of the Press.

FATAL RAILROAD ACCIDENT.--A man named JOHN KEEFK, and his wife, were walking on the track of the Huson River Railroad, about 7 o'clock on Wednesday, Nov. 10, near Pecskill, as the up night express was passing, when they both fell against the side of the train. Keefe was instantly killed, and his wife so seriously injured that her recovery is despaired of.

Some of the Opposition papers of Missouri (the St. Joseph West among them), while admitting the indecency of private citizens, who suppose themselves candidates for the Presidency, thrusting their opinions on all questions, unasked, on the country, nevertheless appear to think that the case of EDWARD BATES is an exception.

ANOTHER SUPPOSED INSURGENT ARRESTED IN PENNSYLVANIA. SHIPPENSBURGH, Pa., Monday, Nov. 14. A suspicious looking person was arrested on Saturday, who was supposed to be a Harper's Ferry Fugitive--but after a hearing before Justice MAGKEY he was discharged for want of proof of identity.

Dispatches from the Home Squadron, dated on board the flag-ship Roanoke, off Aspinwall Nov. 2, have been received at the Navy Department. PASSPORTS.--The following official notice from the Department of State, appears in the Consatitution: " Information has been received at this Department, from an official source, that certificates from notaries in the United States of America, issued to naturalized or unnaturalized inhabitants, do not confer the right of entrance into Prussia, nor through Prussia into Germany nor, even with the visa of ministers or consuls, would they have any validity as passports.

The Philadelphia Ledger says: "The Kirkpat. rick case, which excited so much attention during the Summer of 1858, has taken another shape; the defendants in that case, Robert B. Kirkpatrick and Sarah Kirkpatrick, having become plaintiffs in a case against Edwin Kirkpatrick, Mr. P. Hutchinson and Charles C. Culin, the suit being brought to recover damages for the alleged malicious prosecution and false imprisonment of Mrs. Sarah Kirkpatrick.

A ROW AT CENTER MARKET--JAMES IRVING ASSAULTED BY A WOMAN.--While JAMES IRVING, the Superintendent of Markets, was standing in Centre Market yesterday morning, talking with Mr. TUOMEY, the Clerk of the Market, a German, named ENOLE-HARDT HEBRLICH, who has a stand on the premises, accosted him in no very complimentary terms, demanding to know why he (IRVING) had taken away one of this (HEBBLICH'S) stands from him.

HOW THEY ADMINISTER JUSTICE IN THE TOMBS. Not many months since, a tradesman of this city, standing at his counter, was visited by a peddler who produced his wares and invited the tradesman to buy. The latter being attracted by the appearance of a colored lithograph inquired the price, and upon learning that $2 50 would transfer it signified his willingness to purchase. .

THE MISSING STEAMER NORTH STAR.--The steamer Daniel Webster, which arrived at this port yesterday with the California passengers, of the Vanderbilt line, brings no tidings of the missing steamer North Star. The Webster left Aspinwall at 4 o'clock P. M. of the 4th instant, at which time she was fully a week overdue at that port.

Our neighbor of the Tribune has our compassion. We have seldom read a more touching appeal to public pity than that contained in his columns yesterday morning. From Washington. ILLNESS OF JUDGE DOUGLAS-PATENTS ISSUED. WASHINGTON, Monday, Nov. 14. Judge DOUGLAS' early recovery of health was, on Saturday, anticipated by some of his most intimate friends. It is, however, reliably ascertained that he has been extremely ill for the last three days. His physicians remained with him throughout last night, and, this morning, regard his condition about the same as yesterday, though, perhaps, a little more comfortable.

The Aldermen immediately organized as the Common Council.

The Mayor and City Patronage. There would appear to be a very general disposition amongst certain journals to censure the Mayor for a partisan administration of the City patronage, and to hold him responsible for the character of certain obnoxious subordinates employed in several departments of the City Government.

THE COLORED PEOPLE'S VIEW OF THE HARPER'S FERRY INVASION. MEETING IN SPRING-STREET HALL. A meeting of about thirty-five colored persons convened at Spring-street Hall last evening, in response to a call for "All those who love liberty better than Slavery," to hear an address from Mr. J. J. SIMONS' upon the attempted insurrection at Harper's Ferry.

UNITED STATES MARSHALL TYLER CONVICTED.-- The trial of United States Marshal TYLER, of Detroit, for shooting Capt. JONES, of the brig Concord, took place in the Circuit Court of St. Clair County, Mich., last week, and resulted in a verdict of murder in the second degree. Counsel for the State, Messrs. H. MCALPIN, JACOB M. HOWARD, and H. D. TERRY.

BOARD OF CANVASSERS.--The King's County Board of Supervisors met yesterday as a Board of Canvassers, in the City hall, and organized by electing Superintendent STYKER Chairman. All of the returns of the recent election were in except that of New Letts ; and as the law requires that all of them must be received before the canvass can be commenced, the Board had no alternative but to adjourn.

From the New-Orleans Picayune. By the schooner Peter Mowell, Capt. WATERS, arrived yesterday from Tampico, we have advices from that port direct to the 19th ult. The new steam-tug La Reforma arrived Gift on the 14th, and, from the notice in the Prisma, seems to have given general satisfaction.

D. FLOYD JONES PROBABLY ELECTED SECRETARY OF STATE. The State election returns begin to assume an official shape since the canvass made by the County Supervisors, yesterday. In this City and County and Kings and Erie Counties, the canvass was not completed.

If frequency of a change of rulers be a means whereby a country may be expected to advance in prosperity, the Bermudas ought to flourish rapidly. We have had here no fewer than three Governors within twelve months. Gov. MURRAY, after five years' rule, asked for leave of absence to enable him to visit England. He left in June last.

THE BONNER FORGERY.--The correspondent of the Springfield Republican gives the following details of the Bonner forgery: "I suppose you have read in the newspapers of the arrest of LEACH and BISHOP, charged with the forgery on Mr. BONNER, of the Ledger. But it has not been told in any newspaper just how that forgery came about.

Chief Clerk Post-office Department: DEAR SIR: It becomes my duty to inform you that mail-routes 8,606 and 8,595 are made impassable by the forces acting under the bandit CORTINAS. This force commands the country around in every direction to within 400 yards of our city market.

Links between England and America. From the London Spectator. So far from any severence between the two countries, there is at the present moment a constant Increase of new relations of a positive kind and of the most friendly character. Events but little known to the public are almost daily occurring which exercise a powerful influence in strengthening the bonds of individual friendship between the two countries.

THE ACADEMY OF MUSIC. The production of a new Opera is a matter of such labor, and is attended with so much expense and uncertainty, that a manager may well be excused for doing as little in that line of business as possible. Fortunately the public craves novelty, or we might reasonably conclude that never another new work would be given.

DINNER OF A MEDICAL BENEVOLENT ASSOCIATION. - The New-York Society for the Relief of Widows and Orphans of Medical men commemorated its Seventeenth Anniversary, last evening, by a dinner at the Metropolitan Hotel. About 180 persons, mostly members of the Association, sat down to the tables. Among the prominent physicians of the City present were Drs. FRANCIS, STEVENS, REESE, DETMOLD, JAMES R. WOOD, HORACE GREEN.

On the 14th inst. Corporal GORMAN, and Private CAULFIELD, of G's Company, 1st Dragoons, deserted from Fort Buchanan, while out in charge of the Fort herd, taking with them three horses, arms and accoutrements, and fled into the State of Sonora, where they met with a reception very different from that which they expected.

Jacob Mussina and Simon Mussina vs. John C. Watrous, impleaded with Samuel A. Belden, Charles Stillman, Robert H. Hurd, Elisha Basse and William Alling.--This is the original suit brought by the Messrs. Mussina, arising out of the alleged extensive land frauds, which Judge Watrous has been charged with aiding.

Government has received nothing official from Minister WARD since his departure for Peking, but dispatches announcing the ratification of the Treaty are expected by the next steamer. Dispatches from Madrid announce Mr. PRESTON'S departure for home on leave of absence. Mr. PRESTON objected to returning, but was influenced to do so by ex-Postmaster WICKLIFFE, who deemed his presence in Kentucky, as one of the executors of the late ROBERT WICKLIFFE, absolutely necessary.

I have seen many incorrect statements in relation to the Camp Floyd mule sale going the rounds of the newspapers. Being acquainted with the facts, truth and justice require that I shall give them to the public. A Washington correspondent of the Missouri Republican says that the reason for ordering the animals sold upon such short notice was on account of the great mortality among them, as shown by official reports.

HARRY LEE; OR, HOPE FOR THE POOR. HARPER BROS. When book readers shall have finished and discussed the great books of great writers, rested for awbile and taken breath, they will turn to this humbler touching tale of "poverty's wooing" and learn to love its unknown author.

The fate of the North Star steamer, of VANDERBILT'S California line, is still in painfull suspense. The concern and excitement in the public mind from the possibility, not to say probability, that she encountered some very serious accident on her outward voyage, is of course deepened by the great number of human lives with which she was freighted.

THE WATERVLIET ELOPEMENT--APPREHENSION OF THE PARTIES.--It is nearly two weeks ago since we stated that a man, named HOOTOUT, residing in the town of Watervliet, within three or four miles of this city, had abandoned his family, and eloped with his sister-in-law, a girl of only about seventeen years of age.

Our apprehensions on account of the delayed mails, travel and trade between here and New-Mex ico are at length allayed by the safe arrival of a mail train, bringing three over-due mails, three passengers and a mass of correspondence. They arrived on the morning of the 9th, in charge of the indefatigable conductor WOODRUFF, of whose kindness, energy and courage the passengers speak in terms of warmest praise.

From Washington. ILLNESS OF MR. DOUGLAS-HIS REPLY TO JUDGE BLACK-GATHERING OF CONGRESSMEN. WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Nov. 16. There is no perceptible change in the condition of the health of Mr. DOUGLAS to-day. When first stricken down he was employed in preparing a reply to Judge BLACK'S rejoin or. It was issued to-day, in a pamphlet form, in an unfinished state.

IMPORTANT RAILROAD DECISION.-- The New-Haven Journal, Nov. 16, says: It is not generally know, perhaps, that the decision of Judge BUTLER, ordering the New-York and New-Haven Railroad to afford the New-Haven, New-London and Stonington Railroad all the facilities it affords to the New-Haven and Springfield Road, was appealed from, and that the case went to the Supreme Court of Errors.

MEAKIM.--In this City, on Tuesday, Nov. 15, after a short illness, of pneumonia, ALEXANDER MESKIM, in the 45th year of his age. His friends, and those of his brother John; are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, from No. 170 East 15th-st., on Thursday, 17th inst., at ?? o'clock P.M. HYNE.--In this City, on Tuesday, Nov. 15, JOSEPH WM. HYNE, aged 63 years, 8 months and 19 days.

THE COLLEGE OF ST. JAMES IN MARYLAND.--The foundation-stone of the College of St. James, which is situated about twenty miles from Baltimore, on the line of the Northern Central Railroad, was Said on Tuesday, the Bishop of Maryland officiating. The site chosen for the building is on the top of a gently-sloping hill. Adjoining the hill 180 acres of land have been purchased, at a cost of about $7,000.

ARCHER--LOCKWOOD.--In this City, on Wednesday, Nov. 16, by Rev. Mr. J. Howard SMITH, JAMES B. ARCHER and M. LOUISE, daughter of F. H. Lockwood, Esq., all of this City.

The Cleveland Leather, Nov. 15, says: "GEORGE HARTMAN was yesterday morning brought before the Police Court but was immediately sent to jail to await action by the Grand Jury. The jury Failed to find a bill against him. This return was made about 4 1/2 yesterday afternoon. Many colored persons had attended Court closely through the day to learn white disposition would be made with him.

MESSRS. EDITORS: We are now on this coast about nine months, cruising most part of the time between Punta Arenas and Ralejo, watching, as we suppose, for fillibusters, of which there are on this coast, at present, very few. We arrived here on the 12th of this month, and found the U. S; steamer Saranac in port, with orders for us to remain until the arrival of Flag-Officer MONTGOMERY in the Lancaster, from Valparaiso,

Now that the Central Park is at last open to equestrians and carriages, the question how to make use of it becomes of immediate importance. Its vicinity will henceforth be in all probability a favorite place of residence for all who love daily exercise on good roads. It will also, we have no doubt whatever, stimulate the last for riding on horseback, in which our young men have hitherto been lamentably deficient.

The additional official returns of the State election, received yesterday, place the success of the Utica nominations almost beyond doubt. Official reports from all except ?? counties give to Mr. JONES a majority of 1,520 over Mr. LEAVENWORTH; while Mr. RICHMOND, for State Engineer, has a still more decided advantage over his Republican adversary.

Mr. ISAAC ELLIOTT, a prominent citizen of Philadelphia, died in that city on Tuesday, while stepping from his bath-tub. On the Friday Preceding, he was seized with vertigo in the street, and fell in front of a light vehicle, which ran over him before it could be checked. His injuries seemed to be very slight, and to appearance did not affect him subsequently.

The expedition against the Apaches is just taking the field. In all probability, Lieutnant-Colonel REESE will be commanded by Capt. EWELL; the other officers are Lieutenants McNEIL, COOK, LOAD and HOWLAND, Should Col. REEVE be unable to take the field, Capt. EWELL will command the expedition.

The case of Augusta vs. Samuel W. Mackerel and William Simpson, was disposed of in the Circuit, before Judge EMOTT, yesterday, the jury awarding plaintiff $450 damages. The defendants in this action are owners of the East Broadway line of stages in New-York city.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The trite proverb that "we should not look a gift horse in the mouth," ought perhaps to prevent me from making the following suggestions. Nevertheless, I feel that I shall have done others a service, as well as myself, if the following suggestions are adopted.

We have actvices from Tampico to the 21st ult., two days later. An extra of the official journal furnishes us the full particulars of the late outbreak at Victoria City. It was headed by one MAYA, a Spaniard by birth, some time since committed to prison for the murder of a French naturalized citizen.

The Fall elections of 1859 here made a memorable era in politics. They constitute a crisis in the political revolution going on. Six months since there was very little crystalized in our politics; now there is much. There was a vast opposition-an undoubled majority against what is called Democracy; but that opposition did not understand itself-wanted coalescence.

The Academy of Medicine held its monthly meeting last night, in accordance with the terms in which the adjournment of the previous meeting was carried. At a former meeting of the Academy a resolution to exclude reporters was submitted, and temporarily disposed of by being referred to that advisory section of the Academy which is known as "The Council."

The statistics of buildings erected in St. Louis for ten months previous to Nov. 1, show an aggregate expenditure of $7,173,000. This amount does not include the appropriation for the Court-house, of $125,000, nor the amount expended this year on the Lindell House, of $150,000.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.-VERDI'S Trovatore" will be played here to-night for the debit of Mdlle. ??, singer of the first reputation, who has enjoyed long career in Europe. Signor BEAUCARDE is the Manrico, a part written for him by the composer. On Friday the "Sicilian Vespers" will be played for the ast time.

The negro panic down South seems to be passing from the Press to the Executives and the Courts. Gov. WISE received, a few days ago, an anonymous letter, inclosing a document which, said tile writer, had been dropped out of the pocket of a young man who had been sitting in front of him in the railroad cars on his way from Philadelphia to New-York the day previous.

On the 17th October, towards midnight, James McGuire, not having the fear of bad whisky before his eyes, committed himself to the saloon of Michael Murphy, corner of Baxter and Worth streets. There he met with Patrick Clark, a young Irishman, 22 years old, who knocked him down and robbed him of four dollars and fifty cents. Yesterday Clark boldly faced a Jury, who convicted him, almost on the instant.

A sensible man has risen on the Virginia horizon-and the event creates as complete a panic as the appearance of a comet used to excite before the aspect of those heavenly bodies had become so familiar. The whole State is in commotion.

CURSES AND CHICKENS.--The old proverb that curses, like chickens, come home to roost, has been signally vindicated for the benefit of Mr. GEORGE BURNHAM, late "liquor agent" of the State of Massachusetts, in whose case both curses and chickens have returned at once to plague their author.

BOGUS DISTRESS--CAUTION TO THE CHARITABLE--There ought really to be some stringent law against enlisting public sympathy on false pretences. Charity is not so abundant a commodity in any community as to be recklessly lavished on pretended distress and simulated woe.

MISMANAGEMENT OF THE CITY FINANCES. MORE THAN THREE MILLIONS OF DEFICIENCY TO BE PROVIDED FOR. The result of past years of looseness in the management of the finances of the City is becoming more clearly apparent. Not a day passes in which additional indebtedness and additional deficiencies are not discovered, and all because of a lack of judgment in the matter of making the taxes of one year cover the deficiencies of the year before.

From the St. Louis News. A gentleman of this city, whose relation to Mr. BATES is that of a warm and confidential friend, assures us that the statement of opinions attributed to Mr. BATES in a late number of the Evening News, was not an authorized statement.
