CHANGES IN THE NEW-YORK LEGISLATURE.Only four of the members of the last Senate return next Winter. Messrs. WILLIAMS, PROSSER and TRUMAN, Republicans, and SPINOLA, Democrat. Mr. RAMSAY was in the Senate of 1856-'57. The rest, we bebelieve, are all new men. In the Assembly, there are twenty-two of last year's members reelected:

An extra performance of the "Trovatore" was given here last night, for the purpose of introducing Mme, ALBERTINI to a New-York audience. There is always " a something" -- as some one says with immense pathos and force . The "something" last night was a cold which entirely prevented Mme. ALBERTINI FROM doing anything like justice to herself.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: As one of your readers, I feel much obliged for the able statement of the facts bearing upon the San Juan question which appeared in a recent number of your journal, as well as for the very intelligible map which accompanied the same.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: While perusing the columns of the TIMES, (which I regard as a very independent, and, for the most part, truthfully-conducted journal,) I noticed an article captioned " The Presidential Mules," in which stritures of a temperate character are indulged in, reflecting no little discredit upon certain Federal officers of the War Department.

THE NEW TIME BALL. - The new time ball, to be used at the Capitol for the purpose of regulating the time at noon, has been completed, and will soon be placed upon the flag-staff of the Capitol. The ball is very ingeniously constructed, and is the work of Mr. WILLIAM EGGINTON, of this city.

RBNDITION OF FUGITIYES FROM JUSTICE.-JOHN J. HUYLER, arrested a few days since, charged by Mr. WM. VANDEVEER, of Newark, with having stolen a horse and carriage from him two years ago, and WM. BENNETT, under indictment in Newark for having stolen a gold watce and a purse of $20 from a man named JONES, were yesterday remanded to the New-Jersey authorities on a repusition from Gov. NEWELL.

CRICKET AND CHESS.-In Girard College, says the Philadelphia Press, a laudable movement is on foot to insert cricket upon the curriculum. The officers and more advanced pupils have already formed a club, and many pleasant hours are devoted to this healthy and invigorating exercise. On Thanksgiving Day there will be a great time with the ball, bat and wicket,

While we have satisfactory tidings of the safety of tde North Star, we are not lightly to forget the period of fearful suspense through which the friends of the passengers and the public have just passed.

If people could be induced to believe the professions made by Mr. WOOD in his letter accepting the Mozart Hall nomination for the Mayoralty, he would have a tolerably fair chance of success. But unfortunately for him the public has not the smallest confidence in a word he utters in his capacity of politician.

Ex-Governor GEORGE R. GILMER, who died on Wednesday at Lexington, Ga., was born in Wilkes County, now Oglethorpe, on the 11th of April, 1790. On account of ill health he was unable to prosecute his collegiate course, for which a thorough academical education had fully fitted him.

The English navel critics have been busy abusing the Russian frigate General Admiral, which they compare to a huge cotton ship; and they have instituted unfavorable comparisons between her and their Mersey and Orlando--frigates of about the same size as the General Admiral, but carrying much less weight of armament, with two hundred more horsepower.

BROOKLYN PARK COMMISSIONERS.-An adjourned meeting of the Park Commissioners was held Wednesday evening. A report, in favor of a chain of Parks, to be located on the high grounds running through the outskirts of the city, from tile vicinity of Fort Hamilton to Ravenswood Ferry, on the East River.

MEDICAL INSTRUCTION TO FEMALES.--The tenth annual report of the New-England Female Medical College has been published. The principal event of the year, in the affairs of the institution, has been the purchase of a college building in Springfield-street, Boston.

JOHN BROWN's LEGAL. COUNSEL.-Mr. GEORGE SENNOTT, who has been engaged for the past few weeks in defending BROWN and his fellowconspirators in Virginia, has returned to Boston. Although he is a zealous, thorough-going Hunker Democrat at home,

The items of Mexican news which have come to hand by way of New-Orleans have some interest, though they add but little to the information received by telegraph several days since. The Liberals have been defeated in their attack upon Cordova.

FIRE IN UTICA.--The extensive tannery of Messrs. FITCH ALLING, at the foot of ??-avenue, in Utica, was destroyed by fire yesterday. Three watchmen were employed to guard against any such accident. Two of them were sleeping at the time the fire broke out, and the third was on duty. He immediately gave the alarm, but the efforts which the three made to check the flames were unavailing.

Grace Greenwood lectured at Tremont Temple, in Boston, Nov. 15, to an immense audience. Her subject was, "The Heroic in Common Life." She spoke of the 'Dress-reform" movement very contemptuously, remarking: "I have had my heroic moments, when I even dreamed myself equal to the rote of Joan of Are and Grace Darling;

A DELIBERATE SUICIDE.--An old man, named EZRA HOLTON, about sixty-five years of age, who lived in Second-street, Boston, committed suicide on Tuesday evening, Nov. 15, under rather singular circumstances. He followed the vocation of a hand-cartman, and for many years has been employed by numerous business houses of Boston.

The following most important Chinese decree appeared in the Peking Gazette, of the 9th of August. It gives a very moderate account of the ;British repulse on the Pei-ho, and professes, on behalf of his Celestial Majesty, the most friendly feelings towards the United States and the American Envoy.

Since my last communication, no news of particular interest has reached us from the South Park and Blue River. All reports confirm previous statements in reference to the richness of the mines. Most of the miners have left the mines in this region of country, thinking that cold weather was at hand; but in this they erred, for more delightful weather than we have had for several weeks cannot be imagined.

Octavia Boyce vs. The City of St. Louis et al.This is a partition suit lately heard before Justice SUTHERLAND, at the Special Term of the Supreme Court. The facts are as follows: One Brian Mullanphy, formerly living in the City of St. Louis, lately died; being, at the time of his death, owner of considerable landed property in Missouri, also of some lying in this City.

SAFETY OF THE NORTH STAR. The Steamer Ashore at French Keys for Six Days--Her Voyage Resumed. CHARLESTON, Thursday, Nov. 17. A letter to the Charleston Courier, dated Nassan, N. P., Nov. 9, states that the steamer North Star, from New-York for Aspiawall, got ashore about the 25th of October, on French Keys, and remained on the Keys six or seven days,

The excitement in Virginia, arising out of the Harper's Ferry pronunciamento, seems only abated for the instant, to revive with augmented energy. Yesterday the most alarming accounts were forwarded from Charlestown to Richmond, to the effect that a movement for the liberation of BROWN was hourly anticipated, and that various barns and sheds had been fired by confederates of the incarcerated martyr.

RUMORS OF AN ATTEMPT TO RESCUE BROWN-VIRGINIA ARMS FOR THE FRAY. RICHMOND, Thursday, Nov. 17-Evening. The military here are under arms, and ready to march at a moment's warning, in consequence of reports from Charlestown of an intended rescue of BROWN.

A NEW CHAMPAGNE.--We have been urged to ask the attention of our readers to the new brand of champagne recently introduced into this country from the establishment of Messrs. BINET, SON C., of Rheims, in France,--of which Messrs. THRAILLON, HERBARD Co., No. 50 Broad-street, are the American agents.

To-day finds us just where we were on the 2d, the date of my last letter, except perhaps that we are a little worse off. Since then we have had no great battle. Both parties in the interior of the country appear to be making use of their respective military tactics to avoid a collision.

The Tammany Hall convention meets tonight for the nomination of a candidate for Mayor. The Republicans follow their example on Tuesday next. Both, we- presume, will nominate respectable men,--men who have position and influence in the community, and who enjoy the public confidence as men of integrity and some degree of public spirit.

The following statement of the wreck of the ship Mastiff, reported in our last news from the Sandwich Islands is from the pen of Mr. RICHARD H. DANA, Jr., of Boston, who was a passenger on board the vessel at the time of the disaster :

THE MINISTER'S WOOING. By HARRIET BEEOHER STOWE. New-York: DERBY JACKSON, No. 119 Nassau-street. We have never read Uncle Tom's Cabin. We mention the fact, not for the purpose of inviting Mr. BARNUM to offer us an engagement to go on exhibition,

Our community was not a little surprised on Sunday morning last, the 6th inst., by the arrival of a steamship of great size and power. It turned out to be the Royal Mail West India steamer Tasmania, Capt. JOLIFFE, from St. Thomas, bound to Englanda vessel larger than the Cunard steamer Persia, being no less than 376 feet in length, and drawing 23 feet water.

COLVIN.--In this City, on Friday, Nov. 18, JOHN COLVIN, aged 53 years. 10 months and 10 days. The relatives and friends of the family, also the members of the Street Department, and the Police of the Nineteenth Precinct, are invited to attend the funeral, from his late residence, Lexington-av., near 48th-st., on Sunday morning, the 20th inst., at 10 o'clock.

We have already referred to a demand made upon Gov. MORGAN by Hon. G. J. TUCKER, Secretary of State, for the removal from office of the Sheriff of Cattaraugus County, Mr. A. A. GREGORY, on charge of having mutilated the official copy of the Notice of Election sent him for publication in the newspapers of his County. It seems that the notice sent by Mr.

Very interesting details of recent events in Mexico are given in the letters of our Special Correspondent at the capital. The civil war progresses with its usual catalogue of horrors. Assassinations, robberies, and outrages upon persons and property, were of daily occurrence. Our latest advices from the City of Mexico are to Nov. 1.

Dr. HOWE:, of Boston, like Col. FORBES and several other persons at the North, supposed to be implicated more or less directly in tile Harper's Ferry invasion, have taken their departure for Canada. FRED. DOUGLASS has gone to England. Others will probably imitate their example.

ARREST OF A FUGITIVE MURDERER.--A little more than a week ago JEREMIAH SULLIVAN, a resident of Jersey City, while passing through Newark-avenue late at night, was assaulted by a negro named ELIJAH JONES. He received nine stabs with a knife, and was left insensible upon the sidewalk. In the struggle JONES lost his hat which the Police found near the scene of the struggle.

We have a new and curious phase of the troubles on our Mexican frontier. While our Press has been teeming with reports of fresh Mexican outrages,-and while the President is said to have been concocting measures for seizing Mexican territory by way of redress,

To the Honorable Board of Police Commissioners: GENTLEMEN: In compliance with my official duty, I once more make to you a formal report of the condition and operations of the Police force during the quarter just ended. There are altogether 1,699 persons belonging to tile Metropolitan Police Department, and of these there are:

The Federal authorities place no reliance whatever on the reports from Charlestown that efforts will be made to rescue BROWN. The constant fires which are occurring in that neighborhood have added much to the popular excitement here, and disunion is openly discussed in the streets. Q.

The California news for my letter of to-day contains little of marked interest, and is entirely overshadowed by the interesting news from the Sandwich Islands, sent therewith. By the mall of Friday last I gave you an account of the flight hence of a child twelve years of age, the daughter of an actor, and herself a promising pupil in histrionic art.

Our Postmaster-General is making vigorous efforts to abate, if he cannot Wholly uproot, the gross abuses which time and toleration have gathered around the franking privilege. He began by deciding, most justly, that no frank was valid which was not in the handwriting of the person whose name was used,-in other words, that no Member of Congress could authorize other people to sign his name for him.

The Navy Department is in receipt of dispatches from Com. TATNALL, dated at Woo-Sang, Aug. 30. Mr. WARD returned to the Powhatan on the 17th August, having exchanged the ratifications of the Treaty. He reports that he received very kind treatment from the Chinese.

John R. Platt et al. vs. Samuel M. Simpson et al,-This action was brought to recover personal property, it being the furniture of Engine-house No. 28, and valued at $1,500. The plaintiffs were formerly members of this Company, and the defendants still remain such, and have possession of the property sued for.

The Evening Journal's footings-up to noon today show the following majorities: JONES, 816; SKINNER, 175-deducting the reported gain of 206 for CHAPIN in Richmond County; FORREST, 400; RICHMOND, 1,000. ALBANY, Friday, Nov. 18-10 P.M.

Mr. THURLOW WEED AND THE HERALD.With reference to the partial retraction made by the Herald of the charges preferred against Mr. THURLOW WEED, the Journal of last evening says: It is quite true that for nearly thirty years we have been saying ugly things of the Herald and its editor.

This forenoon the bark Samuel Shepherd, Capt. HATHAWAY, from Havana, brought to this port the only survivor of the schooner Charles S. Peaslee, which was wrecked at sea in October. The schooner sailed from Jacksonville the latter part of October, laden with lumber, and bound to Philadelphia, under the command of Capt. BAKER.

FATAL FALL.-A seaman named H. S. COLLISON, belonging to the schooner A. T. Eells, lying at the South Brooklyn naval store yard, Thursday evening, while intoxicated, fell from the string-piece of the dock into the hold of a lighter, and was instantly killed. Coroner HORTON was notified anti held an inquest.

PRANKARD--MARSHALL.--In this City, on Wednesday evening, Nov. 16, at the Stanton-st. Baptist Church, by Rev. Dr. Hiscox, FRANCIS T. PRANKARD to ADELAIDE R., youngest daughter of M. J. Marshall, all of this City. HART--NESTELL.--In this City, on Wednesday, Nov. 16, by Rev. James L. Shock, JOSEPH H. HART, Jr.. Esq., of Chicago, to EMMA S. NESTELL, eldest daughter of John J. Nestell, Esq., of this City.

The Fire Department of our City has been engaged for several weeks in getting up a parade in honor of the late Senator BRODERICK, of California, with special reference to the position he once held as foreman of one of our fire companies.

The Cincinnati Gazette has a letter from Cambridge City, Ind., dated Nov. 16, which develops a curious history of depredations upon the mails. The writer says: From present indications, it appears that one of our fast young men is, at last, to get his deserts and justice to be rewarded by an examination, at least, of grave charges against him.

A FIGHT IN THE STREETS.-While several individuals were in a barber's shop on Clinton-street, near Pierrepont, yesterday morning, about 11 o'clock, a dispute arose between BARNEY MCCAFFREY and Deputy Sheriff G. F. HARDY, as to whose turn it was to be shaved, The former claimed that his turn had arrived, and took the vacant seat.

Senator NICOLSON reached here to-day, and reported an interesting programme for the organization of the House. JEREMIAH CLEMENS claims to be fully authorized to speak for the entire Southern delegation, including H. WINNER DAVIS. If the Anti-Lecomptonites stand firmly by the Democracy,

The following letter appears in the Philadelphia Evening Bulletin: BEESELEY'S POINT, CAPE MAY COUNTY, N. J., Thursday, Nov. 17, 1859. On Tuesday, the 15th inst., the inhabitants of this place were startled by a very extraordinary meteorie phenomenon, which shook the windows and doors of some of the houses, considerably disturbing the equanimity of the inmates.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.-MOZART'S opera of the " Magic Flute" will be produced here to-night for the first time. A work so world-renowned will not be without honor here. Tile cast is exceedingly good, and includes all the best artists of the Academy. Mme. COLSON is the Queen of the Night;

The long-talked-of-funeral obsequies of the late United States Senator, DAVID C. BRODERICK, by the Fire Department of this City, took place yesterday afternoon, and were witnessed by many thousands of spectators, the streets through which the procession passed, and the balconies of the houses, present ??, apparently, one dense mass of human beings, of whom a large proportion were ladies.

All is quiet at Charlestown, but the military forces are steadily augmenting there. The barns, stock-yards and farming implements, amounting In value to many thousands of dollars, the property of Messrs. JOHN BURNS, GEORGE H. TATE and M. SHIRLEY, all of whom were jurors upon the late trials have been destroyed by incendiaries.

We are decidedly puzzled by the Virginia demonstrations over the John Brown invasion. In common with the whole North, we have been astonished at the immense outcry raised over that wild and absurd freak of a hardheaded, strong-willed fanatic.

The President of the United States has quietly relieved his Minister in Mexico of the most important duties connected with his mission. In full Cabinet Council, after mature deliberation upon the actual state of our relations with Mexico,and upon the nature of the recent troubles

We are permitted to copy part of a letter to one of our citizens, from a reliable source, which throws a new light upon the supposed stealthy escape of the Wanderer, and strongly squints to the connivance of the Government officials in such escape. We would call the attention of the authorities at Washington to the statements contained in the letter,

The Cabinet determined this morning, in extraordinary session, to invade Mexico, and seize upon the Northern States. Six companies of heavy artillery at Fort Monroe, Old Point Comfort, are ordered by telegraph to hold themselves in readiness to leave for Brownsville as soon as the Quartermaster in New-York can obey the orders which have been given him to charter a steamer immediately for their accommodation.

We have no further particulars of the fatal rencontre at Nashville, on Friday last, than the telegraphic statement that Mr. ALLEN A. HALL, of the Daily News, killed Mr. PCINDENTER, of the Union and American. The previous editorial controversy between the parties was no-doubt bitter and personal.

The Boston Transcript states that a complete set of the London Times for the past thirty years has been presented to the library of the Boston Atheneum by Bussell Sturgis, Esq.. of the firm of Baring Bros., of London. There has been hitherto no file of this paper in any public library in Boston.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The "Meteoric Displays" already noticed in your paper as occurring on Tuesday, were simultaneous, or very nearly so, with one observed by me at Passaic Falls. A few minutes before 10 A. M., as I was standing near the Falls,

The Tammany Democracy have made a most excellent beginning of the City canvass. They have nominated Mr. HAVEMEYER for Mayor, and S. J. TILDEN, ESq., for Corporation Counsel. Both are excellent nominations, and both, we are assured on good authority, have accepted and will run.

The Cunard steamship Canada, from Liverpool at 3 P. M. of the 5th inst., and Queenstown evening of the 7th inst., arrived at Halifax at 4 A. M. to-day?? She sailed this morning for Boston, where she had not arrived at the hour we go to press. The steamship Indian, from Quebec, arrived at Liverpool at 2:10 P. M. of the 3d, and the City of Washington, from New-York, arrived about two hours later.

THE BRODERICK PROCESSION.--We fear the slain Senator BRODERICK scarcely received his full meed of public honor from the procession held yesterday on his behalf. Such funeral demonstrations, being purely scenic in their character, depend wholly on their numbers and the pump of their show for the effect they produce.

SERIOUS STABBING AFFRAY.--About 5 o'clock, yesterday afternoon, JAMES PURCELL, an Irishman, accompanied by several friends, called at a small store, No. 203 Varick-street, kept by a widow named O'NEIL After drinking several times the party refused to pay, when high words passed, and PURCELL, it is charged, boat Mrs. O'NEIL in a most shameful manner about the face and head. He then went away.

Joseph J. West and James D. Oliver vs. Chas. Cartridge and John Horspool.-This is a case which clearly illustrates the uncertainty of the law, while it shows the great age which litigation sometimes attains. The parties to the action are such as may be called excellent clients, as will appear when it is

DAVIS.--In this City, on Sunday, Nov. 20, after a short illness. MARY ALICE. youngest daughter of Elisha and Alice M. Davis, aged 11 years, 7 months and 17 days. The friends and relatives of the family are invited to attend the funeral service, at No. 57 St Mark's-place, on Tuesday, the 22d inst., at 10 o'clock A. M., without further notice. The remains will be taken to Greenwich, Conn., for interment.

The first thing that strikes us on reading Superintendent PILLSBURY'S interesting report of the doings of the police force during the last quarter, is the misfortune that so useful a body should be so small.

The Tennessee Opposition would unquestionably support lion. JOHN BELL, as the candidate of the National Opposition, and they have more than strength enough to carry their State for him. Hon. EDWARD BATES, on the same ground, might enlist the vote of Tennessee, as of his own State and Kentucky.

The Administration at Washington has at last resolved upon that decisive step which must determine the fate of Mexico. At a Cabinet meeting held on Saturday, we learn from our special correspondent, it was resolved to move an army of occupation across the Rio Grande,

Mr. John E. Ross, for the past two seasons a member of the Boston Theatre stock company, died in that city on Sunday last, aged 54. Mr. Ross was born in Palgrave, Suffolk Connty, England, and made his first appearance on the American stage at the Chatham Theatre, in this City, in 1839, as Kingston, in "High Life Below Stairs."

The Republican Mayoralty Convention met last evening at the Republican headquarters in Broadway, for the purpose of nominating a candidate for Mayor of the City. All the delegations were fully represented, and, notwithstanding the storm, there was a very large gathering outside.

The Springfield Republican gives the details of a fearful tragedy which was perpetrated in Southwick, Conn., on last Thursday afternoon. Mr. HENRY HALCOMB, a citizen of that town, who has hitherto been highly esteemed, beat his wife's head against a piece of heavy oak scantling until the back of her skull was dashed to pieces, and then fled.

The Trenton (N. J.) State Gazette reports a case of horrible cruelty to a child, A man named APPLEGATE was recently arrested in Monmouth County for ill-usage of a little girl. The child was kept half starved, and it was a frequent practice of APPLEGATE to whip her in the most brutal manner for the most trivial causes.

Although the great body of American merchants and engineers seem quite inclined to submit, without an effort, to the superiority which Europe is fast asserting in the carrying trade of the world, there are some among us who continue to speculate, if only on paper, upon the means of maintaining our old position as the most enterprising of commercial nations.

HOLMES--WATSON.--In this City, on Monday, Nov. 21, by Rev John Dowling, WILLIAM HOLMES to Miss FRANCES L. WATSON, daughter of Harley Watson, Esq., all of this City. BRANT--BRADEN.--In this City, on Thursday, Nov. 3, by Rev. Mr. Pierce, of Gowanus, Mr. RANDOLPH BRANT to Miss MARGARET BRAIDEN, both of this City.

The most disastrous conflagration of the many that have recently depopulated whole sections of the city, took place yesterday in the upper part of the Fourth District. It was terrific in its destructive aspect, for almost a gale of wind blew while the fire raged; and it was saddening beyond expression considering the desolation it caused, for over one hundred poor families

In the Macon (Miss.) Beacon we find a number of letters, which were not intended for publication, and were addressed to an intimate friend, from the bedside of the late Gov. JONES, of Tennessee. They will be read with interest by all the friends of that distinguished statesman, and we therefore reproduce the following extract, which was dated only a day or two before his death:

The war which on Saturday was impending over the unconscious head of Mexico, yesterday ended in a fortunate peace. A special session of the Washington Cabinet was called at an early hour of the morning, and in view of the improved reports from Brownsville,

A correspondent of the Diario de la Marina, writing from Laguayra, on the 25th ult., says: "Senor TOVAR, in his character of Vice-President of the Republic, continues the prosecution of measures best adapted to tranquilize the country, and to restore internal and external credit.

The will of the late Robert Stephenson has been sworn to by his executors. Tile document is dated the 13th of August, 1859. The personalty is sworn under ??400,000. A cousin of the deceased is the principal legatee, receiving, besides large industrial interests, the house in Gloucester-square, Hyde Park, will all its valuable appointments.

A NEW-YORK AGENT ARRESTED FOR SELLING GOODS BY SAMPLE--The Pittsburgh Evening Chronicle, Nov. 18, has the following: "Alderman JOHNS, this morning, delivered his decision in the case of the Commonwealth vs. JULIUS ESSELBOM, charged with a violation of the statute, which forbids, under a penalty of $300 for each offence. the selling of goods by sample in the city.

Indian murders and other depredations continue, on the Texan frontier, in all the worst phases. The San Antonio Ledger, of the 8th November, announces the killing of two men by the Indians on the Leona, seven miles below Fort Inge. One was Capt. Hurd. The name of the other not given. They were killed and scalped on the 6th, and their bodies found.

The United States frigate Congress was at the Island of Bahia on the 21st of October, having put in there when sixty-five days at sea. She was short of water and provisions. She was to leave for Rio Janeiro as soon as she had procured fresh supplies. [BY TELEGRAPH.]

The New-Orleans Picayune, Nov. 15, contains news from Mexico one day later: CITY OF MEXICO, Saturday, Nov. 5 1859--P. M. I have already written you of the seizure, by MARQUEZ, at Guadalajara, of a specie conducta of $1,800,000, en route to the Pacific. Just at this moment, when the courier is leaving for Vera Cruz, full partieulars of the whole affair, documents and all, have come to hand by the Southern Express Mail.

We should be sorry even to suspect so dignified a personage as the President of the United Slates of practising that trivial art of vulgar diplomacy known in the vocabulary of slang as "trying it on."

MURDER IN NEW-ORLEANS. - HENRY E. HYAMS a clerk in a wholesale drug store, in New-Orleans, was shot by a policeman named HUGHES. Mr. HYAMS was talking with two or three acquaintances, when HUGHES, who was under the influence of liquor, crossed the street and accused some of the party of hurrahing for one of the candidates then in nomination, to whom he was opposed.

LECTURE OF DR. O. A. BROWNSON.-A lecture on "Patriotism" was delivered last evening before the Cumming's Literary Union in the hall of the Medical College, corner of Twenty-third-street and Fourthavenue, by Dr. ORESTES A. BROWNSON. The attendance, regardless of the weather, was large enough to fill the whole apartment.

The Church of the Puritans held an interesting and exciting business meeting last evening, the object of which was to take action in reference to the recent appeal for aid which has been made to the British Churches. Mr. J. O. BENNETT was called to the Chair, and, after some discussion in regard to the admission of reporters, the meeting proceeded to business.

We are indebted to Mr. CHARLES DICKENS for graphic and faithful reports of the opinions entertained by Mr. Augustus Toots, on almost every subject within the range of common social discussion. Mr. Toots held fast to the belief that many things considered important by the rest of mankind, were really "of no consequence."

Mr. GRISWOLD, one of the counsel who defended BROWN, has been defending himself somewhat tartly against the charge of having behaved unhandsomely in taking a fee of $250 from the old man for his professional services. It was supposed that in accepting this sum he had deprived the prisoner of tile remnant of his property, and left nothing whatever for the support of his unfortunate family.

The case of Horace Cooley, charged with receiving three sewing-machines and a number of screws, plates, needles, , , connected with sewing machines, the property of the Wheeler Wilson Manufacturing Company, valued at $526, knowing them to be stolen by W. Lambert, the porter of that establishment, which was commenced on Friday last, was continued this morning, and occupied the entire day without reaching a conclusion.

A BIT OF MILITARY ADVICE.-If so martial a people as tile Virginians seem to be would allow us to offer them a little military advice, we would suggest the propriety of their organizing a good horse-patrol, as we really cannot think of anything so likely to furnish a safeguard against the dangers they most dread.

There was a large number of spectators at the Union Course, yesterday. to witness the promised contest between Flora Temple and George M. Patchen. Notwithstanding the continued triumphs of the former in her Western tour there were a few found willing to bet against her. She had the call, however, at $100 to $60. After the fourth heat the race was postponed on account of the darkness.

The United States Mail steamship De Soto, J. D. BULLOCK, arrived from New-Orleans, via Havana, last evening, having left the latter place on the 16th inst. The news is of secondary moment. Among the arrivals at Havana, upon Her British Majesty's ship Basilisk, were Gen. BEIL, Commander of the British forces in Jamaica ;

SMITH,--In this City, on Saturday evening. Nov. 19, suddenly, CAROLINE, the wife of William Smith, in the 51st year of her age. The relatives and friends of the family are particularly invited to attend her funeral, on Wednesday, the 23d inst., at 1 o'clock P.M., from her late residence, No. 50 Dominick-St.

The Royal Mail steamship Canada, from Liver pool, via Halifax, arrived at Boston yesterday morning. Her news is mostly embraced in the dispatch received via Sackville. Her mails were forwarded in the morning train, and reached this City last evening The steamship Saxonia, of the Hamburg line, front Southampton, Nov. 5, arrived at this port yesterday in the afternoon.

The Street Commissioner has, it appears, drawn on the Comptroller for $6,868, for the hire of carriages used by members of the Common Council, when employed on "Commiittees," during the three months ending Sept. 30.

The event of most interest during the past month has been the departure of their Majesties, the Emperor and Empress, for the northern provinces, which took place on the 1st inst. Their Majesties embarked on board the Aspa, at 7 1/?? A. M. on that day, and attended by the steamers-of-war Amazonas and Belmont, proceeded directly to sea.

FLOUR in fair demand, and steady. Sales 1,500 bbls., at $4 for fine, $4 40 for superfine Western, $5 for extra Wisconsin, $5 25$5 40 for extra Indiana and Ohio; $5 50@$6 for double extras. WHEAT quiet and steady; sales 5,500 bush. Chicago Spring at 41 2,000 Canada Club, in lots, at $1 02$1 03. CORN steady and in moderate request; sales 7,000 bush. new at 60c@61c. PEAS firm and in demand:

THE COAL-DIGGERS' STRIKE AT PITTSBURGH.--The Pittsburgh Evening Chronicle, Nov. 19, says: This morning, in the Criminal Court, the coal diggers recently convicted of riot, were brought up for sentence. They numbered twenty-one in all, and were, in many instances, accompanied by their wives and friends, making altogether a demonstration such as is seldom seen in our Court House.

SINGULAR TRAGEDY IN TEXAS.--The Marshall (Texas) Republican, of the 5th of November, has an account of a remarkable murder. The murderers were two boys, who slew the decreased, a teacher in Marshall County, in retaliation for evidence given by him in a late suit of the State vs. HALL, for shooting MASON, for alleged criminal intercourse with his wife, the mother of the boys.

The United States Mail steamship North Star, A. G. JONES, Commander, from Aspinwall on the 11th inst., arrived at this port yesterday morning. The North Star left New-York Oct. 20, at 2 P. M. On the morning of the 25th, at 4:40 A. M., she struck on a reef near Plana Island, one of the French Keys. The weather being rainy the day previous no observation could be taken.

BUFFALO AND THE PUGILISTS.-The authorities at Buffalo have, it appears, sent on an officer to arrest MORRISSEY and HEENAN and take them to Buffalo, to be tried under an indictment found against them for their prize-fight a

AFFAIRS AT WASHINGTON. An Extra Session of the Cabinet-Movement of Troops towards Mexico Conntermanded. Special Dispatch to the New-York Times. WASHINGTON, Monday, Nov. 21, 1859. An extra session of the Cabinet was held this morning, at which the proceedings of Saturday were reconsidered.

Our place is the scene of a terrible calamity. This morning, a freight train, consisting of fourteen or seventeen cars, (in the confusion the writer could not ascertain,) drawn by the locomotive "Sol Meredith," was precipitated through the bridge which spans the cast fork of Whitewater, at this place, and ten or twelve cars are now lying beneath, and upon the bridge, in total ??.

BOARD OF CANVASSERS.--Another meeting of the County Canvassers was held yesterday afternoon. The Board was engaged most of the session in calling off corrected returns. Mr. BIRDSALL, the Democratic candidate for Justice of the Peace in the Fifth District, at the late election, was present with counsel to urge upon the Board not to adopt the returns of the Nineteenth Ward for that officer.

EMIGRATION TO THE VINE DISTRICTS OF MISSOURI.--Mr. F. MUNCH, a well-know German agriculturist from Missouri, has just returned from an interesting mission in Germany and Switzerland. He has been employed by the "Farmers' and Vine Growers' Society" to scalter information in regard to the resources of Missouri throughout Germany, and to direct the currents of emigration towards the vine and hemp districts of that State.

" Peace hath her victories not less renowned than war," and I doubt not that all true-hearted Americans will rejoice to hear that our Minister to China has achieved such a bloodless triumph. He is now bearing back his blushing laurels from a hard fought field ;

As the Atlantic Monthly has become an institution among our Magazines, the appearance of the December number, understood to be the first issued under the new management of that periodical, has been looked for with a certain anxiety by our literary circles.

THE MASSACHUSETTS LIQUOR AGENCY--THE FORBES AFFAIR.--Mr. BURNHAM, the deposed State Liquor Agent in Massachusetts, writes to the Boston Journal that he knows nothing of "one H. B. FORBES," who has figured in connection with his case, and adds:

The triennial message of Gov. MOORE, of Alabama, was delivered to the Legislature, Nov. 14. The Governor reports a balance of $631,000 in the State Treasury, with outstanding bonds amounting to $3,482,000.

BOARD OF SUPERVISORS. VACANCIES IN THE BOARD OF REGISTRATION FILLED-BILLS AUDITED AND ALLOWED. In the absence of the President, yesterday, Supervisor BELL presided over the Board of Supervisors. Supervisor KENNEDY moved that before proceeding according to the regular order of business, the vacancies in the Board of Registration be filled.

The Savannah papers give full reports of the trial of BRAM, ROUESTA, and AGURA, late of the yacht Wanderer, for piracy. We quote from the report of the Morning News: The trial began on Wednesday, Nov. 16, in te United States Circuit Court, Judges WAYNE and NICOL on th Bench. THE OFFICIAL STATEMENT OF THE CASE. The following statement of reasons for Dr. CHEEVER'S appeal to the Abolitionists of Great Britain on behalf of the Charch of the Puritans, was read at the meeting of the Society on Tuesday evening.

We have three candidates for Mayor fairly before the people. Each of the three accepts the nomination;--only one of the three can be elected. The voters of the City are to decided which one that shall be. As a matter of course they will be asked and urged, and, if possible forced, to decide it on party grounds.

BREACH OF PROMISE CASE.-- A Cleveland paper says : A case in the Court of Henry County tried at the recent term excited much interest. Miss AMANDA JONES, a maiden lady of thirty years, sued JOHN Scofield, a well-to-do citizen, of 45 years, for breach of promise to marry, when a widower. Miss JONES claimed $2,000 damagcs.

Gazaette says: "During last week over one hundred slaves, from Lewis, Clark and Scotland Countries, have passed down on boats, en route for the South, to be sold.

NEW POLITICAL MOVEMENT IN ILLINOISE.--The Chicago Times publishes a statement from Mr. LEON STRAUS, of that city, to the effect that a number of respectable citizens have united and organized themselves into a party to exist in the State of Illinois, under the name nad title of "Free Citizens." The principles and objects of the party are laid down in a platform and constitution.

An Untrotunate Newspaper controversy between ALLEN A. HALL, editor of the Nashville news, an Opposition Paper, and GEO, G. POINDEXTER, editor of the Union and American, a Democratic paper, which had assumed a personal character, terminated yesterday in the death of Mr. POINDEXTER, at the lands of Mr. HALL.

We have already been favored with the "history" from the British point of view, of Mr. WARD'S journey to the Chinese capital, of his reception there, and of the final ratification by him of our treaty with China at the Peitang, on the 16th of August.

Important Rumor from Mexico. FLIGHT OF MIRAMON AND MARQUEZ--THE ARMY PRONOUNCED FOR SANTA ANNA. MOBILE, Monday, Nov. 22. The schooner Mary Clinton has arrived from Vera Cruz, having left that port on the 11th inst. It was reported that President MIRAMON had joined MARQUEZ, and that both had fled the county on board a British steamer, taking the two millions of specie seized by MARQUEZ, whereupon MIRAMON'S army had pronounced for SANTA ANNA.

The Springfield Republican of yesterday gives further particulars of the attempted murder of Mrs. HOLCOMB, of Southwick, by her husband: Mrs. HOLCOMB, after two days of insensibility from the terrible wounds inflited by her husband, rallied on Sunday, and asked and received food.

SHANNON.-- In this City, on Tuesday morning, Nov. 22, Miss MARY AMELIA, daughter of John and Eliza Jane Shannon, aged 21 years, 8 months and 26 days. The friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral this afternoon, at 6 o'clock, from the residence of her father, No. 70 Morton-st. The remains will be taken to Hempstead, L. I., the next morning for interment.

AN ATTACHING CREDITOR HELD ENTITLED TO IMPEACH FRAUDLENT TRASNFER OF DEBTOR'S PROPERTY. Erastus D. Thayer vs. James C. Willett.--This case was reported in the TIMES of Tuesday, Nov. 1, when on argument before the General Term of the Superior Court.

THE REVOLUTIONARY MONUMENT IN NEW-JERSEY.--The Trenton State Gazette, describes the plan for the New-Jersey monument to the created in honor of the Revolutionary heroes. It is a shaft of brown free-stone, 270 feet in height, perfectly round for some thirty or forty feet, and above that height, with thirteen sides, emblematic of the Union formed by the thirteen original States; the base will be wide platform, reached by thirteen flights of steps,

A young man, named JOHN D. WINSLOW, Committed suicide some time during last night, at No. 38 South Third-street. The deceased was twenty-seven years of age, and was a native of Providence, R. I., where be has a mother and other relatives residing. He was a traveling agent for a firm in New-York, and sold jewelry by sample.

The letter of our Virginia correspondent, which we publish this morning, gives a gloomy report of the condition of affairs in the Old Dominion. He represents the people as in a state of profound alarm-as looking forward to conflicts with the North which will render property insecure and peace impossible, and as seriously intending, many of them, to leave the country in order to escape the losses and discomforts of such a state of things.

DR.SOUDDER'S LECTURES ON INDIA.-The closing lecture of this brilliant course, though delivered on a rainy night, was attended by more than two thousand people. In both manner and matter it excelled the preceding efforts of the eloquent lecturer; and as a just philosophical analysis of the relations of British power to the Indian race, it was werthy of a Christian statesman.

Yesterday was spent in a grand military parade and review, by Gov. WISE. During the afternoon, Gov. WISE and his staff had a long interview with the prisoners, urging them to prepare for death, as the sentence of the Court would be carried out without any interference on his part. BROWN declared himself prepared to die, and justified his course, only regretting his error in not allowing the train to pass.

THE PURITAN APPEAL. - The Church of the Puritans has made another formal attempt to ??indicate its appeal to British Abolitionists for pecuniary aid. We copy it into our columns, - partly that they may be fairly heard on their own behalf, and partly because it shows that they can, when driven to it, write the English language without descending to billingsgate.

The chess library of Prof. George Allen, of the University of Pennsylvania, is said to be unequalled in size and importance in this country, if not, indeed, in Europe. MOZART'S fairy opera of "The Magic Flute" was produced here on Monday night with fair success. The day when such a work could make a sensation, if it ever was, is not now, and we have no hesitation in adding, never will be again.

Hon. David A. Simmons died in Roxbury, Mass., on Sunday last, aged 72. He studied law in Boston, was elected Representative from Roxbury to the State Legislature in 1825, 1826, 1835 and 1836 ; was a member of the Executive Council in 1939 and 1940, and was chosen a Senator from the District of Norfolk in 1848 and 1849.

GARIBALDI, after having prepared the present movement for the Italian independence, under the auspices of VICTOR EMANUEL, suspended operations as soon as the war began.

Our advices from the Overland route announce the death of the celebrated pioneer and explorer, CHRISTOPHER CARSON, at TAOS, New-Mexico, where he had been residing as Indian Agent. CARSON was a native of Kentucky, having been born in Madison County, at the close of 1809.

The rainy season is nearly at an end, and occasionally we have now a week's fine weather. The small pox, which malady has raged here some months past, has entirely left us, and the new settlcment appears in its full bloom.

GONE TO EUROPE, PROBABLY.-It is to-day supposed that Major EDMUND FRENCH, late acting disbursing agent for the construction of the extension of the Treasury building, in this city, who, it will be remembered, is under bonds of $10,000 for his appearance before the Criminal Court of this District to answer to the charge of defalcation, is now on the ocean on his way to Europe.

The tidings from the Venetian provinces grow sadder and sadder. In the city of Venice alone, 45,000 paupers are inscribed on the registers,--more than one-third of the entire population of 105,000 souls ! Whereas, in 1849, after the united disasters of the seige, famine, and cholera, but 27,000 paupers were inscribed.

The unknown steamship, whose wreck was reported from the coast of Nova Scotia in our morning impression of yesterday, proves to have been the Indian, of the Montreal Steamship Company's line. The Indian left Liverpool on the 9th inst., and in ordinary circumstances was due at Portland on Sunday.

He robbed the house of Mr. JOHN W. THOMPSON, on the 21st of October last.

FIRE IN WEST TWENTY-EIGHTH-STREET.--At about 3 o'clock, on Thursday, morning, a fire broke out on the second floor of the Jackson Hall, in West Twenty-Eighth-street, near the Eighth-avenue. The firemen were promptly at work, but before they extinguished the flames, the premises were damaged to the extent of $1,800, which is covered by an insurance of $3,000 in the Exchange Insurance Company.

LAST TUESDAY IN CIIARLESTOWN. A DAY OF EXCITEMENT AND PERIL. Correspondence of the Baltimore American. CHARLESTOWN, Wednesday, Nov. 23. Yesterday was another bustling day in this village, now the centre of excitement and although no actual or probable demonstration was made against the peace, the dignity, and the honor of the glorious old Commonwealth, yet there were men enough to have repelled an assault of the most formidable character.

The Conference at Zurich had been brought to a close, the three treaties already announced having been formally signed. A reduction of 2,000,000 of francs is reported to have been made in the sum to be paid by France to Austria.

The Victoria Bridge. PASSAGE OF THE FIRST RAILROAD TRAIN. MONTREAL,, Thursday, Nov. 24. The first train, consisting of engines and a single car, having on board about fifty persons, ran over the Victoria Bridge this afternoon. The time occupied on the passage was about twelve and a half minutes.

FIRE IN A LUMBER-YARD.--A little after 3 o'clock yesterday morning, a fire broke out in a small stable at the foot of North First-street, E. D., owned and occupied by Messrs. HARDY BROWN. The building, with the contents, were speedily consumed, and the fire, fanned by a fresh breeze, quickly extended to a large quantity of lumber in the yard adjoining, belonging to the same company.

TRIAL OF CHARLES MOORE FOR MURDER--SPRINCE DENIED A NEW TRIAL. At the opening of Court, yesterday morning, exRecorder Smith moved to have the verdict in the case of Sprince, the noted receiver of stolen goods, recently convicted of that offence, set aside, on the ground that the conviction was inconsistent with the evidence.

Bishop Paine, of the M. E. Church South, made a narrow escape from violent death recently, near Bentonville, Arkansas. The stage in which he was traveling upset, the horses took fright, and, dashing off at a furious rate, dragged the vehicle over a rock road, fracturing two of the Bishop's ribs, and confining him inside the stage until its top was broken to pieces.

PETERSON. --In this City, on Thursday, Nov. 24 after a long and painful illness, which she bore with Christian fortitude and resignation, LYDIA ANN, wife of Abram P. Peterson, and eldest daughter of William and Catherine Edwards, aged 38 years, 7 months and 24 days.

THAT BALLON VOYAGE TO EUROPE.--The Ballon exhibition of Prof. LOWE is finally closed for the season, and the promised Aerial trip to Europe postponed--mainly "on account of the weather." All the apparatus having been removed from the Palace grounds, visitors who, on Thursday, were allured to the spot to witness an ascension in the small ballon, found " the great globe itself, gone like the baseless fabric of a vision."

The past week at the Academy of Music has been fruitful of musical sensations ; It has given us a miled one in the shape of MOZARI'S "Magic Flute," and a strong one in the debut of a new singer, Mile. ADELINA J"PATTI. The former event is, we suspect, of more importance to amateurs than of real value to the management, but the latter is something of which they may well feel proud.

We publish this morning an able, valuable and timely vindication of the existing laws against the foreign Slave-trade, embodied in a charge delivered by Justice WAYNE, of the United States Supreme Court, to the Grand Jury in Savannah. Its special object is to show that the laws of Congress on this subject have been uniform in their tenor,

The celebration of the thirty-sixth anniversary of the New-York Bible Society was held last evening in the Madison-square Presbyterian Church. The annual report, which was read by JOHN E. PARSONS, Esq., stated that the peculiar object of the Society was to distribute the Bible in New-York City: not indiscriminate distribution, but also visiting the destitute of the population.

From Washington. BREVITY OF THE FORTHCOMING MESSAGE--MEXICAN AFFAIRS--CANDIDATES FOR OFFICES IN THE HOUSE. WASHINGTON, Sunday, Nov. 27. It is understood that the President's next Annual Message will not be more than two-thirds the length of that of 1858. It is now ready for the Press.

The New-Orleans Picayune has the following report from the purser of the steamship Arizona, at that port: "The steamship Arizona left New-Orleans on the 11th inst., for Brazos direct, and arrived there on the 14th inst., after encountering a severe gale on the 12th and 13th, with 50 United States troops under Capt. J. B. RICKETTS.

LARGE ARREST OF GAMBLERS--A SCAMPERING AMONG THE FANCY.--On Saturday afternoon a nest of gamblers, who have for years occupied a den over CLARKE'S exchange office, corner of Chatham and Chambers streets, was suddenly thrown into consternation by the appearance of the Police, led by officer BARTHOLOMEW, of the City Hall squad.

About four hundred persons attended the Academy of Music on Saturday evening, on the occasionof the first lecture in the course before the Kane Monument Association. The platform was occupied by a number of invited guests, and an excellent brass band enlivened the exercises with inspiring music. Dr. JOHN W. FRANCIS commenced the proceedings with a brief address .

As already announced, the steamer Indian, Capt. SMITH, of the Canadian line, which left Liverpool on the 9th inst. for Portland, was totally wreaked at Marie Joseph, a fishing village, about seventy miles from Halifax. The Indian had eight cabin and thirty steerage passengers, with a crew that made the total number of souls on board one hundred and fifteen.

The steamship Baltic arrived at this port yesterday morning, bringing the California mails and treasure of Nov. 5. The Baltic's specie list amounts to $1,700,000. Among the passengers were Judge HAUN, United States Senator from California, who will occupy the seat of the late Mr. BRODERICK at the coming session of Congress, and the officers of the United States frigate Saranac.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: An American, by temporary absence from home, must not be supposed to lose the inherent right and privilege of Anglo-Saxons, that of "writing to the papers." Nor does distance necessarily involve incapacity. It is sometimes advantageous to a man to be "set on'a hill." If unable to observe every detail with accuracy,

On the very day appointed to launch the first iron steamer ever built in this City, and while the wreck of the iron steamer Royal Charter is still the topic of public interest, we receive the sad details of the total destruction of the iron steamer Indian. Thus, at the lawn of this great revival of our manufacturing and commercial interests, we are startled by two warnings which we cannot mistake.

The steamship Baltic, Capt. GRAY, arrived at this port, yesterday, from Aspinwall Nov. 19, bringing the California malls, treasure and passengers of Nov5. The Baltic had 650 passengers, among whom were Judge HAUN, United States Senator from California, Mr. H. G. FOOTE, British Consul at San Salvador, and Capt. KELLY and other officers of the United States steam-frigate Saranac.

On the 5th inst., Lords BROUGHAM and STANLEY, M. P., distributed prizes and certificates to the pupils in connection with the East Lancashire Union of Mechanics' Institutes. The distribution took place at Accrington, and, in the course of his speech, Lord BROUGHAM spoke as follows in correction of some misunderstanding which has arisen in regard to the speech he delivered at Bradford :

Such a delegation of trust imposes upon yourselves as Grand Jurors, upon this Court,

The observance of Thanksgiving Day in Massachusetts is consistent, for the authorities annually dispense turkeys and creature-comforts to the prisoners they keep in jail. Last Thursday, the 512 prisoners in the State Prison were regaled with the following excellent variety: 500 pounds poultry, 350pounds sausages, 5 barrels apples, 5 bushels oranges, 2 barrels turnips, 5 barrels potatoes, 150 pounds raisins, 200

The telegraphic dispatch of Saturday contradicted previous statements of Mexican affairs, and furnished us with fresh accounts, in the main, as improbable as the former. The only reliable fact of any importance is, that Mr. McLANE has arrived at Vera Cruz. The statement that MIRAMON, at the suggestion of the French Minister, is to open Alvarado as a port of entry, and at the same time attack Vera Cruz, is absurd.

Through the politeness of Mr. M. B. LILLIS, telegraphic operator of tile Panama Railroad at Panama, I have received the following important dispatch: PANAMA, Saturday, Nov. 19, 1859. The Age arrived at 6:30 A. M. She was detained in a gale off Tehuantepec forty hours. She brings the following items from Mexico :

The Whig Party held a Municipal Convention on Saturday night, and our reporter has given an outline of the proceedings thereof. It is an instructive record. It shows what meaning our most " respectable" politicians attach to the words they use about public duties, and what weight they give to the claims of the City in which they live, and with whose honor and welfare their own are so closely connected.

The Application of Louisa Cook and Louisa Brower.-The prisoners in this case were arrested in a lager-bier saloon on Leonard-street on Friday night, at the instance of George Cook and George Broomhurst, who charged them with vagrancy. They were taken before Justice OSBORN, and committed on the charge.

The Albany Evening Journal publishes the official vote for State officers. The footings are as follows: SECRETARY OF STATE.-Leavenworth, 251,136; Jones 252 594. Majority for Jones, (Dem.) 1,458. COMPTROLLER.--Denniston, 275,849; Church, 226,674, Majority for Denniston. (Rep.) 49,175. STATE TREASURER.--Dorsheimer, 275,580; Vauderpoel, 226,385. Majority for Dorsheimer, 49,195. The returns for Attorney-General, State Engineer. and Canal Commissionor are not yet officially complete.

The SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES, published This Morning, contains the following: NEWS FROM THE PACIFIC COAST,--Correspondence from California, "Podgers" on the Gossip of San Francisco, South America, Central America, EUROPE.--The state of the Italian Question--Speech of Sir G. C. LEWIS, at the Lord Mayor's Banquet--Our Foreign Correspondence.

The steamship Empire City, Capt. JOHN MCGOWAN, having left New-Orleans at 10 A. M., on the 20th inst., arrived at Havana on the 23d, reached this port last evening. She brings front New-Orleans $34,400, in Mexican dollars, consigned to the Metropolit an Bank. By telegraph, we learn that the Isabel, from Havana on the 25th, yesterday reached Charleston, and the Moses Taylor, from Havana on the 2th, is reported at New-Orleans.

ISAACKS.--In this City, on Sunday, Nov. 27, SAMSON W. ISAACKS, in the 83d year of his age: The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, from his late residence, No. 99 West 16th st., this (Tuesday) afternoon, at 1 o'clock precisely. ??REED.--In this City, on Monday, Nov. 28, JOSEPHANE V., wife of Chas. R. Reed, and eldest daughter of Jacob Berlin, aged 28 years, 5 months and 20 days.

Hon. Z. COLLINS LEE, Judge of the Superior Court, died in Baltimore, on Saturday morning last, at 5 o'clock. His decease was the result of an attack of paralysis, with which he had been seized a few days previously. Judge LEE was born in Fairfax County, Virginia, Dec. 5, 1805. His father, RICHARD BLAND LEE, was an intimate friend of President MADISON.

THE GALE ON FRIDAY NIGHT.--The gale of Friday night last was the severest experienced at Buffalo in several years. A great deal of injury was done to bridges, piers, shipping and buildings. A train of cars on the Central road, west of Rochester, had a narrow escape. During the night an immense tree had been blown across the track.

FATAL ACCIDENT. - At an early hour, yesterday morning, the body of JOHN MCGIRNEY, of No, 18 State-street, was found in an area at No.151 Atlantic-street. Officer BARR caused the body to be taken to the First Precinet Station-house, where an inquest was held, and the neck of the deceased was fond to have been broken. His fall is supposed to have been accidental. Deceased leaves a widow and several children.

A case of great importance, and involving principles affecting more or less the entire mining interest of the State, is now being argued before the California Supreme Court. It is the case of Col. J. C. FREMONT vs. The Merced Mining Company. The leading points made by Mr. INGE, who appears for the Merced Company, are:

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In your paper of this morning, I notice a rumor of the death of the famous mountaineer and Indian agent, KIT CARSON. Present letters from Taos, NewMexico, where I am connected as a merchant, do not mention this event, and therefore I doubt its authenticity.

FROM WASHINGTON. Democratic Programme for the Organization of the Honse-Dispatches from LieutenantGeneral Scott--The Brazilian Mail Contract--A Noteworthy Coincidence--Health of Secretary Floyd-Biography of Secretary Toucey. Special Dispatch to the New-York Times. WASHINGTON, Monday, Nov. 28. The Democratic programme for the House nominations is pretty definitely made up on a basis intended to unite the two great wings of the party.

The Alton (Ill.) Courier calls the attention of the authorities of that city to the shifting of the channel of the river, which is growing more serious every day, and threatens, if not checked, to make Alton an inland city. The Courier says that a stick of wood thrown into the stream, near Mitchel's mill will drift rapidly almost directly across to the opposite shore, going down between the island and the Missouri shore.

A writer in the Tribune, some days since, in urging the delay of the election for United States Senator, had the following paragraph, which I shall use as a text. The ??, signed a "Republican," was so accurate, and so truly conservative, that he deserves some notice: ce:

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--Mlle. ADELINA PATTI, our young and remarkable prima donna, who, in a single stride, has reached the sympathies of the entire musical public, will make her third appearance to-night, as Lucia, in the opera of " Lucia di Lammermoor." It is worth a long journey to hear a singer so fresh and perfect in this very delightful role. There will, we hope, be a fine attendance.

A SICKLES AFFAIR AT CANANDAIGUA.--The Rochester Union, Nov. 25, reports that the village of Canandaigua was thrown into commotion on Wednesday evening bp the sudden exposition of a case in which parties well known there were concerned. The parties concerned are WILLIAM H. PHELPS, WILLIAM WARREN, and the wife of the latter.

To the Editor of the NeW- York Times: We scarcely realize in the present day the obligations we are all under to astronomy for delivering us from the vague terrors of ignoranco and superstition, respecting the heavenly bodies, with which men were tormented in earlier times.

Two days later advices from the Pacific have been brought overland to St. Louis. Business at San Francisco remained without material improvement. The engrossing topic of talk was the approaching election of a State Senator, for which Gov. WELLER had issued his writ. The long-vexed question of the bulkheads on the San Francisco water-line is understood to be involved in this canvass, and hence the prevalent interest.

BOARD OF SUPERVISORS. SPECIAL POLICEMEN FOR ELECTION DAY-THE OLD POLICE AGAIN-ESTIMATE OF COUNTY EXPENDITURES FOR 1860-THE COMMISSIONERS OF RECORDS-REGISTRARS APPOINTED. The President of the Board of Police Commissioners, yesterday, sent a communication to the Board of Supervisors calling for an appropriation of $800 to pay Special Policemen to be employed on the Charter election day.

It is a fact that hard by Newport, in Covington, some of our Republicans did assemble in State Convention on the 16th, transacted their business without molestation, and adjourned to meet again in Richmond, Madison County, next June. I am gratified to hear it. It shows there is still some respect for law and order even in that mobbish neighborhood.

IMPORTANT MAIL CONTRACTS.--A postal arrangement of extreme importance, both to the United States and tile Brazils, was perfected this morning, and the contract for the transportation of the United States mails from New-York to St. Thomas, Bahia, Pernambuco, and Rio Janeiro, was awarded by Postmaster-General Holt to JAMES D. STEVENSON, Esq., of New-York.

ACCIDENT TO THE CITY OF HARTFORD.--The steamboat City of Hartford met with a serious disaster on Friday evening last, while on her way to this City. She had just made the landing at East Haddam, and was backing out from the pier when the schoonet Daniel Russell, which was boend up the river, was observed near by, and was signaled to keep her course.

FLOUR firm and in fair demand ; sales 1,200 bbls. WHEAT steady, and in good demand ; sales 15,000 bushels No. 2 Chicago Spring, to arrive, at 12,000 bushels, also from store, #1 03 ; 17,400 bushels Ke??osha Spring, at $1 04; 10 000 bushels No. 1 Milwaukee Club, at $1 05@$1 06 ; 2,000 bushels No. 1 Chicago Spring, at $1 05 ; 6,000 bushels Green Bay Club, at $1 06 1/2.

The New-York Herald thinks that Mr. FERNANDO WOOD ought to be made Mayor of NewYork, because the Mayoralty is really a matter of no sort of consequence whatever, the capacity of our citizens for being plundered and put to shame not having yet been by any means exhausted.

The People, ex rel. McSpedon and Baker, vs. The Board of Supervisors of New-York.--Justice INGRAHAM has filed his opinion denying the motion to quash the return of the defendants to the alternative mandamus sued out to compel them to pay for printing the records. The decision of the case was mentioned in yesterday's TIMES.

CLOSE OF THE WASHINGTON STATUE FAIR.--The Boston Transcript says the Washington Statue Fair in that city closed on Thanksgiving night, and that the net proceeds, we believe, will amount to a sum sufficient to warrant the Committee to order Mr. BALL to proceed at once upon his work. The Music Hall was crowded during the evening.

PUDDLED STEEL is being extensively tried in England for steam boilers. The best qualities are as easily worked as copper, and may be one-quarter to one-third thinner and lighter than iron. So far the experiment is successful in every particular, except that some makes of steel plates split and peel under the intense action of fire-others do not to an objectionable extent.

MURDER IN PENNSYLVANIA--The Pittsburgh Chronicle, Nov. 26, says: "Intelligence reached us to-day of an affray that occurred near Kuhn's Station, on the Connellsville Railroad, yesterday, between two men named JAMES DICK and WM. HERBON, and in which the latter stabbed the former twice with a knife, inflicting wounds from which he died last evening.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Mr. SONNTAG is a young artist, residing in this City. He is a native of Pennsylvania, and descended from Italy his new picture- has been painted, and it has had a large number of visitors at the Dusseldorf Gallery. Artists and critics generally have studied and admired It.

On Saturday and Sunday the town was guarded with strangers and soldiers. Extensive preparations are making for the reception of additional military forces, which are hourly expected. The churches have all been taken possession of for barracks. Sentinels nightly fire at imaginary foes, and a number of citizens have narrowly escaped their bullets.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The TIMES, which is universally regarded as the most reliable authority upon Mexican affairs, cannot always be expected to correct the errors of telegraphic reporters, or to be accountable for the misstatements of its numerous and distant correspondents.

A meeting of about one hundred persons convened at the Mercer-street Church last evening, on the occasion of the sixth anniversary of the Southern Aid Society. Rev. Mr. BLISS, of Boston, opened the proceedings with prayer. Mr. JAMES BOORMAN, who presided, addressed the meeting.

The reported receipts of the principal kinds of Produce, since our last, have been 103 bbls. Ashes ; 31,303 bbls. Flour ; 14,585 bushels Corn ; 5,500 bushels Rye ; 48,587 bushels Barley ; 45,770 bushels Oats ; 3,271 pkgs. Provisions, and 226 bbls. Whisky. ASHES--Sales have been reported of 100 bbls. Pots, at $5 12 1/2, and 40 bbls. Pearls, at $5 25 ?? 100 lbs.

Possibly some four readers may remember the election for Mayor in 1856. It presented features so much like those of the present contest that a recurrence to them may not be without interest and value. FERNANDO WOOD was then Mayor, and was the regular candidate of the Democratic Party for reelection.

The Message of Gov. RUNNELS, of Texas, delivered Nov. 15, is prodigiously long, violently Pro-Slavery, and very full in its references to topics of local interest. The Governor reports that nearly one-half of the two millions appropriated, the interest on which is set a part for purposes of education, has now been loaned to railroad companies,

A COSTLY CANDIDATE.-Mr. WOOD'S admirers gave a taste of their quality, and their leader a proof of his financial skill, at the Cooper Institute meeting on Monday night. The Hall of that buildingg was rented to the followers of FERNANDO the First for the sum of one hundred dollars.

When the pious Pecksniff, standing in his night-robes upon the landing of Mrs. Todgers' boarding-house, with the air blowing cool about his legs, looked blandly down over the staircase upon the guests in the hall below, he felt his heart warm even to his foes, and lavished a large benediction upon all the human race.

We are in the receipt of numerous communications concerning the Harper's Ferry affair, and the various topics connected with it. They are from all quarters, and on all sides,-some defending the North, assailing Slavery, urging the policy of not hanging JOHN BROWN, ,

The steamship Bohemian, from Liverpool at 10 o'clock on the morning of the 16th inst., arrived here at 8 1/2 o'clock this (Tuesday) evening. Her dates are two days later than those already received. She brought fifty passengers and a fair cargo. This is her first trip. She did not touch at Queenstown. Among her passengers are Hon. JOHN ROSS and family.

A determined resistance is being made on the part of the Mormons against the authority of the Federal Courts in this Territory by creating courts of their own with concurrent jurisdiction with the United States District Courts, in defiance of the Organic Act.

THE BONES OF WHITFIELD.--There is considerable indignation in Newburyport in regard to an illnatured letter published in the Courier by Rev. d. MAGILL, of the Scotch Presbyterian Church in this city. That gentleman visited Newburyport for the purpose of seeing the bones of the celebrated preacher GEORGE WHITFIELD, but was prevented from so doing by circumstances easily explained.

MERCANTILE LIBRARY LECTURES.--The fifth of this course of lectures was delivered, last evening, by ?. J. P. HALE, taking for his subject "Agrarianism." He Warmly defended it from the ?? that had been ?? upon it. A large audience listened to the lecture, and frequently interrupted the speaker with their applause.

THE NUISANCE OF MORMONISM.-The Grand Jury of Carson Valley have presented the whole Mormon Church " for making and unmaking laws, ad libilum, and for committing murder and the highest crimes in defiance of the United States authority, and in contempt of law." The document in which these and various other charges are set forth is not remarkable for its legal accuracy,

James Brown and others vs. The New-York and Eric Railroad.--This was an application by the Receiver of the Company for leave of the Court to lease rolling stock to the lessees of the Buffalo and New-York City Railroad, and was reported in the TIMES of Nov. 23. The motion was made at Chambers of the Supreme Court, before Justice STRONG, who now grants the application.

In the Christian Advocate and Journal, Rev. Dr. McClintoek explains the delay in the publication of his Life of Bishop Asbury. He says: "There are two reasons for this delay. The first is, that my other literary engagements will keep me fully occupied for a long time to come. The second is, that an excellent memoir of Bishop Asbury has recently been issued from the Book Room."

The State election having passed over quictly, and none of the numerous predictions that a dissolution of the Union would follow immediately upon the return of a Republican Legislature, having proved true, that great prophet FERNANDO WOOD, has now taken up his parable and begun to make the safety of the country dependent on his election.

The excitement here increases as the day of execution draws near. Panic pervades all classes. Every eye is anxious, and even the presence of the large body of troops does not allay the apprehension of an invasion from the West. Spies are out in all directions. It would be hard to induce any Virginian to say that there is an expectations of an attempt at rescue;

The St. Louis Bulletin, Nov. 25, learns that orders have been received from Washington for the removal to St. Joseph of the Indian Superintendency hitherio located in that city. This measure has been agitated for some years.

COHEN.--In this City, after a lingering illness, EUGENIA, daughter of the late Jacob T. Cohen. The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend her funeral, from No. 105 Sullivan st., this day, (Wednesday.) at 1 o'clock, without further invitation. RAMSEY--In this City, on Monday, Nov. 29, after a lingering illness, Miss ROSANNA RAMSEY, a native of Cavan, Cavan County, Ireland, aged 27 years.

MR. WOOD ON ARMS AND LAWS.-FERNANDO WOOD views with horror the employment of the military to aid the civil power of the City. Well he may; inasmuch as he doubtless remembers perfectly well the array of the Seventh Regiment in the Park, when he was intrenched in the City Hall resisting the service of the process of the Superior Court.

The Jaque, of Matamoras, of Nov. 12, says, that on the previous day one hundred and fifty Texan volunteers (Capt. TOBIN'S command) arrived at Brownsville. CoRTINAS had had news of this approach, and, therefore, during the night, came up to the town and tired a couple of volleys, which induced the people inside to suppose that the reinforcements, when they approached, were enemies.

LECTURE BY MR. MULLALY ON CATHOLIC EDUCATION.--Mr. MULLALY, the proprietor of the Metropolitan Record, lectured last night, in the Cooper Institute, before a fair audience, on "Catholic Education." He treated the subject from a purely religious point of view, and argued that to the parents belonged the important office of tracing on the tender mind of childhood the characters of knowledge and virtue.

In acknowledgement of a contribution of $122 50 from the sailors of the United States sloop-of-war Portsmouth, now off Cape Palmas, Africa, to the Sisters of Mercy, in this City. Archbishop HUGHES has written the following letter, which we reproduce form the Metropolitan Record:

The United States Mail steamer Yorktown, Cap. SHUPELDT, arrived at 8 o'clock P. M. last evening from Havana, having left that port Friday last, 25t, at 4 1/2 o'clock P. M., making the voyage in four days and three hours. Gen. CONCHA will remain upon the Island in an unofficial capacity through the Winter.

THE HISTORY OF THE PHILADELPHIA SUICIDE. The Philadelphia Sunday Manuscript gives the following interesting particulars of the life of Mr. JOHN D. WINSLOW, whose remarkable suicide in that city has been noticed : " Mr. WINSLOW, at the period of his death, was a traveling agent for the firm of SACKETT, DAVIS POTTER, manufacturing jewelers at Providence, Rhode Island. The firm make their headquarters at New-York.

THE WANDERER TRIALS AT SAVANNAH,--The Savannah Republican states that the trials of BROWN, RAJESTA and AUGUIER, before the United States Circuit Court, were brought to a close on Wednesday last. After a consultation of nearly a day, the jury brought in a verdict of "Not Guilty." "We cannot say," adds the Rapublican, "that the public expectation has been disappointed in this result.

PARIAH RACES.-An association is said to have been formed in San Francisco, having for its object "the exclusion of the Chinese from all employment except that of the lowest kind." We are sorry to hear that the Californians have no more sense of justice than to undertake such an outrage on humanity, and no more common sense than to rush blindfold into so much peril.

FROM WASHINGTON. Organization of the House--Chinese Rescript--President Interfering in behalf of the Public Printer. Special Dispatch to the New-York Times. WASHINGTON, Tuesday, Nov. 29. Members of Congress are pouring in, Messrs. BOCOCK, PHELPS, and ETHERIDGE, are at BROWN'S.

AKENHEAD-BEAUMONT.--At Jonesville, Mich., on Wednesday, Nov. 23, by Rev. C.R. Huson, WALTER AKENHEAD. Esq., of Lyons, N.Y., and Miss GERTRUDE BEAUMONT, to the first named place. Lucas.--VAN COURT.--In this City, on Saturday, Nov. 19. by Rev. Isaac M. See, PHILIP LUCAS, Jr., OF MOUNT Vernon, to MARY EMMA, eldest daughter of D.W. Van Court, of San Francisco.

THE SUNDAY QUESTION AT PITTSBURGH--MAYOR WEAVER'S DECISION REVERSED.--The Pittsburgh Chronicle, Nov. 25, says that the decision of Mayor WEAVER, by which JAMES NESRIT, Mr. LOGAN'S carriage driver, was fined $25 "for performing worldly employment by driving" his employer's carriage on the Sabbath, has been reversed, and the deed declared not an unlawful one.

Mr. JAMES T. BRADY is something more than a Tammany Hall orator, and does other and better work than furnish entertainment for the habitues of the wigwam. He is a good lawyer and a good orator, and has, moreover, on several occasions recently made himself somcwhat prominent in movements which the rest of the community consider decidedly "progressive."

Dispatches arrived at Fort Buchanan this morning, from Sonora, to be mailed to the President, which I hasten to anticipate. Capt. PORTER, of the St. Mary's, cruising in the Gulf of California, entered the port of Guaymas, and not being boarded as customary by the officers of the port, did not salute the town.

BOOTH--JONES.-In this City, on Tuesday, Nov. 29, by Rev Dr. Hawks. D. ALONZO BOOTH to LOUISE, daughter of Walker P. Jones, Esq., both of this City. EELLS.--SARINE.--In this City, on Tuesday. Nov. 29. by Rey. Thomas Armitage, Mr. HENRY B. EELLS to Miss JANE ANN SARINE, all of New-York City. MACY--CARPENTER.--In this City, on Tuesday, Nov. 29. JOSIAH HENRY MACY to JENNIE CARPENTER, daughter of the late Henry Carpenter.

HORRIBLE WIFE-MURDER.-A correspondent informs us that a horrible murder was committed-last Friday night, at Woodsville, New-Hampshire. Mr. FRANK WRIGHT struck his sister a severe blow in the back with a large knife. She succeeded in making her escape, and with the blood running down herback, rushed across the bridge to Wells River, where help was procured.

THE SIOUX INDIANS.--The St. Joseph (Mo.) Gazette notices the return of Major SCHOONOVER,agent of the Upper Missouri Sioux, comprising six nations of that tribe. The number of Indians under charge of Major S. is not less than 27,000.

BOARD OF ALDERMEN. The Board of Aldermen held a special meeting at 3 P. M. yesterday. The President, Alderman McSPEDON, stated that the meeting had been called, in accordance with the suggestion of the Mayor, for the purpose of making a suitable expression of the sentiments of sorrow to which the death of Washington Irving gave rise.

SENSE FROM SOUTH AMERICA. - The South Americans, who have enjoyed an unusual experience of revolutions, have at last hit upon a very original remedy for their chronic complaint. The Government of Chili has just proposed a law making all individuals who may be concerned in getting up a revolution personally responsible for any damage which may be thereby caused;

SUDDEN DEATHS.--JAMES WOOD, residing at No. 10 Franklin-street, returned to his home, Tuesday afternoon, enjoying, apparently, good health. Ile took a seat at a table, and leaned forward upon his hands. A few minutes afterward he was found to be quite dead. TIMOTHY HASSETT made a call upon a friend, Tuesday, at No. 10 State-street, and while there died of a disease of the heart. The family of deceased reside in New-York.

EX-MAYOR WOOD ON THE STUMP. NINTH WARD WOOD MEETING--SPEECH OF THE EX-MAYOR. By dint of burning tar-barrels, bonfires, a band of music, an illumination of the Ninth Ward Head-quarters and a torch-light procession, about a thousand persons assembled at the Jackson-square Wood Mass Meeting last evening.

Several prominent Republican Memberss of Congress have arrived, and they are sanguine of securing the organization of the louse without a struggle. The Democrats may adopt tile policy of making no nomination for Speaker, as many of them believe this the surer mode of securing an organization. The Southern Opposition can then exercise their choice, and may more readily coalesce.

The R. M. steamship Europa, from Liverpool on Saturday, the 19th inst., has arrived at this port. The steamship Kangaroo, from New-York, arrived at Queenstown on the 17th, and reached Liverpool the following day. The steamship Ocean Queen, from New-York, arrived at Southampton on the 18th. The R. M. steamship Persia, from New-York, arrived at Liverpool on the 19th.

On one side of the coach there were six passengers, on the other five ladies, whose ample crinoline apparently covered the sixth seat.
