A lecture was delivered last evening, at the Lecture-room of the Historical Society, corner of Eleventh-street and Second-avenue, by Mr. HORACE GREELEY, the subject as announced being " The Pacific Railroad." There were not more than a hundred persons present.

ATTEMPT ON THE PENITENTIARY OF THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA.--Information having been given to Mr. C. P. SENGSTACK, Warden of the Penitentiary, by one of the convicts, that an attempt would be made, on Saturday night, to rob and set fire to the Penitentiary, it was thought best to set a guard upon the building.

SPEECH BY HON. CHARLES SUMNER.--CARL SCHURZ, of Wisconsin, lectured, on Tuesday evening, in the Fraternity Course at Boston. His subject was "Reforms and Revolutions." At the close of the lecture Mr. SUMNER, who was present, was persistently called for and spoke as follows:

Three passengers by the western train of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad were taken out of the cars to-day on their arrival at Harper's Ferry, by the military there, and imprisoned. The parties arrested are merchants of Cincinnati, who were on their way to this city. At Grafton they were heard to express themselves quite freely in relation to JOHN BROWN and his family, expressing great sympathy for him and them.

The Hon. Mr. TOM CORWIN made a sharp and telling exposure on Tuesday evening of the fallacy wrapped in WENDELL PHILLIPS' slashing proposal to have the country governed by "the thought of the pavement," and to allow all individuals who might feel themselves aggrieved by the decisions of the majority to vindicate their notions by force of arms.

On Monday night Mr. ZORHAR MILLS was presiding at a People's Convention for the nomination of School officers in the Seventh Ward. He is a bitter opponent, according to his own statement, of FERNANDO WOOD, and is prepared to vote for any candidate for the Mayoralty, who is likely to defeat that person.

A call signed by thousands of the most respectable citizens of New-York, without distinction of parties, for a public meeting in ratification of the nominations of Mr. WILLIAM F. HAVEMEYER and Mr. S. J. TILDEN, to fill the two most important municipal offices in the gift of our people, will be answered to-day at the Merchants' Exchange.

MEYFRBEKR'S famous opera of the "Huguenots" was revived here fast night with a cast almost entirely different from that of last season. A work of such proportions demands at any time a first rate company, and it is a proof of rare resources that it can be given at all.

COMMISSIONERS OF EMIGRATION-- PAYMENTS FOR THE FLOATING HOSPITAL.--There was not a quorum yesterday at the regular weekly meeting of the Commissioners of Emigration. The weekly statement shows that there have been only 50 emigrant arrivals for the week, and $2,258 87 received for commutation.

In the organization of political machinerywhat may be called the stage-business of City politics-the trap-door, sliding scenes, dissolving views and property parts of the popular political drama, Mr. WOOD may be said to stand without a rival. He begins at tile beginning, when attempting to manufacture some appearance of public sentiment in his own favor.

The Tennissee arrived on the morning of the 18th, but owing to a norther there was no landing until next day, Saturday. Senior LERDO was on board, and his arrival was the occasion of great joy on the part of his many friends. The United States propeller Brooklyn made her appearance on the 21st.

" How touching," CARLYLE somewhere observes, "is the loyalty of men to their sovereign man." From an early hour yesterday morning, carriages, barouches, rockaways, farm-wagons, poured into Tarrytown from, all parts of Westchester County, and from long miles beyond, bearing sincere mourners to the grave of WASHINGTON IRVING.

To-day several persons, editors of the abolition newspapers published at the North, were ejected from the cars for Harper's Ferry. They had purchased tickets and were very anxious to proceed, but were refused on account of the arrangement entered into between Gov. WISE and the Presidentof the road

NEW SHIP-CANAL PROJECT IN CANADA--The Canadian Public Works Department several years age commenced the survey of the Ottawa River. with a view to ascertain whether a ship navigation between Lake Huron and Montreal, via the Ottawa, was practicable. This survey was suspended in 1857, and again revived in the year. 1858.

David Colden Murray, Receiver, , vs. Cornclius Vanderbilt.--This was a motion by the defendant in the action for an open commission to take testimony in California and Nicaragua, where he alleged he had important witnesses whose testimony was of the utmost importance to him in the trial of the action.

ORGANIZATION OF THE HOUSE--The Philadelphia North American, of Thursday, says: The Opposition members of the Pennsylvania delegation in Congress, held a consultation in this city, last night, upon an invitation issued by the State Committee, for the purpose of considering the best mode of facilitating the organization of the House of Representatives.

The Republican Ratification Meeting at the Cooper Institute, last night, was almost as large as the gathering at the same place, a few nights ago, by the Mozart Hall Democracy. What it lacked in point of numbers, it more than made up for in respectability and enthusiasm. Early the large hall was killed, and still outside processions were constantly arriving, and crowds from all points were congregating.

The Commissioners of Deeds seem likely to make almost as great a harvest from the various stories concocted about Mr. HAVEMEYER as they reaped from the confessions of the pugilists whom Mr. WOOD took with him to the Syracuse Convention.

THE HAVEMEYER MEETING.--The strength and sincerity of the movement which is now on foot to rescue our City from the perils with which it has been threatened by corrupt personal ambitions and reckless partisan passion, was most impressively exhibited yesterday afternoon in the meeting of citizens called to ratify the nominations of Messrs HAVEMEYER and TILDEN, at the Merchants' Exchange.

The San Francisco Herald states that Mr. Elnathan L. Sanderson has commenced an action against the Pacific Mail Steamship Company, claiming $30,000 damages. The alleged grounds of complaint are, that the plaintiff, in November, 1855, being a practicing attorney in this city, took passage for himself and wife on the steamship Sonora for New-York.

THE AMERICAN OPERATIONS AT SEBASTOPOL--Mr. SAMUEL F. HOLBROOK, of this city, in a letter to his pastor, dated Sebastopol, Crimea, Oct. 23, says : "We are quite busy in raising the big ships, and I assure you it is hard work. We have raised eleven ships of the line, and twenty-four smaller ships, such as frigates, corvettes, gun-brigs, and steamers."

A CHURCH DIVIDED AGAINST ITSELF. The People exrel., William J. Randall, Lewis Valentine and two others vs. The Trustees of the African Methodist Episcopal Church.--This was an application by the relators for a writ of alternative mandamus against the defendants, commendig them to reinstate the relators as Trustees, also, or to show cause why they should not do so.

REGISTERING VOTES FOR THE CHARTER ELEC TION.-Very many persons registered their names previous to the late State election, who, nevertheless, did not vote. They may naturally suppose that their names will remain upon the list, and that they will be permitted to vote at the charter election without being required to register their names again.

Major Alvan Allen, of Worcester, Mass., was run over by the ears on Tuesday evening, between Mechanic and Front streets, and was instantly killed. In 1835, he went from Strubridge to Worcester, and was mail agent for many years on the route between Worcester and Hartford. He has been a member of the Common Council and City Marshal, and at the time of his death belonged to the School Board.

JOHN BROWN has paid the penalty of his crime. He was executed yesterday, according to appointment, with due solemnity and under a very imposing display of the military strength of the State of Virginia. The event created a good deal of feeling throughout the country. Our columns contain notices of meetings and other indications of sympathy, held in various sections of the Northern States.

LECTURE ON HUMBOLDT BY BAYARD TAYLOR. --An address on the life and character of ALEXANDER VON HUMBOLDT was delivered last evening in the Cooper Institute by Mr. BAYARD TAYLOR. The lecturer said that as the aloe flowered but once in a hundred years, so the world's great men came forth in rare years. Such a year was 1769, which produced CUVIER, WALTER SCOTT, WELLINGTON, NAPOLEON AND HUMBOLDT.

But it proceeds to say that the anticipation of such calamities has had a very different effect upon the people of the two nations.

ONE CANDIDATE LESS.-Mr. OGDEN, it will be seen, has withdrawn his name as a candidate for the Mayoralty. He seems to have discovered, somewhat sooner than we predicted, that the contest is not for the Presidency, and that the salvation of the Union does not depend upon the result,-but that it is a municipal struggle, and is to decide whether the City is to be honestly or dishonestly governed for the next two years.

MEETING OF PARK COMMISSIONERS.--An adjourned meeting of the Park Commissioners was held last evening. The special subject for consideration was the propriety of laying out several small Parks. One was proposed to consist of between one and two hundred acres, on the high ground between Greenwood and Fort Hamilton, and another in tile Eastern District of the city, between Ridgewood Reservoir and Greenpoint.

The election for Mayor comes off to-morrow. The supporters of Mr. HAVEMEYER held their final meeting on Saturday night, and in spite of the extreme inclemency of the weather,-a test to which neither of the other parties has been exposed,-it was a very large and enthusiastic demonstration.

METHODIST CENTENARY.--The true centenary of Methodism is the year 1860. Dr. ROBERTS, of Baltimore, has fully demonstrated this fact from local as well as general documents, and other evidence. The late Local Preachers' Convention, at Baltimore, appointed a committee to consult the General Conference respecting measures for its due observance.

Hon. Alfred Kelly, a prominent citizen of Ohio, died at Columbus, Dec. 1. He was an early and constant friend of common school education.

The Mayor of Charlestown, Mass., visited Mystic Pond on Friday, for the purpose of making examinations in regard to the feasibility of obtaining a supply of water for the use of that city. Mystic Pond has an area of 230 acres and a depth of 70 feet. and its distance from City-square is six and a half miles. It is proposed to take the water of the pond at a short distance from it,

ARTICLES OF DIET.--The useful articles of diet are numerous, and the commonest we have. As to the quantity required, the prize-fighter, who requires, most, has thirty-six ounces per day, besides the innutritious portion which everybody swallows at every meal. for women, twenty ounces may suffice, though a larger allowance is better. Healthy working men ought to have from twenty-five to thirty ounces.

The office of Corporation Counsel is not inferior, in influence or utility, to that of Mayor. It is quite as important for the welfare of the City, that this office should be filled by a man of ability and of character, as that the Mayor should be a man beyond reproach.

They kept a vigilant look-out, however, and a cool bearing,

If FERNANDO WOOD is not defeated to-day, it will be simply because his opponents cannot determine which is the strongest of the two candidates, running against him. At the lowest estimate, two-thirds of the voters of the City are resolutely hostile to his election.

LADIES' FAIR AT THE ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--The Sisters of Mercy preside over an institution in Houston-street, in which many friendless girls are taught, supported, and from which they are enabled to procure situations. A fair in aid of their commendable charity was commenced last night at the Academy of Music under circumstances somewhat unfavorable, for the weather was forbidding,

They have professed to find in them evidences of our sympathy with the invasion, and of our contempt for the rights, the peace and the honor of a sister State.

Mr. FERNANADO WOOD and the Herald are not alone in their endeavors to addle the minds of quiet citizens with vague notions of immense " national" consequences to follow the strictly municipal election which takes place in this City to-day.

The business of opening up the mining country here has just commenced, and of course new discoveries are made every day. The season being too far advanced for mining operations to be carried on as pleasantly as during the Summer months, more attention has been paid lately to searching out new diggings which shall pay when Spring opens.

Upon the retirement of President PIERCE from public life, his Secretaries addressed him a parting letter, to which he replied with unwonted felicity. The correspondent shows the admirable harmony which subsisted between the members of the late Administration: WASHINGTON, March 3, 1857.

PROGRESS OF THE PACIFIC TELEGRAPH.--The St. Louis Republican says: "The Overland Mail, with California dates to the 11th ult., inclusive, arrived at Warsaw, Mo., yesterday, twenty days out, and will be in this evening. It brings seven passengers. Warsaw, from which this intelligence reached us, is fifty miles beyond Syracuse, the present terminus of the Pacific Railroad.

BROOKLYN COMMON COUNCIL.--At the regular weekly meeting of the Board of Alderman last evening, Alderman VAN BRUNT called up a resolution of said of the table April 20th, fixing the amount of assessment for grading and paving Fourth-avenue from Baltic to Twenty-first-street, and from Twenty-third-street to the New-Utrecht line, at $105 867 81. The resolution was adopted.

Mr. BOCRCICAULT'S new drama, called "The Octoroon," will be produced to-night at the Winter Garden. The work presents, in a series of acts, a picture of Southern life, involving, necessarily, the Slavery question in its concrete form of a slave-sale. The extreme East also has its representative; and that he will be a powerful one, cannot be doubled when we mention the name of Mr. JEFFERSON.

DISTURBANCE AT THE GREEN-STREET THEATRE IN ALBANY.--The Albany Times mentions a disturbance which occurred in the Green-street Theatre on Monday evening last. A New-York gentleman attempted to procure an encore of a song, and was remonstrated with by a spectal policeman for being too demonstrative.

OSWEGO, Monday, Dec. 5--6 P. M. FLOUR unchanged, with a moderate demand ; sales at $5 for State from Chicago Spring Wheat. WHEAT wanted for milling, but as holders are asking $1 10@S1 12 for Chicago Spring, and $1 13@$1 15 for Milwaukee Club, buyers are out of the market. RYE--Small sales at 75c. Other Grains quite. Imports--17,360 bushels Wheat, Exports--6,700 bushels Wheat : 2,460 bushels Peas.

The Democrats to-day sprang in medias res at once, and inaugurated what is destined to be the most exciting Session of Congress the country has known for many years. In the Senate, Mr. MASON of Virginia, submitted a resolution directing an inquiry into the facts surrounding the Harper's Ferry imbroglio.

The Detroit papers have the particulars of the loss of the propeller Miilwaukee, and the death of five men, by a collision in the Straits of Mackinaw, Dec. 1, with the schr. J. H. Tiffany. The crew of the schooner consisted of ten men, of whom five were saved. These were MONROE TURNER, the Captain; JOEL TURNER, first mate; and FREDERICK MELLON, JOHN M. SMITH and HENRY MERRITT, seamen.

The Richmond Enquirer publishes under the head of "Demonia?? Letters," an anonymous epistle from Vermont, in which the writer menaces Gov. WISE with swift destruction if he dares to execute JOHN BROWN.

The Thirty-sixth Congress assembled at Washington at noon yesterday, to hold its first session. From the Senate several of the leading members were noted as absentees, while in the House the numbers were remarkably full, two hundred and thirty-one members answering to their names at the roll-call.

OLD MONASTIC LANDS IN ENGLAND.--This very day the broad acres of England hear the impress stamped upon them by their former monastic possessors. The meadow, the field, the well-stocked mill stream, the capacious barn, the grass more soil and luxuriant, the landscape more civilized, show the footsteps of the these earliest of scientific farmers, who labored, prayed and learned with a vigor and earnestness never outdone.

AN IRRECONCILABLE DIFFERENCE OF OPINION--A characteristic anecdote of Stephenson and Brunel is now current. Brunel was complaining to Stephenson that his (Brunel's) contractors were never satisfied and always quarreling with him. Stephenson returned that Brunel kept his contractors too much to the letter of their agreements, even when they had an equitable right to the modification of these agreements.

FERNANDO WOOD has a perfect right to claim his reelection as a signal personal triumph. It is one of the most remarkable instances we have ever known of a personal victory against overwhelming odds. It is not to be explained by the imputations of fraud at the ballot boxes--for the whole machinery of the election was in the hands of his opponents.

The Cape Ann Advertiser of the 2d inst. contains a recapitulation of the loss of Gloucester seamen and fishermen for 1859. Five vessels belonging to that port have been lost during the present year, with all on board. Many officers and sailors belonging to the place have been lost in vessels sailing from other ports, so that the total number of Gloucester seamen and fishermen who have been lost the present year amounts to seventy.

Dodge, arrived at Galveston on the morning of the 23d, having left Point Isabel the day before, and bringing news from Brownsville to the 2Oth inst. This gentleman brings full and official accounts from the scene of difficulties on the lower Rio Grande.

* * * It must be by this time known in America, that Prof. AGASSIZ, just before he was called back by the unfortunate death of his father-in-law, concluded the purchase of the geological collection of Councilor BRONN, Professor of Mineralogy and Geology at Heidelberg, and for this year Pro-rector of the University. This collection was one of great value, being remarkably rich in varieties, and almost unique specimens.

INFLUENCE OF RAILROADS ON TIIE VALUE OF PROPERTY-ILLUSTRATIONS FROM THE GROWTH OF NEW-YORK. Gov. STEWVART, of Missouri, in his annual Message, argues strongly in favor of the extension of Railroads through the State. In support of the position he assumes, he cites the experience of this State as an example of the influence of Railroads in increasing the value of property.

The term of this Court was opened yesterday morning by Judge INGERSOLL. A Grand Jury and a Petit Jury were summoned from King's County, as at the last October term. There was not however a sufficient number of Grand Jurors present; the panel of Grand Jurors were discharged until to-morrow. The calendar of jury causes was commenced to be called, but was finally put over.

An actor named Darny, of the Palais Royal, Paris, after one of his performances, was seized with a severe attack of colic, which was attended with other symptoms of poisoning. The physician who was called determined that the sickness was the result of the use of pearl powder, which upon analysis, was found to contain a quantity of carbonate of lead.

This would be as curious an assemblage as could well be collected together. No other body of men represents the various opinions and prejudices of the people.

A CATTLE TRAIN OFF THE TRACK-FIVE THOUSAND DOLLARS DAMAGE. As the extra cattle train which left Albany Monday evening, was passing over tile two-mile bridge near Sing Sing, about 12 1/2 o'clock yesterday morning, an axle of one of the cars broke. Tile train was under such headway that before it could be stopped the engine and two or three of the cars had passed the bridge in safety.

The Charter Election in this City has resulted in the defeat of Messrs. HAVEMEYER and OPDYKE, and the triumph of FERNANDO WOOD. The vote was as follows: WOOD, 30,125; HAVEMEYER, 26,843; OPDYKE, 21,773. Plurality for WOOD over HAVMEYER, 3,285,-nearly the same as the majority for TIEMANN (3,331) over WOOD in 1857. The aggregate vote cast was 78,711-less by 4,492 than the total polled at the election of 1857.

A FORMER SLAVE ATTEMPTING TO PURCHASE THE FREEDOM OF HIS BROTHER.--Rev. JEREMIAH BOWMAN, a minister of the Methodist Episcopal Church, from Cincinnati, is now in this City. He was formerly a slave in Tennessee, and having become converted, exerted such an influence over his master's family, that several of its members were also converted.

MERCANTILE LIBRARY COURSE OF LECTURES.--The regular weekly lecture before the Brooklyn Mercantile Library Association, was delivered in the Athenaeum last evening by Col. EDWARD G. PARKER, of Boston, Notwithstanding the inclement weather the house was well filled.

In every Southern State we have heard Democratic denunciation, loud and deep, of our Buchanan Government. Influential Democrats throughout the South have said it is most corrupt, more so than any Government in the world. It is inherently, and thoroughly and insufferably foul. Its officials and proteges are all more or less stained, tainted and lcprous. Its dealings are scandalous and revolting.

THE SWIMMING-SCHOOL AT PARIS. As many parents are wishing to know how girls can be taught the use of their limbs in the water, it may he interesting to them to hear how the art is taught at Paris. The water is that of the Seine. This is the least agreeable circumstance in the ease, as the water of the Seine is quite as unfragrant in the Summer months as that of the Thames.

I have just returned from Munich, where it was my good fortune to be present at the celebration of the "October-Fest," during the first week of the present month. As this great national festivity presents, more than any other annual occurrence, the peculiarities of the Bavarian "country people," I think some account of the sights and scenes in Munich, at the time I speak of, may not be uninteresting to your readers.

Hon. ERASTUS CORNING, has presented to the Trustees of the Albany Fire Department between three and four hundred volumes of valuable public documents. BOARD OF SUPERVISORS.-- An adjourned meeting of this Board was held Tuesday evening. A communication from Judge LOTT, asking for increased Court accommodations, was referred to a special committee. This will, doubtless, cause the project for a new County Court-house to be revived.

HORRIBLE MURDER IN CLEVLAND.--JOHN R MATHESON, the keeper of the Northern House in Cleveland, Ohio, a favorite resort for boatmen, was killed on Friday night last. MATHESON'S wife states that he and MARTIN, one of his most intimate friends, drank freely, and finally became engaged in a violent altercation because MARTIN refused to introduce him to a Free Masons' Lodge.

To-day is the last day of the Schiller Fest in Munich. It has been celebrated here under the most favorable circumstances, the Government granting all the requests of the Committee, and the people taking a lively interest and an active part in the proceedings.

AN EXAMPLE AT LAST.-An emigrant runner was for a wonder convicted, on Thursday, of assault and battery, and Recorder BARNARD in remanding him for sentence, was compelled to announce in open court, that if any appeals were made to him outside on behalf of the prisoner, his sentence would only be the heavier.

THE NAUTILUS EXPLORING PARTY.-Several of the party who left this port in August last, by the schooner Nautilus, to make examination of the alleged gold deposits among the Indian graves of Chiriqui, have returned. They report that these diggings will not pay. In examining other localities.

SOMETHING WORTHY OF ATTENTION.--The controversy concerning the reading of the Bible in the Public Schools has led to one injustice, which ought to be promptly remedied. The Board of Education has decided that it shall be road in all the Public Schools.

THE LOSS OF THE SCHOONER ADA--THE LIVES LOST.--Intelligence has been received at Halifax of the wreck of the schooner Ada, of Westport, N. S., and the loss of ten lives. The Ada sailed from St. Barbes, Labrador, on Sept, 30, for Halifax. On Oct. 7, during a fearful gale of wind, she was driven on a ledge of rocks near Sandy Bay, and the vessel and all on board were lost.

VISITS TO THE PRESIDENT.--Chief Justice TANEY and the Associate Justices who had arrived in season for the opening of the Court, viz.: Judges NELSON, GRIER, CLIFFORD and CAMPBELL--paid their respects yesterday to President BUCHANAN, and the interview was a most agreeable one, indeed, sufficiently indicating the hearty mutual respect and good feeling existing between the Executive and the Judiciary of the nation.

The President, owing it is said, to the non-arrival of the Tennessee, with dispatched from Mexico, did not send in his message yesterday. This obstacle is now removed by the arrival of that steamer at New-Orleans last evening, and it is anticipated that the message will be given to Congress to-day. There seems to be no reason to believe that the delay of the Executive is at all dependent on the movements of the House.

The People VS. James Stephens.---In this case as will be well remembered, the time originally fixed for the execution of the prisoner passed by, while his case was pending upon appeal to the Court of Appeals. The conviction having been affirmed,

CONGRESSIONAL DEBATES.--The House of Representatives seems determined to exhaust all possible topics of discussion before it organizes, and it discusses them all with such coherency, connection, precision, and such evident enlightenment of everybody present, that the country will soon begin to look forward to the election of a Speaker with regret.

Hollow walls for buildings, by inclosing and confining a stratum or wall of non-conducting air, preserve both equable temperature and dryness, whatever may be the outside heat or cold. Protection against the direct action of the elements-of rain and wind--of course constitutes the leading idea of a house.

BARNABAS CAMPAU, who has been missing since Nov. 29, Mr. DEMILL,

Commodore MONTGOMERY arrived in the Merrimac, expecting to meet the Lancaster, a fortnight ago, But receiving orders from home to repair to Central America at once, he hoisted his pennant on board the Cyane and sailed North in her. The Lancaster has not arrived yet. She has been heard from by Overland Mail vid Buenos Ayres, and is now looked for daily. The Merrimac still waits for her before sailing

It seems to be taken for granted by some of our contemporaries that the proposed Unionsaving meeting is to help the Democratic Party. The Tribune and Evening Post are especially vehement in opposing and denouncing it on this ground.

LARGE FIRE IN ROCHESTER.--On Saturday night, between 11 and 12 o'clock, a fire broke out in the grocery store of Messrs. BURNS VANCE, No. 131 Main-street, Rochester, and before the flames could be checked they extended to the Second Baptist Church, destroying the interior of the building, and leaving only the walls standing. The steeple fell over within the walls with a great crash, soon after the church caught fire.

Extensive preparations are making for the approaching executions. Nineteen companies of military are now on duty, and guards are stationed at every street corner and crossroad. Picket guards patrol the surrounding county, and six more companies are announced as on their way here.

It is quite impossible for many intelligent persons to conceive of such a thing as an independent newspaper. Journalism, especially in this country, has been so long considered a mere appendage of political partisanship, that it has ceased even to claim for itself any higher function than that of echoing the sentiments, defending the acts, assailing the enemies and seeking the success of one or another political party.

FURMAN.--In this City, on Monday Dec. 12 CHARLES HENRY CLAFLIN, only child of Dr. G. and Elvira Farman, aged 7 months and 22 days. The friends of the parents and the medical profession in general are respectfully invited to attend, without further invitation, the funeral from St. Lake's Church, Hudson-st., on Wednesday, Dec. 14, at 12 o'clock. The remains will be taken to Greenwood Cemetery.

The promise, or, if our readers please, the menace, of a thorough, emphatic snow storm, has been hanging over us just long enough to give a special zest to the preparations which are making at the Central Park to convert that noble pleasure-ground of the people into a true Winter Garden of the most delightful kind.

We are to have two Opera nights next week, with Miss ADELINA PATTI, Signor BRIGNOLI and Signor AMODIO. The success of our new prima donna has been the most fortunate circumstances of the Philadelphia campaign, and her re-appearance here will undoubtedly be the occasion of a a revival of the enthusiasm which she created on her debut.

About 10 o'clock on Wednesday morning, Rev. Mr. TERRY called on me, and startled me by the awful announcement, "Poor SOUTHARD is dead." It is section that I have received so great a shock, and the peculiarity sad circumstances of his death have most deeply and painfully affected me, as they have all who knew him.

RECEPTION OF GEN. SERRANO--NEW LINE TO ST. THOMAS--WRECK OF A SPANISH WAR VESSEL. From the Diario de la Marina we derive dates from Porto Rico to Nov. 27. The Boletin of San Juan abounds in particulars of the reception there, en route for Havana, of Captain-General SERRANO. He was received with great honors, and for three days kept the little island in a fever of excitement.

BURGLARS SENTENCED IN POUGUKEERSIM.--FOX, BADULRY, WILSON, DAVIS AND PERRY were arrested and lodged in the Poughkeepsie Jail two months ago, charged with having committed numerous burglaries in the neighborhood of the city. DAVIS turned State's evidence, and on information given by him, PERRY'S arrest was affected, and the booty which the two had accumulated was recovered.

A Result of the Syracuse Convention-The Police Commissioners and the Courts of General and Special Sessions at Loggerheads. Samuel Russell and Samuel Snow, indicted for forgery in the second degree, in passing counterfeit bills on the Merchants' Bank of this City, pleaded guilty, Russell, to the fourth degree of the offence, and Snow to the third degree.

The unanimous passage of Mr. MASON'S resolution in the Senate was expected. No one dared oppose it. The debate grew out of an effort to destroy its effect by adding an unimportant inquiry as to the seizure of the Liberty Arsenal in Missouri. The debate, however, may be productive of good results.

The Canadian Reciprocity Commission. Special Dispatch to the New York Times. HAMILTON, C. W., Wednesday, Dec. 14. Mr. HATCH, of Buffalo, appointed to examine the working of the Reciprocity Treaty, commenced his investigations here to-day.

There are trifling signs of life in the proceedings of Congress. The Senate devoted the earlier portion of the day to a continuation of the Slavery debate. Mr. WADE, of Ohio, defending the Republican Party, and paying a warm tribute to JOHN BROWN for his heroic resistance to the Border Ruffians in the Kansas war.

From the St. Louis Democrat. We doubt whether any city of 10,000 inhabitants in the United States ever waited twenty-four hours for its correspondence because the head of a Depart ment in Washington delayed and dickered about the difference between $175 aud $239.

PARADISE.-In this City, on Tuesday morning, Dec. 13, SUSAN DURAND, wife of J. W. Paradise, and daughter of Cyrus Durand, in the 48th year of her age. The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend the funeral from her hate residence, No. 328 West 24th-st., on Thursday, Dec. 15, at 1 o'clock.

Two Yankee peddlers, named Manchester and Coon, have been expelled from Columbus, Geo., and warned out of the State. A correspondent writes from that place to the Montgomery Mail: "Yesterday a batch of Yankee drummers took through tickets for home, saying that their samples did not suit this market." A batch of peddlers were also overhauled last week at Yorkville, S. C.

OUR UNION MEETINGS.-The Richmond Examiner notices the fact that the Union meeting in Boston was exclusively in the hands of those whose regard for the rights and interests of the South has never been doubted. But it remarks that "not a single leader of the dominant party of Massachusetts participated in its proceedings."

SCUDDER--FROST.--In This City, on Tuesday, Dec. 13, by Rev. Samuel Osgood. TOWNSEND SCHUDDER to SARAH M. FROST, daughter of Philomen H. Frost, Esq. VAN WART-FRIEN.-In this City, at the house of the bride's father. On Monday. Dec. 12, by Rev. V.M. Hurl. But, STEPHEN L.VAN WART to Miss EMMA R. FRIEND.

ACCIDENTS.--A young man named ROBERT McCULLOUGH, residing on Twenty-second-street, Gowanus, fell from a Court-street car on Tuesday evening last, and had his skull fractured. JAMES FARRELL was badly crushed between a boat and the fender while attempting to get on one of the Fulton Ferry boats.

HOSPITALS AND SISTERHOODS.-Dr. W. C. ROBERTS delivered a lecture last evening in the Freewill Baptist Church, on "Hospitals and Sisterhoods." These institutions he pronounced to be the offspring of Christianity. The first hospital of any note was established in Ceser??, 373 A. D., after which one was founded in Constantinople by St. Chrysostum, and in 650 A. D., the Hotel do Dieu was established in Paris.

CITY SALARIES.-The Common Council has been displaying a good deal of energy in increasing the salaries of City office-holders, which for a variety of reasons may be a very proper proceeding, but not upon the ground assumed by Alderman BRADY.

The second session of the Superior Court is engaged in the trial of a suit for breach of promise of marriage, brought by Miss HENRIETTA RICHARDSON against JEROME B. CARPENTER, the damages claimed being $3,000. A. A. RANNEY appears as counsel for the plaintiff, and C. G. THOMAS for the defence.

The Boston Journal, Dec. 9, reports tile following case: " The Supreme Court, this forenoon, is engaged in trying a suit brought by Harrison Fay, et al. vs. the Alliance Insurance Company, to recover insurance upon the freight of the cargo of the ship Columbus, which ship, with a portion of its cargo, was burned in the bay known as Port Phillip, Australia.

The Crescent City has now well-nigh filled her horns, and is in what is called " the season." The hotels are overflowing with guests, the levee and all the business streets are alive with traffic, the places of amusement are nightly crowded, and every steamship, river boat and railway train are adding to our population. "Cotton is king" again, in our busy marts, and reigns right royally.

THE DANCING MALADY IN GERMANY.--A few months after the dancing malady of 1374 had made its appearance at Aix-la-Chapelle, it broke out at Cologne, where the number of those possessed amounted to more than five hundred, and about the same time at Metz, the streets of which place are said to have been tilled with eleven hundred dancers.

MY DEAR SIR: It was only a short time since that I heard of the death of our mutual friend, Dr. ABBOTT, which all who knew him must sincerely lament, for there never was a more liberal, kind-hearted and estimable man ; and it is a pleasure to express an opinion, formed from an acquaintance with Dr. ABBOTT of many years, to you who have taken so great an interest in his welfare.

FINANCES OF PENNSYLVANIA.--The statement of the finances of Pennsylvania, which has just been prepared by Hon. Jacob Fry, Auditor--General shows that the revenue of the State for the fiscal year just closed, amounts to $3,825,350 14. The balance in the Treasury Nov. 30, which is available, is $892,027 76, and the depreciated funds, which are unavailable, amount to $41,032.

A young man who registered his name at the Hoyle Hotel, Providence, R. I., as John Dudley, of Connecticut, made a desperate attempt to commit suicide. He retired early on Thursday evening, and as he did not make his appearance by the next evening, the door of his room was forced open. It was found that he had cut his throat and had severed the brachial veins in each arm with a dull knife.

HARRIET MARTINEAU ON MODERN DRESS.-Do the petticoats of our time serve as anything but a mask to the human form-a perversion of human proportions ? A woman on a sofa looks like a child popping up from a haycock. A girl in the dance looks like the Dutch tumbler that was a favorite toy in my infancy.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The hoisting of a red ball upon the bell tower in the Central Park as a signal that the ice in the pond is safe or skaters, is a wise and timely arrangement, and will be appreciated by thousands. But why not make ?? signal more universal?

THE COLUMBIA -STREET HOMICIDE.--The investigation of the circumstances attending the shooting of JAMES MURRY, in Furman-street, South Brooklyn, on Sunday night last, was commenced before Coroner HORTON and a jury, last evening Medical testimony was first introduced to show that the deceased died form the would received. Capt. SHANNON, of the Third Precinct Police, was the next Witness.

The leading topics of conversation and discussion in England are the anticipated war with France, the volunteer Rifle Corps and the Channel Fleet. Never since the assemblage of the first NAPOLEON'S Boulogne flotilla has the question of the National defenses occupied so large a share of public interest; and in proportion as the necessity of preparation for war becomes more evident, statements of the military and naval strength of other nations are more anxiously scrutinized.

In two of the largest cities of the United States a mad attempt was last evening made to inflame the Abolitionisin of the North into tenfold fury and strength. Some ill-advised worshipers of the Union in Philadelphia and New-York undertook to mob sundry lecturers and speakers of the Garrisonian School.

MEETING OF THE KEYSTONE CLUB.--At a moting of the Keystone Club of Philadelphia, which was held on Monday evening, there was an irruption of outsiders. Suddenly the Constitution was spirted away and subsequent proceedings are thus described by the Evening Bulletin: A motion was made to postpone the election of others. .

Another week without a Message, and with public business at a dead lock. The Senate, at its session yesterday, met only to appoint a Committee under Mr. MASON'S resolution, elect a Chaplain, and transact unimportant business, and presently adjourned till Monday.

STATUE OF HON. JOSIAH QUINCY.--A meeting of the Committee of the Association of the Alumni of Harvard College appointed at the annual meeting of the Association on last Commencement day, to procure a marble statue of the venerable ex-President of the University, from the chisel of W. W. STORY and to collect subscriptions therefor, was held in the Council Chamber at the State House, on Friday, Dec. 8, Gov. BANKS presiding.

ARGUMENT OF MR. M'KEON--THE DECISION RESERVED. The case of Dr. SCHILLING was resumed yesterday before Commissioner BETTS. Mr. McKEON, for the Government of Wurtemburg, insisted that the papers showed a gross case of forgery; that eighty-seven forged acceptance had been found, as charged by the Government of Wurtemburg, amounting to over 100,000 florins; that the accused counterfeited these while a citizen of Stuttgart, in 1856, and fled from there in January, 1857.

NARROW ESCAPE OF AN AMERICAN SHIP--A few days ago a large American ship, laden with cotton, from New-Orleans to Liverpool, had a mostnarrow escape from destruction. She had, during lazy weather, come in close proximity to Sarn Badrir, in Cardigan Bay.

LECTURE BY LOLA MONTEZ AT MOZART HALL. LOLA MONTEZ delivered, last night, at Mozart Hall. to an audience of fifteen hundred persons, her first lecture since her return from England. The quite natural subject which she chose was "John Bull at Home," which she treated, perhaps, with less than her usual vivacity, but with a due appreciation of the individual she had to deal with.

A BANK SWINDE.--A broker of Coronna named WALLACE has swindled several brokers and one or two banks of this city, out of various sums of mouey, amounting in the aggregate to three or four thousand dollars, by selling drafts on the People's Bank of New-York purporting to be drawn by a banking firm in Illinois. The drafts were protested, the firm having no account at the People's Bank. Mr. WALLACE

On yesterday the sixth Session of our Territorial legislature assembled here. The Council (or what ?? familiarly termed in the Eastern States the Senate,) is composed of 13 members, and stands, politically, 10 Democrats to 3 Republicans. This body was elected last year, and "hold over." The House ?? Representatives is composed of 39 members, whose political cast is 26 Democrats and 13 Republicans. This body is elected annually.

CAREY.--In this City, on Wednesday morning, Dec. 14, at her residence, No. 19 Suffolk-st., ELIZA, the beloved wife of P. H. CAREY, after a short but severe illness. Her remains will be taken to St. Mary's Church, in Grand st., at 9 1/2 o'clock on Friday morning, where a solemn requiem mass will be said, and thence to Calvary for interment. Requiescat in pace.

EXPLOSION OF A PERCUSSION CAP FACTORYONE MAN KIILLED.-Between 9 and 10 o'clock this morning, the percussion cap factory of D. J. GAEDSMARK, on Carroll, near Nevins street, and property in vicinity, was severely damaged by the explosion of a small out-building used as a magazine, (where the material for the percussion caps are stored,) and killing instantly a German named ERNEST HYLER--the only person about the premises.

B. P. Stikman and G. B. Bruce, engineers, have arrived at Montreal to test the condition of the Victoria Bridge before it is handed over by the contractors to the Grand Trunk Railway Company. Mr. Robert Stephenson, a short time before his death , deputized these gentlemen to perform this duty.

The slip, or motion without propulsion, of well-proportioned screws and paddle-wheels, is about the same. That of the Great Eastern's screw and paddle was about 12 per cent. In some of our coasting and lake propellers the slip of the screw is 40 per cent., and sometimes 60 per cent.

AMERICAN-BUILT SHIPS FOR THE MUSCOVITE NAVY An interesting and instructive commentary upon the often-repeated announcements of the peace and civilization policy of the present Czar, is afforded by the article on Russia in the November section of tile new edition of the Encyclopedia Britannica, written, not by an Anti-Palmerston and Russia-hating subject of Queen VICTORIA, but by an adjunct professor of the Ecclesiastical College, in the Monastery of ALEXANDER NEFFSKI, St. Petersburg.

Mine. Catharine Benoist died at St. Louis on Friday last. She was the daughter of Charles Sanguinet and a granddaughter of Dr. Conde, a surgeon of the French army, who came to St. Louis in 1755, from Fort Chartres, after the treaty of that year between France and England, by which the country east of the Mississippi was ceded to England, and all that west of it to France.

THE BOSTON BREACH OF PROMISE CASE.--The breach of promise case of RICHARDSON vs. CARPENTER, in Boston. was continued Dec. 13. The plaintiff was further examined, and testified that defendant had kept company with her nearly three years. She heard he was about to marry another person, and spoke to him about it, when he denied it; he was married a few days after. He visited her as often as be could

A PHASE OF CITY LIFF WORTH THINKING OF. From the Sunday Times. The last days or one of tile loveliest of Indian Summers have let us, and Winter is coming-stern, hard, frosty old Winter. With what varied feelings is tile coming season regarded by the thousands of inhabitants of this great City ! Some look forward to it as a season of delight; others, as one of sorrow.

AVOLIO, A LEGEND OF THE ISLAND OF COS WITH OTHER POEMS, By PAUL H. HAYNE TICKNOR FIELDS. 1860. This collection of poems bears testimony to the author's conscientious cultivation of fine poetical gifts. A shocking murder took place near a little town called Rome, in Adams County, Ohio, a week ago last Thursday, under the following circumstances: A man named WILLIAM HODGE, son of RANSOM HODGE, who lied in the Penitentiary some years ago while undergoing a sentence for counterfeiting, invited number of his neighbors, and among them a cousin named MILTON hodge, to assist him in raising a new building.

THE TAMMANY GENERAL COMMITTER.-This body met last evening at their rooms--Mr. ISAAC V. FOWLE in the Chair. A call was adopted ordering primary elections for the General and Ward Committees for 1860, to be held in the several Wards on Saturday, Dec. 17, between the hours of 6 and 8 P. M. EDWARD BURKE, of the First Ward, and THADDEUS MOTT, of the Twelfth, were expelled from the Committee by reason of having supported WOOD.

THE EDDA.--The word Edda means "Greatgrandmother." What Homer's poetry was to the Greeks, the Edda is to the Teatonic tribes of Northern Europe. It is the only vista through which they can obtain a glimpse of the life of their barbaric ancestors two thousand years ago.

THE TURF--HRENAN'S PRIZE FIGHT--A NEW BILLIARD CHALLENGE. The challenge to the owners of Ethan Allen for a race wit Patchin, has been answered, but in indefimite terms. Mr. HOLCOMB, owner, of Ethan, proposes to reduce the purse to $1,000, giving as the reason there for the temptations which would be excited by a larger figure "for plots and practices which may interfere with the health of the horses."

There is an affected impartiality which is more to be dreaded in the crisis of a great cause than the most irrational partizanship: a calculated independence. Which may have its price perhaps for the individual who assumes it but can have very little value for the community in which he lives.

The Senate, to-day, made quick work of their session, and after electing Dr. GURLEY Chaplain, and appointing Messrs. Mason, Davis, Filch, Collamer and Doolittle a Committee to investigate the Harper's Ferry affair, adjourned over until Monday, when, if he Senate be full, the President again promises them his message.

From Mexico. CHANGES IN THE LIBERAL CABINET-RATIFICATION OF THE MEXICAN TREATY. New-ORLEANS, Thursday, Dec. 15. The Mexican correspondent of the Picayune says that Senor LERDO has returned to the Cabinet, and that he consents to the ratification of the McLane treaty without alteration.

We have had an entire cessation of Indian depredations for two weeks past. There appear to be no more marauding parties in the settlements, and their whole force is either concentrated to repel the invasion of their Territory, or they are inspired by fear, and hope to meet with clemency by an appearance of friendliness.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Your article that appeared a few days ago upon "Iron Hulls," is one that should command the attention of all. The disasters that have befallen the ill-fated steamers Royal Charter and Indian should load to a close investigation of the defects in construction and material that tended to produce such deplorable results, that they may, if possible, be avoided.

It is proposed to have an Agricultural Convention at Vale college, during the present Winter, to continue in session during the whole month of February. The exercises are to consist of lectures by leading men, eminent in the different departments of agriculture, horticulture, stock raising, About eighty lectures are provided for. Each lecture will be followed by a general discussion.

The Herald and Tribune have joined their forces for the annihilation of the Union Meeting on Monday night. Having succeeded in their joint effort to defeat Mayor HAVEMEYER, they seem ambitious of again testing the power of their united influence.

Gen. GARIBALDI has been too long and too widely identified with the cause of Italian independence and liberty, for the world to pass lightly over his recent resignation of the high position which he held as Commander-in-Chief of the Central Italian Army.

Tile Royal Mail steamship America, from Liverpool on Saturday, the 3d instant, via Queenstown 4th, arrived at this port at noon to-day, and sailed at 3 P. M. for Boston, where she will be due on Saturday night. The news by the America is quite unimportant. The approaching European Congress, and the probable representatives of the various Powers there, attracted public attention almost exclusively.

THE COLUMBIA-STREET HOMICIDE.-The investigation before Coroner HORTON and a jury as to the circumstances attending the death of JAMES MURRAY, who was shot in Columbia-street last Sunday night, was continued last evening. MICHAEL COCHRANE, who was with deceased at the time of the affray, was examined. His story was substantially the same as that of QUIGLEY, who was examined yesterday.

The Journal of Commerce is entirely at fault in representing the TIMES as having urged that "the conservative national men of the North should hold their peace" until "those speak." We have never dreamed of anything of the kind.

The Tribune denounces the Union demonstrations of this and other Northern cities, on the assumed ground that the men who get them up are merely seeking Southern trade thereby. It dwells upon this accusation with an emphasis and pertinacity which imply, that it is the most heinous of crimes for men to have any regard for their own interests in connection with their public action.

Caucuses of the Democratic and Republican members of tile Legislature, were held last evening. The Legislature met at 12 o'clock. Whole number of members 117. Tile Senate is composed of 23 Republicans, 13 Democrats and Independent;the House of 58 Republicans and 22 Democrats.

Rev. Timothy M. Cooley, of East Granville Mass., died Dec. 14, at the age of 87 years. Born in Granville during the Revolution (1774,) he graduated and studied divinity at Yale College, and preached his first sermon in Granville on the 30th of April, 1795, and was settled as pastor there Feb. 3, 1796. This relation he actively and uninterruptedly maintained until 1854, a period of 58 years, when he preached his farewell sermon.

TESTIMONIAL FROM GEN. URQUIZA TO COMMISSIONER BOWLIN.--The Washington Star says: "Minister YANCEY, on his return from South America, was made the bearer of a magnificent present from Gen. URQUIZA. President of the Argentine Confederation, to Hon. JAMES B. BOWLIN, of Missouri, who was for some time the guest of Gen. U. on his return from Paraguay, and evidently won his kind regards.

From the Albany Evening Journal. We gave our money, as Republications gave their names, to promote the circulation of the Compend, because we knew that Mr. HELPER'S book contained much valuable information; and because we desire that everybody should realize that Slavery enervates and impoverishes even the States most favored in climate and soil, and ought not, therefore, to be extended.

LAURA KEENE 'S THEATRE--A now three-act piece, called "Distant Relations," Was produced here last night, and enjoyed the favor of a very crowded and singularly one-sided audience. It is a coarse transcription of vulgar events, chiefly connected with an inferior class of boarding-houses, and perhaps true, but repulsive, and therefore inartistic.

THE CARLISLE KIDNAPPING CASE--RELEASE OF MYERS--The Frederick (Md.,) examiner, of Wednesday, says that EPHARAIM MYERS, of that county, recently convicted at Carlisle, Pa., of kidnapping certain "free" negroes from that State, was released from imprisonment by arrangement, on Monday last, upon his personal recognizance, and has returned to his home.

The result of the first ballot for Speaker in the House, to-day, furnished no little amusement to those in the secret. Many of Mr. SHERMAN'S friends were alarmed for him, as they heard THADDEUS STEVENS and others vote for GILMER, while the Democrats were dumb with astonished. What did it mean? No one seemed to know except those who are were aware of the South American Campus this morning.

ADDRESS OF THE TAMMANY COMMITTEE. At a meeting of the Democratic Republican General Committee held at Tammany Hall, Thursday evening, December 15, 1859, James English, John Vance, Joseph M. Marsh, Nicholas Murphy, Richard T. Compton, Michael Connolly and John Hardy were appointed a Committee to prepare an address, and they reported the following, which was unanimously adopted by the General Committee:

Judge HALL has sent down his decision in the case of the balk Orion, charged with being engaged in the Slave-trade, which was tried before him some weeks since. The Judge decrees the condemnation of the vessel, tile first laver that has been forfeited here for some years.

SALE OF THE BROOKLYN FERRY LEASES.--Reguarding the sale of the Brooklyn ferry leases, announced to take place to-day, several important rumors are afloat. The one to which the most importance is attached is, that a combination of wealthy men intend to outbid the Union Ferry Company to however high a figure the latter may go.

A SUGGESTIVE CONTRAST.-The Union meeting called for next week is assailed daily by the Tribune, on the alleged ground that it will not express the real sentiment of the Northern people. It will not denounce the "only disunionists in the country,"--namely, the Southern ultraists,

The Charleston (S. C.) Mercury announces the formation of a Committee of Safety in that city, and says that its object will be to aid in the detection, arrest and proper disposal of all Abolition sympathisers and emissaries, whose presence may be prejudicial to the peace of our community.

The Detroit Advertiser, Dec. 14, says: "After an immense amount of fuming in regard to a number of disappearances, some of the parties for whom rewards have been offered have turned up. The man JOHN C. SMITH, from Disco, has written from New-Jersey, and COLE, from Pontiac, is in Milwaukee.

The Philadelphia Evening Journal says that during the lecture delivered by Mr. CURTIS, last evening, several citizens were arrested for hissing some passages it contained. Mr. ROBERT E. RANDALL was among the number.

The Cunard steamer America, at Halifax, brings European advices to Dec. 3. The news is of trifling moment. The question of the Congress--which of the Powers will be there, and who are to be their representatives--engrosses general attention. The London Times strongly urges Lord PALMERSTON to attend as the English Plenipotentiary. The first session is said to be appointed for the 5th of January.

We have had an exciting time during the twenty-four hours which halve just closed with the execution of four prisoners. In order to correct understanding of what has transpired, I give you a succinct narrative of the events since yesterday morning.
To the Editor of the New-York Times: Hitherto I have refrained from noticing the various unfriendly remarks which have been published in this country concerning the American Chapel in Paris,

The Massachusetts historical Society held a special meeting on Thursday evening, at the residence of Hon. DAVID SEARS, to pay a tribute of respect to the late WASHINGTON IRVING. After a formal announcement of the death of Mr. IRVING, by Mr. SEARS, Prof. LONGFELLOW made a few remarks, alluding, in affecting terms, to his personal intercourse with tile deceased, and concluded by offering a series of appropriate resolutions.

THE PROGRESS OF NON--INTERCOURSE.--The movements of the South towards an entire cessation of all traffic with North, and towards arming themselves against future emergencies, have resulted thus far in very largely increasing one branch of northern tariff.

ALL WELL ON BOARD-LIST OF THE OFFICERS. The United States steam-frigate Wabash, bearing the flag of Flag-officer E. A. F. LAVALETTE, arrived yesterday from the Mediterranean, having made the voyage from Genoa in 33 days. The Wabash has been on a long cruise in the Mediterranean, and reports that the movement of Spanish vessels and troops about Gibraltar was very lively.

MORRISON,--In this City, on Thursday, Dec. 15, WILLIAM BYERS, endest son of James Morrison, in the 25th year of his age. The friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the i??neral, on Saturday afternoon, at 1 1/2 O'clock, from the residence of his father, No. 83 7th-av. The remains will be taken to Greenwood for interment.

The New-Orleans Crescent of Tuesday says that 67 ships are loading there for Liverpool, 16 for Havre, and 16 for other foreign ports. Sixty-four of the principal cotton buyers and brokers of New-Orleans have acquiesced in the resolution published in the New-Orleans Price Current of Nov. 16, and it will go into effect on Monday next.

Time and reflection always afford the best corrections for such a heated public sentiment as has prevailed for the last few weeks in the South, and especially in Virginia. The excitement was perfectly natural, and so were the indignation and resentment by which it was attended.

HEAVY BURDEN.--Canvassing and Collecting Agents from the North in Mississippi are now said to require the guarantee of an editor, both as to their own character and that of the house with which they are connected, before they can be allowed to travel in the State. We think it is hardly fair to impose this burden upon the Press without a liberal scale of remuneration fixed by law.

The adjourned caucus of the Senate meets again to-morrow morning to settle definitely the distribution of the Committees. Some changes from the first programme were determined upon yesterday, and others are contemplated. It is rumored that Senator GREEN will decline the Chairmanship of the Territorial Committee, with a view to having Senator DOUGLAS restored to his old position.

WILL FRANKFORT-STREET BE WIDENED ?-Some ten years ago, about the time that French's Hotel was erected, a proposition was started for the widening of Frankfort-street, the design being to take off the necessary slice from the northern side. The movement aroused serious opposition, and the property owners were extremely severe upon the originators.

LOCKWOOD.--In this City, on Saturday, Dec. 17, after a short illness. JAMES LEWIS C., son of Samuel and Susan H. Lockwood, aged 16 years 5 months and 12 days. The relatives and friends of deceased, without further notice, are invited to attend his funeral, from Rev. Dr. Burchard's Church, in 13th-st., between 6th and 7th avs.. on Monday. Dec. 19, at 9 o'clock A. M.

A WOMAN MURDERED IN CLEVELAND.--The Cleveland (Ohio) Leader, Dec. 16, says: "Yesterday, between 3 and 4 o'clock, another brutal murder was committed upon the West Side, in what is called 'Irishtown.' The name of the murdered woman is O'MALEY, and the persons arrested for the crime are JOHN KELLY and his wife.

DODGING ONE'S CREDITORS.--One of the "curiosities of debt" has recently come to light in the English bankruptcy Courts. The Scotch law, it appears, affords as many facilities for fraudulent debtors as it once afforded to clandestine marriages, so that by a few title-simple proceedings, anybody who has been a resident in that ancient Kingdom for forty days, can wipe off all old scores and begin the world anew.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In a card published in your paper of yesterday, signed by the District-Attorney, my name is mentioned, but in a sly and evasive manner, intended to insinuate that my character is not unimpeachable. It is obviously done for the purpose of setting aside the force of the affidavit read in Court on Tuesday last.

The " Union Meeting" which is to be held at the Academy of Music, in this City, to-night, will depend for its justification against the sneers and scoffs which have been heaped by the partisan Press upon it, and upon those who have been instrumental in calling it together, very much upon the tone and temper of the conservatism to which it shall give expression.

THE BOARD OF CITY CANVASSERS. THE DIFFICULTY IN THE FOURTH DISTRICT OF THE TWENTY-SECOND WARD--THE BOARD DECLINES TO RECEIVE THE RETURNS. The Board of City Canvassers, for want of a quorum, did not commence its Saturday's session till 3 P. M., at which hour the Special Committee appointed the day before to investigate further the allegations against the Canvassers and Poll-clerks of the Fourth District of the Twenty-second Ward, had been instructed to report.

From California. A MISSING STEAMSHIP--ANOTHER DUEL--MARINE ITEMS--THE MARKETS--MISCELLANEOUS. ST. LOUIS, Friday, Dec. 16. The Overland Mail, with San Francisco dates of the 25th ult., passed Malloy's Station at 2 o'clock this morning, and will reach here to-morrow night.

Morgan, of the Committee for the Preservation of the Union: In reply to your proposal that I should act as one of the Vice-Presidents of the Union meeting to be held at the Academy of Music on Monday next, I have to say that if I can be assured that an equal opportunity will be afforded

The steamship Vanderbilt at this port, and the North American at Portland, having achieved remarkable Winter passages from England, furnish us with European advices to the 8th inst. There is little of stirring interest in the news. The arrangements for the forthcoming Congress, now fixed definitively for Jan. 5, still engross public attention, to the exclusion of other political topics.

By the arrival of the Brazilian mail in England, we have dates from Buenos Ayres of the 28th of October, Rio Janeiro, Nov.19, and Bahia, Nov. 13. From Rio we are advised that but little of general interest had transpired during the month, the Chambers being closed and the Emperor away on a visit to the northern part.

The U. S. Mail steamship Vanderbilt, P. E. LE FEYRE, Esq., commander, from Havre and Southampton at 8 P. M. on the 7th ultimo, arrived off the Highlands on Saturday evening at 5 o'clock, bringing 208 passengers, the usual French and English mails, together with an unusually valuable cargo.

CELEBRATION OF THE THIRTY-THIRD ANNIVERSARY. The Thirty-Third Anniversary of the City Tract Society, and the thirty-seventh of the Female branch, was held, last evening, in the Dutch Reformed Church, on Fifth-avenue, corner of Twenty-ninthstreet. The Treasurer's report, read by Mr. A. R. WETMORE, showed tile receipts for the past year to have been $17,378 15, of which $1,271 01 were contributed by the Female branch.

The body of JOHN E. COOK, one of the four associates of JOHN BROWN, executed at Charlestown or Friday, was brought to Jersey City about midnight on Saturday, by ADAMS' Express. It was at first designed to remove the remains to Williamsburgh in a hearse, but,

John P. Treadwell et al. vs. Myndert Van Schaick et al.--This was the injunction suit brought by the proprietors of the St. Nicholas Hotel against the Croton Aqueduct Board, to prevent them from cutting off the supply of Croton water at the hotel for non-payment of the water tax. The case has been several times reported in the TIMES at earlier stages of the proceedings.

PROF. MORSE IN COURT.--A suit has been pending in the Supreme Court of this State for some time, brought by Mr. CHARLES SPEAR, Of Boston, against Prof. MORSE, for the recovery of damages for having sold to him a telegraph privilege which was deemed not valid by reason of a certain condition of things. The suit was terminated on Wednesday by a verdict against Prof. MORSE of $1,590.

This morning, on the opening of the House, CLEMENT L. VALIANDIGHAM, of Ohio, rose to a personal explanation. He wished to correct a misstatement of his late speech, made in the New-York Herald. Mr. VALLANDIGHAM is s ill a very young man to have attained such prominence.

When I telegraphed you, yesterday, that Mr. H??TCH had commenced the investigation of the working of the Reciprocity treaty, a service for which he was told off by the Washington authorities, I was under the impression that he would devote at least a week to the business, and procure the evidence of some of our leading commercial men.

The Union demonstration last evening at the Academy of Music certainly equaled in numbers and character any movement of a political character in the previous story of the City. The building was not only densely crowded, but outside as many as five thousand persons were gathered about the different stands, constituting an assemblage very little short of tell thousand in numbers.

ROAD--HIGH BRIDGE--FURTHER APPROPRIATION OF $98,500 FOR EXPENSES OF THE CITY GOVERNMENT THE PRESENT YEAR. GOVERNMENT THE PRESENT YEAR. The Board of Aldermen, last evening, adopted a resolution offered by Alderman BRADY in favor of meeting every day the present week at 5 P. M., Saturday excepted.

Judge CLERKE, in delivering a lecture at the University Law School on Tuesday evening, on "The Marriage Relation," touched upon a subject which bears very closely upon that most momentous of all themes under discussion at the present day, "The Future of the Working Classes."

The Democratic family quarrel in the Senate today was for a while quite entertain to the Republican side but when Senator BROWN concluded his speech he returned thanks to the desks and empty chairs for their kindness in remaining until he closed. Not a single Republican Senator was in the Chamber, and not more than a dozen Democrats a strong proof that Popular Sovereignty is played out.

I am enabled to inform you that there is a prospect of improved postal communication between our Island and New-York. The Secretary of State for the Colonies has forwarded a dispatch to the Governor, embodying a proposition on this subject; but the exact nature of tile scheme will not be fully known before our Legislature is again convened.

DEATH OF PROF. HOPE OF PRINCETON COLLEGE.--Rev. MATTHEW B. HOPE, Professor of Belles Lettres in Princeton College, died suddenly, on Saturday evening, from disease of the heart. Prof. HOPE was appointed to the position which he held in the College, in 1817, and few men in the country were more eminently qualified for the important and distinguished post conferred upon him.

NEW-YORK ASSOCIATION OF THE SUNDAY SCHOOL TEACHERS' UNION.--The regular meeting of this Association was held, last evening, in Dr. POTTS' Church, corner of University-place and Tenth-street, Mr. RALPH WELLS in the Chair. Prof. JOHN S. HART, editor of the Sunday School Times, and late Principal of tile Philadelphia High Schools, delivered an exceedingly able address upon "the General Theory of Teaching and Training."

We have not the slightest objection to telling the Tribune what we consider " Northern sectionalism." We should have given our neighbor this important information long ago, if we had supposed he was really anxious for it. We regarded his pertinacious catechism as rather a chirrupping kind of rhetorical habit, than as indicating any special desire to know our views :

SUIT--WILLMARTH--In this City, on Tuesday, Dec. 13, at the residence of the bride's father, by Rev. J. P. Thompson, D. D., S. TAYLOR SUIT, of Louisville, Ky., to AURELIA B. WILLMARTH, daughter of A. F. Willmarth, Esq., of this City. COGER--MANGAM.--In this City, on Wednesday, Dec. 14, by Rev. Thomas Armitage, D. D., JOHN J. COGER to Miss EMILY, daughter of Henry H. Mangam, Esq., all of this City.

The SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES, published This Morning, contains: WENDELL PHILLIPS' Speech, delivered at the John Brown sympathy meeting at Cooper Institute--in full. THE CHARLESTOWN EXECUTIONS--Full account of the Execution of Cook, COPPIC, GREEN and COPELAND--Arrival of the Remains of Cook at Williamsburgh. A PHYSICIAN'S STORY--Concluded. LITERARY MISCELLANY--Interesting Items.

The Richmond Enquirer suggests that the Virginia Legislature will order a compilation of all the "laws passed by Northern States inimical to the States of the South and their citizens." This is a sensible recommendation, and we trust it will receive attention. It will aid the people, not only of Virginia, but of the whole country,

THE ARMSTRONG GUN.-A complete battery of twelve Armstrong guns has been shipped for the British expedition against China. It is greatly to be regretted that the powers of this much talked-off weapon in actual warfare should be first tested against such indifferent enemies as the Chinese,

In September an application was made in the Supreme Court--full Bench--on a bill of exceptions, prepared by W. J. HADLEY, Esq., for a new trial in the case of Mrs. MARY HARTUNG, convicted of the murder of her husband by poisoning; the execution of judgment having been stayed by an order from Judge W. B. WRIGHT. After listening to the arguments on both sides, the Court took the papers for consideration, and reserved its decision.

Brownsville, Texas, dates to the 14th iust., are received. Brownsville was defended by 300 men. CORTINAS had been reinforced, but no fight had yet taken place. DEGOLLADO lost half of his army and all his artillery is a battle with MIRAMOK near Queretaro. Being pursued by the Church forces, he retreated to Monterey, but was also forced to abandon that point. The road to Tampico is now open to the Church forces.

The grand demonstration of the citizens of New-York in favor of Constitution and the Union, which had been announced for several days, took place last night at the Academy of Music. Long before the hour for meeting, the spacious Academy was thronged, from pit to dome. Even in the spacious amphitheater every seat was occupied, and throughout the house standing room within hearing distance was eagerly sought.

COMMON COUNCIL.-At a regular meeting of the Board of Aldermen, held last evening, the Railroad Committee submitted a report in favor of allowing the City Railroad Company to continue tile present charges for carrying passengers, provided they fully comply with the original agreement with the city, and increase the accommodations for carrying passengers.

The attempt which has been made in Philadelphia, and which finds countenance with some organs of opinion even here in New York, to establish the doctrine that the fact that a meeting is a "public meeting," entitles any number of persons, however small, who disapprove of the object for which it is held,

Ex-President Pierce intends to pass the Winter at the Bahama Islands. The place has been recommended by the highest medical authority in Boston as promising, by its climate and other surroundings, beneficial results to the health of Mrs. Pierce, which it is found cannot bear the severity of our Winter in New-England.

The U. S. Mail steamship De Solo, J. D. BULLOCK commanding, from New-Orleans and Havana, arrived at her dock at 6 o'clock, P. M., Dec. 19, having made the entire passage, including 9 hours' detention at Havana, in six days and 10 hours. The actual running time of this passage is the shortest ever made. The De Solo left Havana on the 15th, in company with steamship Yorktown.

The UNION meeting last night was immensely large, decidedly enthusiastic, and entitled to weight and consideration as an expression of the substantial sentiment of the people of New-York City concerning the Union, and those features of the Slavery agitation which threaten its peace.

STOLEN PROPERTY RETURNED--One night last week three overcoats were stolen from the house of ex-Alderman FITHIAN, in the Tenth Ward. Yesterday the coast were returned, with a note, in which the thief apologized for stealing them, not knowing that it was Mr. FITHIAN'S house he had entered. He returned the property because Mr. F. had once rendered him a kindness, and states that he was compelled to steal because he could not get employment.

The screw-steamship City of Washington, Capt. PETRIE, from Liverpool on the 7th, and Queenstown on the 8th inst., arrived here yesterday morning. The letter and newspaper dispatches to the 7th have been anticipated at length by the Vanderbilt, but the telegraphic advices from Queenstown are more extended than those to the same date furnished by the North American at Portland.

The Yonkers railway scheme, which the Mayor has just vetoed, is another example of the tenacity with which the Common Council of New-York adheres to the tactics which have for years back made it so notorious, and we might almost add, so infamous. The family of Prince Czartoryski has just suffered a painful loss by the death of the Princess Anna Saphiea, mother-in-law of Prince Adam Czartoryski, who breathed her last on Nov. 26, In the 86th year of her age. Prince Czartoryski had been absent from Paris for some considerable time, but returned on the 25th, and on the ensuing day, at 4 o'clock in the morning, the princess died without a sign of suffering.

The " Union Meeting" of Monday night was intended to be a great manifestation of the Conservatism of New-York. This was its only possible value, as the only possible reason for calling it together was to be found in the impression which now pervades the Southern States, that Conservatism is dead at tile North, that Abolitionism reigns from Maine to Minnesota. and that JOHN BROWN is its prophet.

The important intelligence reaches us from NewOrleans that Mr. McLANE has returned from Mexico, bearing with him a Treaty with the Liberal Government, which only awaits ratification here to be complete. The United States Mail steamer Yorktown, Capt. W. D. COOPER, arrived at this port on Monday evening, from Havana, having left that port last Thursday, 15th inst. Another Senatorial caucus was held, this morning, to nominate a Printer, but without success. There were five candidates: Brigadier-General BOWMAN, Mr. WENDELL, Mr. SMITH, of the Alexandria Sentinel, Hon. H. WATERSON, of Tenn., and Capt. DUNNINGTON, of the Capitol Police. Mr. SMITH is said to be Senator HUNTER'S favorite. Mr. WEHLELL has strong backers, and Mr. WATERSON is sanguine.

The United States steamer Brooklyn has arrived here, bringing Mr. McLANE, our Minister to Mexico, and his family. Mr. H. R. LA RAINTREE, Mr. McLANE'S Secretary of Legation, has also arrived, bearing with him the treaty with the Juarez Government.

OLD MEN'S COMMITTEE. The Republican Primary Meetings were held last evening. We give the tickets elected from all the Wards, save the Sixth, from which we have no returns. Wards. l..James Marshall, Joseph P. Boyce, John Corly, Levi Leonard, J. M. Andrews.

TUTHILL.--In this City, on Sunday, Dec. IS, ANDREW J. TUTHILL, In the 34th year of his age. The relatives and friends of the family, and of his brother James M. Tuthill, are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, from his late residence, No. 535 Hudson st.. on Wednesday next, Dec. 21, at 12 1/2 o'clock.

FELONIOUS ASSAULTS.--ANDREW ROGERS and JAMES DERRICK were brought before Justice CONNOLLY, at the Tombs, yesterday morning, charged by JOHN BROTHERS, of No. 21 Baxter-street, with having committed an unprovoked assault on him. He alleged that ROGERS struck him a violent blow with a pitchfork. and that DERRICK followed up the attack with a cart-rung.

JOHN A. LOGAN, of Illinois, whose maiden speech and maiden clash with Mr. KELLOGG from the same State, attracted some attention a week since, is a very young man, certainly not over 28 years of age, and he is deemed to be on the Democratic side one of the most rising members.

In spite of the incessant rain, yesterday morning, several hundred persons attended, at the residence of SAMUEL L. HARRIS, Esq., in Williamsburgh, the funeral of Capt. JOHN E. COOK, recently executed at Charlestown, Va.

The fuse factory of JOSEPH Toy,in Simsbury, took fire at about 7 1/2 o'clock this morning, and was entirely destroyed. The fire took in the lower part of the building, while the employes were at work in the upper story, and the flames spread with such

Fall of a Ware house on Broad-street--Two Persons Killed, and Several Others Injured. The wholesale grocery and commission store of Messrs. KENT, LOWBER Co., of Nos. 54 and 56, Broad street, in consequence of being too heavily stored with flour and other merchandise, gave way last evening, and falling, buried several persons in the ruins.

POISONED BY LEADEN WATER PIPES--Er-A1-derman MUCHMORE and family--in all seven persons--were, a few days ago, seized with sickness and every appearance of poison was manifested. Dr. SAMUEL J. SWALEN, having been called to attend them, succeeded in tracing the poison to the lead water pipes by which the Ridgewood water is conducted into the house.

BARBEE'S statue of "The Fisher Girl," to be sold by LEEDS, at the, Exchange to-day, at 12 o'clock, in point of its history, as well as of its intrinsie merits, is one of the most remarkable works of are which this country has yet produced.

A Force of laborers were engaged yesterday in clearing the ruins of Messrs. KENT LOWDER'S warehouse Nos. 54 and 50 Broad-street which fell on Tuesday evening, and caused the death of Mr. WILLIAM J. ELY and Officer JOHN STEWARD, of the First Precinct. The operation was, of course, witnessed by a crowd of curious idlers, but they were kept at a safe distance by a police force.

THE "OCTOROON" WAR.--The brilliant and attractive play of the "Octoroon" at the Winter Garden seems to prosper upon the lopping off of some of its limbs, very much as trees do by pruning. The admirable acting of Mrs. ALLEN in the character of Zoe, combined with the attractive effect of the thousand idle rumors which always spring up out of a little "difficulty," crowd the house nightly;

The Catholic laity in Ireland are beginning to find themselves in a position, the difficulties of which are daily increasing. When the Italian war broke out, the avowed hostility of the English Ministry to NAPOLEON'S enterprise, led most of them into an enthusiastic support of the whole movement,

Miss PATTI'S return to the scene of her first triumph, flashed, too, with a new success achieved in Philadelphia, was commemorated last night by a magnificent house, and by a warmth of approbation which showed clearly the hold the young prima donna has already obtained on our community.

The Board of Supervisors have once more taken up the question of an increase in the salaries of Judges. It is now proposed to increase the salaries of all the Judges of Courts of Record in this City, from $5,000 to $6,000 per annum, to take eftect on the 1st of Januars next.

Congress has evidently no intention of attempting an organization this year. The Senate yesterday named its Standing Committees, and entertained a motion of Mr. SLIDELL, of Louisiana, in favor of appropriating a sum for the purchase of Cuba. This, with some Executive-session business, constituted the sum of its labors.

The students from the Southern States, who are at present in attendance at our various medical colleges, assembled last evening in the rooms of the University Medical College, to deliberate on the action which they should take with reference to learning this City and pursuing their studies in Southern institutions. There were between three and four hundred in attendance.

The National Republican Committee of the United States met yesterday in this City, and appointed a day in June next for the assembling in Chicago of the Convention which is to nominate tile candidates of the Republican Party for the Presidency and the Vice-Presideney in the Electoral contest of 1860.
