The Oveland Mail, with San Francisco dates of the 28th ult., passed Malloy's Station at 12 o'clock last night, and will be due here on Thursday night. Dr. John Barry, the Catholic Bishop of the diocese of Georgia, whose death in Paris was announced a short time since, was born in Parish Olgate, County of Wexford, Ireland, in July, 1799, and emigrated to the United States about the year 1822. He was educated at St. Peter's College, in Wexford, and completed his studies under Bishop England, in Charleston.

The Cunard steamship Asia, from Liverpool on the morning of the 10th inst., arrived here yesterday. The advices are less than two days later than these by the City of Washington. The most important intelligence is contained in a dispatch, of unverified authenticity, forwarded from St. Petersburgh, stating that the Emperor of China had ordered the Russians to remove from the Amoor region, the treaty ceding that territory never having received his sanction.

I express, not only my own, but the general sentiment of our community, in saying, that th NEWYORK TIMES is looked upon as the best, most conservative and reliable Northern journal-or, in other words-New-York newspaper, that circulates south of Mason and Dixon's Line. It commands respect, not only for its editorial sentiments, but also for the general character of its news and management.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.-Miss PATTI'S appearance In the " Somnambula" last evening was celebrated by another fine house. We are not surprised to hear that two additional performances will be given prior to the filial departure of the company. No one should quarrel with other people's success, and perhaps the managers are rather to be congratulated on the occasion that so happily exists for a little more opera,

LIABILITIES OF EXPRESS CARRIERS.--Dr. EGBERT, of Mount Holly Springs, Cumberland Co., Penn., brought an action recently against an express company to recover $500 for the non-delivery in New-Orleans of plans which he had prepared for competition for the prize offered by the Commissioners of the Touro Almshouse in that city, for the best design for the building which they proposed to erect.

In September last, the United States Attorney for Wisconsin appeared before the Supreme Court of Wisconsin, and asked leave to file with the Clerk two mandates from the Supreme Court of the United States. directed to the Supreme Court of Wisconsin, commanding that Court to reverse its decision in the case of Mr. Booth, prosecuted under the Fugitive Slave act.

Congress is now in the third week of its session, and the prospect of an organization of the House of Representatives seems still as blank and discouraging as it was when the Republican minority first drew themselves up in battle array on the question of the Speakership. Every day of this state of suspended political animation breeds new perils for the permanent peace of the country.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Your musical correspondent pretends to answer, in to-day's paper, the question : What the Germans would do when GORTHE's centennial arrived. Allow me to state in reply that GOETHE was born on the 20th August, 1740 ; and that on the 20th of August , 1849, his centennial was celebrated in most of the large cities of Germany--principally in his native city. Frankfort-on-the Main.

PUBLIC SCHOOL HOLIDAY ENTERTAINMENT.In anticipation of the Christmas holidays the pupils of Grammar School No. 11, In Seventeenth-street, near Eighth-avenue, entertained their friends yesterday morning in a manner as appropriate as it was pleasing. The proceedings commenced with songs and calisthenic exercises by the little ones in the Primary Department.

VENTION. The National Republican Committee met at 9 A.M. Yesterday, at the Astor House, and was in session al the morning. The following call for the National) Convention has been issued: A National Republican Convention will meet at Chicago, on Wednesday, the 13th day of June next, at 12 o'clock noon, for the nomination of candidates to be supported for President and Vice-President at the next election.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I have read with much interest your excellent article on "Railway Accommodation Traffic" in this morning's Times. The facts stated are most striking, and the reasoning unanswerable. Is it not astonishing that railroad directors should be blind to matters so vitally affecting the interest of their stockholders and the convenience of the public?

Our town has resumed the "even tenor of its way," after the excitement of the recent election for State officers. The result of the election is not fully known, as the returns have come in unusually slow. Up to the present time there is a majority of two thousand and ninety-six for CHARLES ROBINSON, the Republican candidate for Governor. M. C. CONWAY'S majority is not as large.

Some four months ago, it will be remembered, the staunch, sharp-pointed and fleet little schooner Nautilus, formerly in the United States Revenue service, left this City, for Chiriqui, with a party of explorers, whose avowed purpose was to delve among the mountains and streams of Chiriqui, in search of gold.

VICTOR HUGO, of all the exiles of French Democracy the most democratic, has spoken his mind in the matter of JOHN BROWN to the whole Republic of the United States. To say this is to say that he has spoken it well, with emphasis with fervor, in that clear and vigorous prose which is the prerogative of great poets.

THE MISSING ENGLISH MAIL OF THE "INDIAN."--The missing mail from Liverpool to Toronto, per steamer Indian, is no doubt lost in the wreck of that vessel. The Post-office department have diligently prosecuted the necessary inquiries respecting it, and the only conclusion arrived at is that it was never recovered from the wreck.

ORATORIO.--The New-York Harmonic Society will give its annual Christmas performance of the "Messiah" to-night, at the Academy of Music. The TIMES blew "hot" upon some of the transactions of that meeting and "cold" upon others.

THE PUBLIC STORE CONTRACT.--It is proposed in certain quarters to call a public indignation meeting, to be held at the Fifth Ward Hotel, to express disapprobation of the action of Secretary COBB in giving the Public Store contract to Messrs. MATHER, McINTYRE Co., and the of the conduct of these gentlemen since they obtained the contract, in turning out of office many laboring men whom their predecessors had appointed.

WALLACK'S THEATRE--"Everybody's Friend" has so completely fulfilled its title that everybody and everybody else's friend go to see it. The piece is now in its prime; the "points" are taken up with the greatest precision, and the language enjoys all the social significance of which it is capable, without too many cheap literary improvements from the comic artists. A more suitable entertainment for the holidays could not be found.
The Richmond papers are loudly exultant over the withdrawal of Southern students from the medical schools of Philadelphia. They regard it as the first step towards a dissolution of the Union!

CONGRESSIONAL PROSPECTS.--The House of Representatives takes one ballot a day, and remains therewith content. The rest of the time has been devoted to talking. Hitherto the Democrats have had their part of the business mainly to themselves, as the Republicans have declined to permit themselves to be either provoked or seduced into such a general exchange of political compliments as debating in the House has now become.

FIRES--At about 1 o'clock, yesterday morning, ?? barn or Hewes-street, near Kent-avenue, owned and occupied by BARNETT JOHNSON, was consumed by fire, together with a quantity of hay and feed. The police succeeded in rescuing five of the nine horses which were in the building, but the other four, together with a cow, were destroyed. Mr. JOHNSON'S loss is about $1,800.

TRINITY CHURCH SABBATH SCHOOL. CHRISTMAS EVE GATHERING--INTERESTING SERVICES--THE CHILDREN'S CHRISTMAS TREE. The chimes of Trinity Church pealed forth a merry welcome to the coming Christmas, on Saturday afternoon, and the pews and aisles of the edifice were thronged at 3 o'clock by children with beaming holiday faces, and parents and friends assembled to witness their jubilation, and enjoy their happiness.

MICHAEL DONOVAN, an aged Irishman, who was found grossly intoxicated in Cherry-street, on Saturday night, was taken to the Second Ward Station-house, and yesterday morning was found dead in the cell to which he had been committed. Suspicions that he had been killed in an encounter with a fellow prisoner were removed by the Coroner's inquest.

INCENDIARY NEWSPAPERS. - The following paragraph is from a private letter front Washington: "Positive information is now on record here, that incendiary Abolition articles and documents, which the Tribune, from its party position, dare not publish, are regularly sent over to the Herald with a request for publication, and that these requests are never refused.

AYMAR.--In this City, on Friday, Dec. 23, in her 26th year. ELEANOR KINGSLAND, wife of Edmond B. Aymar, and daughter of R. S. Clark. The relatives and friends are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, without further notice, at Calvary Church, on Monday, Dec. 26, at 10 1/2 o'clock.

We inclose you copies of Mr. R. H. KING'S and our own bids for the lately awarded loan at Albany. By looking at your files you will see what were the lowest figures at which any awards were made, and that Mr. KING was awarded $190,000 of the twelve-year stock, and a considerable portion of the six-year stock, by virtue of the codicil to his bid.

NEW-JERSEY MILITARY COMMISSION.--The Commission appointed by the Governor to revise the Militia Laws of the State held their fourth meeting in this city on Friday, Gen. RUNYON was called to the Chair, Col. J. S. BUCKALEW acting as Secretary. The Committee on Arms, Armories and Aresenals, Courts Martial and their Proceedings General Regulations, and the Duties and Requirements of the Organized Militia, made reports, which were adopted.

DEATH OF A WIFE RESULTING FROM JEALOUSY. Coroner FENNER, on Saturday afternoon, held an inquest on the body of ELIZABETH, wife of JOHN DOUGLASS, tailor, who died at No. 244 Quince-street. The Testimony showed that the deceased was married to JOHN DOUGLABS in Ireland, about nine years, and that they have been in this country several years.

The Detroit Advertiser says: The Corunna Banker, WALLACE, who had ?? operations" with some of our Brokers a few week ago, has been writing letters to some of his ?? friends. It seems, by the explanation he gives, the his object was not merely to "put money in his purse, but to "swindle the Abolitionists," in order to pay an old score against them which he had inherited from his father.

Our double-headed Democracy have been amusing outsiders and weakening themselves, by holding a State Convention, the avowed object being the election of Delegates to the Charleston Convention, though the real purpose was to concentrate all political power in the hands of the Jo. Lane faction.

I have positive assurance from the President that his Message will be sent in to Congress to-morrow at 1 o'clock. Forty Senators, who will constitute a qnorum, are here. The Printer will not be elected until next week, when, it is understood, the Republicans will vote with the anti-Bowman Democrats. If so, the fate of the General is sealed.

The negro man, HENRY HOLSINGER, convicted at the August session for the murder of a woman named MARY SMITH, was executed to-day in the prison yard, in accordance with the sentence of the Court. It will be recollected that this murder was committed on the 14th of February, in the present year, in a grove in Conewago township, near the farm-house of Mr. JoHN REISEY.

Wednesday last, Vice-President BRECKINRIDGE reached Frankfort, Ky., where, at the residence of Gov. MAOOFFIN, he was entertained at a dinner, to which there bad been Invited those who favored his election to the Presidential Chair,as also those whose influence was thought to be valuable in that behalf, but whose inclinations seem to point to another choice.

If wit consists in the sudden juxtaposition of incongruous ideas, Governor WISE has just delivered the wittiest speech over made upon this Western Continent. He has selected the occasion of a small medical exodus of Southern students from a Northern city, for proclaiming his determination to maintain the American Union;

DEATH OF NON. LINN BOYD. Hon. Lynn Boyd, ex-Speaker of the House of Representatives, died at his residence in Padacah Ky., Dec 17, aged 59. Mr. Boyd was a native of Tennessee, born at Nashville on the 22d November, 1800; but removed early in life to Kentucky, in which State his political career began and terminated.

MCGUIGAN.--In this City, on Sunday morning, Dec. 25, after a short and severe illness, ANDREW MCGUIGAN, aged 32 years. The friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, from his late residence. No. 8 Domimick-st., this (Tuesday) aftertoon, at 1 o'clock.

FAREWELL MISSIONARY MEETING.--Quite a large assemblage gathered in the Reformed Dutch Church on Fifth-avenue. corner of Twenty-ninth-street, last evening, to tender a word of parting to Rev. JACOR CHAMBERLAIN, Jr., who is soon to sail as a missionary to the Arcot Station in India.

In my last letter I fell into an error by following the careless statements of those whom I thought good authority, which I hasten to correct; namely: Ispoke of GOETHE's Centennial as a future occurrence, where as, in fact, it took place on the 28th of August, 1849. It was celebrated in one or two of the largest German cities, but not universally by the people.

This is the height of Winter, but I have scarcely seen a fire this week,-the depth of the rainy season, but the prettiest day in June has not a clearer, finer sky. The first secular thing I did on landing here was to buy an umbrella. I have carried it ever since, being very strongly impressed that it must be of service in the rainy season.

A MONUMMENT TO J. FENIMORE COOPER--The Cooperstown Democrat states that a monument to COOPER is to be erected in that town at a coot of $3,200. It will be located in the beautiful Lake Wood Cemetery, between Lake Otsego and Mount Vision and Prospect Rock, and near the spot of the "Panther scene."

Last Sabbath brought with it cold weather. In the afternoon of that day a cold wind spring up, and at 9 in the evening mercury went down below zero, and on Monday evening at 9 o'clock the mercury congealed at minus thirty-nine and a-half. Liquors were frozen in most of the saloons; wines and ale bottles were broken.

There is one light in which the Mexican question can be viewed, that should commend it to the favorable attention of the whole country. It is, that the treaty just concluded has no sectional significance or character.

EDUCATION IN UPPER CANADA.--Dr. RVERSON'S Reporter for 1858 exhibits, on the whole, the healthy progress of the Common School System. Although the Presence of "hard times" makes itself manifest in the falling off of the aggregate sum raised for their support to the extent of $49.927, the average duration of school teaching shows a slight increase.

The Wanderer seems likely to furnish employment to the officers of the law for some time to come. She has for the last month been engaged in two different kinds of piracythe Stave-trade and the robbery of other vessets.

Great disappointment was experienced here last night, in consequence of there being no performance. A crowd of people perambulated Fourteenth-street, in perplexity at the mystery which seemed to pervade the postponement, and its cause. There was a lantern at the door saying, " No performance to-night,"

MEETING OF COLORED PEOPLE.-A meeting of colored people was called for last night in the church on Broadway, near Eleventh-street, to take some action to refute the statement made by Mr. CHARLES O'CONOR, at the late Union meeting in New-York, that God intended the black men to be the slaves of the whites. At the hour named for the meeting fourteen persons were present-ono half being white.
Both Houses of the Legislature met in convention to-day, at 12 o'clock M., for the purpose of choosing a United States Senator. MORTON S. WILKINSON was elected upon the first vote.

Capt. EWELL has returned from Sonora His mission, as I stated in my last, has been successful. He was received with coolness, but met with courteous treatment, and secured the object for which he was sent. On his return, however, while at Hermosillo, one of his animals was taken from him by the authorities under some frivolous pretence, which caused a detention.

Arrival of the Northern Light. The U.S. Mail steamship Northern Light, Capt. TINKLEPAUGH, from Aspinwall Dec, 20, with the mails which left San Francisco Dec. 5, reached here last evening. Much excitement is reported to exist on the Isthmus in reference to the Washoe Gold Diggings, in California.

Pride, and daughter of the late Andrew Garr, Sr. The friends of the family, and those of her son-in-law, Dr, By, F. Quackenbose, are respectfully requested to attend the funeral, without further invitation, from the residence her son, A. H. Pride, No. 95 basis 33rd-st. hear lexington-av,. on Wednesday, the 23rd inst., at 1 o'clock P. M.

PROBABLE MURDER IN A HOUSE OF ILL-FAME.--The Cincinnati Commercial, 24th, says: Last night about 20 minutes past 7 o'clock, a young woman named CLARA THOMPSON. was shot by a man whose name is LONG TAPMAN, at the house of Mrs. NOBLE, on Lodge-street TAPMAN, who is a pilot on the steamer Alma, was in the habit of visiting Mrs. N's house last Summer, but had been there but seldom lately.

LEISURE MOMENTS.--The female writers of the South are doing their best, most loyally to redeem their section of the country from the charge of lacking a literature, and it would be ungracious to remark upon the fact that they usually pay our Northern publishers the compliment of asking them to stand god-fathers to these spiritual children of theirs.

LOSS OF THE AMERICAN SHIP MARGARET. By the steamship Karnak, we have Nassau, N. P., dates to the 23d inst. The American ship Margaret, of Portland, HEART A. MERRYMAN, master, from New-Orleans, bound for Glasgow, with a cargo of 1,310 bales of cotton, was lost on little Bahama Bank on Sunday, the 18th inst., at 2 A. M. The cargo had been saved,

Fire at Newark, N. J.--Loss of Life. ARREST OF SUPPOSED INCENDIARIES. NEWARK, Tuesday, Dec. 27. About 3 o'clock, yesterday morning, a dwelling house in Coe's Court, in this city, occupied by four families was destroyed by fire. All the inmates escaped save one, a Mrs. LYONS, who reached the front door, but, becoming bewildered, could not open it.

MOZART'S "Don Giovanni" was played here last night to a good house, and in a satisfactory manner. The opera is usually murdered ruthlessly; its place on the regular programme being generally the last and saddest. On the present occasion the cast was very strong, and the leading artists, without exception, were excellent.

SMITH--SMITH.--In this City, on Tuesday, Dec. 27, at Trinity Chapel, by Rev. Dr. Digbie, Mr. WM. R. SMITH, Jr., to Miss VALERIA E. SMITH, both of this City. TOWER--WHITNEY.--At All Souls Church, on Tuesday, Dec. 27, by Rev. Mr. Frothingham, W. SCOTT TOWER, of Long Island, and KATE L. WHITNEY, of New-York.

PRINCETON COLLEGE.-The funeral of Prof. HOPE of Princeton, was largely attended on Tuesday. The sermon was preached by Rev. Dr. McLEAN, President of the college. The people of the town showed their respect for Dr. HOPE by closing all the S??. He was beloved by the whole community.

PRESIDENTIAL.,--The leading Democratic paper in Allegheny County, Penn., --the Mountain Echo, --nominates Mr. BRECKINRIDGE for the Presidency. The movement, however, is 'held strictly subordinate to any great necessity which may arise for the remonination of Mr. BUCHANAN." We presume that triffing qualification will not in the least invalidate the nomination.

COMMON COUNCIL.--A regular meeting of the Board of Alderman was held last evening. The first business of importance that came up for consideration was the report of the Railroad Committee, made one week ago, in favor of permitting the City Railroad Company to continue to change the same rate of fare for passengers as heretofore charged.

Capt. FARNUM publishes the following letter in the Savannah (Geo.) News, premising that he has not seen the letter of Mr. JACKSON, to which he refers, and that he is sure that gentleman has been grossly imposed upon: SAVANNAH JAIL, Saturday, Dec. 17, 1859. SIR: Much to my surprise and mortification, I have this morning been informed of the contents of Mr. JACKSON'S letter to you in reference to my affairs.

HOUSE OF EMPLOYMENT FOR THE PHILADELPHIA POOR.--The Committee appointed by Councils to consider the propriety of establishing a House of Correction and Employment for the idle and disclosure, concluded their inbors on Wednesday last.

THE NEW CANADIAN CAPITOL.--On Tuesday as t, 20th inst., Mr. ROSE turned the first son in the process of breaking ground for the Parliament buildings. The ceremony was confined to the residents of the city alone, and all extra parade appears to have been avoided.

Fellow-citizens of the Senate and House of Representatives: Our deep and heartfelt gratitude is due to that Almighty Power which has bestowed upon us such varied and numerous blessings throughout the past year. The general health of the country has been excellent ; our harvests have been unu. usually plentiful, and prosperity smiles throughout the land. Indeed, notwithstanding our demerits.

The case is brought in the Maine Court, but, as yet, nothing has been done but to fire the papers therein. It is an agreeable surprise to find that our relations with Mexico form the most prominent feature in the President's Message, and it is a pleasure as well as a surprise for us, in recognizing this fact, to add that they are treated in a proper spirit, and with a just appreciation of their importance.

President BUCHANAN feels greatly relieved by getting the Message off of his hands. It was received in each House without the slightest demonstration of any kind. Twelve Senators voted against the reading, as they considered it a violation of the implied understanding that no business should be transacted this week.

CHILTON, of your City, the chemist who made an analysis of the contents of the stomach and other organs of the deceased Mrs. HARDEN.

VERDE'S opera of the "Sicilian Vespers" was played here last night, for the first time this season, and the tenth of its production in this country. The United States Mail steamship Arago, Capt. LINES, from Southampton on the 14th of December, arrived at this port last evening. She brings 137 passengers, the usual mails, and a large and valuable cargo.

FOREIGN INSURANCE COMPANIES IN GEORGIA.--The Legislature at its recent session passed an act on this subject, which is of importance to outside corporations. It requires all foreign insurance companies (or companies not incorporated by the State) whenever they establish an agency in Georgia, to be licensed by an Insurance Commissioner appointed by the Governor.

HOW ARE THEY TO BE PAID? The People vs. Frederick W. Schwalbc.--This is one of the "liquor cases" of 1857. The defendant, who is an extensive importer of wines and liquor, doing business at No. 73 Chatham-street, was arraigned on a charge of selling liquor on the Sabbath, contrary to the Statute. After a long pending of the action, the complaint was dis??ned and judgment given against that State 86 22 costs.

EXTENSIVE FRAUD UPON A RAILROAD COMPANY.--The Rochester Union states that the officers of the Great Western Railway in Canada have been engaged for some time past in trying to discover the authors of a gauge of fraud, which has been extensively practiced, the pecuniary loss of the Company.

Senator SEWARD arrived in this City last evening on board the Arago from Havre, just in time to find himself welcomed by the metropolis of the great State which he represents, in a manner worthy of the City and of his own high station.

MSSOURI POLITICS.---The Republican State Convetion of Missouri, called to meet on the 28th December, has been postponded, proabably to the 22d of February, though no time is fixed. The change, says the St. Louis Democrat, is made for the purpose of relieving Republicans and Free Democrats from the necessity of making tow journeys to the capital.

THE FERRY MEETING.--There was no ferry meeting held in the City Hall last evening--the time to which the last meeting was adjouned--because no decision has yet been made on the injunction granted by judge HOGEEOOM.

Our neighbor of the Herald feels a little uneasy at out exposure of his nice arrangement for doing the incendiary work of the abolitionists in the Southern States. He is needlessly sensitive on the point. Nobody is in the least surprised at the disclosure of the fact. The arrangement is perfectly in keeping with the character and career of the Herald, and only extends a little the sphere of its ordinary activity.

In spite of the storm, about a hundred and fifty persons assembled at the Cooper Institute yesterday afternoon to attend the adjourned session of the Health Convention.

A SHIP FOR THE NAUTICAL SCHOOL.--The ship Rockall has been purchased by WAINWRIGHT TAPPAN, for $12,000. to be used as a nautical school for boys of the State Reform School. The ship is of 700 tons burden, and will be able to accommodate 150 boys, with the necessary officers. The vessel is in good condition, and the purchase includes spare sails, spars, , of the value of about $600.

Mr. BRANCH demanded to know if Mr. GROW charged him with conduct unbecoming a gentleman.

Were it asked what disease is the most prevalent in the world, a throng of emaciated faces would answer, Dyspepsia. You meet it everywhere, as far as civilization extends; indeed, it may be called the creature of civiiization. It is one of the greatest of human afflictions, --bearing directly upon the physical, and complicating the mental and moral condition of mankind, and affecting seriously the affairs of life.

The first intelligence from the United States which we have received for three weeks, came today by the mail canoe from Minatillan. All our letters and papers by the previous mail were, by design, or through the stupidity of the official, carried over to the Pacific side.

DEATH OF A NUN.--Yesterday morning the funeral obsequies of Sister MARY CY?ILLE DE NE?KERE, who died on Sunday morning, were performed in the Church of the Assumption, Spring Garden-street, below Twelfth. The church was thronged to excess. Rev. Mr. CARTER, Pastor, officiated. The deceased was 36 years old, and was 15 years in religion, as a Sister of the Convent of Notre Dame.

The Plug Uglies proved victorious, and Nabb, with his party, retreated.

To the Editor of the New York Times: Permit me to correct a somewhat serious error which your reporter has made in relation to my remarks in the Health Convention at the Cooper Institute. I am reported as having "defied the drug physicians to explain the theory of any one disease, or the effect of any one medicine." What I did say has a very different meaning.

INCREASING IMPORTANCE OF THE OVERLAND MAIL.--The increased number of letters now transported by the Overland Mail attests the importance of the service, and rebukes the attempts to impair its efficiency in the most emphatic manner. The mail has been steadily increasing in size for several months. The last arrival brought the enormous number of 5,009 letters, besides the bag from Fort Smith to Memphis, of which we have no present account.

CASHMERE GOATS.--An importation of these valuable animals has been made by Hon. W. H. STILES and after a tedious voyage has arrived safely at this place up the river, having been accompanied by a Greek, who is still with them as an attendant, all the way from Smyrna.

Hon. Isaac Blackford, senior Judge of the Court of Claims, died in Washington on the evening of the 31st ult. He was appointed by President Pierce, in 1853, and was indefatigable in the discharge of his duties. He was a resident of the State of Indiana at the time of his appointment, held a high rank in the legal profession, and was much esteemed as a citizen and friend.

Notwithstanding the excessive coldness of the weather, which continued to increase throughout the day, till towards evening it became quite intense, there was no coldness in the disposition of our citizens towards the celebration of New Year's. Maugre the depression of the thermometer, and the day was splendid indeed. A light blue sky and a sun that tried to thaw the snow, and failed through no fault of his.

David W. Wetmore vs. The Steamboat Granite State. This case came up on exceptions to the report of a Commissioner to whom it was referred to ascertain the damages sustained by the libellant by reason of the sinking of the barge Rambler, owned by him by the Granite State. The Commissioner, among other things, allowed $850 for the loss of the vessel, to which the claimants excepted.

FORT LEAVENWORTH, Saturday, Dec. 24, 1859. In August last the steamer on which I had taken passage was detained at this post long enough to take on board 30,000 bushels of condemned "contract corn," which had been purchased in Nebraska at 83c. The Quartermaster, thus freed from this load of "coals sent to Newcastle," has supplied himself at 40c. To the great scandal of army jobbers, he is using corn tainted with Black Republicanism.

Mayor Wood's Message has been sent to the Common Council, and will be found in this morning's TIMES. It is mainly devoted to showing that the Mayor, under the present Charter, has little or no influence in the government of the City. He has no control over either the Finances, or the Law Department, or the Police, or Public Education, or the Street Department, or the City Inspector's Department, or the Board of Supervisors.

A meeting comprising about fifty colored persons and half as many whites, convened at the corner of Broadway and Eleventh-street, Brooklyn, Eastern District, last evening. The object, as stated in the call, was to reply to the insults to the African race offered by Mr. CHARLES O'CONOR in his speech at the late Union meeting, in which he sustained the Divine origin and justness of Slavery. Mr. W.A. HODGES was chosen Chairman of the meeting.

The St. Lawrence is not a mile broad at Quebec; it is two miles across at Montreal. Yet it now takes but five minutes to dash from one to the other shore at Montreal, while at Quebec from one to six hours are necessary! In the one case the passenger rushes through the Victoria Bridge; in the other he entrusts himself to a canoe.
The State Convention met to-day, at the State House, pursuant to a call of both wings of the Opposition. It was the most exciting political meeting that has occurred here for some time.

It has been ascertained by the Receivers, on application to the engravers, that there is no fraudulent over-issue of bills of the Norembega Bank. The circulation is about seventy-five thousand dollars.

We published yesterday a remarkable letter from LIEBIG, the great German chemist, addressed to MECHI, the famous English farmer, upon that most momentous of all sublunary themes, the production of corn. He shows that the corn-producing power of the civilized, cultivated countries of the globe, is rapidly becoming exhausted; that it is owing to guano that the decline has not been more rapid and more marked; but that the existing supply of...

Political events develop themselves peculiarly enough in these days. The sudden and tiger-like bound of NAPOLEON into Italy and out again, startled all Europe and the world. Now we have seen the United States treating with Mexico for over a year, as if a word of menace would force the Mexicans in any position desired.

Commission Sales of Produce for the week ending Jan. 4, 1860, prepared for THE NEW-YORK TIMES by PINNEY JOHNSON, Produce Commission Merchants, No. 231 Fulton-street. Our quotations are such as merchants and producers realize who skip their Produce to this market to be sold on commission.

The United States Mail steamship Cahawba J.W. SMITH, Commander, from New-Orleans on the 27th ult., reached Havana at 6 A.M. on the 30th, and left there at noon of the same day for this port, where she arrived last evening at 7 o'clock. The Cahawba experienced since the 1st inst. heavy northeast gales.

SALE OF THE STEAMBOAT COMMONWEALTH.-- The steamboat Commonwealth, of the Norwich and New-London line, has been sold to Mr. DANIEL DREW, for the New-Jersey Steamboat Company, and will hereafter run on the Stonington route, in connection with the Plymouth Rock. This result was foreshadowed a year ago, when an effort was made to obtain from the Norwich and Worcester Railroad Company a more liberal share of the earnings of the route for the boats.
The Philadelphia Evening Journal has been permitted to publish the following letter of CHARLES DICKENS to a citizen of Philadelphia:

In the death of WASHINGTON IRVING, the announcement of which reached us in our American news of yesterday, the United States have lost at once one of the most respectable and estimable of diplomatists and men of letters. The name of WASHINGTON IRVING, indeed, is quite as much identified with any place where the English language is spoken as it is with America.

This Court met yesterday before Judge INGRAHAM. The Grand Jury was dismissed till the 16th of the month. The Court remains open from day to day, but no trial, it is understood, will take place during the present week.

The communication from our Vera Cruz correspondent, which appeared in the TIMES of Wednesday, announced the fact that the Church faction in the City of Mexico, with Messrs. GABRIAC, JECKER Co., would shrink from no expense, and stick at no measures, to prevent the ratification of the McLane treaty by the United States Congress.
The Senate transacted no business to-day, but met only to adjourn over.

Mayor WOOD has issued a public notice of certain rules by which he proposes to be governed in administering the high office to which he has been chosen. In the main these rules are admirable, and one of them in particular, which promises the establishment of a sort of bureau for the protection of emigrants, immediately under the eye of the Mayor himself, in the City Hall, deserves to be commended in the warmest terms.

Something more serious than an earthquake has shaken San Francisco since my last. Riocon Hill and the whole of the south part of the city has felt a shiver and a tremor so threatening that the last earthquake the fourth since December opened produced no sensation whatever, and the whole town from Telegraph Hill to Mission Greek is thrown into such excitement that the very stupidest meeting you can go ...

Judge HARDY, of Calaveras County, (a State Judge,) has rendered a decision of vast importance to miners, and of much interest to Californians everywhere. It is the case of Gillon vs. Blott and others, in which plaintiff sued for an injunction to restrain rainers from trespass and waste in his premises. The practice under supposed law in California has always been for miners to go where they choose to dig gold.

NEW-YORK, Thursday, Jan. 5, 1860 6 P.M. The reported receipts since noon of yesterday have been 11 bbls. Ashes, 1,409 bbls. Flour, 176 bushels Corn, 10,101 bushels Oats, 187 pkgs. Provisions, and 363 bbls. Whisky.
The steamship Bohemian, from Liverpool at 9 o'clock on the morning of the 21st of December, and from Queenstown on the following day, arrived here at 10 o'clock this (Thursday) evening.

The valuable library of the late poet, Dr. James G. Percival, has been sent from New-Haven to Messrs. Leonard Co., of this City, by whom it will be disposed of for account of the mortgagees, at public auction. It contains 10,000 volumes, and is variously appraised at from $10,000 to $30,000.
The Pike's Peak express, which left Denver City Dec. 28, has arrived here, bringing $15,000 worth of dust.

POLICE TELEGRAPH.--The Police Telegraph has recently been connected with the principal office in New-York, so that orders of the Superintendent of Police, can be communicated directly to the Deputy Superintendent in this city.
Governor CHASE alludes briefly, in opening his Message, to the events of the past year, and then passes to a treatment of the financial condition of the State.
The monthly meeting of the Chamber of Commerce was held yesterday, P. PEEIT, President, in the Chair.

The concurrent resolutions adopted last year, for increasing the number of Judges of the Court of Appeals to six, and for extending their terms of office to nine and twelve years, were reintroduced in conformity with the Constitution, and being concurred in, were laid over under the rule.

BANK DEPARTMENT, Dec. 31, 1859. The past year has furnished additional evidence of the utility, as well as the safety, of the business of banking, as now pursued in this State under the provisions of the "Act to authorize the business of banking," passed April 18, 1838, and the amendments to the same.

Mr. MASON'S explanation of what he meant by the epithet "servile" which he applies to Northern States, to distinguish them from what are called the "Slave States" of the South, is a very good specimen of that laborious hunting for parallels which in heated controversies often supplies the place of argument.
The journal of all the firings with rifle-cannon, offered by the different inventors, gives the results in detail.

The question of a Broadway Railroad is rapidly settling itself, or rather, the companies which monopolize the present conveyance of City passengers are practically settling it. They are managing the roads and vehicles under their control in such a manner as to make absolutely imperative some additional accommodations for City locomotion.

Steamships Huntsville. Post, Savannah, H.B. Cromwell Co.; Prince Albert, (Br.,) Prowse, Galway, Am. Express Co.; Northern Light, Tinklepaugh, Aspinwall, D.B. Allen: Baltic, Gray, Aspinwall, North Atlantic Steamship Co.; Empire City, McGowan, Havana, O.M. Roberts.
The Board of Councilmen met last evening for the purpose of organizing. Councilman SHAW, Presdent pro tem., was in the Chair.

Our whole system of City Railways is a compromise between the convenience of the largest number of passengers and the inconvenience of private and goods traffic; but since it accommodates more people, is a shorter time, at less expense, and with more economy of street room, than omnibuses, its bad points can be tolerated if they are necessary.
George C. Jordan vs. Laura Keene. This was an action to recover one week's salary of $100, of the defendant. The particulars of the case have been fully reported in the TIMES (Dec. 28.)

The Chambers of Commerce of Hamburg and Bremen have issued a memorial on the subject of the rights of neutrals at sea in time of war, and are about to make an attempt to bring the whole subject once more before the coming European Congress at Paris. As the case stands at present, the European Powers have abolished privateering, and have acknowledged that the neutral flag shall cover even an enemy's goods.

The Ohio Democratic State Convention met at Columbus,yesterday. Hon. WM. B. WOODS presided. Resolutions were adopted by a large majority, declaring STEPHEN A. DOUGLAS the favorite of the Ohio Democracy, and instructed the Delegates to the Charleston Convention to cast their entire vote for him.

Gen. HENNINGSEN'S letter, which we published on Thursday, to Capt. FARNHAM, late of the Wanderer, and now lying in jail at Savannah on a charge of slave-trading, is perfectly of a piece, in the way of originality, with the whole curious and unprecedented history of that now famous vessel. Nothing in fiction can surpass the dramatic contrasts of the Wanderer's experience. To-day a lovely...

The Union meeting at the State Capitol is called for Thursday evening next. Over 10,000 names are signed to the call. Ex-Lieutenant-Governor RAYMOND has consented to speak, and Ex-Governor SEYMOUR is invited to address the meeting.

A man named JOSEPH BOGARD was arrested yesterday at Paris, C.W., for passing $5,000 in counterfelt bills on the Bank of Philadelphia in St. Louis, last month. His examination is now going on here, and an application will be made to the Government for the surrender of the prisoner under the Ashburton treaty.

VERDICT AGAINST LAURA KEENE. Grorge C. Jordan vs. Laura Keene. This action was as tried on Thursday, before Judge MAYNARD, in the Marine Court, and was partially reported in the TIMES of yesterday.
The large flouring mill at Jerseyville, Ill., was burned on the 2d inst. Loss $ 18,000. Insured $3,000. COURT-HOUSE IN WISCONSIN.

Two of the Ottawa rescuers were brought before Judge DRUMMOND, of the U.S. Court, yesterday. A. motion was made to quash the indictment, which will be argued this morning. Their bail was fixed at $1,500 each, which they declined to give, and they were remanded to jail.

The Italian question, matured amidst the struggles and sufferings of half a century, has just entered a phase which it may be perhaps permitted us to consider the final one. Under the penalty of allowing Europe to rush into complications, the issue of which could be foreseen by no person, it is necessary that Italy shall cease to be a menace to a prey for the nations that surround her.
The Overland Mail, with San Francisco dates to the 16th ult., reached Jefferson City, Mo., about 1 o'clock to-day.
Mayor WOOD met for the first time since his reelection to the Mayoralty with the Police Commissioners yesterday, and was amicably greeted.
Gov. MORGAN has appointed BENJAMIN W. BONNEY as Supreme Court Judge, in the place of HENRY E. DAVIES, resigned.

The first bill of the Session was on its final passage in the Senate to-day, having passed the Assembly yesterday. It was an act to authorize the Supervisors of Rennsselaer County to audit certain bills.

To America belongs the honor of giving to the world many new inventions of great practical importance to mankind. Prominent among these are the Electric Telegraph, the Reaper and Mower, and the Sewing-Machine. What the telegraph is to the commercial world, the reaper to the agricultural, the sewing-machine is to the domestic.

The reported receipts of the principal kinds of Produce since our last have been: 2 bbls. Ashes, 4,756 bbls. Flour, 4,926 bushels Wheat, 1,048 bushels Corn, 812 bushels Rye, 225 bushels Barley, 48,550 bushels Oats, 407 pkgs. Provisions, 224 bbls. Whisky.

The Democratic State Convention met here today to nominate Delegates to Charleston. The temporary organization was presided over by Hon. Mr. McCONNEL, of Moran County. A Committee on Permanent Organization, consisting of two Delegates from each Congressional District, was appointed. The Convention then adjourned till 1 P.M. During the recess speeches were made by S.S. MARSHALL and U.F. LINDER, urging harmonious and conservative action and conciliation towards the Buchanan Party in Illinois.

If I say a word to-day in regard to the weather, it is because the cold has acquired an intensity which entitles it to the dignity of an event. For five days, the Fahrenheit scale has balanced between eighteen and twenty-eight degrees below freezing point, in the heart of the city; while at certain points in the country, six points below the bulb has been attained according to the indications of the centigrade scale.
MADRID, Dec. 23. The Moors have attacked the Spanish on the road to Tetuan, in order to obstruct the works. They were victoriously repulsed.

If Parliamentary Goverment is no longer considered on its trial, certainly Municipal Corporations have still to make good their claim to superiority. In the great concerns of life every man is interested, the conduct of them is looked upon as the highest duty to which a citizen can aspire, political office confers the highest social position, and, without conferring wealth, brings with it most of what wealth can buy.

When the election of Printer is proposed in the Senate, a committee will be called for and appointed, to investigate the whole subject of Executive interference in the distribution of the profits during the last two years; and a Printer will not be chosen until after this committee has reported.

The Royal Mail steamship Arabia, Capt. STONE, from Liverpool at 9:30 A. M. on the 24th of December, arrived at this port yesterday, in the afternoon.

The annual dinner in aid of the funds of this most valuable and important charity took place yesterday evening, at the London Tavern, and was most numerously and respectably attended. The dinner was excellent and abundant, and all the arrangements gave complete satisfaction. The chair was taken by CHARLES DICKENS, Esq., supported by GEORGE MOORE, Esq., the Sheriffs, Messrs. PHILLIPS and GREATOREX, Alderman MECHI, and others. About 200 gentlemen sat down to dinner.
The fluctuations in the Funds had been but slight. The market was quiet, owing to the approach of the Holidays. Consols on the 23d closed dull at 95 @ 95 5/3 for account, ex dividend.

The second concert of the present season came off on Saturday night, with the usual concomitant of a storm. Under circumstances so depressing, it would not have been remarkable if the house had presented a comparatively empty appearance, but the subscribers to the Society are famous for their endurance, and there was scarcely a perceptible thinning in the ranks, despite the fierce attack of the Pluvial forces.
The meetings of the Cabinet have been suspended until after Christmas, and most of the Ministers have left town to prepare for hospitalities at their country residences.

The Board of Aldermen met at 5 P.M. yesterday, the President (Alderman PECK) in the Chair, and all the members present.
Politics are in a hubbub here to-day. The Democratic State Convention is in session to elect four Senatorial Delegates to the Charleston Convention to represent the State at large.
The steamship Atlantic arrived at this port yesterday morning, from Aspinwall Jan. 2. She brings $1,788,666 in specie, with 254 passengers, and California dates to Dec. 20.

THE WEATHER AND THE STREETS. On Saturday the mercury in the thermometer rose and the rain in the evening descended in torrents. The storm passed away with the night, and Sunday and Monday were like days in June. But such walking! Mud to the right of you; mud to the left of you; mud in front of you; wherever you rambled. No lady ventured forth without her Balmoral.

The Tammany Society or Colombian Order celebrated last night the Anniversary of the Battle of New-Orleans. The commemoration lacked neither in numbers nor dignity. The hall was appropriately and elaborately decorated. The walls were festooned with flags and banners, among which were interspersed the emblems respectively adopted by the States. Pictures, busts, and national souvenirs were exhibited at appropriate intervals.
The steamship Atlantic arrived yesterday from Aspiwall, having left that port on the 2d inst. Her treasure-list is $1,788,666. The Atlantic brings 254 passengers and dates from California to Dec. 20.

Southern members of Congress have made very severe aspersions upon the personal character of Mr. H.R. HELPER, based upon alleged misconduct during the early part of his previous career, while he was a resident of North Carolina.

At the meeting of the Board of Councilmen, last evening, resolutions were offered and laid over directing that the printing of the Common Council be done by Edmond Jones Co. until permanent arrangements can be made.

The Royal Mail Steamer Teviot, with the London mails of the 17th of November, arrived at this port yesterday morning! She brings intelligence that the Queen has conferred the dignity of Knighthood upon BRYAN EDWARDS, Esq., Chief-Justice of Jamaica. Mr. EDWARDS is the son of the celebrated historian of the West Indies.

GOV. LETCHER seems disposed to follow the example of his illustrious predecessor, at a decent interval, in proposing methods of increas ing the existing exasperation between North and South. Except Abolitionism, it would be hard to think of anything which seems to stand so low in the estimation of the Virginian political world at this moment as discretion and common sense.
Mr. WINSLOW, of North Carolina, (Dem.,) asked Mr. GARTRELL, who was entitled to the floor, to give way for a call of the House.

SENEX. Conductor, who is that imperious, disdainful, and highly-ornamented young lady, who wears golden manacles, and glories in a golden cross? The skirts of her charity covered several adjacent sinners, and, at her egress, she created a vaccum, if not a sensation, and was followed by a whirlwind.

By way of San Francisco, we'receive Japan news to the middle of November.

The stemship Quaker City arrived yesterday from Havana, whence she sailed Jan. 5. The weather at Havana has been extremely disagreeable, commencing on the evening of Sunday, the 1st, to rain, with strong winds from the northeast, with heavy showers. The bad state of the weather has tended to retard the receipts of produce.
The board of Supervisors met at 3 P.M. yesterday, all the members present, except Supervisor CONNER.
Thirty members answered to their names in the Senate last evening, and a quorum was present in the House.

The adjourned Annual Meeting of Plymouth Church, having under discussion the question as to whether the Church contributions to the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions shall be continued, took place last a evening, the large lecture room being quite filled. The proceedings were commenced with prayer.

A bill was noticed by Mr. CALVIN, in the Senate, to-day, relative to rents. Mr. CALVIN seeks to reopen the anti-rent question. It virtually nullifies the recent decision of the Court of Appeals against tenants, and provides that there is no rent where there is no subsisting reversion or interest left in the land in the party claiming such rent.

When a house is on fire, it is generally considered the duty of every one to aid in quenching the flames. A person who should be detected in heaping fresh fuel upon the fire, would be dealt with as a miscreant and a public enemy. We do not see why political and social incendiaries should not be regarded in the same light.

The Mayor's scheme for the establishment of a "protective bureau" for the benefit of strangers and emigrants, promises to supply an unquestionable defect in our municipal system. It is certainly most desirable that there should be an office, occupied by employes whose, sole business it shall be to afford information to new-comers, and protect simpletons from the hands of the sharpers who infest our streets.

I commence my term as Chief Magistrate of the commonwealth of Virginia at an evenful period in the history of the State and of the Union. No one of my predecessors has taken upon himself the duties and responsibilities of the office under the same circumstances. The Legislature and the people expect from me, therefore, an expression of my views upon the absorbing question of the day, and some suggestions looking to the future.

After an absence of a fortnight, I find the House of Representatives in much the same state as it stood on Christmas Eve--with the difference, perhaps, that the uncombined National elements have become more obstinate in the resolve to demand supremacy for their several organizations.

Mr. GARTRELL, of Georgia, (Dem.,) said that no blame could attach to the Democrats for non-organization. The scenes enacted here are but the beginning of the "irrepressible conflict" of which they heard so much a conflict between opposing forces a conflict between the North and South.

Last night, at the Academy of music, that saltatory anniversary of the New-York Light Guard was observed with more than usual spirit. In the first place, to notice the decorations of the building, one hundred canary birds sang from one hundred cages, suspended from chandeliers, and from various projections of the ornamental protrusions, cherub's fingers, , of the boxes. And they sang with a will.

One of the most appalling catastrophes which has ever shocked the country, occurred yesterday at Lawrence, Massachusetts. About 5 o'clock in the afternoon the Pemberton Mills fell with a tremendous crash. Six or seven hundred operatives were at work in them at the time, and the lowest estimates state that the number of those buried in the ruins way at least three hundred.

For many years I was thrown into personal contact with many men who occupied a prominent position before the public. It may not be uninteresting for me to give desultory notes of my intercourse with some among them whose names are most familiar to our readers. And partly for the sake of commencing here, at home, I will begin with MIKE WALSH.

Seth W. Peckham vs. Morris Ketchum and Ed ward Bernett, Surviers, c, This was an action to recover from the defendants the price paid by the piaintiff for what purported to be ten shares of the Stock of the New-York and New-Haven Railroad Company.

An Anti-Slavery Convention is now in progress in this City. PARKER PILLSBURY, SUSAN B. ANTHONY, A. M. POWELL, and other leading Abolitionists, are in attendance. The resolutions are characteristic, embracing the following ideas: American Slavery is the sum of all villanies, a combination of all cruelties and crimes, robbery, piracy, adultery, murder, and whatever else is impure, unholy and accursed.

We published in the TIMES of Yesterday morning a report of the festivities which attended the celebration of the auniversary of the Battle of New-Orleans, by the Tammany Society, on Monday night. The supper came off at so late an hour that we were compelled to postpone a notice of it. It was after midnight when the company sat down. After the supper was over, the toasts were announced by I.V.FOWLER, Esq., the Grand Sachem.

The Pemberton Mills in Lawrence, in this State employing between five and six hundred operatives, fell this afternoon about 5 o'clock, burying nearly every person in the ruins. The mangled bodies are being taken out by the cart-load. It is supposed that over two hundred were killed instantly.

Clark et al. vs. George Law et. al.--This is the injunction suit brought in the New-York Common Pleas to restrain the defendants from using certain wharves, buildings, , at Navy Bay in New-Granada. The facts of the case were given in the TIMES of Dec. 12, when the cause was on argument; and the decision of the Court, refusing the injunction asked, was mentioned a few days since.

ANOTHER MYSTERIOUS CASE.--One week ago last Saturday, a man named McNAMARA, residing at No. 202 Columbia-street, South Brooklyn, took a gun and went into Tiffany-place, just at the rear of his residence, for the purpose of killing a dog, which had bitten one of his children. Heretofore, in the history of the country, the antagonism of party has frequently produced intense excitement, but never before was it of a dangerous character. Now it directs itself, not merely against individuals and their opinions, but against the laws and institutions of the country.

We have received the "Report on Federal Relations," submitted by a Select Committee to the House of Representatives of the State of Florida. It is a well-written document, and states the grievance of the South with apparent candor and considerable force. We do not ...

In executive session, to-day, the following appointments were sent in by the Governor, and confirmed: For Superintendent of the Insurance Department, WM. BARNES; Canal Appraiser, THOMAS B. CARROLL, in place of Mr. HULL, of Steuben, whose time expires. No Harbor Masters or Port Wardens were sent in to-day.

Hon. MORTON J. WILKINSON, the Senator recently elected in Minnesota, for six years, commencing on the 4th of March 1859, appeared in the United States Senate, yesterday, and was sworn in. Mr. GREEN subsequently resumed his remarks on the Territorial Question, controverting the position of Mr. DOUGLAS, and was followed by Mr. PUGH, of Ohio, in response to the attacks of Mr. IVERSON. Mr. PUGH early gave way to an Executive Session.
Wilkes' Spirit of the Times states that the Racket-players of New-York are stirring again in the matter of a grand international match with England for the Championship.
The Board of Education for 1860 net last evening, to organize and elect Committees.
Our last-news from Buenos Ayres had been that URQUIZA had defeated the army of the State of Buenos Ayres, and was at Caseros, distant about 20 miles from that city.
We have received, by the bark Sarah A. Mickels, Montevideo papers of the 15th November. Peace has been concluded, and the treaty ratified between Buenos Ayres and the Argentine Confederacy.

The Herald points to the contrast which the catastrophe at Lawrence suggests, between the condition of Northern operatives and Southern slaves. Negro slaves at the South are never shut up six or seven hundred at a time in a rickety factory, by parsimonious and reckless employers, but tenderly cared for, and so forth. Our Abolitionist cotemporary might have carried the comparison further, with equal success.

Mr. Christopher Dresser, the lecturer on botany to the Department of Science and Art of the Privy Council for Education, South Kensington Museum, has been presented with the degree of Doctor of Philosophy, for his botanical discoveries, by the University of Jena.

The Board of Aldermen last evening adopted a resolution, offered by Alderman CORNELL, directing that the rooms of the Fourth District Court, corner of Third-avenue and Fifth-street, be assigned to the seventeenth Precinct Police for sleeping-rooms, and that the Street Commissioner make the necessary alterations and repairs.
We append information and incidents gleaned from the Boston Herald, Courier, Atlas and Bee, and Advertiser, of yesterday morning:

Adolph Crononine, of Pittsburg, suspected William Langner of improper intimacy with his wife, and meeting him at a tavern, discharged a pistol at him. He was so intoxicated by liquor and enraged with passion, that he missed the mark he aimed at and shot away two of his own fingers instead. He stands committed on a charge of assault with intent to kill.

Public attention has recently been directed to the immense grant made by COMONFORT to the firm of JECKER, TORRE Co., of the City of Mexico, of all the public lands in Sonora, Chihuahua, , for a consideration in money, and with the stipulation that said lands shall be surveyed by the said JECKER, TORRE Co., and separated from the private lands.

Lawrence Reilly and Thomas McAlier were tried and convicted of burglary, before Judge RUSSELL. They broke into the house of Mr. Skaats, in West Thirty-eighth-street, on Dec. 5, and stole a quantity of lead pipe. Sentenced to two years in the State Prison.

CITY POLITICS. At the last meeting of the Union League Club No. 1, in this City, a resolution was adopted indorsing the conduct of those members of Congress who denounced the supporters of HELPER'S book. The meeting having accomplished this purpose, adjourned, ordering the resolution to be printed.

The Union meeting at the Capitol to-night was attended by fully four thousand persons, while an untold number were excluded from the great outer hall of the Capitol by inability to obtain admittance. The hall was packed as closely as men could stand the speakers occupying the landing at the top of the stairs leading to the Senate Chamber.

DINNER.--The Members of the Kings County Bar gave a dinner last evening to Ex-Judge STRONG, whose term as Supreme Court Judge expired on the 31st ult. The dinner was at the Pierrepont House, and all of the leading members of the Bar were present.
Having just returned from the recently-discovered gold mines in Madison County, in this State, I send you as follows:

In the Senate of the United States yesterday an exciting debate took place on Mr. PUGH'S resolution, in which Messrs. PUGH, DOUGLAS, DAVIS, GREEN and CLAY participated. Mr. DOUGLAS defended the consistency of his course. He charged that others had changed their views, and said that he would not accept a nomination at Charleston, unless on a platform acceptable to him. He would reply fully hereafter to attacks made on him.

Petitions were presented for the extension of the Chenango Canal; for a pro rata freight law; for aid to the Albany and Susquehanna Railroad, and for the erection of a new County from parts of Steuben.
As the attendance of members was slim, there was a call of the House.

Alexander McKenzie vs. Jane McKenzie. This is another branch of the noted McKenzie divorce case. The action is to recover from the defendant house No. 765 Broadway, which the plaintiff conveyed to defendant at a period when he was in the habit of drinking to excess.

Pease et al. vs. the Steamship Ocena Bird. This was one of five suits commenced against the steamer for repairs and supplies furnished to her in this port. The matter came before the Court on application for the discharge of the vessel from the processes issued in he cases.

Yesterday the newly-elected Governor and the other officers of this state were inaugurated at the Capitol in this city. They are all Republicans: ALEX. RAMSEY, Governor; J. DONELLY, Lieut.-Gover nor; J.H. BAKER, Secretary of State; CHAS. SCHEFFER, Treasurer; and GORDON E. COLE, Attorney-General.

As the early Croton Falls train, on the Harlem Railroad, was on its way to this City yesterday morning, two passenger cars were thrown from the track down an embankment some 15 feet high. The accident occurred just this side of Pleasantville.
The dull monotony of the Congressional proceedings, was unexpectedly disturbed in both Houses of Congress, to-day.

NEW-YORK, Thursday, Jan. 12, 1860 P.M. The reported receipts of the principal kinds of Produce since our last have been: 90 bbls. Ashes, 245 bbls. Flour, 100 bbls. Corn Meal, 282 bushels Corn, 1,322 bushels Rye, 5,028 bushels Oats, 1,593 pkgs. Provisions, and 73 bbls. Whisky.

A communication was received from the Secretary of the Treasury, in reply to the resolution of the Senate calling for information as to the unexpended balance of the amount appropriated under the treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo, to pay the claims of American citizen. The balance is stated at something over two hundred thousand dollars. The communication was ordered to be printed.

At the meeting of the Board of Councilmen last evening, a petition was received from Samuel M. McKay, John B. Clapp and many others, asking for a reduction of fares on the City Railroads to three cents.

Three more bodies were taken from the ruins to-day. These were all badly mutilated two of them so much so that they could not be identified. The third was discovered, by fragments of clothing, to be that of Mrs. AUGUSTA ANN ASHWORTH. She was 18 years of age, and was married in March last. Her husband is a shoemaker, and works at North Salem. Her body was nearly consumed.
The majority of the candidates on the State ticket are Administration men.
William Hutchinson, indicted for taking letters which did not belong to him from the Post office, withdrew his plea of not guilty and pleaded guilty.

The reported receipts of the prinicipal kinds of Produce since our last have been: 12 bbls. Ashes, 1,848 bbls. Float, 7,128 sacks Wheat, 2,338 bushels Corn, 242 bushels Rye, 5670 sacks Barley, 2,876 bushels Oats, 1,741 pkgs. Provisions, and 711 bbls. Whisky.
The steamship New-York, from Bremen, vid Southampton, 29th ult., arrived at this port this afternoon, for one hundred tons of coal, with which to continue her voyage to New-York.
At the Union meeting in Albany, on Thursday evening, the following letters were received from Ex-President VAN BUREN and Ex-Governor HUNT:

We have the returns of the British Post-office Department to compare, or rather contrast, with those of our Postmaster-General. The two documents are as unlike in their general style as in the results which they unfold. The one is a clear, precise, business-like statement the other a document confused in its general plan, and most discouraging in the conclusions to which it leads.

The bill to amend the section of the act for the incorporation of companies to navigate the lakes and rivers so as to make it apply to the waters of Long Island Sound, was read a third time and passed.

Judging from the multiplicity of notices of bills which are pouring in upon both branches of the Legislature at Albany, we fear the approaching session will be as prolific in laws as so many of its predecessors. Before it is too late, however, it may not be amiss to beg of the members to remember, that the curse of the country and of the age in which we live is over legislation.

SANDY HOOK, Jan. 13, sunset. Ship Isaac Bell, for Havre, sailed from the S.W. Spit and crossed the Bar at 9:20 A.M.; Hamb. ship Donau, for Hamburg, at 12:55; ship Carolus Magnus, for Mobile, at 3:30 P.M.; ship Amazon. one bark and one brig have anchored at S.W. Spit, bound out. Wind light S.E.; weather cloudy.

The United States mail steamer Moses Taylor, S.P. GRIFFIN, Esq., Commander, arrived last evening from New-Orleans, via Havana. She left the latter port on the 8th inst.

The Leavenworth Daily Times, Jan. 9, gives the particulars of two conflagrations which occurred in that city on the 8th. The first occurred in the extensive flouring mill of EARLE BUNTING, in the southeastern portion of the city, at the corner of Main and Choctaw streets.

Charles Mallory, Charles H. Mallory, Charles Grinnell, Elihu Spicer, Jr., Samuel Willetts, Robert Willetts and Daniel J. Willetts vs. The Commercial Mutual Insurance Company. This is an action involving an important question as to the nature and construction of policies of insurance.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 12. The steamer City of Norfolk was floated off by the steamer Georgia last night, after taking off deck-load, and has proceeded to Savannah.

The New-York Tribune is evidently preparing to shorten sail in expectation of a coming storm. It no longer talks of irrepressible conflicts between the North and the South, and even takes Mr. CHARLES O'CONOR sharply to task for asserting that no compromise with Slavery ought to be tolerated if that institution is the evil thing which it is represented to be.

Thomas Jones and James Wilson, indicted for forgery in the second degree, pleaded guilty to forgery in the fourth degree. They were charged with passing counterfeit $5 bills on the Wooster Bank of Danbury, Conn. Sentenced to two years in the State Prison.

The following incidents, which occurred last Sunday morning in the church of Rev. ELERY was arrested by Officers FORAN and RYDER in he Third Precinct, Saturdar night, for attempting to pass counterfeit $5 bills on the Wamsutta Bank of Fall River, Mass. ELI STANDISH was arrested in the First Precinct the same evening by Officer BENNETT, for attempting to pass a similar counterfeit. The accused were yesterday committed for trial.

It is reiterated that the Congress meets on the 19th of January. An announcement in a St. Petersburg journal effectually dispels any doubt whether the Russian Minister for Foreign Affairs would be present at the Congress.

LONDON--Saturday morning. The Daily News' City Article says that the Funds on Friday were firmer. There was a partial recovery on the Paris Bourse, and the disquieting rumors relative to the Congress met with less countenance. The market closed at 1/8@ higher than on Thursday. The demand for Money was pressing in the open market, and the rates were generally 1/3@ above the Bank minimum.

ALBANY, Tuesday, Jan. 17. The United States District Court which was to convene here to-day did not do so in consequence of the serious illness of the father of Judge N.K. HALL. The Judge was suddenly summoned to what will probably be the death-bed of his father.

WASHINGTON, Tuesday, Jan. 17. There being a slim attendance, there was a call of the House. Mr. PENNINGTON withdrew his resolution proposing the adoption of the plurality rule. He did so, he said, to avoid confusion.

ST. LOUIS, Tuesday, Jan. l7. The Overland Mail, with San Francisco dates of the 26th ult., passed Malloy's Station this morning. Business at San Francisco remained unchanged since the departure of the previous mail, and the large number of vessels due tended to increase the indisposition to operate. No change is expected until the new year opens.

PARIS, Thursday, Dec. 29, 1859. A great excitement reigns in our political circles. Many rumors are afloat, and the result has been a decided baisse at the Bourse. I must relate to you what these rumors are, praying you to hear in mind that they are but on dita, and must be taken with due reserve.

BALTIMORE, Wednesday, Jan. 11, 1860. Our State Legislature is now in session at An napolis. Its proceedings are, and will be, looked to with deep interest. Measures of decided moment having especial reference to Baltimore, have already been introduced. Amongst these is a Metropolitan Police bill, to regulate the Police Department of our city. This, to us, is a matter of vital importance.

WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Jan. 18. Mr. McREA, of Mississippi,(Dem.,) was entitled to the floor, but yielded it to Mr. CLOPTON, who was about to address the House, When Mr. WASHBURNE, of Maine,(Rep.,) interrupted him by calling for a vote on Mr. HUTCHINS' resolution for the adoption of the plurality rule. He insisted that they were obliged by law to proceed to vote for Speaker without debate and delay.

FESTIVAL OF THE BURNS CLUB.--The Burns Club of the City of New-York held its anniversary last evening in honor of the birthday of ROBERT BURNS, at the Pacific Hotel. About one hundred and fifty guests were present. Mr. J. NICHOLSON, the President of the Club, presided, assisted by the VicePresidents.

YOUTHFUL BURGLARS ARRESTED.--Three boys, named JOHN JOHNSON, JAMES KELLY and IGNATIUS SPHAZIL, were brought before Justice CORNWELL, yesterday, and committed in full to answer several charges preferred against them by different merchants doing business on Atlantic-street. The accused are members of a gang of youthful thieves located in the Second and Fifth Wards. .

Senator WILSON, to-day, entered a defence for the Republican Party, against the indictments from Senators DOUGLAS and TOOMBS, and then carried the war into Africa and charged high crimes and misdemeanors upon the Democracy. He was followed in spirited addresses by Senators CLINGMAN and DAVIS, when the Senate adjourned without an Executive Session.

Hon. F.P. BLAIR, JR., of Missouri, lectured last evening in the Cooper Institute, in compliance with the invitation of an association of Republicaus, who, in the campaign of 1856, assumed the title of the "Young Men's Freemont and Dayton Club." His audience was large, though not sufficient to fill the Hall. It was, however, exceedingly enthusiastic.

Miller vs. The Cincinnati, Hamilton and Dayton Railroad Company.--This was an action brought by the plaintiff on eight second mortgage bonds, and the interest warrants thereon, or coupons of May, 1857. These bonds were made by the defendants, and were originally issued to Messrs. Varnum, Carlisle and C.J. Steadman. They were for $4,008 each, and payable in the usual form of such bonds to parties above named, "or bearer."

A holiday absence from London prevented my despatching my usual letter yesterday. About 2 o'clock yesterday morning flames were seen issuing from the stable No. 265 West Thirty-fourth-sheet, occupied by RICHARD FARRELL, M. W. LATTEMORE, WM. FARMER, and W. C. SEAMAN, milkmen, all of whom lost their horses, sleighs, wagons and harness, as the building was entirely consumed. We must, therefore, commend to his immediate and earnest attention a little proceeding which has just taken place in Columbus, Mississippi.

The Overland Mail of the 6th, with one day's later news from California, arrived this morning. The failure of a Sacrammento house, involving the temporary suspension of a San Francisco jobbing firm, has been undoubtedly magnified by a portion of the Press into three or four failures of heavy houses.

Affairs at Annapolis, where the Legislature is in session, still absorb general attention. The "Ancient City," as it is termed, is literally packed with parties from almost every precinct in each county, all of whom have some favorite project on hand.

At the meeting of the Board of Police Commissioners at 2 P.M., Commissioners STRANAHAN and BAILEY were not present. George Foster, a Doorman, who was dismissed from the Department on the 16th of January, 1859, was reappointed.

The fair setting-in of the rainy season makes merry times among the miners. From all quarters we hear that immense flumes are just being set to digging down hills and washing into the mountain sides, and everywhere preparations approach their completion for beginning the golden harvest. From all the mines the most encouraging accounts are daily received. But the great rush next Spring will be for the Washoe and Mono Diggings.

On the night of the 21st of last September, the residence of Jacob B. Herrick, in West Farms, Westchester County, N.Y., was entered by burglars, who forced open the basement windows and took about $250 worth of silverware.

The District-Attorney, at the opening of Court yesterday morning, commenced to sum up for the prosecution in the case of John Donnelly, charged with the murder of Charles Cobane on Oct. 28, in West Sixteenth-street. He said, after viewing the evidence, that he would not ask for a verdict for murder, but one of manslaughter in the third degree.

The House of Representatives has at last evinced the possibility of an organization. After certain Anti-Lecompton and Pennsylvanian members had explained their positions for the hundredth time, a ballot was ordered; and while it was proceeding, members of all parties found it necessary to account for their votes.

The Boston Journal, 21st, says there was a great panic on that day among the parents and children of the Adams School District in East Boston, in consequence of a rumor that the school-house was unsafe.

A curious debate took place on Thursday in the Senate between Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts, and Mr. DAVIS, of Mississippi, each interlocutor being sustained by friends, who played for each the parts of Aaron and Hur holding up the hands of Moses; on the relations which exist, and which ought to exist, between the slaveholdieg and the non-slaveholding States of the Union.

The Committee of the Confederation, appointed to consider the establishment of a General Supreme Court for Germany, have called VON LINDE to aid them in making their report. We may consider this as a favorable omen, since this eminent jurist has long been known as a strenuous advocate for the creation of such a court.

The visit of the Legislatures of Kentucky and Tennessee to Ohio, and their enthusiastic reception by the Governor and Legislature of the latter State, are amongst the most convincing of the many indications which already exist that the dissolution of the Union is not quite so close at hand as a good many of the fire-eaters and Abolitionists would fain have us believe.

The war between Buenos Ayres and her sister States is at an end; the arbitrament of the Paraguayan President has proved successful, and we have recently received, via Southampton, the text of the Convention to which the representatives of the late belligerents have agreed, and which is to reunite the recusant Republic to the other members of the Confederation.

Running for dear life away from the cold weather of the North about a month since, I reached here by steamer Karnak after a run of five days--pleasant, except the two first, which were cold and blustering, and the saloons miserably warmed by two weak excuses for stoves, both of which would have not kept the ticket-office of the Peck-slip ferry comfortable.

Clinton Hall was crowded last evening with an appreciative audience, on the occasion of Mr. ETHAN ALLEN'S lecture for the benefit of the Widows' and Orphans' Fund of State Rights Lodge, I.O. of O.F. Mr. ALLEN commenced by saying: Odd Fellowship imposes upon all who seek its honors or material advantages the first great duties of a Christian life--benevolence and work.

ALBANY, Friday, Jan. 27. Before the Pro-Rata Committee to-day Mr. J. W. BROOKS, President of the Michigan Central Road: Mr. HUDBY, President of the Cleveland, Columbus and Cincinnati Road; Mr. BRADY, President of the Toledo and Wabash Road; Mr. PHILLIPS, President of the Boston and Worcester Road; Mr. SPALDING, the large forwarder of New-York, and several other officers of important lines of railroad, were examined.

Judge BROWN, of Lewis Country, and "half a dozen other judges," have, according to our correspondent at Albany, testified to their desire for an increase of salary by addressing a petition to the Legislature in favor of an amendment to the Constitution for that very purpose.

WYNKOOP HALLENBECK THOMAS, steam job-printers.

The last earthly honors were yesterday paid to the remains of the great man who has just gone from among us. Escorted by the noblest and highest in the land, the body of MACAULAY was left to mingle its dust with those of the great of past days who slumber in peace beneath Westminster Abbey.

Whatever opinions may have been entertained by independent observers as to the wisdom or patriotism of the course pursued by the Republican Party in Congress in their adhesion to Mr. SHERMAN as their candidate for the Speakership, there has never been any question about the manliness and dignity with which Mr. SHERMAN himself has behaved throughout the struggle.

The trial of Frank Fowler, charged with defrauding Christian Heine of $35, by selling to him for that sum a worthless piece of paper, purporting to be a genuine passage ticket on the steamer Hammonia to Bremen, such steamer not belonging to the Bremen line, and the said piece of paper being entirely useless for any passage in any steamer whatever.

Alderman BARRY presented a resolution to the Board of Aldermen, last evening, directing the Street Commisioner to remove the building No. 24 Roadestreet, because it projected beyond the line of the street, as widened.
Almost the entire population of the District, including thousands of strangers, flocked to the Capitol this morning, to witness, as they had hoped, the election of Speaker.

QUEEN ELIZABETH AND THE EARLY PROTESTANT STRUGGLES IN ENGLAND--This was the subject of a lecture delivered last evening by Rev. ALEXANDER CLEMESTS, in the Presbyterial Church in Twentyeighth street, near the Ninth avenue. The audience, whose Hiberno-Scottish nationality was betrayed as much by their enthusiasm as by their faces, completely filled the edifice.
