The Finance Committee of the Virginia House of Delegates have reported a bill to that body entitled "A Bill making Regulations concerning Special Licenses," the design of which is to carry into effect, by legislative enactment, that famous policy of commercial non-intercourse with the North, which has, of late, been so extensively revived at the South.
Recorder BARNARD has at last got one notorious ticket swindler named FOWLER, who once figured as one of Mayor WOOD'S Police, fairly into his judicial clutches.

Yesterday afternoon it was discovered that JAMES STEPHENS AND FELIX SANCHEZ, the one convicted of having murdered his wife and the other of having killed his father in-law, were about to attempt to escape from the City Prison by murdering the two night watchmen.

The public discussion on the constitution of the Royal Academy, (observes the Atkeneum,) pricks on the artists in their professional work. We recollect no year in which, at so early a date, we could announce so many remarkable works as are now in progress, and likely to be done in time for the opening in May.

Mr. NICHOLSON, of Tennessee, held the attention of the Senate yesterday, speaking upon Mr. BROWN'S resolution. There was little of novelty in his remarks. He regarded Mr. SEWARD as the source of Brownism and Helperism; pronounced the Republican movement an attempt of Northern capital to divert Northern labor from the vindication of its own rights : and saw no escape from the mischievous tendencies of the Republican Party.
The New-York Tribune does not seem to be well informed in regard to the condition of the Republican Party in Congress.
The One Hundred and Twenty-third Anniversary of the Birthday of THOMAS PAINE was celebrated with the accustomed ball and supper at the City Assembly Rooms last evening.
Dodworth's Hall was crowded on Sunday morning last, in consequence of the announcement that ex-Judge JOHN W. EDMONDS would occupy the desk.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Wednesday, Jan. 11, 1860. Since the date of my last letter the Jamaica Legislature has been prorogued. The quarrel between the Assembly and the Governor has been patched up without either party backing down.
The Overland Mail arrived here about 2 o'clock this afternoon, with San Francisco papers of Jan. 9, and telegraphic advices, via Furbaugh's Ferry to 3 P.M. on the 10th.

I write you in great haste, to go by the English mail via Bonny, the steamer having been reported as now in sight, outside the harbor. The Spanish vessels stationed here (three in number) are dressed with flags in honor of the birth-day of Prince ALPHONSE, the heir apparent to the throne.

UNITED STATES STEAMER SAN JACINTO. Off the mouth of Congo River, West Coast of Africa, Monday, Nov. 14. 1859.) Arriving at Monrovia, Liberia, Oct 25, we left the same place Nov. 1, for Congo River, in compliance with Commodorial orders. The Constellation left Monrovia for the lower " Coast" Oct. 26.

Three important trials were on the Calendar yesterday, in this Court, Judge INGRAHAM occupying the Bench--Willard P.Maynard, for the murder of John N. Zilken, on oct.7, 1859; Mortimer Shay, for the murder of John Leary, on Nov. 23, 1859; and John Crummins, for the murder of Dennis McHenry, on Oct. 10, 1859.

In 1850 students who were suspected of frequenting the bowling-alleys of New-Haven lost favor with the Faculty; in 1860, the Faculty provide for students bowling-alleys better than any New-Haven can afford.

The House of Representatives yesterday came almost as near the election of a Speaker, as on Friday, when Mr. SMITH was so sadly disappointed. The absentees numbered seven, five of them being Democrats. Mr. SHERMAN having moved that the House proceed to vote viva voce, the vote was taken, several gentlemen interpolating speeches as it proceeded.

As Mr. RAYMOND remarked, in his Union speech at Albany, "Agitation on the one side creates and stimulates agitation on the other." We see this truth illustrated every day throughout the country. Our Buchaniers, however, do not care to recognize and respect it. They look for light and guidance to Mr. O'CONOR rather than to Mr. RAYMOND.

The official returns of the emigration from Liverpool during the year just closed have now been completed at the Government Office; and, although on comparison with the year preceding, the numbers in the aggregate do not appear to vary very materially, the variation in the tide of emigration to the different countries has been most marked.

Mr. JAQUES' bill, now before the Legislature, settling the manner in which the Common Council may make grants for railroads in this City, at last provides that all such grants shall be put up at auction. Our citizens were startled this morning by the announcement that an attempt had been made to poison the family of JAMES O. PETTINGILL, Esq., of Ogden, a gentleman well known as an Ex-member of Assembly and prominent as a citizen. He resides at the village of Adams Basin, twelve miles out of the city.

The largest pumping-engine in the world has recently been put in operation in Brooklyn, and after a satisfactory test, has been accepted by the City. The neat largest is the Leighwater engine, for draining the Harlaem Meer; in actual working power the Brooklyn engine exceeds it by 16 4-10 per cent.

There is a marked contrast between the valedictory message of Gov. WICKLIFFE, of Louisiana, and the inaugural of Gov. MOORE, of the same State. The former commented on National affairs is the most ultra manner, recommending disunion projects, and berating the the North. Gov. MOORE employs the following temperate language:

In yesterday's TIMES we published an account of a conspiracy on the part of JAMES STEPHENS and FELIX SANCHEZ, two of the condemned murderers in the Tombs, to kill their keepers and escape from confinement. Upon further investigation it has been ascertained that STEPHENS alone originated the plot, and that SANCHEZ did not wholly enter into it, as it was he who revealed the matter, and thus most probably prevented the murder of the keepers.

The Republican State Central Committee met at Congress Hall this evening, and agreed to call a State Convention, composed of two delegates from each Assembly District, to meet at Syracuse on the 19th day of April, to elect delegates to the Republican National Convention. Some discussion as to the election of delegates by Congressional Districts was had, but the final action of the Committee was unanimous.

The most intense excitement pervaded all ranks and classes this morning--those outside political circles confidently betting, by apples and heavier stakes, that a Speaker would be elected to-day; while the insiders indulged in sagacious winks and shoulder. shruggings--shaking their heads, taking all the bets offered, uttering oracularly, "We'll see," and predicting that the Republicans would either abandon SHERMAN or fillibuster against a vote.

The expected election of Speaker did not take place yesterday. It has been confidently proclaimed on the Democratic side that the only difficulty in the way of the organization of the House was the persistence of the Republicans in the support of a candidate for Speaker who was obnoxious to the conservative sentiment of the country by his indorsement of the Helper book.

The weekly report from the institutions to the Board of Governors yesterday showed that the number of inmates remaining Jan. 28 was 8,394, an increase of 122 as compared with the number reported at the previous meeting. While the Clerk was reading the requisitions, the Board was informed that two more foundlings had been left in charge of the Governors. .

The Richmond Enquirer advocates the proposed Southern ,Conference as the great panacea for the political evils of the times, and, therefore, as an infallible specific for the preservation of the Federal Union.

On Christmas day the city was thrown into quite an unusual excitement by a fight among the Danites. BILL HICKMAN, their notorious leader, and LOT HUNTINGTON, who has heretofore figured as first lieutenant of the band, became engaged in a quarrel, in a house on Main-street, in regard to the division of their stolen property.

Neither of the great parties realized their an ticipations to-day. The Committee appointed by the Democratic caucus, last evening, after casting about for a candidate, fixed on Mr. McCLERNAND, although the Southern Opposition preferred Judge LARRABEE.

BUSINESS UPON THE WHARVES.--Much activity is observable along the wharves, particularly in the vicinity of the piers from which the great bulk of merchandise is shipped upon the different steamer and sailing lines. The Sound steamers are doing as much business now as during the same months last year.

The New-York and Boston Express train, which left this city for Boston at 1 o'clock this afternoon, met with a serious accident on the Western Railroad, about five a miles west of Palmer, by the breaking of an axle of the car neat to the rear car, which threw it down an embankment of sixty feet, injuring SIMON DALY, a brakeman, so badly that he died in less than two hours.
The trial of Crummins was resumed, yesterday, before Judge INGRAHAM. Counsel for defence contended, in his opening to the jury, that the wounds were given in self-defence.

SAN FRANCISCO, Friday, Jan. 6, 1860. The chances of Mr. WELLER'S election to the vacant Senatorship begin to look exceedingly slim.

WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Feb. 1. The election of a Speaker to-day was not at tended by particular excitement, as it was known to be a foregone conclusion, and the excitement, too, had in a measure exhausted itself by its previons intensity.

THE REGATTA MARCH BETWEEN ENGLAND AND AMERICA--THE ENGLISH CHALLENGE ACCEPTED.--There was a meeting of the Empire City Regatta Club at the St. Mark's-place Restaurant, last evening, to consider the challenge issued through Bell's Life, some six weeks ago, from ROBERT CHAMBERS, the champion of the Thames, to the champion of America, to row a match for $2,500 a side, single pair of sculls.

The final result of the long contest for the Speakership, was yesterday reached in the election of Mr. PENNINGTON, of New-Jersey, by a majority of one, the decisive vote being cast by the much-abused Mr. BHIGGS, of New-York.
The Harper's Ferry Investigating Committee discharged REALF to-tay. He will leave immedeately for New-York.

At the meeting of the Board of Education, last evening, a communication was received from the School officers of the Seventeenth Ward, asking an appropriation of $7,832, to alter, repair and heat School No. 19. The work had been advertised for and the contracts awarded, amounting in the aggregate to the sum named.

ALBANY, Wednesday, Feb, 1. In the Executive Session of the Senate, to-day, Messrs. SCHULTZ, BENEDICT, ANABLE, WHITING, and MASTEN, were confirmed as Harbor-Masters for NewYork, and THATCHER, and SEAMAN as Port-Wardens. The remaining nominations were not acted on.

Mr. HUNTERS of Virginia, occupied the attention of the Senate, on Tuesday, with an elaborate defence of Slavery. Mr. DOUGLAS' bill for assuring peace between the States was the order of the day, but in the report of the speech we cannot find so much as an allusion to this wise and conservative measure.

The long-drawn battle for the Speakership is happily brought to a close. Upon the first ballot yesterday, 233 being present and 117 necessary to a choice, Mr. BRIGGS, of New-York, added his vote to those which Mr. PENNINGTON had secured the day before, and Mr. PENNINGTON having thus 117 votes was declared elected. He was conducted to the chair by Messrs. SHERMAN and BOCOCK, and the...
FIRST BALLOT.--On the first ballot, Mr. GROW, (Rep.,) of Pennsylvania, received 43 votes. He then withdrew his name.

This Board held a meeting at the Mercantile Library last evening, the President, GEO. OPDYKE, in the chair. Hon. AMASA WALKER, of Boston, read a paper upon the character and increase of Bank Deposits, which was well received.

Application of Phoebe A. Pierson.--This was the return of a writ of habeas corpus directed to Charles H. Pierson, requiring him to produce Charles H. Pierson, Jr., and William Pierson. These are two children aged about four and two years respectively. The applicant is their mother; the respondent their father.
From the Rochester Union, Jan. 31. The conduct of the servant of the PETTINGILL family is rather like that of a bold and experienced criminal.

ALBANY, Wednesday, Feb. 1. The Senate, last evening, ordered to a third reading the bill to grant State aid, to the amount of a million of dollars, to secure the construction of the Albany and Susquehanna Railroad.

The jury in the case of John Crummins, indicted for the murder of Dennis McHenry, remained in deliberation during Tuesday night, and came into Court yesterday moring with a verdict of "Guilty of murder, with a recommendation to mercy."
From the Boston Post, Feb. 1. A fatal accident occurred on the Western Railroad, yesterday afternoon, which resulted in the death of one person and the injury of many others more or less seriously.

ST. JOHNS, N.F., Wednesday, Feb. 1. The steamship City of Manchester, from Liverpool Jan. 11, and Queenstown, at 4 P.M., on the 13th arrived here at 1 o'clock this morning, short of coal. She will remain here nearly thirty-six hours, and will be due at New-York about Wednesday next.

VANDYCK, the Superintendent of Public Instruction, states in his Annual Report, that the whole number of reported School Districts in the State exclusive of cities is 11,358; being an increase of 49 during the past year. The average number of persons between the ages of 4 and 21 years in each district, is 79 5/8. The average number attending school in each district is 53.

At about 10 o'clock yesterday morning, a boiler in the distillery of Messrs. FURMAN POLLY, on North Fourth, near First-street, exploded, destroying a large portion of the main building, killing two men at work on the premises, and injuring two others at work in the vicinity. The explosion was so violent that fragments of the boiler and portions of the building were thrown a distance of several hundred feet.

VERA CRUZ, Tuesday, Jan. 24, 1860. The latest accounts from the City of Mexico state that MIRAMON was still there. A large public meeting was convened in Philadelphia last Saturday evening to inaugurate a "Constitutional Union Movement." Mr. FILLMORE, Mr. CRITTENDEN and other distinguished gentlemen were expected to be present and make addresses, but they contented themselves with writing general letters of approval of the objects of the meeting, and of the union of conservative men of all sections in the present crisis of national affairs.

ALBANY, Wednesday, Feb. 8, 1860--8 P.M. The Senate has now been in Executive Session for seven hours. The contest upon the confirmation of Harbor-Masters and Port-Wardens has been very severe. QUEBEC, Wednesday, Feb. 1,1860. The Legislature of Canada passed a Fishery act about two years since for the regulation, protection and encouragement of the inland as well as the gulf fisheries; and two Superintendents of Fisheries were appointed--one for Upper, one for Lower Canada-- each with a staff of suitable overseers, The Upper Canadian official has made but little progress in his duties; the Lower Canadian a great deal.

The tardy manner in which the American mail is delivered in London and Paris each time the Boston steamer stops at Cork, has very justly excited loud reclamations in both these cities. When the steamers went directly to Liverpool, the mail was always, on a normal passage, delivered in London on Mon day and in Paris on Tuesday.

Whether the good St. Valentine was a burly bishop, or but a simple priest, still remains an open question; but all the world is agreed, we believd, that he was a kind and gentle saint as ever lived, and for his many deeds of love and charity became the unconscious patron of emotions which we are unfortunately bound to believe his own ascetic heart was never suffered to indulge.

The Senate yesterday, by an almost unanimous vote, passed the bill introduced by Mr. GWIN, entirely abolishing the franking privilege. Various amendments were offered, but the, determination of Senators was evident either to have total abolition or nothing. The fate of the bill in the House is regarded at Washington as doubtful.

The British Government sent a dispatch expressing satisfaction at this assurance.

About 5 o'clock yesterday morning a fire was discovered on board the Endymion, lying in the river, between Egremont and New-Brighton, ready for sea, and intending to have sailed on the same day for New-York. The greatest consternation prevailed on board, for, in addition to the crew, numbering 30, there were about 25 second-cabin passengers, many of whom were in their berths.

TRIAL TRIP OF STEAMER R.R. CUYLER.--This new steamer, belonging to Cromwell's Line, went on a trial trip yesterday, having a large party of invited guests aboard. The heavy northeast snow-storm Which commenced about noon, interfered greatly with the pleasure of the excursion. The Cuyler was built by SAMUEL SNIDEN after the most approved models, and is 230 feet long, 33 wide and 16 deep.

Mr. ADAMS, of Kentucky, (American,) presented the petition of the delegate from Jefferson and the memorial of the Provisional Government of that Territory, asking that he be recognized as such. Also, a memorial authorizing the inhabitants thereof to call a Convention and form a Constitution preliminary to admission into the Union. Referred to the Committee on Territories.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC. A very excellent performance of "Der Freischutz" was given last night. The attendance was bad, owing partly to the weather and to the fact that an American audience does not care about this opera.

A message was received from the President announcing that he had signed the Post-office Appropriation bill.
The Democratic State Convention assembled here to-day, and temporarily organized by the choice of Mr. PAYNE, of Fauquier, Chairman, which is a triumph for the friends of HENRY A. WISE.

Mr. TUCKER gave his concluding lecture on English Agriculture this morning. He discoursed more particularly, to-day, on the different breeds of stock in England, the implements used there, the high system of manuring they adopt, and on drainage.

The telegraphic report from New-Orleans, stating that MIRAMON had left the City of Mexico with five thousand men, to attack the city of Vera Cruz, and that the advanced guard of his army had reached the National Bridge, is untrue. This whole report is bogus.

Dr. Breda, of Natchitoches Parish, La., has devoted much time to experiment with grapes. Following Mr. GOLD came Prof. SILLIMAN on "Meteorology." As I have given no report of this gentleman's first lecture, I will briefly allude to it here. His subject related chiefly to temperature, and his time was mostly occupied in showing us on what its condition depends, and in describing the two instruments, the thermometer and the hygrometer.

In the TIMES of Saturday, the 25th, was an article upon Senator BRODERICK, filling nearly three columns. "A Layman," in the TIMES of the 22d, has indulged himself in discoursing on the poverty of the country clergy of New-England, and the remedy for such a sad condition. He says they have an "air of poverty," their "homes are uncomfortable," their "children are ill-clad and ill-bred," their "wives pale, weary-looking and hard-worked." The remedy which he proposes for this doleful state of things is CELIBACY.

Our correspondents with the United States Squadron on the African coast furnish us highly interesting details regarding the present condition of the Slave-trade. The advices extend to Dec. 20. The season at the Academy of Music came to a triumphant close on Saturday, when the last Patti matinee filled the building from pit to dome. The performances--although not at all what was announced--gave general satisfaction. COLSON and STIGELLI car ried off the honors of the principal piece--"Ernani"--and PATTI and BEIGNOLI sang deliciously in an act of "Martha." The company opens to-night in Philadelphia, and will not probably return to the City until Easter Monday.

WASHINGTON, Monday, March 5. Mr. MILLSON, of Virginia, (Dem.,)was unwilling that the House should seem to be indifferent to a usage coeval with our Government, and dignified by so many historical recollections. He therefore offered a resolution providing for the election of a Chaplain to-morrow, to officiate alternately with the Chaplain already elected by the Senate.

LONDON, Friday, Feb. 17, 1860. John Bull can talk about nothing save the Treaty and the Budget at present, and well he may, considering that not only are John's comforts and luxuries concerned in their precious concoctions, but also his safety and his very existence.

Hon. K. RAYNER publishes a letter in the North Carolina Standard, correcting some errors in a report of his speech, and taking occasion to say that he is in favor of resisting the continued domination of the Democratic Party without compromise or conciliation, and that he would as soon "trust his slave-property to the Republican Party as to the Democratic Party as a political organization."

QUEBEC, Tuesday, Feb. 28, 1860. The Provincial Parliament was opened this day by His Excellency in person. There was the usual banging of guns, cheering by the mob, parade of military, ascent of the throne in the Upper House, summoning of the Commons, rush of the last-named to the bar of the "Lords," bowing and scraping of all the officials, , , ad libitum.

MOLOY'S STATION, Monday, March 5. The California Overland Mail stage, with regular San Francisco dates to the 13th, and telegraphic advices to the evening of the 14th February, passed this station about noon to-day.
ANNAPOLIS, Tuesday, Feb. 28, 1860--10 P.M. I am now writing in the State Library Hall. A Democratic Caucus is in session below in the Chamber of the House of Delegates.

A movement was made yesterday in the House of Representatives, towards investigating charges of improper Executive conduct in various branches of the public service. A Committee was asked to inquire into the manner in which public duties had been performed, and the public interests protected, in various localities.

The Board of Councilmen last evening directed the Committee on Repairs and Supplies to report whether it would be more economical to heat the City Hall with steam than with wood and coal, as at present.

The examination of WOOD, MURPHY, MURRAY, PERRY and BUCKLEY, was continued on Saturday before Justice NEWHALL of Lynn, and the government having finished its case, a large number of witnesses were called for the defence. Their testimony was to the-effect that the parties were seen at times to do all in their power to preserve order, and that they appeared far from being desirous of inciting a riot. No decision was reached.

In the supreme Court this afternoon, the three Commissioners of Alleghany County--JOHN S. McLLHENNEY, ZACCHEUS PATTERSON and JONATHAN BEAEFY-- were presented in the custody of the Sheriff of Alleghany County. They were severely interrogated whether they stood by the return made by them to a writ of mandamus, refusing to obey the order of the Court. Each answered that he stood by the return.

A new steamboat, named the Alfred Thomas, which had been built at Easton, to ply between Belvidere, New-Jersey, and Port Jervis, set out from Easton in the morning, to ascend the stream. KEEPERS OF DISORDERLY HOUSES SENTENCED. Hermann Krall, a First-Ward politician, was in dicted for keeping a notoriously disorderly house, at No. 158 Greenwich-street. The profit of the house are said to amount to $300 per week. He Pleased guilty. Judge RUSSELL fined him $100, and discharged him. The fine was ready, and was immediately handed to the Clerk of the Court.

The German Turners gave a public exhibition yesterday, intended to show the practical use which can be made of certain descriptions of apparatus for saving life and property at fires. The place selected for the purpose was their Gymnasium in Orchardstreet, and the hour 4 o'clock P.M. A large crowd witnessed the experiments, testifying their admiration by shouts of applause at the successful termination of each feat.

The steamship Cahawba arrived yesterday morning from New-Orleans and Havana, having left the latter port on the 1st inst. She brings, on freight, $100,000 in Mexican silver from New-Orleans.

A trial took place yesterday afternoon before Justice STANTON and a Jury, at HENKLE'S lager-bier saloon, No, 144 Newark-avenue, Jersey City, at which there were some revelations as to the manner in which speculations are carried on in the interment of the dead, by which a small plot of ground is made to yield large revenues by a system of tenement graves.
ALBANY, Tuesday, March 6, 1860. The Senate had no quorum yesterday forenoon, so the few that were on hand took a recess until evening.

The North Atlantic Company's steamship Atlantic, R. H. PEARSON, Esq., Commander, left Aspinwall at 8:40 P. M. on the 3d of March, with 337 passengers and $1,198,711 in treasure, and arrived at New-York at 12 M. yesterday, making the passage in 7 days 15 hours.

The proposal to amend the Constitution for the purpose of reorganizing the Court of Appeals, and at the same time increasing the salaries of the Judges already in office, met with a decided rebuff in the Senate on Friday, by the passage of a resolution, by a large majority, postponing its further consideration to the 2d of April next.

The prospects of the Mexican treaty appear more favorable, and several prominent Senators give it as their opinion that it will be ratified. After the documents last called for are printed and distributed, it is understood that secrecy will be removed and the treaty discussed in open Senate.

The State Comptroller has sent a communication to the Legislature on the condition and prospects of the State Treasury. The picture which he presents is not very cheerful. The total amount of money which is to be raised by tax for the service of the year, is $5,470,000, or three mills and seven-eighths of a mill upon every dollar of property in the State.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Saturday, March 10. The Republican State Convention assembled at Mercantile Library Hall yesterday afternoon. B. GRATZ BROWN called the Convention to order and was afterward chosen President. The attendance was very small, less than 200 being present. But one County in the State sent regularly-elected delegates.

Joel Wolfe vs. The Supervisors of Richmond County.--This action was brought to recover damages from the County of Richmond for plaintiff's property destroyed by the mob in the Staten Island Riots. The suit was brought under a statute passed la 1855, providing that any city or county shall be liable to an action for any damages sustained by acts of a mob.

The Royal Mail steamship America, from Liverpool at 10 A.M. Saturday, the 25th ult., vid Queenstown 27th, arrived at Halifax at 1 A.M. of the 12th inst., and sailed at 6 A.M. for Boston, where she will be due on Tuesday afternoon.

Mr. HYATT again figured before the Senate today, and proceedings were interesting. In the general view of the subject, the Senate was nearly unanimous in maintaining its constitutional power to compel the attendance of witnesses and the consequent power to compel them to testify. Mr. DOOLITTLE conceded it to be vitally important that this power should not be disclaimed as requested by HYATT.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, January, 1800. The Planters of Jamaica constitute no longer the over-ruling oligarchy, or "Plantocracy," that they once actually were, and are still somewhat insolently designated in the bitterness of party spirit Poverty may not have humbled their pride or changed their belief; in their own homes and on their own estates, and in public whenever an opportunity offers, they wage, under different guises the old war against free labor.

At the meeting of the Board of Supervisors yesterday afternoon, Mr. BLUNT offered are resolution calling upon the legal adviser of the Board to state whether the law passed April, 1857, making it the duty of the Clerk of the County to provide each Election District with stationery, , applies to all elections, general, charter and special, and whether the same are County charges.

The Joint Select Committee of the Legislature of Maine, appointed to investigate the defalcation of BENJAMIN D. PECK, late State Treasurer, has completed its report, which we find in the Boston papers of Saturday. The developments are extraordinary; the case involving not only the name of Mr. PECK, but those of NEAL DOW, DANIEL E. SOMES, member of Congress from the First District of Maine, and other prominent men in the State.

Various law projects, destined to work important changes in the civil administration of England, will be brought before Parliament in the course of this session. The opening speech of the Queen has already announced them; works exchanged in the House of Lords on Tuesday last give us reason to hope that they will this time be submitted to debate, and perhaps disposed of.

Vandervoort vs. Gould.--This is an action now on trial before Justice BONNEY, of the Supreme Court, at Circuit, and is brought to obtain possession of certain real property, on the southerly side of Eighthstreet, in this City, which it is alleged is wrongfully withheld from the plaintiff by the defendant.

On motion of Mr. J.M. MURPHY, of this City, the Senate of New-York on the 3d inst. adopted a preamble and resolutions calling upon the Commissioners of the Central Park (who had already handed in to the Legislature a remarkably clear and detailed report of their proceedings and their plans) to reply to a series of questions on the matter of their trust.

The New-York Tribune, in a recent number, commenting somewhat severely upon the failure of Western investments, alludes in terms of condemnation to a bill recently introduced into the Legislature of this State to abolish all laws for the collection of debts. The Tribune very justly denounces the policy of such a law, especially if retroactive.

On the occasion of a missionary meeting, a large audience assembled in the Church of the Incarnation, Madison-square, Sunday evening. Rev. Messrs. MONTGOMERY, CHAUNCAY, DENNISTON, Bishop PAYNE, and in the latter part of the service, Dr. TYNG, occupied seats in the chancel, and participated in the exercises.

Alderman RICHARD BARRY, indicted for an assault and battery on PHILIP WOLFE, with intent to kill, (technically termed a "felonious assault and battery,") pleaded guilty to simple assault only in the Court of General Sessions, before Recorder BARNARD, on Oct. 4, 1858. The indictment was found by the Grand Jury when PETER B. SWEENY was District-Attorney.

Who the deuce is "Glaucus?" Who's the man that's treading on my toes again, and writing newspaper letters from here for the TIMES? Has he no more creditable occupation?--and he don't content himself with the heavy topics of the day, the "feeling in sugar," the shade higher or lower in flour and reviews of the market, but he must needs trespass upon my preserves, and he really seems determined to be funny.

"Were you at Madame B--'s ball last night?" "Were you in masquerade at the Borghese Palace, on the first night of the Carnival?" "Were you nearly smashed in the brilliant crowd at the last ball given by the wife of the Gonfaleniere, at the Palace of the Croeetta?" Such are the inquiries made by gay people of each other at the Cascine and other places of daily reunion.

The Board of Fire Commissioners of Baltimore in their Annual Report, recently submitted to the Corporation of that city, set forth that during the past year they have fully organized the paid Fire Department, in accordance with the ordinances of the Common Council, with economy and efficiency, and without interference to any considerable extent on the part of members of the volunteer Department.

Judge COLLAMER, of Vermont, made a very able speech upon the Slavery question in the Senate of the United States a few days since. It was marked by historical research, logical ability and excellent temper. In the course of it he said that the Republican Party propose to restore the Missouri Compromise line.

The first of a series of lectures on Egypt, its Antiquities and History, was delivered last evening in the Hall of the New-York Historical Society, by WH. C. PRIME, Esq. The audience was exceedingly large, and not more large than fashionable. The seats overflowed into the aisles, so that the Hail was but one compact mass of interested and applauding listeners.

A writer in the Savannah Republican makes an announcement, which will, doubtless, shock if not prostrate the manufacturing interests of the North. The students and soldiers of South Carolina have resolved to discard every article of apparel of Northern make. Minerva and Juno are to be arrayed in Carolina homespun ...

The steamer Ondine, from Dublin to London, came in collision with the schooner Heroine, off Beechey Head, about 1 o'clock on Sunday morning, Feb. 19. In twenty minutes no traces of her were left. Twenty one passengers and crew were saved in the jollyboat, about 30 went down in the steamer, and the captain, with 20 others, were lost in a life-boat.

The People vs. Frank Fowler.--This was an appeal by the defendant from a conviction at the Oyer and Terminer. The prisoner was indicted, together with John Gilbert, for obtaining money on false protences from one Christian Heine, by selling him a bogus ticket for a pasage to Bremen by the steamship Ammonia.

London, Thursday, March 1. The Daily New's City article says the funds ad vanced 1/8 this morning, in answer to a rise of cent. at Paris yesterday. A relapse followed, but at the close the market was again steady at an improvement of 1/8 cent.

PORTLAND, Me., Tuesday, March 13. The steamship North American arrived here at 5 o'clock this afternoon. She left Liverpool simultaneously with the stemship City of Baltimore, at noon on the 29th of February, touching at Queenstown the next day.

The North American, having left Liverpool Feb. 29, and Queenstown, March 1, has brought to Portland news from Europe four days later than previous advices. The reported loss of the American ship Luna is confirmed. Of 107 persons on board, but two reached the shore, and one of the two died shortly after. A tremendous gale had again visited the British coast, doing much damage to shipping, ...

The vote in the Senate, to-day, making th Homestead bill the special order for Thursday, is regarded by some as indicative of its strength before that body. But I know such not to be the fact. Several Senators who voted to make it the special order will vote ultimately against the bill. Its passage would prove ruinous to those who have been speculating in land warrants.

LAURA KEENE'S THEATRE.--Mr. BOURCICAULT'S new three-act piece called " Vanity Fair" was produced here on Monday night. The scene, although laid in Paris, might as well be in NewYork, and the two words " Vanity Fair" convey closely ...

THE REFORM BILL. Lord J. RUSSELL will introduce the ministerial measure to-night. The Daily News believes that besides the English Reform bill, the leading provisions of Irish and Scotch Reform bills, if not the bills themselves, will be laid before the House of Commons this evening.

PETRIE, which sailed from Liverpool at noon on the 29th of February, simultaneously with the North American, and touched at Queenstown on the following day, arrived here yesterday morning. Mr. FOSTER presented to the Senate yesterday, petitions signed by the leading manufacturers of Connecticut, asking that the tariff law might be so amended that their interests should be more ef- fectually protected. A bill to amend the act regulating the carriage of passengers in steamships and other vessels, was reported by Mr.BAYARD, who urged immediate action, on the ground that the decency and morality of the country were involved.

CONGRESSIONAL. The proceedings of Congress to-day were with- out any special interest. Commissioner GREENWOOD was called before the Committee on Indian Affairs, to give information touching the contemplated change in the Indian policy of the Government; also, to advise respecting the large amount of indemnity claimed for Indian spoliations, the bulk of which the Committee believe to be bogus.
Mr. TEN EYCK, of New-Jersey, (Rep.,) presented a petition of 103 citizens of New-York and New-Jersey, praying for the passage of the Homestead bill.

In advance of the action of Conventions, the position of parties can be determined only by watching the drift of public sentiment. Judged by this standard, the Democrats of the South seem more and more inclined to repudiate Judge DOUGLAS, and to insist upon their own Pro-Slavery programme, pure et simple, as the basis of their action in the coming contest.
The steamship Circassian, from Galway on the 3d inst., arrived here this forenoon. The Circassian's dates are two days later than those already received.

The Cunard steamer Australasian, probably the largest screw-steamer afloat, unless the Great Eastern be considered as belonging to this class, arrived at this port on Wednesday from Liverpool, with a heavy cargo of valuable merchandise. She was built in 1857, at Glasgow, by Messrs. J. G. THOMSON, for the Australian matl contract service. After a most successful rial trip to Alexandria, she made the voyage to Australia, carrying the mail down the Red Sea.

The regular meeting of this Board took place last evening at 5 P.M. Councilman LENT appeared and took the place of Councilman BAKER, who vacated his seat not only by a vote of the Board, but by a decision from a high legal tribunal, which declared him an alien at the time of his election.

The reported receipts of the principal kinds of Produce since our last, have been: 27 bbls. Ashes, 2,235 bbls. Flour, 18,560 bushels Corn, 366 bushels Rye, 715 bushels Oats, 600 bushels Malt, 1585 packages Provisions, and 364 bbls. Whisky.

The bill for the location of the Schuyler countyseat at Havana was before the Senate Committee today. It will be favorably reported, and seems certain to pass the Senate. A test vote, taken on Mr. ROBINSON'S motion of reference, shows a majority for the bill; the Democratic Senators, although voting against the reference, favor the passage of the bill, in the belief that it will aid them politically in the county.

The old adage of "give an inch and take an ell" is daily verified in this department. The ordinance regulating the construction of vaults in front of stores and dwelling-houses limits them to the outer edge of the sidewalk, except by special permission from the Croton Department, and this on payment of a speci- fied fee for the permission.
The House held a special session last evening, to consider the bill granting aid to the Albany and Susquehanna Railroad Company.

I have been in this ancient capital since Monday last. It has been quite a stormy and excited week. The legislative session closes to night at 12 o'clock, when, by the Constitution, an adjournment must take place sine die. Never before in the history of our State has there been so strong an outside pressure.

Mr. HICKMAN has reported a resolution in the House of Representatives instructing "the Committee on the Judiciary to inquire and report what legislation, if any, is necessary to give protection to citizens from one State going into another, to engage in private and lawful business, and that they report by bill or otherwise."

IMPORTANT TO CHUCH-GOERS.?In the City Hall Park, yesterday morning, an inventive genius had on exhibition a contrivance for the benefit of those hard of hearing, which attracted the attention of the evercurious crowd. The instrument was nothing less than a great reservoir for the collection of sound, connected with a series of distributing pipes for conveying to many different ears at once.
The steamer North Star arrived at this port yesterday morning from Aspinwall, via Havana, with 392 passengers and $152,000 in specie.

Most men, when going to sleep, take off the covering they wore in the day-time, and then tuck in the bed-clothes around the neck, which becoming too warm, gets open or thrown off; and the next day these people are trying in vain to remember when they were impatient. The ounce of prevention, which is worth more than a pound of cure, is to tie a handkerchief around the neck before going to sleep.

The grave and imposing demonstrations which have taken place in every city during the month of January against Austrian domination have determined the Cabinet of Vienna to invest the police with more power, in order that this agitation may be checked by all means, not excluding force, arbitrary punishment, deportation or terror.

Two mothers and their eight children--in all ten human beings--were burned to death yesterday morning, in one of a row of tenement-houses in West Forty-fifth-street. The fire is believed to have been the work of an incendiary, because when first discovered it was confined entirely to the stairway of the house, No. 90, in which six families resided.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Thursday, March, 22, 1860. The intestine Democratic war goes on. Our Buchaniers vow they will not be overpowered by the "Douglas squad." Headed by their ponderous chieftain, the "sound, conservative, cool-headed" ExSecretary, they will crush out and extirpate the treacherous and rebellions Douglasism on Kentucky soil.

CITY HOTEL, PROVIDENCE, R.I., Tuesday, March 27, 1860. Little Rhody is in a flutter, and well she may be. In common with her sister Connecticut, she is attracting the attention of the whole confederacy. All eyes turn anxiously hitherward, waiting, fearing, hoping for the result of the election which is to be held on the 4th of April next.

PARIS, Sunday, March 11--6 P.M. The monthly account published by the Directors of the Bank of France on Thursday last, shows a continued falling off in commercial affairs. The commercial bills discounted have diminished by 29,000,000 frances, showing that merchants and manufacturers are suspending their operations. The credit side of the accounts current has increased by 21,000,000...
The screw steamship City of Washington, Capt. JEFFREY, which sailed from Liverpool at noon on the 14th March, and from Queenstown on the following day, arrived here at 9 o'clock yesterday morning.

To the resignation of Dr. GREEN, late Professor of Theory and Practice in the New-York Medical College, we learn is to be added that of Professors PEASLEE and FLINT. Drs. CAENOCHAN, DAVIS and DOREMUS remain, and will, it is supposed, speedily constitute a new Board by supplying these vacancies, and forming several new Assistant Professorships on collateral and special subjects. Several, gentlemen are spoken of as successors to the various honorable responsible situations.

ST. LOUIS, Thursday, March 22, 1860. Gov. STEWART, of Missouri--more familiarly known as BOB STEWART--is an oddity of the first water. Possessing abilities more than respectable, he has, by protracted and open drunkenness and notorious ribaldry and obscenity, made his Gubernatorial career a disgrace to himself and a reproach upon the State.

As the session of our Legislature draws to a close, bills involving money are pushed rapidly forward. Yesterday the whole batch of our City Railroad bills were ordered to a third reading. The Protestant Communions of Hungary have again formally rejected the ecclesiastical constitution assigned them in the Imperial decree of the 1st of September last, and they as persistently as justly demand the reestablishment of the historical basis of their Church. This was to be foreseen, the reestabishment of amity between Hungary and Austria has for some time seemed a thing quite impracticable.

RENTON, Wednesday, March 28. The Democractic State Convention met at 11 o'clock for the choice of delegates to Charleston. There was a large representation. ANDREW DUTCHNE was appointed temporary Chairman. Adjourned to 2 o'clock.

Petitions in favor of the House Homestead bill and of a uniform bankrupt law were presented to the Senate yesterday. The Navy Pay bill was so amended that Captains at sea should receive a salary of $4,000; those who were waiting orders and are on leave, $3,000, and those discharging other duties $3,600. After some other unimportant amendments the bill was read a third time and passed.

Soon after dark last evening, a well-dressed young man, named Thomas Newell, attempted to pass a three-dollar counterfeit bill on the Exchange Bank of Hartford, Conn., at the store corner of Ninthavenue and Fiftieth-street, but the proprietor refused to accept it; and after Newell left, the circumstance was made known to Officer Tompkins, of the Twenty-second Ward, who immediately went in pursuit of the supposed forger.

The State Senate yesterday ordered to a third reading a bill locating our City Hall on Madison-square! To-day they will probably order the Post-office to be placed on the Central Park, and to-morrow the Battery will be legislated to Macomb's Dam. The prisoner was taken from the Tombs into the presence of Mr. WHITE, the Commissioner, by officers D'Angelis and Duggan, and on the way conversed with them quite coolly and freely.

The Secretary of War to-day sent a communication to the Military Committee of the House, recommending the raising of a regiment of Texas mounted volunteers. He would have done so earlier, but was hesitating between that and a new regiment of cavalry. He now thinks the latter would cause too great delay, and recommends the former, which can be raised and put in the field in thirty days.
The Overland Mail Coach, with regular San Francisco dates to March 9, and telegraphic advices to the 10th, arrived here at 3 o'clock this morning.

The Police bill was up in the Senate last evening, by a special vote. Senator SPINOLA pitched into it vigorously, citing as arguments against the bill, quotations from the report made by himself to the last Senate, and extracts from the New-York Tribune, in about equal proportions.

The New-York and New-Haven Railroad Company vs. Schuyler et al. In this case Wm. Curtis Noyes now offered to put in evidence the whole of the transfer books of the Company in the New-york office, which was objected to by nearly all the opposing counsel, for as many different reasons as there were counsel.

The Chair laid before the Senate a message from the President in reply to a resolution of inquiry relative to the operations of the navy in Mexico, and the authority therefor. Ordered to lay on the table and be Printed.

LONDON MONEY MARKET. The demand for MONEY continued active, and in the open market business could not be done below 4 cent. It was thought that the market would continue tight until the payment of the April dividends.

In the House of Commons, on the 14th March, a bill, having for its object the extension of the ecclesiastical liberty of clergymen of the Church of England to the extent enjoyed by non-conformists, was debated and rejected by a vote of 168 to 131.
The following bills were passed: To incorporate the Board of Foreign Missions of the Reformed Protestant Dutch Church.
I have no important news; the town and Islands are quiet. The Spanish regiments have all left for Morocco, and the town is now garrisoned by militia.

Mr. BUCHANAN is so terribly hurt by the pro- posal to institute an inquiry into the general administration of the Government by means of a Committee of the House of Representatives, that he has indited the lamentable epistle which we published yesterday. All who have read that remarkable production will feel that this is the strongest language we could possibly use with regard to it.

THE RECIPROCITY TREATY. Petitions from all parts of New-York are pouring in, praying that the Reciprocity Treaty with Canada may be amended or rescinded. Hostility to it is daily growing more bitter, so ruinous is it to the interests of Western New-York. Mr. HATCH'S report will not only be strongly condemnatory of the Treaty, but will urge that it be abrogated at the earliest possible day.

Express, March 27, has the following: "We learn from a friend residing in Burkeville, Nottoway County, that a most shocking and brutal murder was perpetrated within three-quarters of a mile of that place, on yesterday morning about 1 o'clock, the victim being HIRAM FOWLKES, Esq., and his murderers his own servants.

The execution of CRUMMINS yesterday will strengthen the growing disposition of the community to tolerate the abolition of capital pun- ishment. Almost everybody concedes that the deliberate murderer, one who kills in cold blood, from a distinct, well-defined motive, whether it be avarice or revenge, ought to be hung.
BY TELEGRAPH TO LIVERPOOL. PARIS, March 17. The Moniteur of to-day, in its report of the last sitting of the Legislative body, states that the election of M. DE LA FERRIERE has been annulled.

The examination of the Chinaman, "Jackaloo," charged with the murder of Jonathan and Josiah Leete, on board the sloop Spray, of Guilford, Conn., was resumed yesterday morning before United States Commissioner J.P. VROOM and Recorder BEDFORD, at Jersey City. The excitement was as great as ever, and the Court-room was filled during the greater part of the day.

In the House of Commons on the 16th, on the order for going in a Committee of Supply, Sir DE LACY EVANS, who had given notice of a series of resolutions on the subject of the expedition against China, drew attention to the vast armament which was to form that expedition, and which must cost, he said, an enormous sum of money, with little chance of its being repaid by the Imperial Government at Peking.

The total result of the voting in Tuscany on the question of annexation to Piedmont, was as follows: Total number inscribed, 386,446; for annexation, 366,571; for a separate kingdom, 14,925; canceled 4,949.

Jacob Wichelhausen vs. James C. Willett, Sheriff. This case has been several times mentioned in our columns. It is an action against the defendant, as Sheriff, for an escape under the following circumstances: The plaintiff recovered a judgment against one John D. Williamson, and issued execution against his person to the present defendant. The defendant arrested Williamson and held him in custody in the jail limits, on the usual bond.

THURSDAY EVENING, March 29, 1860. Mr. A.L. BOGART presented for the considera tion of the Institute a new gas-burner, which he claimed would save a large amount of gas, and yet give, while burning less gas, a better light.
The steamship Arabia, from Liverpool on the 17th inst., arrived at this port yesterday morning, bringing two days later news.

Dr. E.Y. ROBBINS delivered a lecture last week at Clinton Hall, before an appreciative audience, on the operations of air, light and costume upon the health of the female sex. He advocated the improvement of woman's health as a certain means of improving the race. He found a great deal of fault with the costume of the ladies.

The great question of the Court dress of American Ministers is about to be brought up again, by the presentation to Congress by the President of all correspondence in the possession of the Government touching this weighty matter, from the treaty of Ghent to the present time. It is produced in obedience to a call of the Senate, and will probably furnish materials for a debate to that not very much overtasked body.

WILLIAM CURTIS NOYES, Esq., delivered the last lecture before the Columbia College Law School, on Tuesday evening. His subject was "The Law Regulating the Enjoyment and Use of Light."

In consequence of some dissatisfaction at the management of the Medical Department of Bowdoin College, Edward R. Peaslee, Professor of Surgery, and Charles A. Lee, Professor of Materia Medica, have resigned their Professorships, and it is stated, upon good authority, that Prof. William Sweeter will resign his office at the expiration of the present term. An effort is to be made, as matters now stand, to remove the school to Portland, which may be successful.

The Board of Excise Commissioners vs. Patrick White. This was an application on the part of counsel for defendant, before Judge HILTON, at the Special Term of the Common Pleas, to have the case of the defendant taken out of the hands of the counsel to the Excise Commissioners, Mr. Holmes, who is represented by Mr. Mckeog, his attorney, and to have it placed under the control of the Law Department of the City.

We have already expressed the opinion that CRIMMINS, who was hung on Friday, did not deserve his fate; and that Gov. MORGAN, by refusing to commute his sentence, or even to postpone its execution, had sacrificed justice to his own reputation for firmness and consistency. The circumstances of his refusal confirm this conviction.

The election in Connecticut takes place today. It is an important contest, and efforts have been made by both political parties corresponding to the extreme interest felt in the result. The whole State has been canvassed with a degree of vigor, activity and enthusiasm seldom evinced in any State contest.

A fire in Brighton on Saturday night destroyed the lumber-yard and contents of J.H. FULLER SON, whose loss is $20,000, on which there is $9,000 insurance; one dwelling and two stores, owned by E. SPARHAWK, loss $7,000, no insurance; the grocery of SALMON, KENDALL Co., loss $7,000, insured $5,000, and two buildings, owned by CEPHAS BRACKETT, loss $6,000, insured $3,000. The fire was the work of an incendiary.

NEW-YORK, Saturday, March 31, 1860 6 P.M. The reported receipts of the principal kinds of Produce since our last have been: 1 bbl, Ashes, 1,089 bbls. Flour, 10,249 bushels Corn, 1,867 bushels Oats, 158 pkgs, Provisions, and 229 bbls. Whisky.
An extra of the Brownsville Flag, March 18, gives the particulars of the invasion of Mexican territory by a force of Rangers in pursuit of CORTINA. The Flag says:

To say that Lord JOHN RUSSELL'S new Reform bill does not meet with general approbation in England, is not saying much in condemnation of it. No Reform bill since 1832 has ever been received by either Parliament or the public with anything approaching to acclamation, and the best thing which the general verdict has ever said of any of them has been, that it might have been worse.

PATRICK ROAKE, aged 21 years, was shipped as seaman last Saturday, on the ship Niagara, now lying off the Battery, but about to depart for New-Orleans, going on board while intoxicated, he first threatened the lives of the officers of the vessel; then entering the forecastle, he shot himself in the neck with a pistol, inflicting a wound which immediately resulted fatally. Coroner JACKMAN was summoned to hold an inquest.

Se or BARANDIARAN is in possession of late dispatches from the Miramon Party, which state that Gen. ROBLES was wounded, but not seriously, during the last day's attack on Vera Cruz. MIRAMON attributes his defeat to the interference of the American forces with his steamers.

Sniffen vs. McNeil. This suit was brought in the Common Pleas, and came before Judge BRADY at Special Term lately, on an appeal from a taxation of costs by the clerk. The question was whether a witness who had attended court from day to day, to testify on the trial, returning home at night, was entitled to traveling expenses for each journey made.
Sellers vs. Berdan This was an application to compel defendant to disclose patents alleged to havfe been obtained by him, and was made before Judge HILTON at the Special Term of the Common Pleas.

The steamer Habana, from Havana 30th ult., has arrived. The markets are unchanged. The excitement about the captured steamers continued.

DEATH OF MURPHY, THE BURGLAR--CHARGES MURPHY, the young man who some six weeks ago, in company with one BEENOWSKI, a Pole, broke into the warehouse No. 540 Pearl-street, and jumped from the roof of the building in his effort to escape from the officers who had discovered him, died yesterday morning at the New-York Hospital, in conse quence of the injuries he then sustained.
ST. JOHNS, N.F., Monday, April 2. Messages for Europe to go forward per steam ship Circassion to Galway can be filed at No.21 Wallstreet to-day, and up to noon to-morrow.

EXPLOSION AT THE TUNNEL--JOSEPH HARNDEN, one of the workmen at the tunnel, yesterday morning went to the powder chest, in which there were two kegs of powder with the heads out, for the purpose of obtaining a supply for blasting purposes.

MARTIN DORSCHER, a young German laborer, employed by a gardener named JOHN MILLER, was driving with a load of manure down a steep hill in Broadway, near One Hundred and Twentieth street last Saturday, when his horse becoming restive, he determined to detach him from the vehicle and allow it to roll down the hill of itself.

POLITICAL--The charter election, which takes place to-day, bids fair to be an exciting one, and doubtless a respectable vote will be polled. There are three "department" offices to be filled, viz.: Collector of Taxes and Assessments, Street Commissioner, and Commissioner of Repairs and Supplies. For these offices there are four tickets in the field
MELOY'S STATION, Sunday, April 1. The Overland Mail coach, with San Francisco dates to March 11, arrived at this station at about 12 o'clock last night.
BOSTON, Monday, April 2. MORGAN, CHAMBERLAIN and DUNNING, late officers of the bark Orion, an alleged slaver, are held in $5,000 each for trial. The examination will probably take place to-morrow.

HARRISBURG, PA., Monday, April 2. The Legislature will adjourn sine die to-morrow. Both Houses are still in session hurrying through the consideration of the calendar. The Committee of Conference on the Sunbury and Erie Railroad bill reported it in an amended form, postponing all foreclosure claims.

WASHINGTON, Monday, April 2. INDIAN AFFAIRS. The annuity goods for the Indians in the Eastern District of Washington Territory will be dispatched over Lieut. MULLAN'S new wagon road, and distributed at Hellgate.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Saturday, March 31, 1860. The excitement increases; day succeeds day excitement follows excitement; money flows like water; liquor flows like money party bitterness grows more and more rancorous; partisans abuse and vilify in every conceivable manner the candidates of opposing parties, and the whole community, from Westerley to Providence, and from Woonsocket to Newport, is in a universal hubbub and tumoil.

-The Board of Su pervisors yesterday again refused to pay Mayor WOOD'S bills for advertising the ordinances and resolutions awaiting his approval. This is perfectly right and proper. There is no law authorizing any such publication on his part, and he has no more right to expend money in this way than in any other.

ALBANY, Monday, April 2. The Attorney-General's communication further argues against the constitutionality of the bill repealing the tolls on railroads, on the ground that it diverts the public revenues for the benefit of private corporations.

After having been locked up forty-two hours, the jury in the case of James Shepherd, on his second trial for murder and arson, came into Court yesterday morning and stated that they were still unable to agree, and that there was no prospect of a consummation so much to be desired; whereupon Judge RUSSELL dismissed them, and Shepherd was returned to the Tombs to be tried a third time on a speedy occasion.

ST. LOUIS, Sunday, April 1. Major WRIGHT closed his argument in the Car stang-Shaw case last evening. His speech occupied nearly eight hours in delivery, after which the jury retired, and in twenty minutes rendered a verdict for the defendant. Complete returns show the election of BUCKINGHAM, Republican, for Governor, by 571 majority. The Representatives stand 142 Republicans to 89 Democrats, and the Senators, 13 Republicans to 7 Democrats. One District is doubtful.

The Conference Committee of the Senate and Assembly on the Railroad Toll bill disagree. The Senate Committee offer various propositions, one of which is to raise the compensation for tolls to $1,300,000, and to remove the restrictions on the fare of the Central Road. The Assembly Committee decline this, and insist on their own bill imposing tolls, or on the repeal of the law removing the tolls.

The result of the Rhode Island election was not a Democratic victory, though it was a Republican defeat. If it shows that the Republicans are in a minority, it does not indicate that the Democrats have the majority in the State. Both parties will doutless draw more useful practical lessons from the issue, than an unqualified triumph for either would have inculeated.

George De Noir, alias George Smith, a prisoner on Blackwell's Island, yesterday concealed himself behind a wall in the stone quarry, just before the dinner hour, and when the keepers had gone away, emerging from his hiding-place, he entered a small boat which two of his former companions had in waiting for him, and was rowed down to Williamburgh, where the boat was abandoned.

One of the most inveterate traditions of our fathers was the immobility of Royalty. That the King should remain habitually within a certain radius of his capital, and never go beyond it, except for the purpose of making a solemn and formal visit to some loyal province, was with the latter sovereigns of the House of Hanover almost an article of faith.

WASHBURNE, of Illinois, entitled "An act to provide for the better security of the lives of passengers on board of vessels propelled in whole or in part by steam, and for other purposes." It has many excellent provisions, and some errors which render the bill almost worthless.

Mr. WASHBURN'S bill, before Congress, intended to promote comparative safety in that now most perilous of undertakings, going down to the sea in ships, is severely criticised for two reasons first, the proposed penalties in case of calamities are very severe; second, and chiefly, the limited number of psengers and the unlimited number of life-boats will materially curtail the profits of steamship owners.

George Dower, second mate of the packet ship Devonshire, was put on trial, charged with the murder of a seaman named Humphreys on board the ship While on her passage from this port to London.

A gentleman has just arrived here from Browns ville, Texas, whose statements corroborate those heretofore received in regard to the outrages perpetrated by CORTINAS and his band of marauders. He says there is no doubt but that CORTINAS is upheld and sustained in his operations by Mexicans who profess to be friendly to the United States.

"The results of the elections in Connecticut and Rhode Island have called out no rejoicing from either party in Washington. The pervading feeling there appears to be one of deep solemnity, in view of the mighty interests involved in the great contest to come off next Fall. I have never witnessed so little desire to trifle or make merry about anything.

The Philadelphia Inquirer says: "The two negro boys who were attempted to be sold by Capt. BRALEY, of the British schooner Alice Rogers, to a citizen of Hampton, were brought to Norfolk on Friday, together with the mate and crew of the schooner as witnesses, in the custody of DeputyMarshal NASH.

NEW-YORK RESCUING COMPANY PUBLIC EXHIBITION: A volunteer association with the above title, which has lately been started in this City for the purpose of saving life and property in case of fire, gave a public exhibition yesterday afternoon in the rear of No. 171 Christie-street.

A small party of Savoyard gentlemen have just settled the question which disquieted Europe. They have made NAPOLEON III, a present of their country. Who they are and what their position may be in their own country we are not told.

As boats' crews Nos. 1, 2 and 8 of the Harbor Police were returning, about 5 o'clock, yesterday afternoon, in the steamtug Magnolia from the Narrows, where they had been engaged in removing shad poles, their attention was attracted by a signal of distress on board the ship Ironsides, lying near Ellis' Island, and bound for St. Johns' New-Brunswick.

An inquest was held yesterday at the NewYork Hospital on the body of an aged Frenchman named JEAN BAPTISTE LA ROCHELLE, who died in consequence of shocking burns received on the 20th ult., while engaged in setting fire to the crockery store No. 233 Greenwich-street, occupied by the brothers DEDACE and CORNE MORRISSETT.

Mr. JOHN COCHRANE, of New-York, (Dem.,) introduced a bill for preventing the vessels of any Government, inclusive of those under subventions with any such Government, from carrying aught save bullion and specie, and neither passengers, letters nor freight for hire, under a penalty of seizure.

James Burkard et al. vs. L.O. Wilson et al. This was an action to remove Bates and Wilson, as assignees of the defendants, upon the allegation that they were not sufficiently responsible to act in such a capacity. The assignment was made on the 30th of June, 1858.

Mr.BROWN, of Mississippi, (Dem.,) presented the resolutions adopted at the meeting at Nashville, Oct. 10, 1859, in regard to the improvement of the navigation of the Mississippi River. Referred to the Committee on Commerce.

Mr. FOWLER, Postmaster of New-York, reached here this morning, and has made full and satisfactory explanations at the Post-office Department of the alleged deficit in his accounts. They have accordingly been adjusted and permanently settled.

When, in a nation or union of States, the elementary States, or sections, or races, of which the Union is composed, are to be represented in the General Government, not precisely per capita, nor by States, but by a fixed unit of population in each, it becomes one of the most interesting problems to know how time and growth have modified the political relations of States, races and sections.

The business in this Court, for this and the ensuing week, will consist of murder and manslaughter cases, to be tried before Judge EMOTT. Yesterday the District-Atrorney called on for trial the case of John Pfromer.

Mr. SUMNER, of Massachusetts, moved in the Senate yesterday a resolution calling upon the President for information in regard to the seizure of Mexican vessels in time of peace, and their disposition agreeably to the law of prizes applicable to a state of war. It was adopted. Notice was given by Mr.WILSON, of Massachusetts, of a bill to suppress the Slave-trade.

Tenders for five sewers, opened yesterday at the Croton Department, were awarded as follows: Sewer in Tenth-avenue, from Thirty-fifth to Thirtysixth street; four bids, of which Hugh McGrane was the lowest; surety, $1,000.

Young JOE SMITH has at length acceded to the proposal to take upon himself the place of his father in the Mormon Church, with a view to clear it of those enormities which in Utah are so disgracing to humanity. This day, at the Conference, he offered himself for acceptance as the Prophet, and was accepted.

STOLEN GOODS RECOVERED Officer COYLE, of the First Preeinct Police, at an early hour yesterday morning, discovered a man carrying a bundle on Fulton-street, under circumstances which excited his suspicions. He approached the man, who upon seeing the officer, dropped his bundle, and succeeded in escaping. In the bag was found a quantity of tools, which had just been stolen from the store of E.C. WOOD, No. 40 Fulton-street.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The sermon of Rev. Mr. CORBITT to "thieves and harlots" was a very good thing. He deserves credit for his effort to reach these unhappy classes, to save them from the terrible fate that inevitably awaits them unless they reform and repent.

The Senate closed the fillibustering on the Almshouse resolution this afternoon, by ordering the bill to be read a third time at 7 o'clock this evening. At that hour it was read, and the vote being taken, the resolution was lost-ayes 16, noes 13. Five Republicans voted in the negative. A motion to reconsider was made, and laid on the table. The bill will pass the Senate.

The defeat of the New-York Health bill in the Assembly causes more sadness than indignation among the reflecting portions of our community. Its object is so purely beneficent, the necessity for some measure of the kind is so pressing and imperative, and the lives of thousands of children during the approaching Summer depend so directly upon its enactment, that no one can regard its rejection without sorrow and profound regret.

The Secretary of the Treasury communicated to Senate yesterday the amount of revenue collected and the expenses thereof, together with the number of persons employed. In 1858, the revenue amounted to $42,542,287; the, expenses to $3,529,788. The number of employees was 3,041. In 1859, the revenue collected amounted to $49,353,439. Expenses $3,395,030. The employes numbered 2,972.

This handsome building is now nearly completed, the first coating of paint is dry, the floors are being laid, and on the 1st of May the stalls will be up, the butchers will be at work and the Seventh Regiment, before the 1st of June, will take possession of its new quarters, In dimensions this building is 181 feet nine inches long, by 100 feet wide.

Augustus Maverick and Ellen G. Maverick vs. The Eighth-avenue Railroad Company This is an action to recover from the defendants $10,000 damages, for injuries to the person of Ellen G. Maverick, wife of Augustus Maverick sustained in consequence of alleged negligence or willfulness on the part of the agents of the defendants, in charge of one of their cars.

The royal mail steamer Tyne, Capt. PEEK, with the mails from the Brazils, has arrived here and will leave this evening for Southampton. She brings 204 passengers and 7,000 in specie. M. BELADO has been elected President of Montevideo. No other political news.

The Royal Mail steamship Persia, Capt. JUDKINS, which sailed from Liverpool at about 2 P.M. on the 31st ult., and from Queenstown on the evening of the 1st inst., arrived here at 4 o'clock yesterday morning.

The Henry Clay Statue was inaugurated to-day. The ceremonies were very imposing, while the military display was the finest ever witnessed here. The crowd of strangers was immense. Mr. BARBOUR'S oration was a masterly tribute to Mr. CLAY. The statue is a beautiful work of art.

The New York East Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church is holding its twelfth Annual Session here, in the pretty little church that casts its shadow on the village green. It will be a protracted meeting; the hour of adjourament, I am told, will not come until a week or more has gone. There are more clergymen present than usual, and it is the Slavery question chiefly that has drawn so many together.

The unfortunate officers of the Brazilian corvette, Donna Isabel, are about to have " the hospitalities of the City " inflicted upon them. These gentlemen remained, we believe, for several days in the harbor without attracting the notice of the Common Council or any of our authorities. In an evil hour, however, they paid the Mayor the compliment of a visit at the City Hall, and thus revealed their presence to their tormentors.

Soon after 10 o'clock last night a fire was discovered in the lower part of the six-story brick building No. 244. Water-street, occupied by EPHRAIM TREADWELL a cracker and ship-bread bakery.

THE ADAMS' EXPRESS SALE. This sale was continued and closed yesterday, having afforded for two days a fund of amusement to hundreds who, having nothing of present importance to engage their attention, were glad to while away their time in watching the "fools who came there for bargains."
We have had a memorable twenty-four hours here-hours that have witnessed more extraordinary legislative results than were ever crowded into the same space.
The session opened yesterday morning, with the accustomed exercises. The Bishop finished the examinations of character, and declared all passed.
The Assembly took up the veto of the Governor on the West Washington Market bill, and passed the bill over the veto of the Governor by a vote of 73 to 29.

The annual session of the Troy Conference commenced at the Methodist Church in Lansingburgh on Wednesday morning last. The place of meeting is three miles north of this city, in a pleasant country town, where the members find hospitable treatment. The Conference embraces Troy, Albany, Western Massachusetts, Northern and Eastern NewYork. It is about 200 miles long and 50 wide, and numbers about 250 members.

Malvina T. Ray vs. Fowler M. Ray, Executor, , et al. This was an action by the plaintiff, who is the widow of Fowler M. Ray, Sen., deceased, for a judgment declaring the will of said Ray void, and annulling all proceedings had under it.

The Legislature devoted its last day to making laws, without the Governor's signature. The veto of the Susquehanna Railroad Subsidy reaching the Senate at its morning session. Mr. RAMSEY, of Schoharie, made a long and earnest speech in favor of the bill, when it was passed over the veto 16 to 8. It was subsequently lost in the Assembly.

The semi-annual session of the Presbytery of New-York (Old School) was continued yesterday in Dr. POTTS' Church, from 9 A.M. to 3 P.M. The principal business was the reception of verbal reports from the pastors and ruling elders of the different Churches.

The New-York East Conference held the last meeting of the present session to-day. The members assembled at 8 A.M., and at 10 o'clock adjourned till the afternoon. Very little business of interest was transacted.
ACADEMY OF MUSIC. BELLINI'S opera of " La Somnambula" will be played here to-night with Miss ADELINA PATTI the heroine, and the best male members of the troupe in the other characters.

A message was received from the President inclosing a communication from the Secretary of War, in reply to a resolution asking for information as to the seizure and impressment of naturalized citizens by foreign governments. The communication was not read, but was ordered to be printed.

Mr. SCHWARTZ, of Pennsylvania, (Anti-Lecompton Dem.,) offered a resolution which was read for information, instructing the Committee on Public Expenditures to report a bill reducing the compensation of members of Congress to $8 per diem for each day of actual service; and providing, also, that when both Houses, by joint resolution, adjourn to attend a political Convention, the members voting therefor shall not receive pay during the recess. [Laughter.]
The Republican State Convention met at Coriathian Hall at 11 o'clock this morning. The attendance was large, and embraced very many of the leading Republicans of the State.

A dispatch dated at Hertford, March 31, says: "This afternoon a warrant was granted to apprehend THOMAS SAYERS and JOHN C. HEENAN, in order that they night be bound over to keep the peace. It is understood that the warrant would be at once executed, and the parties required to find sureties to a heavy amount, as the magistrates are determined to prevent, if possible, the fight from coming off in Hertfordshire."
A dispatch from Vienna, under date of March 31, says:

The Conference was opened at the usual hour yesterday morning with singing, reading the scriptures and prayer by Rev. B.F. ADAMS. Further ballots for the election of delegates to the General Conference resulted in the choice of Rev. PAUL. R. BROWN and Rev. J.B. BEACH, (Progressive.) An election for two alternates resulted in the choice of Rev. L.M. VINCENT and Rev. L.H. KING.

From Chili there is but little of importance. The Government troops had severely chastised the Indians of Arauco in several encounters, until they had plead for peace. Four chiefs, whose tribes had submitted, had arrived at Santiago to negotiate a treaty with the Government, and are willing to aid it in bringing to terms the few refractory tribes that are yet ill-disposed.

NEW-JERSEY. Nothing new has transpired since the inquest on Tuesday night which tends to throw further light upon the mysterious murder of the unknown woman. Information has been received which tends to the belief that Miss KIRLEY, the Boston girl who was supposed to be the victim, is living with a family in Brooklyn.

The Arago, with dates from Southampton to April 4, arrived here last evening. Her news is of less than usual interest. A Congress of the Great Powers upon the questions of Italy and Savoy is now said to be determined upon.
The rumors concerning an approaching Ministerial modification have ceased.

By the arrival of the Quaker City, we have news from Havana to April 11.

Mr. CHARLES STEARNS, a man of wealth and position in Springfield, Mass., died recently in the Northampton Lunatic Asylum. He was a remarkable character, in various ways. By trade a mason, he became an active operator in real estate, and petted a mania for putting up houses. His invariable answer to applicants for tenements was, "I have none now, but I can build one immediately."

Count RECHBERG has communicated to M. STEIGER, Charge d'Affaires of Switzerland, the definitive reply of Austria to the protest against the annexation of Savoy, addressed by the Federal Council to the great Powers.

A large number of the New-York (Wood) delegates to the Democratic National Convention at Charleston left yesterday in the steamer Nashville, of SPOFFORD TILESTON'S line.
