Hon. ROBERT J. WALKER has at last published Mr. BUCHANAN'S celebrated letter to him, urging the submission of the Lecompton Constitution to the People of Kansas. We give this interesting document in another column of this morning's TIMES.

Joseph Woodruff, a young man who is well known in the Fifth Ward as a fireman, and whose brother is now a member of the State Legislature, called about 19 o'clock last evening at the house No. 101 Mercer-street, and suddenly, as is alleged, without any provocation, attempted to kill Josephine Wilson, a young woman with whom he had been conversing.

The Times' City Article of April 3, says: The English funds opened on Monday at a fresh lecune If one-eighth, but a rally occurred in the middle of the day, and was maintained to the close. The recovery was attributable to a slight improvement in the quotations from Paris.

In reply to the request addressed by Switzerland to the Powers who signed the Treaty of Vienna, Russia, England, Austria and Prussia have pronounced themselves in favor of the immediate assembling of a Congress.

In the House of Commons on the 3d inst., Lord JOHN RUSSELL brought up and laid upon the table further correspondence relating to theaffair's of Italy. The noble lord said: In laying these papers upon the table, I wish to state shortly and generally their contents, and also to explain what is the present state of affairs, as far as I can do so consistently with my public duty.

MRS. HOEY'S BENEFIT. This accomplished and deservedly popular actress, announces her benefit at Wallack's Theatre for Saturday evening. Mrs. HOEY took her benefit morally at the Academy of Music yesterday, when she generously came forward at the eleventh hour, to rescue the Dramatic Fund Association, suddenly left in the vocative by the failure of another leading actress to fulfill her engagement.
The Deficiency bill was taken up. Mr. HOUSTON, of Alabama, (Dem.,) demanded the Yeas and Nays on its passage.

The Paris correspondent of the Times says: "Public opinion in the financial and commercial world is greatly agitated by alternate hope and fear, in consequence of the uncertainty which prevails with respect to the future position of the country. The Government has made extraordinary efforts to restore confidence, but without success. Every commercial man admits the importance of Lord JOHN RUSSELL'S last speech on the annexation of Savoy and Nice to France."

President CASTILLA has resumed the Presidential chair, filled by Dr. MAR during his absence in Ecuador, and issued a preclamation, bragging of his exploits in that country, in which nobody was killed and the same number wounded, and concludes by threatening to undertake an equally brilliant campaign against Bolivia. I wrote you in my last that his Ministers had refused their assent to a war on Bolivia.

VERDICTS AGAINST RAILROAD COMPANIES. The jury in the case of LYDIA RILEY against the Brooklyn City Railroad Company, tried in the City Court yesterday, rendered a verdict in favor of plaintiff for $2,250. The action was brought to recover damages for injuries received by plaintiff, while leaving one of defendants' cars called "extras," at Bedford on the 1st of March last.

Is Slavery, after all, the greatest evil that afflicts this Republic? Is there no other danger looming on the political horizon, which good men should watch and guard against? Here, in this State of New-York, is there not some peril quite as great as that which grows out of the Lemmon Slave Case, and the effort of Virginia to bring Slavery into our borders?

This Court was occupied yesterday till a late hour. Charles W. Brown was tried on an indictment for forgery in the second degree, in attempting to pass counterfeit $5 bills on the Merrimack Bank, Massachusetts. The evidence was inconclusive, failing to show beyond a rational doubt that the defendant was aware of the spurious character of the bills. He was accordingly acquitted.

The excitement in Jersey City regarding the recent mysterious murder has greatly abated, but as the papers have carried the particulars to other places, persons have come from distant localities to view the heed of the unfortunate woman. Yesterday and daybefore the individuals from Philadelphia called at Dr. OZPOK'S residence fearing that they might be able to identify the remains. They were unable to do so however.

The reported receipts of the principal kinds of Prod- uce since our last have been: 56 bbls. Ashes, 6,171 bbls. Flour, 1,850 bushels Corn, 3,343 bushels Oats, 1,229 packages Provisions, and 446 bbls, Whisky.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.?An audience of nearly a thousand persons, comprising the elite of the musical public of New-York, assembled by invitation at the Academy yesterday morning to witness what we may call the tentative debut of a young lady of this City, who has been devoting the last three years to preparation for the career of a lyric artist.

The Democratic members of our State Legislature have issued an address to their constituents. It is prolix on the question of the Finances and the Canal Enlargement, and eloquent upon the subject of Negro suffrage.

A meeting of the Police Commissioners was held on Wednesday at the head-quarters in Broome-street, all the members present.

We are heartily rejoiced that the Covode inquisition have obtained possession of the private letter addressed by the President to Gov. WALKER on the 12th of July, 1857. Various rumors concerning the contents of this letter have been long in circulation, which will all be instantly dissipated by the perusal of the letter itself; and we take pleasure in laying it before our readers to-day.

Everybody is eagerly watching for the movements of the Democratic Convention at Charleston. Men of all parties look upon the nomination to be made there as deciding their own action. In the political game which is impending, the Democrats have the first move. When that has been made, the other parties will see more clearly the course which they must take.

The spacious and beautiful Church in Rutgersstreet was filled, on the evening of 15th inst., with the children of the Sunday School, and their parents and friends, celebrating the 24th anniversary of the Childrens' Missionary Society. The School consists of 400 children, nearly all of whom were present. Mr. CRAWFORD, of Georgia, (Dem.,) was satisfied that no quorum was present, and therefore moved to [adjourn till Tuesday. He was determined the House should transact no business without a quorum if there was power to enforce the rules.

A young man named JOHN SHOUFFER, residing in Dalton, Ohio, committed suicide by shooting himself through the head with a rifle. The only cause assigned for the rash act was, that he was in love with a young lady, but could not afford to get married. More instances are on record of men shooting themselves because they were married, than because they were not.

Application of the Rector and Vestrymen of St. Thomas' Church This application came on to be heard pursuant to notice. It is, as will be remembered, a petition of a number of the congregarion of St. Thomas' Church, located on the corner of Boardway and Houston street, for an order of the Court granting leave to the petitioners to sell the edifice and premises.

THAT LETTER AGAIN. The Covode Committee met again this morning, but did nothing. Mr. WINSLOW will submit to the House a protest against the manner in which the Committee possessed itself of the President's letter to Gov. WALKER.

At the Westminster Police Court Sir JAMES FEROUSSON, M.P. for Ayrshire, appeared to prosecute a complaint against Mr. WEMYSS JOBSON, a man between 50 and 60 years of age, who had been appreciated by KNOWLAND, one of the summoning officers, on a warrant charging aim with sending a threatening letter to the complainant whereby a breach of the peace might have been occasioned.

Le Nord, of Brussels, gives the text of the proclamation distributed by the Roman National Committee, with the object of restraining the people from any violent manifestation against the Papal Government, in revenge for the brutal massacre perpetrated by the Papal gendarmes on the Corso. Its temperance, dignity and firmness are worthy of all praise.

The National Democratic Convention assembles to-day, at Charleston. Full delegations from every State in the Union are present, with, however, an unusually slender attendance of outstde members, speculators, spectators and regulators; a deficiency probably due to the astonishing stories heretofore current regarding the extortions contemplated by the publicans of Charleston.

There could not be a more instructive commentary upon the absolute worthlessness, in an electioneering point of view, of violent and extravagant language and reckless behavior, on the part of candidates for the Presidency, than is afforded by Gov. WISE'S letter of the 18th inst. to the Virginia delegates, announcing his final withdrawal of his name from the list of competitors.

The political news is unimportant. HERNAN was arrested near Derby on the morning of Good Friday and was kept in custody until the day the America sailed, when he would be brought before the magistrate. It was supposed that the fight would be indefinitely postponed.

It is highly probable that the local Government of this City has a right to pave its streets without the interference of the Albany logrollers; at least, this time-honored custom will not probably be made illegal before the next session of our valuable Legislature.

At St. George's Church, Stuyvestant-square, last evening, was held the sixteenth anniversary of the Protestant Episcopal Church Missionary Society for Seamen in the City and Port of New-York. The spacious edifice was about half filed, and Rev. Dr. VINTON presided over the services.

I have been requested to meet a number of my friends. Delegates to Charleston, at Richmond, on the 19th inst. Determining not to do so, for obvious reasons, I have come to this city for family purposes alone, on my way to attend to professional duties in Accomac.

We publish in another column the act passed by the Legislature at its late session, providing for the transfer to the City of all lands along the North and East Rivers belonging to the State. We do this, because the subject is one of the utmost importance to the City, and because it is seriously misrepresented by the general comments of the Press, and in the veto message of the Governor.
A dispatch from Rome, 3d, received via Marseilles, says General LAMORICIERE was received at the Vancan.

The clipper Andrew Jackson came into port on Saturday afternoon in 89 days and 7 hours from NewYork, thus beating the Flying Cloud, which has hitherto borne the palm for the shortest trip, by six hours. She came in firing rockets and thundering a salute from her deck to the astonished town. The Andrew Jackson is Boston-built, and not a full clipper.

The Tribune tells a tale of a Republican dog, who is sent regularly to a news-stand for the morning papers. It says that he curls his tail contemptuously at the TIMES, but is greatly elated when the Tribune is placed in his mouth. This only proves that he is a dogged devotee of party.

The city is thronged with delegates and strangers, though the immense rush of roughs has been kept away by the cry of high rates. The hotels are filled to their utmost capacity, and their various passages resemble hives lined with busy bees.

After all, we are inclined to think the Legislature has done the City more good than harm by its Winter's work. Attention has been so absorbed by one or two very bad bills, that we have had no thought for other laws which have been enacted.

There has been a great Anti-Austrian demonstration at Pesth, the Capital, the occasion being the funeral of a student who died of injuries received from the police in the recent demonstration. The Democracy at Charleston are rapidly "settling to their work." They yesterday completed their organization, selecting Hon. CALEB CUSHING as their permanent Chairman, and appointing a Committee to draw up the platform on which they propose to stand or fall in the coming contest.

TIMPSON, No. 81 Railroad-avenue, was robbed of spoons and money to the amount of $17 on Monday afternoon, and yesterday morning the store of JOHN McCANN, No. 134 Newark-avenue, was entered, and $150 worth of cloths and clothing were taken. A change has been made in the time of the Pony express leaving San Francisco and St. Joseph. It will leave San Francisco every Tuesday, at 5 P.M., and arrive here on Friday of the following week; and it will leave St. Joseph every Saturday, at 11 o'clock, P. M., and arrive at San Francisco on Tuesday of the second week.

Mayor WOOD's fillibustering expedition to Charleston has come to an unhappy end. He has been refused admittance to the Conven-- tion by a very decisive vote. In the Committee on Credentials his claims were supported by only six States,--and these the most remote from New-York, and, therefore, the least likely to have any accurate knowledge of the facts which those claims involved.

The Courier and Enquirer announces the discovery of a new silver-lead mine in Pennsylvania, "within eight hours' ride of the City of New-York," the ore from which has been examined, among other "reliable men," by Prof. TORREY of the Assay-office, and found to yield silver to the value of "three times the rich placers of Arizona."

WINTER GARDEN.--The most popular opera of the Italian repertoire is undoubtedly the "Trovatore," for where and whenever produced it never fails to attract a brilliant audience. This was the case last evening, when Madame FREZZOLINI, for whom it was written, made her rentree as the heroine.

--The Herald has discovered that Abolitionism has a demoralizing effect on the clergy, and the editor of that paper straitway makes a pulpit of one of his columns, announced his new discovery as the text, and with singular unction delivers a sermon for the benefit of those misguided ministers who uphold the equality of races, and preach the Gospel of Abolitionism.

STATE DEPARTMENT, AUSTIN, April 13, 1860. SIR: Notwithstanding the fact that we have now in the field a minute detachment in almost every frontier county, the depredations continue. The utmost vigilance is kept up. Active scouts are continually out in about twenty counties, besides the force which has been sent from the interior, but Indians still are seen, and losses are daily reported.

It was telegraphed, via Queenstown, on the 12th inst., that on that day the Bank of England raised its minimum rate of discount from 4 to 5 per cent. The event was preceded by a revival in the demand for money, the applications at the Bank of England having become extraordinarily numerous. The jointstock banks and discount houses raised their allowance on deposits to 4@4 per cent.

Ladies were debarred from visiting the Japanese corvette while it lay in San Francisco. But two French ladies were determined to see the decks of the foreign ship; the feminine lexicon, like that of youth, contains "no such word as fail." Accordingly, by the connivance of their husbands, they donned the distinguishing articles of the masculine uniform, and clambered up the ship's sides.

The Thirteenth Session of the General Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church commenced at St. James Hall in this city to-day. It is composed of delegates from all the Annual Conferences, and meets to consider the affairs of the Church, on the 1st of May in every fourth year.

An Express reached this place on the 11th inst. from Lieut. MULLAN, (Wintering in Bitter Creek Valley, nearly 400 miles North,) with a requisition for 90 animals, all those accompanying his expedition having perished from the cold. He was able to buy others at that place, but at exorbitant prices. Under the circumstances, his request was not complied with.

GILMORE'S Brass Band made every one homesick this mornning, at the opening of the Convention, by playing "Home, Sweet Home." Mr. FLOURNOY, of Arkansas, after it had got through, jumped upon a chair and called at the top of his voice for three cheers for the Union. All present, ladies included, responded heartily. Then our drooping spirits were revived by "Hail Columbia" and "Yankee Doodle."

Commission Sales of Produce for the week ending May 2, 1860, prepared for THE NEW-YORK TIMES by PINNEY JOHNSON, Produce Commission Merchants, No. 231 Fulton-street. Our quotations are such as merchants and producers realize who skip their Produce to this market to be sold on commission.

The reported receipts of the principal kinds of Produce, since our last, have been: 42 bbls. Ashes; 4,792 bbls, Flour; 406 bbls, Corn Meal; 1,036 bushels Wheat; 840 bushels Corn; 1,467 bushels Oats; 1,821 pkgs, Provisions; and 403 bbls, Whisky.
THE HOUSE AND THE MEMBERS. Hon. MASON W. TAPPAN returned to Washington this evening from a flying visit to his home in New-Hampshire.

For the present the curtain has fallen upon the proceedings of the National Democratic Convention. Yesterday morning, as soon as the Conven tion had reassembled, Mr. RUSSELL, of Virginia offered a resolution that it adjourn to meet at Baltimore on June 18th, in order to afford States which were not represented an opportunity to fill up their delegations.

The annual meeting of the Chamber of Commerce took place yesterday, and was numerously attended PELATIAH PERIT, the President, in the Chair. The first business being the election of officers, Mr. PHELPS announced that Mr. PERIT had consented to serve another year, and he was accordingly unanimously elected.

A regular annual meeting of the Society was held last evening, Vice President GEORGE FOLSOM in the Chair. From the annual reports presented, it appeared that the resources of the Society during the year, including balance on hand, were $2,179.79; expenses, $2,001.40. Two thousand volumes have been added to the Society during the year, besides a valuable collection of maps, pamphlets and statistics.

The members of Dr. CHEEVER'S Church met again last night to consider the matters at issne between their Pastor and the Trustees of the building in which he officiates as minister. There was a crowded attendance in the lecture-room, which has been the scene of so many excited debates, broked by the same or other topics equally agitating.

Moran, Austin Kelly and T. Schmidt, on the other, filed the 7th of February last.

The Inaugural Message of Gov. BUCKINGHAM, on resuming the gubernatorial chair of Connecticut for another term, was delivered on the 2d instant. The Governor reports a balace of $15,000 in the State Treasury, with an aggregate indebtedness of $434,142.

The vicissitudes of human affairs were never more signally illustrated than by the short and brilliant episode in the career of "His Honor the Mayor," which commenced on the first Tuesday in last December, and has now terminated on board the new and powerful steamship James Adger, bound for this port, with "His Honor" and a large cargo of fruit and vegetables on board.
A regular meeting of the Commissioners of this Department was held yesterday, all the members being present.

We publish a letter in another column concerning the West Washington Market controversy. The writer commends the TIMES for its "Vigorous exposure and denunciation of public abuses," but protests vehemently against our advice that the City should compromise the State claim to certain lands in its possession, and to back rents for their use, instead of contesting it further in the Courts of law.

NEW-YORK, Thursday, May 3, 1860 P.M. The reported receipts of the principal kinds of Produce, since our last, have been: 91 bbls. Ashes; 7,374 bbls. Flour; 91 bbls. Corn Meal; 150 bushels Wheat; 1,306 bushels Corn; 927 bushels Oats; 1,448 pkgs. Provisions; and 266 bbls. Whisky.
The Southern Convention assembled at noon, about forty delegates present Mr. BAYARD, of Delaware, President.

The attendance at the Convention, this morning, was very slim. Many delegates went away, this morning, by the early train. All parties are disgusted and worn out. The Douglas strength controls the Democratic Party, and without it nothing can be done.

The Convention resembled this morning. Mr. RUSSELL, of Virginia, made an Explanation with regard to the Tennessee compromise resolution, and offered a resolution that when this Convention adjourn to-day it adjourn to meet at Baltimore on the 18th of June.

BAPTIST MARINERS' SOCIETY. The earliest of the May anniversaries was held last evening in Dr. GILLETTE'S church, known as Calvary Church, in Twenty-third street, it being the third annual celebration of the American Baptist Mariners' Society. The audience was quite small, not more than one hundred persons being present.

Great excitement prevailed, yesterday, on Staten Island in consequence of disturbances growing out of the passage, by the Legislature, of a bill creating the new township of "Middletown," embracing mainly a part of the town of Castleton said bill having been put through the Legislature, as is alleged, by a few individuals of the Island, who wished to be elected officers of the new township.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC. ROSSINI'S charming opera of the "Barber of Seville" was played here last evening to a good house, by the old cast, and with the old success. This work may now, thanks to Miss PATTI, be placed on the list of those that are successful and popular. It never fails to draw well.

At the meeting of the Board of Aldermen last evening, a resolution was adopted directing the Mayor to offer a reward of $2,500 for the detection of the party who set fire to the tenement house No. 96 Fortyfifth street, by which eleven persons lost their lives.

The Charleston Convention has abandoned the attempt to nominate a Democratic candidate for the Presidency. The failure is due partly to the disorganized condition of the party, and partly to the blind blundering of the Convention itself. The contest between the two sections of the Union has at last penetrated the Democratic Party, and rendered it impossible for the two wings to agree upon a declaration of principles.

A steamer has come in from Palermo just in time to allow of my giving the reports of two consuls. They say that the city was quiet; the shops not open; and they write, on the 12th, the insurgents were in occupation of all the neighboring places except Monreale. Engagements occurred daily, in which losses were incurred on either side. The troops were expecting reinforcements, when they could advance, but not till then.

We have already referred to the importance of reforming our Patent Office, and to some of the vital and essential features of good and useful laws, which the present bill before Congress entirely ignores. Our Patent Office, unlike those of other countries, assumes the responsibility of deciding upon the validity of inventions, and of granting and rejecting patents accordingly.

Mr. ANTHONY yesterday presented to the Senate a remonstrance against any alteration in the patent laws, which should take away from patentees the right of appeal from the decision of the Commissioner.

The political prize-fight at Charleston was renewed yesterday at Washington. The Democrats on this side the water have this advantage of the champions on the other, they can have a fresh "mill" whenever they like. If the result upon one trial is not satisfactory they can try again. The "drawn battle" which closed the proceedings at Charleston satisfied nobody.

THE FEDERAL OFFICE-HOLDERS IN NEW-YORK. Peremptory orders have gone forth to Post master FOWLER, and the other office-holders in NewYork, instructing them to call a meeting forthwith at Tammany, for the purpose of denouncing Popular Sovereignty, and taking other measures to kill off DOUGLAS. Any one who shall refuse to join in the call and proceedings will be instantly removed from office.

We published, a few days since, a letter from HENRY CLAY, written immediately after the adjournment of the Philadelphia Convention in 1848. The following letter from Mr. CLAY, addressed to a delegate from New-Jersey prior to the meeting of that Convention, has been handed us for publication:

To Edwin D. Mergan, Governor, SIR: The undersigned, your friends and fellowcitizens, beg leave to tender to you the expression of their approval for the fidelity to the public interests which has characterized your administration of the State Government, and especially for your firm and discreet exercise of the veto power in opposition to the dangerous schemes of the late Legislature.

Cooper Institute was about half filled yesterday morning on the occasion of the twenty-seventh anniversary of the American Anti-Slavery Society, a majority of the audience consisting of ladies. At 10 o'clock WM. LLOYD GARRISON opened the exercises by reading a portion of Scripture from the second and third chapters of Ezekiel, and the eighteenth chapter of Jeremiah.

The Triennial Convention of the Brotherhood of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the United States was held yesterday at 11 A.M., in St. Ann's Church, Eighteenth-street, between Fifth and Sixth avenues. At the beginning of the week there remained unsold 718 head in Twenty fourth-street. The demand has been quite brisk for common horses. Omnibus, railroad and ice companies have bought pretty freely at lower figures than last season say $115 to $135 each. Good coach horses have been selling slowly. A few teams brought $1,000 to $1,250.

The anniversary exhibition of the pupils of the Institution for the Blind took place at the Academy of Music yesterday afternoon, attracting an audience of over two thousand persons.

The twenty-fifth annual meeting of this Association was held yesterday in the Bleecker-street Church. The Association was called to order by Rev. S.I. SAWYER, and after prayer and the reception of credentials of delegates, Rev. G.W. BARNES was elected Moderator.

Mr. DUNN, of Indiana, (Rep.,) asked, but did not obtain leave, to introduce a resolution instructing the Committee on Foreign Affairs to inquire into the practicability and expediency of obtaining a location on some part of this continent or the adjacent islands, for the colonization of the free negroes of the United States, under the protection of this Government.

The British Mail steamer, from Valparaiso, and intermediate ports, arrived here on the 22d. The news is meagre. The Panama Railroad Company's steamer Columbus, arrived from Central American ports on the 5th. She brought no papers, as she was not generally expected on the coast to commerce her trips when she did.

The Sunday schools connected with the various Universality Churches in New York and vicinity held their Anniversary yesterday afternoon, at Rev. Dr. CHAPIN'S Church, in Broadway. The weather showed itself no respector of persons or creeds, and did not treat the Universalist children with any more consideration than was shown to the young Evangelicals who celebrated under the auspices of the "Union" on the previous day.
The U.S. corvette Powhatan, with the Japanese Embassadors and suite, consisting of seventy-two persons, arrived at Panama yesterday morning, the 24th, at 5 o'clock. They are all in good health.

The public seem to have fallen into two great errors with reference to the proceedings of the Charleston Convention, first in supposing that what are called the Tennessee resolutions, (resolutions offered by a member of the Tennessee delegation) were adopted by the Convention, and second that the delegates of the seven States who withdrew from the Convention which had refused to recognize their rights, had adjourned sine die.

At half-past 10 o'clock WM. LLOYD GARRISON called the meeting to order, the room containing but a few hundred persons. The list of officers, headed by Mr. GARRISON, was reported by the Nominating Committee, and unanimously adopted.
The twenty-sixth anniversary of the Female Guardian Society and Home for the Friendless was commemorated yesterday at the Home in Twentyninth-street.
Dispatches received at the French Legation announce that the new Minister will leave Havre for the United States about the 10th of June. Vicomte TREILLIARD will then retire from this mission.

Two vessels leave this port to-day for New-York fully laden with potatoes. The whole quantity of that edible shipped to this date is about 15,000 barrels of which New-York has had about 10,000, Baltimore about 1,000, and the remainder have been shipped to the West Indies.

The Illinois Republican State Convention met at Decatur to-day. The Illinois Republican State Convention reassembled at Decatur this morning and nominated the balance of the State ticket, as follows: Auditor, JESSE K. DUBOIS; Treasurer, WM. BULLER; Secretary, O.M. HATCH; Superintendent of Schools, NEWTON BATEMAN.

Mr. CONNOR, the pupil of Mr. WISE, the aeronaut, was advertised to make an ascension from Palace Gardeh at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon; and at the appointed hour, the fences, house-tops and trees in the vicinity were filled with a curious crowd, anxious to see all they could without paying the admittance fee.

Why the "American Tract Society of Boston" should hold its anniversary in the Provincial town of New-York, 250 miles away from that great "hub of the Universe," the dome of the Massachusetts State-House, it is difficult to conjecture; but that it was thus held, and at Dr. CHEEVER'S Church, in Union-square, the small audience who gathered there yesterday morning can testify.

Before the Convention assembled this morning circulars and handbills were liberally circulated through the Hall, setting forth the availability of Gen. HOUSTON for the Presidency, with EDWARD EVERETT for Vice-President. Though the current had, during the night, set strongly against HOUSTON, his supporters had been very busy. It was understood that a damaging break had been made against HOUSTON in the New-York delegation, and that BELL would receive ten to fifteen votes from that state.

About 250 children, male and female, including a small sprinkling of colored juveniles, represented the good work which Mr. PEASE, with his coadjutors, has been doing for the City during the past year.

OPERATIC. ROSSINI'S opera of "Moss in Egypt" will be given to-night for the third time at the Academy of Music.

A resolution to widen Catharine-street fifteen feet, on the southerly side, from the Bowery to Catharine-slip, was referred, as was a communication from Mr. Lyford, who claims that the fire escape of Messrs. Mickle Carville, which the City proposes to buy, is an infringement of a patent obtained by him over a year ago, and publicly exhibited in this City.

The regular meeting of the Board having these interests was held yesterday, all the members being present. The usual weekly reports from the several institutions were presented, from which we gather that on the 28th of April, they contained, 7,382 inmates, increased during the week ending May 5 by 1,754 admissions, and decreased by the discharge of 1,524, leaving a total at present subsisting on official charity, of 7,463.

The annual business meeting of the American Bible Society was held at 9 o'clock yesterday morning, at the Bible House, Hon. THEO. FRELINGHUYSEN in the Chair, supported by a number of Vice-Presidents. After prayer by Rev. WALTER CLARKE, the President appointed Francis Hall, Dr. Butler, James Brown, Wm. W. Chester and Horace Holden to nominate candidates for the office of Managers.

The General Conference to-day has been occupied principally with the consideration of miscellaneous resolutions, petitions and memorials on all manner of subjects. Most of them were referred without debate.

The Baltimore Constitutional Convention achieved the object of its meeting, yesterday, by nominating for President JOHN BELL, of Tennessee, and for Vice-President, EDWARD EVERETT, of Massachusetts. Upon the first ballot, the strength of Mr. BELL was so clearly apparent, that upon the second, nearly all the delegates hastened to record their votes for him; and he was declared the unanimous choice of the Convention.

COMMISSIONERS OF EMIGRATION. The Commissioners of Emigration held their weekly session on Wednesday afternoon, at Castle Garden. A full Board present Mr. VERPLANCK, the President, in the Chair. Mr. VERPLANCK asked how much was owing to different counties of the State for supplies furnished emigrants, and the care of them during detention by sickness, in passing through their counties.
The bark Inman, from Pernambuco 15th ult. reports no arrivals.

We deeply regret that we are obliged to announce the death of Mr. S.G. GOODRICH, more widely known as "Peter Parley," the pseudonym under which he acquired his reputation. He died very suddenly, at his residence in Ninth-street, of disease of the heart. Mr. GOODRICH was a native of Connecticut, and was born in 1793, though no one would have judged from his appearance that he was so nearly seventy years old.

After much tribulation, we have at last one Presidential Candidate fairly in the field. The Union Convention at Baltimore yesterday nominated JOHN BELL, of Tennessee, for President, and EDWARD EVERETT for Vice-President. Two more respectable names could not be found in the country, nor will any one doubt that in their hands the Government would be administered with ability, dignity and the most conscientious devotion to the honor and welfare of the whole country.
Alfred H. Hovey vs. The Steamboat Francis Skiday. This case came up on exceptions to the report of the Commissioner to whom the case was referred under the rules of January Term, 1859.

Williamson.1 This was an application to Justice LEONARD, of the Supreme Court, sitting at Chambers, by Mr. Williamson, touching the examination of witnesses in the matter of the contested election case between himself and Daniel E. Sickles, of the Third Congressional District.

COURT OF SESSIONS. The Grand Jury came into Court yesterday and presented twenty-eight indictments, fourteen of which were for selling liquor without a license. JOHN ROBSON, indicted for forgery in the fourth degree, was arraigned and pleaded guilty. CHARLES JONES pleaded guilty to an indictment for keeping a gambling house, and several persons indicted for selling liquor without license pleaded guilty, and were fined ten dollars each.

The Royal Mail steamship Asia, Capt. LOTT which sailed from Liverpool at noon on the 28th, an touched at Queenstown on the 29th ultimo, arrived here at 3 o'clock yesterday morning. An outline of her intelligence appeared in a portion of our edition of yesterday.

JOHN C. BELL, the Assemblyman from Eldorado County, is dead. Last Wednesday noon he stood in the Sergeant-at-Arms'room, adjoining the Chamber where the Assembly was in session, the door between the two rooms being open, talking in a low voice with another member. Dr. STONE, a lobby member, whose business at the capital was to procure a division of Eldorado County, stepped up and joined in the conversation.

A meeting was held this evening at the Constitutional Party Head quarters. After addresses by the Delegates of the late Convention, a procession was formed, headed by a band, which proceeded to the Lapierie House to serenade Senator BELL. Mr. BELL was introduced from the balcony by JOSEPH R. INGER SOIL, who eulogized the unanimity of the Convention and the candidates presented.

We have had a tremendous rain-storm all night. The rain is still falling, though it has somewhat abated. There is a great flood on the falls, and the streets in the vicinity are overflown. It is feared that considerable damage has been done above.

My last letters referred to the progress of the English negotiations for peace, and communicated the fact that the Constitutional Government had given to Capt. ALDHAM a definitive reply, adhering strictly to the letter of Lord JOHN RUSSELL'S propositions viz.: the calling of a Congress legally elected, as provided in the Constitution of 1857, and the establishment of civil and religious liberty.

The hoisting of an Anti-Brigham banner upon the Mormon battlements, and the railying call of the new Prophet, JOSEPH SMITH, Jr., is a subject of general comment among the Mormon population of this portion of the Far West; and, judging from the Press, it is also one of interest to those Saints who are found by hundreds in your far Eastern States.
It is asserted that the Hungarians regarded the new letters patent of the Emperor of Austria as of no value.

The past has been a week of festivities in Florence and in other cities of Tuscany. The visit of the King to this new portion of his dominions has been made the occasion of a general outbreak of joy. Florence, during the few years that I have known it, has been many times decorated with festive ornaments, but it has never worn so gay and graceful an aspect as on this last most happy occasion.

The adoption of the resolution offered yesterday, directing the Committee on Law Questions to give a decision on the question, "Does the General Rule on Slavery prohibit the holding of men, women and children in the same sense that it does the buying and selling them?" may bring the Slavery question before the Conference in a different form from that contemplated by the majority of the Committee on Slavery.

A fire broke out at Hannibal, Mo., this morning, on Market-street, spreading in every direction, and consuming two entire blocks. Loss between $30,000 and $40,000. Considerable excitement prevails among the citizens, who have commenced burning all houses, the inmates of which are supposed to have fired the buildings consumed this morning. No further particulars are yet received.

MERCANTILE LIBRARY ASSOCIATION. Last evening the discussion on the subject of increasing the annual dues of the members of the Mercantile Library Association was resumed in the Lectureroom at Clinton Hall. The Chair was occupied by GEO. W. BLUNT, Esq., who filled it on Tuesday evening last the occasion of the annual meeting at which time the consideration of the matter in question had been postponed.

The sales of Cotton for the last two days add up 17,500 bales, of which 5,500 bales were on speculation and for export. The market closes steady. Imports to-day, 3,550 bales; previously this week, 47,297 bales. Breadstuffs are very dull, owing to the weather being very favorable for the crops.

We have dates from Bogota only up to 31st March. The danger of a general revolution is becoming every day more imminent. Not only has Congress declined to repeal or modify the obnoxious election law, but it has declared it to be a just and proper one, and that it must be executed at all hazards.

A new pamphlet has appeared with the "selling" title, "La Nouvelle Carte d'Europe." It is from the pen of M. EDMOND ABOUT, known for various productions in light literature, and particularly for his work on Rome, against which a mock prosecution was instituted, but which, of course, came to nothing. It was published at Brussels, and was at first ostensibly prohibited from access to the French frontier, but subsequently allowed pratique.

On Tuesday the whole town went mad with sudden joy of the announcement that Gov. DOWNEY had vetoed the Bulkhead bill. Cannon were fired 147 guns on the Plaza, of which 101 were for the plucky Governor from North Beach and from South Beach. The flag bearing the city arms was run up on the City Hall in token of the city's redemption from an anticipated sale; the national bunting was displayed ...

The Committee on Slavery was in session yesterday afternoon. The report of the Committee appointed to draft a report a as presented, and it was directed that it be printed. Lest any one outside of the Committee should get hold of it, the printer was bound to secrecy.

Dispatches have been received at the Navy Department from the African squadron. There was not only no abatement in the slave traffic, but it was greatly on the increase. Notwithstanding the vigilance of the various squadrons on the coast, the persons engaged in this inhuman work manage in some way to elude the vigilance of our ships and crews, who are constantly on the alert, and often escape with full cargoes of live Africans.

ORDINATION SERVICES AT DR. BURCHARD'S CHURCH. Religious services of more than usual interest were held last evening at the Thirteenth-street Presbyterian Church, the occasion being the ordination of Rev. ARTHUR T. PIERSON to the work of the Gospel ministry. The house was well filled at the hour appointed, and the services were commenced by an appropriate anthem from the choir.

When the first Embassy departed from these shores to the unknown City of Peking the expedition created almost as much sensation as would have been occasioned by a voyage to the moon. We are now dispatching an Ambassador to the same country under very different conditions; but it happens that at this moment an Embassy is on its way, probably to London, which is at least as extraordinary as the first British mission to China.

Count APPONYI and Messrs. MURMANN, SCHOELLES and VAY, will be appointed Councillors of State. The Requiem of Count STEPHEN SCZECENYI took place on the 20th, at Pesth, without any disturbance. 10,000 persons were assembled on the occasion, in the principal square of the town.

In every direction the prospects are brightening for the Liberal cause. By our last dates from the United States to the 16th April, from New-Orleans via Havana we learn that a favorable change has taken place with regard to the Treaty, and that its ratification with the amendments proposed by Mr. SIMMONS is now considered certain, thus giving us both pecuniary assistance and moral support ...

The passengers by the Southern Lake Shore line left Buffalo this morning, and reached Chicago at 9 o'clock this evening. Great enthusiasm was exhibited all along the route; at every point crowds of people thronged the depots. Bands of music, the booming of cannon, and numberless cheers, testified the great interest felt by the masses touching the objects of the Convention.

The Irish emigration to this country which it was supposed, a year or two ago, would abate under the influence of great prosperity at home, has again set in with such violence that the English Press begins to prophesy the total transfer, at no distant period, of the Celtic population ...

The "Old Dominion Society," an association of residents of this City who are Virginians either by birth or parentage, held their first anniversary celebration last evening in the Copper Institute. The hall was barely more than filled to one-third of its capacity.

The mysterious rumors which have been floating for some time between Washington and New-York, of serious defalcations chargeable to the account of a leading Federal officer in this City, yesterday took shape and substance. DUPONT doing the honors of the table, with the First Ambassador and Adviser on his right, and the Second Ambassador and Treasurer on his left. The other Japanese officers occupied a separate table.

At 4 o'clock, on Sunday afternoon, they were transferred from the Roanoke to the Philadelphia, and in ten minutes afterwards were at Old Point, where they were received with salutes and music.

Mr. TOM TAYLOR'S latest dramatic success is not his least. His comedy of the "Overland Route," which has been running in London ever since the beginning of February, and which began its career in New-York at Wallack's Theatre last night, is the most ingenious and creditable piece of work he has given us since "Still Waters Run Deep."

The magnificent little steamer, chartered and fitted up by the Government for the special purpose of conveying the Japanese Embassy up the Potomac River to the Capital of the nation, is a perfect picture in her Sunday dress of new paint, bouquets and banners, and well adapted for the purpose intended. Want of time has compelled me to omit my usual communications for your paper the last few mails, and after a hard day's work I sit down now to give you a few items.

A letter from Paris tells a strange story of a recent discovery in science, culminating in a melancholy denouncement. A governess in private families had under her charge a little Russian boy, who had been born deaf and dumb. The gentle disposition of the boy greatly endeared him to the governess, who devoted much of her time to developing ...

The woman Amelia Morrell, alias Sarah Fann, a noted shoplifter, indicted for grand larceny, and bailed in April in the sum of $2,000, and who afterwards fled to Canada, forfeiting her bonds, was brought into Court yesterday morning by officer Rosenberg, of the Twenty-sixth Precinct, who pursued her to Canada and arrested her. She pleaded a second time Not Guilty to the charge preferred against her, and was ordered to be committed without bail.

In a letter, dated some eight or ten day's ago, I informed you of the death of Mr. TOWNER, the American Consul at this port. I repeat the announcement for letters sent by sailing vessels do not always reach their destination. The Consul died suddenly of inflammation.

Flag-officer McCLUNEY, of the Home Squadron, has asked to be relieved, owing to debilitated health, arising from long detention in Aspinwall Bay. He is not as ill as has been represented by one of your contemporaries.
ROBERT C. McDONALD has saved the DistrictAttorney the trouble of filing those cross-interrogatories which he has been so long promising.

There was a slim attendance, owing to a general interest felt in the arrival of the Japanese. The galleries were almost deserted, which led to some witty remarks that the Japanese Embassy drew better than DOUGLAS.

ITEMS. Rev. Dr. STINSON, President of the Canada Wesleyan Conference, was introduced to the Conference, and presented an address, which was read and referred. Dr. STINSON afterwards addressed the Conference in an eloquent manner. He was followed by Rev. Mr. HURLBURT, a co-delegate from the same Conference.

The California Pony Express arrived here at 1 o'clock this morning, with California dates to May 5, Oregon to April 28, and British Columbia to the 30th The crops in California are considered sadly damaged, from heavy storms of rain and hail.

At the meeting of the Polytechnic Association last week, Prof. SEELY, Chairman of the Committee to whom was referred for consideration JOHNSON's new patent gas burner, reported in behalf of the majority of the Committee, unfavorably to the invention.

The attendance at Chicago, not only of delegates but of interested and curious spectators, is large beyond any precedent in the history of National Conventions. No decisive opinion seems to be expressed by a recognized majority as to the candidate, though the friends of Mr. SEWARD are supposed to be the most numerous and most perfectly organized.

The reported receipts of the principal kinds of Produce, since our last, have been: 61 bbls. Ashes, 11,160 bbls. Flour, 1,230 bbls. Corn Meal, 26,824 bushels Wheat, 79,161 bushels Corn, 262 bushels Rve, 8,892 bushels Oats, 690 pkgs. Provisions, and 874 bbls. Whisky.

The startling developments connected with the alleged Post-office defalcations in this City, and the sudden disappearance of the widely-known and universally popular head of that department, Mr. ISAAC V. FOWLER, continue to be the theme of discourse in all places of public resort throughout the City, as well as in the more private and social circles where that gentleman has so long moved a welcome guest.

Judge SMALLEY, we are glad to see, has pronounced against the attempt to introduce into the Federal Courts, in the Hicks case, the absurd rule, so stringently enforced in our State Courts, that the mere fact of a man's having read the comments or reports of a newspaper, on the commission of a crime, shall disqualify him for acting as a juryman on the trial.
The Japanese delegation has remained in almost strict privacy to-day, but few minor officials making their appearance outside outside their quarters.
A great crowd of people arrived to-day by the morning and evening trains. The various delegations are full, and are busy arranging their committee-men and officers.
The Court met at 10 o'clock, yesterday morning, when the trial of Johnson was resumed.

Coroner JACKMAN, yesterday morning, made an investigation into the circumstances attending the death of ROBERT C. MACDONALD, the murderer. The evidence corroborated the statement of the case which has been given in the TIMES, the only additional point of interest having been developed in the testimony of THOMAS JEFFERSON LONAN, the colored...

The American brig Townsend Jones arrived here in April, 1858, with a cargo of arms and munitions of war. Nothing was accomplished for the sale of these articles until the revolution commenced in 1859. The Government then suspected that a bargain was under way for the transfer of these dangerous implements to the Rebel party, who held Coquimbo and Caldera. There cannot be much doubt that some ground for the suspicion existed.

A grand meeting, to ratity the nominations BELL and EVERETT, will be held on Thursday evening in Penn-square; distinguised speakers are promised, including a grandson of PATRICK HENRY. DOUGLAS MOVEMENTS IN GEORGIA AND ALABAMA.

We ventured, in commenting some weeks ago upon the approaching reception of the Japanese by the Municipal authorities, to conjecture that the fame of our Common Council and their "hospitalities" had spread through Eastern Europe and Asia, and had perhaps reached the ears of the Japanese, secluded though they have been from the rest of the world. Testimony to the correctness of our supposition is daily turning up.

You have already received from myself and others, and published in the TIMES, a full account of the reception of the Japanese Embassy, to-day, and the sayings and doings on the occasion. There are' however, a number of details that the mail may carry as well as the telegraph.

The action of the Board of Aldermen on Monday night, in removing A.V. STOUT, Esq., as City Chamberlain, and confirming the nomination of NATHAN C. PLATT, Esq., President of the Artisans' Bank, in his stead, places the financial affairs of the City in a very singular position. The bonds of the newly-appointed Chamberlain must be approved by the Comptroller.

All England is now prostrating itself at the feet of TOM SAYERS in a literally golden silence of admiration, that so small a boxer should have made so great a fight. Dukes and stockjobbers unite in applauding the pluck which has enabled a "light weight" so long to hold the Championship of the Prize Ring. This is all natural enough in a country which worships the flesh, calls itself "John Bull,"

PRESENTATION On Monday evening, Capt, SHAURMAN, of the Third Precinct Police, was presented with a valuable gold watch, as a token of respect by his friends on the occasion of his retiring from the Police Department.
Adjutant-General COOPER has received a dispatch from Col. LEE, Commanding the Department of Texas, in which he says:...
Certain departmental communications were received.

The first festival of the Society which is designated as above was held last evening in the Metropolitan Hotel. It was marked by a large attencance, an exquisite table, and a representation of sympathetic talent rarely to be met with on suck an occasion.

The House met at 11 o'clock. Mr. BOTELER, of Virginia, (American,) from the Committee on Military Affairs, reported a bill to remove the United States Arsenal from St. Louis, and establish the same and an Armory at Jefferson Barracks.

Yesterday developed no new particulars of interest connected with the defalcation in the NewYork Post-office, and the excitement that attended the first announcement of the news is fast dying away. The friends of Mr. FOWLER, forgetting the crime in their regard for the man, continue to express their sorrow at his downfall, their joy at his escape from the clutches of the law, and their wonder as to what he has done with the money.

The Richmond Enquirer, edited by Gov. WISE'S son, informs the Democrats of the North that their only possible chance of victory lies in nominating Gov. WISE for the Presidency, and JOSEPH LANE for the Vice-Presidency; that these gentlement will carry "all the Southern States, and Pennsylvania, Indiana, New-York, Oregon and California," and thus secure the victory, and that nobody else can accomplish as much.

We are told that the Court of Oyer and Terminer adjourned on Tuesday without doing any business, owing to the continued absence of Mr. District-Attorney WATERBURY, though several manslaughter cases remain to be disposed of. We commented two days ago upon the delay in bringing MACDONALD to trial, caused by what we must regard as the remissness of this same official. Mr. WATERBURY pleads that...

Herman Boerngen vs. The Harlem Railroad Company. This was an action against the defendants to recover the value of the contents of a certain trunk of the plaintiff's, alleged to have been lost through the negliaence of cefendants as common carriers. The trunk was claimed to be worth $487,50, plaintiff averring that it contained valuable books and clothing.

The proceedings of the M.E. General Conference to-day were of more general interest than they have heretofore been. The reports of the Slavery Committee, which have been so anxiously looked For, and about which there has been so much speculation, were to-day presented, read, and ordered printed. Both the majority and minority reports were documents of some length, occupying nearly two hours in the reading.

The Court-room was even more crowded yesterday than on the preceding days, and the proceedings, in consequence, were several times interrupted. The testimony for the prosecution is closed, and the defence will proceed to-day.

The various City Departments were yesterday pregnant with official dullness. The only topic of conversation was the quarrel of the Chamberlains' and the officials generally seemed to feel a deep personal interest in the possible or probable result of the contest, for a contest is resolved upon by both sides.
Forrest vs. Forrest. This case was again before Justice MONCHIEF, at a Special Term of the Su- perior Court, for the purpose of settling the final decree or order.
A communication was received from the Interior Department relative to the Indian depredations in California.

At the beginning of the week there were 718 head in the stables at Twenty-fourth street unsold. Business has been brisk during the few pleasant days which we have had. Very few fine matched teams have been sold. Prices, however, are well sustained.
The mails from Bombay April 11, Calcutta April 7, and Melbourne March 17, were forwarded via Queenstown by the Europa.

Ministers not members of the Conference are congregating here in great numbers, and when the Slavery debate opens the galleries of St. James' Hall will be full of Methodist pastors and people. The venerable Dr. NATHAN BANGS, of New-York, made his appearance at the Conference to-day, and was invited to take a seat on the platform.

The display at PICKETT'S warehouse in this city of 240 hbds, of tobacco, averaging 1,200 pounds weight, under the patronage of the Kentucky State Agricultural Society, is said to be the largest exhibition of fine tobacco ever witnessed in the world. Tobacco dealers from every section of the Union are present.

At the meeting of the Board of Education last evening, Mr. ANDREW H. GREEN in the Chair, a communication was received from the School officers of the First Ward, to the effect that Ward School No. 29, in Greenwich-street, is totally inadequate for school purposes.

Commission Sales of Produce for the week ending May 16, 1860, prepared for THE NEW-YORK TIMES by PINNEY JOHNSON, Produce Commission Merchants, No.231 Fulton-street. Our quotations are such as merchants and producers realize who ship their Prod- uce to this market to be sold on commission.

The jury, which for three days have had under consideration the mysterious circumstances in connection with the death of FRANZ GREDEY German, who was instantly killed last Sunday morning, by falling from the fifth-story window of the tenemont house No. 184 Eldridge-street, yesterday returned a verdict in which they implicated ECHA HOLT, alias Miller, the occupant of the apartment from the win- dow of which the deceased fell, as an accessory to his death.

The steamship Europa, Capt. LEITCH, from Liverpool 5th, via Queenstown 6th Inst., arrived at this port at 11 o'clock last night, and sailed at an early hour this morning for Boston, at which port she will be due by Thursday noon.

A meeting of the Police Commissioners was held, yesterday, at their office in Broome-street. Mr. ACTON, who supersedes Gen. PILSBURY, and who had on the previous day formally assumed his seat as a member of the Board, was promptly in attendance. The Board was therefore full.

Another dispatch had been sent out; Gen. CASS' reply thereto was looked for shortly, and further steps would depend on the nature of that reply.

The throng of in-pouring multitudes, by rail, by sail and by wagon, has continued without cessation, all the adjacent States sending their innumerable representatives. The Convention met at the hour prefixed, in the great Wigwam, which holds, and today held, ten thousand people, while twenty thousand more surrounded the building. The proceedings, which will be found at length in the general report, were marked with the utmost good feeling and unbounded enthusiasm.

Your correspondent was one of the favored few admitted to witness the interview between the Japanese Embassy and the Secretary of State. SIME-BUJEN-NOKAMI, MURAJAKI-A WAGE-NO-KAMI, OJURE-BUNGO-NOKAMI, MOSITA-OKATORA, and six other Japanese officials were present.
The King of Sardinia was at Bologua, and had received an enthusiastic reception. The Syndicats had presented him with five million francs as a voluntary contribution from the people.
M. THOUVENEL had issued a dispatch showing that the annexation of the neutralized districts of Savoy will not change the situation of Switzerland.

It was written in reply to one from Several gentlemen in Bibb County, and in it he reviews the exciting questions of the day:

The Republican Convention at Chicago met yesterday morning, in the Great Wigwam erected by the Republicans of that city. Gov. MORGAN, of New-York, as Chairman of the National Commit- tee, called the Convention to order adding a brief and sensible exhortation to harmony, dignity, and patriotism, and indicating the evils to be avoided by the example of the late Convention at Charleston. He then nominated as temporary chairman Hon. DAVID WILMOT, of Pennsylvania, ...

The Commissioners of Emigration held their regular weekly meeting yesterday, Mr. VERPLANCK, the President, in the Chair. The Committee on the claims of the different Counties for the support of aliens made a report by which it appears that the amount due them is $23,746,26. They recommended that the claim be paid.
Prince ALEXANDER, of Hesse, had been nominated as Commander-in-Chief of the Austrian army in Italy.

There markets have undergone little change during the week. In no part or division has there been an absolute scarcity, nor there been a large oversupply of any variety....Beeves show a diminution of numbers, but so many of them have been of large size and in good killing condition, that no more could have been sold without crowding prices below the prevailling rates of one week ago.

The members and Trustees of Dr. CHEEVER's Church met again last evening in the lecture-room of the edifice in which he ministers, to resume the debate which has so long been in progress, relative to the expediency and propriety of Miss JOHNSON'S mission to England.
The Rebublican National Convention succeeded yesterday in clearing away all the formal and preliminary business before it, leaving nothing to be done but to ballot for a Presidential candidate.

Abigail Dodge Vs. Ezra Flagg et al.--This was an appeal to the General Term of the Supreme Court from a judgment at Special Term, directing an ad- measurement of the plaintiff's dower in four houses and lots situated in West Eleventh-street, in this City, valued at $40,000.

Supplement No. XXIII of American Lloyd's Registry of Shipping has been issued, and contains the usualnumber of vessels newly surveyed. This publication is said to be fast becoming standard authority among insurers and shipping merchants. Published by E. and G.W. Blunt.

To-day the Japanese Embassadors visited the Secretary of State at his office, and presented their credentials. To-morrow they visit the President and Diplomatic Corps, and after that they will be at liberty to receive municipal ovations.

SANDY HOOK; May 17, Sunset Propeller Montgomery, for Savannah, cleared the Bar at 6 P.M. One brig is coming in past the Hook. Ships Patrick Henry and Emerald Isle are still at anchor at the Spit, bound out. A large fleet of vessels, bound East have come in and anchored on account of adverse wind. Wind fresh from East; weather hazy.

We had heard so much from his own "organ" of the almost superhuman eloquence of "His Honor the Mayor," during the recent canvass in Connecticut, that we have been waiting with some anxiety for the production of a specimen of it a little nearer home.

On Wednesday evening, the 2d inst., HEENAN arrived in Liverpool from Chester, and took up his quarters at the Waterloo Hotel. His visit was kept stricily private, so that no manifestation took place on his behalf, and even the persons in the hotel were not aware for some time of the presence of the farfamed Benecia Boy.

The Convention has made decided progress today. It has acted upon the credentials of members; designated the vote which each State shall have; adopted rules and an order of business, and laid down the platform of the party. The details of all these movements will reach you by telegraph to the Associated Press.

The announcement that the National Republican Convention at Chicago had nominated ABRAM LINCOLN for President, on the third ballot, was published in the City at 1 o'clock, and, as it spread, was received by the friends of Senator SEWARD with some show of disappointment.

The Panama Railroad Company's steamer Gua- temala, Capt. Dow, arrived at Panama from Central American ports on the 5th inst. Dates from Guatemala are to April 25, Salvador to the 27th April, Nicaragua to May 1, and Costa Rica to May 2. There is not the least news from either Guatemala, Salvador or Nicaragua. Hervy vs. Kerr. -- This action was brought to recover of the defendant the value of a quantity of glass.
The steamship Philadelphia arrived at this port yesterday morning, from Havana on the 12th inst. The health of Havana was good.

The reception of the news of LINCOLN'S nomination, at Chicago, threw the House of Representatives into such excitement as to suspend business for some minutes. Everybody was delighted. Even Mr. SEWARD'S warmest admirers pronounced the nomination most able and judicious. Judge DOUGLAS and his friends think it the heaviest blow the Democracy has yet received, and say that by to-morrow night there will not be a tar barrel or a pound of powder in Illinois.

The steamship Adriatic, from Southampton on the 9th May, arrived here on Saturday morning with three days' later news from Europe. She left Havre on the 8th inst., and arrived off Cowes the same evening. Having embarked the mails and passengers she sailed again on the evening of the 9th, passing the Needles at 6:20 P.M., from whence to Cape Race she encountered a constant succession of strong westerly winds, with head sea.

Mr. HALE, of New-Hampshire, (Rep.,) introduced a bill to alier and improve the construction of the Senate chamber. Referred to a select committee.
The Archbishop died on the 5th inst., at his resi- dence in Belgrave-square, London.

Rarely has Washington, the city of sensation presented so brilliant a spectacle, or the White house so select an assemblage, as yesterday on the occasion of the reception of the Japanese Embassy by the President.

The first surprise at the nomination effected by the Convention at Chicago, appears to have given way in the Repnblican party to a feeling of satisfaction more or less decided. In this City the tone of sentiment was on Saturday much more favorable to the ticket than on Friday evening, while from other points in the Northern States we hear a promising tale of gratification and rejoicing.

In reply to the proposals of France, England con- cents to adopt as the basis of the Conference Article 92 of the final Act of Vienna, which refers to the neutralization of the districts of Chablais and Fauoigny. England reserves, however, the right of making at the said Conference proposals relative to the mode of this neutralization. This declaration of England is likely to increase the probabilities of the assembling of the proposed Conference.

There is no surer sign of an imperfect civilization than a passion for noise. The Fejee Islanders, whenever they had secured a particularly fat family of foreigners for one of their national feasts, used to give vent to their delight by blowing through horrible tubes the most dissonant and far-resounding notes.

BENNY, J. Artisans' Bank vs. Treadwell et al. Order granted, giving defendant leave to serve answer on payment of $10 costs. Judgment and execution to stand aside, and proceedings stayed.

The Twenty-third-street Presbyterian Church was about filled last evening on the occasion of the sermon, by Rev. J.R. SLOANE, on " Political Corruption."

The late performance of the steamship Fulton, of the New-York and Havre line, deserves special no- tice, on the ground that it is one of the shortest westward passages ever accomplished between the port of Havre (by way of Southampton) and New-York.

Quite a storm is raging at the White House concerning Marshal RYNDERS, who left yesterday for New-York, and his removal from office is yet is dispute. The act of his assistants, in letting a slaver escape, has been excused on the ground that the warrant had not the name of a Commissioner on it a fact which they knew in advance and should have attended to.

The Paris correspondent to the Morning Post says, according to official dispatches, there is no truth about a modification of the Spanish Cabinet. A subscription for the Pope has been opened at Madrid, but as yet it only anounts to 48,534 reals.

COTTON market steady; sales yesterday and today 18,000 bales, including 5,000 on speculation and for export, BREADSTUFFS quiet and easier, but quotations unchanged. PROVISIONS dull. TALLOW nominal. PRODUCE generally unchanged.

The following letter, signed by persons from California, now in this City, was yesterday addressed to their Representatives in Congress:

VICTOR EMANUEL left Florence at the beginning of the present week, and the town has returned to its usual quiet. At 4 o'clock in the morning, the loyal inhabitants heard a furious rattling of wheels and spirited cracking of postillions' whips in their streets, and they could sleep no longer, for they knew it was the train of vehicles which was bearing their King and his counselors away.
Her Majesty and the Prince Consort proceeded to the camp this morning at Aldershott, where they will remain till Tuesday.

THE COVODE COMMITTEE. The Covode Committee developed nothing of interest to-day. The testimong taken yesterday has been sent to the Postmaster-General, with the request that he will furnish the Committee with copies of all correspondence touching the Vanderbilt and Johnson contracts.

Judge RUSSELL is waking up, or District-Attorney WATERBURY has returned to the City: Yesterday several cases, mostly of importance, were disposed of in this Court, principally, however, by the accused parties pleacing guilty.

The revolution which has been firing minuteguns from one and another height of the Sicilian coasts for the last two months, has been heard and answered. There can be no doubt now that GARIBALDI, after maturely weighing the actual chances of the rising in Sicily, has once more drawn his sword in the cause to which his whole life has been given.

--The brutality of American masters at sea has furnished English journalists with a prolific theme for at least a dozen years. That occasional instances of maltreatment may be met with on American vessels we admit, but that such an unmitigated piece of brutality as the Aylesbury News chronicles as having just been displayed in England, would have been tolerated anywhere upon American soil, we doubt.

MR. JOHN M. KOPPER, for some time past General Superintendent and out-door Manager of the Weehawken Ferry Company, came to his death on Thursday morning last, under the following circumstances: He had been in the habit, on Sabbath evenings, of going down to the Ferry for a short time to assist in getting over the crowds that usually fill the boats at such times.

Mr. Fry, of Bristol, is engaged, we understand, in preparing an edition of Tyndale's New Testament, printed at Worms in the year 1525, from the copy preserved in the Baptist Museum at Bristol. It is to be an exact transcript of the original, which will be first traced page by page, and then lithographed in facsimile.

During the past two days the Street Commissioner has been the recipient of more "calls" than ever fell to the lot of any oificial with the exception of the Mayor on New-Year's day. At the meeting of the Association on Thursday evening, the subject of gas-burning having been set apart for special discussion, was considered. Mr. ASHMORE, of South Carolina, (Dem.,) offered a resolution that the Sergeant-atArms be instructed to withhold the further payment of salary from such members as have neglected or refused to report their mileage to the Committee on Mileage. THE STORM The rain storm on Saturday caused considerable damage in this city. The water ran with great volume down the steep grade of Hicks into Fulton-street, doing much damage to the sewer being constructed on the former street.

The General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church, New School, to-day referred the whole plan of education for the ministry to a permanent Committee, with the addition to their number of Rev. A. BARNES and Drs. HUNTINGTON and ALLEN, to report the necessary changes to the next General Assembly.

The principal feature of Japanese news to-day has been the continuation of yesterday's levee at Willard's, from 11 to 1 o'clock, for the benefit of members of Congress and their families, and many others. The ceremonies were conducted precisely the same as yesterday.

The leaders of the Republican host are now chosen. A Convention unequaled in ability, unparalleled in harmony and enthusiasm cheered by such a crowd of citizens from the East, West, North and South, as never before gathered at a National Convention of any party has deliberately, after cool and dispassionate consultation, selected ABRAHAM LINCOLN, of Illinois, and HANNIBAL HAMLIN, of Maine, to be our standard-bearers in the coming contest.

A Vienna telegram of the 14th states on reliable information that part of GARIBALDI'S expedition disembarked at Marsala on the 11th from two vessels. The Royal ships were obliged to cease firing, during two hours being, it is asserted, prevented by English steamers. The firing could not be resumed until the English officers had returned from the shore to their vessels.

Application of Nathan C. Platt. -- On Monday evening Justice BONNEY granted an alternative man- damus against the Comptroller, requiring him to approve Mr. Platt's bonds as City Chamberlain, or to show cause on Tuesday why he did not. The matter was now returnable before Justice MULLEN at Chambers.

The Grand Jury yesterday brought forty indictments into this Court, including one against Lawson, Wells, Totten, and the two Thompsons, for forging deeds. These parties were arrested through the agency of Mr. W.H. Allen, of the District Attorney's office, and held to bail. The Grand Inquest also indicted 53 persons, charged with having sold liquors.

The case of HAMILTON vs. the Pittsburgh Councils came up to-day, Mr. HARDING, counsel for plaintiff and Mr. PENNY for defendant. A statement was made that the Councils had not yet taken action, when the Court suggested that the case be held over until June 26, at Lancaster. A decision will be given this afternoon.
The Opinion Nationale of Paris, evidently with the connivance of the French Government, announces the opening in France of a sabscription for GARIBALDI. The editor, M. GUEROULT, writes:

The Malta correspondent of the London Times, under date of May 12, announces the arrival on that morning of Her Majesty's steamer Intrepid, from Marsala, with intelligence of the landing thereat on the 11th of a band of 2,000 Italians, under GARIBALDI, who immediately pushed on to Canata Fimi and Alcomo, where the insurgents are concentrated, and will, it is hoped, hold their ground.

The mails of the steamship Arabia, bringing correspondence, and London files to May 19, arrived here from Boston last evening.

We have received a great number of communications from various parts of the country, concerning the action of Mr. GREELEY, as delegate from Oregon, at the Chicago Convention. We must decline their publication, partly because they can serve no useful public purpose, and partly because they involve a personal controversy, for which we have no taste.

The Pike's Peak Express, which arrived here this morning, furnishes the following summary of news, under the date of Denver City, May 24:

Application of Nathan C. Platt. This was the return of the mandamus against the Comptroller requiring him to judge of the sufficiency of Mr. Platt's bonds. The return in substance was that Mr. Platt was not entitled to the office, and for that reason his bonds were not approved.

AMERICAN CLAIMS UPON PERU. Our Government having requested the presence of Senor ZEGARRA, the Peruvian Minister, informed him of the determination to make a peremptory demand for the amount of claims for the confiscated ships Georgiana and Lizzie Thompson. This demand was necessarily forwarded by a war vessel, but with no view to backing the demand by force.
The House passed a bill for the removal of the Arsenal of St. Louis to Jefferson City.

Commission Sales of Produce for the week ending May 16, 1860, prepared for THE NEW-YORK TIMES by PINNEY JOHNSON, Produce Commission Merchants, No. 231 Fulton-street. Our quotations are such as merchants and producers realize who ship their Produce to this market to be sold on commission.

A DISCUSSION IN THE HOUSE OF COMMONS. In the House, Commons on the 17th inst., Mr. MONSELL wished to know what course Government intended to take with respect to the parties raising the subscriptions. He called upon them to act fairly and repress this attempt, as they would com- plain if a similar attempt was made to aid a rebellion in Ireland or in the Ionian Islands.

We have had a good deal of "talk" and some "older" to-day. Rev. R.M. HATFIELD, of the NewYork East Conference, made a well-defined and emphatic avowal of the principles of the Progressive party to-day. He is an orator of acknowledged ability, and spoke to-day with a warmth and show of faith that evinced an intimate acquaintance with the subject he was discussing, and a thorough conviction that he had the right of it.

The Weeping philosopher of the Tribune refuses to be comforted. He is obstinately and incurably unhappy. His mood is that of the Frenchman who declared that he "would drown nobody should help him." GREELEY'S grief, however, is as fantastic as it is profound. It springs from a hallucination, which has already lasted six or seven years, and which bids fair to attend him to his grave.

REJECTION OF THE M'LANE TREATY. The Senate to-day first rejected Mr. SIMMONS' amendment to the Mexican treaty, and then rejected the treaty, all the Republicans but Senator TRUMBULL voting against it. War is predicted with Mexico within six months.

GENTLEMEN: I have the honor to present to the Chamber the law project, which authorizes the Government of the King to execute the treaty, concluded at Turin on the 24th March, 1860, for the reunion of Savoy and the District of Nice with France.

There was a large gathering of Republicans at Springfield, Conn., on Wednesday evening, to respond to the Chicago nominations, not less than 2,000 persons, including many from neighboring towns, being present. The principal speakers were Hon. GEORGE ASHMUN, President of the Chicago Convention, and ERASTUS HOPKINS.

The Senate, yesterday, in Executive session, spent four hours in deliberation over the Mexican treaty, and eventually rejected it by a large ma- jority. The Republican members, with the exception of Mr. TRUMBULL, of Illinois, voted against the ratification.

Enoch Hidden vs. The Steamship Ocean Bird. This was an action for supplies, the question being one simply as to the jurisdiction of the Court. The ship was a domestic vessel, her owner residing here. The supplies were proper and necessary for a foreign voyage, on which she was destined, but there was no necessity for a bottomry upon her at the time. The libel was filed Sept. 20, 1855.
Steamship Roanoke, Couch, Norfolk, Ludlam Heineken.
The steamship St. Louis, Capt. CAVENDY, from New-Orleans on the 24th, stopping at Havana on the 27th, arrived here last evening. She brings nothing of interest.

Mr. EVARTS' reductio ad absurdum of Mr. O'CONOR'S opinion upon the Chamberlaincy dispute, on Wednesday, as to what constitutes "cause" for the removal of a municipal officer, was an excellent illustration of the dangerous predicament in which Mr. O'CONOR'S theory would place us.
The telegraph brings us tidings of the death of Hon. Judge DANIEL, of the United States Supreme Court, which event took place yesterday, at Richmond, Va., after a long illness.
The proceedings of the General Conference to- day have possessed more of general interest than those of any previous.

Catharine N. Forrest Vs. Edwin Forrest. This was an application, on the part of defendant, for leave to file un undertaking on appeal, giving a number of sureties who shall justify in an aggregate amount equal to that required by law, instead of being obliged to find two sureties who will justify for the whole sum some $37,000. Defendant also asked to be relieved from filing security for future payments of alimony.

The Pony Express, with the dispatches and mail missing from the Pony Express which arrived Tuesday evening last, arrived here at 2:20 P.M. today. No explanation is given as to the cause of its detention. The mail was all safe. The dates from San Francisco are to 4 P.M. on the 18th inst.

The long agony is over. The new chapter proposed by the majority of the Committee on Slavery is inserted in the Discipline. The conservatives fought it with substitutes and amendments, motions to adjourn and calls for the ayes and noes, long and well, but all Without avail.
