Last night the Republicans of this town held a meeting to ratify the Chicago nominations. Several hundred persons were in attendance, a number quite unusually large for evening meetings in this locality. Hon. EMERY F. WARREN, President of the Pomfret Republican Club, presided; and addresses were made by Hon. JAMES O. PUTNAM, GEOREGE BARKER, Esq., W. McKINSTRY, Esq., and others of this village and Dunkirk.

In the United States Senate yesterday, Mr HALE procured the adoption of a resolution instructing the Naval Committee to inquire into the disposition made of the land purchased for a Naval Depot at Brunswick, Georgia. The bill amending the act relative to private land claims in California was taken up and passed.

The new directors of the Great Eastern have made the Portland people the victims of "a sell," almost as gigantic as the great ship herself. The last Board positively announced that when the ship came to this country, she would come to Portland, and the Portlanders accordingly expended over $100,000 in building a pier and making other preparations for her advent.

In the M.E. General Conference, Mr. BLADES, of Michigan, offered a resolution that new chapter on Slavery for the Discipline, which was adopted yesterday, was meant only as advisory in its nature, not statutory; that the chapter is in itself so clearly declaratory of principle and advisory of parctice, that it requires no explanatory clause. The resolution was adopted, 165 against 6.

The Presidential campaign will not be fairly opened until the Democratic Party marshals its forces in fully the field. The canvass awaits the proceedings at Richmond and Baltimore. Until the Democratic candidates have been named, nothing can be done. The question of commanding interest in political circles, therefore, is what will the Democrats do?

The private life of THEODORE PARKER was a study, no less entertaining and instructive than his public career. A man of profound learning, unfailing geniality and warm affections, he added to the charms of a brilliant conversationist the stronger attraction of a large human sympathy. Troops of friends surrounded him. He never denied them access.

That the people of Massachusetts are in dire distress about their cattle is well known throughout the country. The farmers are stricken with a panic, and the panic is spreading to other States. A disease has appeared among their herds which proves to be contagious, and which veterinary men pronounce to be incurable.

The suicide of the Hungarian patriot and hero, Count SZECHENYI, is the most important and striking among the many sad events which characterize the decay of the Austrian Empire. Count STEPHEN SZECHENYI was born Sept. 21, 1791, in Vienna, and was educated as a soldier.

The Board of Councilmen last evening had under consideration a resolution directing the Attorney to the Corporation to suspend all prosecution of suits for violation of the ordinances relating to signs, awning posts, and awnings, until further instruction from the Board.

A caucus of National Democrats, determined to cooperate with the general Convention assembled here so long as there is a hope that the national organization will be preserved, is in session. In the event that delegates are sent to Richmond, or a platform is adopted by the general Convention different from that adopted at Charleston, the National men will quietly organize a separate Convention.

A terrible tornado passed over the eastern part of Iowa and the northwest part of Illinois last night. The telegraph lines west of the Mississippi being down, we are unable to ascertain how far West the tornado reached, and what is the real amount of loss of life and property.

This match was commenced yesterday on the St. George's new ground, Elysian Fields, Hoboken. The Methodist General Conference, after a session of five weeks, adjourned finally to-day, for want of a quorum. There was very little more business to be transacted, but the conduct of those who left before all was completed, and compelled those who remained to separate without clearing the docket, is severely censured.

A resolution has been introduced making the pension act of 1853 retrospective and extending its operation to March, 1848. This resolution, if adopted by the Senate, would take from the Treasury two millions dollars. The Senate has already ignored a similar proposition.
At the regular meeting of the Board of Councilmen yesterday, the Street Commissioner was directed to clear all obstructions from Broadway prior to the 13th inst.

The storm of Saturday evening was very severe at Alton, Ill. The total loss will probably exceed $100,000. The German Catholic Church is almost a complete wreck. The Episcopal Church lost its steeple, and is said to be almost a total loss, in consequence of the walls being cracked. The organ is also ruined.
The Legislative Republican caucus, to-night, nominated CHAS. H. BELL for Speaker of the House; EDWARD SAWYER, Clerk; for President of the Senate, GEORGE TOWLE; G. CUMMINGS, Clerk.

MEETING OF THE FRIENDS OF HOUSTON FOR PRESIDENT. A meeting of those citizens of Brooklyn favorable to the claims of Gen. SAM HOUSTON, of Texas, assembled on Monday evening at Una Building, corner of Adelphi-street and Myrtle-avenue. Mr. J.H. VAN DERZEE was selected as Chairman, and Mr. MACKEY acted as Secretary. The Regular Democratic State Convention assembled here to-day. The Committee on Resolutions reported a series that were soundly Southern, declaring "That we will take no step backward."

We publish to-day the most important papers relating to a grave case of domestic scandal Which has for months past been disturbing the surface of society in a leading Western city. Upon the merits of this case we, of course, do not now propose to pronounce any opinion.
The steamer De Soto, from Havana on the 2d inst., has arrived.

The annual meeting of "The Most Worshipful Grand Lodge of the Most Ancient and Honorable Fraternity of Free and Accepted Masons of the State of New York" was opened yesterday afternoon, in their Grand Lodge-room, at the Apollo Rooms, No. 410 Broadway.

In the Senate yesterday, Mr. SUMNER presented a petition from LEWIS TAPPAN and others, of this City, asking for the release of THADDEUS HYATT. The Kansas bill was taken up. Mr. GREEN, of Missouri, moved to change the boundary of that Territory, and then submit the Lecompton Constitution to a vote of the people.
The steamship Prince Albert arrived at the Bay of Briton at 5 o'clock on the morning of the 5th inst. She brings Galway dates of the 23d of May, and Liverpool dates, by telegraph, of the 25th of May.

In the northeast corner of the Park, overtopped by surrounding buildings, stands a modest edifice, the second story of which is reached by stairs on the outside in the manner of tenement bouses for one of which it might be mistaken, but for the close resemblance its exterior bears to the well-appointed stable of a brown-stone house.

The comparative indifference recently displayed by the public to the "big ship," since her arrival here, is likely, as the time for her departure for NewYork approaches, soon to give place to something like the interest felt in her fortunes last year. The result of her first trip across the Atlantic and back will be something like a test of the correctness of the calculations of her designers.

On Wednesday morning play was resumed, with the St. George still at the bat. The weather was fine for Cricket, and everything was favorable for good play, the ground not being so dead as on the previous day.

The Senate has received to-day from the Secretary of War some interesting statistics of sickness and mortality in the United States army for the past five years, which was ordered to be printed for circulation. They will form a good-sized volume.

The ratification meeting advertised to come off at the Old Court House in White Plains yesterday, owing to some defect in the manner of giving the notice, was not large. Few persons, even in the village, had heard of the meeting.
The Keeper of the House of Detention for witnesses has made a return to the Board of Supervisors of the number of persons detained therein, and the length of time their imprisonment has lasted.

The Board of Education, last evening, received a resolution from the school officers of the Twelfth Ward, asking for an appropriation of $4,800, to purchase lots in Ninety-ninth-street, near Tenth avenue, for a new school site. The resolution was referred to the Committee on Sites and School-houses. A resolution from the same source, asking for an appropriation of $4,355 for carpenters' and masons' work for School-house No. 46, was referred to the Committee on Finance.

On the evening of Wednesday, the 23d ult., a meeting was held at Memphis, Tenn., to sustain those who seceded from the Charleston Convention. Letters were read from Hon. JACOB THOMPSON, Secretary of the Interior, and Hon. W.L. YANCEY.

In the Senate yesterday the Houmas Land bill was read a third time and passed. The Army Appropriation bill was taken up, but no action was had thereon before adjournment. In the House the consideration of the Missouri Contested Election case was resumed, but no action was taken on the subject.
The regular weekly meeting of the Board took place yesterday afternoon at Castle Garden President VERPLANCK in the Chair.

The schooner Spring Hill, one hundred tons burden, at this port, has been purchased for the Arctic Expedition of Dr. HAYES, and will be fitted out forthwith. The necessary funds have been subscribed in Philadelphia, New-York and Boston.

A stringent bill has passed the Legislature of Rhode Island to prevent the importation of cattle from Massachusetts during the pendency of the cattle disease, Gov. HALL, of Vermont, is visiting the infected district in this State, for an investigation of the cattle disease.

The Quarantine Commissioners met at noon yesterday at No. 42 Wall-street, pursuant to adjournment of the previous day, Mr. LEAVENWORTH, the Chairman, presiding. A meeting was held yesterday at the City Hotel, Elizabeth, N.J., which was principally attended by farmers of the vicinity interested in the Cattle epidemic, which, commencing in Massachusetts, has spread through several Eastern States, and has now reached our neighbors across the North River.

If the Committees of the Common Council of New-York City were invested with a jurisdiction to examine and decide all claims that should be made against its Treasury, on the showing and the testimony of the parties, produced in writing, not exposed to the sifting of a cross-examination nor the analysis of an opposing counsel, we apprehend that the City would be even more extensively robbed and plundered than it is at present.

THE QUESTION OF ADJOURNMENT. The House resolution for adjournment on the 18th was adopted in the Senate today by Democratic votes, only two Republicans voting for it. The impression is that it will be again rescinded, as the business cannot be disposed of. If this is not done the President will immediately call an extra session. REPORT OF THE APPROPRIATION BILLS REFUSED.

The reported receipts of the principal kinds of produce since our last have been; 107 bbls. Ashes, 17,863 bbls. Flour, 512 bbls. Corn-meal, 20,858 bushels Wheat, 94,176 bushels Corn, 720 bushels Rye, 18,463 bushels Oats, 589 pkgs. Provisions, and 728 bbls, Whisky.

Rarely has the New-York Yacht Club enjoyed a more exciting regatta than their sixteenth contest yesterday, for the unpropitious forebodings of the morning tended rather to heighten the pleasure. From an almost dead calm and drizzling rain, the day emerged into fresh breezes and clear sunshine, and all agreed that the occasion has seldon, if ever, been equaled.

We are suddenly plunged into another Indian war. The savages have risen in the Carson Valley; the whole region form Walker's Lake to Pyramid Lake is said to be alive with them. They have daubed on the full war-paint, and taken their women and children to Regtown, on the Carson River, a little west of where it sinks into Carson Lake.
The Japanese Embassy left Washington this morning, at 8 o'clock, in a special train for Baltimore. No escort attended them, nor was there any display.
Joseph M. Dake and H. Fincke vs. David Radley. This action was brought to recover the purchase money for a quantity of eggs delivered at this port, and shipped from Chicago.

Hon. J.L. SCHOOLCRAFT died at 12 o'clock last night. The intelligence has cast an unusual gloom over this city, where his many good qualities as a citizen and virtues as a man endeared him to all classes.

Johnson vs. Johnson. This is the suit brought by a wife against her husband for a divorce on the ground of cruel and inhuman treatment, as mentioned in yesterday's TIMES. The case is on trial before Justice WOODRUFF of the Superior Court.

The United States Mail steamer Arago, Capt. LINES, arrived at this port last evening, having left Havre on the 29th, and Southampton on the 30th of May. Her intelligence is of the same date as that published in the TIMES of yesterday, received by telegraph from the North Briton, at Fathar Point. She brings us papers and correspondence two days later than had previously reached us.

The arrival of the Arago puts us in possession of our European mails two days later than had been previously received, although the news is of the same date as that published yesterday by telegraph from Father Point.

JERSEY CITY YACHT CLUB.--This fine Club have their yachting harbor on the bay which makes in at the southwesterly point of Jersey City. Two years ago the Club built a fine two-story Club-house, and sunk a number of canal boats to the south and west of it.

The great point of interest concerning the Japanese Embassy to-day, has been the reception of the news, per Pony Express, announcing the alleged assasination of the Tycoon. Considerable doubt as to the authenticity of the dispatch has been evinced by the officers of the Naval Commission, and others, but as to what the Prince Ambassadors think on the subject it is difficult to say.

GARIBALDI'S troops are six miles distant from Palermo, and occupy the heights surrounding it. An engagement has taken place, but without a definite result. The insurgents have maintained their positions, and the royal troops have reentered Palermo. Several Neapolitan vessels of war have arrived before Palermo, and a bombardment was feared, should a rising take place in the city.
Mr. KENNEDY, of Maryland, (Am.,) presented the credentials of Mr. PEARCE as Senator from Maryland from the 4th of March next.

Recorder BARNARD disposed of several cases yesterday. The first was that of Stephen Chase, alias Chapin, who pleaded guilty to a charge of perjury. On April 21, James Burns was arrested for arson, and held to bail i n the sum of $1,000 by Justice Quackenoush.

The Tribune, with a promptness which does credit to its benevolence, solves our doubts on the subject of rail-splitting as a qualification for the Presidency. Dispatches have been received from Palermo by the Sardinian Government, which fully confirm not only the victory obtained by GARIBALDI at Calatafimi over the 4,000 Neapolitans led by LANZA, but the more important one, which placed the heights surrounding Palermo in the hands of the Sicilian patriots. Between 3 and 4 o'clock this morning flames were discovered issuing from the fourth floor of the building No. 11 Cedar-street, occupied by TIMOTHY O'LEARY, dealer in rag and paper stock. A damage of about $500 was done by fire and water, covered by an insurance of $1,000 in the New-York and Maline Insurance Company.

At the meeting of the Board of Aldermen last evening, a resolution was adopted to the effect that as the Police have notified milk-vendors to cease the sale of milk on Sundays, therefore be it resolved, that the milk-vendores be allowed to continue the sale of milk as heretofore.

The festival in aid of the fund of the Steuben Monument Association, which occurred yesterday at Elm Park, drew together some fifteen hundred persons, a number which would have been considerably increased but for the fact that similar festivities were going on at the same time at Yorkville.

The very late advices direct from the City of Mexico, which appeared exclusively in the TIMES of yesterday morning, are highly interesting and suggestive, especially that portion relating to the failure of JECKER Co. It will also be perceived that our correspondent, who dates from the City of Mexico the 29th ult., places no confidence in the reported defeat and capture of URAGA by WOLL, at Guadalajara.

The course of exchange at New-York on London for bills at 60 days' sight is 109 5/8@169 per cent., which, when compared with the Mint par between the two countries, shows that the exchange is slightly in favor of England; but, after making allowance for charges of transport and difference of interest, the present rate leaves scarcely any profit on the importation of gold from the United States.

We have received various telegrams from Naples and other planes, headed "Official." They all announce the defeat and retreat of GARIBALDI. The following is the latest intelligence which we have received from an authentic source:

The detailed account which has now reached us from California of the reported assassination of the Tycoon of Japan, spares the life of that Prince himself, and contents itself with slaughtering the head of his Government. The difference is material, not only to the Tycoon but to the rest of the world, for it is the Japanese Lord Palmerston, and not his nominal sovereign, who has been put of the way.

Bavaria was one of the latest States in Germany to feel the impulse of that revival of Classical education of which this century has been the witness. England had produced some of her greatest critical scholars, the Universities of Prussia and the Rhine were already celebrated for their Philologic Departments, when Bavaria yet labored under an inadequate school system and a total want of thorough classical instruction.

ST. PAULDE LOANDO, West Coast of Africa. Twice have I, in my journeyings around the borders of this darkened land, come upon LIVINGSTONE'S footprints. At one of his starting points, Cape Town, I had heard his praises sounded by his friends; and here, again, on the west Coast of Africa his other starting point I find his name great among the heathen, both white and black.

Lord BROUGHAM was installed as Chancellor of the University of Edinburgh on the 18th ult., in presence of an immense audience, comprising a large number of distinguished persons. The Democrats renew their attempt to nominate a Presidential candidate to-day, at Baltimore. Everything at present indicates a stormy session. The case of Judge WATROUS is one which must excite in a special manner the honest indignation of Messrs. BUCHANAN and TOUCEY. To the Editor of the New-York Times: I notice in your paper of yesterday an article stating that the grave of PIERRE DAILLIE, the minister of the old French Church, established at Boston by French Protestant refugees, has just been discovered in the Granary burial ground there. Another memorial of the man and olden times may not be uninteresting to your readers.

The requisite points of etiquette having been settled; the Japanese Embassy, yesterday, in company with the Naval Commission and the Common Council Committee, called upon the Mayor and Gov. MORGAN, at the City Hall.

The Board of Aldermen had their regular meeting yesterday, but in view of the fact that the Japanese were waiting for the Committee, or the Committee for the Japanese, the meeting was not remarkably harmonious.

The Committee immediately retired to deliberate, taking the printed reports with them, and during their absence Hon. R. D. ARNOLD, of Georgia, made a verbal report on the subject of small-pox and vaccination, to the effect that he had investigated the matter as far as the city of Savannah ways concerned, and he had arrived at the conclusion that this disease was not infectious. His report was accepted.

By special Arms orders (number seventy-six) it is directed that the three companies of Second Dragoons at Camp Floyd, B, E, and H, march for Lander's Road, in the southern part of Oregon, with the view of affording protection to emigrants against marauders and Indians, and of chastising depredators, during Summer and Autumn. Assistant-Surgeon BREWER is assigned to this command.

Senator MASON has just wound up the Harper's Ferry affair by presenting a majority report which reveals nothing, and by getting himself discharged from the manufacture of a bill to protect States from invasion. THADDEUS HYATT has also, at last, been released from his dungeon, and the country has thus been delivered from the horrors of civil war, with which Dr. CHEEVER threatened it.

The Homestead conferees met this morning for the twelfth time, and to the surprise of both branches of Congress finally agreed on a report. By this compromise all the land subject to private entry is to be open for homesteads at twenty-five cents per acre;

Among our foreign extracts this morning will be found an interesting letter from St. Petersburg which we have translated from the Independance Belge, concerning the emancipation of the Russian serfs.

The People and Taylor vs. The Mayor, This case again came up for argument on the motion to set aside the judgment Judge Edmonds moved for a postponement until Wednesday week, on the ground of the absence of associate counsel at the Court of Appeals. Besides their affidavits were in the hands of the printer.

GARIBALDI has gratified and almost outstripped public impatience. The preparation, the departure, the landing, the quick succession of decisive battles, and the surrender of the Royal army have followed each other almost as rapidly as telegraphs could tell them.

The twenty-seventh anniversary of the formation of the City Guard was celebrated yesterday by an excursion to Long Branch, and a dinner at the National Hotel. It being the occasion of the opening of the Raritan and Delaware Bay Railroad, to Long Branch, the City Guard accepted the invitation of the Railroad Company to pass over their road and join in the opening celebration at the same time that they celebrated their own anniversary.
Steamship De Soto, JAS. D. BULLOCH, Commander, arrived yesterday morning from New Orleans, via Havana, with moderate freight, and a large passenger list to LIVINGSTON, CROCHERON Co.

The Evening Post is inclined to believe that our Common Councilmen intend to swindle the City. It suspects such a design from certain movements on their part. It seems they have passed a resolution asking the Corporation Counsel, in substance, whether they have not a right to violate the Charter whenever they can make something handsome by it. They desire to re-pave Broadway, but not by contract.

Congress has pushed through its business today, and had the House not refused to consider the Loan Bill the adjournment would take place to-morrow. As the Committee on Ways and Means refused to report the Loan Bill the rules had to be suspended by a two-thirds vote to allow it to be considered. The vote was 100 to 65, not two-thirds. It will be again tried to-morrow.

George Deshon vs. Mary C. Packwood and the Merchants' Bank. This was an action upon a check for $2,000, drawn by Samuel Packwood, deceased, husband of the first-named defendant, in favor of the plaintiff a relative to whom deceased was partial. The deceased, shortly before his death, transferred his bank account to his wife, that she might draw money for household purposes; but subsequently gave the check in suit to plaintiff.
The steamship United Kingdom, from Glasgow 9th inst., passed this point at 8 A.M., to-day, bound to Quebec. Her news is three days later than has been received.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: We wish to deny emphatically, over our own names, a statement injurious to us contained in a paragraph in your paper of this morning, headed "Chief Engineer's Department." Your reporter has been misinformed by the Chief Engineer in nearly every particular.

The second day's races of the Spring Meeting on the above course took place yesterday. The morning was sufficiently beautiful to tampt crowds of people to the Course, but as the time for the race approached, ominous clouds began to appear, which admonished the more cautious that they might expect a repetition of the showers of the previous day.

One peril and one pain, at least, our Japanese visitors have scarcely undergone in their visit to America, which would have figured in the front rank of their distresses had they gratified the self-complacency of our British cousins by recognizing England as Queen of the Seas. The peril of being hunted, and the pain of being shown up as social lions, are penalties which all distinguished foreigners in London must pay for their distinction.
The Commissioners of Emigration held their weekly meeting yesterday present, Messrs. HUNT, PURDY, CARRIGAN, CURTIS and JELLINGHAUS; the President, Mr. VEEPLANCK, in the chair.
To the Editor of the New-York Times: In your paper of the 18th inst., with the reported proceedings, occurs the following, in reference to the Committee on State Medicine, viz.:

A NARROW ESCAPE A CHURCH STRUCK BY LIGHTNING SEVERAL PERSONS IRJURED. During a violent thunder storm which passed over Bloomfield, New-Jersey, on Tuesday evening, between 7 and 8 o'clock, the Methodist Church, where a strawberry festival was in progress, was struck by lightning. Happily the rain had made the attendance at the festival thin, so that there were but about one hundred and fifty persons in the building at the time.

BALTIMORE, Thursday Evening. The Convention has accomplished nothing practical to-day. The reports of the Committee on Cre dentials are in, and serve to draw a line of demarcation between the respective factions. But there is too much bad blood among the delegates to permit business to be done, and an adjournment until tomorrow was carried mainly because it seemed impossible to do anything else.

The amount estimated by the Secretary of the Treasury for the service of the next fiscal year was $46,270,000, and the additional estimates by the other Departments, $18,223,582; total, $64,502,476. The committee of Ways and Means reduced the total estimates $1,230,000.

The Paris Presse gives the following extract from its private correspondence, concerning the political disturbance in Japan. The Editor attributes he deplorable reaction which has taken place in the mind and Government of the Japanese towards foreigners to the treacherous conduct of European traders. The following is the extract:

The English papers state that the reply of the Chinese Government to their ultimatum has not been received. We find that important document, however, in the Moniteur, of Paris, and transiate it as follows:

Advices of June 9, from Denver City, to which credits given, state that Mr. FOWLER, the defaulting New-York Postmaster, whose whereabouts has been so long unknown, and about whom so much cariesity has been felt, is reported to have been identified at Pike's Peak. The main features of the statement are as follows: The Pike's Peak Express arrived at 6 o'clock this evening, bringing $8,900 in specie and Denver City dates to June 14.

The police of Newark telegraphed, last evening, that they had arrested John Stewart, the young scoundrel who robbed a poor blind Indian on the Erie Railroad train, a few days since, of about $75 worth of fancy articles which he was bringing to this City for sale.
The schooner Star; Capt. GANMON, arrived at this port this morning, direct from Vera Cruz, with dates to the 9th inst., one week later.
